webTitle: The best of this month's cyber cinema

fields.headline: The best of this month's cyber cinema
fields.standfirst: Burning rubber and a wannabe Bond, Hitchcock hip hop, or get inside the mind of Puff Daddy and the NYPD... Kate Stables picks her top ten essential viewing for May
fields.trailText: Burning rubber and a wannabe Bond, Hitchcock hip hop, or get inside the mind of Puff Daddy and the NYPD... Kate Stables picks her top ten essential viewing for May
fields.body:
Ambush: The Hire
(www.bmwfilms.com)
Let's say that you're a big corporation, looking to get beyond oh-so-20th-century marketing concepts like ads, sponsorship and product placement. Fortunately, you manufacture aspirational, photogenic motors which are just ripe for starring in their own series of glossy internet mini-thrillers, helmed by big-name directors like Ang Lee and Guy Ritchie. To kick off you'll need fast cars, screaming tyres, and a cryptic hero behind the wheel. Sounds like a job for John "Ronin" Frankenheimer, the man who is to the car chase what Cezanne was to a bowl of fruit. Based on the small section this glitch-prone site allowed me to view, the old master opens up the throttle nicely enough with a high-octane attempted kidnapping on an LA freeway, despite rubber-burning action sequences squeezed into a two-inch window. Clive Owen, in Bond-wannabe mode as The Driver, tries not to let a BMW740i act him off the screen, uphill work in a film showcasing "this thrilling performance vehicle". Buckle up and you'll come away humming the gear changes.
 View the film

Hitchcock Hip-Hop (pictured)
(www.robertosmith.com)
A cut-out Hitchcock croons to Tippi Hedren: "Why do birds suddenly appear / Every time I strike fear" in this funky animated homage to The Fat Man. Creator Robert O. Smith lets a dancing stream of Hitchcockian symbols loose across the screen, rendered as crude collages of Matisse-style figures and cut-outs. Ringmaster Hitch drives them along to a hit-and-miss rap of tumbling film titles ('Dancin's no sin, bro / There's Jimmy Stewart in Rear Window'). Cineastes will waste at least five minutes trying to acquire this jolly, primary-coloured loop as a screensaver - for the moment, it stays firmly stuck to the site.
 View the film

We Deliver: Handsome Eddie Becomes a Model, Episode 1
(www.sputnik7.com)
The astonishingly realistic retail website which accompanies this "mockumentary" series about a New York pot-delivery service, led some net innocents to assume that they could order door-to door doobies from the boys at Green Acres. Nope, what you'll get here is superior slices of drama looking at the risky lives'n' loves of GA's young employees - a kind of "As Spliff". Keep your eye out for Mo, the cynical owner cum despatcher ("Let's be careful out there"), and several stand-offs in this first episode which show up the modish "Sopranos" toughness that pervades the show. A slangy, confident vibe puts this streets ahead of similar webisodics, even if the bong'n'weed screensavers on offer are too Cheech and Chong for comfort.
 View the film

The Exterminator
(www.warnerbros.com)
Can anyone remember a time when Gary Busey wasn't playing blue-collar psychotics? It's another outing for the overalls and terrifying chuckle in this Warner Bros black comedy about an exterminator faced with a plague of rats whose "diseased little frames are always plotting and planning". Theresa Russell stars opposite him as the helpless householder, in another outing for her dressing gown and blank stare acting mode. There's a twist, of course, reminiscent of Roald Dahl's Tales of the Totally Anticipated, but it's not half bad. Save this all-pro product for a day when you can't face another "highly recommended" film-school short shot in Wobblyvision.
 View the film

Golden Boy
(www.thebitscreen.com)
Follow the bouncing golden baby to find your way through Bill Callahan's beatifically eerie Flash animation recording the rapturous crowds-and-billboards reception given to a holy child with healing powers, when it appears on briefly on earth. His stylised sequences melt into one another like soap bubbles, and combine with an incongruously catchy soundtrack to make a strangely beautiful whole. So delicious, you'll want to spread it on toast and eat it.
 View the film

Yoorinal
(www.britshorts.com)
In case Britshorts aren't kidding about the Limited Time Only tag attached to this mildly outrageous and very funny British mens-room comedy, get over and see it now. Paul Kay, almost unrecognisable from his Dennis Pennis persona, is our cheeky cockney tour guide on an ammonia-reeking anthropological trip round the last bastion of male privacy. Apparently "Going to the urinal is like an SAS raid. You go in, do the job, and get out PRONTO. Go, go, go !". Jibes at Mr Conceited, Mr Reluctant, and Mr No-Aim are sharp, if a tad predictable, but make sure you see the wonderful final fantasy sequence graphically illustrating Nicholson Baker's cure for a shy bladder - namely, "Imagine that you are urinating on the head of the man next to you".
 View the film

The Center of The World
(www.center-of-the-world.com)
State of the art AI (artificial intelligence) makes this virtual stripclub, in which you can solicit one-on-one chatroom and webcam conversation from a synthetic version of US porn star Alisha Klass, feel uncannily real. It's all actually a marketing device for the unrated Wayne Wang erotic romance of the same name, a movie ironically far less interesting than this cunning honey-trap of a site. Click through the stripclub to the dressing rooms, and you find yourself caught up in a personalised tits-and-arse interactive mini-drama with the capricious Virtual Alisha, whose attention is harder to hold than a handful of mercury. It's either an intriguing 21st century version of those fairytales in which the princess's challenge must be taken up, or a wired wankfest - depending on your point of view.
 View the film

Being Puff Daddy
(www.urbanentertainment.com)
For anyone who's ever wondered just what went on between P. Daddy and the NYPD, Urban Entertainment's witty interactive animation provides the answers. Experience police interrogation at its finest, through the eyes of the man himself, and then click on the correct answer you've chosen for him. "Do you prefer the Colonel's fried chicken Original or Extra Crispy?" - "That's easy, I don't like *anything* original." When they get to the question (yes, really) about doing it doggy-style with Martha Stewart, get the right answer or it'll be Sing-Sing, rather than bling-bling, baby.
 View the film

fields.headline: Future Pilot AKA
fields.standfirst:
The Attic, Edinburgh
****
fields.trailText:
The Attic, Edinburgh
****
fields.body:
Can any man have such cool nerves as Sushil K Dade? For one thing, he makes a living as a driving instructor on the mean streets of his native Glasgow. For another, he somehow manages to remain composed while at the helm of Future Pilot AKA, a band who give new meaning to the term "organised chaos".

The anarchic nature of this set should come as no surprise to anyone familiar with Dade's working practices. During the sessions for Future Pilot's latest album, Tiny Waves, Mighty Sea, he acted as "musical director" as up to 15 musicians at once played around with his ideas. Somehow the result was a million miles from the frenzy of ego-flexing one would expect from such a set-up; indeed, the instrumentation could hardly have been more subtle or restrained.

Dade seems equally laid-back about live performances. Band members aren't just encouraged to improvise: they often have little choice. Guest singer Eugene Kelly is instructed to perform one song "a cappella, like Destiny's Child". Likewise, keyboard player Bill Wells has to play unaccompanied. "I want to see what this man's made of," says Dade.

But then Future Pilot AKA can afford to have fun with their sound: a live act as effective as this carries the confidence required to play around a little. When the crowd is carried away by the infectious groove of new single, Beat of a Drum, you sense the band is feeding off the audience's enthusiasm. What's more, performing live seems to add a new dimension to the Future Pilot sound. Tonight the pastoral lilt of Maid of the Loch seems a hundred times more elegant than on record.

Perhaps, though, it is Dade's down-to-earth approach that keeps the mood so buoyant. Throughout the evening he keeps up a steady stream of irreverent banter, gradually thawing the aloof Edinburgh crowd. "Bloody hell, I thought I was in New Orleans there," he says after a clarinet break. "The boy's good, really," we are reassured after the DJ fluffs a song intro. By the time Dade starts scat-singing "Mad cow! Foot and mouth!" there's barely a straight face in the room.

This steadfast refusal to take themselves seriously is what distinguishes Future Pilot AKA from most of their experimentalist peers. And, judging by the yells of approval from the audience, Dade's simple, almost childlike, enthusiasm for music seems to be rubbing off.

fields.headline: Creatures of habit
fields.standfirst: Have you scrawled your name on your stapler and labelled your mug? Would you humiliate anyone who pinched your mousemat? If so, you're not alone.  Dolly Dhingra  on why workers are so possessive
fields.trailText: Have you scrawled your name on your stapler and labelled your mug? Would you humiliate anyone who pinched your mousemat? If so, you're not alone. Dolly Dhingra on why workers are so possessive.
fields.body:
Are you one of those people who would hyperventilate if your office chair went missing? Would you hunt down and publicly humiliate the culprit who failed to return your stapler to the right drawer? Or perhaps you avoid the cracks in the pavement on your walk to work. Don't worry, you are not alone. A study by recruitment consultants Office Angels has revealed that there are a lot of you about. British office workers, it seems, are creatures of habit who seek comfort in daily rituals in the workplace.

The survey of 1,500 office employees and employers found that 49% of workers always use the same toilet cubicle at work, even if it means waiting for it to become vacant. Thirty-eight per cent will drink only out of their favourite mug.

A staggering 74% paint their name on office belongings such as rulers and staplers as a way of marking their territory. Not in blood thankfully, just in Tipp-Ex, in capital letters, with exclamation marks to imply they are only joking about their possessive tendencies, when we all know they're deadly serious.

So why do they do it? "People tend to impose these workplace rituals on themselves as a way of gaining control over situations, or to help them feel more 'at home' and able to cope with daily stresses and strains," says Paul Jacobs, director of corporate communication at Office Angels. More than three-quarters of the respondents said that these rituals had a positive impact on their morale. Without their habits, presumably, they would all be gibbering wrecks.

One of the biggest problems with rituals is that people often forget they are performing them - such is the nature of habit. A good idea would be to make a log of your idiosyncracies and then make every effort to alter some of them. Check if your habits match any of those revealed by the survey. Sixty-nine per cent of interviewees admitted that they stand in the same place on the platform each morning on their way to work and find themselves making a dash for the same seat on the train. (Oh dear.) Fifty-six per cent admit they typically check where their name is in the pecking order on an email or memo address. (Low self-esteem no doubt.) Seventy-four per cent reward themselves for completing their least favourite tasks. (There's nothing like an incentive to get the job done.)

"Thinking about it I've realised that I always buy a cup of tea on the way to work. I have a routine of putting my handbag under my table, hanging my coat up, draping my scarf over the back of my chair, just in case I get cold in the day. Oh, and I always have to have a packet of crisps, an apple, some sugar and some serviettes stashed in my draw. If I don't have a store of food I get a bit twitchy," confesses one office worker.

Jacobs claims that the force of habit is so ingrained in people that given extra freedom some office workers become nervous and anxious. Dress down Fridays, when certain companies relax the dress code at work, causes all sorts of problems. "Workers become very self-conscious about what they should and shouldn't wear. For most, wearing a suit is the easiest and safest option," says Jacobs. British workers it would seem really do need to chill out and get themselves a life.

Stephen Bevan, associate director of the Institute for Employment Studies, says: "More and more people are expected to use their time efficiently at work. As a result, they derive comfort from habit. It helps them collect their thoughts. It sets them up for the day. With so much change and uncertainty in the workplace, many workers use routine as the backbone of the day. It's something they can anchor onto - a way of staking out a patch of territory to help them feel secure."

Bevan also points out that rituals are more important to certain personalities than others. Some people, he says, feel they are in control of their destiny and are likely to push for their own career development. "They tend to have little time for superstition or ritual - they feel they determine their own fate. They are the types who roll with the punches and are most likely to leave a job if they are dissatisfied."

Then there are the ones who cling to ritual. "They believe that things are outside their control. They plod on at work in the hope that their employer will reward them when necessary, but they are not going to scream and shout for it. They tend to be the ones who seek comfort in small things," says Bevan.

Rituals are one thing, but superstition is quite another. Working with people who are superstitious means, in essence, that you are sharing an office with people who are irrational. Twenty-four per cent of respondents believed that they would be plagued by bad luck without their rituals and 46% felt that their moods would be dampened, or their concentration severely affected if they did not carry out their routines. Alarming stuff.

"Rituals are a psychological comfort blanket - humans like stability. With longer working hours and increased workloads, the animal part of us craves some personal territory. Although I understand it, I don't think it should be encouraged," says Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology and health at University of Manchester's Institute of Science and Technology.

Cooper argues that if a healthy work/life balance is to be achieved by the British workforce, workers need to be more flexible. "We need more people willing to take on change rather than have everyone driving on the M25 to work everyday. We need parents to be able to work from home. Two out of three families are working families with both adults working - things are not healthy for those who want to spend time with their children. The last thing you want is people to be getting tied up in petty rituals in the office."

Paul Jacobs also offers a warning. "We should all make sure we do not become too preoccupied by routine. This will ensure our habits do not turn from being productive to time-wasting distractions."

fields.headline: Back from the break
fields.standfirst: More people are now taking extended time off work. But how easy is it to return, asks  Sarah Ebner
fields.trailText: More people are now taking extended time off work. But how easy is it to return, asks Sarah Ebner.
fields.body:
After nine years of staying at home and bringing up four sons, Susan Chamberlain went out and bought a computer. Her purchase didn't just help her back to work - it led to the formation of her own business.

"I'd been a secretary for years," she says. "I'd done PA jobs, reception and audio work. I didn't think I'd ever be my own boss, but times change."

In fact, during Chamberlain's career break, time changed things so much that she could barely recognise the technology on her return. When she left her last job, she was still using a typewriter. "There was just one computer in the office," she says. "I remember going to look at it, marvelling at the mouse and wondering if I would ever have to use one."

She did, of course. In her time away, the computer became a necessity and, once Chamberlain had refreshed herself, she asked around to see if anyone needed any secretarial duties dealt with. They did, and she has now established a business working from home.

As daunting as making a comeback sounds, it is becoming increasingly common. Children, stress, early retirement or simply a desire for a long, leisurely break often takes a chunk out of the career path. It may be a long, windy road back but, as secretarial agencies are increasingly ready to testify, it's never too late to start again.

"If you gave up work some years ago and have now decided to return, you'll find that the way we're working is very different," says Amanda Bedford, from the Institute of Qualified Private Secretaries. "What you'll notice most is how skills have changed. The technological demands are huge."

Every office now has computers, email is more common than faxes and, in the past year or two, the internet has taken off immeasurably, particularly as a reference tool.

The secretarial role has changed. "Many top PAs don't sit and type any more. They go to meetings and join in projects. The job has become more responsible and pro-active. They'll be booking conferences on the net, sending emails, juggling different skills. I would recommend any returner to go on a course to update skills and to try not to be scared by how fast-moving the office environment has become."

Karen Dorling was a PA in a bank for 11 years before leaving to bring up her son."I was very worried about going back to work," she says. "I had lost confidence by being away so long and found that it wasn't at all how I remembered. You could achieve something so much more quickly than you could before."

After six months of temping, Karen, from Stanford-le-Hope in Essex, took a permanent job, as PA to Sandra Hitching, director of human resources for Kelly Services. She says she was encouraged by Hitching's attitude to her. "What was difficult about returning to work was rebuilding my confidence," she says. "Suddenly I was working and I was a mother - a situation I hadn't experienced before - and I discovered that some people didn't appreciate it. They felt I didn't have the ability to be a good PA because I was a mother, but Sandra never questioned my devotion to the job."

Hitching says that juggling home and family gives someone organisational and multi-tasking attributes that can be transferred to the workplace. "Not everyone thinks that, because some people are blinkered," she says. "They won't look at someone if they're below or above a certain age and they worry about people being rusty if they've been away a long time. But basic competencies aren't eroded by time. You have to come back, acquire the technical skills and market yourself the right way."

"I gave up my job to join my fiance in Poland," says Rachael. "It was quite daunting at first as I chose to do something completely unlike anything I'd ever done, but it was fantastic to do something so different."

She says she would recommend travelling to anyone, but admits that when she returned to the UK she found it difficult to get back into an office routine. fields.headline: Liberty to defend census dodgers
fields.trailText: Liberty, the human rights group, yesterday promised to defend anyone prosecuted for either failing to return their census forms or refusing to denote their ethnicity on the nationwide survey.
fields.body:
Liberty, the human rights group, yesterday promised to defend anyone prosecuted for either failing to return their census forms or refusing to denote their ethnicity on the nationwide survey.

John Wadham, Liberty's director, said: "There is a clear public interest in people filling in their forms, but we don't think it should be a criminal offence to fail to do so, and we are particularly concerned that it is an offence not to answer the question on race."

He said a legal defence would be based on article eight of the human rights convention covering the right to privacy.

By yesterday, national census day, thousands of people had still not received their form. During the past 10 days when all 24m households should have received their forms about 1m people called the 1,000 helplines - increased by 500 lines at the Manchester call centre on Friday - to complain they were being left out.

With the threat of a £1,000 fine for those not sending back their forms, the office for national statistics (ONS) conceded yesterday that it would have to extend the return deadline beyond the end of May. "People shouldn't be concerned that they are going to be prosecuted," a spokesman for the ONS said yesterday.

Graham Jones, the census director, suggested the numbers of callers showed that the publicity campaign had struck a civic chord. "We were victims of our own success," he said. "I do not believe that a lot people are not going to be filling it in. I believe we are actually going to get a very good response rate to this particular census." After the last census, in 1991, 342 people were prosecuted.

The question on race - and the omission of "English" as a category - is one of a number that have caused controversy. But the ONS said people can record their ethnicity in their own words.

New questions this year include one on general health, when unemployed people last worked, and a query on religion with answers being voluntary. In answer to fears about the answers not remaining confidential, the ONS said the personal data would be closed for 100 years. Anyone passing it on to another government department or private organisation would be committing an offence.

Yesterday Len Cook, the registrar general for England and Wales, appealed to parents not to forget the inclusion of newborn babies. At the last census, a large number of babies were omitted from the population count, either because they were still in hospital on census day or because as very recent arrivals their parents forgot to include them.

Babies born before April 30 should be included on their parents' form even if they are still in hospital.

"The census is a platform for the future, and if babies are left out that can affect planning for services such as schools and hospitals," Mr Cook said. "It's important that no one is missed."

The entire exercise is costing £200m. The ONS explained on its website that this amount of money was the equivalent of everybody eating a Mars Bar a year for 10 years.

Any householder who has not received a form can request one by phoning 0845 301 3000. The main helpline is 0845 301 2001.

fields.headline: Saving for a rainy day
fields.trailText: Any sensible approach to managing your finances should include keeping £1,000 in an easy access savings account for emergencies.
fields.body:
Any sensible approach to managing your finances should include keeping £1,000 in an easy access savings account for emergencies.

Look for a savings account with a high rate of interest and the right withdrawal conditions. You are highly unlikely to get more than 7% on instant access accounts; currently rates of 5% to 6% are the norm, with internet and telephone banking accounts usually offering the best.

Accounts which require you to give notice of withdrawal do not offer much better rates. The best deals will offer around 7% or 7.5%, but you may have to agree to a six-month notice period. Waiting six months for your cash is no good for an emergency fund so only consider these accounts if youre sure you can wait the required period.

Its also important to check the rate you are offered wont go down after a few months and some finance companies often good rates when they launch products, but then lower them after a few months.

fields.headline: Songs from the African desert
fields.standfirst:
Baaba Maal
Queen's Hall, Edinburgh
****
fields.trailText:
Baaba Maal
Queen's Hall, Edinburgh
****
fields.body:
"Epic but simple" is how producer John Leckie describes Mi Yeewnii (Missing You), Baaba Maal's new acoustic album recorded largely in Senegal. The same back-to-basics approach applies to the record's promotional tour: a series of gigs in intimate venues, heavy on atmosphere, acoustic guitars and Maal's astonishing voice.

You can hear the cultural and autobiographical traces that feed into his voice as it soars, plaintive and powerful in turn, across a small room - African and Arabic influences, and the fact that Maal grew up on the edge of the desert. It's a voice made for such vast open spaces; in a smaller, formal interior like the Queen's Hall, it reaches out and envelops us all in its swoops and arcs of sound.

Like Youssou N'Dour, a similarly blessed vocalist, Maal has tried musical collaboration with western artists (such as Howie B and Brian Eno on the last album) and has gone for a sound big enough - cue electric guitars, strings, big bands and troupes of backing singers - to match that voice.

Now, though, the voice is the thing, with traditional, evocative backing from a five-piece band. The atmosphere moves from stirring chants as the gig begins in almost sombre mood with Malalo to up-beat rhythms that quickly get Maal's hardcore fans and good friends in the audience dancing. Wild, galloping percussive sections combine with irresistible melodies on tracks such as Miyaabele to get just about everyone else on their feet. The small venue amplifies the party feel just as it does the scale of the sound: Maal jumps down into the dancing crowd and people return the compliment, popping up on stage for a few moments of passionate boogie.

The only thing missing on the night was any sense of the stories or emotions behind the songs. Maal may have a huge voice, but he keeps quiet between songs, save the occasional "merci beaucoup". With the vocals starring, and tracks on the new album covering everything from love to loss and the changing role of African women, a few introductory words for some numbers might have added something to the live show. But, during the two encore numbers, Koni and Thieolo, the Queen's Hall is one big party that doesn't want to end. The music and Maal's extraordinary voice are doing the talking.

 Baaba Maal plays The Lemon Tree, Aberdeen (01224 642230) tonight, then continues touring.

fields.headline: LPO/Perlman
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
When instrumentalists turn to conducting, the results can be unpredictable. Itzhak Perlman took up the baton two years ago, joining the ranks of such illustrious musicians as Daniel Barenboim, Christoph Eschenbach and Vladimir Ashkenazy, all of whom managed the transition with varying degrees of success and, in the case of Eschenbach, considerable controversy. Time alone will tell whether Perlman's conducting career will supersede his playing. I sincerely hope it won't, though there's little doubt that he's mightily impressive on the podium, combining beauty with idiosyncrasy in ways that are often thrillingly innovative.

He began his London Philharmonic Orchestra concert at a kind of halfway stage, playing and directing Beethoven's violin Romances from the leader's chair. The pieces themselves, widely believed to be abandoned sections of projected concertos, are graciously slight and mysteriously obscure. The first is excessively repetitive, which Perlman couldn't disguise, although he played both with a shrouded tone that hinted at inner stillness and great spiritual calm.

Thereafter, he plunged straight into Beethoven's Egmont Concerto with refined tentativeness, focusing on points of dramatic and dynamic contrast at the expense of Dionysiac frenzy, reining it in, and not always letting it swirl off, as it should, into extremes of elation.

His Brahms, by contrast, was high-voltage stuff, riddled with a sense of danger. He opted for the Third Symphony, unleashing a torrent of heady emotionalism that reared, plunged and gripped the listener from the gaunt, savage opening to the ecstatic close. Occasionally, the structure slipped. You missed the daunting logic that binds the symphony together - but Perlman is right in thinking there's nothing safe in Brahms, and his interpretation is infinitely preferable to those of many conductors, who turn him into a cosy, stentorian bore.

In between came Prokofiev's Classical Symphony, a performance of poise, wit and tremendous warmth. The LPO players have apparently adored working with Perlman, and here, above all, it showed - in the gilded string tone, the jewelled woodwind solos, the flashy, exultant clarity of the counterpoint and in the mercurial buoyancy that characterised the whole.

fields.headline: BBCPO/ Sinaisky
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
***
fields.body:
Despite Shostakovich's popularity, most of his film scores - of which there are more than 30 - remain neglected in concert hall and recording studio. Most of the music he wrote for the 1931 film Alone seems destined to remain in the archives: the whole soundtrack lasts more than 70 minutes. Although the five numbers played here worked well as a suite, this is still music more of curiosity value than intrinsic merit, oddly lifeless beneath a veneer of activity.

Consequently, it was a rather disappointing replacement for the scheduled work - Gerard McBurney's reconstruction of the Second Jazz Suite - which was withdrawn without notice or explanation.

The rest of the programme continued as billed and, for every listener who found Leonidas Kavakos's performance of Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto a little plain, there is likely to be another who relished its clarity and restraint. Certainly, there have been warmer and more poetic accounts of its first movement, going beyond the notes on the page to explore its nooks and crannies more lovingly. Kavakos chose instead to present a clean text, uncluttered by flights of fancy. This made for a rather drab first movement - even the BBC Philharmonic Orchestra sounded uninspired - but all that changed in the finale, where Kavakos's flamboyance and charm brought everything to life.

It would be unfair to take virtuosity as formidable as this for granted, and the warmth of Kavakos's reception was proof that his Manchester audience was justly dazzled.

Despite fairly regular programming, Skryabin's symphonies and symphonic poems have failed to achieve the kind of popularity enjoyed by those of his Russian contemporaries. They are not easy works to get to know, and those conductors who wallow in their luxuriant textures make comprehension even harder. But in Sinaisky's hands the Second Symphony was refreshingly unconvoluted. Its Straussian second movement was robust and assertive, and even the bombastic finale was played with such glorious conviction that it was irresistible. The slow movement - an intriguing mix of Wagner and Albert W Ketelby - was pure magic.

webTitle: Backlash against May Day zero tolerance

fields.headline: Backlash against May Day zero tolerance
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: There was a backlash yesterday from protesters against the "frenzy of aggression" by police, the media and Ken Livingstone towards tomorrow's May Day celebrations and protests in the capital.
fields.body:
There was a backlash yesterday from protesters and sections of the labour and trade union movements against the "frenzy of aggression" by police, the media and the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, towards tomorrow's May Day celebrations and protests in the capital.

With more than 9,000 police ready to make preventive arrests and on order to stamp on any trouble, there was concern that the zero tolerance policy could incite violence and was a "brazen abuse of civil rights".

In a letter to the Guardian, 27 union representatives, including journalists, teachers, lecturers, car workers, miners and civil servants, declared their support for the anti-capitalism demonstrators and condemned what they called the establishment's over-reaction to the planned protests.

They questioned the media's role in the build-up to the events, which has included widespread accusations that protesters would be making bombs and wielding swords. Several newspapers have printed photographs of people known to have been on previous demonstrations.

"The publications of photographs of people 'suspected' by police of 'intending' to cause violence by newspapers with a pathetic or non-existent record of exposing capitalism's monstrous daily destruction of people and environment is witch-hunting, not journalism," say the signatories.

Mr Livingstone was attacked for urging protesters to stay away and for ordering the police to arrest anyone whose intention was "to engage in criminal activities".

Yesterday Mr Livingstone said: "If you really believe in cancelling third world debt and saving the environment, then beating the hell out of a police officer or smashing in a shop window is really going to alienate public opinion. You will actually damage the causes you serve." He warned that "at the slightest sign of violence, people will be arrested".

Liz Leicester, chairwoman of the Camden branch of the public service union Unison, said: "There has been an incredible hype built up against these demonstrators, the vast majority of whom want peacefully to express their anger and despair at the real horrors of capitalism, and it is regrettable that Ken Livingstone is fuelling that. He always stood up for the rights of the Irish and on other civil liberties issues."

The Labour MP Tony Benn compared the anti-capitalist movement with the trade unions and the suffragettes, saying: "Every single progressive movement in history has been denounced as violent."

He accepted that violence would distract people from the anti-capitalist cause but refused to denounce the protest.

The support was welcomed by many intending to demonstrate on what has traditionally been a workers' day of solidarity and a pagan celebration.

"There will be violence on the day, and I think the violence will be organised by the police," said John, a spokesman for the socialist youth group Revolution. "What they want to do is provoke violence and ultimately put the demonstrators on the defensive.

"They are consciously [constructing] a moral panic to justify the fact they will be tooled-up on the day."

Revolution has been investigated by special branch.

Another member, John, said: "The strategy [of the authorities] is to justify any excessive use of force by police on the day and sweep the issues under the carpet. They see the success of the anti-capitalist movement, and I think they're genuinely worried; they are trying to stop people turning up and using their democratic right to demonstrate."

The role of the media in demonising the protesters was condemned by some journalists and protesters. "In the past month more than 100 often hysterical articles have been printed in the mainstream press hyping the violence, with few suggesting that the protesters have any valid point," said David Jones, a former organiser in Reclaim the Streets, which is not involved in this year's protests. "The imbalance has been remarkable. No one wants to look at why people are protesting."

Daniel, of Revolution, said: "When have the issues been covered? All they want to do is zone in on broken windows. Millions of people die needlessly around the world: what are a couple of broken windows?

"It's like saying you could justify stopping anyone from going to a football match and beating up the whole crowd because one person is violent."

Tomorrow's events include a trade union march, samba dances, bike rides against congestion in the city, a handout of veggie burgers to protest against the food system, demonstrations by and for the homeless, prisoners and refugees, the feeding of birds in Trafalgar Square, a pagan celebration to welcome spring and a rally against third world debt.

The three potential points of confrontation between police and some demonstrators are at a demonstration against capitalism at Elephant and Castle, at the World Bank, in the West End, at lunchtime and after a gathering in Oxford Street in the afternoon. Random protests against the press and the arms trade are expected.

They questioned the media's role in the build-up to the events, which has included widespread accusations that protesters would be making bombs and wielding swords. Several newspapers have printed photographs of people known to have been on previous demonstrations. "The publications of photographs of people 'suspected' by police of 'intending' to cause violence by newspapers with a pathetic or non-existent record of exposing capitalism's monstrous daily destruction of people and environment is witch-hunting, not journalism," say the signatories. Mr Livingstone was attacked for urging protesters to stay away and for ordering the police to arrest anyone whose intention was "to engage in criminal activities". Yesterday Mr Livingstone said: "If you really believe in cancelling third world debt and saving the environment, then beating the hell out of a police officer or smashing in a shop window is really going to alienate public opinion. You will actually damage the causes you serve." He warned that "at the slightest sign of violence, people will be arrested". Liz Leicester, chairwoman of the Camden branch of the public service union Unison, said: "There has been an incredible hype built up against these demonstrators, the vast majority of whom want peacefully to express their anger and despair at the real horrors of capitalism, and it is regrettable that Ken Livingstone is fuelling that. He always stood up for the rights of the Irish and on other civil liberties issues." The Labour MP Tony Benn compared the anti-capitalist movement with the trade unions and the suffragettes, saying: "Every single progressive movement in history has been denounced as violent." He accepted that violence would distract people from the anti-capitalist cause but refused to denounce the protest. The support was welcomed by many intending to demonstrate on what has traditionally been a workers' day of solidarity and a pagan celebration. "There will be violence on the day, and I think the violence will be organised by the police," said John, a spokesman for the socialist youth group Revolution. "What they want to do is provoke violence and ultimately put the demonstrators on the defensive. "They are consciously [constructing] a moral panic to justify the fact they will be tooled-up on the day." Revolution has been investigated by special branch. Another member, John, said: "The strategy [of the authorities] is to justify any excessive use of force by police on the day and sweep the issues under the carpet. They see the success of the anti-capitalist movement, and I think they're genuinely worried; they are trying to stop people turning up and using their democratic right to demonstrate." The role of the media in demonising the protesters was condemned by some journalists and protesters. "In the past month more than 100 often hysterical articles have been printed in the mainstream press hyping the violence, with few suggesting that the protesters have any valid point," said David Jones, a former organiser in Reclaim the Streets, which is not involved in this year's protests. "The imbalance has been remarkable. No one wants to look at why people are protesting." Daniel, of Revolution, said: "When have the issues been covered? All they want to do is zone in on broken windows. Millions of people die needlessly around the world: what are a couple of broken windows? "It's like saying you could justify stopping anyone from going to a football match and beating up the whole crowd because one person is violent." Tomorrow's events include a trade union march, samba dances, bike rides against congestion in the city, a handout of veggie burgers to protest against the food system, demonstrations by and for the homeless, prisoners and refugees, the feeding of birds in Trafalgar Square, a pagan celebration to welcome spring and a rally against third world debt. The three potential points of confrontation between police and some demonstrators are at a demonstration against capitalism at Elephant and Castle, at the World Bank, in the West End, at lunchtime and after a gathering in Oxford Street in the afternoon. Random protests against the press and the arms trade are expected.

webTitle: Theatre review:  A Little Night Music

fields.headline: Sondheim's frosty musical
fields.standfirst:
A Little Night Music
Haymarket, Leicester
****
fields.trailText:
A Little Night Music
Haymarket, Leicester
****
fields.body:
Poor Henrick has problems hanging himself - which is actually quite a feat in Paul Kerryson's spectral, moon-washed production of Sondheim's masterpiece, in which everything is held in a state of magical suspension. Chandeliers, grand pianos and banqueting tables all dangle languidly from the midnight sky. Only Henrick has neglected to attach his rope to anything and tumbles back to earth.

Jody Crosier's splenetic portrayal of this suicidal student is just one of the many tragi-comic delights that Kerryson teases from this glittering group portrait of the early 20th-century Swedish demi-monde at play. For this 1973 hit, Sondheim brilliantly plucked Ingmar Bergman's film Smiles of a Summer Night from the European art house and set it down on Broadway, bringing urgency and coherence to its Chekhovian montage of character studies with a score propelled by brisk polonaises and pointed, waltz-time set-pieces.

The result has to be the frostiest piece of musical comedy ever written. From the moment the cast glides out onto the glacial, reflective surfaces of Paul Farnsworth's set, you sense that these neurasthenic, vacillating creatures are skating on very thin ice.

Fading actress and femme fatale Desirée Armfeldt provides the show with its centre of gravity, given that all the amorous plot lines eventually lead to her; and that she is gifted the ubiquitous hit number, Send in the Clowns. Kathryn Evans is perfectly poised in the part: physically louche and vocally lavish. As her old flame, Fredrik, the excellent Russell Dixon bumbles poignantly around her like an aged bee round a honeypot.

Skilful musical director Julian Kelly has a proper band to play with - what a treat to hear Sondheim's sly allusions to Viennese operetta played by a full pit orchestra with real strings. He is equally blessed with a pool of fine voices: Annalene Beechey is especially sweet in the wide-eyed innocent role of Anne.

Ultimately, though, one can get too much of this kind of thing. The high point arrives with one of Sondheim's finest ensemble narratives: A Weekend in the Country. With this particular crowd of highly-strung house guests, a weekend is probably quite enough.

 Until May 19. Box office: 0116-253 9797.

webTitle: Who's who in protest and action

fields.headline: Who's who in protest and action
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: Wombles (White Overall Movement Building Liberation Through Effective Struggle) Anarchist movement styled on Ya Basta! the non-violent, direct action, Italian group supporting Mexico's Zapatistas. No leadership; tactics and actions are agreed at open meetings. Police view them with suspicion.
fields.body:
Wombles (White Overall Movement Building Liberation Through Effective Struggle) Anarchist movement styled on Ya Basta! the non-violent, direct action, Italian group supporting Mexico's Zapatistas. No leadership; tactics and actions are agreed at open meetings. Police view them with suspicion.

Reclaim The Streets Focuses on anti-capitalist and environmental causes, but will not operate as a group tomorrow. Hugely influential through its "stunts", but seems to have had a split, with some claiming it has been hijacked by a thuggish element.

Class War Anarchist group which believes violence is the only way to overthrow capitalism. Took a leading role in the 1990 poll tax riots. Says its targets are rich individuals as well as the ruling class.

Critical Mass Organisers of the mass cycle ride, pushing for better public transport and an end to car culture. Strong links to Reclaim the Streets.

London Animal Action Animal liberation group which uses legal tactics but "[recognises] the effectiveness of illegal direct action as a weapon". Campaigned against furriers and hunting.

Socialist Workers party Hard-left revolutionary socialists. Played a key role in big demonstrations such as that which protested against the Criminal Justice Act.

No Sweat! Campaigns peacefully against sweatshop labour, in UK and overseas.

Revolution Socialist youth group. Keen to build links with the Labour movement and will march with the TUC.

Anarchist Federation "Anarchist communists" fighting third world debt and globalisation. Involved in digging up the grass in Parliament Square last year.

Solidarity Federation Aims to replace capitalism and the state with direct democracy, class solidarity and individual freedom. Campaigns on issues ranging from homophobia to the environment.

The Urban Alliance Formed last year to oppose the Countryside Alliance and "royalists, aristocrats and other pro-hunting groups". Includes hunt saboteurs and supporters of Class War and Movement Against the Monarchy.

Other protesters Students (against fees); Campaign Against the Arms Trade; homeless activists; the TUC, with traditional May Day march from Highbury Fields to Clerkenwell in protest at issues including globalisation and tube privatisation.

fields.headline: The tumultuous sound of Sonny Rollins
fields.standfirst:
Sonny Rollins
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Sonny Rollins
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
One night - unless he really is the supernatural being he sometimes resembles - the 70-year-old Sonny Rollins may do what other venerable jazz heroes finally bow to the need for. That is, sit down between solos instead of prowling the stage, play shorter, concentrate on texture and tone instead of torrential saxophone soliloquys, and give other soloists more to do.

If and when that happens, Rollins will still sound like no other tenor saxophonist on the planet, including the thousands who have imitated him. But on his only UK date at the Barbican on Saturday, Rollins eschewed only one virtuosic spectacle of old - the unbroken, lung-punishing circular-breathing exercises that fuelled chorus after chorus of improvisation without intake of breath. Everything else was there - the bone-shaking low notes, the slewing momentum intermingling abstract playing with his familiar rugged, ironic lyricism and affection for cut-and-paste quotation - and, of course, the insistence that the improvising is the point. Rollins and his band played more or less exactly the same tunes as the last time he came, and most of the ones from the time before.

The show also started familiarly with the sense of Rollins's muse being a piece of gigantic, complex, heavy-industry machinery that needs to get the oil circulating at first - an impression reinforced by initially rather muddy and unmusical amplification. But his squirty, impulsive phrasing, braying wails, sonorous low-register rumbles and preoccupied passages were appearing by the arrival of In a Sentimental Mood. Trombonist Clifton Anderson, Rollins's front-line foil, was also introducing more of an edge and clip to his phrasing on a good solo on They Say It's Wonderful.

A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square, What a Difference a Day Makes and the inevitable Don't Stop the Carnival were the button-pushing turning points of the second half that finally brought almost the entire house to its feet. Rollins's tumult of sound snorted, bellowed and soared from the sax as he paced the stage to its edge and seemed disinclined ever to stop.

But both pianist Stephen Scott and Rollins himself played their solos of the night - long, percussive, hard-driving forays without a repeated phrase that wasn't intentional - on the fast, hard-bop classic Tenor Madness, the climax of the first half. That was really the 10 minutes or so in every Rollins show that stays roaring in your head until the next time.

webTitle: Buffett is given a smooth ride

fields.headline: Buffett is given a smooth ride
fields.trailText: Thousands of investors, young and very old, stood to attention and cheered wildly as Warren Buffett entered the vast auditorium this weekend. At last year's annual meeting, some questioned the Sage of Omaha's wisdom. This year, there were no doubts.
fields.body:
Thousands of investors, young and very old, stood to attention and cheered wildly as Warren Buffett entered the vast auditorium this weekend. At last year's annual meeting, some questioned the Sage of Omaha's wisdom. This year, there were no doubts.

After shunning technology stocks and sticking to his value-based investment policy, Mr Buffett's investment vehicle, Berkshire Hathaway, saw its shares rise 12.8% over the past year. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index slumped 60%.

One investor generated a wave of applause by standing up and congratulating Mr Buffett for resisting the temptations of internet stocks.

The 70-year-old multi-billionaire did not glory in the vindication. Mr Buffett told 10,000-plus people who had travelled across America to hear him that expectations were still too high.

Mr Buffettt, who founded his company 35 years ago, said that growth had to slow as the business became larger. The 15% annual return typically offered by investment houses was unrealistic and 6-7% was more realistic. Anyone doubting that was "living in a dream world".

Continuing his theme pounded home during the bull run of the past 10 years, Mr Buffett said the stock market was still overvalued. He chided investors whose buying led to the record-breaking run for US shares last year. "It is just astounding to me how willing people are, during a bull market, to throw money around."

He has in recent years proved willing to buy some assets he considered undervalued, including insurance and retail companies. Last year he paid $8bn (£5.5bn) for eight companies making a range of goods from cowboy boots to carpets. He is ready to invest up to $10bn in a US utility company but is waiting for regulatory changes before he can do so.

In the annual report, he wrote: "We remain awash with liquid assets and are both eager and ready for even larger acquisitions. The larger the company, the greater will be our interest."

webTitle: Brown snubs ECB on inflation target

fields.headline: Brown snubs ECB on inflation target
fields.standfirst: Go-it-alone chancellor refuses to match eurozone level
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday delivered a calculated rebuff to the European Central Bank when he announced in the most public way possible that Britain's inflation target would remain unchanged in order to safeguard jobs and growth.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott and Jane Martinson in Washington
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday delivered a calculated rebuff to the European Central Bank when he announced in the most public way possible that Britain's inflation target would remain unchanged in order to safeguard jobs and growth.

Rejecting calls that he should cut the inflation target from 2.5% and bring it into line with the 2% ceiling in the single-currency zone, the chancellor underlined his concern over the ECB's structure and conduct by continuing with a go-it-alone approach.

The decision was announced in Washington in Mr Brown's keynote speech to the International Monetary Fund's international monetary and financial committee, attended by 24 finance ministers, and comes at a time when the ECB is coming under increasing pressure to join other central banks in cutting interest rates.

"At this time of global risks, we need to continue to steer a course of stability," Mr Brown said.

"That demands consistency and clarity in macroeconomic policy. With inflation forecast to be 2.5% next year, imposing a lower inflation target - as some have suggested - would mean upward pressure on interest rates and risk lower growth and higher unemployment. So I have decided to reaffirm the inflation target at 2.5% for the coming year and have today written to the governor of the Bank of England [Sir Eddie George] to set out the monetary policy committee's remit for the coming year."

One of Britain's leading economic think tanks, the National Institute for Economic and Social Research, will today call for Britain to adopt a 2% inflation target as the first step towards joining monetary union. It says reducing the target to 2% will help ensure lower interest rates and facilitate"the process of convergence with the European monetary union."

Mr Brown believes that Britain's system is preferable to that used by the ECB, however, since the 2.5% target for the Bank of England is symmetrical, with an inflation rate below the target treated just as seriously as an inflation rate above the target. The ECB's mandate is to keep inflation at 2% or below, an approach that the chancellor believes exacerbates the ECB's deflationary bias.

Treasury officials said that remarks made by the French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, showed that Mr Brown's doubts about the ECB were shared by his colleagues in Europe and stressed that the decision to leave the inflation target unchanged had no bearing on whether the government would hold an early referendum on joining the euro.

In the light of the chancellor's leading role in any decision to call a referendum, both supporters and opponents of UK membership are likely to see his decision as having a wider significance.

In its quarterly report, the institute admits the prospect of Britain joining the single currency is less likely than it has been for a "considerable time".

Mr Fabius yesterday added to the calls for the ECB to change course on interest rates.

"We have had the distinct feeling, over the last few weeks, that the balance of risk has altered, influenced by the global slowdown. Inflationary pressures are under control," Mr Fabius said in his IMF speech.

"Our central financial objective is to balance public finances in the next three years: it would be paradoxical to see this compromised by a growth slowdown. Our monetary stance will have to take these elements into account."

Wim Duisenberg, head of the European Central Bank, made it clear in Washington that the bank prided itself on its independence, and - with inflation likely to above 2% until early next year - would not be bounced into a rate cut.

fields.headline: Among Unbroken Hearts
fields.standfirst:
Bush Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Bush Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Scotland is currently the prime source of works about drugs. And after the facile sensationalism of Trainspotting it's a relief to report that Henry Adam's play, first seen at the Edinburgh Traverse, is a sombre, serious study of addiction. What it doesn't fully explain is why it so afflicts an apparently confident, prosperous country like Scotland.

The Wick-born Adam sets his play in the Highlands, where Ray returns to his grandmother's cottage with his friend Neil. Both are heroin addicts in their early 20s, seeking an escape from urban pressure and the death of friends. During the trip they meet up with Chaimig, an old blind poet-farmer who was Ray's childhood mentor, and his adoring granddaughter, who has sacrificed a university education to look after him. But, although Ray and Neil encounter philosophical values and a way of life entirely opposed to their own, they remain cocooned in a cooking-up drug culture.

Adam has a poetic sense of place, a genuine gravity, and offers several clues as to Ray and Neil's problem. Not only are they victims of a rootless, market-dominated society, but they have also inherited the morbidity and irresponsibility that, Adam implies, runs through Scottish life. Neil comes across an old copy of Barrie's Peter Pan in the cottage and falls eagerly on the hero's cry of "no one is going to catch me and make a man"; and, lest we miss the point, Mark Leese's design shows the boy Peter declaring "to die will be an awfully big adventure". But while I accept the element of escapist death wish in heroin addiction, I still feel Adam avoids the real question: what precisely is it about modern Scotland that has created a huge drug problem in many of its key cities?

Plays are works of art rather than social documents but Adam leaves too much out: he never explains, for instance, how Ray and Neil finance their expensive habit. Where he does score, if that's the right word, is in creating a pervasive sense of sadness and loss. It is well realised in John Tiffany's production and in the fine performances of Adam Robertson and Mark Channon as the young addicts and, most especially, in Billy Riddoch's blind sage, for whom the Highlands is "the land of the dispossessed" and Lesley Hart's touching portrayal of his granddaughter. Grieve though the family couple may, at least Adam implies through them that there is a moral alternative to the addict's narcissistic nihilism.

 Until May 19. Box office: 020-7610 4224.

Where he does score, if that's the right word, is in creating a pervasive sense of sadness and loss. It is well realised in John Tiffany's production and in the fine performances of Adam Robertson and Mark Channon as the young addicts and, most especially, in Billy Riddoch's blind sage, for whom the Highlands is "the land of the dispossessed" and Lesley Hart's touching portrayal of his granddaughter. Grieve though the family couple may, at least Adam implies through them that there is a moral alternative to the addict's narcissistic nihilism.  Until May 19. Box office: 020-7610 4224.

webTitle: Young lives blighted in a nuclear wasteland

fields.headline: Young lives blighted in a nuclear wasteland
fields.standfirst: Today's shocking revelation about a child leukaemia cluster in the Severn Valley sounds a radiation health alert for all who live near nuclear plants. Anthony Browne reports
fields.trailText: Today's shocking revelation about a child leukaemia cluster in the Severn Valley sounds a radiation health alert for all who live near nuclear plants. Anthony Browne reports.
fields.body:
It was a home video that first made the family realise something might be wrong. As Sue and Allen Langford looked back at the footage of their 18-month-old son Stephen, they noticed he seemed lethargic. He usually raced up and down his favourite climbing frame, but the video showed he now had little interest.

Rapidly Stephen got more and more tired. He would crawl into the centre of the floor and just sit there. He didn't want to walk at all. He eventually went off his food. 'We took him to the doctor four times,' said Sue, sitting in the front room of their house with its view of the River Severn.

From here, when the weather is clear, they can see Oldbury nuclear power station. 'I knew it was something serious, even life threatening - but I had no idea it was cancer.'

Eventually Stephen was diagnosed as having myeloid leukaemia, one of the most unusual and dangerous forms of the disease, so rare there are only a handful of child victims every year in Britain. 'He was in such a bad state by the time he had treatment, I think he only had a week left. It was touch and go,' said Sue.

A new study suggests that Stephen is part of a leukaemia cluster among children in the small town of Chepstow, sitting across the Severn from Oldbury power station. The report claims that children in the town are 11 times more likely to get leukaemia than the national average, and the probability that it is just bad luck is one in a thousand, making it probably the most significant cancer cluster near a nuclear power station in the UK.

Dr Chris Busby, a former adviser to the Irish government over the health effects of radiation in the Irish Sea, said: 'This is a discovery of a new nuclear site leukaemia cluster. The high level of myeloid leukaemia suggests that radiation is the cause.'

The report also catalogues the increased risk of many forms of cancer for all those who live along the Severn estuary. Based on cancer figures over five years for 147 wards in the area, it claims that living near the Severn can make you up to80 per cent more likely than the national average to get some forms of cancer.

Women living along the coast downstream from Oldbury power station are 50 per cent more likely to die of breast cancer than those living more than five kilometres further inland. The chance of this being just random is one in 50,000.

Overall, death rates for any form of cancer are 18 per cent higher for people living within 5km of the Severn, compared to those living further inland. Men living within 7.5km of Oldbury are 37 per cent more likely to die of prostate cancer than the national average.

Oldbury has two ageing Magnox reactors, and has permission to release a limited amount of tritium, or radioactive hydrogen, into the air and water. But the Severn also has other possible sources of contamination. Just upstream is the now decommissioned Berkeley power station, and downstream is Hinkley A, which was closed after it too was associated with a leukaemia cluster a decade ago. On the Welsh coast, there is the nuclear research company Amersham International.

Anti-nuclear campaigners say that the Severn has more radioactive hydrogen than any other stretch of water in the world.

Dr Busby said: 'It shows that living near the Severn is bad for you. It's probably got the highest concentration of nuclear power stations and sources of radiation in Europe. There is airborne concentration of radioactive particles near the mudflats, which can get into the lungs of children.'

For Stephen's parents, it was clear that something was unusual as soon as he started four horrific - but ultimately successful - rounds of chemotherapy. Doctors at Llangdough Hospital in Cardiff conducted a blood test on him, and were surprised to find he wasn't naturally prone to leukaemia. They also had the house tested for radium, but the reading was insignificant.

In Magor primary school, which Stephen went to, there were just a couple of hundred pupils, but three children had leukaemia, a highly unusual statistical occurrence. The leukaemia study is based on figures from 1974 to 1990, but The Observer has discovered that in the past couple of years in Chepstow, there have been two further cases of childhood leukaemia, making the evidence for the cluster even stronger.

Jim Duffy, of the Shut Oldbury campaign, leapt on the findings: 'It's an atomic bomb in the lap of the nuclear industry. The leukaemia cluster must put a lid on Oldbury's operation.' Michael Holmes, one of the MEPs for the South West, who commissioned the research from EU funds, said: 'If there is a significant risk to public health, Oldbury should be decommissioned, and not allowed to stagger on.'

Since the controversial discovery of a leukaemia cluster around Sellafield nuclear processing plant in 1983, the existence of such clusters has become widely accepted. Whether they are caused by the nuclear industry is still subject to debate.

In 1988 the Somerset Health Authority found a strong correlation between leukaemia in young people and the opening of Hinkley A station in 1964. The new cluster, combined with the increased risks in lung, prostate and breast cancer, suggests that Oldbury could be the most significant finding yet.

The nuclear industry has always dismissed the connection between its emissions and cancer clusters.

It insists - with the backing of the Government's National Radiological Protection Board - that the level of radiation released into the environment is insignificant compared to natural background radiation, and is far too low to lead to cancer.

BNFL, which runs Oldbury, says it can emit only one 400th the level of background radiation. But Busby claims that if the radioactive particles are ingested, even low levels of radiation can spark off tumours.

British Nuclear Fuels dismissed both the new report and its author. Its spokesman, David Cartwright, said: 'He's a professional scaremonger_ he comes up with these things every week.'

Dr Michael Clark, scientific spokesman for the National Radiological Protection Board, also attacked the report and its author: 'Dr Busby has discovered clusters in other parts of the country. But when these have been looked at by professional epidemiologists, they tend to disappear.'

But Busby also has powerful supporters. Vyvyan Howard, professor of toxico-pathology at Liverpool University, said: 'Busby is a good statistician.'

And Professor Ray Cartwright, director of the Leukaemia Research Fund's centre for clinical epidemiology, said: 'His epidemiology is OK. It is important there is a robust debate about this.'

Back in Chepstow, Stephen is now an almost healthy 13-year-old. The leukaemia treatment left his heart weak, and may mean it will be impossible for him to father children.

It has also left his parents wondering why he ended up with this terrible disease. 'We need more research into this. If the power station is a risk, then it ought to close,' said Allen.

webTitle: Cancer cluster found close to nuclear plant

fields.headline: Cancer cluster found close to nuclear plant
fields.trailText: One of the most significant leukaemia clusters in Britain has been discovered among children living near the Oldbury nuclear power station on the banks of the Severn.
fields.body:
One of the most significant leukaemia clusters in Britain has been discovered among children living near the Oldbury nuclear power station on the banks of the Severn.

A study has found that people living near the river, which contains high levels of radioactive particles, are up to twice as likely to die of cancer as people elsewhere.

The report claims children in Chepstow, South Wales, are 11 times more likely to get leukaemia than the national average and that the probability that this is just coincidence is one in a thousand.

One primary school near Chepstow had three cases of leukaemia at the same time. The study is based on figures from 1974 to 1990, but The Observer has discovered that over the past two years there have been at least two more cases of childhood leukaemia in the town.

The report highlights a particularly high incidence of myeloid leukaemia, a very rare and dangerous form of the disease that has been linked to radiation.

The author, Dr Chris Busby, a former adviser to the Irish government on the health effects of radiation in the Irish Sea, said: 'This is a discovery of a new nuclear site child leukaemia cluster. The high level of myeloid leukaemia suggests that radiation is the cause.'

The study also finds that men living near Oldbury are 37 per cent more likely to die of prostate cancer than expected. Women living along the coast downstream from Oldbury are 50 per cent more likely to die of breast cancer than those living more than three miles inland. The chance of this being random is one in 50,000.

In Gordano, downstream from Oldbury, men are 80 per cent more likely to die of cancer than elsewhere, and women 40 per cent.

The work was commissioned by Michael Holmes, an Independent MEP for the South West, who works in co-operation with the Green Party. Holmes said: 'If the possibility of cancers is related to living near a nuclear power station, they should be closed down.'

Leukaemia clusters were first discovered around Sellafield nuclear processing plant in 1983, and have now become widely accepted by cancer epidemiologists. However, there is no consensus on whether they are caused by radiation. BNFL, which runs Oldbury, insisted that the levels of radiation emitted there are far too low to cause cancer.

A spokesman dismissed Busby's findings: 'He comes up with these things virtually every week. Every time he comes out with a report it is rubbished by people.'

webTitle: Leader: M. Redeker should be a good sport

fields.headline: Ayer 1 France 0
fields.standfirst: M. Redeker should be a good sport
fields.trailText: French intellectuals often proclaim their sympathy for the masses but, given their inevitably élitist trade, share their enthusiasms uneasily.
fields.body:
French intellectuals often proclaim their sympathy for the masses but, given their inevitably élitist trade, share their enthusiasms uneasily. They always had the conceit that theirs was a nation of players, not spectators. Sartre said that 'to play was to be'. Now, according to the philosopher Robert Redeker, an obsession with sport is poisoning France, creating false communities glued to TV, and making the nation 'stupid'.

We are disappointed; we had imagined that France had got over its recent bout of morosité. But M. Redeker's gloom is surely misplaced. France's victory in the World Cup strengthened the vision of a multicultural society. In a welcome fit of generosity, France embraced the English yachtswoman Ellen MacArthur. M. Redeker should get out more and follow the example of the late A.J. Ayer. He was not only a logical positivist and a Spurs fan, he also danced the samba.

Related story
Sport fever 'turns the French into cretins'
