webTitle: Mel Brooke's hit musical The Producers

fields.headline: Let's hear it for Hitler
fields.standfirst:
New Yorkers are queuing round the block for The Producers. Could Mel Brooks's hit musical signal the end of British supremacy and the birth of a new era on Broadway?

More Observer Theatre coverage
fields.trailText: New Yorkers are queuing round the block for The Producers. Could Mel Brooks's hit musical signal the end of British supremacy and the birth of a new era on Broadway?
fields.body:
It's the opening night party for Stones in his Pockets on Broadway, the sort of Cinderella story on which the theatre thrives - small-scale Belfast play makes it all the way to the Big Apple. But while celebrants toast the show's visiting Irishmen, Conleth Hill and Sean Campion, the real excitement is about a homegrown American musical that is playing on 44th Street, one block over from Stones.

'Have you seen The Producers yet?' says Frank Skinner, who is in town for the weekend with his girlfriend, Caroline. 'It's incredible.'

'Just amazing - uh-may-zeeng,' says a senior London producer, looking disappointed to know that the UK rights to the show seem more or less sewn up.

'It's going to be mega,' says a well-placed New York Times journalist rarely given to hyperbole.

And all that buzz with 11 nights still to go until the formal opening of Mel Brooks's musical.

The Producers opened on 19 April. Adapted by Brooks from his 1968 film, with songs specially written for the stage by him, it is directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman, whose late husband, English director Mike Ockrent, was originally intended to stage the show. By this time next year, Stroman should have an astonishing five productions running concurrently on Broadway, including the New York transfer of the National Theatre's Oklahoma! , for which Stroman did the dances. The stars are two previous Tony-winners who are much loved in New York: Matthew Broderick, now on screen in You Can Count On Me, and Nathan Lane, whose credits include Guys and Dolls and Noël Coward on Broadway.

The Producers isn't just a hit; it's a fully-fledged event in a city that thrives on such things, and its cultural repercussions look sure to be felt in English-speaking theatre the world over, although given its subject matter, the show seems an unlikely export to Germany.

The plot in the main follows that of Brooks's movie, in which Zero Mostel and Gene Wilder played two New York nogoodniks, Bialystock and Bloom, who deliberately conceive the worst musical ever, Springtime For Hitler, with the aim of absconding with their backers' dosh. Instead, their would-be flop is a hit, even with Hitler played by a drug-addled hippie called LSD (that character has been droped from the stage version as doubtlessly just too 1960s for today). Brooks won an Academy Award for his screenplay.

But the road from celluloid to the stage isn't necessarily a smooth one - look at the West End's ever-evolving The Witches of Eastwick, which opened last summer in London to decidedly mixed reviews. What's more, in these obsessively PC times, you would have to possess a combination of hubris and devil-may-care glee to think about staging a show that sends up Nazis, blacks, Jews, gays - hell, even little old ladies - with equal abandon, as The Producers so merrily does. That person exists in Mel Brooks, 75 this year. Here is someone people thought was in the twilight of his film career now embarking upon an altogether new one: the theatre.

'The long-ago dream of the nine-year-old Brooklyn boy has at last come true,' Brooks wrote in the New York Times before the show's opening. 'I hope for the best, expect the worst.' And yet, even he could not have realised to what extent his dream would end up being the one so evidently shared by New York audiences and critics, desperate for a real musical with singing and dancing and laughs after decades of through-sung (and mostly Britain-originated) pop operas and Sondheimian angst.

'Oh, boy!' exulted John Heilpern in the New York Observer. 'When things go right! Mel Brooks's The Producers is quite simply the best time you could ever wish for at the theatre.' Over at the New York Times , Ben Brantley offered up the sort of encomium he traditionally reserves for visiting British imports like Skylight, Janet McTeer in A Doll's House or New York's current Mnemonic . 'How do you single out highlights in a bonfire?' ran Brantley's opening sentence. 'Everybody who sees The Producers - and that should be as close to everybody as the St James Theatre allows - is going to be hard-pressed to choose one favourite bit from the sublimely ridiculous spectacle.'

Certainly, the packed Sunday-matinée crowd with whom I watched the show cheered so heartily that it gave pause for thought. True, the Broadway musical has always feasted on shows about showbiz, from Kiss Me, Kate through to Gypsy, A Chorus Line and 42nd Street (a lavish twentieth-anniversary Broadway revival of which opens on Wednesday). But what does it say about American society when a piece featuring dancing jackboots and tapping zimmer frames (one of Stroman's more inspired touches) is received so rapturously?

'I really felt what people must have felt at the opening of My Fair Lady,' says the Broadway producer Carole Shorenstein Hays, who attended a Producers first night more reminiscent of a Hollywood than a Broadway opening. Consider the guest list: Demi Moore, Alec Baldwin, Glenn Close, Sex and the City's Sarah Jessica Parker (who happens to be Producers co-star Matthew Broderick's wife). For once, however, the celebrities weren't the story; the show itself was. Here is a love letter from Broadway to itself, told with the sort of theatrical nous and panache that doesn't exist any more.

It is also, of course, a distinctly American show - take that, Lord Lloyd-Webber and Sir Cameron!, or so one gleaned from the subtext of the reviews - as well as the work of a team of individuals, not the latest corporate concoction from Disney. (According to a report this week in the New York Post, Stroman alone could earn as much as £25,000 a week for her work on the show.) The New York theatre has long felt ambivalent about hosting one visiting British behemoth after another (last year's closing on Broadway of Cats was greeted with relief rather than regret), not to mention utterly impotent in the face of the Disney machine, notwithstanding its respect for The Lion King 's visionary director, Julie Taymor.

As for sondheim, Broadway holds its leading composer dear while simultaneously acknowledging that he caters to a rarefied market. In any case, his only real commercial hit, A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, was first seen almost 40 years ago, and exists in the raucous musical comedy tradition that The Producers carries forward (and that Sondheim's subsequent career has virtually ignored). Prior to The Producers, the Broadway season's most anticipated opening was the first-ever New York revival of Sondheim's 1971 Follies.

But it may not just be the problematic nature of Matthew Warchus's bare-bones staging that has seen Follies fully eclipsed by The Producers. (The latter show even includes the earlier one in its roll call of Broadway pastiche, which includes Fiddler on the Roof, Cabaret and, in a delicious visual gag, Cats .) As Michael Feingold put it in the Village Voice: 'After decades of musical-theatre pundits declaring that musicals have to be solemn, unpleasant and good for you, The Producers represents a recoil so extreme that the aesthetic pendulum seems to have jammed at the other end.'

Not that such cavils will matter much to audiences. Ticketbuyers have been snaking around the block, a rare sight these days in New York, where most such transactions take place over the phone, with demand so intense the day after opening that two neighbouring (and rival) Broadway theatres opened their box offices to accommodate the overspill. At present, the show looks set to recoup production costs totalling some £7.5 million ($10.5m) within 35 weeks, with advance sales up to £12.5m ($20m) and the top ticket a hefty $100, or £65.

That last manoeuvre, cannily announced the morning after the opening so that it wouldn't feature in the critics' remarks, isn't a Broadway first: Nicholas Nickleby; Kevin Spacey in The Iceman Cometh ; and, for a while, even Miss Saigon charged the same, while many other Broadway shows, including Cabaret and Follies, are only $10 cheaper, as The Producers was at the start. But it's the first time that an open-ended run of a show has ever given over so much of an auditorium to such a pricey ticket, with some of Broadway's more hysteria-prone habitués arguing further that the producers of The Producers should open a second company of the same show in Manhattan to meet demand.

Indeed, despite talk of The Producers displacing The Lion King and running for decades, you wonder what it will be like several casts on, once the comic tornado that is Lane's Max Bialystock has left the show and, with him, Broderick's quaveringly sung but likeable Leopold Bloom, the accountant blessed with Astaire-like terpsichorean gifts. (Nor ought one to overlook a supporting ensemble sporting such ripe theatre talents - and New York stage regulars - as Roger Bart, Gary Beach and, playing Bloom's Swedish love interest with the unpronounceable name, Cady Huffman, a singer with legs as long as the Empire State Building.)

For one thing, Lane has a number, 'Betrayed', which recaps the entire show, and it comes so tailormade to his outsized talents that one feels Broadway history being born, as it once regularly was in the same vanished era of Ethel Merman and, yes, Mostel, to whom The Producers pays homage.

London will surely get the show - some are saying as early as next March, possibly at the Dominion - but that's to wrench a particular urban phenomenon out of its very specific context. Ideally, The Producers should be seen in the same New York that Bialystock sings plaintively of once having ruled: 'I used to be the king/ the king of old Broadway,' he laments in one of the 17 fresh numbers that composer-lyricist Brooks has provided for his show. (The movie had two.) Now, Broadway has a new king blessed with an old-style chutzpah and heart. Max Bialystock, not to mention Mel Brooks, can relax.

Broadway's all-time longest running shows

1. Cats 7,485 performances
2. A Chorus Line 6,137
3. Oh! Calcutta (revival) 5,962
4. Les Misérables, 5,815*
5. The Phantom of the Opera 5,526*
6. Miss Saigon 4,095
7. 42nd Street 3,485
8. Grease 3,388
9. Fiddler on the Roof 3,242
10. Life with Father 3,224
* denotes still running

 Matt Wolf is London theatre critic for Variety

The stars are two previous Tony-winners who are much loved in New York: Matthew Broderick, now on screen in You Can Count On Me, and Nathan Lane, whose credits include Guys and Dolls and Noël Coward on Broadway. The Producers isn't just a hit; it's a fully-fledged event in a city that thrives on such things, and its cultural repercussions look sure to be felt in English-speaking theatre the world over, although given its subject matter, the show seems an unlikely export to Germany. The plot in the main follows that of Brooks's movie, in which Zero Mostel and Gene Wilder played two New York nogoodniks, Bialystock and Bloom, who deliberately conceive the worst musical ever, Springtime For Hitler, with the aim of absconding with their backers' dosh. Instead, their would-be flop is a hit, even with Hitler played by a drug-addled hippie called LSD (that character has been droped from the stage version as doubtlessly just too 1960s for today). Brooks won an Academy Award for his screenplay. But the road from celluloid to the stage isn't necessarily a smooth one - look at the West End's ever-evolving The Witches of Eastwick, which opened last summer in London to decidedly mixed reviews. What's more, in these obsessively PC times, you would have to possess a combination of hubris and devil-may-care glee to think about staging a show that sends up Nazis, blacks, Jews, gays - hell, even little old ladies - with equal abandon, as The Producers so merrily does. That person exists in Mel Brooks, 75 this year. Here is someone people thought was in the twilight of his film career now embarking upon an altogether new one: the theatre. 'The long-ago dream of the nine-year-old Brooklyn boy has at last come true,' Brooks wrote in the New York Times before the show's opening. 'I hope for the best, expect the worst.' And yet, even he could not have realised to what extent his dream would end up being the one so evidently shared by New York audiences and critics, desperate for a real musical with singing and dancing and laughs after decades of through-sung (and mostly Britain-originated) pop operas and Sondheimian angst. 'Oh, boy!' exulted John Heilpern in the New York Observer. 'When things go right! Mel Brooks's The Producers is quite simply the best time you could ever wish for at the theatre.' Over at the New York Times , Ben Brantley offered up the sort of encomium he traditionally reserves for visiting British imports like Skylight, Janet McTeer in A Doll's House or New York's current Mnemonic . 'How do you single out highlights in a bonfire?' ran Brantley's opening sentence. 'Everybody who sees The Producers - and that should be as close to everybody as the St James Theatre allows - is going to be hard-pressed to choose one favourite bit from the sublimely ridiculous spectacle.' Certainly, the packed Sunday-matinée crowd with whom I watched the show cheered so heartily that it gave pause for thought. True, the Broadway musical has always feasted on shows about showbiz, from Kiss Me, Kate through to Gypsy, A Chorus Line and 42nd Street (a lavish twentieth-anniversary Broadway revival of which opens on Wednesday). But what does it say about American society when a piece featuring dancing jackboots and tapping zimmer frames (one of Stroman's more inspired touches) is received so rapturously? 'I really felt what people must have felt at the opening of My Fair Lady,' says the Broadway producer Carole Shorenstein Hays, who attended a Producers first night more reminiscent of a Hollywood than a Broadway opening. Consider the guest list: Demi Moore, Alec Baldwin, Glenn Close, Sex and the City's Sarah Jessica Parker (who happens to be Producers co-star Matthew Broderick's wife). For once, however, the celebrities weren't the story; the show itself was. Here is a love letter from Broadway to itself, told with the sort of theatrical nous and panache that doesn't exist any more. It is also, of course, a distinctly American show - take that, Lord Lloyd-Webber and Sir Cameron!, or so one gleaned from the subtext of the reviews - as well as the work of a team of individuals, not the latest corporate concoction from Disney. (According to a report this week in the New York Post, Stroman alone could earn as much as £25,000 a week for her work on the show.) The New York theatre has long felt ambivalent about hosting one visiting British behemoth after another (last year's closing on Broadway of Cats was greeted with relief rather than regret), not to mention utterly impotent in the face of the Disney machine, notwithstanding its respect for The Lion King 's visionary director, Julie Taymor. As for sondheim, Broadway holds its leading composer dear while simultaneously acknowledging that he caters to a rarefied market. In any case, his only real commercial hit, A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, was first seen almost 40 years ago, and exists in the raucous musical comedy tradition that The Producers carries forward (and that Sondheim's subsequent career has virtually ignored). Prior to The Producers, the Broadway season's most anticipated opening was the first-ever New York revival of Sondheim's 1971 Follies. But it may not just be the problematic nature of Matthew Warchus's bare-bones staging that has seen Follies fully eclipsed by The Producers. (The latter show even includes the earlier one in its roll call of Broadway pastiche, which includes Fiddler on the Roof, Cabaret and, in a delicious visual gag, Cats .) As Michael Feingold put it in the Village Voice: 'After decades of musical-theatre pundits declaring that musicals have to be solemn, unpleasant and good for you, The Producers represents a recoil so extreme that the aesthetic pendulum seems to have jammed at the other end.' Not that such cavils will matter much to audiences. Ticketbuyers have been snaking around the block, a rare sight these days in New York, where most such transactions take place over the phone, with demand so intense the day after opening that two neighbouring (and rival) Broadway theatres opened their box offices to accommodate the overspill. At present, the show looks set to recoup production costs totalling some £7.5 million ($10.5m) within 35 weeks, with advance sales up to £12.5m ($20m) and the top ticket a hefty $100, or £65. That last manoeuvre, cannily announced the morning after the opening so that it wouldn't feature in the critics' remarks, isn't a Broadway first: Nicholas Nickleby; Kevin Spacey in The Iceman Cometh ; and, for a while, even Miss Saigon charged the same, while many other Broadway shows, including Cabaret and Follies, are only $10 cheaper, as The Producers was at the start. But it's the first time that an open-ended run of a show has ever given over so much of an auditorium to such a pricey ticket, with some of Broadway's more hysteria-prone habitués arguing further that the producers of The Producers should open a second company of the same show in Manhattan to meet demand. Indeed, despite talk of The Producers displacing The Lion King and running for decades, you wonder what it will be like several casts on, once the comic tornado that is Lane's Max Bialystock has left the show and, with him, Broderick's quaveringly sung but likeable Leopold Bloom, the accountant blessed with Astaire-like terpsichorean gifts. (Nor ought one to overlook a supporting ensemble sporting such ripe theatre talents - and New York stage regulars - as Roger Bart, Gary Beach and, playing Bloom's Swedish love interest with the unpronounceable name, Cady Huffman, a singer with legs as long as the Empire State Building.) For one thing, Lane has a number, 'Betrayed', which recaps the entire show, and it comes so tailormade to his outsized talents that one feels Broadway history being born, as it once regularly was in the same vanished era of Ethel Merman and, yes, Mostel, to whom The Producers pays homage. London will surely get the show - some are saying as early as next March, possibly at the Dominion - but that's to wrench a particular urban phenomenon out of its very specific context. Ideally, The Producers should be seen in the same New York that Bialystock sings plaintively of once having ruled: 'I used to be the king/ the king of old Broadway,' he laments in one of the 17 fresh numbers that composer-lyricist Brooks has provided for his show. (The movie had two.) Now, Broadway has a new king blessed with an old-style chutzpah and heart. Max Bialystock, not to mention Mel Brooks, can relax. Broadway's all-time longest running shows 1. webTitle: Simon Callow: Sounding off - Don't make The National just more of the same

fields.headline: 'The National should do what it uniquely can do, offering the whole range of world theatre'
fields.standfirst: More Observer Theatre coverage
fields.trailText: Simon Callow responds to Susannah Clapp: the National Theatre must remain unique, not provide more of the same.
fields.body:
The departure of Trevor Nunn from the National Theatre is a perfectly appropriate moment at which to reconsider the purpose and value of the organisation, but Susannah Clapp's analysis of what needs to be done is deeply unhelpful (The Observer, 22 AprilSusannah Clapp: It's time for the National to be shaken up - and stirred).

Her simple, all-purpose solution, the same one that is always wearily trotted out - get the unquestionably charismatic Stephen Daldry - ignores the question of what the place is for. Her litany of shortcomings - why did David Hare do Via Dolorosa at the Royal Court and not at the NT? Why doesn't it do more physical theatre? Why doesn't it do more new plays? Why doesn't it do more non-plays? - absurdly proposes that the National should excel at every form of theatre, be all things to all theatregoers. When this all-engulfing National triumphs, what then will these other theatres do? Close, presumably; they'll be redundant.

No. The National should do what it uniquely can do, what it was brought into existence to do - create a living, evolving organisation offering the whole range of world theatre, subject to perpetual reinvention and rediscovery. The best way to do this is by establishing a permanent group of actors who, by working together over a period of years, constantly training and retraining and regularly being exposed to the world's most brilliant directors, developing the sort of rapport and trust that a symphony orchestra, for example, has a collective brilliance which enables real and profound risks to be taken. Impossible? Undesirable? But this is exactly what the National Theatre was when it was founded by Laurence Olivier.

The greatest actors in the country and the absolute cream of the newcomers were all welded into a superb, dragon-slaying ensemble under their heroic leader. In addition to the acknowledged classics, the repertory explored forgotten works from the seventeenth century alongside Beckett; new translations, new plays were constantly commissioned. Ingmar Bergman, Franco Zeffirelli, Victor Garcia, Peter Brook and Jacques Charon came and challenged the company to ever-greater heights, while the theatre's own directors worked as trainers on extending the actors' flexibility and endurance. Movement and voice classes were mandatory for the entire ensemble, from spear carriers like Mike Gambon to Maggie Smith and Michael Redgrave.

The development of the company was always the focus: plays were chosen as much for what they would do to spur on the company as for their inherent value. When the National boldly attempted a musical, there was no question of importing stars who could sing: Jeremy Brett, Geraldine McEwan, Robert Lang, all regular members, not to mention Sir Laurence himself, were cast in the leading parts and immediately began singing and dancing classes.

For nearly five years, the actors who had flocked to the company put up with preposterously small salaries, but inevitably they started to drift away to television, film and the West End. The notion gradually took hold that the National should become more self-sufficient by engendering productions that could transfer profitably. One director after another has wrestled with the intractable problem, creating a great deal of excellent work, but sacrificing in the process the basic governing idea of the National Theatre. Trevor Nunn's heroic attempt to sustain a company proved that there is nothing to compare with the excitement created by collective and sustained artistic endeavour.

Various names apart from Daldry's have been touted, all of them, of course, directors; it has become a truism that only a director has the skills, the foresight, the leadership to run a theatre. One of the key problems of the NT has been the failure to attract or develop extraordinary directorial talent. Could that have something to do with the fact that the incumbent has always been a director himself?

Throughout theatrical history, the actor-managers led the theatre and the greatest of them all, the founder of the National Theatre, made sure that there was a steady stream of exceptional directors, not to mention an outstanding succession of remarkable big-scale new plays. A brilliant leading actor, in conjunction with a literary manager of genius, could transform the National, leading it from the front, making it not just a source of quality product but a unique creative organisation in which every production built on the one before instead of a series of ad-hoc triumphs.

I'm not appealing to some misty past. In terms of vital appeal to the audience, Mark Rylance is arguably the most successful artistic director in the country. The right person for the job at the National? Here's my short list: Ian McKellen, Fiona Shaw, Kenneth Branagh, Barrie Rutter, Steven Berkoff, Antony Sher. All are individuals of exceptional intelligence, energy, passion and talent who have stood up, night after night, year in and year out, in living proof of the power and pertinence of the theatre, celebrating in their own persons and with their unique presences what Edward Bond has so beautifully called the ancient novelties of the theatre.

Let them have a turn at creating a National Theatre which offers something unique to the public, not more of the same, as Susannah Clapp seems to want.

fields.headline: The childcare theorists
fields.standfirst: The writers who have influenced the way we bring up our children, and the facts about childcare today
fields.trailText: The writers who have influenced the way we bring up our children, and the facts about childcare today.
fields.body:
Jay Belsky (1952-) Daycare analyst, pin-up of social conservatives. First year with baby is vital to well-adjusted future. 'Something's got to give as [working] women acquire a new role. What gives is the marriage.'

Penelope Leach (1937-) Champion of 'child-centred' care. Best-selling book Baby and Child, 1977, advises parents to take cue from baby, feed on demand not to timetable. First six months vital. Being apart (e.g.day care) after that is no threat to attachment with mother.

Benjamin Spock (1903-1998) Father of 'instinctive' parenting. 'Trust yourself. You know more than you think.' Let baby cry. Baby and Child Care remains a best-seller.

John Bowlby (1907-1990) Championed 'total maternal care'. Child could be irrevocably damaged if separated from mother at any stage in infancy. Created enormous guilt in 1950s and 1960s among working mothers.

John B Watson (1878-1958) Bitterly opposed intimacy. 'Never hug or kiss your children, never let them sit in your lap. If you must, kiss them once on the forehead when they say goodnight. Shake hands in the morning.'

Childcare in 2001

 Almost 90 per cent of children under three are in non-parental care.

 42 per cent of women and 11 per cent of men stay home if a child is ill.

 61 per cent of working families have a parent away from home during evenings, nights and weekends.

 The Government promises a million more childcare places by 2004.

 Only 4 per cent of parents say child rearing lives up to their expectations.

fields.headline: Lonely Planet: Britain, Lonely Planet, £15.99
fields.standfirst: Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: This straight-talking guidebook will ruffle the feathers of a few tourism bosses, but for visitors and residents it will prove a valuable resource. The highlights section at the beginning of the book provides a useful orientation tool and throws up some unexpected choices.
fields.body:
The Millennium Bridge is the 'cock-up of all cock-ups'; the streets are full of 'liquored-up lager louts' and Land's End is marred by 'crass commerce'. Welcome to the fourth edition of Lonely Planet Britain. This straight-talking guidebook will ruffle the feathers of a few tourism bosses, but for visitors and residents it will prove a valuable resource. The highlights section at the beginning of the book provides a useful orientation tool and throws up some unexpected choices: the small market town of Melrose is listed alongside tourist honeypots such as Edinburgh and Bath while the Tenement House in Glasgow merits a listing with Hampton Court Palace.

It's unfortunate that the advent of foot and mouth has made some chapters seem a little bit wide of the mark. The Lake District chapter laments: 'Ambleside can barely cope with the numbers of walkers in fluorescent outdoor gear.' If only.

 Readers can order Lonely Planet Britain (retail price £15.99) for £12.99 plus p&p. Freephone 0800 3168 171.

fields.headline: Early birds catch the Canaries
fields.trailText: The Canary Islands could soon present a viable alternative to Greece as a destination for island-hopping holidays.
fields.body:
The Canary Islands could soon present a viable alternative to Greece as a destination for island-hopping holidays thanks to a new package from tour operator Eclipse Holidays. Eclipse claims to be the first UK operator to introduce island-hopping in the Canaries, available for summer 2002.

Designed for holidaymakers who like the variety of a multi-island holiday without the hassle of making their own travel reservations, the tours feature the lesser-known islands of La Palma, El Hierro, La Gomera and La Graciosa as well as the more well-known destinations.

The islands are a short hop from each other, with travel by ferry, hydrofoil or flights.

Holidaymakers can choose to start in Tenerife or Lanzarote. A sample 14-night holiday leaving Gatwick for Tenerife (five nights), El Hierro (four nights) La Gomera (four nights) and Tenerife (one night) in early May costs £496, combining bed and breakfast and self-catering.

The number of nights spent in each place and the order in which the islands are visited can both be changed before travel, as can the accommodation, which is mainly in two- and three-star hotels, with upgrades possible.

 For information and reservations, call Eclipse on 08705 010203.

webTitle: Brief encounter with the king of steam

fields.headline: Brief encounter with the king of steam
fields.standfirst: A girlhood dream comes true for award-winning novelist  Kate Atkinson as she drives  one of the  world's greatest steam engines. Additional reporting by Herpreet Kaur Grewal.
fields.trailText: A girlhood dream comes true for award-winning novelist Kate Atkinson as she drives one of the world's greatest steam engines.
fields.body:
I have been in love with steam trains for as long as I can remember. I have railways in my blood. I come from a railway town, my uncle and grandfather were employed at the now-defunct carriage works in my old home town of York. I was brought up in a house beside the York to Scarborough line and spent many a happy hour of my childhood waving to the train drivers.

I also have vivid childhood memories of visiting the small museum that closed to make way for the National Railway Museum in York. In those days, you could climb into the locomotive cabs and touch all those polished brass dials and levers. (And a note to all those men who always tell me that my obsession with trains is a phallic thing: do they honestly think their rather unattractive genitals bear any relation to a 102-ton steel locomotive? I think not.)

My greatest wish has always been to ride on the footplate of a Class A-4 Pacific locomotive, the most magnificent thing ever to come out of an engineering shed. The A-4 Pacific was Britain's very own streamliner, an art-deco 'racehorse' introduced in 1935, just in time for George V's silver jubilee. The A-4s were designed by Sir Nigel Gresley - probably the greatest locomotive engineer the world has ever seen.

In the thirties, the goal of steam was speed and a Doncaster-built A-4 called the Mallard provided it by hurtling through the Lincolnshire countryside at 126mph to became the fastest steam locomotive in the world.

At the time, it must have seemed as though this was only the latest achievement in a race that would go on forever - that better, faster engines would come along and overtake the Mallard's achievement. History, however, knows better and the Mallard now holds the record for steam 'for all time', a poignant phrase on a par with 'the line ended in daughters'.

Falcon, Wild Swan, Kingfisher, Merlin, Silver Fox, Golden Fleece, Sparrow Hawk - once there were 35 A-4s. One was destroyed in a second world war air raid on York and the rest were decommissioned in the sixties, that reign of terror for the steam train. Now there are only six A-4s left, four of which are in Britain. The grande dame herself, the Mallard, takes pride of place in the National Railway Museum.

A chance remark during a newspaper interview resulted in a call from the North Yorkshire Moors Railway, the preservation society now running what was once the Whitby to Pickering line, offering a trip on the Sir Nigel Gresley, the engine named for the great man himself. The line, planned under the supervision of George Stephenson of Rocket fame and opened in 1836, using trains drawn by horses, is one of the oldest in the country. It was closed by British Rail as part of the Beeching cuts in the Sixties.

We set off early from Edinburgh and drive without stopping for breakfast so that when we arrive on the station platform at Grosmont, the sight of the tea-room (with a real coal fire) provides a brief but welcome encounter with coffee and buttered scones.

Grosmont appears completely authentic - a station preserved in time - but, like most of the other features on the line, a considerable portion of it has been cobbled together from the leftovers of abandoned stations - a booking office here, a lamp-post there.

And here she is, the Sir Nigel herself (even locos with male names are female), number 60007, painted in the old BR blue livery and almost pawing at the ground as she works up a head of steam. So it's on with the overalls and on to the footplate with George, the driver, Peter the fireman and Roger, who is the custodian of the engine for the Sir Nigel Gresley Locomotive Preservation Trust.

We are a full complement - the maximum number of crew allowed on the footplate is four. Peter gallantly offers me the fireman's seat, although as the journey progresses it becomes difficult to see when a fireman ever gets to sit down. The job is a lot more than just shovelling coal. For one thing, he has to keep an eye on all those dials so that the boiler doesn't either lose pressure or 'blow-off', that is, build up too much steam, although every time anyone says this I think they're saying 'blow-up'. A little nerve-racking, especially as, when we do let off steam, there is an ear-shattering noise in the cab.

In bright spring sunshine, we set off across the North York Moors which are eerily deserted, having been closed by the spectre of foot-and-mouth disease. We won't be breaking any records today, for although the Sir Nigel holds the postwar record for speed (112mph), restrictions on private railway lines dictate a paltry 25mph.

Everything is somehow as I imagined it: the signalman requesting a shovelful of coal for his fire, the hosing down of the footplate (George runs a clean cab), the exchanging of tokens at every station.

I am in a state of bliss, especially as I get to blow the whistle all the way there and back. Grosmont, Goathland, Newton Dale Halt, Levisham, Pickering - the 18-mile journey takes us past beautiful scenery and bizarre sights, such as the early-warning station at Fylingdales, where the Prisoner-like golf ball shapes have been replaced by an equally surreal receiver that looks like a giant wedge of cheese. The line also boasts one of the steepest gradients in the country - 1 in 49.

Even if you've never been to the North York Moors you will almost certainly have seen this railway and the trains that run on it, in The Secret Garden, Brideshead Revisited and countless other films and television productions. fields.bodyText: I have been in love with steam trains for as long as I can remember. I have railways in my blood. I come from a railway town, my uncle and grandfather were employed at the now-defunct carriage works in my old home town of York. I was brought up in a house beside the York to Scarborough line and spent many a happy hour of my childhood waving to the train drivers. I also have vivid childhood memories of visiting the small museum that closed to make way for the National Railway Museum in York. In those days, you could climb into the locomotive cabs and touch all those polished brass dials and levers. (And a note to all those men who always tell me that my obsession with trains is a phallic thing: do they honestly think their rather unattractive genitals bear any relation to a 102-ton steel locomotive? I think not.) My greatest wish has always been to ride on the footplate of a Class A-4 Pacific locomotive, the most magnificent thing ever to come out of an engineering shed. The A-4 Pacific was Britain's very own streamliner, an art-deco 'racehorse' introduced in 1935, just in time for George V's silver jubilee. The A-4s were designed by Sir Nigel Gresley - probably the greatest locomotive engineer the world has ever seen. In the thirties, the goal of steam was speed and a Doncaster-built A-4 called the Mallard provided it by hurtling through the Lincolnshire countryside at 126mph to became the fastest steam locomotive in the world. At the time, it must have seemed as though this was only the latest achievement in a race that would go on forever - that better, faster engines would come along and overtake the Mallard's achievement. History, however, knows better and the Mallard now holds the record for steam 'for all time', a poignant phrase on a par with 'the line ended in daughters'. Falcon, Wild Swan, Kingfisher, Merlin, Silver Fox, Golden Fleece, Sparrow Hawk - once there were 35 A-4s. One was destroyed in a second world war air raid on York and the rest were decommissioned in the sixties, that reign of terror for the steam train. Now there are only six A-4s left, four of which are in Britain. The grande dame herself, the Mallard, takes pride of place in the National Railway Museum. A chance remark during a newspaper interview resulted in a call from the North Yorkshire Moors Railway, the preservation society now running what was once the Whitby to Pickering line, offering a trip on the Sir Nigel Gresley, the engine named for the great man himself. The line, planned under the supervision of George Stephenson of Rocket fame and opened in 1836, using trains drawn by horses, is one of the oldest in the country. It was closed by British Rail as part of the Beeching cuts in the Sixties. We set off early from Edinburgh and drive without stopping for breakfast so that when we arrive on the station platform at Grosmont, the sight of the tea-room (with a real coal fire) provides a brief but welcome encounter with coffee and buttered scones. Grosmont appears completely authentic - a station preserved in time - but, like most of the other features on the line, a considerable portion of it has been cobbled together from the leftovers of abandoned stations - a booking office here, a lamp-post there. And here she is, the Sir Nigel herself (even locos with male names are female), number 60007, painted in the old BR blue livery and almost pawing at the ground as she works up a head of steam. So it's on with the overalls and on to the footplate with George, the driver, Peter the fireman and Roger, who is the custodian of the engine for the Sir Nigel Gresley Locomotive Preservation Trust. We are a full complement - the maximum number of crew allowed on the footplate is four. Peter gallantly offers me the fireman's seat, although as the journey progresses it becomes difficult to see when a fireman ever gets to sit down. The job is a lot more than just shovelling coal. For one thing, he has to keep an eye on all those dials so that the boiler doesn't either lose pressure or 'blow-off', that is, build up too much steam, although every time anyone says this I think they're saying 'blow-up'. A little nerve-racking, especially as, when we do let off steam, there is an ear-shattering noise in the cab. In bright spring sunshine, we set off across the North York Moors which are eerily deserted, having been closed by the spectre of foot-and-mouth disease. We won't be breaking any records today, for although the Sir Nigel holds the postwar record for speed (112mph), restrictions on private railway lines dictate a paltry 25mph. Everything is somehow as I imagined it: the signalman requesting a shovelful of coal for his fire, the hosing down of the footplate (George runs a clean cab), the exchanging of tokens at every station. I am in a state of bliss, especially as I get to blow the whistle all the way there and back. Grosmont, Goathland, Newton Dale Halt, Levisham, Pickering - the 18-mile journey takes us past beautiful scenery and bizarre sights, such as the early-warning station at Fylingdales, where the Prisoner-like golf ball shapes have been replaced by an equally surreal receiver that looks like a giant wedge of cheese. The line also boasts one of the steepest gradients in the country - 1 in 49. fields.headline: Ask the experts
fields.trailText: Chicago on the menu | Grape expectations | Peace and parties
fields.body:
Letter of the week

Having spent a wonderful fortnight in Ireland last year chugging down the Shannon on an old-style Dutch barge, we would like to cruise farther afield. Do you know of companies in Holland that hire barges? We are aware of the British-based companies that rent white plastic cruisers in Europe, but are looking for something with a more local and traditional flavour.
Simon Applegate by email

The Dutch are keen sailors and there are a lot of vessels available for hire. These boats vary immensely in type and price but if you shop around you can get something to suit your needs and budget. The cheapest option is to hire a botter, a converted fishing boat with long narrow leeboards and sleeping space (for up to eight people) under the deck. Rental periods vary in length and you can negotiate pick-up points and prices. Friesland Boating (Tel: 0031 514 522 607, Fax: 0031 514 522 620) have canal boats for weekly hire ranging in size fromfour berth (£340 per week) to12 berth(£765). Alternatively, Boat Charter Holland (Tel: 0031 515 424 617, Fax: 0031 515 423 290) represents firms all over the Netherlands and should be able to fix you up with some great summer deals.

Chicago on the menu

I'm travelling to Chicago shortly and want to invite some guests out for dinner. Can you recommend somewhere smart, trendy and untouristy? Also, any suggestions for somewhere to stay with the same criteria? I don't mind spending a lot for the right experience.
Sally Rogers by email

Dining out is one of Chicago's highlights. We enjoyed Cyrano's Bistro (001 312 467 0546, 546 N Wells St). It It offers a blend of French and local fare at £20-£40 per head, not including drinks.

For a truly trendy night, the hip district of Bucktown hosts Café Absinthe (001 773 278 4488, 1954 W North) for fine bistro dining at £25-£35.

Prices and availability for accommodation vary greatly, mostly dependent on whether any of the big conventions are in town. The Chicago Convention and Tourism Bureau (001 312 567 8000) can advise.

Architecture buffs will be in their element in the Hotel Burnham (001 312 782 1111). Built as the Reliance Building in the 1890s, it has been lavishly restored. Doubles cost £100 to £190. The City Suites Hotel (001 773 404 3400) offers stylish rooms and suites evoking the city's vaudeville past at similar prices.

Grape expectations

My friends and I are thinking of buying an InterRail pass that connects France with Italy and includes ferries to Greece. As students, we are looking for advice on cheap accommodation; also, does the romantic idea of grape squashing/fruit picking still happen, or is it all done by machines now?
Joanna Scarrott by email

The romance of the vendange (grape harvest) normally lasts about half an hour into your first day! Work is hard and you'll spend long hours under a hot sun, but if you stick at it the money can be good - most people save several hundred pounds during a fortnight-long harvest.

Work Your Way Around the World by Susan Griffiths is the essential starting point for planning a working holiday. There's no shortage of hostels and campsites for travellers InterRailing around Europe in the summer, most of which make themselves known when you arrive in a major city. Try also to spend a few nights on trains and the ferry to Greece, the classic InterRailing experience. This will save you the cost of a bed, while getting you to the next port of call. By joining Hostelling International (YHA in the UK), you can prebook hostel accommodation anywhere on the Continent. Make sure you pick up an international student identity card (ISIC) from your college or university; having one will get you discounts at all sorts of attractions across Europe. Lonely Planet's Europe on a Shoestring is full of hints and tips for budget-conscious travellers.

Peace and parties

I am a 47-year-old single mother with a 14-year-old daughter. She wants a holiday in a hotel, preferably by a beach, where she can meet other teenagers. I want somewhere I can find peace to read and swim and not feel swamped by noise and tourists.
Leonie Bennett by email

What you need to look for is a destination that has a good coastline, which is developed for beach tourism but also has some unspoilt parts. Check out the South of France, the Algarve and, rather surprisingly, the island of Ibiza. Despite its huge clubbing culture and party atmosphere, there are endless miles of secluded coves to which one can escape. Spend the first week at a resort where your daughter can meet people her own age, while you can keep an eye on her. Then, once she's made new friends, you'll be able to take off on your own for a few hours at a time to somewhere quiet and relaxing.

A whale of a time

I think I saw an advert for day trips to Iceland to go whale watching. Was I dreaming?
Andrew J. Hill

Your eyes were not deceiving you. There is a cetacean-spotting day trip available, even if it is a very long day. Superlative Travel (020 8943 8899) offer six departures in May and June from Luton or Manchester for the three-hour flight to Keflavik. As well as a whale-watching trip that boasts a 90 per cent success rate, the tour includes a dip in the thermal waters of the Blue Lagoon and visits puffin cliffs and lava fields. Iceland is the closest place to the UK where you can observe whales in their natural habitat. The trip costs £299, leaves at 7am and returns at 11pm.

Crossing the Sahara

I'm hoping to travel across Africa from west to east, or west to north-east. Do you know if it's possible to cross the Sahara into Algeria or, alternatively, is it possible to travel through Sudan?Phil Coote

Algeria remains on the list of places to avoid, due to continuing unrest, but Lonely Planet receives reports of travellers crossing the continent in an easterly direction via the safer parts of Senegal, Mali, Niger, Chad and Sudan. However, this journey crosses some of the world's poorest countries and is fraught with transport problems, visa hassles and will take at least a month by bus, bush taxi and truck. Planning a trip like this in detail is almost pointless, given the speed at which the situation in a country can change, but you should keep a close eye on the Foreign & Commonwealth Office's advice and ensure you have contacted the relevant embassies for up-to-date visa information. Adaptability and patience should be the first things you pack!

 Our experts Tom Hall and Rachel Suddart will try to reply to as many of your questions as possible. Email us at travel.tips@observer.co.uk, or write to Escape, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1M 3ER.

fields.headline: Quick escapes
fields.standfirst: This week's top recommendations from Travel Editor Jeannette Hyde
fields.trailText: This week's top recommendations from Travel Editor Jeannette Hyde.
fields.body:
Under £200

Ireland: Join the rescheduled St Patrick's Day celebrations in Dublin with Stena Line Holidays (08705 421166) between 18 and 20 May. The festivities were postponed from March due to foot-and-mouth restrictions. Two nights' bed and breakfast in the three-star Mount Herbert Hotel cost £108 per person, including car-ferry travel.

Greece: Enjoy Greece's picture-postcard destination of Parga with its traditional-style houses and maze of streets beneath a castle ruin. First Choice (0870 750 0001) has seven nights' self-catering breaks at the Byzantio Studios, set in a garden of lemon and orange trees, leaving Gatwick on 16 May for £189.

Under £300

Britain: Follow in the footsteps of Bridget Jones by spending a weekend at the Stoke Park Club (01753 717171) near Heathrow. The country club - the venue for a romantic break in the film version of Bridget Jones's Diary - offers two nights' accommodation, champagne and chocolate-dipped strawberries, a signed copy of the book, breakfast and three-course dinner each day for £235 per person. Stay in the Pennsylvania Suite featured in the film for a £100 per night supplement.

Tuscany: Book a room with a view over the Italian countryside with Invitation to Tuscany (020 7603 7111). A one-week self-catering holiday based at the twelfth-century La Torre di Poggiarello, which has panoramic views to Siena, costs from £258 for an apartment sleeping two to three until 12 May.

Cyprus: Lunn Poly (0870 333 4400) is offering seven-night, self-catering breaks with Thomson Holidays for £243 per person departing on 13 May from Newcastle airport.

Under £400

Amsterdam: Pick up some tips on sandcastle building at the International Sand Sculpture Festival at The Hague from 6 May to 3 June with the Amsterdam Travel Service (0870 7275916). A four-night break for a family of four costs £378 including travel by car from Dover or Folkestone.

France: Walk in the Pyrenees and make a pilgrimage to the town of Lourdes with Guerba (01373 826611). The eight-day walking break, which features three days of hiking and two days of optional walks, costs £320 per person, including accommodation in a guesthouse of character and most meals but excluding flights.

Italy: Go by coach with Consort Travel (01709 701701) on 25 May for a week on the laid-back Italian Riviera for £349. The nine-night holiday includes seven nights' half-board in the resort of Diano Marina and two nights' bed and breakfast enroute in France. The price includes pick-ups from around England and Wales plus two excursions in Italy.

Under £500

Granada: Learn the art of Arabic dancing, then relax with a massage and sauna in the old Arab quarter and soak up the atmosphere of the Alhambra Palace with Dance Holidays (01206 577000). Seven nights' bed and breakfast leaving Stansted on19 May, with 10 hours' tuition and nights out costs £495 per person.

South Africa: Take a seven-day fly-drive in Cape Town for £469 with Trailfinders (020 7938 3939). Bookings must be made before 18 May and outbound flights must be taken before 30 June. Accommodation can be booked from £62 per night with breakfast.

Under £600

Morocco: Stay with the Berber people and try to climb Toubkal peak, the highest point in North Africa, on a 15-day High Atlas Trek departing on 5 May with adventure specialist Explore Worldwide (01252 760100). The £595 price includes flights, accommodation and the services of a tour leader.

Beijing: Jade Travel (020 7734 7726) is offering a five-night, fully-escorted tour of Beijing for £559 departing on 9 May from Heathrow. Bed and breakfast accommodation is at the four-star Gloria Plaza and two full-day escorted tours with lunch are included in the price.

Under £700

Uganda: Spend a long weekend on the shores of Lake Victoria with the Uganda Trail for £699, departing on 17 May. The price includes scheduled flights and three nights' half- board at the Ranch on the Lake resort, as well as guided tours of Entebbe and Kampala.

Sri Lanka: Tradewinds (0870 7510004) is offering a 14-night package at the all-inclusive Seashells Hotel in Negombo for £649 between 1 May and 30 June.

fields.headline: Early birds catch the Canaries
fields.trailText: The Canary Islands could soon present a viable alternative to Greece as a destination for island-hopping holidays thanks to a new package from tour operator Eclipse Holidays.
fields.body:
The Canary Islands could soon present a viable alternative to Greece as a destination for island-hopping holidays thanks to a new package from tour operator Eclipse Holidays.

Eclipse claims to be the first UK operator to introduce island-hopping in the Canaries, available for summer 2002.

Designed for holidaymakers who like the variety of a multi-island holiday without the hassle of making their own travel reservations, the tours feature the lesser-known islands of La Palma, El Hierro, La Gomera and La Graciosa as well as the more well-known destinations.

The islands are a short hop from each other, with travel by ferry, hydrofoil or flights.

Holidaymakers can choose to start in Tenerife or Lanzarote. A sample 14-night holiday leaving Gatwick for Tenerife (five nights), El Hierro (four nights) La Gomera (four nights) and Tenerife (one night) in early May costs £496, combining bed and breakfast and self-catering.

The number of nights spent in each place and the order in which the islands are visited can both be changed before travel, as can the accommodation, which is mainly in two- and three-star hotels, with upgrades possible.

 For information and reservations, call Eclipse on 08705 010203.

webTitle: The Observer Profile:   Phoenix the calf

fields.headline: Calf? I nearly died
fields.standfirst:
Her mother died before her eyes, she never knew her father, and she was condemned to death at five days old. But this plucky little heifer didn't know when to give up... and made a government change its mind

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Her mother died before her eyes, she never knew her father, and she was condemned to death at five days old. But this plucky little heifer didn't know when to give up... and made a government change its mind.
fields.body:
For a national symbol, she couldn't have chosen a more symbolic day to be born. Not just any Friday the 13th, appropriate enough for a calf apparently doomed to die. But Good Friday the 13th. Phoenix, the angel-white product of an immaculate (or at least artificial) conception, was born in a barn and was then executed and resurrected. And by so doing, she changed the world.

In our secular nation, little attention was paid to the Christian imagery, although those involved in the Phoenix saga admitted the emotive power of such a tale of resurrection and of cheating death. As soon as Phoenix was discovered alive, vets warned the Exeter Ministry of Agriculture press office that the story would take off. The Egyptian legend she was named after - a mythical bird rising from the ashes - shows the power of such a tale.

But what caused so much outrage was that having survived the slaughter, and been proved to be completely healthy, the men from the Ministry were insisting she still must die.

There have been other animals whose tales have caught the national imagination. Blackie the Donkey after it was reported that she was to be crushed beneath the bottoms of six fat men during a Spanish fiesta. The Tamworth Two, plucky pigs who escaped the slaughterhouse and local police, only to be saved by the Daily Mail. And, in this foot and mouth crisis, Lucky the Lamb.

But Phoenix transcended all these by becoming embroiled in high politics, through the fortuitous timing of a looming general election and a policy of slaughtering healthy animals that was beginning to nauseate farmers, country dwellers and city folk alike.

Tabloids and backbench MPs warned Labour that slaughtering Phoenix would mean slaughtering their election chances. The Government insists that the change in policy, which lifted Phoenix's sentence, was coincidence: the policy that has condemned two million animals would not be changed on the need to save just one, however cute.

The Sun put it satirically on its front page, with a picture of Blair and a gunsight targetted on Phoenix: 'Vote Labour or the calf gets it!' The Government insisted the new policy was merely a refinement.

Good looks and a remarkable tale made Phoenix internationally famous at the age of two weeks. She has appeared in newspapers and television news programmes around the world. Her owners, Michaela and Philip Board, have had to stay up at night not to feed her, but to do radio shows in Sydney, Australia.

She was born on Clarence Farm near Axminister, Devon, her mother a Belgian Blue, and her father a Charolais, an all-white breed prized for their beef. But Phoenix was not born to be a burger, but to breed, her purpose in life to give birth to other cows that will be slaughtered and eaten. Under normal circumstances, she would have lived for many years.

But just after she was born, an outbreak of foot and mouth at a neighbouring farm meant that all animals at Clarence Farm had to be culled within 48 hours even if they were healthy. It was this policy that condemned Phoenix, worth £100, to death.

On Wednesday 18 April, five days after her birth, the overalled Ministry slaughtermen arrived at Clarence Farm, corralled the animals inside the big barn and closed the doors. Philip Board stayed inside his bungalow with his wife and son, Ross.

The slaughtermen administered lethal injections to 15 cows and around 30 sheep. They killed two other calves, both less than a week old. The job done, they left the carcasses behind closed the doors until they could be disposed of.

Five days later, the pile of bodies rotting, more men from the Ministry came to disinfect them. When they opened the doors, amid the putrefying scene of carnage, angelic Phoenix got up and walked towards them, mooing quietly. She had spent five days next to the body of her dead mother.

Startled, the men went back to the bungalow and told the farmer the news. 'I couldn't believe it. I told them they must be joking,' recalled Philip. 'But they weren't.' Nobody knows whether the calf was given the injection and survived, or was simply overlooked.

Despite its miraculous survival, Philip and Michaela knew the calf with no name still had to be culled. 'I was so cross we found her alive among the dead animals. I was fuming that an animal could be treated that way,' said Michaela. 'I phoned Maff and gave them an hour to deal with it, or else I would go to the press.'

An hour passed, and no one from Maff arrived or called back. In fury, Michaela phoned the Express and Echo in Exeter. The farmers realised the calf needed a name, and Michaela suggested Lucky. Philip said a calf born on Friday 13th only to watch its mother killed five days later was anything but lucky, and suggested Phoenix. They took Phoenix to the garage and bottle-fed her.

A photographer took her picture, the story appeared in the local paper and the nationals picked it up. The photo was iconic: the pure white calf peering out of the black background. The photographer later said that if Phoenix had been a dark calf, the image just wouldn't have had the same impact.

A Maff vet gave Phoenix a clean bill of health, but still the Ministry insisted the calf must die. Mr Board phoned his solicitor. A Maff official, a slaughterman and a policeman arrived at the farm, and the Boards stood their ground. They told the Maff official they would need a court injunction. The policeman, there to protect the slaughterman, ended up having to do the opposite. He told the Maff official they would have to leave the land. Phoenix survived the second attempt to kill her. Maff was furious: 'Phoenix has to die. This stand will not alter what we have to do.'

But pleas to spare Phoenix flooded in. The Mirror launched a campaign to 'Save Phoenix from the Ashes'. Animal rights groups and actress Carla Lane threw in their support. Anthony Gibson, regional director of the National Farmer's Union, said the calf's slaughter would 'make King Herod look like a humanitarian'. Tony Banks, Labour MP and former Government Minister, spat: 'I was extremely angry. The idea of slaughtering this animal was totally unacceptable. The officials from Maff are Daleks.'

Phoenix recovered, played with the farm dogs, danced around on her hooves. Clarence Farm was deluged with flowers and cards. The farmer's 11-year-old son Ross said: 'If Maff had a heart, they'd leave Phoenix alone.'

A Maff spokesman denounced the 'hideous sentimentality'. They had a point: after all, most of the animals being culled had been bred for slaughter.

But the national mood was set. On Wednesday, a Downing Street spokesman announced there would be a change in slaughter policy so that healthy animals in neighbouring farms would no longer automatically be killed. It was, of course, nothing to do with Phoenix, but the spokesman admitted: 'As a result, Phoenix will be saved.'

The first Agriculture Secretary Nick Brown knew of the change was when he heard it on the 10 O' Clock News. The switch had been made in Downing Street, which overruled Maff. Brown was furious but made a dutiful statement to the Commons. It wasn't a relaxation but a revision: vets would be given more discretion on whether healthy animals would be culled or not. In fact, they had had this discretion all along, but weren't using it.

Phoenix's reprieve was widely celebrated. The Boards rejected a tabloid's offer to buy the calf, insisting she was now a pet. Her remarkable tale crystallised a widespread but muted revulsion against the slaughter of healthy animals and she became the perfect symbol at the perfect time. She can now live the rest of her life in peaceful obscurity.

Phoenix the calf

DoB: Good Friday, 13 April 2001

Appearance: Cuddly white fluffy toy

Hobbies: Playing with the dogs on Clarence Farm, dancing on her hooves and being bottle fed with milk

Family: Mother culled in front of her

Big moment: Surviving to become international celebrity and changing Government slaughter policy at the age of two weeks

webTitle: Classicwatch: Wind, Sand and Stars by Antoine de Saint Exup*ry

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: Into his own history he weaves the stories of nomadic Arabs he meets, and the courage of fellow pilots, but the climax of this slim and beautifully written book is the tale of his near-fatal crash in the Libyan desert
fields.body:
Wind, Sand and Stars
Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
Penguin Classics £6.99, pp119
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, best known for The Little Prince , became obsessed with aviation as a boy, and in 1926, after qualifying as a military pilot, he began flying for the airline Latécoere, opening up the first mail routes across the Sahara and the Andes.

Wind, Sand and Stars , first published in 1939, is his poetic account of the five years spent in pioneering flights for Latécoere. The perils of early flight are not romanticised - the unreliable engines, the terrifying weather of desert and mountain. But Saint-Exupéry evokes with the pure passion of the adventurer how it feels to look down over uncharted territories. 'Those who have experienced the inexpressible love of flying will understand me fully.'

Into his own history he weaves the stories of nomadic Arabs he meets, and the courage of fellow pilots, but the climax of this slim and beautifully written book is the tale of his near-fatal crash in the Libyan desert in 1936. The description of his survival is unemotional and profoundly moving.

fields.headline: Bring me  sunshine
fields.standfirst:
Beat the summer hordes and soak up some early rays on a relaxing spring break. Liz Bird suggests 20 of the best getaways
Late offers
fields.trailText: Beat the summer hordes and soak up some early rays on a relaxing spring break. Liz Bird suggests 20 of the best getaways.
fields.body:
Pay less and avoid the crowds by heading to the sunshine hotspots before the peak holiday months of July and August. The weather is still likely to be warm but prices can be as much as a third cheaper than holidays in the main summer season.

It's also the best time for walking and wildflowers in places such as Crete, Corsica, Majorca and Madeira. And if you go now, your holiday won't be spoilt by children hogging the swimming pool.

There's still availability left for May and June departures. Here's our guide to 20 of the best spring getaways:

Malta

Keen divers can get their fix of underwater wonders on a diving short break with Regal Holidays on the Maltese island of Gozo (0870 2201 777). A four-night stay at the Divers Lodge in May and June costs £449 per person and includes flights from Gatwick or Heathrow, transfers and all diving. Non-divers can try snorkelling or do a 'try dive'.

The Italian Lakes

Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333) is offering three-night breaks to the four-star Hotel Sirmione in Lake Garda from £451 per person in May and June. Guests can dine under the stars on the waterside terrace or swim in the outdoor or indoor pools. Return flights to Verona, return car transfers and B&B accommodation are included in the price.
More on Italy

Morocco

Spring is the perfect time to visit Marrakesh before the searing summer heat makes it uncomfortable. Worldwide Journeys (020 7386 4646) features the centrally located four-star Tichka Hotel which is decorated with Moorish tiles, fab rics and furniture. The swimming pool is set in landscaped gardens next to the restaurant. A three-night break starts from £375 per person based on two people sharing and includes return flights from London, transfers and B&B accommodation.
More on Morocco

Turkey

Want to guarantee you're not going to share the hotel swimming pool with lots of screaming kids? The mountain-top Dionysos hotel and apartments in Kumlubuk, Turkey has banned children under 12 between 29 April and 8 July. Tapestry Holidays (020 8235 7777) is offering week-long holidays at the hotel from £475 per person until 26 May. Flights, transfers, B&B accommodation and a day's sailing trip on a gulet are included.
More on Turkey

The Dordogne Valley

Belle France (01797 223777) still has availability throughout May on its eight-night Dordogne valley cycling holiday. Guests follow a pre-planned route and have their luggage transported to the next hotel. A self-drive holiday starts from £598 per person including eight nights' half-board accommodation in four hotels (all with swimming pools), bike loan, route guides and short Channel crossing.
More on France

Andalucia

Spring is the best time to experience the mountain wilderness of the Grazelema National Park in southern Spain. A four-night break at the Cortijo El Horcajo hotel costs from £479 per person until 22 May with The Real Spain (020 8686 3638). The hotel is set in extensive grounds with a swimming pool and sun terraces.
More on Spain

Dubai

The sail-shaped, five-star Burj Al Arab in Dubai is not your average hotel. Set on an island, the all-suite hotel boasts the world's largest atrium lobby, a restaurant at 200 metres overlooking the Arabian Gulf and an underwater restaurant reached via a submarine. Somak Holidays (020 8423 3000) is offering three-night breaks for £1241 per person based on two people sharing including flights, transfers and room-only accommodation.

South-west France

Discover the windy country roads and hill-top villages of Cathar country on the back of a motorbike. The Midi Pyrenees Tourist Office (020 7355 4747) has designed a three-night tour of the region on a 500cc motorbike for £336 per person in May. Half-board accommodation in two- and three-star hotels, hire of the motorbike, mileage and a travel pack are included in the price. Transport to the region can be arranged.
More on France

Monte Carlo

Hang out with the jetset at the five-star Hotel Hermitage in Monte Carlo with Cresta Holidays (0870 161 0910). Guests are transferred by helicopter from Nice airport to the hotel which offers complimentary entrance to the casino along with free use of the Monte Carlo Beach Club and the Thermes Marins Spa. A two-night package costs from £592 per person including return flights from Heathrow and continental breakfast.

Tuscany

Inntravel (01653 629010) is offering seven-night walking breaks through the hill-top towns of Tuscany for £689 per person. Part of the walk takes you through the Etruscan Volterra to San Gimignano and medieval Siena. Accommodation is in three- or four-star hotels on a B&B or half-board basis. Return scheduled flights, rail and taxi transfers, maps and luggage transportation between hotels are included in the price.
More on Italy

Madeira

The green island of Madeira is at its most lush now. A two-night weekend break at the five-star Crowne Plaza Resort (0800 897 121) in the capital Funchal costs from £105 per person per night until 23 June. Facilities include a thalassotherapy marine spa, fitness centre and scuba diving centre.
More on Portugal

Cyprus

They don't come much more luxurious than the five-star Anassa hotel in Paphos, Cyprus. The beachfront property is set in landscaped gardens and has whitewashed and terracotta-tiled villas, three swimming pools and a thalassotherapy spa. The Mediterranean Experience (020 8445 6000) is offering five-night breaks from £910 per person including flights and transfers.
More on Greece

Lanzarote

Fancy staying in a villa with your own swimming pool and private garden? Guests staying at the Garden Villas in the five-star Gran Melia Salinas hotel in Costa Teguise, Lanzarote, can even choose what kind of pillows and sheets they want on their bed. A seven-night stay based on two people sharing starts from £1,615 per person during May with Sovereign (08705 768 373). Return flights, transfers and B&B accommodation are included in the price.
More on Spain

Tunisia

Go on a desert safari in Tunisia with Cadogan Holidays (02380 828302). The three-day, two-night trip takes in some of the locations used in the English Patient such as the mountain oasis of Tamerza along with the underground dwellings of the Berbers at Matmata. The safari costs £129 per person including accommodation, breakfast and dinner. The trip can be combined with a three-night stay at the five-star Amir Palace hotel in Monastir, which costs from £409 per person including flights from London Gatwick, transfers and taxes.
More on Tunisia

Greek Islands

The Greek Islands Club (020 8232 9780) is offering a seven-night holiday in Lefkas from £571 per person. Guests stay in the terraced cottages in Ulysse on a picturesque hillside overlooking the sea. The price includes return flights, transfers, seven nights' villa rental, car hire and maid service.
More on Greece

Italy

Villa holiday specialist Something Special (08700 270 520) has reduced the price of selected villa holidays in May. Among them is Casa L'Vento, a four-bedroom villa with a private pool located halfway between Rome and the Adriatic Coast. A one-week break now starts at £335 per person based on six people sharing.
More on Italy

Provence

Abercrombie & Kent (0845 0700 612) is offering three-nights at the Chateau De Berne in the heart of Provence from £665 per person. Set in extensive grounds with woods and gardens, the hotel grows its own organic vegetables. A health spa, outdoor swimming pool, tennis courts and boules are among the facilities. Each of the 19 air-conditioned rooms and suites have a private balcony or sun terrace.
More on France

Majorca

Chill out at the Hotel La Residencia in north west Majorca with Castaways (01737 812255) The four-star hotel is made up of two manorial houses furnished with antiques and decorated with contemporary art. Two heated swimming pools with terraces, a gym, sauna and two tennis courts are among the extensive facilities. A seven-night stay starts from £687 including flights, transfers and breakfast.
More on Spain

Tenerife

If you like small, characterful hotels then the San Roque in north-west Tenerife is for you. Situated in the colonial town of Garicho, the seventeenth-century townhouse has 19 rooms overlooking a central courtyard with a small, heated swimming pool. Each room has a CD player, satellite TV, video and bathroom with Jacuzzi. Seven nights in mid-May cost £718 per person with Bonaventure (020 8780 1311) and include return flights from Gatwick, private transfers and B&B accommodation.
More on Spain

Corsica

The best time to go to this mountainous Mediterranean island is May and June when the wildflowers are blooming and before Italian tourists descend in peak season. Corsican Places (01903 748180) has reduced the cost of one-week villa breaks by up to £200 for departures on 20 May. Seven nights at the hill-top Terra Marina villa above the harbour town of Bonifacio cost £299 per person including return flights from London Gatwick and car hire.
More on France

Tapestry Holidays (020 8235 7777) is offering week-long holidays at the hotel from £475 per person until 26 May. Flights, transfers, B&B accommodation and a day's sailing trip on a gulet are included. fields.headline: Swatch Bikini Watch
fields.trailText: The removable dial of this ultimate beach accessory attaches on to bikini bottoms for a chic and stylish timepiece.
fields.body:
Kiss watch-strap marks goodbye but still make sure you know when it's time to put on more sun cream with Swatch's new bikini watch. Called Rainbow, the removable dial of this ultimate beach accessory attaches on to bikini bottoms for a chic and stylish timepiece. It comes with its own bikini too - a black and white number. The swimming costume, made from polyester, is available in one adjustable size. The watch, with a red face and white surround, secures one side of the bottoms while the other side is held by a see-through Swatch badge. And the watch won't just look good on the beach - it is waterproof to a depth of 30 metres. In the evenings, the timepiece can be removed and worn in the traditional way with a separate white tie-on strap.

 The watch and bikini cost £55. Check them out on www.swatch.com. For stockists and direct mail order, call 02380 646830.

webTitle: Indian rope trick on body and soul

fields.headline: Indian rope trick on body and soul
fields.standfirst: Jennifer Coyle  pleads to be treated gently after opting for an authentic Ayurvedic massage in Kerala
fields.trailText: Jennifer Coyle pleads to be treated gently after opting for an authentic Ayurvedic massage in Kerala.
fields.body:
Now that you can get a Brazilian wax and French manicure on every corner, the beauty cognoscenti are anxiously seeking out the next exotic treatment. The word is that Ayurvedic treatments, in particular the massages based on this ancient Indian medicine system, are the 'new black' of the beauty world, just as Kerala is the new Goa.

Conveniently, Kerala is also the self-styled home of all things Ayurvedic, so where better to try an authentic massage? I scanned the Massage Menu at Doctor Franklin's Ayurvedic Centre and decided to go for the Keralan Speciality.

I was expecting a temple of warbling New Age music, perfumed oils and smiling masseuses in white coats. The room I was shown into was more reminiscent of an S&M dungeon; pitch black and empty but for a rubber mattress on the floor with a rope swinging ominously above it and an equally portentous examination table in the corner. What exactly did this Keralan Speciality involve?

A tiny sari-clad woman marched in, briskly warming a bottle of oil between her doll-sized hands. 'On your FRONT!' she ordered and I hit the deck, or rather the greasy mattress. Rolling up her sari in a businesslike manner, she bounced on to the mattress with the agility of a 10-year-old. She poured sweet-smelling sandalwood oil on to my back, my neck, my legs and then she stepped firmly onto my head, took hold of the rope and proceeded to stamp along the length of my body, swinging like Tarzan. Her calloused feet pounded every inch of my body and I gasped as she mercilessly trod out every knotted muscle in turn. Paying no attention to my strangled entreaties to be slightly gentler please, she informed me that she had trained with 'Doctor FRANKLIN, very famous'. This was a great comfort to me.

After the initial bone crunching was over, she dropped to her knees and pummelled me with her gnarled hands, flipping me over like a helpless amoeba at regular intervals. I resigned myself to her dextrous ministrations and even fell into a dazed trance as she kneaded me with incredible strength. Next I was ordered to climb on to the examination table. She massaged my face and feet with featherlight touches, stopping at times to choose different oils, according to my particular Ayurvedic type. Now that the rough stuff was over, I began to feel incredibly invigorated and renewed, as though she had wrung me out from the inside as well.

Ayurveda translates as the 'science of life'. A person can be diagnosed as predominantly one of three body types or 'doshas' - Kapa, Vada or Pitta. Optimum health and wellbeing can be achieved when the three doshas are balanced, through diet and treatments such as massage. Whilst there are Ayurvedic treatments available throughout India, there is some truth to Kerala's claim be the original home of this 5,000-year-old system and there are many renowned schools and institutions here dedicated to the teaching of the principles of Ayurveda. Here you can spend anything from a weekend to a year learning more about this science. In any case, no trip to Kerala is complete without an Ayurvedic treatment, whether it is a massage or a facial.

'So, which Ayurvedic type am I?' I asked my diminutive masseuse, as I paid her 500 rupees (£8) for the 90-minute experience. All I got in response was a toothless cackle and a pitying 'Western type!'. She told me not to wash the oil off for an hour and I staggered off gratefully, greasily, to spread the word about Ayurvedic massages.

 For further information on Ayurvedic treatments and a list of Ayurvedic health centres and practitioners in Kerala, visit www.ayurveda-in.com/ayurveda.html.

webTitle: Tour reps to educate holidaymakers about sun danger

fields.headline: Tour reps to educate holidaymakers about sun danger
fields.trailText: Summer sun seekers travelling with JMC Holidays this year will get tips on 'sun sense' from tour reps. JMC is the first tour operator to link up with the Imperial Cancer Research Fund to promote its 2001 campaign on the dangers of sunbathing.
fields.body:
Summer sun seekers travelling with JMC Holidays this year will get tips on 'sun sense' from tour reps to warn them of the dangers of tanning.

JMC is the first tour operator to link up with the Imperial Cancer Research Fund to promote its 2001 campaign on the dangers of sunbathing. The charity hopes to get other tour operators on board to get the message across.

'Since the advent of cheap package holidays there has been an increase in melanoma [the more serious form of skin cancer],' says the fund's consultant dermatologist, Charlotte Proby. 'We are not saying don't go to the beach. We want people to enjoy the sun, but to enjoy it safely. Intermittent holidays abroad and sun bingeing are very dangerous.'

She says holidaymakers should take sensible measures such as covering up, avoiding the midday sun and wearing a sunscreen of at least SPF15.

A survey by the fund found that we are still keen to soak up the sun. Three-quarters said they liked having a suntan at some time of the year, and a quarter preferred a year-round tan. Some 24 per cent said they would only use low-factor sunscreen and 14 per cent said they would sunbathe with no sunscreen.

There are about 5,000 cases of melanoma a year in the UK, leading to 1,500 deaths.
