fields.headline: Hot air, cold bubbly
fields.standfirst: A giant  balloon goes up for Martin Buckley in Kenya on his mission to hitchhike round the world by air
fields.trailText: A giant balloon goes up for Martin Buckley in Kenya on his mission to hitchhike round the world by air.
fields.body:
With his weathered face and luxuriant moustache, Doug Morey looks as a pilot should. He began flying in the Sixties in the United States Air Force, graduated to private charter work and, when he got bored with that, went to Africa for six months. 'I never left,' Morey tells me. 'Air traffic control isn't as hi-tech as in Europe. Pilots out here aren't just extensions of somebody's computer. We have to think for ourselves and I like it.'

Morey flies a fleet of small planes for Air Kenya which mostly fly tourists to game reserves. He offered me a spin to the Masai Mara. Our flight included a giddy 200-second hop between two air strips, which he was set to enter for the Guinness Book of Records as the world's shortest commercial flight until he heard there was a shorter one in the Orkneys.

He dropped me at a place called Little Governors' Camp, run by a friend of his, Murray Levett. It turned out to be a Hemingwayesque former hunting camp, where tourists sipped tea in front of luxurious tents around a lake where hippos wallowed. Armed Masai guards looked on keenly. Murray makes a living designing and building these Edenic camps.

If that seemed like the good life, I had yet to meet Robin and Greg, the pilots of the camp's balloons, which fly tourists across the Mara at dawn, before a champagne breakfast in the bush (Governors' is proud of its status as Kenya's largest consumer of champagne). I wondered if there might be a spare place aboard the balloons, but both were fully booked. We repaired to the bar for a cold glass of the local Tusker beer.

'You're a pilot and you've never been ballooning!' exploded Robin, who has a passion for the sport, and whose uncanny resemblance to another well-known balloonist results in requests for Richard Branson's autograph. After a long and largely liquid lunch, room had been found for me.

Next morning, I watched as two of the world's largest balloons - each 10 storeys high - were inflated, looking in the pre-dawn darkness like a fiery scene out of Dante. I clambered into Greg's wicker basket, he heaved on a rope, an 8ft tongue of flame leapt into the canopy and we were airborne.

It was starting to get light. The sky grew slowly pink, revealing the River Mara shrouded in silver mist. Suspended at 1,500ft, we watched the rising sun cast long shadows across a landscape of emerald marshes and honey-coloured grasses, awakening flocks of birds and herds of buffalo and antelope. We could also see the ground crew, their Land Rovers tracing our course, carrying a cargo of eggs and bubbly. We watched a male leopard slinking through tall grass close to a herd of impala. The American woman beside me murmured: 'This is the best experience I have ever had.'

After 90 minutes aloft, Greg asked: 'Where shall we land?' 'How about next to Robin?' said an adolescent wag. Robin had landed ahead of us, far to our right and everyone knows balloons can't be steered.

'I'll do my best,' said Greg. For 10 minutes, he felt his way forward, intuitively working the light airs that, at different altitudes, blew in slightly different directions. Sometimes, we rose high; at others, the basket was so low that it brushed the grass. To our astonishment, Greg brought us precisely to the other balloon and laid the basket to earth without even a bump. As I climbed out, corks popped and the smell of eggs and bacon filled the still morning air.

fields.headline: Press freedom campaign: introduction
fields.trailText: Welcome to The Observer's new press freedom campaign pages - our attempt to highlight and contribute to the many struggles for press freedom around the world.
fields.body:
Welcome to The Observer's new press freedom campaign pages - our attempt to highlight and contribute to the many struggles for press freedom around the world.

Launched to mark this year's World Press Freedom day on Wednesday May 3rd 2001, this campaign will seek to take forward The Observer's long history of engagement with issues of internationalism and human rights - for example, the fledgling Amnesty International was launched through an article in the newspaper on its opening day in 1961 - by seeking to take advantage of the increased ability of international networking which new technologies make possible.

We have chosen to begin by asking journalists from around the world to tell their stories of the many and innovative ways in which they are fighting to gain or protect the freedom of the press, and are indebted to the many journalists and organisations who assisted

These diverse accounts show how the particular circumstances in which journalists seek the opportunity to do their job, and play their role in a democratic society, differ widely. But they also speak of a universal aspiration to be allowed to speak truthfully and investigate openly - and demonstrate that, while those who can offer assistance from outside may have increasing opportunities and duties to help those who want support, the pressure and drive for change and reform everywhere in the world comes from within.

Further accounts and resources will be added to these pages shortly - including a short guide to the best of the press freedom web . Our intention is to continue this campaign by highlighting, on a monthly basis, particular issues and cases surrounding press freedom.

If you have suggestions and ideas about the future direction of this campaign - or if you would like to receive occasional updates by email (which we do not envisage sending out more than around once a month), please email sunder.katwala@observer.co.uk

For more information on world press freedom day, please see:

World Press Freedom Day, World Association of Newspapers

UNESCO World Press Freedom site

Information on the World Press Freedom 2001 survey, from Freedom House

Freedom Forum - International media news

webTitle: Sport fever 'turns the French into cretins'

fields.headline: Sport fever 'turns the French into cretins'
fields.trailText: France is becoming more stupid and its political life is being destroyed because of the nation's growing obsession with sport, according to a leading French philosopher.
fields.body:
France is becoming more stupid and its political life is being destroyed because of the nation's growing obsession with sport, according to a leading French philosopher.

Robert Redeker suggests it would be a terrible misfortune if Paris succeeded in its campaign to host the 2008 Olympic Games - a bid launched with great media hype and thousands of car stickers bearing the legend ' Paris 2008 - Oui! '

Redeker says the impact of sport has been totalitarian and has 'impoverished the lives and intelligence of millions of men'.

'A crime has taken place against society and against political life,' he argues. 'And sport is the assassin. It has got rid of a real community of political life and replaced it with an ersatz, phoney community united by sport. It's a perfect crime: we don't see the body because the victim gives off the impression of still being alive. But sport has installed a phoney community in the place of the victim, which is the people united in the form of a political community.'

Redeker says the 1.5 million people who celebrated on the Champs Elysées the victory of France's football team in the 1998 World Cup 'gave the impression of having really come alive', but in fact they were all victims - assassinated by the woeful impact of sport.

'Political life has been discredited by all the legal cases and corruption, while all the opinion polls put sportsmen and women on the summits of collective admiration,' laments Redeker, an editor at the influential philosophical review Les Temps Modernes.

Even scandals - the exposure of drug-taking in the Tour de France, footballers with false passports and rigged matches - have not undermined this admiration. In fact, he argues, scandals have become fodder for endless chat about sport - the ruin of Tour de France cycling star Richard Virenque's career after he admitted drug-taking, or the disappearance of sprinter Marie-José Perec before her Olympic Games clash with Australian Cathy Freeman have been two of the biggest media stories of recent months.

Ever since France won the World Cup at the Stade de France near Paris, the country has become obsessed with sport. Historically, the French have enjoyed participating in sports more than their British neighbours, but have been less interested in being spectators.

French teams seldom did well internationally - their record in the Olympic Games before 1996 was feeble (in 1976, for instance, France came eighteenth), but this changed at Atlanta in 1996 when the French won 15 gold medals (compared with Britain's one).

As a result of such triumphs, sport often dominates conversations in bars and even seeps into the columns of newspapers such as Le Monde and Libération, which hitherto gave sport a wide berth.

When France's handball team won the world championship in February a headline ran: 'Beaux comme des dieux' ('As fine as gods'). When a French team won the European women's basketball championship this month, they were feted as national heroes. And when Ellen MacArthur came second in the round-the-world Vendée Globe yacht race in February, some patriotic enthusiasts tried to claim her as French.

It is in this context that Redeker made his outburst. He asks exasperatedly: 'It's one of the greatest mysteries of the modern world - how can it be that men in contemporary society don't vomit in disgust at sporting corruption (while they detest it in politics), and still don't get unutterably bored in front of sporting spectacles, which are always the same, cyclical, as if time had been frozen?'

Ever since goalkeeping existentialist writer Albert Camus picked his last ball out of the back of the net more than 50 years ago, philosophers haven't had much time for sport.

The Italian philosopher Umberto Eco wrote an essay in which he confessed he could not share his country's passion for football. In 1998, a French philosopher wrote in Le Monde disparagingly of the football team's World Cup triumph: 'Cette vague footballistique qui crétinise encore plus les Français', a jibe which that perhaps requires no translation.

But Redeker's diatribe goes much further - his is a detailed diagnosis of how sport has corrupted French life. He draws a parallel with Marx's description of religion as the 'opium of the people', arguing that sport is worse than opium.

But why shouldn't the rise of sport in France be a good thing? After all, one of the most symbolic moments in the country's public life came when a French multi-racial team lifted the Jules Rimet trophy three years ago. The team included blacks and Arabs: their triumph took the wind out of the extreme Right's sails and did wonders for race relations.

'It's a typical French intello having a go,' said one sports fan in a Paris cafe last week while watching France's 4-0 defeat of Portugal on the TV behind the bar. 'All head and no body.'

Vive La France! Recent sporting triumphs

July 1998: France beat Brazil 3-0 in World Cup final to win Jules Rimet Trophy for first time.

October 1999: France beat New Zealand 24-10 in semi-final of Rugby Union World Cup, before going on to lose to Australia in the final. Asked how the unfancied French team had managed to beat the All Blacks, one team member replied: 'The cockerel [France's national emblem] sings loudest when he is knee-deep in shit.'

July 2000: France beat Italy to win Euro 2000 football tournament.

September 2000: France fail to repeat their Atlanta medals triumph at the Sydney Olympics. Sprinter Marie-José Perec leaves Australia before her 400m final, prompting long articles about her existential crisis.

February 2001: France wins seventeenth world handball championship, prompting many French youngsters to take up this hitherto unpopular sport.

February 2001: Frenchman Michel Desjoyeaux wins the Vendée round the world race, but Englishwoman Ellen MacArthur, arriving second at Les Sables d'Olonne a day later, captivates France.

webTitle: Gene find will help us to regrow limbs

fields.headline: Gene find will help us to regrow limbs
fields.trailText: Men and women could one day grow limbs lost in accidents or regenerate organs destroyed by illness.
fields.body:
Men and women could one day grow limbs lost in accidents or regenerate organs destroyed by illness. The prospect has been raised by geneticists who have revealed the biological secret of creatures that can replace limbs that have been severed in fights or attacks by predators.

This ability - possessed by animals such as the salamander, which can regenerate entire legs and various species of lizards, which can regrow tails - has baffled scientists for centuries.

But now, thanks to breakthroughs in modern molecular biology, researchers have discovered this process is controlled by a genetic signal switched on in cells of amphibians but turned off in mammals.

'The presence of this activated gene in amphibians allows them to regrow legs,' said Professor Juan Belmonte, of the gene expression laboratory at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California. 'More importantly, its absence explains why higher vertebrate creatures like ourselves cannot regenerate lost limbs.

'That awareness in turn raises the prospect that we could one day intervene and switch on this gene. In other words, we could could regrow lost organs.'

The ability to reverse amputation operations would have a huge medical bonus. However, scientists believe the technique is likely to be of even greater benefit when used to regenerate organs - such as the heart or the liver - that have been destroyed by disease.

For 10 years, Belmonte and his colleagues have carried out experiments in which they have identified chemicals that trigger limb development in chick embryos. They found a chemical called fibroblast growth factor (FGF) initiates limb development. A second signal, TBX, determines what kind of limb it will be: TBX4 produces a hindleg in a chick, while TBX5 initiates a forelimb.

Such research caused great interest when it was first published, and fast food companies wanted to know if chickens could be created with extra legs. They were disabused of the idea.

More recent work by the Salk team has revealed a precursor genetic signal that plays an earlier, crucial role in this biological cascade. This is known as Wnt. Only when it is present, and has activated its associated gene, can the events that lead to limb growth begin.

The Salk team is investigating whether the Wnt gene is permanently switched on in salamanders and lizards, while in higher vertebrates, it is switched off - except briefly during embryo development.

'The trick is to switch on the Wnt gene,' said Belmonte. 'If you could find a chemical that could switch on a person's Wnt gene, then you could introduce the other chemical signals involved in limb growth and so regenerate a lost organ. However, we have to understand a lot more about the whole complex cascade of chemicals that are involved in this business before we can go plunging in at the deep end.'

Mammals appeared long after amphibians evolved on Earth. The latter already possessed the power to regenerate limbs. So why did mammals cast it aside?

'We simply don't know at present,' said Belmonte. 'However, it is very likely the signals that trigger limb regeneration are similar to those that trigger cell division - and are linked to the development of cancer.

'Limb regeneration may be great for salamanders and lizards, but when longer-living creatures - such as mammals - evolved, it left them vulnerable to cancer. So the business was dropped like an evolutionary hot potato.

'If that is true, we clearly have to proceed carefully.' added Belmonte.

webTitle: X-ray vision reveals how Old Master hid his love for the baker's daughter

fields.headline: X-ray vision reveals how Old Master hid his love for the baker's daughter
fields.standfirst: She was the beauty who drove a genius to die of 'sexual excess'. Now restorers believe the painter aimed to make an honest woman of his adored model, La Fornarina
fields.trailText: She was the beauty who drove a genius to die of 'sexual excess'. Now restorers believe the painter aimed to make an honest woman of his adored model, La Fornarina.
fields.body:
She is the woman who is alleged to have driven one of the greatest ever artists to die 'of sexual excess'. To her detractors she is a harpie and a whore. But now it seems that La Fornarina, the baker's daughter who was Raphael's lover and favourite subject, may also have been his betrothed.

Restorers have discovered a crucial new detail on a portrait of Raphael's mistress that he left unfinished when he died in 1520 aged 37. Painstaking X-ray analysis of the painting, undertaken in the course of its restoration in Rome, has revealed a square-cut ruby ring on the third finger of La Fornarina's left hand.

Experts say that such a ring - even on a heavily bejewelled courtesan - would be unusual. In the 1520 portrait, currently on display at the Palazzo Barberini in Rome, it indicates a far deeper bond between the artist and his subject than had previously been suspected - possibly even an engagement to be married. The girl already wears a ribbon around one arm with the artist's name on it.

'It's a beautiful detail in one of the most beautiful love affairs ever. It's very sentimental. When I heard about it I was absolutely overcome,' said one British expert in High Renaissance art last week.

Raphael's love for La Fornarina, whose real name was Margherita Luti, had to be hidden. The artist was known to be engaged to be married to Maria Bibbiena, the niece of his rich and powerful patron, a Roman cardinal.

For six years Raphael, said by the artist and Renaissance biographer Giorgio Vasari to have a 'great fondness for women', procrastinated over the wedding date. Unable to recognise his true love publicly he immortalised La Fornarina in dozens of his major works instead.

Now, with the discovery of the ring, it seems that the couple were in fact betrothed after all - despite Raphael's previous engagement to another woman.

The ring has been hidden for 500 years. Raphael, or possibly his friend and student Giulio Romano who sold the painting shortly after the artist's death, painted over it. Had the truth it revealed been widely known there would have been a damaging public scandal.

Raphael scholars say that the discovery of the ring means that the artist's reputation as a playboy may now have to be reconsidered.

Some say that Vasari unfairly blackened the young artist's image. Vasari records that the handsome and charming Raphael 'was always indulging his sexual appetites'.

He claims that when Raphael, who was born in 1483 at Urbino in the north of the Italian peninsula, was commissioned by the Sienese banker Agostino Chigi to paint his villa on the Tiber embankment in Rome the artist 'could not give his mind to his work' because of his infatuation with La Fornarina, who lived nearby in the bawdy and noisy Trastevere district. Chigi, no mean philanderer himself, solved the problem by moving the girl into the villa.

Vasari says that it was the sexual appetite of the artist, who is best known for his Madonnas and for his large figure compositions in the Vatican, that led to his downfall. His pursuit of sensual pleasures 'with no sense of moderation' resulted in a 'violent fever' which killed him.

But modern art historians believe that the illness was not serious and that the artist died as a result of the bleeding that the Roman doctors thought would cure him.

Vasari does concede, however, that Raphael provided his beloved model with 'the means to live a decent life' in his will. A legend even before his death, he was mourned by the Pope. His last completed work, Transfiguration, rested on his bier and his body was buried in Rome's Pantheon.

fields.headline: Arbitrator speeds up its act
fields.standfirst: Abta overhauls its scheme for handling holiday complaints
fields.trailText: The Association of British Travel Agents (Abta) has cut the time it takes to handle holiday complaints as part of its new-look arbitration scheme.
fields.body:
The Association of British Travel Agents (Abta) has cut the time it takes to handle holiday complaints as part of its new-look arbitration scheme.

Previously, people making an official complaint about a holiday bought from an Abta tour operator would have to wait up to nine months to find out whether they had won their case . Now the same case will take a maximum of three months to be resolved.

The levels of compensation consumers can claim has also increased, from £1,500 to £5,000 for individual cases and from £7,500 to £15,000 per family, to bring it into line with the maximum claims allowed by the Small Claims Court, the alternative avenue for holiday grievances. Keith Richards, Abta's head of consumer affairs, says: 'The increase reflects the fact that holidays have become more expensive, particularly with more people travelling to long-haul destinations.'

Complainants with personal injury or illness claims of up to £1,000 can be heard by an arbitrator for the first time, which also brings the scheme in line with the Small Claims Court.

Holidaymakers who are unhappy with the decision reached by the arbitrator can now take advantage of a new appeals procedure introduced from 1 May. The case will be heard by a senior arbitrator who has the power to reverse an award or revise compensation levels. Around 80 per cent of the 1,300 complaints taken to arbitration last year were won by the holidaymaker. The most common complaints relate to the quality of hotel or self-catering accommodation. Flight delays are another big gripe.

Complainants pay a fee to have their case heard by an arbitrator. Fees range from £72.85 for claims of up to £3,000 to a maximum of £164.50 for claims between £10,001 and £15,000.

 For more information, contact Abta's Information Bureau (020 7307 1907). Complaint forms can be downloaded from the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators' website.

fields.headline: Captain sensible
fields.standfirst: Sweden's Kronan is solid, reliable and very sensible - in fact, it's the Volvo of the bicycle world.
fields.trailText: Sweden's Kronan is solid, reliable and very sensible - in fact, it's the Volvo of the bicycle world.
fields.body:
Among the Lycra tights, drop handlebars, bottom-in-the-air cycling brigade, weight (that of the bike rather than its owner) is the equivalent of the 0-60 reading for sports-car owners. 'Just pick it up,' says the proud owner, as the latest carbon-fibre, titanium, multi-thousand pound offering is displayed to his slavering coterie, and they duly swoon. My first acquaintance with the Swedish-made Kronan bike was a variant on this. I picked it up to howk it into the Observer 's bike shed, and strained my back.

The Kronan weighs, at a rough estimate, at least twice as much as the slender carbon Trek machine on which Lance Armstrong won last year's Tour de France, but, at £150, it will set you back only a 20th of a replica of Armstrong's bike. The comparison is unfair, however: you can't ride an Armstrong bike to work without mortal fear that it will get scratched or nicked, any more than you could drive a Ferrari to the office.

There's a good reason why, in bike terms, the Kronan is more Giant Haystacks than Calista Flockhart. It is bombproof - literally. It is based on a Swedish army design first made 60 years ago and, indeed, the first Kronans to be sold were actually rescued from an army warehouse where they had gathered dust for decades. They were, however, in perfect working order.

In the same way that Volvos have flashing lights to remind you to put on your seatbelt, the Kronan leaves little to chance. It's made of steel, and that steel is heavily enamelled to counter rust - down to the wheel rims. The brake doesn't involve any cables to fray or brake blocks to wear out - it's a hub brake like that of a motorbike. Dynamo lights means no batteries to forget or to fall out when you hit a pothole.

The tyres are bigger than those of many mountain bikes, while the carrier is sturdy enough bear a small field gun. Indeed, it seems to have a small, backwards-pointing gun barrel on it, although closer inspection reveals that, sadly, this is not some device dreamed up by a Swedish Q for wasting couriers with nose rings who take the mickey, but is in fact more prosaic: it's for you keep your pump in. And if you thought that was in the sledgehammers-and-nuts category, it pales next to the sturdy ring of steel to protect the reflector on the mudguard from those who take pleasure in destroying such things.

There is, however, a certain overengineered urban chic - as in work boots and divers' watches - to all of this. There may be too many features, but the same could be said of combats and pockets. And some of the fussiness makes eminent sense: you won't get oily yick on your trousers, as the chain has a solid cover. The huge mudguards (steel again, I suspect) keep you clean as well.

There is a ubiquitous, functional elegance about the Kronan: it is precisely the kind of bike you could imagine carrying John Major's old maid through the mist to communion, but it would look as well-placed chained to the railings outside a minimalist flat in Notting Hill. And the beauty of something this substantial is that, when it is chained to those railings - outside house, office or shop - that if a vandal comes along and attempts GBH, he will come off the worst.

The Kronan has gone down well in Holland, where there is a tradition of riding to work or the shops on bikes like this. And as for its appeal here, you only have to look at the success rate of practical-looking, mildly kooky Swedish products in this country, led by furniture and football coaches. The makers also hope it will be adopted by companies who want to set up bike pools or merely to provide their employees with company bikes. Its numberplate is designed to help you work out which one is yours in the bike shed.

It's a stylish enough and user-friendly enough (and, for the accountants, cheap enough) bike to suit this end, but all that solidity comes at a price. Riding up anything bigger than a railway bridge is like pushing a steam roller out of a ditch. 'No complicated gears to go wrong,' boasts the literature, conveniently and rather patronisingly omitting to mention that gears help you go up hills. And on the Kronan, you need all the help you can get.

If you live in a valley and work on top of a large hill, the Kronan would only be recommended for the masochistic. On the other hand, if you make sure the journey is relatively flat, or take to canal towpaths or converted railway lines such as those in the Sustrans network, you can bowl along, cushioned on those huge tyres. But don't lift it without due care and the number of your osteopath ready to hand.

 For more information, go to www.kronan.co.uk.

The comparison is unfair, however: you can't ride an Armstrong bike to work without mortal fear that it will get scratched or nicked, any more than you could drive a Ferrari to the office. There's a good reason why, in bike terms, the Kronan is more Giant Haystacks than Calista Flockhart. It is bombproof - literally. It is based on a Swedish army design first made 60 years ago and, indeed, the first Kronans to be sold were actually rescued from an army warehouse where they had gathered dust for decades. They were, however, in perfect working order. In the same way that Volvos have flashing lights to remind you to put on your seatbelt, the Kronan leaves little to chance. It's made of steel, and that steel is heavily enamelled to counter rust - down to the wheel rims. The brake doesn't involve any cables to fray or brake blocks to wear out - it's a hub brake like that of a motorbike. Dynamo lights means no batteries to forget or to fall out when you hit a pothole. The tyres are bigger than those of many mountain bikes, while the carrier is sturdy enough bear a small field gun. Indeed, it seems to have a small, backwards-pointing gun barrel on it, although closer inspection reveals that, sadly, this is not some device dreamed up by a Swedish Q for wasting couriers with nose rings who take the mickey, but is in fact more prosaic: it's for you keep your pump in. And if you thought that was in the sledgehammers-and-nuts category, it pales next to the sturdy ring of steel to protect the reflector on the mudguard from those who take pleasure in destroying such things. There is, however, a certain overengineered urban chic - as in work boots and divers' watches - to all of this. There may be too many features, but the same could be said of combats and pockets. And some of the fussiness makes eminent sense: you won't get oily yick on your trousers, as the chain has a solid cover. The huge mudguards (steel again, I suspect) keep you clean as well. There is a ubiquitous, functional elegance about the Kronan: it is precisely the kind of bike you could imagine carrying John Major's old maid through the mist to communion, but it would look as well-placed chained to the railings outside a minimalist flat in Notting Hill. And the beauty of something this substantial is that, when it is chained to those railings - outside house, office or shop - that if a vandal comes along and attempts GBH, he will come off the worst. The Kronan has gone down well in Holland, where there is a tradition of riding to work or the shops on bikes like this. And as for its appeal here, you only have to look at the success rate of practical-looking, mildly kooky Swedish products in this country, led by furniture and football coaches. The makers also hope it will be adopted by companies who want to set up bike pools or merely to provide their employees with company bikes. Its numberplate is designed to help you work out which one is yours in the bike shed. It's a stylish enough and user-friendly enough (and, for the accountants, cheap enough) bike to suit this end, but all that solidity comes at a price. Riding up anything bigger than a railway bridge is like pushing a steam roller out of a ditch. 'No complicated gears to go wrong,' boasts the literature, conveniently and rather patronisingly omitting to mention that gears help you go up hills. And on the Kronan, you need all the help you can get. If you live in a valley and work on top of a large hill, the Kronan would only be recommended for the masochistic. On the other hand, if you make sure the journey is relatively flat, or take to canal towpaths or converted railway lines such as those in the Sustrans network, you can bowl along, cushioned on those huge tyres. But don't lift it without due care and the number of your osteopath ready to hand.  For more information, go to www.kronan.co.uk.

webTitle: Epidemic of hard drugs in schools

fields.headline: Epidemic of hard drugs in schools
fields.standfirst: Survey shows disturbing increase among younger groups
fields.trailText: Survey shows disturbing increase among younger groups.
fields.body:
Hundreds of thousands of British schoolchildren, some as young as 11, have experimented with hard drugs, including heroin and cocaine, and many more use cannabis, amphetamines or glue on a weekly basis, according to a major new survey.

More than one in 100 boys aged 12 said they had tried heroin. A similar number of 11-year-olds said they had tried cocaine. Around twice as many said they had used cannabis, glue or had sniffed propellents and inhalants known as 'gas'.

The findings, based on questionnaires filled in by 20,000 children in 67 secondary schools last year, contradict recent government claims that juvenile drug use is falling.

Last week experts called for a complete overhaul of Britain's drugs education programmes.

The biggest such exercise ever undertaken, the survey is the first to look in detail at the habitual use of drugs by schoolchildren. It aimed to show whether they used drugs regularly rather than on an experimental basis. A user was defined as someone taking drugs on a weekly basis for at least three months.

'The results were very striking,' said Jeremy Gluck, of Adolescent Assessment Services, the Swansea-based consultancy that carried out the survey on behalf of local education authorities. 'Drug use is much more extensive than we thought. The sheer numbers involved are very worrying. Some totals were so high that we genuinely didn't want to believe them.'

The survey found that one in nine 16-year-old boys who admitted using drugs said they did so every day. More than a third used drugs - mainly cannabis, but also harder drugs - at least once a week.

The figures for girls were only slightly lower and nearly 8 per cent of all 16-year-olds said they had been using drugs, including ecstasy and LSD, on a weekly basis for at least three months.

The survey also found that patterns of drug use shifted according to age. A fifth of 16-year-old boys said they preferred cannabis, whereas only one in 50 said they habitually used glue or gas.

It also looked at drinking and smoking. It found that 5 per cent of 11-year-olds and 40 per cent of 16-year-olds drank alcohol on a weekly basis. A fifth of 16-year-old boys said they were 'drunk' - defined as 'feeling sick and falling about' - at least once a fortnight.

The figures confirm a suspected increase in alcohol consumption among youngsters, especially in 'binge' drinking.

According to the research, around one in 20 11-year-olds smoke daily. Nearly a third of 15-year-old girls do so, an increase of more than 40 per cent compared with 1998 official figures. Young smokers' habits are also surprisingly heavy. Around half of all 11- to 16-year-old smokers consume between six and 15 cigarettes daily.

According to Gluck, one of the most significant findings is the importance of smoking and drinking to initiating later drug use. Children most commonly start to use drugs, cigarettes and alcohol between 13 and 14.

There are concerns over the ability of schools to cope with the problem. A recent Ofsted survey found that under 50 per cent of primary schools had a policy on drug-related incidents. Many believe the traditional approach involving lectures by police officers, former addicts and specialists is not effective.

'There is too little, too late,' said Michelle Roe, a director of Life Education Centres. 'There is no point in lecturing 12 year olds, whose attitudes are formed. You have to speak to five year olds.'

webTitle: Council inequalities can cost £20,000 per pupil

fields.headline: Postcode lottery wrecks school funding as red tape divides rich from the poor
fields.standfirst:
Council inequalities can cost £20,000 per pupil

Full ranking of English LEAs
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Council inequalities can cost £20,000 per pupil.
fields.body:
It is the end of the school week and chattering children in neat blue sweatshirts are piling aboard buses that will ferry them to homes scattered throughout local villages.

The headmaster, Ron Berry, watches them with pride: Melbourn Village College in Hertfordshire is a good school where everyone from support staff to teachers, from pupils to parents, work hard to keep standards high.

What the children don't know is that they are a stark example of an iniquitous postcode lottery which has grown up in school funding due to a system of arcane rules and bureaucratic muddle, and has left schools trying to attain national education standards with vastly differing resources.

New figures from the Treasury reveal the location of the school a child attends could make as much as £20,000 difference to the amount the Government spends on his or her education.

If Berry moved his school, brick by brick, just three miles down the road and across the county boundary his annual budget would rise by anything up to £300,000, or £570 per pupil. Critics describe the system of funding as unfair and damaging for many pupils' prospects.

The place with the lowest level of funding is South Gloucestershire where, on average, during a child's school career £26,000 will be spent on their education by the Government. That figure can rise to £41,800 in the well-heeled borough of Kensington and Chelsea in London where higher salaries and better resources mean schools are much better funded.

In Bristol, one of the neighbouring education authorities to South Gloucestershire, pupils can expect to have £29,600 spent on them. Schools a few miles apart, despite having similar catchment areas, can have budgets which differ by hundreds of thousands of pounds a year.

The Government has now ordered a review of what it admits is an unfair system but it is likely to be 2003 before any changes are put in place, despite a pledge by the Labour Party before the last election that the problem would be tackled.

'Now that the Government has got money washing around in its coffers it is time to bring those at the bottom up to the standards of everyone else,' said Peter Downes, a member of the Government's education funding review group and the country's leading expert on school funding. 'We are arguing for a levelling up, not a convergence down.'

Although Downes says that some areas will need extra cash help to deal with problems of social deprivation or remoteness, he says it is now time for a national funding formula which gives schools the same basic entitlement whether they are in Cumbria or Devon.

'We now have a national education system, a national examination system, a national curriculum and national inspection, and yet people are being expected to meet these criteria with inequitable amounts of money,' he said.

The anomalies have grown up since the 1970s when schools were given differential funding levels to try to balance social differences. Local education authorities were also allowed to decide how much top-up money they gave to schools.

The league tables of school funding reveal schools in Leicestershire receive £26,800 to educate each pupil, putting them second only to South Gloucestershire in the 'lowest funded' table. But Leicester itself, the capital of the county, receives £31,500. Kensington and Chelsea receives £41,800, the same amount as the far more socially deprived Lewisham and more than £5,000 more than Brent, which also has a high level of economic and social problems.

Some of the top funded areas include the relatively comfortably-off towns of Slough, Luton, Reading and Brighton.

'These anomalies have grown up over decades; very few people understand how they work and it is about time they were tackled,' said Phil Willis, the education spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, who analysed the Treasury figures.

Melbourn School's problem comes because of a quirk in the postcode system which goes right to the heart of the funding issue. Although the school's address puts it officially in Hertfordshire, it is run under the umbrella of South Cambridgeshire. That means that every one of the 560 pupils in Melbourn School have between £173 and £570 a year less spent on their education than the children who go to Meridian School in Royston, three miles away across the county boundary in Hertfordshire.

This year, primary schools in Hertfordshire will receive £161 more per pupil per year than in Cambridgeshire.

'It is an anomaly that we have long been aware of,' Berry said. 'The figures seem to come out different depending on who you ask, the Treasury or the local education authority, but even if we err on the side of caution we are year on year £100,000 worse off than Hertfordshire schools. That would pay for three more full-time teachers or twice the amount we are presently able to spend on books and equipment.'

fields.headline: IMF's four steps to damnation
fields.standfirst: How crises, failures, and suffering finally drove a Presidential adviser to the wrong side of the barricades
fields.trailText: How crises, failures, and suffering finally drove a Presidential adviser to the wrong side of the barricades.
fields.body:
It was like a scene out of Le Carré: the brilliant agent comes in from the cold and, in hours of debriefing, empties his memory of horrors committed in the name of an ideology gone rotten.

But this was a far bigger catch than some used-up Cold War spy. The former apparatchik was Joseph Stiglitz, ex-chief economist of the World Bank. The new world economic order was his theory come to life.

He was in Washington for the big confab of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. But instead of chairing meetings of ministers and central bankers, he was outside the police cordons. The World Bank fired Stiglitz two years ago. He was not allowed a quiet retirement: he was excommunicated purely for expressing mild dissent from globalisation World Bank-style.

Here in Washington we conducted exclusive interviews with Stiglitz, for The Observer and Newsnight, about the inside workings of the IMF, the World Bank, and the bank's 51% owner, the US Treasury.

And here, from sources unnamable (not Stiglitz), we obtained a cache of documents marked, 'confidential' and 'restricted'.

Stiglitz helped translate one, a 'country assistance strategy'. There's an assistance strategy for every poorer nation, designed, says the World Bank, after careful in-country investigation.

But according to insider Stiglitz, the Bank's 'investigation' involves little more than close inspection of five-star hotels. It concludes with a meeting with a begging finance minister, who is handed a 'restructuring agreement' pre-drafted for 'voluntary' signature.

Each nation's economy is analysed, says Stiglitz, then the Bank hands every minister the same four-step programme.

Step One is privatisation. Stiglitz said that rather than objecting to the sell-offs of state industries, some politicians - using the World Bank's demands to silence local critics - happily flogged their electricity and water companies. 'You could see their eyes widen' at the possibility of commissions for shaving a few billion off the sale price.

And the US government knew it, charges Stiglitz, at least in the case of the biggest privatisation of all, the 1995 Russian sell-off. 'The US Treasury view was: "This was great, as we wanted Yeltsin re-elected. We DON'T CARE if it's a corrupt election." '

Stiglitz cannot simply be dismissed as a conspiracy nutter. The man was inside the game - a member of Bill Clinton's cabinet, chairman of the President's council of economic advisers.

Most sick-making for Stiglitz is that the US-backed oligarchs stripped Russia's industrial assets, with the effect that national output was cut nearly in half.

After privatisation, Step Two is capital market liberalisation. In theory this allows investment capital to flow in and out. Unfortunately, as in Indonesia and Brazil, the money often simply flows out.

Stiglitz calls this the 'hot money' cycle. Cash comes in for speculation in real estate and currency, then flees at the first whiff of trouble. A nation's reserves can drain in days.

And when that happens, to seduce speculators into returning a nation's own capital funds, the IMF demands these nations raise interest rates to 30%, 50% and 80%.

'The result was predictable,' said Stiglitz. Higher interest rates demolish property values, savage industrial production and drain national treasuries.

At this point, according to Stiglitz, the IMF drags the gasping nation to Step Three: market-based pricing - a fancy term for raising prices on food, water and cooking gas. This leads, predictably, to Step-Three-and-a-Half: what Stiglitz calls 'the IMF riot'.

The IMF riot is painfully predictable. When a nation is, 'down and out, [the IMF] squeezes the last drop of blood out of them. They turn up the heat until, finally, the whole cauldron blows up,' - as when the IMF eliminated food and fuel subsidies for the poor in Indonesia in 1998. Indonesia exploded into riots.

There are other examples - the Bolivian riots over water prices last year and, this February, the riots in Ecuador over the rise in cooking gas prices imposed by the World Bank. You'd almost believe the riot was expected.

And it is. What Stiglitz did not know is that Newsnight obtained several documents from inside the World Bank. In one, last year's Interim Country Assistance Strategy for Ecuador, the Bank several times suggests - with cold accuracy - that the plans could be expected to spark 'social unrest'.

That's not surprising. The secret report notes that the plan to make the US dollar Ecuador's currency has pushed 51% of the population below the poverty line.

The IMF riots (and by riots I mean peaceful demonstrations dispersed by bullets, tanks and tear gas) cause new flights of capital and government bankruptcies This economic arson has its bright side - for foreigners, who can then pick off remaining assets at fire sale prices.

A pattern emerges. There are lots of losers but the clear winners seem to be the western banks and US Treasury.

Now we arrive at Step Four: free trade. This is free trade by the rules of the World Trade Organisation and the World Bank, which Stiglitz likens to the Opium Wars. 'That too was about "opening markets",' he said. As in the nineteenth century, Europeans and Americans today are kicking down barriers to sales in Asia, Latin American and Africa while barricading our own markets against the Third World 's agriculture.

In the Opium Wars, the West used military blockades. Today, the World Bank can order a financial blockade, which is just as effective and sometimes just as deadly.

Stiglitz has two concerns about the IMF/World Bank plans. First, he says, because the plans are devised in secrecy and driven by an absolutist ideology, never open for discourse or dissent, they 'undermine democracy'. Second, they don't work. Under the guiding hand of IMF structural 'assistance' Africa's income dropped by 23%.

Did any nation avoid this fate? Yes, said Stiglitz, Botswana. Their trick? 'They told the IMF to go packing.'

Stiglitz proposes radical land reform: an attack on the 50% crop rents charged by the propertied oligarchies worldwide.

Why didn't the World Bank and IMF follow his advice?

'If you challenge [land ownership], that would be a change in the power of the elites. That's not high on their agenda.'

Ultimately, what drove him to put his job on the line was the failure of the banks and US Treasury to change course when confronted with the crises, failures, and suffering perpetrated by their four-step monetarist mambo.

'It's a little like the Middle Ages,' says the economist, 'When the patient died they would say well, we stopped the bloodletting too soon, he still had a little blood in him.'

Maybe it's time to remove the bloodsuckers.

There are other examples - the Bolivian riots over water prices last year and, this February, the riots in Ecuador over the rise in cooking gas prices imposed by the World Bank. You'd almost believe the riot was expected. And it is. What Stiglitz did not know is that Newsnight obtained several documents from inside the World Bank. In one, last year's Interim Country Assistance Strategy for Ecuador, the Bank several times suggests - with cold accuracy - that the plans could be expected to spark 'social unrest'. That's not surprising. The secret report notes that the plan to make the US dollar Ecuador's currency has pushed 51% of the population below the poverty line. The IMF riots (and by riots I mean peaceful demonstrations dispersed by bullets, tanks and tear gas) cause new flights of capital and government bankruptcies This economic arson has its bright side - for foreigners, who can then pick off remaining assets at fire sale prices. A pattern emerges. There are lots of losers but the clear winners seem to be the western banks and US Treasury. Now we arrive at Step Four: free trade. This is free trade by the rules of the World Trade Organisation and the World Bank, which Stiglitz likens to the Opium Wars. 'That too was about "opening markets",' he said. As in the nineteenth century, Europeans and Americans today are kicking down barriers to sales in Asia, Latin American and Africa while barricading our own markets against the Third World 's agriculture. In the Opium Wars, the West used military blockades. Today, the World Bank can order a financial blockade, which is just as effective and sometimes just as deadly. Stiglitz has two concerns about the IMF/World Bank plans. First, he says, because the plans are devised in secrecy and driven by an absolutist ideology, never open for discourse or dissent, they 'undermine democracy'. Second, they don't work. Under the guiding hand of IMF structural 'assistance' Africa's income dropped by 23%. Did any nation avoid this fate? Yes, said Stiglitz, Botswana. Their trick? 'They told the IMF to go packing.' Stiglitz proposes radical land reform: an attack on the 50% crop rents charged by the propertied oligarchies worldwide. Why didn't the World Bank and IMF follow his advice? 'If you challenge [land ownership], that would be a change in the power of the elites. That's not high on their agenda.' Ultimately, what drove him to put his job on the line was the failure of the banks and US Treasury to change course when confronted with the crises, failures, and suffering perpetrated by their four-step monetarist mambo. 'It's a little like the Middle Ages,' says the economist, 'When the patient died they would say well, we stopped the bloodletting too soon, he still had a little blood in him.' Maybe it's time to remove the bloodsuckers. gregory.palast@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Observer review: Global Sex by Dennis Altman

fields.headline: Different strokes for different folks
fields.standfirst: Sexual intercourse did not begin in 1963 - Nelly in Rochester got there first. Philip Hensher on Global Sex by Dennis Altman
fields.trailText: Sexual intercourse did not begin in 1963 - Nelly in Rochester got there first. Philip Hensher on Global Sex by Dennis Altman
fields.body:
Global Sex
Dennis Altman
University of Chicago Press £15.50, pp192

Sexual desire is a more or less irrepressible and unchanging fact in humans. But the forms it takes are culturally conditioned and subject to influences and fashions like anything else. It is not just attitudes to sex that change in different times and places, but the act itself. The range of sexual acts is not that wide, but what a culture regards as commonplace and what seems exotic has changed and will go on changing.

Until quite recently, for instance, in Western culture, it seems to me that fellatio and cunnilingus were fairly exotic acts, an occasional divertissement. When the act was brought to the attention of England in the notorious Argyll divorce case in the Sixties, it was news to many readers of the Daily Beast that such a thing was possible or desirable, but then that was in the age of the weekly bath.

References to both in literature are relatively rare and always produced with a flourish; there is the whore in Pope who is 'at either end a common shore', or Nelly in Rochester, who has to use 'hands, fingers, mouth, and thighs/ Ere she can raise the member she enjoys'. Cunnilingus is probably rarer; as late as Lolita, Humbert's 'bay[ing] through the undergrowth of dark decaying forests' is still meant to shock.

With the improvement of personal hygiene in the West, these, and the previously still more exotic act of analingus, have become quite ordinary pastimes. Anecdotal evidence suggests that anal sex is still an exotic item of the vocabulary and one subject to negotiations between men and women; if it is a central part of male sexual fantasy, it is also an insistent, unspoken presence in the divorce courts. In other places and times, that has not been the case; the prevalence of heterosexual Aids in sub-Saharan Africa has been widely attributed to the resort to sodomy as a form of birth control.

The spread of an individual practice is explicable by Richard Dawkins's idea of the 'meme'. What militates against the introduction of a new sexual practice is precisely its novelty, which will be enough to categorise it as a perversion in most cultures. If that novelty seems less important than the pleasure derived from it, then it will spread. A hundred years ago, fisting was more or less unheard of - in Teleny, a piece of late nineteenth-century pornography unconvincingly attributed to Oscar Wilde, a sepoy is fisted to death with the lubricating aid of foie gras, but I think that must be regarded as a one-off. Now, although still more or less limited to homosexual men, it is not that uncommon a practice.

The fashions in individual acts are relatively easy to understand, but what is less susceptible to explication is the rise and fall of sexual identities which might seem fundamentally rooted in human nature. Homosexuality, in particular, is a poser; the prevalence of homosexuality now, compared to recent history, cannot entirely be explained away with reference to repression and taboo. Although there were always individuals who led a homosexual lifestyle, they were comparatively rare until recently. Astolphe de Custine was a rarity even in nineteenth-century France, where there was no legal prohibition. English law took no cognisance of lesbians, but the 'Ladies of Llangollen' were unusual enough to become a tourist attraction in the early nineteenth century.

What these shifts in practice and attitude point to is never very clear and it is never wise to try to draw conclusions about the larger psychology of a society on the basis of its peculiar sexual habits.

Occasionally, you can say something; it seems apparent that homosexual practices, until relatively recently, proceeded by analogy, and if sodomy became less common with the appearance of Aids, there was also a sense that same-gender relations need not always refer back to the penetrative habits of heterosexuals.

Dennis Altman has an interesting subject here, but has not quite managed to illuminate it. The question of rape in the Balkans wars, for instance, cannot helpfully be discussed in isolation from the political context. Similarly, discussion of sexual tourism in Bangkok falls instantly and rather sleazily into an evocation of 'colonialism', which is rather a routine assumption. The sexual history of colonialism is far more complex than that, and provides no easy conclusions. To take an example from an episode I've been doing a lot of work on; the sexual relations between the British and the Afghans during the British occupation of Kabul in the late 1830s were not clearly exploitative; a major casus belli was that many Afghan men preferred each other to their wives, and many Afghan wives took British soldiers as their lovers.

Bangkok is not a clear instance of colonial exploitation, but of economic inequality. That has always been the meaning of prostitution, and it is not very helpful to try to go much beyond that. An interesting subject, as I say, and if this book raises some real subjects for speculation, even if it fails to provide anything but the predictable responses of contemporary fashionable academia, it serves some kind of purpose.

webTitle: Observer review: Annie's Box by Randal Keynes

fields.headline: Unnatural selection
fields.standfirst: Charles Darwin never stopped grieving for the loss of his favourite daughter to tuberculosis. Randal Keynes shows how this tragedy shaped his scientific and emotional life in Annie's Box
fields.trailText: Charles Darwin never stopped grieving for the loss of his favourite daughter to tuberculosis. Randal Keynes shows how this tragedy shaped his scientific and emotional life in Annie's Box
fields.body:
Annie's Box: Charles Darwin, His Daughter and Human Evolution
Randal Keynes
Fourth Estate £16.99, pp320
Buy it at a discount at BOL

She was 'the joy of the household', a child with a 'generous, handsome and unsuspicious' nature who 'defied the world in her joyousness'. Thus Annie Darwin, favourite child of Charles and Emma Darwin, is described by her father in a memorial written days after her death. Annie's demise, aged 10, from 'bilious fever' devastated the great naturalist. She was expected to be 'the solace of our old age' but was taken from her parents in the most harrowing of circumstances. These tribulations were recorded by Darwin in notes and letters that he stored in 'Annie's box', a trunk of her memorabilia subsequently inherited by Keynes, the naturalist's great-great-grandson. This correspondence forms the core of the author's intriguing, pacy family portrait.

From this we learn that medicine's only weapons for coping with what we now recognise as tuberculosis were mustard poultices, brandy, chloride of lime and ammonia. All were given to Annie but proved useless. Darwin - with the eye of a practised observer - carefully noted each downward step as his daughter succumbed to worsening bouts of vomiting and delirium, though he refused to give up hope until the poor girl 'expired without a sigh' on 23 April 1851.

It is a grimly unsettling story. In particular, Darwin's desperate search for signs of his dying daughter's recovery make excrutiatingly poignant reading. Publication for this reason alone would be justified, if nothing else to remind us of our debt to twentieth-century medicine. Until the roots of infectious disease were deciphered, childhood deaths like Annie's were commonplace.

But there is more to this story - expertly conceived by Keynes - than the outlining of the vicissitudes of Victorian family life, for Annie's death cast a long shadow over the great scientist's thinking about the natural world and the nature of the struggle for survival. The crucial point is that life and science 'were all of a piece' for Darwin, Keynes notes. You can still see evidence of this conceptual intertwining at Darwin's beautifully restored home at Down House, near Bromley in Kent: the glasshouses where he carried out his plant experiments; the paths that he wandered round, pondering the origin of species; and the study in which he outlined his theory of natural selection.

Here we can see just how tightly family life and career meshed together for Darwin - while from Keynes we learn that this coalescing even applied to Annie. Her death strengthened his belief in the bleak, amoral character of natural selection. A creature's deserved fate had little to do with its prospects for survival, he realised.

Indeed, to his dying day, Darwin found he could not push the death of Annie from his mind. 'It still sickens me when I cannot help remembering some of the many illnesses our children have endured,' he wrote to a friend. Not 'when I remember', please note, but 'when I cannot help remembering'. Nor could Darwin forgive God or believe in a deity that caused 'the immense amount of suffering in the world'. So he took revenge, producing a theory that disenfranchised God from his role in our creation, and has marooned mankind in a moral vacuum ever since. Annie's life may have been tragically short, but its impact has - to say the least - been long-lasting and profound.

fields.headline: What a sew and sew
fields.standfirst: Yet again, Tracey Emin proves she can embroider the truth
fields.trailText: Yet again, Tracey Emin proves she can embroider the truth.
fields.body:
Tracey Emin You Forgot to Kiss My Soul, White Cube 2, London N1, until 26 May

New Labour Saatchi Gallery, London NW8, until 15 August

Tracey Emin needs no introduction. This is her defining characteristic as an artist. The subject of her work is Being Tracey Emin; the object is to make herself known. This is achieved as much through the art - the drawings, videos and embroideries, the famous tent, the even more famous bed - as through the incessant newspaper interviews, the appearances on billboard and box. Each feeds the other, is co-dependent, if not symbiotic.

One result of this sustained exposure is that more people know about Emin's early life in Margate, her rape, her abortions, her drinking, her despair, than have ever seen the merest scrap of her art. Her celebrity as the star saboteur of TV's Turner Prize night, her torrentially outspoken behaviour and her emotional appeal as some sort of Hoxton Medea all outstrip her popularity as a visual artist. Which is why some people prefer to think of the woman as the total artwork in herself and why it is so hard to separate the objects she exhibits from the life.

Thus, for example, at White Cube 2, in her first solo show in four years, you can't look at the hospital gown on its peg without wondering if and when Emin once wore it. You can't easily approach the two tiny chairs in the corner without wondering if they commemorate her lost twins, whose names she embroidered in the tent. Even those capable of extreme scepticism towards Emin - and there are many - could hardly view these items without compassion. They aren't asking to be admired as works of imagination - they are simply the relics of her experience.

In the past, Emin might just have installed them in the gallery and left them to stand for themselves, like the bed, the beach hut or the newspaper cuttings about herself. Here, the hospital gown connects with a forlorn little drawing of a patient hooked up to a saline drip that looks painfully like a noose. The chairs are arranged in front of a video, in which Emin questions her mother, a wise and generous woman, about the effect on her life of having children. Moving associations are made between words and symbols, as between one life and the rest. Emin, it seems, is no longer so solipsistic.

The whole show feels more cheerful and outgoing, more in the spirit of Emin's Mum. The walls are painted baby blue. There's a meadow of plants in one corner and a couple of perkily stuffed birds. Climb the ladder to a little treehouse and you find yourself looking through a peephole at a merry stranger whose smile broadens as he walks towards you. Enter the free-standing closet and you can watch a video of timid Tracey being bullied by her ferocious alter ego: the lamb, the witch and the wardrobe.

Of course, there are plenty of Emin's trademark blankets, embroidered with tales from the cursed life of womankind like gigantic, miserabilist samplers. There are also dozens of her rachitic little figures, drawn in monoprint, that testify to the anguish - though also the pleasures - of her sexual life. Emin may be an old-fashioned expressionist, but she's a million miles from Käthe Kollwitz or Egon Schiele when it comes to drawing. She's much stronger with caricature: absurdly fetishised shoes, toppled drinkers, nippy meerkats poised ready on their hind legs - a good mascot for any girl, 'Always watchful, always alert!'

The centrepiece of this show, at least in terms of scale, is a helter-skelter made out of bare plyboard. Without stairs, and not quite big enough for an adult, this is clearly intended to be an impossible ride. The gallery is also handing out a short text by Emin in which she refers to the way one tiny incident can send you helter-skelter in a downward spiral. But the words are quite not in kilter with the model, which is too small and quaint to disturb. Maybe Emin was thinking of Louise Bourgeois's colossal helter-skelters, made for Tate Modern last year, up which one clambered only to be confronted by a grotesquely enlarged reflection of oneself.

Like Bourgeois, Emin is often aggressively defensive. Unlike Bourgeois, she can be comically pathetic, as in the title of this show, You Forgot to Kiss My Soul , written up in Barbie-pink neon. It's a sharp self-parody, in keeping with the closet video in which she hams a good-girl Tracey, in dressing-gown and slippers, pretending to cower as her bad-girl counterpart hammers on the door by night. The battle between marauding ego and abject id is always Emin's best performance - and performance is what she does best: dramatising, and now sending herself up as the double-act of confessional art.

Earlier in the year the Saatchi Gallery announced a forthcoming show by Damien Hirst. It was a no-show. The substitute is New Labour, an anthology of nearly-new work. The first thing you see in the foyer is Liane Lang's animated film in which a Plasticine hand fumbles at a Plasticine clitoris. Masturbation is ineptly modelled, clumsily filmed and its sniggering joke - putty in her own hands - is as crude as everything else.

The piece was made in 1997, the year of the Sensation show at the Royal Academy. It reminds you just how much art was being made in crass imitation in those days, and how much of it was bought by Saatchi. It's undoubtedly a mistake to deduce a buyer's tastes from his collection, particularly when it is as manifestly various as this one. But now that the scene has contracted and changed, Saatchi still seems to be buying sexual one-liners.

Rebecca Warren makes unfired clay sculptures that play on the roughly-modelled 'non-finito' state, and on the writhing forms of classical statues. From her claggy grey lumps, reminiscent of the clay sweating beneath its polythene in the art-room cupboard, the emerging forms writhe in lewd and prodigious orgies. Here and there, as in the crucifixion with erection and gilded thumb tacks, she applies a decorative glaze to the clay, an idea she shares with Grayson Perry.

Dozens of Perry's vessels are displayed in rows, like a graveyard of classical urns. This doesn't do him any favours. It makes what he does, which is to explore his psyche, plus the seediness of the world in general and the art world in particular, in drawings, words and photographs, all decorated with Victorian decals and glazed with fine lustre, seem like a repetitive gimmick. Yet Perry makes ingenious use of each vessel's separate shape in evolving his circular narratives.

Saatchi's bulk-buy habits work both ways. DJ Simpson's colossal abstract 'paintings', made using an electric router to cut through the archaeological layers of laminated board, seem to cancel each other out in close confinement. But Martin Maloney's friezes work brilliantly as a suite, a version of pastoral for the city. Dog lovers, girls on bikes, mothers loving children, each is elaborated in tiny fragments of bright vinyl glued to a sheet of cartridge. Together, they amount to a modern mosaic of urban life; instead of a marble pavement, set forth on a page.

It makes what he does, which is to explore his psyche, plus the seediness of the world in general and the art world in particular, in drawings, words and photographs, all decorated with Victorian decals and glazed with fine lustre, seem like a repetitive gimmick. Yet Perry makes ingenious use of each vessel's separate shape in evolving his circular narratives. Saatchi's bulk-buy habits work both ways. DJ Simpson's colossal abstract 'paintings', made using an electric router to cut through the archaeological layers of laminated board, seem to cancel each other out in close confinement. But Martin Maloney's friezes work brilliantly as a suite, a version of pastoral for the city. Dog lovers, girls on bikes, mothers loving children, each is elaborated in tiny fragments of bright vinyl glued to a sheet of cartridge. Together, they amount to a modern mosaic of urban life; instead of a marble pavement, set forth on a page.

fields.headline: The big chill blows south
fields.standfirst:
Claims made for the new economy were bogus, says Jamie Doward, and Britain's pain is only just starting

Special report: Global recession
fields.trailText: Claims made for the new economy were bogus, says Jamie Doward, and Britain's pain is only just starting.
fields.body:
The new economy is falling down and no one is immune. Not JDS Uniphase, the world's largest fibre optical network company, whose equipment wires the information superhighway, which wants to close its operation at Bracknell in Berkshire, in favour of another plant in Toronto. Nor the giant investment bank CSFB which plans to cull 130 support staff jobs. Other big investment banks, notably Merrill Lynch, have also cut support teams.

Companies are viciously trimming their capital expenditure budgets and the firms and workers at the forefront of the new economy are becoming the first to hit the wall. And, slowly but surely, the UK is waking up to the truth that the claims made for how a wired world would create huge and sustainable growth rates were bogus. It is a dawning with massive implications for this country.

'The telecom infrastructure manufacturers thought they could grow 30% per annum for ever. Though the sector will continue to grow it will be more like 6% per annum,' said Anthony Parish, director general of the Federation of Electronics Industries. Few of the sector's big firms are escaping.

Last week it was the turn of US mobile phone giant Motorola to swing the axe, with the announcement that its Bathgate factory, in Lothian, is to close with the loss of 3,100 jobs, saving a loss-making factory in Germany. Tony Blair had personally intervened to try to keep it open, and news of the closure stunned a community. 'We anticipated a cutback. But we expected around 1,000 jobs to go,' said Danny Carrigan, the AEEU's national officer for electronics.

There will be further bad news in Scotland following the Bathgate closure. Question marks now hang over plastics company Rosti, which employs 700 people at its factories near Glasgow, at Hamilton and Larkhall. Rosti makes the casings for Motorola phones. Unions say there will be job cuts.

Another firm in Hamilton, APW, which makes metal plating for Motorola handsets, will be hit. Separately, there are fears for the future of the Panasonic factory, in East Kilbride, which employs 300 people. Sun Microsystems, too, is preparing to announce redundancies at Linlithgow, near Edinburgh.

But it isn't just Silicon Glen that is suffering. Carri gan was involved in talks with Lord Simpson, chairman of Marconi, earlier this month when the internet infrastructure maker announced plans to cull 1,500 UK jobs.

The Marconi boss said firms like his were feeling the heat for a number of reasons:

 There are too many players in the market.

 The huge growth of the last few years was unsustainable.

 Companies overstretched themselves to buy third generation (3G) mobile licences.

 Nervous investors are discouraging US firms from investing in technology.

Hop back only a couple of years and the telecoms land scape was unrecognisable from the way it looks today. Thousands of dot.com firms were setting up shop, and telecom traffic was exploding as the world clicked its mouse. Demand for internet equipment, such as routers and servers, was outstripping supply. Makers of the equipment started to stockpile components in anticipation of continuing demand.

But there was too much competition, and the price of bandwidth collapsed. The telecoms landscape is a bombed out minefield.

'There is carnage on the supply side,' was the succinct assessment of Jack McMaster, chief executive of KPN Qwest, one of the few fledgling telecoms firms to hit its targets.

Frank Pipe, managing director of Lucent UK, whose parent company is to axe 10,000 jobs around the world, said: 'Over the last two and a half years virtually every communication corporation in Britain has been spending on telecoms equipment at a faster rate than they have grown.

'You don't need to be a rocket scientist to know that you can't do this forever. They've now put the handbrakes on and are looking to reduce costs.'

Falling demand for telecom infrastructure has been exacerbated by a flood of second-hand equipment on to the market as failed dot.coms sell up. The likes of Cisco have been left high and dry with huge, expensive stockpiles of new kit.

Such sclerosis hurts Cisco's suppliers. Intel, the semi conductor giant, for example, is axing 5,000 jobs. Bookham Technology, which makes fibre optic equipment for the likes of Nortel Networks, last week saw its share price slide 9% on the day it said sales for the second quarter were going to be disappointing.

Most industry pundits predict more dark clouds ahead. Parish, from the electronics trade body, said: 'We can expect further bad news from the telecom equipment manufacturers. The US situation is very bad. Many companies have run out of credit.'

Further job losses are likely as firms consolidate to stay alive. Swedish mobile phone giant Ericsson is in talks with Sony to merge the two companies' handset divisions. Philips is looking for a buyer of its mobile phone arm. The smaller, 'second tier' telecom networks are looking for buyers.

More firms are likely to follow Motorola's lead in sacrificing UK manufacturing plants in favour of operations abroad (see box below). 'We need to analyse what these job losses mean. Should we diversify, go up the knowledge stream and invest in creating more research and development jobs rather than screwdriver jobs?' said Carrigan of the AEEU.

The question now is how long before bad news on the hardware side migrates to the software industry. 'The chief technology officers in the big user departments are beginning to cut projects,' said John Higgins, director general of the Computer Services and Software Association, the organisation that represents the UK software firms.

With little to cheer the markets now internet mania has evaporated, investment banks are starting to sacrifice more than their IT staff as merger and acquisition activity dries up. Morgan Stanley sent shockwaves through the banking world last week when it announced it was axing 1,500 employees globally. Other banks are contemplating similar moves.

The chill wind blowing through Silicon Glen is heading south.
