fields.headline: Brussels tech tsar who means business
fields.standfirst: Europe's IT supremo wants to dispel notions of hidebound bureaucracy. Profile of Erkki Liikanen by  Hugo Miller
fields.trailText: Europe's IT supremo wants to dispel notions of hidebound bureaucracy. Profile of Erkki Liikanen by Hugo Miller.
fields.body:
Ii is 6pm, at the end of a wet and unseasonably cold April day in Brussels, but in his large office in the heart of the city's EU quarter, Erkki Liikanen is all smiles. While tech stocks continue to play havoc with investors' nerves and there are mountains of new legislation to tackle, the EU's Commissioner for Information Society and Enterprise is doing what he enjoys best, talking technology.

Cigar in hand, the affable Finn launches into discussion of a networked Europe, peppering his speech with words such as 'transparency' and 'inclusiveness' - all too aware, perhaps, of the Commission's lingering reputation for secrecy and Byzantine-style government. After all, Liikanen is no newcomer to Brussels.

But he is relatively new to the tech world. Though his CV boasts three years in the Seventies as a board member of Televa Oy, a Finnish digital switching pioneer, Liikanen began professional life as a politician in his native Finland. He rose rapidly through the ranks of Finnish politics to become Minister of Finance from 1987 to 1990.

Ten years ago he moved to Brussels and, in 1994, became EU commissioner responsible for the Commission's budget and personnel. In 1999, Liikanen took over the IT portfolio as part of the 'house cleaning' overseen by incoming President Romano Prodi.

Since taking on the role of Brussels' Mr Technology two years ago, Liikanen has been quick to make overtures to the tech community in the UK and across Europe to try to dispel notions of a Brussels bureaucracy unable to keep up with the pace of technological change.

Liikanen 'understands not just telecoms and technology issues, but also the business community - that is the key thing,' says Ed Meier, a London-based analyst with Fletcher Advisory, an IT research and consulting firm.

At the same time, Liikanen's efforts to ingratiate himself with the private sector have generated grumblings that he hasn't been tough enough on some businesses, particularly the for mer telecoms monopolies across Europe.

'If you ask the telecoms incumbents, they say I don't give them a day of peace,' he counters. 'But if you ask some new entrants, they say: why don't you destroy them all.' Liikanen is on to one of his favourite topics: unbundling the loop.

The loop, in this case, is the 'last mile' of copper cable connecting homes to telecoms networks that incumbent telecoms operators across the EU have been required by law to open up to competition from 1 January. Though many politicians heralded the new legislation as something that would bring down the cost of internet access dramatically, little has happened, with most incumbents continuing to enjoy a near-monopoly. Moreover, the cost of entry for new telcos is often prohibitively high.

Oftel, the UK telecoms regulator, which has postponed unbundling until July, has been singled out for its failure to put more pressure on BT to open up to competition. Recently, Olli Rehn, Liika nen's chef de cabinet , issued this stinging rebuke: 'The UK has relegated itself from the premier league [of European telecoms liberalisation] to the relegation zone of the second division.'

Awkward football metaphors aside, Oftel has also been criticised by private sector players. Over the past seven months, nine of the original 28 telcos that were committed to UK unbundling have pulled out, including RSL Com, WorldCom, Colt and Telewest.

While a telecoms slump has undoubtedly played a part, a number of firms cited a flawed unbundling process and a lack of commercial opportunity. One RSL Com representative accused Oftel of giving BT 'time to tighten its grip in the prime markets while competitors are left to struggle for market share in the least populated exchanges'.

Is Liikanen frustrated at the pace of change? 'If I hadn't spoken to Bill Kennard [FCC chairman] when they unbundled in the US, I might have been,' he jokes. 'But I had a good talk with him. He told me it will be a long struggle.'

Shouldn't Brussels be doing more to try to force wider competition through the new law? 'It was a job for us [before 1 January], but now that it is becoming law [across member states], it is up to the national regulators.'

David Tan, also with Fletcher Advisory in London, agrees: 'Only so much can be done to force the incumbents to change, and there is only so much Brussels can do.'

So it's up to Oftel, then? If so, Tan is not optimistic: 'For anyone that believes in a scenario of perfect competition, it's not going to happen.'

The other big telecoms headache on Liikanen's plate is third-generation mobile technology. Though the auctioning of the 3G licences was the responsibility of member states, the wide disparity in prices paid across the EU is seen to be at odds with Brussels' mantra of harmonisation. The UK auction last summer was one of Europe's most expensive: netting the Treasury £22.5 billion and costing Vodafone £5.96bn and BT Cellnet and One 2 One around £4bn each for their licences.

'There are huge differences in prices that were paid,' he concedes. 'And if we had auctions today, of course many would pay less. Now the question is how they carry those costs.' With a sharp drop in telcos' share prices, Meier of Fletcher Advisory agrees that this is the big challenge. 'After all, it's hitting their balance sheets hard,' he says.

Just how hard was revealed by last week's announcement that Group 3G, a German operator owned by Finland's Sonera and Spain's Telefonica, will begin sharing portions of its net work in a bid to save £910 million and cut operating costs by 40%. Considering that the UK and Germany both saw high auction prices, might Britain's burdened telcos make a similar move? Hard to say. While Liikanen sees it as a way for debt-ridden companies to manage costs, the UK Government sees stiff 3G competition as the model for consumer choice and may disapprove of network sharing.

One of the biggest sticking points between Brussels and Washington on internet issues is e-commerce taxation. While the US government is moving ahead slowly, wary of stepping on internet libertarians' toes, Brussels knows what it wants and has come under fire for moving ahead unilaterally.

The Commissioner believes that any business setting up shop online for EU consumers should register in a single member state and pay VAT there. Otherwise, a US business could sell to European consumers at a major discount because it doesn't pay the tax its European rivals have to.

'If one business pays VAT, and one does not, where's the competition? I don't believe in heavy regulation but I do believe that taxation must be neutral across the board,' he says. Of course this could mean that any foreign business that might be considering setting up in London will register in low-tax havens such as Luxembourg instead. Not ideal, then, but a start.

As for Europe's broader future, Liikanen is cautiously optimistic. 'Of course the slowdown in the US will have an impact, but it looks like we'll still continue to grow.'

The fact that Europe's tech fortunes have not hinged quite so critically on venture capital may be a mitigating factor. 'I don't say it's going to be easy for Europe, but the prospects are solid.'

With that, the tech discussion is over, and thoughts turn to other matters. He asks his spokesman: 'Who's playing tonight? Barcelona?' And like a flash, he's off into the wet Brussels night.

 Hugo Miller is a former London editor of the Wall Street Journal

fields.headline: Mommy wars
fields.standfirst:
A study that terrified working parents on both sides of the Atlantic is now seen as seriously flawed. Ben Summerskill and Edward Helmore report on the latest in a series of alarmist stories

The childcare theorists
fields.trailText: A study that terrified working parents on both sides of the Atlantic is now seen as seriously flawed. Ben Summerskill and Edward Helmore report on the latest in a series of alarmist stories.
fields.body:
Homework. Cornflakes. Swimming things. Toast. Packed lunches. Fruit juice. Bus money. Milk. Please wipe your mouth, darling. Weekday breakfast-times in millions of British households are stressful enough. But if you had only 30 seconds for a quick glance at the paper one morning three weeks ago, it suddenly got worse. Minutes before legions of small children were to be delivered into the care of childminders or nurseries, the headline, 'How daycare can make a toddler grow up unruly,' rebuked you from the page.

New American research involving 1,300 children showed - apparently - that even when parents chose the best care, it could still be harmful. Disobedient. Badly behaved. Insecure. Anxious. That's how children end up, the new study confirmed.

The research was endorsed by Jay Belsky, a feisty professor from London University. Could anything be better designed to make parents - and, let's be frank, mothers in particular - feel guilty, regretful and angst-ridden that they were about to leave their children with strangers once again?

The same scene was played out in tens of millions more households, not just in Britain, but in the United States. A string of newspapers - from the Los Angeles Times to the International Herald Tribune - reported the same alarming story. One American tabloid said 'Mommy Wars' had broken out.

Internet sites and message boards have been deluged with hits from worried parents. And last week's Time, a magazine emblematic of the American zeitgeist, pictured an elusive 'Superkid' on the cover, cautioning inside that Belsky's new research meant 'something awful for just about everyone'.

Thousands more American therapists will be funding their mortgages as you read this, helped out by parents riddled with guilt at what they might be doing to their children. In Britain, we just worry. But parents still reflect, as they set off to work each day, that they have to pay the mortgage. So what else can they do?

Calm down, for a start. What has quietly emerged in the past three days - with less fanfare and certainly much less hyperbole than the original story - is that the research trumpeted around the world might not be right. And it certainly would not be the first time that millions of parents have been terrified by claims from apparently reputable researchers, only for their fears to prove unjustified.

Belsky first suggested 15 years ago that the absence of mothers might harm their children. He worked then at Pennsylvania State University, but his views were latched on to by battalions of enthusiastic 'family values' campaigners both in America and Britain. Meanwhile, the number of British working mothers with children under a year old has risen to almost 50 per cent. Small wonder that as a nation we hang on almost every word of those who claim to have discovered something new about the nature of childcare.

Belsky, bright, earnest and media-friendly, has since moved to Birkbeck College, London, but still works with the American National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. It is this body's monitoring of children during the last decade which has provided the fuel for the 'Mommy Wars' controversy.

But now some of the 12 other academics involved in the research have decided they did not like the publicity that Belsky is securing. They say that the professor's much-publicised interpretation of the data is flawed and that he 'hijacked' the study, in which he was only a minor player. Moreover, they claim he interpreted it in a way that will advance his anti-childcare agenda.

They suggest that Belsky's dire pronouncements are not based on conclusive data, and that his identification as a 'principal investigator' in the study is wrong. 'Belsky interprets the findings very differently from us,' says Margaret Burchinal, the leading statistician on the 10-year project, with an academic's tact. 'Our results do not actually support his conclusions.'

Children in the study, she says, 'were typical of what you'd expect for a normal four-year-old. We're not seeing that childcare produces super-aggressive kids.' What is not in dispute is that some children having full-time childcare tend to behave a little less well than others. 'They're slightly more likely to call each other names but they're not super-aggressive and could not even be labelled as aggressive,' she says.

In almost complete contradiction of Belsky's reported claims, Burchinal adds: 'Our findings don't indicate that childcare is a major risk factor. The level of problems is not such that parents should make different decisions about their children based on this study.'

And in an email to colleagues, the study's co-author, Professor Marsha Weinraub, now says witheringly: 'We did not prepare a press release because this report has not yet been peer-reviewed. This was a series of reports to conference colleagues. Generally, scientists are pretty circumspect in reporting conference findings, but this was not the case.'

Other academics complain that the research has not been based on 'like-for-like' comparisons. Aggressive children might have other reasons for being unruly, such as aggressive parents or trauma in their early childhood. Researchers had not been able to make these distinctions.

Back in Britain Stephen Burke, director of the widely respected Daycare Trust, says: 'Research like this causes parents unnecessary alarm. Our experience, based on evidence in this country, is that good quality childcare has benefits for children, not just in terms of learning, but in terms of positive behaviour. Childcare here is much more regulated than in the United States, and it's unclear how much Professor Belsky took this into account.'

But Burke acknowledges a political perspective which terrified parents are all too inclined not to notice. 'The results of this research, interpreted in this way, can be used to promote an agenda which contradicts the reality of women with young children playing a bigger and bigger role in the workplace.

'It would be far better to provide affordable childcare which enables them to do their job and give their children a good start in life. This issue is about dealing with the reality of life today rather than some fictional world of yesteryear.'

Rival researchers disputed the validity of a survey which started 30 years ago when British childcare was almost entirely unregulated.

So if this week brings a further parenting scare, don't get too anxious about that either. Another one will be along shortly.

That's how children end up, the new study confirmed. The research was endorsed by Jay Belsky, a feisty professor from London University. Could anything be better designed to make parents - and, let's be frank, mothers in particular - feel guilty, regretful and angst-ridden that they were about to leave their children with strangers once again? The same scene was played out in tens of millions more households, not just in Britain, but in the United States. A string of newspapers - from the Los Angeles Times to the International Herald Tribune - reported the same alarming story. One American tabloid said 'Mommy Wars' had broken out. Internet sites and message boards have been deluged with hits from worried parents. And last week's Time, a magazine emblematic of the American zeitgeist, pictured an elusive 'Superkid' on the cover, cautioning inside that Belsky's new research meant 'something awful for just about everyone'. Thousands more American therapists will be funding their mortgages as you read this, helped out by parents riddled with guilt at what they might be doing to their children. In Britain, we just worry. But parents still reflect, as they set off to work each day, that they have to pay the mortgage. So what else can they do? Calm down, for a start. webTitle: Cosmic tourist blasts into space amid the usual holiday hold-ups

fields.headline: Cosmic tourist blasts into space amid the usual holiday hold-ups
fields.standfirst:
When Sputnik shot into orbit, Dennis Tito's ambitions went sky-high too. And yesterday, the millionaire bought his dream

Special report: space exploration
Comment: Ten things about space travel
fields.trailText: Millionaire Dennis Tito, the world's first interplanetary tourist, was preparing today for his first major experience in space: stacking in orbit while ground controllers try to clear a traffic jam round the International Space Station.
fields.body:
Millionaire Dennis Tito, the world's first interplanetary tourist, was preparing today for his first major experience in space: stacking in orbit while ground controllers try to clear a traffic jam round the International Space Station.

The Soyuz space capsule bearing the 60-year-old Californian and two Russian cosmonauts, Talgat Musabayev and Yuri Baturin, is now heading towards a rendezvous with the station, 240 miles above the Earth, after its launch from Kazakhstan's Baikonur cosmodrome yesterday.

A bid by American space officials to have blast-off delayed was rejected by their Russian counterparts at the last minute, a move that left US astronauts on the shuttle Endeavour - now docked at the station - with less than a day to complete their mission, which has been plagued by computer breakdowns and other delays.

If the shuttle's seven-person crew fail to meet their departure deadline today, and US space officials say such an outcome is likely, the Russian craft carrying Tito will be unable to dock.

The world's first space tourist will then have to spend a large part of his time doing the astronautical equivalent of stacking over Gatwick.

Not that the grey-haired, slightly built former rocket scientist will complain. He has spent a fortune getting into space and more than a year of his life training for the event. An extra day in orbit is likely to leave him unworried.

Indeed, as the launch began yesterday, Kazakh television showed a delighted looking Tito sitting next to mission commander Talgat Musabayev. A transcript of exchanges between them showed Tito starting his space journey by exclaiming, 'Khorosho!' (Good!) in Russian.

On the ground, the launch was witnessed by many of Tito's relatives, as well as his girlfriend Dawn Abraham.

As his rocket lifted off flawlessly and disappeared into the heavens, trailing a red flame and a faint line of white smoke, his son Mike shouted: 'He's really gone ahead and done it. I'm thrilled, I am ecstatic.'

Nine minutes after launch, the Soyuz TM capsule separated from its booster and Tito entered orbit around the Earth.

His success in reaching space - against the express wishes of his own country - is a fitting achievement for someone who has been described as the Ross Perot of space travel: a small man with a deep pockets and a large ego, an individual who has sidestepped the establishment to get his own way.

Tito has also been dismissed as 'a cashmonaut', an entrepreneurial opportunist who has used his fortune to buy himself the ultimate thrill. Such descriptions are only partially accurate, however.

Tito grew up in Queens, New York, the oldest child of working-class Italian immigrants from the town of Tito in southern Italy, and was destined for a mundane future until the launch of the Soviet Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite in 1957, fired his teenage imagination. Tito decided to pursue the dream of travelling in space, and after gaining bachelor's and master's degrees in aerospace engineering, was employed by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasedena to chart flight paths for Nasa's Mariner probes to Mars. If nothing else, such experience makes a lie of critics who claim he is 'an amateur in orbit'.

However, Tito's $15,000 wage at JPL clashed with his other main dream - of making millions - so he left to set up his investment company Wiltshire Associates in the early Seventies. By the time he was 40, Tito had made his first million. Today Wiltshire manages more than $10 billion in assets, while its founder's fortune is estimated to be $200m.

It is this fortune that Tito has used so successfully to get himself into space. Noting the decision of Russia's space officials to permit a Saudi prince, a Japanese journalist and a British chemist, Helen Sharman, to fly on their spacecraft, albeit for a fee, Tito offered $20m to follow suit. His offer was promptly accepted by Russia's cash-starved space agency.

Originally, Tito was expected to fly on Mir, the Russian space station, but its demise left the Russians with no alternative but to send him to the international space station whose construction they were sharing with the US, Europe and Japan.

This plan provoked the fury of Nasa, which had spent 20 years planning the space station and did not want it used as a glorified tourist trap. So agency officials refused to let Tito train at the Johnson Space Centre when he arrived in Houston several weeks ago with Musabayev and Baturin. The decision infuriated his crewmates who threatened to walk out of the space centre unless Tito was permitted on board the station.

The result was a diplomatic stand-off that lasted several days. Eventually, Nasa blinked and agreed to let Tito fly, though only on condition that he signed an agreement waiving his family's rights to sue if he was killed, in addition to a promise to pay for anything he breaks while on board.

Such an agreement may permit Tito to realise his dream but it offers him little prospect of much action, a point he openly acknowledges.

'My specific goals will be to photograph the Earth, do a lot of photographics inside the station, to document my feelings and thoughts,' said Tito, shortly before take-off.

However, Tito's experience with Nasa has certainly changed at least one US millionaire's view of the red menace. As he said a few days ago, 'Russia is not nearly as regulated and paternalistic as America, which is much more controlled and has rules not only about safety in space flying, but for job activities, smoking, labelling of alcoholic beverages and so forth.

'This market attitude is going to create a lot of economic benefits to this country.'

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: The Powerbook by Jeanette Winterson, plus Last Words: The Final Journals of William Burroughs edited by James Grauerholz, Dreaming of Strangers by Matt Thorne, Hokkaido Highway Blues: Hitchhiking in Japan by Will Ferguson, The Faustian Bargain: The Art World in Nazi Germany by Jonathan Petropoulos, and The Island in the Mind by Rodney Hall
fields.body:
The Powerbook
Jeanette Winterson
Vintage £6.99, pp244
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Though loosely set in cyberspace, Jeanette Winterson's strange and beautiful love story has more in common with medieval tales of courtly love than the techie e-novels that have mushroomed in the past few years. Winterson is fascinated by the way in which cyberspace dissolves time, geography and identity, allowing the midnight surfer 'freedom, just for one night' - like love or fiction.

Ethereal tales of love and snatches of fairy story created on the web are anchored in what the narrator's lover calls 'meatspace', in the ongoing affair between a writer and the married woman with whom she falls in love. But distinctions between real and imagined identities gradually become meaningless as the relationship itself melts into allegory. In her internet stories, the writer slips in and out of history to become all the 'great and ruinous lovers' whose desires led them to tragedy - Lancelot, Francesca da Rimini, George Mallory. Her longing and suffering become theirs; her quest is doomed because she will risk everything for love but will not compromise, and as with all great passions there's a streak of masochism: 'Loving you is like lifting a heavy stone. It would be easier not to do it and I'm not quite sure why I am doing it.'

The novel also returns allusively to the territory of Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit , in a pseudo-mythical story about the writer's childhood in 'the Muck House' with unloving, puritanical, shuttered parents, though these passages feel awkwardly familiar, as if they don't quite belong in this free-form, mesmeric account. It may not be the entirely original form of storytelling that the narrator sets out to achieve, but Winterson has found a way of writing about sexual desire that is at once profound and startling, and will strike a chord with anyone who has ever fallen in love with someone they shouldn't have fallen in love with.

Last Words: The Final Journals of William Burroughs
Edited by James Grauerholz
Flamingo £7.99, pp276
Buy it at a discount at BOL

'But what does an evil recluse do? Just sit and be evil?' As the original hard-drinking, hard-drugging transcendentalist sodomite pilgrim, there is one thing Burroughs is quick to establish: this won't be an exhibition of self-pity. For starters, it's riotously funny and life-affirming. Having officially retired from novel writing and never producing an autobiography, these last journals - spanning a significant nine months - are both, as well as a thesis on life and art, morality and injustice, addiction and consumerism and, above all, the concept of last words, final judgment, the basis of moral absolutism rather than relativism, which requires active reason, not obedience to pre-ordained values. For its insight and humour, verbal and narrative inventiveness, this is a magnificent work to place alongside Allen Ginsberg's 'Kaddish' or Lenny Bruce's How to Talk Dirty and Influence People . Can life have narrative sense, a conclusion, a moral? For an untamed genius, it can: 'Most natural painkiller there is. LOVE.'

Dreaming of Strangers
Matt Thorne
Phoenix £6.99, pp243
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In less than a decade, the cash cow that is ' High-Fidelity -for-cineastes' has gone from being a likelihood to an emergent trend. Michael Zadoorian and Christopher Brookmyre have provided some entertaining twists on Hornby's formula, having borrowed the concept and structure (viz, interstitial chapterlets entitled 'Dodgy Boyfriends' and 'Favourite Films'). The only reason the characterisation hasn't gone, too, is, most probably, a dearth of talent when it comes to observation,let alone humour. Matt Thorne's most explicit adoption - 'Which came first: [Jack Nicholson's] notoriety or acclaim?' ( pace Hornby '_ the music or the misery?') - isn't even an interesting variation. The plot? Becca's surprisingly successful (twist-free) seduction of Chris, by contriving to make life imitate (low) art (ie John Hughes films). If further proof were needed of the haste with which this was apparently written - Becca manages to enjoy 2001's trashed Mission to Mars .

Hokkaido Highway Blues: Hitchhiking in Japan
Will Ferguson
Canongate £9.99, pp433
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Following the blossoming of the cherry trees, marking Japan's seasonal change, Ferguson was bound to be poetically and even philosophically-inspired (the traditional response after drinking plenty of saki), but finds space for countless pop-culture references too: 'What's the point of rebuilding Tokyo Tower? Godzilla will just knock it over again.'

Granted, Ferguson tells a lot of old jokes, eg riffing on the similarity of words for 'human' and 'carrot ', but there's no escaping the fact: he tells a lot of jokes, besides delving into the mythology of Japan (priapic monsters seducing peasant girls); the anthropology (the Wisest Monkeys in Japan got their name from their trick of_ washing potatoes) and making a memorable visit to the Taga shrine, whose 'main object of veneration is a_ battering ram of a phallus'.

An embarrassment of riches, most definitely; when did you last read a book while grinning in anticipation of the next joke?

The Faustian Bargain: The Art World in Nazi Germany
Jonathan Petropoulos
Penguin £8.99, pp395
Buy it at a discount at BOL

As a microcosm of the bourgeoisie or intelligentsia, the Third Reich's art world - at first glance, a subject of limited appeal - is in fact almost perfect for an analysis of the relationship between ethics and culture, or the ethics of the supposedly cultured.

And yet their involvement is far from paradoxical, for the likes of Ernst Buchner were 'educated to revere high culture and to believe in German superiority in this regard', and visual artworks have generally been the pre ferred assets of plutocrats seeking to dignify their lucre.

The psychology of mass denial is considered - Primo Levi's 'silent transition from falsehood to self-deception' - as is the extent of responsibility: were the half-dozen key figures known to deal directly with the Führer and his high command victims of conformity or victimisers? Overall, this is indispensable reading on Nazi Germany and for everyone concerned with the relation between aesthetics and ethics.

The Island in the Mind
Rodney Hall
Granta £8.99, pp560
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Australians seem to have a fondness for rewriting history to put their marginalised continent centrestage. After Einstein as an Australian, Stalin's lovechild raised down under, and Hall's own The Day We Had Hitler Home , this is a subtler comedy in which the 'isle full of noises' of Shakespeare's Tempest is relocated to the Antipodes. Drama and reality are remixed and shuffled so that the staging of the quasi- Tempest precedes a Venetian Miranda's attempt to save the soul of an Aboriginal Caliban before the long-sought land - as unfulfilled desire, as Paradise - is reached.

More of a reinvention than a re-telling, this novella-trilogy manages to combine the speculation of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead with the fun and silliness of Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter . Cerebral and visceral, lavish and grotesque, Hall is indubitably the late Robertson Davies's literary heir. A triumph.

Dreaming of Strangers Matt Thorne Phoenix £6.99, pp243 Buy it at a discount at BOL In less than a decade, the cash cow that is ' High-Fidelity -for-cineastes' has gone from being a likelihood to an emergent trend. Michael Zadoorian and Christopher Brookmyre have provided some entertaining twists on Hornby's formula, having borrowed the concept and structure (viz, interstitial chapterlets entitled 'Dodgy Boyfriends' and 'Favourite Films'). The only reason the characterisation hasn't gone, too, is, most probably, a dearth of talent when it comes to observation,let alone humour. Matt Thorne's most explicit adoption - 'Which came first: [Jack Nicholson's] notoriety or acclaim?' ( pace Hornby '_ the music or the misery?') - isn't even an interesting variation. The plot? Becca's surprisingly successful (twist-free) seduction of Chris, by contriving to make life imitate (low) art (ie John Hughes films). If further proof were needed of the haste with which this was apparently written - Becca manages to enjoy 2001's trashed Mission to Mars . Hokkaido Highway Blues: Hitchhiking in Japan Will Ferguson Canongate £9.99, pp433 Buy it at a discount at BOL Following the blossoming of the cherry trees, marking Japan's seasonal change, Ferguson was bound to be poetically and even philosophically-inspired (the traditional response after drinking plenty of saki), but finds space for countless pop-culture references too: 'What's the point of rebuilding Tokyo Tower? Godzilla will just knock it over again.' Granted, Ferguson tells a lot of old jokes, eg riffing on the similarity of words for 'human' and 'carrot ', but there's no escaping the fact: he tells a lot of jokes, besides delving into the mythology of Japan (priapic monsters seducing peasant girls); the anthropology (the Wisest Monkeys in Japan got their name from their trick of_ washing potatoes) and making a memorable visit to the Taga shrine, whose 'main object of veneration is a_ battering ram of a phallus'. An embarrassment of riches, most definitely; when did you last read a book while grinning in anticipation of the next joke? The Faustian Bargain: The Art World in Nazi Germany Jonathan Petropoulos Penguin £8.99, pp395 Buy it at a discount at BOL As a microcosm of the bourgeoisie or intelligentsia, the Third Reich's art world - at first glance, a subject of limited appeal - is in fact almost perfect for an analysis of the relationship between ethics and culture, or the ethics of the supposedly cultured. And yet their involvement is far from paradoxical, for the likes of Ernst Buchner were 'educated to revere high culture and to believe in German superiority in this regard', and visual artworks have generally been the pre ferred assets of plutocrats seeking to dignify their lucre. The psychology of mass denial is considered - Primo Levi's 'silent transition from falsehood to self-deception' - as is the extent of responsibility: were the half-dozen key figures known to deal directly with the Führer and his high command victims of conformity or victimisers? Overall, this is indispensable reading on Nazi Germany and for everyone concerned with the relation between aesthetics and ethics. The Island in the Mind Rodney Hall Granta £8.99, pp560 Buy it at a discount at BOL Australians seem to have a fondness for rewriting history to put their marginalised continent centrestage. After Einstein as an Australian, Stalin's lovechild raised down under, and Hall's own The Day We Had Hitler Home , this is a subtler comedy in which the 'isle full of noises' of Shakespeare's Tempest is relocated to the Antipodes. Drama and reality are remixed and shuffled so that the staging of the quasi- Tempest precedes a Venetian Miranda's attempt to save the soul of an Aboriginal Caliban before the long-sought land - as unfulfilled desire, as Paradise - is reached. More of a reinvention than a re-telling, this novella-trilogy manages to combine the speculation of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead with the fun and silliness of Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter . Cerebral and visceral, lavish and grotesque, Hall is indubitably the late Robertson Davies's literary heir. A triumph.

fields.headline: Refugees face rise in violence
fields.standfirst:
Asylum-seekers came to Glasgow for shelter but find only danger as teenage gangs inflict terror

Special report: refugees in Britain
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Asylum-seekers came to Glasgow for shelter but find only danger as teenage gangs inflict terror.
fields.body:
Shiren Abdallah and her husband ran from Iraq because of death threats. In Glasgow, they run a gauntlet of stone-throwing teenagers and racial abuse. A decade ago, soon after the European Capital of Culture year in 1990, Glasgow was presented to visitors as the Friendly City. But on housing schemes less than a mile from the city centre, Mrs Abdallah and thousands of others seeking political asylum are finding hatred.

Scotland's largest city extended the hand of friendship to those claiming to be fleeing persecution just over a year ago, when attempts were made to disperse them throughout the UK to await a decision on whether they could stay.

Mrs Abdallah, who did not want to give her real name, arrived at Heathrow with her husband on 22 May. He had been a supporter of Abdullah Ocalan's Kurdish Workers Party (PKK), which has for years sought a Kurdish state spanning land mainly in northern Iraq and southern Turkey. Following Ocalan's arrest two years ago by the Turkish authorities, the factional Kurdish movement was subject to further splits and bitter infighting. Political violence had already claimed the lives of close relatives and now Mr Abdallah found his own life threatened.

'He was told he would be killed if he stayed,' said Mrs Abdallah. 'But all we wanted was a normal life. So we went to Istanbul and from there got on a plane to London. If people did not have problems they would not come to the UK, leaving their homes, their friends and their families.'

Fluent in English and four other languages, the 33-year-old said there was little in the way of advice on arrival at Heathrow. The couple had just £200 to last a month. 'We had no idea London was so expensive. I had to sell a gold ring that I used to wear. A woman bought it from me for £12. We needed money. When we got to Glasgow I had to ask the people at the Scottish Refugee Council for a food parcel.'

Surviving on vouchers of £37 and £20 cash a week, the couple are housed in a small flat in the Sighthill area of the city, which has a massive heroin problem.

Asylum-seekers have come to Glasgow from Iran, Iraq, Somalia, Turkey and other countries. Some have been sent to the outskirts and few problems with local residents have been reported. But a heavy concentration of the 4,000 who are in the city are in Sighthill and it is here that serious problems are emerging.

Last week, in one of many recent incidents, two badly bruised Palestinian brothers said they were beaten by a gang of teenagers. 'It is horrible what has been happening,' lamented Mrs Abdallah. 'For me it is not so bad as I know the language, but still people swear and throw stones. I cannot tell you the things they say. It is unrepeatable. The attitude towards us has got much worse in recent months.'

Mrs Abdallah said that a pregnant Lebanese woman and her husband were recently pursued by a gang of 16- and 17-year-olds. 'The husband pleaded with them not to touch his wife but she was scratched and beaten. She was physically attacked.

'On another occasion some boys got golf clubs and went into a flat where Kurdish boys were living and hit them. Irn-Bru bottles have been thrown at our window, as have stones. And there is a small hole in our window that cannot have been made by a stone. It looks like a bullet hole.'

Chief Superintendent Allan Burnett, race relations officer with Strathclyde Police, is adamant that the force is tackling the problem. 'The issue of children is a big one. Over 50 per cent of people detected causing problems are children.'

Burnett said a number of factors are working to lift the figures: 'There is a seasonal factor. With the longer nights in the summer months there is usually a pattern of increased trouble among youths. As each month has passed the number of incidents has increased, but there has been an increased willingness to report incidents.'

He said: 'We need to build links and trust with the asylum-seekers.' Burnett pointed out that, while there are around 4,000 in the city now, the number will increase towards a ceiling of 6,000. He believes that many will choose to stay should they be granted asylum and a community of greater numbers will develop.

'The force has embarked on a series of community relations meetings, the first of which was well-attended last weekend.'

To deal with the minority, and to build links and trust with those who have recently arrived, Burnett is making sure that officers on the beat provide a visible presence in the problem areas. 'Foot patrols have been put in place. Officers must be visible in appropriate, not necessarily big, numbers.'

Paul Martin, MSP for the Springburn constituency that includes Sighthill, supports the move for an increased police presence. 'People need to be aware that the officers are there. We need to be directing additional funding for policing.' Martin also said more could be done at a local level to help new arrivals learn English, one problem Mrs Abdallah does not have. She helps translate for others who do not possess her strong command of the language. 'It is important people coming here learn English,' she said. 'Life is so much easier when you know the language.' As of last month there was a 500-strong waiting list for English lessons.

Despite the anger that faces her on a daily basis, Mrs Abdallah remains very fond of Scotland and hopes to remain in Glasgow: 'We have neighbours who deal in drugs, yet many people have been very nice to us. We have made an effort to fit in and most people do seem to appreciate that. In these areas many people are suffering. It is not just us. The biggest problems are down to waiting. We must wait for a decision. We must wait to hear about work.'

While she waits, Mrs Abdallah has one simple desire as she walks from her Sighthill flat to catch the bus that will take her to college: 'I just wish to be treated gently.'

webTitle: Black Tory peer fears party axe

fields.headline: Black Tory peer fears party axe
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The black Conservative peer Lord Taylor, who has fiercely criticised William Hague's stance on race, could be silenced this week by his party.
fields.body:
The black Conservative peer Lord Taylor, who has fiercely criticised William Hague's stance on race, could be silenced this week by his party.

Taylor said yesterday that he feared being expelled from the Tories when he is summoned before the party's chief whip in the Lords for a 'discussion' about his views.

The peer, who suffered racial abuse as Tory candidate in Cheltenham in 1992, yesterday renewed his attack on the party leader for failing to discipline the maverick backbench MP John Townend.

Taylor said: 'It would be ironic, wouldn't it, if I were thrown out while John Townend remained in the party?'

However Tory vice-chairman Steve Norris said Taylor was unlikely to be disciplined: 'It's not my place to tell the chief whip how to do his job but John Taylor spoke from the heart about something that he felt strongly about.

'He has made his views plain and I think that he understands that having made his point it's not necessary to elaborate on it any further,' said Norris. 'Those of us who know him well know he is a conviction Conservative and he wants to see the party do well.'

With Conservative Central Office desperate to dampen down the row, Taylor's chief whip, Lord Henley, is expected to ask him to keep a low profile.

Yesterday, however, Taylor backed a speech by the black union leader Bill Morris in which the TGWU leader criticised Hague for his 'foreign land' speech.

'Recently, Mr Hague, described Britain as a foreign land,' Morris told a meeting in Perth. 'To many of us, it is indeed a foreign land. A foreign land where ordinary black British families wake up almost every morning to listen on the radio to descriptions of themselves that they do not recognise.'

He feared not the racist in the street but 'the words of our politicians - which are sometimes taken by the racists as a licence to attack anyone who does not look and speak like them.'

Hague has come under increasing pressure to take the whip away from Townend for his outspoken remarks about immigration, but has refused, arguing that the MP has only weeks left to serve.

Meanwhile, Morris accused the Police Federation, which represents junior and middle-rank officers, of a silent campaign to undermine Sir William Macpherson, author of the report on race and policing. Macpherson complained that he had been hounded into silence by the right-wing press.

webTitle: Observer review: Down the Highway and Bob Dylan, Behind the Shades

fields.headline: Answers are still blowin' in the wind
fields.standfirst:
Bob Dylan just wants to be left alone. Fat chance. Down the Highway and Bob Dylan, Behind the Shades take one more look at the most mythologised figure in pop

Howard Sounes's top 10 music biographies
fields.trailText: Bob Dylan just wants to be left alone. Fat chance. Down the Highway and Bob Dylan, Behind the Shades take one more look at the most mythologised figure in pop
fields.body:
Down the Highway. A Life of Bob Dylan
Howard Sounes
Doubleday £17.99, pp527
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Bob Dylan, Behind the Shades: Take Two
Clinton Heylin
Penguin £9.99, pp780
Buy it at a discount at BOL

With the imminent sixtieth birthday of rock's poet laureate about to unloose a train of tributes and retrospective musings, is there anything left to say about the most mythologised figure in popular music?

There shouldn't be. Dylan's tale has been so frequently told, his works so extensively analysed, his associates so exhaustively interviewed, that even a life as carefully cloaked as his must surely have few further secrets to yield - in pop terms, only the Beatles can boast a comparable list of biography and criticism. But while the Fabs' story ended 20 or 30 years ago, Dylan's continues to ramble on. Just last month, he picked up his first Oscar - for 'Things Have Changed', the bleak hymn of disillusion he supplied for The Wonder Boys - which the ravaged icon acknowledged by video link from Australia, his current port of call on the 'never-ending tour' on which he's been hiding out for the last 15 years.

You can find Dylan's Oscar acceptance speech on the web, along with the set lists from his Australian dates and from every other tour. You can also unearth a tally of the dogs (mostly large and fierce) owned and, it's alleged, apparently abandoned by the bard, and, on a site called Tangled Up In Jews, an account of where he celebrated Passover throughout the Eighties. Increasingly, Dylan studies are a matter of niche marketing; next month, for example, Bloomsbury issues David Hadju's Positively Fourth Street, a book devoted to the formative years on the Greenwich Village folk scene.

Grand overviews of Dylan's sprawling, inconsistent career, from its roots in small-town Minnesota to the present, are harder to come by. One is confined to Clinton Heylin's recently updated Behind the Shades, now issued in paperback, and this new volume from Howard Sounes, whose previous books were biographies of the murderers Fred and Rose West and the writer Charles Bukowski.

In Down the Highway, Sounes pulls off several revelatory coups, chief among them that in 1986 Dylan secretly married Carolyn Dennis, one of his backing singers, after she had added a sixth child, Desiree, to the five from his first marriage to model Sara Lownds. The couple set up home in a bland bungalow close to the roar of LA's Ventura Boulevard, though neither this nor Dylan's aggressive religiosity stopped him maintaining a series of other love affairs, such as that with label executive Carole Childs, who was also set up with a Beverly Hills home.

If the apparent duplicity of his tangled love life is one reason for Dylan's secrecy, obsessive fans are another. After John Lennon's murder, and a series of stalking incidents, he purchased a bulletproof vest, and Sounes suggests that the list of problematic individuals held by Dylan's security staff currently runs to some 500 names. Endlessly bootlegged, his garbage ransacked, his every move scrutinised by an army of Bobaholics, it's small wonder Dylan says simply: 'Like most famous people, I want to be left alone.'

Fat chance. Sounes put in three years and 250 interviews to produce Down the Highway, though the great man himself predictably declined to contribute. Engagingly written and scrupulously researched, it proves a sympathetic but never fawning account which moves evenly through Dylan's career; too evenly, since the comings and goings of years on the road are never going to yield the cultural payback of his mercurial Sixties.

At a third longer, Heylin's book arguably offers more insight into the elusive psyche of one of pop's few bona fide geniuses. Yet it's Sounes who unravels Dylan's shrouded romantic life and business affairs more satisfactorily. He pries open the bitter legal battle between the singer and his former manager, Albert Grossman (resolved only after Grossman's death in 1986) and reveals the ruthless streak required of any star who wants to avoid being asset-stripped by the rapacious music business.

Neither author, however, can explain just why Dylan, having gained control of his catalogue, should choose to let 'The Times They Are a Changing' become an advertising jingle for both the Bank of Montreal and the accountancy firm, Coopers and Lybrand. Sheer contrariness seems to be the best explanation, together with Dylan's distaste for the 'Voice of a Generation' tag foisted on him during his protest years.

Dylan's perversity is a recurring theme. His various bands have all had to get used to his playing unannounced numbers in undeclared keys, to being roundly ignored when not on stage and to being summarily dismissed.

Sounes is weakest where Dylan is at his strongest. The majestic trilogy of 1960s albums at the heart of Dylan's reputation - Bringing It All Back Home, Highway 61 Revisited and Blonde on Blonde, records which redefined the art of popular song - slip past unilluminated. Rarely does either book drive one to the source of all the wonder, the music itself, or offer a glimpse of its resonance.

webTitle: Freedom, censorship and spin in the Asia-Pacific

fields.headline: Freedom, censorship and spin in the Asia-Pacific
fields.standfirst:
Change for the better - but have those with most freedom forgotten what it is for?

Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Pieter Wessels on some signs of positive change - but have those with most freedom forgotten what it is for?
fields.body:
Things are looking up for media freedom here is the Asia-Pacific. There is a glimmer of improvement throughout most of South-East Asia. In countries like Vietnam there is perceptible change as repressive rules and restrictions are very slowly lifted, probably as a response of international pressure. Even in Burma, there are signs that pressure could lead to change.

That does not look much in the glare of the very active and free media in Thailand, or of the Philippines, where a free media has overthrown a popular but corrupt President.

The freedom flower in the region, however, is Indonesia whose press and broadcast media has blossomed since the toppling of the Suharto regime.

Censorship and red tape is gone and both local and foreign journalists reporting in Indonesia are free to travel where they want and say what they like.

It's led to a rush of news throughout the world - not all of it nice. But the understanding of the huge problems Indonesia faces has led to a helpful sympathy from governments and people in the region, and the rest of the world. Indonesia takes the prize this decade for showing the concrete advantages of a free media, even when the news is so frequently so bad.

The same can't be said for the new repression apparent in Malaysia and Singapore. Already strict licensing of the press and government control of broadcast news have been beefed up even as commercial broadcasting grows and the quality of production of both press and broadcast reaches high levels of excellence. In Malaysia the ruling party feels its grasp on power slipping, and is using oppressive media laws from the days of the Communist Emergency and the entrenched old-boy network among media proprietors to dampen bad news and stop criticism.

Singapore continues its clever use of law to restrict what the press can do and say, both internally and internationally. Journalists who depart from the "Singapore" line are subject to both criminal and civil proceedings in the courts and damages are huge.

It is the non-metropolitan areas of Asia that present the most interesting developments in press freedom. Small newspapers still exist in large numbers and - in a rural sort of way - are active and push the boundaries of what's allowed. Being far from the centres of government control, they frequently get away with things that city newsrooms can't. Starting a newspaper costs little, and small circulations are acceptable. Journalists gets paid a pittance and usually are not trained, but it does work in favour of a certain freedom.

It's not all sweetness and light however. Journalists working in rural Asia have a problem with respect. Respect for age, respect for authority, respect for local culture and mores makes it hard for reporters to get stories and makes investigate a dirty word when used with journalism. During interviewing training journalists say "I can't ask him that ... he's my chief/uncle/superior." In some places a journalist is so lowly he can't even talk to the chief, much less ask a question.

This same respect for authority is a problem in the Pacific as well. The many small, even tiny states, in the Pacific have strong cultural traditions that get in the way of "western" style journalism. To criticise or even question someone staging a coup in your country can be not only rude, but can endanger your family. Everyone knows everyone else on the islands and the heavies always know where you live. Can press freedom exist under such intimate conditions?

Fiji and the Solomon Island have been the media freedom hot spots in the Pacific in the last year. The Fiji media is heavily divided on how good a job it did of covering Speight's highjacking of parliament but is universal in its condemnation of how badly the international media covered it. The nation's media is relatively free but has become aware that being free isn't enough. They've discovered it takes skill and experience to handle political crises and violence. Is this a threat to media freedom, or just reality?

Violence against journalists is the problem in the inter-island fighting in the Solomons as well. A small, well-organised and relatively free media suddenly found itself confronted not only with differences within its own membership, but also in crossing or not crossing lines. A breakdown of effective government didn't help much either, in a country where much of the media is government owned.

Perhaps the most spectacular threat to media freedom in the Pacific was in Vanuatu where Marc Neil-Jones, the editor of the country's only independent newspaper The Trading Post, found a deep throat and started exposing suspect government business dealings. Police grabbed him from his home and shoved him on the first plane out, on the pretext that he was British born and not a local. Within days the courts ruled the government couldn't do that and he returned. The story says something good and something bad about Vanuatu, but the result is a step forward for media freedom throughout the Pacific.

Between the Pacific and Asia is Australasia - Australia and New Zealand - both shedding the brightest light in the region on freedom of the media. Everyone - even the politicians and the military - pays lip service to a free and responsible press and the right of broadcasters to say and do what they want.

But in Australia and New Zealand the media itself is probably its own worst enemy, As in the rest of the developed north, readership is falling, independent papers are disappearing into global corporations, government broadcasters are being corporatised, privatized, downsized and out-sourced to death, and private broadcasters are so challenged by the new media they don't know which way to turn.

At the same time Australian journalists are finding a new source of high income - spin doctoring. Every politicians, bureaucrat, and CEO you see on TV has a hack hovering in the background of every interview. Usually it is someone journalists used to know as a colleague - frequently a very skilful and hard working one. Now that colleague is working the other side of the tracks, forcing the truth and frequently corrupting it.

As well as a PR and media industry to influence them, and the pressures of 'downsizing', journalists in Australia have to put up with a legal industry set on stopping them. Writs and damages have become a big part of any media effort in Australia and the costs have killed a number of small and independent newspapers.

Not long ago Australia's best know investigative reporter, the brilliant Chris Masters whose reports have brought down governments, got up and said that it wasn't worth being an investigative journalist any more. The legal side took just too much time and effort. It was perhaps the biggest blow media freedom in Australia has taken in recent years.

Pieter Wessels is a senior journalist working out of Sydney and spending half the year in South and South-east Asia and the Pacific. He worked for many years in broadcast journalism, with the Australian Broadcasting Commission, and is now an independent reporter, writer and trainer for the press and the internet. He heads the Asia-Pacific chapter of the Commonwealth Journalists Association.

webTitle: Cricket: Aussies pull the plug on talent pool

fields.headline: Aussies pull the plug on talent pool
fields.standfirst: The days of top-class Australians adding class and style to county cricket are numbered
fields.trailText: The days of top-class Australians adding class and style to county cricket are numbered.
fields.body:
Changes to Australian playing contracts will put an end to cricketing greats such as Shane Warne and Glenn McGrath plying their summer trade. Last year both bowlers were on £100,000-plus contracts with Hampshire and Worcestershire respectively.

In the past, top attractions such as Allan Border Dennis Lillee, Jeff Thomson and Graham McKenzie added lustre to the domestic championship. Now the routine trawl of Australia by counties in pursuit of a reliable overseas player is likely to be checked once an agreement between the Australian Cricket Board and the Australian Cricketers Association has been finalised.

Negotiations between the ACB and the ACA, whose chairman is the former Australian off-spinner Tim May, are due to be completed by 1 July and the outcome will be that Australian state players as well as their Test cricketers will be restricted in their appearances for English counties.

There are 11 Australians playing in county cricket even though their national side is touring England this summer. Independently the counties have come to the conclusion that 'second-XI Aussies' represent good value. Invariably they fit in well, set a fine example to their colleagues and all seem to appear near the top of the averages come September.

Moreover, since they are not international superstars, they do not - unless they happen to be Warne or McGrath - command astronomical salaries, though each would expect to earn at least £50,000. However, the ACB are becoming concerned that prolonged spells in English county cricket, which the Aussies have never regarded very highly, might lead to burn-out among their potential Test players.

Moreover, the Australian authorities are conscious that the absence of state players for so much of the Australian winter also disrupt the state teams' preparation for their new season. Last summer Warne and McGrath needed the permission of the ACB to play county cricket, which was reluctantly given.

It may not have been worth the ACB's while to stop them. Refusal to allow Warne and McGrath to cash in on a rare break in the Australian cricket calendar would have caused considerable acrimony among Australia's two leading players and any dispute might even have ended up in the law courts.

However such permission is less likely to be granted. To compensate, Australian Test cricketers are likely to be given far more lucrative contracts - A$400,000 (£145,000) plus- to reward them for their commitment .

Regular Australian Test players have limited opportunities to play county cricket on a regular basis because of the expanding international calendar. But the move to restrict State players, who have little or no international experience, marks a significant change.

State cricketers in Australia sign 12-month contracts with their state associations, which, for an established player, might comprise a A$50,000 retainer, a figure that could be doubled by match fees if the player was ever-present. Tim May will seek a significant increase for his players if they are to bow to restrictions about playing in England.

A blanket ban of Australians in England is certainly not envisaged, but it may be that players over 25 will only be allowed one ticket to England. And there will be special cases. For example those such as Stuart Law and Jamie Cox, regulars in England, who because of their age are now unlikely to make the Australian side, would be permitted to continue though they might have to sacrifice a fraction of their new, improved state contracts since they would be absent from all the state training in the Australian winter.

Of course the Australians want to exploit the county system as best they can. So they would be happy for under-25s to come to England to gain experience but unhappy to see their players ground down by the volume and - in their eyes - the mediocre standard of county cricket in their middle years. Of those in England at the moment, these plans are most likely to effect Michael Hussey, Martin Love and Jimmy Maher, all of whom have a chance of stepping into the Australian side when the Waughs eventually retire.

If the pool of eager Australians were to dry up, it would leave the counties in a quandary. The resources can still be found for an overseas player and, because the salaries available are attractive, there is no shortage of foreign players attracted to English cricket, but increasingly the international calendar does not permit overseas stars to be available for a chunk of the season.

Australia is the only country where non-Test cricketers can - more or less - be guaranteed to be of sufficiently high standard to excel in county cricket. Now that the Aussie influx cannot be taken for granted, it may be that counties will seek to relax the restrictions so it is possible to have two overseas players on their books, ideally of a high profile, whose appearances will dovetail according to their availability through the English season.

fields.headline: Censorship in Egypt
fields.standfirst:
Growing pressures for democratisation

Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Tariq Hassan-Gordon argues that pressure for democratisation is growing.
fields.byline: Tariq Hassan-Gordon, Egypt News Editor, Middle East Times
fields.body:
Egypt is a country of contradictions. Despite massive economic liberalization the state still maintains a tight grip on political activity and freedom of expression.

Every week the government censor reads our newspaper before it can be distributed.

Out of necessity the editorial staff must self-censor articles to ensure that the publication makes it to the newsstands and to subscribers without disruption.

We still push the boundaries, but taboo topics such as religion, sexuality, political violence and the presidential family must be treated with care.

The situation may soon change. Internet access is doubling every year in Egypt, which gives unprecedented access to everything from pornography to banned Islamic groups. At some stage the momentum will force the government to democratize its censorship laws, and we will be there to cover it.

The Middle East Times censored page

The man who doesn't do what he doesn't do - a Middle East Times interview with the censor

webTitle: How the capital of  cool lost its allure

fields.headline: How the capital of  cool lost its allure
fields.standfirst: Four years ago London was hailed by Newsweek as the coolest city on the planet. Now even Fishguard gets more plaudits.  Amelia Hill discovers why the gloss has worn off and asks just what has gone wrong
fields.trailText: Four years ago London was hailed by Newsweek as the coolest city on the planet. Now even Fishguard gets more plaudits. Amelia Hill discovers why the gloss has worn off and asks just what has gone wrong.
fields.body:
It was the moment Londoners stopped apologising for the drabness, the traffic, their manners and the price of a cappuccino. Suddenly, everything was cool, sophisticated, innovative and of such quality that the rest of the world could only watch in envy.

It was 4 November 1996 and the capital was, officially and categorically, labelled the coolest city on the planet. 'When I wrote that cover article for Newsweek , London was bubbling over with creativity and verve,' said Stryker McGuire, UK editor of the American magazine.

'The city's clubs, fashion industry, art world, architecture and general lifestyle were streets ahead of anything the rest of the world had to offer,' he added. 'My only concern was that enough people wouldn't be able to get here in time to enjoy the fun because one thing was certain: it wouldn't last.'

And it hasn't. Four years after coolly accepting the accolade, London has come back to earth with a bump. This week could see the city descend into chaos, paralysed by May Day rioters and disgruntled Tube workers.

This is just the climax to a litany of grinding problems, apparently unsolved despite the election exactly a year ago of a maverick Mayor. In the past few weeks alone, accounts of gangland shootings have hit the headlines; tourists have deserted the capital in droves, frightened off by stories of national malaise; Mayor Ken Livingstone has failed to resolve the Tube crisis and the city's stock has plummeted in the eyes of the world.

So steeply, in fact, that the latest edition of the Lonely Planet travel guide unceremoniously stripped the city of its crown of cool, condemning it instead for its worship of commerce over culture and awarding it the wooden spoon.

'It's not a great time for London's tourist industry,' admitted Lonely Planet 's Jennifer Cox. 'But this book is extremely positive about the majority of places in Britain. We rave about Fishguard.'

How did London lose out to Fishguard? A cursory glance at the paeans inspired by the London Eye, the Tate Modern, Somerset House, British Museum and the restored Wallace Collection seems to prove that the capital's cultural life is still bubbling.

Leading architects including Richard Rogers and Norman Foster are continuing their transformation of the city and, when it finally reopens, the Millennium bridge will enable tourists and natives alike to view the chaos all around them, once magnificent, now depressing.

'Londoners and foreigners alike are on a generalised downer about the city,' said McGuire. 'It's a feeling that may not be justified by facts and figures, but the psychology of depression that's going around now is just as important.'

The irony is that London has done much to puncture its own myth: the gloss of smugness, with which it assumed that its natural verve and vitality would hide any multitude of sins, has been rubbed away, revealing a natural pessimism.

'Where once there was hope and expectation in London, there's now disillusion and apathy,' said McGuire. 'In the last year or so there has been a sudden convergence of the scepticism and cynicism bred by disappointment. Now people who may have said the glass was half-full four years ago are calling it half-empty.'

Part of the problem was the attempt by Prime Minister Tony Blair in the wake of Newsweek 's piece to trade on London's success. With the age-old wisdom of the terminally uncool, the Government failed to appreciate that the moment it nominated representatives of cool to sip champagne in Downing Street, it ensured the termination of their reputation with deadly accuracy.

Not that this would normally matter, pointed out Rachael Philipps, editor of Time Out 's 'Sell Out' section. One of the central reasons for London's coolness is its ability to spawn and gobble up trends.

But a stillness to London's once whitewater-rapid waters has emerged from the ripples that emanated from Newsweek 's article. A self-fulfilling prophecy of despair is sucking the city down. The malaise can be seen from the top deck of any bus: the No 38, for example, links Hackney, where more shootings take place than anywhere else in Britain, to Piccadilly Circus, battening down its hatches against the May Day rioters.

'I don't know whether it's because the absence of political opposition has taken the positive tension out of the system,' said McGuire. 'But until something changes, this cultural and intellectual stagnation is going to continue and the mood is going to worsen.'

In his book, London: A Biography, Peter Ackroyd tells how London is anthropomorphised in different forms depending on the mood of the time: in times of optimism, the city is portrayed as a young man, lithe and vital; in times of trouble, it becomes a deformed giant, swollen headed and shrunken limbed, choked by ashes and killing more than it breeds.

'This is a city built on money, power, trade and commerce,' said Ackroyd. 'It is uniquely brutalising and ugly, built on the imperatives of money, not the need of its citizens.'

Although crime has fallen overall, police worry that the criminals have simply moved out of the engorged centre and into the less high-profile outlying areas: there were 17 per cent more homicides in south London last year than in 1999, and 8 per cent more in the east.

In the centre of the city, including Theatreland and the rest of the West End, there is evidence that few inroads have been made into serious crime. 'I've been coming to London for business and holidays every year for the past decade and I've never felt so insecure,' said Wafa Omar, pausing in front of a yellow police sign in Leicester Square asking for help with a murder. 'They say crime is down but, to me, it feels more theatening.'

As the map of London grows ever bigger, as the Outer Metropolitan Area melds into the Greater London and Inner London areas, tourists and natives alike begin to feel they are losing grasp of London's true identity.

Rob Humphreys, editor of the London Rough Guide for the past 15 years, believes the city has simply become too big: 'There's very little sense of self in London any more,' he said.

'There's no coherent sense of identity in the city as a whole, there are just a load of disparate communities which swallow people up, all too often forcing them into deprived pockets which they can't get out of.'

Standing on the Royal Victoria Dock footpath down by the Dome, the heart of of London's renewal, Alan Craig bears testimony to this claim. All around him glint signs of the much-praised redevelopment of London's eastern river corridor: cranes dip over the half-built ExCel exhibition centre, finishing touches are now being put to the University of England's campus, shining cars accelerate away from the Britannia Village and planes roar in towards London City Airport.

In the midst of this activity, however, Craig runs a community project, the Mayflower centre, on the Kier Hardie estate in Ordnance ward, Canning Town, Britain's most deprived district.

'We've been waiting for this sort of regeneration for decades,' said Craig. 'We were delighted when all this started happening a few years ago. We thought it was proof that London was really on the up.'

But instead the local council announced in February that 1,900 households were going to be served with compulsory purchase orders and moved out of the area so that private, wealthy tenants could be moved in.

'This treatment exposes the lie at the heart of the claim that London is a modern city of cool,' said Craig.

'The Government has a vision about what they want London to be like and they're determined to achieve that despite the little people getting in the way.

'We were ignored by the previous government, which was bad enough, but this area has two sorts of poverty now - the poverty of material things and the poverty of complete disempowerment.'
