The malaise can be seen from the top deck of any bus: the No 38, for example, links Hackney, where more shootings take place than anywhere else in Britain, to Piccadilly Circus, battening down its hatches against the May Day rioters. 'I don't know whether it's because the absence of political opposition has taken the positive tension out of the system,' said McGuire. 'But until something changes, this cultural and intellectual stagnation is going to continue and the mood is going to worsen.' In his book, London: A Biography, Peter Ackroyd tells how London is anthropomorphised in different forms depending on the mood of the time: in times of optimism, the city is portrayed as a young man, lithe and vital; in times of trouble, it becomes a deformed giant, swollen headed and shrunken limbed, choked by ashes and killing more than it breeds. 'This is a city built on money, power, trade and commerce,' said Ackroyd. 'It is uniquely brutalising and ugly, built on the imperatives of money, not the need of its citizens.' Although crime has fallen overall, police worry that the criminals have simply moved out of the engorged centre and into the less high-profile outlying areas: there were 17 per cent more homicides in south London last year than in 1999, and 8 per cent more in the east. In the centre of the city, including Theatreland and the rest of the West End, there is evidence that few inroads have been made into serious crime. 'I've been coming to London for business and holidays every year for the past decade and I've never felt so insecure,' said Wafa Omar, pausing in front of a yellow police sign in Leicester Square asking for help with a murder. 'They say crime is down but, to me, it feels more theatening.' As the map of London grows ever bigger, as the Outer Metropolitan Area melds into the Greater London and Inner London areas, tourists and natives alike begin to feel they are losing grasp of London's true identity. Rob Humphreys, editor of the London Rough Guide for the past 15 years, believes the city has simply become too big: 'There's very little sense of self in London any more,' he said. 'There's no coherent sense of identity in the city as a whole, there are just a load of disparate communities which swallow people up, all too often forcing them into deprived pockets which they can't get out of.' Standing on the Royal Victoria Dock footpath down by the Dome, the heart of of London's renewal, Alan Craig bears testimony to this claim. All around him glint signs of the much-praised redevelopment of London's eastern river corridor: cranes dip over the half-built ExCel exhibition centre, finishing touches are now being put to the University of England's campus, shining cars accelerate away from the Britannia Village and planes roar in towards London City Airport. In the midst of this activity, however, Craig runs a community project, the Mayflower centre, on the Kier Hardie estate in Ordnance ward, Canning Town, Britain's most deprived district. 'We've been waiting for this sort of regeneration for decades,' said Craig. 'We were delighted when all this started happening a few years ago. We thought it was proof that London was really on the up.' But instead the local council announced in February that 1,900 households were going to be served with compulsory purchase orders and moved out of the area so that private, wealthy tenants could be moved in. 'This treatment exposes the lie at the heart of the claim that London is a modern city of cool,' said Craig. 'The Government has a vision about what they want London to be like and they're determined to achieve that despite the little people getting in the way. 'We were ignored by the previous government, which was bad enough, but this area has two sorts of poverty now - the poverty of material things and the poverty of complete disempowerment.'

fields.headline: No sex and the city
fields.standfirst: Joanne O'Connor  and four friends follow in Sarah Jessica Parker's designer footsteps in New York. They find the shoes, shops and bars. As for the men...
fields.trailText: Joanne O'Connor and four friends follow in Sarah Jessica Parker's designer footsteps in New York. They find the shoes, shops and bars. As for the men...
fields.body:
When a girl is tired of London, it's time to head for New York - where you get more city per square mile, the brunches are longer, the shoes cheaper, the martinis bigger and the men... well, more of that later.

On a cold, drizzly London morning, I fight my way through the London rush-hour traffic to Heathrow with a half-empty suitcase and a few well-chosen friends. Seven hours later, we are fighting our way through the rush-hour traffic on a cold, drizzly New York afternoon. But because we don't live here and because we don't have to get up for work tomorrow and because dollars might as well be Monopoly money the grey skies can't dampen our spirits.

This is my second trip to New York which takes the pressure off as far as sightseeing is concerned. And as we have decided that we are emphatically not tourists, a hotel is, of course, out of the question. For our brief sojourn, we will live like the natives, in an apartment.

When does a brunch become lunch?

If you are going to live in an apartment, you have to buy things like milk and bread for breakfast. Until you grasp this fact (it took us two days), there is always brunch. Brunch is great because it allows you to eat a fried breakfast the right side of 11.30am (that is, after it) and no one will raise an eyebrow if you order a bloody Mary to go with it. It is also a fantastic opportunity to experience some of Manhattan's most fashionable restaurants without booking weeks ahead and still see some change from a $50 bill. Pastis, for example, has been packing them into the Meatpacking District (which at the time of going to press was New York's most upwardly mobile neighbourhood but will probably be very old hat by the time you read this). It is far too cool to take reservations and people will happily wait two hours for a table to rub shoulders with well-groomed regulars such as Sarah Jessica Parker. But on a weekday morning the staff might actually be glad to see you. With the aid of a few carafes of house red, our brunch seeps into lunch and the tables fill up around us. While earnest media execs discuss brand values, we get down to the much more serious business of discussing the pros and cons of plastic surgery.

Do blondes really have more fun?

I don't rate the New York department stores that highly. A hosiery department looks pretty much the same the world over. For shopping with a bit of local flavour, you'll need to get off Fifth Avenue and head downtown to the boutiques of Soho, the West Village or Nolita (the name given to the warren of streets just north of Little Italy).

After an embarrassing struggle with a shop door on Mott Street (in this area, all the shops have entry buzzers), I am sprinkled with rose water by a beautiful nymph wearing a bindi and ordered to 'enjoy'. Be warned: these shops may look like kooky little neighbourhood boutiques but there's nothing kooky about the prices. I try on a couple of dresses which seemed to be made out of gossamer and held together with cobweb. The only thing of any substance is the price tag - $600! I find my karma strangely unbalanced and head for the door. Luckily, there is no shortage of second-hand stores in this part of town where you'll find vintage designer dresses, beaded handbags and Manolo Blahniks for under $200.

No cash was spilt, however, until we got to Soho where it all suddenly went horribly wrong for Kate and Alex. Venus is an emporium of all things kitsch owned by Sex and the City stylist Patricia Field. Leopardskin G-strings, diamanté tiaras, fake furs in tangerine and lime; our credit cards were safe here, or so we thought. But we hadn't reckoned on Alton O. Spot, wig stylist to the stars. Within minutes of entering the shop, Kate and Alex had been lured into his salon at the back of the shop and were being fitted out with tumbling tresses in deep mahogany and Titian hues. We left that shop with less money but considerably more hair than when we went in. Back at the apartment we swap wigs and discuss the etiquette of synthetic hair, including the thorny issue of at what point in the evening you reveal to your date that those locks he is caressing come with their own box and a set of care instructions.

What to wear and other sticky issues

There's nothing like a few days pounding the mean streets of Manhattan to take the roses out of your cheeks. I decide to treat myself to a pick-me-up at one of New York's hippest spas, Bliss. The treatment list is mindboggling. Skipping anything with the word blast or peel in it, I opt for the carrot and sesame body buff. I am shown into a 'wet-room' where I am drizzled with warm milk and honey, massaged with grated carrot, wrapped in foil and baked for 20 minutes. I am then rubbed briskly with sea salt and sesame seeds, glazed with lemon and thyme oil, garnished with parsley (I made that bit up) and returned to the 'robe-room' to recover. I help myself to the free buffet of chilled cucumber and float out to meet the girls who are eager to hear about my adventure. 'I do a fish dish like that,' observes Alex.

Buffed and fragrant, I am ready to hit the town. But confronting the options for a night out in New York is like walking into a deli with a 30ft-long counter. The choice can be overwhelming and, unless you know what you want before you go in, you can end up walking out with a cheese and tomato sandwich. An Ayurvedic meal in Alphabet City, jazz in Greenwich Village, a poetry recital in the East Village or a saké tasting in Soho? Or we could just go for a pizza. Guidebooks are brandished, suggestions trampled on, tempers frayed before a decision is reached. Eventually we emerge from the apartment leaving a trail of teacups, scattered guide books, discarded clothes and wet towels behind us.

There are many different ways to kickstart a night out in Manhattan: champagne in the lobby of the Algonquin Hotel; cocktails in the classy Campbell Apartment at Grand Central station and unnecessarily large martinis in the swanky Fifty Seven Fifty Seven piano bar at the Four Seasons are just a few of the methods we tried and tested.

One night Steph and I find ourselves gatecrashing a college poetry society reunion. In a tiny East Village bar, a lawyer called Peter wearing braces and a Burberry scarf recites the first 25 stanzas of Beowulf , in perfect Middle English. We try to look suitably impressed. As we say our goodbyes, he slips us a business card and tell us to look up his website. When we get back to London there is an email waiting for us from Peter. 'Thanks for a great evening. It was spontaneous and fun which is what New York should be.' Indeed.

Rent the apartment, join the gang

Want to get a slice of the Sex and the City lifestyle? You won't get an invite to the gang if you're clutching your hotel-room key while bar-hopping. The only way to get under the skin of a city is to rent an apartment and live like the locals do. In a city such as New York, where you'd be lucky to get a hotel room for under $100 a night, it can even save you money, especially if you are travelling with a group of friends or family.

There are an increasing number of agencies which specialise in subletting properties to tourists on a short-term basis. New York Habitat's website displays floor plans, pictures and detailed descriptions of more than 3,000 properties ranging from furnished studios at $85 a week to chic three-bedroom West Side apartments for $6,000.

As well as full kitchen facilities, practically all the apartments come with television, videos, stereos and books while the most luxurious have shared gyms and swimming-pools.

But renting an apartment comes with certain responsibilities that visitors should bear in mind: the role of many agencies ends once contact has been made between visitor and homeowner, leaving owners free to impose their personal house rules on their guests. These rules can be as harmless as asking guests to water plants or collect the mail but there is nothing to stop them demanding more onerous duties, such as washing all sheets and towels before leaving.

A good halfway house between an apartment and a hotel is a suite hotel. Manhattan East Suite Hotels offers self-catering apartments with room service, doormen and a concierge on call. The company has 10 properties in Manhattan's stylish East Side and Midtown with prices from $250 a week. A separate living area, kitchen and laundry/dry-cleaning services come as standard while the most luxurious properties include gardens and Jacuzzis.

Some UK tour operators offer apartments as an alternative to hotels for short- break visitors. America As You Like It has around 500 privately-owned apartments on its books, sleeping from two to eight people.

(001 212 966 4066)

A minimalist haven for style worshippers in the heart of the Meatpacking District. Tempting shoe selection.

INA

One of the best places in New York to pick up second-hand designer wear and shoes.

Cafe Gitane
242 Mott St

The perfect coffee stop on a Nolita shopping spree, this trendy cafe attracts an Eastside arty crowd.

Pastis
9 Ninth Ave
(001 212 929 4844)
Tiled walls and antique mirrors create a Parisian ambience at this fashionable Meatpacking District bistro. Be prepared to wait for a table in the evening.

Fifty Seven Fifty Seven at the Four Seasons Hotel
57 East 57th St
(001 212 758 5700)
Enjoy mega-martinis at this sleek, chic and ultra pricey piano bar.

Campbell Apartment

Work your way through the extensive cocktail and champagne list in this opulent bar.

webTitle: Malaysia - ending the government's monopoly on the truth

fields.headline: Ending the government's monopoly on the truth
fields.standfirst:
The internet presents a dilemma for the Malaysian government which those promoting freedom can exploit
Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: The internet presents a dilemma for the Malaysian government, which those promoting freedom can exploit, says Steven Gan of Malaysiakini.com
fields.body:
In Malaysia, we have freedom of speech. But not freedom after speech.

True, there is a constitution which guarantees freedom of speech. But it also allows the government to impose restrictions, as it deems necessary, to protect national security. This has led to a litany of laws that severely curb freedom of expression.

But while the government holds true to its dark reputation of keeping the media on a short leash with a coterie of repressive laws, it has nevertheless decided not to do the same with the internet.

No doubt, this is not because the government has suddenly become more open to political dissent. On the contrary, it has no choice but to leave the net alone. The reason is simple. Censoring the net would mean cutting off our lifeline to the future.

Working in the government's favour, however, is that the penetration rate of the internet is still low. Only 11 percent of Malaysians have personal computers and six percent surf the Net. Simply put, the government has nothing to worry about. Until now, that is.

The phenomenon success of Malaysiakini.com, an independent online news, should serve as an advance warning. Launched over a year ago, it now one of the news websites in Malaysia, registering an average of 150,000 unique visitors a day.

Its success indicates that the self-censored mainstream media have lost so much credibility that a growing number of Malaysians are seeking alternative news on the net. Indeed, with the advent of the Internet, the government can no longer have complete monopoly on truth.

Steven Gan is a co-founder of Malaysia's first and only independent media, Malaysiakini.com. Malaysiakini received the Free Media Pioneer 2001 award from the International Press Institute and Gan received the Committee to Protect Journalists' International Press Freedom Award 2000.

Steven graduated in political economy in Australia in 1989. He spent four years as a freelance journalist based in Hong Kong and travelled extensively during that time. He covered the Gulf War from Baghdad in 1991. He returned to Malaysia in 1994 and was appointed special issues editor for the newly launched Sun newspaper. He also wrote a weekly column, "Thursday with Steven Gan" although he frequently had to battle both the paper's internal censors and with the government.

A year later, he helped break a story on the deaths of 59 inmates in the Semenyih immigration detention camp. When the editors refused to publish the story, he gave the information to human rights activist Irene Fernandez, who was subsequently charged by the government with spreading "false news", which is a crime in Malaysia. Her trial is underway currently in Kuala Lumpur. In 1996, Steven was arrested during the Asia Pacific Conference on East Timor (Apcet II). He was adopted by Amnesty International as a prisoner of conscience. His last column was on the Apcet II fracas, which was spiked by the editor. He resigned from the paper in protest and worked as editorial writer for The Nation newspaper in Bangkok for two years.

fields.headline: The Life and Works of Beethoven by Jeremy Siepmann
fields.trailText: His suffering was on a tragic scale, not least the deafness which imposed upon him the torment of isolation. Yet he produced some of the greatest, most life-enhancing music ever written
fields.body:
(Naxos Audiobooks £11.99; CD £16.99 5hr) Narrated by the author, with Bob Peck as Beethoven and extracts from 18 Naxos Beethoven recordings

Physically, Beethoven was unprepossessing: only 5ft 2in, with ungainly movements, unkempt hair and a wild beard. He was given to periods of self-loathing following indulgence in brothels, and frequently lived in squalid disorder, with sheets of music scattered over the piano beside an unemptied chamber pot. Driven by a craving for a wife and family, the composer lurched from one romantic attachment to another, always with unattainable young women.

Following the death of his brother, Beethoven undertook an extraordinary campaign to claim his nephew Karl as his own, treating him and his widowed mother with such emotional cruelty that, in desperation, Karl shot himself in the head. He survived but Beethoven was permanently scarred.

His suffering was on a tragic scale, not least the deafness which imposed upon him the torment of isolation. Yet he produced some of the greatest, most life-enhancing music ever written. Take the Fifth Symphony: in the dramatic opening, Fate knocks menacingly at the door, yet the whole work is an affirmation of tremendous joy which triumphs over darkness.

This portrait in sound is a great success and, like Beethoven's music - so generously illustrated here - its overall effect is uplifting.

This portrait in sound is a great success and, like Beethoven's music - so generously illustrated here - its overall effect is uplifting.

fields.headline: Count to three for freedom
fields.standfirst:
Editors whose bravery gives the press a good name
Press freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Viewpoint: Peter Preston applauds the editors whose bravery gives the press a good name.
fields.body:
Some awards juries are different. The one I sit on - the one I wouldn't miss - has a special power and a special pull. Sometimes it can get people - innocent people - out of prison. I hope that begins to happen on Thursday for U Tin Win. But he is what he has been since 1989, a prisoner of Burma's unrelenting military dictators. Count three (for 3 May) and pray.

U Tin Win used to edit the Hanthawati Times and campaign for democracy, of which press freedom is an umbilical part. He knowingly courted personal disaster; it duly arrived. He was sentenced to 12 years in jail, then had another eight added, with almost casual brutality, when he was found with a pen and paper in his cell. He languishes now, health broken, behind locked doors at Rangoon general hospital. The generals say they will let him out if he recants and falls silent. He suffers, but he stays.

My jury, 14 journalists from around the globe, meets once a year at Unesco headquarters in Paris to choose the Guillermo Cano prizewinner for World Press Freedom Day. It is, simultaneously, a dispiriting and inspiring task.

Cano (a brave Colombian editor) was gunned down by drug cartel assassins and his family give the prize in his memory. Sometimes - for Christina Anyanwu in Nigeria or Gao Yu in China - winning helps and their prison doors open. Sometimes even the clout of Unesco brings no instant relief. Nizar Nayyouf, going blind in a Syrian military jail, won it last year. Assad the Elder is dead and Assad the supposedly Younger and More Liberal has taken over, but Nayyouf is still wretchedly behind bars and renewing a hunger strike which will surely kill him. Again - a recurring theme - he can go free if he shuts up. He will do no such thing.

What's dispiriting about this jury? The impossibility of choosing between murdered editors in the Congo and murdered reporters in Cyprus, between gallant Serbs who fought the good fight against Milosevic and survived and Burma's legions of the lost. Any individual choice - of the living over the dead, the victors over the vanquished - seems to diminish the whole. Yet inspiration also holds sway.

Here we sit in grubby old Britain, wriggling over the News of the World, and we lose all perspective. We forget what journalism, at heart, is about. It is not about Sophie's slip showing or Posh's new boob job; not about share-tipping or celebrity-mongering: the journalism of Nayyouf and U Tin Win is about raising voices and turning over stones. A brave and necessary trade.

I haven't met U Tin Win, but I feel that I know him because I know U Thaung, a Burmese brother in blood and ink. Almost 45 years ago, he started Kyemon, which became Burma's best-selling paper overnight. The generals came; the editor went to prison; his paper 'nationalised' into acquiescence.

Now he lives in exile in America, writing constantly - 26 books - about the beloved country he cries for. And the striking thing about U Thaung, face to face, is how modest and quiet and calm he is. He endures. Burma's democratic government (in exile, too) doesn't count him an unquestioning friend because he sticks to no party line. He is a prisoner of his own conscience.

That is also the simple truth about so many editors and writers the world over who stand beside U Tin Win and U Thaung as a constantly endangered species - Pius Njawe from the Ivory Coast, Fred M'membe from Zambia, Savea Sano Malifa of Samoa, Daoud Kuttab from Palestine. There is no end, month after month, to the roll of those who must be included.

The freedom day on 3 May arrives, as always, bulwarked by reports and statistics. Has Africa (despite Zimbabwe) edged forward in the decade since Unesco's Windhoek declaration of the rights of independent journalism there? Is Russia slipping back into repression? The Observer has a fine new web campaign (observer.co.uk/freepress) to chart such ebbs and flows. They are the first sure signs of democracy taking hold or fading away. But, alongside these countings, there is always a human dimension which the smug, developed world too easily forgets.

What you see, in the bravery and the strugglings, is a basic definition of what journalism exists to offer - the instinctive, individual impulsion to bring the news and views. When we have to look abroad for that - beyond America, beyond Britain - we also reproach ourselves.

Kofi Annan and Mary Robinson have joined the head of Unesco, Koichiro Matsuura, in a statement to carry us on from Windhoek. They talk of the progress made and of that fundamental human right enshrined in the UN charter: 'the right to receive and impart information free from censorship.' But they also, glancing around, know how 'even the most heinous regimes can gain popular support if they manage to muzzle the media or to manipulate it to arouse fear and hatred among their citizens'.

Free, independent and pluralist media, they say, 'have an indispensable role to play in rooting out racism and xenophobia'. Now, who does that apply to, pray? To U Thaung and those Burmese print warriors who found asylum after distress? Or are we talking of a darkness much closer to home?

Peter Preston is a former editor of the Guardian and former chairman of the International Press Institute

webTitle: Turkey - the summer of my discontent

fields.headline: The summer of my discontent
fields.standfirst: Debating freedom of expression with the security forces
fields.trailText: Umit Ozturk, co-chair of the Amnesty International Journalists' Network, describes the day the security forces came calling for him.
fields.body:
Time flies. It was almost a decade ago. It was a long hot summer - in every way - in my hometown Diyarbakir, the major Kurdish province in South-eastern Turkey.

About half a dozen members of the notorious Special Operation Teams burst into my bookshop, which I had been running since the early '80s. I was standing by my tiny desk where I was just about to fax an article for my column in a national daily.

I bet these guys are not going to ask me for an autograph, I said to myself. The confirmation came quickly in the angry-tiger style and sky-high voice of one of the members of that team:

"Did you write this piece of shit?"

"Well, I have to see it first, sir, if you want me to confirm", I replied.

"We know you wrote it; we know you", the angry tiger yelled at me, "so, you don't like the Anti-Terror Law; so, you talk about this 'human rights violations' thing 'you son of a ...'".

Bingo. They saw my article of last week. I argued in the said article that the newly introduced Anti-Terror Law completely abolished freedom of expression because any sort of criticism about the state and security forces could be considered as a "terrorist" attack against the "indivisible unity of the State".

"Well, son", grinned the angry tiger, "you are proposing human rights education for Turkish security forces, whose ancestors were martyred for this country and watered the land with their blood. Let's start this human rights training and give you the first free lesson".

They ransacked all the display tables and shelves and found the biggest, thickest and heaviest books. Ironically, most of them were about human rights and civil liberties. They began hitting me on the head with those books as well as stumping kicks and riffle-butts. I was like a ball in their tiny football pitch. In the meantime, they were fully enjoying their freedom of expression: grunting, hysterically laughing, quoting a rich collection of nationalist anthems and chanting pro-state slogans.

Desperate situations unleash hidden coping strategies in the inner self and you unknowingly or instinctively expose weird defence methods such as black humour. When they began to concentrate hitting me on the back and the pain increased accordingly, I pretended to be calm and fired my first shot:

"I bet there will be a carpet design on my back - plenty of criss-cross lines, eh?"

Shock therapy. They stopped.

"This guy must be a psychopath", said the angry tiger, "don't give the bastard this pleasure. Let's go". For the first time in my life, I was pleased to be misunderstood. They probably thought I was a masochist.

They left the bookshop after an orgy of torture for half an hour and, by tradition, they threw threats on the doorstep:

"We are watching you, so you watch your step. Terrorists and their collaborators will be punished soon or later". I didn't dare to invite them back and lecture them about freedom of press or about non-violence with quotes from Mahatma Gandhi.

The following year, only after almost two dozens of my colleagues at the said national daily were killed by 'unknown perpetrators', the then President Turgut Ozal gave a statement to the press that it occurred to him that 'it was necessary to launch a human rights training programme for the police force'. Yet the project was shelved for about seven years. After some more journalists were killed and dozens jailed, the first serious steps were introduced last year.

Umit Ozturk is an award-winning journalist from Turkey living in London. He co-chairs Amnesty International Journalists* Network and also the UK section of Reporters Sans Frontieres.

webTitle: Colombia - The inquisitors of press freedom

fields.headline: The inquisitors of press freedom in Colombia
fields.standfirst: How the international media should support their Colombian colleagues
fields.trailText: Luis Fernandes calls for international support as Colombian journalists seek to break the code of silence.
fields.body:
"Don't shoot - I'm a journalist".

Colombia - the most dangerous country for journalists in Latin America and perhaps even the world - has experienced more than 40 years of internal conflict.

Press freedom is placed in jeopardy by both leftist guerrillas and right wing paramilitaries: these groups operate similarly to the Spanish inquisitors, killing anybody who doesn't think, speak or write what is demanded by their ideologies. And there is political corruption too.

In the last 20 years, more than 150 journalists have been murdered, more than 200 kidnapped and many more forced into exile. The National Government responded by helping to create a Committee to Protect Journalists * but nine months into this programme, journalists have been threatened, exiled from their hometown and declared 'military targets' by leftist-guerrilas without receiving any 'protection'.

Colombia needs urgent support from the international community, and from press freedom and human rights groups that watch and help. You should help by protesting to the President Andres Pastrana, who was a journalist and kidnapped too: he has suffered violence like so many colombian people.

Despite the bleak situation, Colombian journalists are an example to the world of courage and professionalism, fighting every single day to show the reality of an absurd war and breaking 'The code of silence' - that nobody knows anything and that everybody should keep silent. In Colombia, there is no protection of journalists, so press freedom doesn't exist.

Luis Fernandez is a Colombian journalist and writer with experience in radio, magazine and television journalism. He has published two novels and a collection of poems. He is founder-director of Prens@ Libre, the network to defend press freedom and protect journalists in Colombia. Established in 1998, the network campaigns for the principle that 'the best press to build the peace is a free press'.

Prens@ Libre

fields.headline: Killing Pablo (part two)
fields.standfirst: Colombian drug baron, playboy and politician, Pablo Escobar started out as a car thief and became the world's seventh richest man. In the first of two extracts from his new book, Mark Bowden explains how the schoolteacher's son would let nothing stand in his way... not even the might of the US government
fields.trailText: As his fortune grew and his fame spread, Pablo began tending his public image, conscientiously denying any official connection to his illicit enterprises and working hard to appear likable, although his reputation terrified even hardened Medellín criminals. fields.body:
As his fortune grew and his fame spread, Pablo began tending his public image, conscientiously denying any official connection to his illicit enterprises and working hard to appear likable, although his reputation terrified even hardened Medellín criminals. Employing leftist rhetoric when it suited his needs, Pablo played upon popular resentments of the established powers in Bogotá and the historical hard feelings toward the United States. Surrounded by bodyguards and worshipful associates, he had begun to see himself differently. It wasn't enough any more to have succeeded on the streets of Medellín or to dominate the international drug trade; somewhere along the way Pablo had begun to see himself as a great man.

Politics was the next logical step. In 1978, he was elected as a substitute city council member in Medellín. He helped underwrite the presidential campaign of Belisario Betancur that year, loaning the campaign planes and helicopters, and also contributed liberally to the campaign of Betancur's rival, Julio Turbay, who won the election.

Two years later, Pablo backed the formation of a new national political movement, called the New Liberal Party, headed locally by former justice minister Alberto Santofimio and nationally by the enormously popular reformer Luis Galán. In 1982, he ran for Congress himself. He stood as a substitute for Envigado representative Jairo Ortega. Under the Colombian system, voters elect a representative and a substitute, who is allowed full privileges of the office and sits in when the primary delegate is unable to attend congressional sessions. Ortega and Pablo were elected in the same balloting that elevated Betancur, on his second try, to the presidency.

So Pablo Escobar was a congressman. It was just a substitute position, but the victory seemed precisely the validation he had sought. He was now officially a respectable citizen, a representative of the people. The post conferred automatic judicial immunity, so Pablo could no longer be prosecuted for crimes under Colombian law. He was also entitled to a diplomatic visa, which he began using that year to take trips with his family to the United States. He posed in front of the White House with his young son, Juan Pablo, and began enjoying for the first time the mansions he had purchased for himself in Miami. Pablo had arrived. He told his friends that he intended some day soon to be the president of Colombia.

At this time, he went to great lengths to erase evidence of his more sordid criminal past (while still flaunting it in private), and undertook an aggressive campaign to be seen as a benevolent, law-abiding citizen. He hired publicists and paid off journalists.

He founded his own newspaper, Medellín Civico, which produced occasional fawning profiles of its benefactor. 'Yes, I remember him,' one Escobar admirer said in its pages. 'His hands, almost priest-like, drawing parabolas of friendship and generosity in the air. Yes, I know him, his eyes weeping because there is not enough bread for all the nation's dinner tables. I have watched his tortured feelings when he sees street children - angels without toys, without a present, without a future.' Pablo sponsored art exhibitions to raise money for charity and founded Medellín Without Slums, an organisation that sought to continue his housing programmes for the poor. He took walking tours of the city slums with two local priests, whose friendship implied the blessings of the church. The only hint of Pablo's personal agenda in this civic outreach was a forum he sponsored on the subject of extradition at a popular bar and disco in Medellín called Kevin's.

Colombia had signed a treaty with the United States in 1979 that recognised the shipment of illegal drugs to be a crime against the United States. As such, it called for suspected drug traffickers to be extradited for trial to the United States, and, if convicted, imprisoned. The prospect struck fear into the hearts of men such as Pablo Escobar, who long ago had learned they had little to fear from Colombia's justice system. Not surprisingly, Pablo's forum on extradition denounced the practice as a violation of 'national sovereignty'. He made banning extradition a point of nationalist pride, and the centrepiece of his political agenda.

With his election, Pablo became a popular public figure. To an increasingly admiring Bogotá press, he became Colombia's own Robin Hood. In April 1983, the magazine Semana profiled him warmly, noting only that the sources of his wealth 'never cease to be the object of speculation'. Waving his diamond-and-gold Rolex, admitting to his ownership of a fleet of planes and helicopters and vast real-estate holdings worldwide, in the article Pablo traced the origin of his estimated $5bn fortune to a 'bicycle rental business' which he said he had started in Medellín when he was 16 years old. 'I dedicated some years to the lottery, then I got into the business of buying and selling cars, and finally, I ended up in property.' It was, of course, preposterous. He was infamous worldwide in law-enforcement circles as a cocaine trafficker.

Pablo was much more than a rich smuggler; he embodied the youthful spirit of the age. Throughout the civilised world, a new generation was coming of age, one that had strikingly different attitudes toward recreational drug use than its parents had. The illegality of these popular drugs was part of their appeal. Using them was an act of defiance, an assertion of hipness. Whether they thought about it or not, everyone who snorted cocaine was executing a small bow to their intrepid Colombian suppliers. Just as Pablo's billions were the sum total of every furtive transaction, his risk was the sum total of all his users' petty risks. At the end of the long chain of illicit commerce that delivered the numbing substance to their nasal membranes, Pablo ran the Big Risk and reaped the Big Reward.

He and the other narco kingpins were, at least for this brief period, popular heroes, the embodiment of cool, as glamorous as they were dangerous in pop-culture portrayals such as the TV programme Miami Vice. In real life, Pablo played his role with panache. He would proudly point out to visitors at Nápoles the small plane that had flown his first shipments of the drug, mounted over the entrance to his estate. He built small, remote-controlled submarines that could carry up to 2,000kg of cocaine from the northern coast of Colombia to waters off Puerto Rico, where divers would remove the shipment and transport it to Miami in speedboats. He would send fleets of planes north, each carrying 1,000kg. There was no way customs and law enforcement would intercept more than a tiny fraction. Eventually he was buying used Boeing 727s, stripping out the passenger seats, and loading as much as 10,000kg per flight. There was nothing to stop him. Or so it seemed.

In response to a growing epidemic of cocaine use in America, President Ronald Reagan had created a cabinet-level task force in January 1982 to co-ordinate the nation's efforts against drug smuggling. He had appointed Vice-president George Bush to lead it. It was not until Bush was elected president in 1988 that the US war on drugs would formally shift its emphasis from trying to stop drugs from crossing the borders to going after narco kingpins, but Bush began moving in this direction early on. The drug lords would eventually become not just law enforcement targets but military ones - an important distinction that the hunt for Pablo Escobar would make clear. Even though few who thought seriously about the drug problem believed it could be stopped or even curbed by arresting a few cartel bosses, it proved a lot easier to get the US Congress worked up about a cabal of billionaires infecting America's youth than about the amorphous smuggling problem. Marshaling public support for war, or even just war spending, requires enemies, and Colombian cocaine barons colourfully fit the description.

During this same period, mainstream attitudes toward cocaine use in the United States underwent a dramatic shift. In June 1986, University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias, the number-one pick in the National Basketball Association draft, collapsed and died at a campus party after snorting cocaine. The decade-long flirtation with the white powder by affluent young Americans had begun to sour anyway, but Bias's death sealed it. Seemingly overnight, cocaine the harmless party drug became cocaine the killer. Suddenly the stories of wild parties and excesses in Hollywood showed a darker side, in stories of overdose and addiction. Cocaine lost all its stylishness when it started showing up on city streets in its cheap, smokeable form - crack. It was now a ravenous social epidemic, spurring petty crimes and destroying lives. Traffickers such as Pablo became not guides to the zeitgeist but criminals.

For the rest of his life, with one brief respite, Pablo was at war with the state. At the centre of the struggle remained extradition, the one fate he feared more than any other - even death. He had proclaimed: 'Better a tomb in Colombia than a prison cell in the United States.' Death was his strategy against extradition, that and money. His policy of plata o plomo became so notoriously effective that it would ultimately threaten to undermine Colombia's democracy. Already, by the end of 1984, he was untouchable in Medellín. He moved openly around the city, attending bullfights and nightclubs, throwing parties at his estates, all the while officially a fugitive. Popular and powerful, he had clearly bought off the police and courts there. Anyone who considered standing up against him was marked for assassination.

In the fall of 1985, Pablo offered to turn himself in if the government would promise not to extradite him to the United States. When it again refused, he settled in for a long fight. His lawyers (and sicarios - henchmen) chipped away at the cases against him. Recognising that its judicial system was stymied, Colombia did away with jury trials (people were too frightened to serve in any trial remotely related to drug trafficking) and began attempting to protect judges by hiding their identities. But often even these 'faceless' judges were gunned down. Pablo also tried in various ways to escape American justice. Betting that the United States had more interest in fighting Communists than narcos, his lawyers approached the US attorney general in 1986 with an offer to trade information against Communist guerrillas in return for amnesty from his drug crimes.

With the offer, Pablo made a gesture. He betrayed his long-time cartel associate Carlos Lehder. Colombian police were tipped off to a party Lehder had planned for 4 February 1987. The colourful, eccentric cartel leader was arrested and immediately extradited, flown from Bogotá to Tampa. Photographers were allowed to snap pictures of him in the back of the plane, wearing combat boots, sweatpants and a striped shirt, looking resigned and oddly bemused as he waited to depart. He would be sentenced to 135 years in prison in the US.

Still, America was not interested in making a deal with Pablo Escobar. It was a sign of how seriously the Reagan administration was taking the drug problem. In April 1986, the President had signed National Security Decision Directive 221, which for the first time declared drug trafficking a threat to national security. Inside Colombia, Pablo kept upping the ante. In December his sicarios killed the former chief of the nation's counter narcotics police and two legislators who had spoken out in favour of extradition. Andrés Pastrana, the journalist son of a former president and Conservative candidate for mayor of Bogotá, was kidnapped, and a week later Attorney General Carlos Hoyos was killed in a hail of machine-gun fire in Medellín. A caller to a local radio station announced Hoyos's 'execution' and called him 'a traitor and a sellout'.

When a judge prepared to indict Pablo for a murder, he received a note from a group calling itself the 'Extraditables'. 'We are friends of Pablo Escobar and we are ready to do anything for him We know perfectly well that not even the slightest evidence exists against Mr Escobar. We want to remind you that you are making a big mistake We are capable of executing you at any place on this planet in the meantime, you will see the fall, one by one, of all the members of your family. By the end of 1987, there were killings in the news almost every day in Bogotá. The new US ambassador, Charles Gillespie, began warning Washington that the escalating violence in Colombia was threatening to topple the state. However, by 1989 the scaffolding of Pablo's once fearful organisation was shaky. Nothing he was doing worked. He had bombed or bribed just about every official in Colombia, but it was clear no one in Bogotá was going to cut a deal that would jeopardise all-important ties with the United States government. So Pablo began trying to work some influence in Washington. He had tried to retain a lobbying firm managed by Henry Kissinger in an effort to influence the Reagan administration, and he retained a lawyer who worked in the same firm as Jeb Bush, son of the president-elect, hoping to eventually persuade the younger Bush to approach his father. Both efforts failed.

The future did not look bright. The Liberal Party candidate for president, Luis Galán, was wildly popular and certain to be elected in 1990. Galán was a charismatic 46-year-old reformer who had become a fearlessly outspoken enemy of the cartel. He had vowed to rid Colombia of drug traffickers, and he made no secret of his desire to ship them off to the United States for trial and imprisonment. His election threatened to undo all the progress Pablo had made by cowing and corrupting the Colombian judiciary. Galán was the nation's darling at that moment.

On 18 August, a sicario with an Uzi submachine gun shot down Galán as he made a campaign speech before supporters in Soacha, a town southwest of Bogotá. Three months later, in an effort to kill Galán's successor, candidate César Gaviria, Escobar's men planted a bomb on an Avianca airliner, blowing it out of the sky. One hundred and ten people were killed, including two Americans. It was an act of audacious cruelty with implications beyond any that Pablo had imagined.

These two atrocities would prove to be fatal mistakes. They made Pablo enemies who were far more powerful than any he had faced before. Downing a commercial airliner was an attack on global civilisation. It meant Pablo now posed a direct threat to American citizens, which meant, as we shall see, that some in the Bush administration believed he could be legally targeted for assassination. Killing Galán had made Pablo public enemy number one in Colombia. The Avianca bombing made him public enemy number one in the world. By the end of the summer of 1989, Pablo Escobar was 40 years old. He was one of the richest men in the world, and perhaps its most infamous criminal. No longer just a law-enforcement target, he was now a military target. To the men of America's secret counterterrorism community, the ruthless doper from Medellín had become a clear and present danger.

Surrounded by bodyguards and worshipful associates, he had begun to see himself differently. It wasn't enough any more to have succeeded on the streets of Medellín or to dominate the international drug trade; somewhere along the way Pablo had begun to see himself as a great man. Under the Colombian system, voters elect a representative and a substitute, who is allowed full privileges of the office and sits in when the primary delegate is unable to attend congressional sessions. Ortega and Pablo were elected in the same balloting that elevated Betancur, on his second try, to the presidency. So Pablo Escobar was a congressman. It was just a substitute position, but the victory seemed precisely the validation he had sought. He was now officially a respectable citizen, a representative of the people. He told his friends that he intended some day soon to be the president of Colombia. Colombia had signed a treaty with the United States in 1979 that recognised the shipment of illegal drugs to be a crime against the United States. webTitle: Sri Lanka - lessons in control from the west

fields.headline: Sri Lanka: Lessons in control from the west
fields.standfirst: Severe restrictions on the coverage of ethnic conflict
fields.trailText: Waruna Karunathilaka on how the Sri Lankan government learnt from how the western allies controlled media coverage of the Gulf War.
fields.body:
In the nineteen-fifties and 'sixties Sri Lanka, then known as Ceylon, had one of the most vibrant print media in the Asian region. The first attempt to curb the media in 1964 resulted in the incumbent government being overthrown when the Press Council Bill was defeated in Parliament.

That unfortunately was the last victory for freedom of expression. Since then successive governments have systematically undermined freedom of expression as democracy itself came under threat. Independent publishing houses were either acquired by the government or closed down under emergency regulations. Electronic media has been kept under strict government control.

The outbreak of the Tamil separatist war in 1983, gave the government an ideal reason to further tighten controls. The country has been run under emergency regulations for most of the past three decades - with censorship the norm rather than the exception.

Intimidation of journalists and media owners, filing of criminal defamation cases against editors and publishers, restrictions on state advertising, and in extreme cases murder have all been used to silence the media.

Reporting the separatist war, one of the bloodiest conflicts in the world, was relatively easy in the first decade. However the Sri Lanka government drew its own lessons from the restrictions imposed on the media by the western allies during the Gulf War.

Severe restrictions have been imposed on journalists reporting from government areas of the north and east of the country,where the separatist war is been fought. Since 1995 access to rebel held areas has been totally denied with threats of serious actions under emergency regulations for any journalist who dared to break the ban.

Strict censorship on local and foreign media during military debacles has left people in dark. Any news organization or journalist which report news adverse to the government is quickly branded as a rebel sympathiser by the powerful state owned print and electronic media which still has the biggest reach.

Intense campaigning for media law reforms has been scuttled by the incumbent government fearing a free media would undermine its credibility by exposing widespread corruption, incompetence in governance and rigged elections.

The Tamil separatist rebel organisation, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) has been no less tolerant of the media. Journalists who criticise the organisation has been routinely murdered and journalists visiting rebel areas are under strict surveillance.

Any criticism of the rebels by people living in the north and east is dealt with harshly. However, despite the odds, a section of media, especially the print media has continued to do exactly that. Editors and journalists have paid a high price for their courage. At least a dozen journalists have been murdered, some have fled the country and others face physical violence, or face court cases and well-orchestrated abuse by the state media.

News organisations critical of the government often find private sector advertisers have been intimidated and state advertising banned. In the past few months, the government has used another weapon to increase pressure on the media. Taxes on newsprint have been increased by 15% at a time of high newsprint prices in the world market and pressure on advertising due to a serious economic downturn while the private electronic media is been threatened with massive increases in licence fees for transmitting stations. In Sri Lanka freedom of expression is facing perhaps its biggest threat since the island nation achieved independence from Britain in 1948.

Waruna Karunathilaka has covered the ethnic conflict in Sri Lanka since 1984 for a range of local and foreign news organisations, and is currently working for Time magazine and Reuters. Waruna is a founder member and former convenor of the Free Media Movement, a non-partisan and independent group of journalists and editors in Sri Lanka committed to freedom of expression and which is campaigning for an an end to governmental control of media institutions

webTitle: Serbia - the unpopular campaign to re-examine the past

fields.headline: Serbia after Milosevic: the unpopular campaign to re-examine the past
fields.standfirst:
How an alternative local radio station became an example to campaigners around the world - and why the most difficult challenges may still lie ahead.
Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Veran Matic of Radio B92 explains how an alternative local radio station became an example to campaigners around the world - and why the most difficult challenges may still lie ahead.
fields.body:
This month we're celebrating the twelfth birthday of Radio B92. I have been editor-in-chief from the beginning. In those twelve years we have been banned four times: on two occasions our entire equipment and personal belongings were seized and our premises usurped. I have been arrested once. Times, at last, have changed but, even without the pressure and threat of the Milosevic regime, the struggle for freedom of speech continues unabated.

Media freedom under a violent, authoritarian regime and media freedom in a democracy are two different experiences. They also call for entirely different vocabularies and discourse. We are speaking about different forms of freedom, but there is ground common to both cases. The basic issue is the responsibility and obligation of the media to fight for their own freedom and independence, to meet and encourage the expectations of society and to promote universal, professional and humane standards without which the media would have no raison d'etre.

Radio B92 and Television B92 have been in a unique position since October 5, 2000. We have grown, literally, from the ground up. We began as a small, alternative, city radio station which could be heard in only part of the Belgrade area and, over time, grew into an increasingly powerful national media system. The way in which a hothouse city radio developed into a highly influential media network is a phenomenon, in terms of both media and society.

In the West it is customary for the alternative to be gradually absorbed into the commercial, becoming part of the dominant cultural mainstream and world view. In our case, rather than market forces, the principal role was assumed by social and political thrusts which had found a common goal in the need for radical change and modernisation of the country.

Our deployment of new technologies, particularly the internet, as powerful tools to break the media and political blockade is today held up as a model for all electronic media, not only those in Eastern Europe. Of course, democracy and transition are still fresh and novel experiences for us. We are faced with many disappointments and dilemmas for the simple reason that we are faced with a model which has no real legal or economic precedents.

There are always pitfalls on the road to independence and freedom. Many concepts of democracy, competition, the market and the rules of the game are still hollow catchphrases. Regrettably, many of our friends from the West have also failed to understand that freedom is won by a complex process and not a ready-made formula applied once and for all when totalitarian and undemocratic authorities are removed from power.

At this time, in addition to our educational activities focusing on a democratic society, we are also engaged in the process of reconsidering and reviewing our own past, a past plagued by wars and atrocities. This is a highly unpopular theme. Had we applied the rules of the profit-driven market we would have ducked this painful issue. But without truth there is no democratic future. And this is why we adhere to the basic definitions of freedom of speech and free media.

Veran Matic is editor-in-chief of B92 Belgrade.

Regrettably, many of our friends from the West have also failed to understand that freedom is won by a complex process and not a ready-made formula applied once and for all when totalitarian and undemocratic authorities are removed from power. At this time, in addition to our educational activities focusing on a democratic society, we are also engaged in the process of reconsidering and reviewing our own past, a past plagued by wars and atrocities. This is a highly unpopular theme. Had we applied the rules of the profit-driven market we would have ducked this painful issue. But without truth there is no democratic future. And this is why we adhere to the basic definitions of freedom of speech and free media. Veran Matic is editor-in-chief of B92 Belgrade. Radio B92 Local media links and free media resources from B92

fields.headline: Once upon a newspaper ...
fields.standfirst:
How we had to survive political and economic struggles.

Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Gwen Lister on how The Namibian survived both political and economic struggles.
fields.body:
Starting a newspaper in an oppressive political environment is one thing; sustaining it in the long-term after donor-funding has ceased is quite another. But both can be done, and therein lies our story ....

The year was 1984. The height of South African apartheid occupation of Namibia. In this large country with a proportionally small population of just over one million at the time, everyone who wasn't 'white', and the few who were and who didn't support the status quo was in trouble one way or another.

From outside the borders of the country, Swapo guerillas fought the war of liberation, as it was known, against occupying South African forces. Inside the country, divide and rule tactics were implemented with full force, conscripting some and not others; compartmentalising ethnic groups into different geographical entities; and above all, propagandising Swapo's struggle as 'communist-inspired' to put the fear of God into the pale-skinned settlers.

Media was at the time, if not openly in favour of the occupation forces, then certainly turning a blind eye to its excesses which were met with increased resistance to colonial rule from within.

Given the almost incestuously small population, critics of the regime could not hide that easily. Those who spoke out were obvious targets of an occupying force that employed all conceivable undemocratic means - such as detention without trial, psychological harassment, victimization and even death - against its critics.

It was in this prevailing atmosphere that myself and a few colleagues started The Namibian. We were warned by many, well-intentioned and otherwise, that to take on the might of the South African military machine may lead to our demise in one way or another.

We pressed ahead regardless, and finally managed to secure donor funding to start a newspaper that promised to promote a peaceful solution to the Namibian dispute by means of international dialogue; to be a voice of the voiceless people who suffered under the apartheid jackboot; and train local journalists. We finally acquired premises - no mean achievement in itself in the predominantly hostile white business environment - and finally geared up for publication.

From the outset we, like other critics, were targeted. The inception of the newspaper saw us go to court to challenge a Rand 20,000 deposit that was demanded on the grounds that myself, as the founding editor, and the newspaper itself were likely to constitute threats to state security. Here we won our first victory.

But in the years that followed, the forces of apartheid unleashed upon the newspaper and staff members a campaign of harassment, intimidation and even terror in an effort to break our resolve. Our offices and equipment were burned to the ground by right-wing arsonists; myself and other reporting staff were jailed, denied passports, and lived under the shadow of constant death threats.

This was more than 'just a job'. This was a commitment, a belief that what we were doing was the right thing, and it required people who were able to swallow their fear and commit to the principles of a free and independent press.

I believe that the qualities required to start a publication in an oppressive environment are probably similar to those that would be required in a more just society under similar circumstances. The will to succeed, to work hard and long hours, often unrewarded, are just some of the qualities necessary for journalists who want to 'make a go of it' in terms of starting their own publication and who want that publication to succeed.

At our inception, commercial viability and sustainability appeared to be an unattainable dream. Few of the white businesses would advertise in a newspaper which called itself 'The Namibian' in a time when 'South West Africa' was the official name of the country, and 'Namibia' was an anathema and represented all things evil. Sales income was minimal because of a low cover price and a readership that was predominantly black and impoverished. Donor funding was necessary for the first few years, and we would doubtless have not succeeded without it, for no effort was spared by the authorities in trying to crush both our spirits and our financial means to sustain the newspaper.

But when independence finally came to Namibia, on March 21 1990, we breathed a sigh of relief to have survived the political struggle, only to face another, and perhaps even more daunting one: the fight for economic self-sufficiency, for donor funding began to dwindle.

This was done primarily by applying the principle of 'lean and mean'. Only with the right kind of people (committed, brave and strong), a spirit of volunteerism and a belief in the principles of a free and independent press, can this type of venture succeed. Maintaining a flat structure with no shareholders to greedily demand and absorb profits; to the trust which the newspaper enshrined with principles of equal pay for equal work, affirmative action, both a minimum and maximum wage, paid off eventually.

But only after we went through some singularly hard times. And we are still here today after independence. More than 15 years later having survived not only the political struggle, but more importantly, the economic one. Still fairly lean, but not quite as mean as we were when times were tough, The Namibian is now the biggest selling daily newspaper in Namibia, self-sufficient, still committed to the same journalistic principles we have cherished since our inception, and continually striving to serve our bosses, the public, to the best of our ability.

Gwen Lister is Director of The Namibian. This piece is reproduced by kind permission of UNESCO.

webTitle: The Arabian Gulf - dilemmas of a free media

fields.headline: Dilemmas of a free media for the Arabian Gulf
fields.standfirst:
Gradual change - and the case for moving more quickly.

Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: S. Nihal Singh on how freedom of the media does not yet exist - but how change is happening, gradually.
fields.body:
Freedom of the media, as we understand it, does not exist in the Arabian Gulf. The surprise is not that this is so, but rather in how new shoots of a more tolerant and liberal era are beginning to sprout.

Restricting access to the new phenomenon of satellite television and the internet is at best a difficult and self-defeating task, especially when vast numbers of tourists, business travellers and resident expatriates give truth to the clich* of a global village.

There are differences between the Gulf states. Kuwait is, in relative terms, the most free - a fact that stems from an elected National Assembly, however circumscribed its rules may be. Alone in the Gulf, Kuwaiti newspapers do not fight shy of reporting the hard-hitting speeches of opposition spokesmen, and even their other local coverage tends to be more aggressive.

But there are striking examples of new developments elsewhere. In Qatar, a country not renowned for its free media, the most free media in the Arab world has taken shape in the form of the satellite television channel al-Jazeera which has won an enthusiastic regionwide audience.

In Saudi Arabia, whose restrictive norms are well known, some of their innovative journalists have gone to a Western capital such as London to be able to report frankly on Arab developments while observing discretion in relation to events in Saudi Arabia.

The popularity of newspapers such as Al-Hayat in the Arabic-speaking world is testimony to readers' endorsement of their form of reporting.

In the United Arab Emirates, a sea-change has taken place in recent years over the leadership's tolerance of dissenting views on world issues outside the immediate area. But strict guidelines on local and national coverage, however, remain the rule, rather than the exception.

Regional leaders increasingly acknowledge the need for reform and that media institutions that offer only echoes of self-serving applause are of no real value, either to government or to the people. But they are also mindful of the risks.

Leaders feel that foreign, especially western, values could undermine their traditions and roots. Second, they would like to maintain their citizens' respectful attitude to their leaders, governed by tribal and religious guidelines. There is a hankering after the media expressing national identity. Information is still seen by the bureaucracy as a privilege to be doled out in small selective doses.

So the traditional caveat of 'the national interest' is only one of the factors circumscribing freedom of the press. All too often, an unpleasant incident is suppressed because of the belief that if it is not reported, it simply did not occur. Other societies have learned the hard way that rumour can be a more deadly weapon than the honest reporting of a bomb explosion or a fire.

The Gulf has a long way to go to catch up with the Western world and other areas in giving freedom to the media. These countries face many dilemmas, including the need to maintain their heritage and traditions in a fast-changing world. The leaders realise that their societies will change, but they do not wish the changes to be disruptive.

In seeking to manage change, the Gulf states have decided that they must also, in varying degrees, manage the media. The publication of Arabic newspapers abroad and starting a free and saucy satellite channel serve as safety vaIves, but the question those in authority must ask themselves is that if Kuwait can live with a relatively free Press, what prevents them from emulating it?

S. Nihal Singh was editor of Khaleej Times, Dubai, from 1994 to July last year and was previously editor of the Calcutta Statesman, editor-in-chief of the Indian Express and founding editor of the Indian Post. He was a senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment for Internation Peace in New York and Project Director of New York's Twentieth Century Fund in Paris on Unesco. He won the International Editor of the Year award of the Atlas Press Service in New York for his role as editor during India's Emergency in the mid-Seventies. He is the author of several books, including 'The Yogi and the Bear' on Indo-Soviet relations, 'The Rise and Fall Of Unesco' and 'The Rocky Road of Indian Democracy'.

webTitle: 'We come here for work, not to live on handouts'

fields.headline: 'We come here for work, not to live on handouts'
fields.trailText: A major study of illegal immigrants has found that almost all of them come to Britain with the intention of finding work, contrary to the popular image of new arrivals in search of generous benefits.
fields.body:
A major study of illegal immigrants has found that almost all of them come to Britain with the intention of finding work, contrary to the popular image of new arrivals in search of generous benefits.

'Not a single illegal immigrant we examined thought that benefits was a reason for coming to Britain,' said Professor Bill Jordan of Exeter University, who carried out the government-funded project.

'A key reason people gave for coming here was that they expected to be able to work,' said Jordan, whose work was based on interviews with more than 150 illegal immigrants. 'It's a reflection of our economic conditions.'

Asylum seekers, who are registered on arrival, are largely prevented from working. But illegal immigrants find work, the survey discovered, because they are highly motivated, presentable and - above all - prepared to accept low pay. Many were also better educated than their British counterparts. Half the immigrant workers doing manual jobs were graduates or had diplomas.

Nick Hardwick, director of the Refugee Council, said: 'This research is very significant. It absolutely destroys the myth that people are coming here for a cushy life on benefits.'

'Hamid', from Turkey, works as a kitchen porter in a restaurant in London's West End. Instead of coming to Britain hidden in the back of a lorry, the popular view of an illegal migrant, he arrived as a tourist four years ago and then outstayed his visa. He earns £3.50 an hour, well below the minimum wage and works six 10-hour shifts every week.

'My employer says that he cannot get British people to do the work,' said the 24-year-old. 'I only ever expected to work hard if I came here. No one ever mentioned benefits or housing and I have not applied for them. Britain is a freer country than Turkey and I can work. That is why I came.' He shares a two-bedroom flat with five other men. They pay the rent of £300 a week in cash.

'One reason that these people do not get identified is that our society is open and deregulated,' said Jordan. 'There are very few internal controls and there is a very good chance that you will avoid detection in any sphere.

'The benefits regime, for so long a point of political controversy, simply appears to be irrelevant,' said Jordan. 'If people can get work in the shadow economy, they don't encounter the benefits system at all.'

The only use of benefits detected by researchers was either when British co-workers sold an immigrant a national insurance number, or when immigrants married a Briton.

Experts believe that there may be up to a quarter of a million illegal immigrants in Britain.

Most recent research into the attitudes of immigrants to Britain has focused on the views of asylum seekers because they are registered and easily identifiable. Jordan and his colleagues, funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, found their respondents through community networks and also by joining workplace 'raids' carried out by the Immigration Service.

webTitle: Mozambique - criticise the government, but not the criminals

fields.headline: Criticise the government, but you may be killed if you tackle crime
fields.standfirst:
Why getting the law right is not enough.

Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Alfredo Libombo on how Mozambique shows that the getting the law right is not enough.
fields.byline: Alfredo Libombo, National Director, MISA - Mozambique
fields.body:
Mozambique is said to have one of the most democratic media laws in Southern Africa where journalists can criticize the government, the president and other government officials without harrasment or fearing of being detained.

With a population of more than 16 million people, Mozambique has two daily newspapers - Noticias published in the country capital of Maputo and Diario de Mocambique, published in Beira second largest city. Several newsletters are distributed by fax, email or limited photocopied runs and six weeklies are distributed countrywide. In 1990 a new Constitution was approved allowing freedom of the press and the right to free association.

But journalists in Mozambique fear that the law doesn't provide enough protection. Last November, Carlos Cardoso was gunned down in one of Maputo's streets. Cardoso was a prominent Mozambican journalist who had been investigating political corruption and organised crime, publishing a considerable range of stories on these issues.

More recently Jose Joao, a journalist with Radio Mozambique in Gaza province, was threatened with death after publishing a story on the arrest of a drug traficking gang and illegal goods importers from South Africa. The unknown man who approached Jose Joao warned him that "your steps will be followed if you follow-up the story".

So journalists can operate without harrassment from the government. But they may risk their lives if they cover the scandals that shake the country. In the case of Cardoso's assassination, arrests were made after public and media pressure. In Jose Joao's case there has been no solidarity or word from the government, either to protect him or to warn the criminals against threathening journalists.

More interestingly, the Mozambican Minister of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation, Leonardo Simao told the Mozambican News Agency (AIM) that the pressure on the government over Cardoso's assassination came because he was white and because there are hidden political parties in Mozambique. This stand was heavily criticised by journalists and other sectors of civil society leading to Prime Minister Pascoal Mocumbi distancing his government from the minister's position, saying that "everyone is free to have a opinion".

Our experience in Mozambique shows that a law in itself it is not everything: the Mozambican government must more act more clearly in defence in protection of the freedom of expression distanciating itself from the criminal gangs.

Alerts on freedom violations must taken more serious nationaly and internationally. International pressure had helped in the past to lead to changes in media laws. Of course, they will always say that there is an "external interference" but soon they will realize that we as journalists are part of the same family... no borders. Networking between us is very important and news exchange sites must be developed which can very quickly pass on an message of an violation in any part of the world.

Alfredo Libombo is National Director of the Media Institute of Southern Africa, Mozambique.

Media Institute of Southern Africa

fields.headline: Asylum translators lost for words
fields.standfirst: Home Office uses inexperienced students to interpret tales of terror as refugees plead to stay
fields.trailText: Home Office uses inexperienced students to interpret tales of terror as refugees plead to stay.
fields.body:
It was when the asylum seekers began describing the abuse they had suffered that Alex Reynolds ceased to understand a word they said. Having been persuaded against his judgment to act as a translator for the Home Office on behalf of refugees, the 22-year-old student was exhausted and traumatised.

He looked across the table at the 17-year-old who was trying to explain for the third time how Nepalese police had tortured him, and turned to the Home Office interviewer sitting calmly flicking through his notebook. 'I told the interviewer I couldn't understand what this man was saying,' said Reynolds.

'I'd been honest that what I spoke was fairly fluent village Nepalese, but this man's life seemed to be in real danger and I couldn't convey that. I'd accepted the job because I'd been told I wouldn't need to know anything complex or political - but this man was telling me his life depended on him being able to stay in Britain for reasons I couldn't understand.'

The man from the Home Office was unmoved. 'He was calm and unruffled by the obvious chaos in front of him,' Reynolds said. 'He advised me to paraphrase what the man said and simplify if need be. He said that if the interviewee disagreed with the transcription of the interview after the judgment had been passed, he could always appeal.'

Reynolds's experience is far from uncommon: an Observer investigation has discovered that the Home Office routinely employs untrained and inexperienced translators for asylum interviews in contradiction to explicit government legislation.

'Potential interpreters are interviewed by staff at the Central Interpreters Unit or at one of their local offices before being accepted on to the panel,' said a Home Office spokeswoman. 'The only exception to this rule is when someone is already working for another government department, the local police force or is a well-qualified professional interpreter.'

Reynolds, an anthropology student at Newcastle University, had not spoken Nepalese for almost two years and was not interviewed or even given a contract before being sent to Liverpool and confronted by asylum seekers with tales of violence and terror. He simply replied to an email from Sakura Communications, a local interpretation unit employed by the Home Office to supply translators to Immigration and Asylum offices.

'I told Sakura exactly what level my Nepalese was at,' said Reynolds. 'They weren't bothered and gave me a brief description of the job on offer. When I asked if they wanted to meet me, they said that wasn't necessary.'

Three days later Reynolds found himself in the staffroom of Liverpool's Immigration and Asylum office. 'All the others were in their thirties and professional translators. They were shocked to see me but one took me aside and gave me a crash course in words he told me I'd need, like oppression, pain and danger. He told me the name of the outlawed Maoist party the asylum seekers would support and made sure I at least had a dictionary.'

Over 70 per cent of asylum-seekers to Britain are refused entry, a decision appealed against by most of them but upheld in over 80 per cent of cases. The Government cites these statistics as proof of its stringent interviewing procedures, but the experiences of Reynolds and others persuaded to act as unqualified translators has left the Home Office facing questions over how seriously it tries to understand the plight of those appealing for help. 'It seems unlikely to me that either of the men I translated for will get asylum,' said Reynolds. 'The system obviously wanted to get rid of them as soon as possible. They didn't seem bothered whether these people got a fair trial or not.'

Veronica Oakeshott, a politics student at Newcastle University who also spent a year in Nepal, answered an advert by Sakura in the student newspaper. 'I explained that I wasn't fluent but the person they'd had lined up for the job had been sacked the day before and she was obviously desperate,' said Oakeshott. 'I was given no trial or interview - they just told me to go to the office in Leeds, but nobody indicated what the job was going to be. She was told to translate legally-binding Home Office statements into Nepalese for the refugees to sign. 'I told the Home Office interviewers again and again that I could not do it but they just wrote that in their scripts and told me to carry on.'

'No qualifications are necessary although we always make sure translators know exactly what they'll be doing. The refugees can start making revelations about what they've been through and we have employed students who have found the experience very traumatic,' he admitted. 'There have been cases when the interviews have had to be stopped because they've found it too upsetting.'
