webTitle: Does Ken's first year amount to pigeon feed?

fields.headline: Does Ken's first year amount to pigeon feed?
fields.standfirst: One year on, London's Mayor is as popular as ever, but the champagne is far from flowing
fields.trailText: One year on, London's Mayor is as popular as ever, but the champagne is far from flowing.
fields.body:
Helen Mirren thinks he's 'wonderful'; the restaurateur Sir Terence Conran considers him mature; even pigeon-feed vendor Bernard Rayner who was furious with Ken Livingstone, has now settled out of court.

The initial verdict on the Mayor of London's first year in charge seems to be a rosy one: he barely needs the services of Joy Johnson, the new spin doctor who was appointed last week.

Yet the champagne will not be flowing this Friday. With a major London Underground strike and May Day chaos predicted this week, celebrations would seem inappropriate.

Livingstone's frustration with the limitations of his job may also help take the shine off this anniversary.

Trouble is looming over his plans next month to issue Londoners with a glossy report on his first year's performance, including a mayoral interview conducted by Mirren.

The first draft, leaked to The Observer , has already been rewritten after objections to a cheeky portrayal of the Greater London Assembly, which scrutinises Livingstone, as uncertain about how to do its job.

The Mayor is also being challenged for taking the credit in 'helping the Metropolitan Police recruit 2,500 more officers', even though only the Home Secretary can authorise changes in police numbers. The GLA sets the Metropolitan Police's budget.

And pledges about 'fighting the Government to get the world-class Underground the capital deserves' gloss over the fact that the Treasury is in charge of Tube privatisation.

But the report's boasts cannot conceal that its author has nowhere near the resources or the freedom given to New York's Mayor Rudy Giuliani, whose success he is expected to match.

'To give him credit, this is still very early days,' said Conservative vice-chairman Steve Norris, Livingstone's closest challenger in the mayoral race last year.

'But what this year has exposed... to his own chagrin, is the paucity of power available to the Mayor. This is the third most important politician in Britain, supposedly, and we don't even give them the power to decide that there will be more policemen on the streets.'

Next month, GLA chairman Trevor Phillips is expected to trigger a review of whether the Assembly's existing powers are adequate. Should London get control over its own hospitals? How can Whitehall Ministers be properly held to account by the Assembly? But such questions may not be resolved until long after Livingstone has left office.

The Mayor's enemies admit he has nimbly avoided many potential traps: he has worked well with the City and avoided serious criticism for raising council taxes. His worst PR disaster was the banning of pigeons from Trafalgar Square - to the outrage of Rayner, the licensed vendor of pigeon feed.

But the honeymoon is over. Friends say Livingstone looks tired: criticism that he has made little visible difference cannot be deflected by the nine-page list of achievements rushed out by his office this weekend.

But it is Norris's charge that there have been 'absolutely no changes for the better on transport as a result of Livingstone's first year' that really stings the Livingstone camp. Critics say but for the personal loathing between Livingstone and Chancellor Gordon Brown a deal could have been done by now on Tube privatisation.

'Livingstone and his team are still operating in some sense as an opposition,' said one senior GLA insider. 'Prior to the election it was Millbank, now it's the Government, they're still running a campaign rather than running London.'

There are tougher challenges ahead, including this week's Tube strike. So far, Livingstone has refused to condemn the hardline RMT union, one of his staunchest backers, but faces increasing pressure from angry passengers to do so.

'It will be a week in which we see what kind of guts this Mayor has,' says one veteran Livingstone watcher.

webTitle: Comment: root causes of poverty and inequality must be addressed

fields.headline: Cradle to the ballot box
fields.standfirst: Baby bonds are welcome, but they'll do little to remove the root causes of poverty and inequality
fields.trailText: Baby bonds are welcome, but they'll do little to remove the root causes of poverty and inequality.
fields.body:
Babies and elections have always been, in the jargon of the moment, contiguous. This time round, there is a difference. Now babymania can jump species. Phoenix the calf, an emblem of Disney cuteness among mountains of scorched flesh, gets the livestock cull curtailed. Less flamboyantly, the 750,000 human infants born every year in Britain also score a victory. Each will soon have a dowry of £250 apiece, rising to £500 for the poorest. With three further top-ups of £100 and a government promise to match any family contributions, the least well-off 18-year-olds should end up with a modest nest egg, courtesy of the four fairy godfathers of government.

David Blunkett is the political driver for the Child Trust Fund, successfully piloted in the US over the past decade and imported by the left-wing think tank, the IPPR. Alistair Darling is also keen on asset-building. An ominous silence hung over the Treasury when baby bonds were first mooted before Gordon Brown eventually proclaimed himself in favour of a plan designed to ensure that every newborn will enter the world with the word 'Prudence' practically stamped on his or her brow. As for Tony Blair, this idea had everything.

To the Right, it offered the camphorous odour of Thatcher's mothballed credo of a property-owning democracy. Baby-bonders would, in the Tory view, be the spiritual heirs to the Sids who snapped up shares and council houses.

To the Left, it bore the equally comforting whiff of progressive universalism. While the scheme's foundation, on the shaky faultline where Beveridge and neo-liberalism collide, rendered it acceptable to almost all, the plan has a special resonance for Blair. In his 1999 conference speech, he described two babies, side by side in the labour ward and destined, if he had his wish, to live in a meritocratic society where all began life on an equal footing. Baby bonds match the policy to the dream. Better still, a scheme costing a modest £1 billion a year offers a branding unbuyable even by a government that splurges £62 million on three months' worth of advertising. This, the subtext reads, is an administration that loves poor children.

And still, our child poverty rate is the third highest in the industrialised world: 100,000 more children were plunged into hardship during the first two years of the Blair government. Although changes to tax and benefits have reversed that trend, more than three million children will remain below the breadline at the election. Of those, 600,000 of them could have been removed from income poverty if the £2.4bn forgone by last year's cut in the basic tax rate had been used to increase benefits.

Regressive taxes on cigarettes and petrol continue to clobber the poor, as does the Social Fund. The Social Security Select Committee recently reported that the fund, a model of Dickensian parsimony, exacerbates child poverty because parents cannot afford to repay crisis loans for items such as fridges and cookers. So far, the Government has resisted subsequent calls for a review.

As ever, the children of poor households continue to do worse at school and to get the worst-paid jobs, or none. By their late teens, that damage may be irreversible. Certainly the notion that 18-year-olds will emerge from a chrysalis of poverty into fully formed trustafarians, ready to spend with care (rather than to squander their money on drugs and drink as their rich-list equivalents tend to) seems unproven.

Nor are parents struggling to buy food and shoes likely to be sustained by the knowledge that their children are custodians of untouchable funds worth several thousand pounds. Perhaps such caveats count for little against a suspicion that approval from those debarred by extreme poverty from saving, including the seven out of 10 lone parents who currently have no back-up funds at all, is not the applause Labour most desires.

Despite last week's volte-face allowing more generous parental leave, women of all backgrounds remain sceptical of a government perceived to have done too little on childcare provision and flexible working hours. So how helpful to have news programmes full of vox pops involving wards full of new 'mums' (not a father in sight, even on politically correct Channel 4 News ) offering warm plaudits to Blair's largesse.

Though it would be cynical to accuse the Government of blatantly touting for votes among those impressed by its drive towards child equality, there is no doubt that some remain more equal than others. One minute, the Government is offering Hans Christian Andersen fairytale outcomes, in which all must have equal prospects. In the next, it sketches cautionary tales worthy of a Hoffman or a Belloc, on what must happen to those corrupted by the forces of exclusion.

Slap a curfew or a school exclusion order on them. March 'yobs' to cashpoints or incarcerate them in one of our scandalous young offenders' institutions to rot or, if especially unlucky, to die. Tony Blair's latest wheeze, to reward non-offending teenagers in high crime areas with vouchers for CDs or trainers, looks either like a belated balance of carrot to stick or the feeblest of pre-election gimmicks.

It may also be a sign that Blair, an expert on wayward adolescents and infant innocents alike, has a Dr Spockish urge to treat the nation's children as his own. The trouble is that parenting is a haphazard, emotional affair, whereas politics is structured and calculating. Conflate the two and the upshot is the liberal press gurgling over Blair's plans while the Daily Telegraph, simultaneously, infers the extinction of the welfare state and the advent of a US-style residuum.

The suspicion is that Blair is bowing to the perception that the views of Left and Right must, like the rich child and the poor, be equally indulged. In addition, political entrail-reading usefully magnifies the scope of what's really on offer. Baby bonds, and an allied savings scheme for poor adults, are a valuable gesture, but a tiny one. Suggesting that they are the foundation of a DIY society is as unrealistic as hoping to buy Chatsworth with Green Shield stamps.

Last week, Blair's personal think tank filled in the gaps on an anti-poverty strategy. The Performance and Innovation Unit urged him to increase income and inheritance tax and end the middle-class stranglehold on getting the best education. A meritocratic society depended, it said, on high social mobility and the absence of any association between class and opportunity. Such truisms bear repetition in a week when Blair plans to stick to his 1997 pledge not to put up income tax while his 'People's Peers', a Gilbert and Sullivan array of toffery, make the notion of democratic appointments look risible.

As for baby bonds, the enthusiasm of its reception should make Labour bolder and less disingenuous. Though the sketch is vague and the budget small, we would love it to work. But voters also know that children's lives cannot be transformed unless direct taxes rise. Blair should flesh out his trust plan, reform the Social Fund, step up the crusade to end child poverty by 2020 and concede that notions of forging equality on the cheap belong in the realm of storks and gooseberry bushes.

webTitle: Epidemic of hard drugs in schools

fields.headline: Epidemic of hard drugs in schools
fields.standfirst: Survey shows disturbing increase among younger groups
fields.trailText: Hundreds of thousands of British schoolchildren, some as young as 11, have experimented with hard drugs, including heroin and cocaine, and many more use cannabis, amphetamines or glue on a weekly basis, according to a major new survey.
fields.body:
Hundreds of thousands of British schoolchildren, some as young as 11, have experimented with hard drugs, including heroin and cocaine, and many more use cannabis, amphetamines or glue on a weekly basis, according to a major new survey.

More than one in 100 boys aged 12 said they had tried heroin. A similar number of 11-year-olds said they had tried cocaine. Around twice as many said they had used cannabis, glue or had sniffed propellents and inhalants known as 'gas'.

The findings, based on questionnaires filled in by 20,000 children in 67 secondary schools last year, contradict recent government claims that juvenile drug use is falling.

Last week experts called for a complete overhaul of Britain's drugs education programmes.

The biggest such exercise ever undertaken, the survey is the first to look in detail at the habitual use of drugs by schoolchildren. It aimed to show whether they used drugs regularly rather than on an experimental basis. A user was defined as someone taking drugs on a weekly basis for at least three months.

'The results were very striking,' said Jeremy Gluck, of Adolescent Assessment Services, the Swansea-based consultancy that carried out the survey on behalf of local education authorities. 'Drug use is much more extensive than we thought. The sheer numbers involved are very worrying. Some totals were so high that we genuinely didn't want to believe them.'

The survey found that one in nine 16-year-old boys who admitted using drugs said they did so every day. More than a third used drugs - mainly cannabis, but also harder drugs - at least once a week.

The figures for girls were only slightly lower and nearly 8 per cent of all 16-year-olds said they had been using drugs, including ecstasy and LSD, on a weekly basis for at least three months.

The survey also found that patterns of drug use shifted according to age. A fifth of 16-year-old boys said they preferred cannabis, whereas only one in 50 said they habitually used glue or gas.

It also looked at drinking and smoking. It found that 5 per cent of 11-year-olds and 40 per cent of 16-year-olds drank alcohol on a weekly basis. A fifth of 16-year-old boys said they were 'drunk' - defined as 'feeling sick and falling about' - at least once a fortnight.

The figures confirm a suspected increase in alcohol consumption among youngsters, especially in 'binge' drinking.

According to the research, around one in 20 11-year-olds smoke daily. Nearly a third of 15-year-old girls do so, an increase of more than 40 per cent compared with 1998 official figures. Young smokers' habits are also surprisingly heavy. Around half of all 11- to 16-year-old smokers consume between six and 15 cigarettes daily.

According to Gluck, one of the most significant findings is the importance of smoking and drinking to initiating later drug use. Children most commonly start to use drugs, cigarettes and alcohol between 13 and 14.

There are concerns over the ability of schools to cope with the problem. A recent Ofsted survey found that under 50 per cent of primary schools had a policy on drug-related incidents. Many believe the traditional approach involving lectures by police officers, former addicts and specialists is not effective.

'There is too little, too late,' said Michelle Roe, a director of Life Education Centres. 'There is no point in lecturing 12 year olds, whose attitudes are formed. You have to speak to five year olds.'

More than one in 100 boys aged 12 said they had tried heroin. A similar number of 11-year-olds said they had tried cocaine. Around twice as many said they had used cannabis, glue or had sniffed propellents and inhalants known as 'gas'. The findings, based on questionnaires filled in by 20,000 children in 67 secondary schools last year, contradict recent government claims that juvenile drug use is falling. Last week experts called for a complete overhaul of Britain's drugs education programmes. The biggest such exercise ever undertaken, the survey is the first to look in detail at the habitual use of drugs by schoolchildren. It aimed to show whether they used drugs regularly rather than on an experimental basis. A user was defined as someone taking drugs on a weekly basis for at least three months. 'The results were very striking,' said Jeremy Gluck, of Adolescent Assessment Services, the Swansea-based consultancy that carried out the survey on behalf of local education authorities. 'Drug use is much more extensive than we thought. The sheer numbers involved are very worrying. Some totals were so high that we genuinely didn't want to believe them.' The survey found that one in nine 16-year-old boys who admitted using drugs said they did so every day. More than a third used drugs - mainly cannabis, but also harder drugs - at least once a week. The figures for girls were only slightly lower and nearly 8 per cent of all 16-year-olds said they had been using drugs, including ecstasy and LSD, on a weekly basis for at least three months. The survey also found that patterns of drug use shifted according to age. A fifth of 16-year-old boys said they preferred cannabis, whereas only one in 50 said they habitually used glue or gas. It also looked at drinking and smoking. It found that 5 per cent of 11-year-olds and 40 per cent of 16-year-olds drank alcohol on a weekly basis. A fifth of 16-year-old boys said they were 'drunk' - defined as 'feeling sick and falling about' - at least once a fortnight. The figures confirm a suspected increase in alcohol consumption among youngsters, especially in 'binge' drinking. According to the research, around one in 20 11-year-olds smoke daily. Nearly a third of 15-year-old girls do so, an increase of more than 40 per cent compared with 1998 official figures. Young smokers' habits are also surprisingly heavy. Around half of all 11- to 16-year-old smokers consume between six and 15 cigarettes daily. According to Gluck, one of the most significant findings is the importance of smoking and drinking to initiating later drug use. Children most commonly start to use drugs, cigarettes and alcohol between 13 and 14. There are concerns over the ability of schools to cope with the problem. A recent Ofsted survey found that under 50 per cent of primary schools had a policy on drug-related incidents. Many believe the traditional approach involving lectures by police officers, former addicts and specialists is not effective. 'There is too little, too late,' said Michelle Roe, a director of Life Education Centres. 'There is no point in lecturing 12 year olds, whose attitudes are formed. You have to speak to five year olds.'

fields.headline: Refugees face rise in violence
fields.standfirst: Asylum-seekers came to Glasgow for shelter but find only danger as teenage gangs inflict terror
fields.trailText: Asylum-seekers came to Glasgow for shelter but find only danger as teenage gangs inflict terror.
fields.body:
Shiren Abdallah and her husband ran from Iraq because of death threats. In Glasgow, they run a gauntlet of stone-throwing teenagers and racial abuse. A decade ago, soon after the European Capital of Culture year in 1990, Glasgow was presented to visitors as the Friendly City. But on housing schemes less than a mile from the city centre, Mrs Abdallah and thousands of others seeking political asylum are finding hatred.

Scotland's largest city extended the hand of friendship to those claiming to be fleeing persecution just over a year ago, when attempts were made to disperse them throughout the UK to await a decision on whether they could stay.

Mrs Abdallah, who did not want to give her real name, arrived at Heathrow with her husband on 22 May. He had been a supporter of Abdullah Ocalan's Kurdish Workers Party (PKK), which has for years sought a Kurdish state spanning land mainly in northern Iraq and southern Turkey. Following Ocalan's arrest two years ago by the Turkish authorities, the factional Kurdish movement was subject to further splits and bitter infighting. Political violence had already claimed the lives of close relatives and now Mr Abdallah found his own life threatened.

'He was told he would be killed if he stayed,' said Mrs Abdallah. 'But all we wanted was a normal life. So we went to Istanbul and from there got on a plane to London. If people did not have problems they would not come to the UK, leaving their homes, their friends and their families.'

Fluent in English and four other languages, the 33-year-old said there was little in the way of advice on arrival at Heathrow. The couple had just £200 to last a month. 'We had no idea London was so expensive. I had to sell a gold ring that I used to wear. A woman bought it from me for £12. We needed money. When we got to Glasgow I had to ask the people at the Scottish Refugee Council for a food parcel.'

Surviving on vouchers of £37 and £20 cash a week, the couple are housed in a small flat in the Sighthill area of the city, which has a massive heroin problem.

Asylum-seekers have come to Glasgow from Iran, Iraq, Somalia, Turkey and other countries. Some have been sent to the outskirts and few problems with local residents have been reported. But a heavy concentration of the 4,000 who are in the city are in Sighthill and it is here that serious problems are emerging.

Last week, in one of many recent incidents, two badly bruised Palestinian brothers said they were beaten by a gang of teenagers. 'It is horrible what has been happening,' lamented Mrs Abdallah. 'For me it is not so bad as I know the language, but still people swear and throw stones. I cannot tell you the things they say. It is unrepeatable. The attitude towards us has got much worse in recent months.'

Mrs Abdallah said that a pregnant Lebanese woman and her husband were recently pursued by a gang of 16- and 17-year-olds. 'The husband pleaded with them not to touch his wife but she was scratched and beaten. She was physically attacked.

'On another occasion some boys got golf clubs and went into a flat where Kurdish boys were living and hit them. Irn-Bru bottles have been thrown at our window, as have stones. And there is a small hole in our window that cannot have been made by a stone. It looks like a bullet hole.'

Chief Superintendent Allan Burnett, race relations officer with Strathclyde Police, is adamant that the force is tackling the problem. 'The issue of children is a big one. Over 50 per cent of people detected causing problems are children.'

Burnett said a number of factors are working to lift the figures: 'There is a seasonal factor. With the longer nights in the summer months there is usually a pattern of increased trouble among youths. As each month has passed the number of incidents has increased, but there has been an increased willingness to report incidents.'

He said: 'We need to build links and trust with the asylum-seekers.' Burnett pointed out that, while there are around 4,000 in the city now, the number will increase towards a ceiling of 6,000. He believes that many will choose to stay should they be granted asylum and a community of greater numbers will develop.

'The force has embarked on a series of community relations meetings, the first of which was well-attended last weekend.'

To deal with the minority, and to build links and trust with those who have recently arrived, Burnett is making sure that officers on the beat provide a visible presence in the problem areas. 'Foot patrols have been put in place. Officers must be visible in appropriate, not necessarily big, numbers.'

Paul Martin, MSP for the Springburn constituency that includes Sighthill, supports the move for an increased police presence. 'People need to be aware that the officers are there. We need to be directing additional funding for policing.' Martin also said more could be done at a local level to help new arrivals learn English, one problem Mrs Abdallah does not have. She helps translate for others who do not possess her strong command of the language. 'It is important people coming here learn English,' she said. 'Life is so much easier when you know the language.' As of last month there was a 500-strong waiting list for English lessons.

Despite the anger that faces her on a daily basis, Mrs Abdallah remains very fond of Scotland and hopes to remain in Glasgow: 'We have neighbours who deal in drugs, yet many people have been very nice to us. We have made an effort to fit in and most people do seem to appreciate that. In these areas many people are suffering. It is not just us. The biggest problems are down to waiting. We must wait for a decision. We must wait to hear about work.'

While she waits, Mrs Abdallah has one simple desire as she walks from her Sighthill flat to catch the bus that will take her to college: 'I just wish to be treated gently.'

fields.headline: People's peers disgrace democracy
fields.standfirst: Last week's appointments to the House of Lords confirm the contempt New Labour has shown for truly democratic principles
fields.trailText: Last week's appointments to the House of Lords confirm the contempt New Labour has shown for truly democratic principles.
fields.body:
Nothing more betrays the hollowness of New Labour's claim to be 'new' than its attitude towards reforming the state and its equivocation about democracy and the sanctity of the public realm. It just doesn't get it. Beyond a group of disillusioned intellectuals, it thinks, nobody cares about voting, accountability or the shape of the constitution.

The national belly-laugh at the House of Lords' Appointments Commission's announcement of 15 new peers should begin to disabuse it. The patronising view that ordinary people have no interest in the hows and whys of their constitution has been punctured. These aren't people's peers; they are from exactly the same pool of great and good who have been occupying the red benches as life peers for the past 40 years.

It wasn't meant to be like this. The commission is independent. It canvassed the country for applications. It has five criteria for selection for a peerage - independence, commitment to high standards in public life, a record of achievement, capacity to contribute to debates and the spare time to attend them - that seem reasonable. The peers to be produced by this rational process would be obviously superior either to the old hereditaries or party hacks.

But the ill-judged aside of Lord Stevenson, chairman of the commission, that 'the human being should feel comfortable in the House of Lords', gave the game away. What is at issue, as Tom Paine, writing 200 years ago, saw more clearly than any other critic of the British constitution, is a structure and culture in which our governors still function as a class above the governed.

As Paine put it, the invading Normans constructed a constitution that allowed the new French-speaking barons to deliberate and then do what they wanted to the subject English. That was the way the system essentially operated in 1800. Universal suffrage and the veneer of modern democracy have been bolted on to the same structures, so that much of what Paine inveighed against is still alive.

For excellence and career achievement, along with feeling at home on the red benches, are utterly inadequate criteria for becoming a national legislator. I'm sure that Sir John Browne, chief executive of BP, or Professor Susan Greenfield, director of the Royal Institution, will make wise and considered interventions in those debates where their expertise will be welcome. But the Lords could have availed itself of their wisdom without making them full-time legislators. It could easily and simply have asked them to become full-time members of its select committees or to give evidence on legislation.

But the solution that has been adopted means that because the newly appointed peers have a track record of achievement in one area, they have the right of voting and speaking in all areas - from asylum-seekers to fox-hunting - despite the fact they are accountable to nobody for how they vote.

This is an impossible principle to defend. Arguments that elections might be dangerous because turnout could be low, that the intake might be unpredictable, that the Lords will gain a legitimacy to rival the Commons and that party point-scoring will replace the considered tone of the Lords are spurious. They are dangers that have to be guarded against, but they cannot obstruct the basic position. In a democracy, legislators must be accountable to the people.

Indeed, the proposition is even larger than that, a point well understood by Paine and his contemporaries in enlightenment Europe, who were delightedly shrugging off centuries of rule by monarch and church. Any community needs a functioning and efficient public realm where argument can be freely made, political support marshalled and those who make decisions can be held to account by those for whom they are made. The eighteenth- and nineteenth-century constitution builders in Europe and the US did no more than try to construct a political architecture that could permit the expression of an accountable public realm, in which democracy and citizenship were key components.

Britain has never tried self-consciously to build a constitution that entrenched and succoured the public interest. The political class has always taken the view that the constitution, designed by the Normans and amended by successive generations, is pretty much unimprovable. But the consequences of this failure are all around. We may not care much that we have the fewest elected officials per thousand of population of most democracies, but more worrying is our lack of commitment to the principle of voting and, beyond that, to an idea of a public sphere. Our spatchcock constitutional arrangements suffuse our public culture, and that culture itself is compromised by our lack of faith in a conception of 'publicness'.

So it is that 3,166 people filled in the form to become a peer, thinking that nothing could be more normal than becoming a legislator via a university-type admissions system. So it is that we do not have the constitutional template properly to entrench the independence of a public corporation like the BBC. In our constitutional system, the public realm is the Crown in Parliament which controls all it surveys; there can be no true independence for anything within its embrace.

So it is that the Government has constructed Private Finance Initiatives and Public Private Partnerships without ever, until being challenged by Ken Livingstone, thinking carefully what the constitution of such arrangements might be that would entrench and safeguard the public interest.

And even the concession that a PPP might have public-interest 'partnership' directors has been squeezed grudgingly from a disinterested Government. And so it is that even the principle of universal taxation has just been breached, with the Government conceding that business can choose what tax it pays instead of local authorities having the right to charge a supplementary business rate. We are back to pre-Civil War England.

The hope was that when New Labour took office and launched its constitutional reform programme that it understood this was the means to the greater end, renewing and so reclaiming Britain's battered public realm.

We were wrong. New Labour had no such ambition. But as the laughter over people's peers reverberates, maybe it will learn. If it wants fewer such cock-ups, it should understand the spirit of the times.

webTitle: Brief encounter with the king of steam

fields.headline: Brief encounter with the king of steam
fields.standfirst: A girlhood dream comes true for award-winning novelist  Kate Atkinson as she drives one of the world's greatest steam engines
fields.trailText: A girlhood dream comes true for award-winning novelist Kate Atkinson as she drives one of the world's greatest steam engines
fields.body:
I have been in love with steam trains for as long as I can remember. I have railways in my blood. I come from a railway town, my uncle and grandfather were employed at the now-defunct carriage works in my old home town of York. I was brought up in a house beside the York to Scarborough line and spent many a happy hour of my childhood waving to the train drivers.

I also have vivid childhood memories of visiting the small museum that closed to make way for the National Railway Museum in York. In those days, you could climb into the locomotive cabs and touch all those polished brass dials and levers. (And a note to all those men who always tell me that my obsession with trains is a phallic thing: do they honestly think their rather unattractive genitals bear any relation to a 102-ton steel locomotive? I think not.)

My greatest wish has always been to ride on the footplate of a Class A-4 Pacific locomotive, the most magnificent thing ever to come out of an engineering shed. The A-4 Pacific was Britain's very own streamliner, an art-deco 'racehorse' introduced in 1935, just in time for George V's silver jubilee. The A-4s were designed by Sir Nigel Gresley - probably the greatest locomotive engineer the world has ever seen.

In the Thirties, the goal of steam was speed and a Doncaster-built A-4 called the Mallard provided it by hurtling through the Lincolnshire countryside at 126mph to became the fastest steam locomotive in the world.

At the time, it must have seemed as though this was only the latest achievement in a race that would go on forever - that better, faster engines would come along and overtake the Mallard's achievement. History, however, knows better and the Mallard now holds the record for steam 'for all time', a poignant phrase on a par with 'the line ended in daughters'.

Falcon, Wild Swan, Kingfisher, Merlin, Silver Fox, Golden Fleece, Sparrow Hawk - once there were 35 A-4s. One was destroyed in a Second World War air raid on York and the rest were decommissioned in the Sixties, that reign of terror for the steam train. Now there are only six A-4s left, four of which are in Britain. The grande dame herself, the Mallard, takes pride of place in the National Railway Museum.

A chance remark during a newspaper interview resulted in a call from the North York shire Moors Railway, the preservation society now running what was once the Whitby to Pickering line, offering a trip on the Sir Nigel Gresley, the engine named for the great man himself. The line, planned under the supervision of George Stephenson of Rocket fame and opened in 1836, using trains drawn by horses, is one of the oldest in the country. It was closed by British Rail as part of the Beeching cuts in the Sixties.

We set off early from Edinburgh and drive without stopping for breakfast so that when we arrive on the station platform at Grosmont, the sight of the tea-room (with a real coal fire) provides a brief but welcome encounter with coffee and buttered scones.

Grosmont appears completely authentic, a station preserved in time but, like most of the other features on the line, a considerable portion of it has been cobbled together from the leftovers of abandoned stations - a booking office here, a lamppost there.

And here she is, the Sir Nigel herself (even locos with male names are female), number 60007, painted in the old BR blue livery and almost pawing at the ground as she works up a head of steam. So it's on with the overalls and on to the footplate with George, the driver, Peter the fireman and Roger, who is the custodian of the engine for the Sir Nigel Gresley Locomotive Preservation Trust.

We are a full complement - the maximum number of crew allowed on the footplate is four. Peter gallantly offers me the fireman's seat, although as the journey progresses it becomes difficult to see when a fireman ever gets to sit down. The job is a lot more than just shovelling coal. For one thing, he has to keep an eye on all those dials so that the boiler doesn't either lose pressure or 'blow-off', that is, build up too much steam, although every time anyone says this I think they're saying 'blow-up'. A little nerve-racking, especially as, when we do let off steam, there is an ear-shattering noise in the cab.

In bright spring sunshine, we set off across the North York Moors which are eerily deserted, having been closed by the spectre of foot-and-mouth disease. We won't be breaking any records today, for although the Sir Nigel holds the postwar record for speed (112mph), restrictions on private railway lines dictate a paltry 25mph.

Everything is somehow as I imagined it: the signalman requesting a shovelful of coal for his fire, the hosing down of the footplate (George runs a clean cab), the exchanging of tokens at every station. I am in a state of bliss, especially as I get to blow the whistle all the way there and back.

Grosmont, Goathland, Newton Dale Halt, Levisham, Pickering - the 18-mile journey takes us past beautiful scenery and bizarre sights, such as the early-warning station at Fylingdales, where the Prisoner- like golf ball shapes have been replaced by an equally surreal receiver that looks like a giant wedge of cheese. The line also boasts one of the steepest gradients in the country - 1 in 49.

Even if you've never been to the North York Moors you will almost certainly have seen this railway and the trains that run on it, in The Secret Garden, Brideshead Revisited and countless other films and television productions. Goathland is the Aidensfield of Heartbeat and Grosmont stars as Hogwarts Station in the new Harry Potter movie.

On the train is a small American boy following the 'Harry Potter trail'. George, our driver, jokes that he's expecting his Equity card any day now.

Kate Atkinson's new novel Emotionally Weird (Black Swan, £6.99) is out now

At the time, it must have seemed as though this was only the latest achievement in a race that would go on forever - that better, faster engines would come along and overtake the Mallard's achievement. History, however, knows better and the Mallard now holds the record for steam 'for all time', a poignant phrase on a par with 'the line ended in daughters'. Falcon, Wild Swan, Kingfisher, Merlin, Silver Fox, Golden Fleece, Sparrow Hawk - once there were 35 A-4s. One was destroyed in a Second World War air raid on York and the rest were decommissioned in the Sixties, that reign of terror for the steam train. Now there are only six A-4s left, four of which are in Britain. The grande dame herself, the Mallard, takes pride of place in the National Railway Museum. A chance remark during a newspaper interview resulted in a call from the North York shire Moors Railway, the preservation society now running what was once the Whitby to Pickering line, offering a trip on the Sir Nigel Gresley, the engine named for the great man himself. The line, planned under the supervision of George Stephenson of Rocket fame and opened in 1836, using trains drawn by horses, is one of the oldest in the country. It was closed by British Rail as part of the Beeching cuts in the Sixties. We set off early from Edinburgh and drive without stopping for breakfast so that when we arrive on the station platform at Grosmont, the sight of the tea-room (with a real coal fire) provides a brief but welcome encounter with coffee and buttered scones. Grosmont appears completely authentic, a station preserved in time but, like most of the other features on the line, a considerable portion of it has been cobbled together from the leftovers of abandoned stations - a booking office here, a lamppost there. And here she is, the Sir Nigel herself (even locos with male names are female), number 60007, painted in the old BR blue livery and almost pawing at the ground as she works up a head of steam. So it's on with the overalls and on to the footplate with George, the driver, Peter the fireman and Roger, who is the custodian of the engine for the Sir Nigel Gresley Locomotive Preservation Trust. We are a full complement - the maximum number of crew allowed on the footplate is four. Peter gallantly offers me the fireman's seat, although as the journey progresses it becomes difficult to see when a fireman ever gets to sit down. The job is a lot more than just shovelling coal. For one thing, he has to keep an eye on all those dials so that the boiler doesn't either lose pressure or 'blow-off', that is, build up too much steam, although every time anyone says this I think they're saying 'blow-up'. A little nerve-racking, especially as, when we do let off steam, there is an ear-shattering noise in the cab. In bright spring sunshine, we set off across the North York Moors which are eerily deserted, having been closed by the spectre of foot-and-mouth disease. We won't be breaking any records today, for although the Sir Nigel holds the postwar record for speed (112mph), restrictions on private railway lines dictate a paltry 25mph. Everything is somehow as I imagined it: the signalman requesting a shovelful of coal for his fire, the hosing down of the footplate (George runs a clean cab), the exchanging of tokens at every station. I am in a state of bliss, especially as I get to blow the whistle all the way there and back. Grosmont, Goathland, Newton Dale Halt, Levisham, Pickering - the 18-mile journey takes us past beautiful scenery and bizarre sights, such as the early-warning station at Fylingdales, where the Prisoner- like golf ball shapes have been replaced by an equally surreal receiver that looks like a giant wedge of cheese. The line also boasts one of the steepest gradients in the country - 1 in 49. Even if you've never been to the North York Moors you will almost certainly have seen this railway and the trains that run on it, in The Secret Garden, Brideshead Revisited and countless other films and television productions. Goathland is the Aidensfield of Heartbeat and Grosmont stars as Hogwarts Station in the new Harry Potter movie. On the train is a small American boy following the 'Harry Potter trail'. George, our driver, jokes that he's expecting his Equity card any day now. Kate Atkinson's new novel Emotionally Weird (Black Swan, £6.99) is out now

webTitle: Thousands more jobs at risk in 'Silicon Glen'

fields.headline: Thousands more jobs at risk in 'Silicon Glen'
fields.trailText: The gloom hanging over workers in Scotland's 'Silicon Glen' is set to deepen with a further rash of bad news in the next few weeks.
fields.body:
The gloom hanging over workers in Scotland's 'Silicon Glen' is set to deepen with a further rash of bad news in the next few weeks.

Companies including Sun Microsystems, Panasonic and Rosti - which makes casings for mobile phones - located in the hi-tech belt between Glasgow and Edinburgh are planning plant closures.

The news follows a devastating week not only for Scotland, where Motorola announced its intention to shed 3,100 jobs at Bathgate, but in the technology sector as a whole as Canadian telecoms giant Nortel cut 700 jobs. Its HQ is in Maidenhead.

Electronics giant Panasonic last Wednesday started a consultation period on the future of its East Kilbride operations, which its 200 employees fear will lead to closure. Another company, APW in Hamilton, which makes metal plating for mobiles, is likely to wield the axe - it also employs 200.

Rosti, which has two plants in Hamilton and Larkhall, employs 700 making the shells for mobile phones.

Workers at Sun Microsystems, which employs 750 at its plant at Linlithgow, West Lothian, have been told to take holidays or unpaid leave while the plant is shut down for the next week.

Danny Carrigan of the AEEU union said unions had requested a meeting with Motorola managers to argue job cuts should be spread over the company's other Scottish and German plants.

fields.headline: The Bath Spa, Bath
fields.trailText: It may be rated as a five-star hotel but there's no pomp or pretension about the place. Staff are young and friendly and the service is low key and efficient.
fields.body:
Address: Sydney Road, Bath

Tel: 0870 400 8222

Website: www.bathspahotel.com.

Weekend rates from £135 per person per night. Three night dinner, bed and breakfast offers available from £300 per person.

Bath has no shortage of swish hotels, so what's special about this one?
True, but most of them don't have their own health and fitness centre with spa treatments, sauna and pool. After a long, hard day pounding the cobbles in search of the perfect Bath bun, what could be better than a soak in the Jacuzzi?

Sounds good, but what's the rest of the hotel like?
The hotel, built around a nineteenth-century mansion house in landscaped grounds overlooking the city centre, has recently undergone a comprehensive refurbishment. Bedrooms have been redecorated in crisp, neutral shades and the purple-hued lounge with log fire is particularly welcoming.

Is the food up to scratch?
The conservatory-style Alfresco restaurant carries off British classics (roast chicken with bubble and squeak) and more adventurous options (steamed clams with black noodles and tomato salsa) with equal panache, and the fresh-baked bread is heavenly. A local couple we got chatting to in the Jacuzzi rated it as one of the best restaurants in Bath.

Do I need to be on my best behaviour?
It may be rated as a five-star hotel but there's no pomp or pretension about the place. Staff are young and friendly and the service is low key and efficient. It manages to feel like a country-house hotel though it's just a 15-minute walk to the city centre. And did I mention the Jacuzzi?

webTitle: Sierra Leone - keeping a newspaper alive in exile

fields.headline: Keeping a newspaper alive in exile
fields.standfirst:
How new technology and international solidarity prevented my newspaper being killed off.

Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Ibrahim Sega Shaw of The Expo Times, Sierra Leone, describes how new technology and international solidarity prevented his newspaper being killed off.
fields.byline: Ibrahim Sega Shaw, Editor, The Expo Times
fields.body:
As the editor of the Expo Times in Sierra Leone, I was forced into exile in February 1998 having narrowly escaped death in the hands of government militias and Ecomog soldiers who had just concluded a military operation to remove the then AFRC junta and return the elected government of Kabbah to power.

They were eager to settle scores with me for having been among the newspaper publishers supporting dialogue to resolve the conflict, rather than the use of force with its attendant consequences on the population.

I therefore came to France in October 1998 where, with the help of the Paris based Reporters Sans Frontiers, I was recognised by the French government as a political refugee two months later. Following the signing of the Lome Peace accord in July 1999, I felt vindicated and relieved - it had been because of my paper's stance for constructive dialogue to end the crisis that my life had been threatened and I had been chased into exile.

While I gave some interviews to the BBC and VOA on the ongoing peace process, I felt that this was not enough. Then suddenly I felt the urge to re-launch my newspaper and continue the campaign for peace, democracy and human rights for all.

But I wondered how I could do this while still in exile and after having lost everything including my office and newspaper gadgets, my staff, two of whom were still detained by the authorities awaiting trial for treason.

My chance came when I met Brian Whitaker of the Guardian and John Owen of the Freedom Forum at a September 1999 conference in London. When I told Brian of my plans to being publishing the newspaper again, possibly by printing copies abroad and then distributing them, Brian sold the idea of publishing online. He also linked me up with Ian Wright, the Guardian Foundation Chairman, who also helped a lot with advice and logistics to start the project.

As I had no experience of using the internet, Brian helped me to build the website, with a template for updating each edition, and offered me initial training on how to do the updates. John Owen paid for the registration of the web site and I launched it on March 15, 2000.

The site got 3000 hits that first day and it has been growing since then. Since then I have been publishing fortnightly with regular online news updates between issues. Brian helped with the updates for three months after which I took over the complete running of the website from him. While doing both the newspaper editing and uploading of the articles on the website has been very demanding, my paper is now enjoying a daily average of 6000 hits.

I've contributors based in Sierra Leone, Ghana, the USA, Canada, Holland, Belgium, Germany, France and I'm happy that they've been co-operating in sending articles about Sierra Leone and Africa. Apart from linking the Sierra Leonean community abroad and those at home, the paper has emerged as one of the most, if not the most vocal and dependemble source of information on Sierra Leone and Africa. With my newly appointed West Africa bureau editor based in Ghana, my paper is now featuring interpretative reports from that region almost on a daily basis.

With the help of this online project I've also been able to relaunch the printed version of my newspaper in Sierra Leone with the help of my small staff. Most of the articles that go into the printed paper are downloaded directly from my on line paper. Apart from some logistical problems the printed paper is facing, coupled with some verbal threats on my bureau editor's life, the printed paper has also been doing fine.

Although I've been hosting some adverts of Sierra Leonean owned businesses, I've not realised much from them and the little that comes in has not been enough to cover the cost of running the website. The desk-top PC I received from the Guardian Foundation through Ian Wright and the laptop John Owen offered me have been indispensable.

Since December 2000, my newspaper has been part of the allafrica.com network operating from Washington in March and since then my paper's articles from Sierra Leone, West Africa and other parts of the world are often among its top headlines. I am also relieved that the little that will come in from that contract in lieu of royalties will help stabilise the paper a little to encourage its contributors who have been doing an excellent job. I am also seeking grant funding which I think I need to expand the web site in terms of target audience and the volume of articles.

The online paper's first birthday event funded and hosted in London by the Freedom Forum European Center on March 15 went a long way to boost its profile. As part of the celebrations, three of my contributors were brought in from Sierra Leone, Canada and Germany by the Freedom Forum to join me in sharing our online experience with other journalists and well-wishers. I was also a guest on 'Global' on BBC Radio 5 and on BBC Network Africa programmes. Among other things, I said that the internet is indeed a salvation for journalists in exile and that African dictators should be warned that no matter what they do to suppress the independent press the internet is always there as the last resort.

Ibrahim Sega Shaw is editor and publisher of the Expo Times, which he continues to publish from exile in France.

The Expo Times

fields.headline: The French are coming
fields.standfirst: Hollywood stars will be thin on the ground at  Cannes this year and there are no British films at all. But that doesn't bother the hosts
fields.trailText: Hollywood stars will be thin on the ground at Cannes this year and there are no British films at all. But that doesn't bother the hosts.
fields.body:
It appeared to be an inspired decision to open the 54th Cannes International Film Festival with Baz Luhrmann's Moulin Rouge (pictured). The 9 May curtain-raiser to the world's biggest fusion of art and commerce is a brash American movie that is also a Valentine to French showbusiness.

But the evening has already thrown up a major headache. 20th Century-Fox wanted to throw an opening night bash befitting its raucous $50 million musical set in Pigalle's red-light district in the 1890s. The festival organisers, however, favoured the traditional black tie gala, complete with polite speeches, ideally to be held in an elegant marquee. The compromise: the studio is recreating Pigalle inside two interconnected circus tents. Against a backdrop of the romantic elements of Paris and the French culture, 2,000 invited guests, including the film's stars Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor, can watch can-can dancers cavort while listening to music overseen by guest DJ, Fatboy Slim.

Party protocol is only one of the differences between the Cannes organisers and Hollywood, whose symbiotic and increasingly strained relationship has dominated the event in recent years. Cannes has always been a global launch pad for American movies, from All About Eve to Pulp Fiction, but soaring production costs mean the US studios are now more jittery about bringing their films to a festival where they are at the mercy of critics and discriminating audiences. On the other hand, in recent years the Cannes organisers have often been so keen to bask in the media spotlight that they have rolled out the red carpet for Hollywood's most commercial follies.

American stars may be thin on the ground this May because of the Screen Actors Guild's looming strike: many productions are currently shooting around the clock to beat the 30 June deadline. One Cannes drop-out is Jodie Foster, who was to have presided over the festival's jury until she was tapped as a last-minute replacement for Nicole Kidman, who had limped off David Fincher's The Panic Room with a knee injury. Panic-stricken Columbia Pictures could not afford to delay shooting to accommodate Foster's Cannes duties.

The fraught relationship between the sensitive artists of the old world and the marauding monsters of the new reached its nadir in 1998 when Godzilla was selected as the event's closing film. You hardly need to be a Jean-Luc Godard buff to grasp the symbolism.

Which is why Thierry Fremaux, in his first year as artistic director, is so keen to reclaim the artistic high ground Cannes has ceded inch-by-inch to rival festivals in Venice and Berlin. There is certainly a feeling of deja vu surveying this year's competition line-up, which includes a new film from 70-year-old Godard. Indeed Eloge de L'Amour is rumoured to be one of the former New Waver's strongest and most accessible works.

Joining Godard is a filmmaker of even more advanced years, 73-year-old former critic, Jacques Rivette, whose new film Va Savoir! is only his twelfth in 40 years. And he is not the oldest competitor. That honour goes to Portugal's Cannes fixture, 92-year-old Manoel de Oliveira, whose Je Rentre la Maison stars the first lady of French cinema, Catherine Deneuve, and John Malkovich.

most of the directors in competition this year are repeat visitors, such as the Coen brothers and David Lynch, whose latest works, O Brother, Where Art Thou? and The Straight Story, premiered at Cannes. Lynch's visceral Wild at Heart won the top prize at Cannes in 1990 and the Coens swept the board the following year with Barton Fink. Their new crime flick, The Man Who Wasn't There, starring Frances McDormand, Billy Bob Thornton and The Sopranos's James Gandolfini, is rumoured to be more offbeat than O Brother, which, despite lukewarm reviews, became their most profitable picture to date. Lynch's latest, the noirish Mulholland Drive, starring Patricia Arquette and Tim Robbins, was originally made as the pilot for a television series.

The fourth American film out of the 23 in competition is Sean Penn's police drama, The Pledge, starring Jack Nicholson and Benicio del Toro. Other American films, directed by Todd Solondz, Hal Hartley and actors Jennifer Jason Leigh and Alan Cumming, are included in sections outside the main competition.

Veteran Japanese director Shohei Imamura, who controversially won the Palme d'Or in 1983 with The Ballad of Narayama and again in 1997 with Unagi is also back this year with the intriguingly titled Lukewarm Water Under a Red Bridge. So is Italy's Ermano Olmi, whose period epic, The Tree of the Wooden Clogs, walked away with the 1978 Palme d'Or. Olmi's latest is The Profession of Arms.

Also returning from Italy is Nanni Moretti with The Son's Room, and the Austrian auteur Michael Haneke is back with The Piano Teacher, starring Isabelle Huppert. Raoul Ruiz returns to close the festival with Les Ames Fortes, which screens out of competition.

Fremaux's most daring decision is to have selected DreamWorks's Shrek, the first animated film to be in competition since 1953, when Peter Pan charmed festival-goers. Mike Myers, Eddie Murphy and Cameron Diaz provide the voices in the state-of-the-art film that pokes fun at Disney animations.

Cannes seems to be infatuated with Italian-Americans. Films screening outside the competition slots include Francis Coppola's extended version of Apocalypse Now (a film that originally premiered at Cannes), the debut film from his son, Roman, entitled C.Q., and Martin Scorsese's four-hour documentary, My Voyage in Italy. The Spike Jonze-produced Human Nature from pop video director Michel Gondry could even be included in this category: Jonze is married to Coppola's daughter Sofia.

Eastern Asian and Chinese-language films are not as dominant at Cannes as they were last year, but the Far East, particularly Japan, still has an impressive presence with three movies in competition. In addition to Imamura, Japan is represented by Hirokazu Kore-Eda, who found fame on the festival circuit with After Life. Kore-Eda's latest film, Distance, is about the relatives of a group of dead terrorists. Also included is Desert Moon, by last year's Cannes discovery, Shinji Aoyama, whose three-hour feature, Eureka, recently opened in the US. Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien is back with The Story of Rose, which stars Shu Qi.

twelve countries are represented in the official selection including first- timers Bosnia with No Man's Land, directed by Danis Tanovic. Ireland is represented by a three-minute short called Chicken. The most notable absentees are the Australians, which is ironic considering that Baz Luhrmann was a Cannes discovery with Strictly Ballroom in 1990, and the British.

Nobody who has sat through the largely woeful collection of British films from the last year could be surprised by the UK's omission from Cannes competition, but at least the French have decided to hold a special sympathy screening of Ken Loach's Kes. While many filmmakers have recently embraced the social realism Loach captured 30 years ago - indeed, the overriding topics of this year's Cannes films are mourning and melancholy, loneliness and violence - the British industry is hurtling in the opposite direction, churning out pale facsimiles of its rare break-out hits. These days, most British films are managing to miss out on both festival plaudits and multiples queues.

Producer Nik Powell, who has had several films screened at Cannes over the years, including Mona Lisa, Neon Bible and Scandal, is more generous in his assessment: 'There are two reasons why there are no British films this year. First, most of our Cannes directors have not made films that are ready. And second, many more filmmaking territories have recently opened up and Cannes has not extended the size of the event to reflect this. For example, a few years ago, there were hardly any Asian films at Cannes.'

More significantly, though, in the last year there have been seismic shifts in the marketplace to the extent that what may initially look like a predictable and esoteric line-up of blink-and-you'll-miss-them festival films is in fact the real vanguard of commercialism. Several titles in last year's Cannes line-up seemed alien to the public but ended up as money-spinners while dozens of more recognisable studio films crashed and burned. Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon hauled in more than $100m in pure profit - even more than Pulp Fiction - while Dancer in the Dark, In the Mood For Love, Yi Yi and O Brother all catapulted their directors into the bankability league. And let's not forget that Billy Elliot took his first steps at Cannes last year. Already there is industry buzz surrounding the film Tears of the Black Tiger, which may bring the Thai western genre to a cinema near you soon.

Look at what three of the directors who had films shown at Cannes last year are up to. Nurse Betty director Neil LaBute has just wrapped Possession, starring Gwyneth Paltrow. Requiem for a Dream director Darren Aronofsky is attached to direct the next Batman movie. And Ang Lee has signed up to direct The Incredible Hulk. By pre-empting the mainstream, Cannes is blurring the line between art and commerce more than ever. Let the party begin.

 The 54th Cannes Film Festival runs 9-20 May

Festival form past and present

The Favourites
Eloge De L'Amour
Director Jean-Luc Godard has the sentimental vote and his new film is eagerly anticipated.
Mulholland Drive
Culled from his aborted TV series, David Lynch's latest is another slice of dark surrealism.
Moulin Rouge
Baz Luhrmann's lavish musical could enchant the jury.

The Jury
Liv Ullmann (president), Mimmo Calopresti, Charlotte Gainsbourg, Terry Gilliam, Mathieu Kassovitz, Sandrine Kiberlain, Phillipe Labro, Julia Ormond, Moufida Tlatli, Edward Yang.

Palme d'Or: The Winners
2000 Dancer in the Dark
1999 Rosetta
1998 Eternity and a Day
1997 Taste of Cherry and The Eel
1996 Secrets & Lies
1995 Underground
1994 Pulp Fiction
1993 Farewell My Concubine and The Piano
1992 Best Intentions
1991 Barton Fink

You hardly need to be a Jean-Luc Godard buff to grasp the symbolism. Which is why Thierry Fremaux, in his first year as artistic director, is so keen to reclaim the artistic high ground Cannes has ceded inch-by-inch to rival festivals in Venice and Berlin. There is certainly a feeling of deja vu surveying this year's competition line-up, which includes a new film from 70-year-old Godard. Indeed Eloge de L'Amour is rumoured to be one of the former New Waver's strongest and most accessible works. Joining Godard is a filmmaker of even more advanced years, 73-year-old former critic, Jacques Rivette, whose new film Va Savoir! is only his twelfth in 40 years. And he is not the oldest competitor. That honour goes to Portugal's Cannes fixture, 92-year-old Manoel de Oliveira, whose Je Rentre la Maison stars the first lady of French cinema, Catherine Deneuve, and John Malkovich. most of the directors in competition this year are repeat visitors, such as the Coen brothers and David Lynch, whose latest works, O Brother, Where Art Thou? and The Straight Story, premiered at Cannes. Lynch's visceral Wild at Heart won the top prize at Cannes in 1990 and the Coens swept the board the following year with Barton Fink. Their new crime flick, The Man Who Wasn't There, starring Frances McDormand, Billy Bob Thornton and The Sopranos's James Gandolfini, is rumoured to be more offbeat than O Brother, which, despite lukewarm reviews, became their most profitable picture to date. Lynch's latest, the noirish Mulholland Drive, starring Patricia Arquette and Tim Robbins, was originally made as the pilot for a television series. The fourth American film out of the 23 in competition is Sean Penn's police drama, The Pledge, starring Jack Nicholson and Benicio del Toro. Other American films, directed by Todd Solondz, Hal Hartley and actors Jennifer Jason Leigh and Alan Cumming, are included in sections outside the main competition. Veteran Japanese director Shohei Imamura, who controversially won the Palme d'Or in 1983 with The Ballad of Narayama and again in 1997 with Unagi is also back this year with the intriguingly titled Lukewarm Water Under a Red Bridge. So is Italy's Ermano Olmi, whose period epic, The Tree of the Wooden Clogs, walked away with the 1978 Palme d'Or. Olmi's latest is The Profession of Arms. Also returning from Italy is Nanni Moretti with The Son's Room, and the Austrian auteur Michael Haneke is back with The Piano Teacher, starring Isabelle Huppert. Raoul Ruiz returns to close the festival with Les Ames Fortes, which screens out of competition. Fremaux's most daring decision is to have selected DreamWorks's Shrek, the first animated film to be in competition since 1953, when Peter Pan charmed festival-goers. Mike Myers, Eddie Murphy and Cameron Diaz provide the voices in the state-of-the-art film that pokes fun at Disney animations. Cannes seems to be infatuated with Italian-Americans. Films screening outside the competition slots include Francis Coppola's extended version of Apocalypse Now (a film that originally premiered at Cannes), the debut film from his son, Roman, entitled C.Q., and Martin Scorsese's four-hour documentary, My Voyage in Italy. The Spike Jonze-produced Human Nature from pop video director Michel Gondry could even be included in this category: Jonze is married to Coppola's daughter Sofia. Eastern Asian and Chinese-language films are not as dominant at Cannes as they were last year, but the Far East, particularly Japan, still has an impressive presence with three movies in competition. In addition to Imamura, Japan is represented by Hirokazu Kore-Eda, who found fame on the festival circuit with After Life. Kore-Eda's latest film, Distance, is about the relatives of a group of dead terrorists. Also included is Desert Moon, by last year's Cannes discovery, Shinji Aoyama, whose three-hour feature, Eureka, recently opened in the US. Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien is back with The Story of Rose, which stars Shu Qi. twelve countries are represented in the official selection including first- timers Bosnia with No Man's Land, directed by Danis Tanovic. Ireland is represented by a three-minute short called Chicken. The most notable absentees are the Australians, which is ironic considering that Baz Luhrmann was a Cannes discovery with Strictly Ballroom in 1990, and the British. Nobody who has sat through the largely woeful collection of British films from the last year could be surprised by the UK's omission from Cannes competition, but at least the French have decided to hold a special sympathy screening of Ken Loach's Kes. While many filmmakers have recently embraced the social realism Loach captured 30 years ago - indeed, the overriding topics of this year's Cannes films are mourning and melancholy, loneliness and violence - the British industry is hurtling in the opposite direction, churning out pale facsimiles of its rare break-out hits. These days, most British films are managing to miss out on both festival plaudits and multiples queues. Producer Nik Powell, who has had several films screened at Cannes over the years, including Mona Lisa, Neon Bible and Scandal, is more generous in his assessment: 'There are two reasons why there are no British films this year. First, most of our Cannes directors have not made films that are ready. And second, many more filmmaking territories have recently opened up and Cannes has not extended the size of the event to reflect this. For example, a few years ago, there were hardly any Asian films at Cannes.' More significantly, though, in the last year there have been seismic shifts in the marketplace to the extent that what may initially look like a predictable and esoteric line-up of blink-and-you'll-miss-them festival films is in fact the real vanguard of commercialism. Several titles in last year's Cannes line-up seemed alien to the public but ended up as money-spinners while dozens of more recognisable studio films crashed and burned. Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon hauled in more than $100m in pure profit - even more than Pulp Fiction - while Dancer in the Dark, In the Mood For Love, Yi Yi and O Brother all catapulted their directors into the bankability league. And let's not forget that Billy Elliot took his first steps at Cannes last year. Already there is industry buzz surrounding the film Tears of the Black Tiger, which may bring the Thai western genre to a cinema near you soon. Look at what three of the directors who had films shown at Cannes last year are up to. Nurse Betty director Neil LaBute has just wrapped Possession, starring Gwyneth Paltrow. Requiem for a Dream director Darren Aronofsky is attached to direct the next Batman movie. And Ang Lee has signed up to direct The Incredible Hulk. By pre-empting the mainstream, Cannes is blurring the line between art and commerce more than ever. Let the party begin.  The 54th Cannes Film Festival runs 9-20 May Festival form past and present The Favourites Eloge De L'Amour Director Jean-Luc Godard has the sentimental vote and his new film is eagerly anticipated. Mulholland Drive Culled from his aborted TV series, David Lynch's latest is another slice of dark surrealism. Moulin Rouge Baz Luhrmann's lavish musical could enchant the jury. The Jury Liv Ullmann (president), Mimmo Calopresti, Charlotte Gainsbourg, Terry Gilliam, Mathieu Kassovitz, Sandrine Kiberlain, Phillipe Labro, Julia Ormond, Moufida Tlatli, Edward Yang. webTitle: Putin regards media as a tool for manipulation

fields.headline: Putin regards media as a tool for manipulation
fields.standfirst: The Russian government believes it has the absolute right to define the public interest
fields.trailText: Andrei Babitsky on how the Russian government believes that it must have the absolute right to define the public interest.
fields.body:
The Russian authorities resist freedom of expression where, in their opinion, such freedom is inconsistent with efficient bureacratic administration.

The starkest example of this is the war in Chechnya. Vladimir Putin and his circle are convinced that reporting of military actions should be controlled, because they believe that the situation in Chechnya demands extremely harsh methods of waging war which are far removed from contemporary European standards.

This is to perceive the role of the media wrongly. The Russian President does not regard the media as a self-sufficient public institution, but as a tool for manipulation which must be used in the interests of what he sees as the greater public good.

The problem is that the present Russian government wrongly believes that only it can possess the final and absolute right to express and formulate the interests of the public.

Andrei Babitsky is a reporter with Radio Liberty. His critical coverage of the conflict in Chechnya infuriated the Kremlin, which branded him a traitor. He was detained by Russian troops and formally arrested a week later. He then disappeared for over a month, with the Russian government claiming he had been handed over to Chechen rebels in a prisoner exchange. Babitsky believes he was held by pro-Moscow Chechens. Babitsky was tried and convicted in Dagestan for the use of false documentation after his own had been confiscated, leading to international pressure on the Russian authorities. For more about the Babitsky case, see Andrei Babitsky background and reports from Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty

webTitle: Anatomy of a fiasco - Wembley chronology

fields.headline: Anatomy of a fiasco - Wembley chronology
fields.standfirst: The twists and turns of the Wembley saga - so far ...
fields.trailText: The twists and turns of the Wembley saga - so far ...
fields.body:
December 1996 : Wembley wins competition to be site of a new, multi-sports national stadium. Critics wondered if the Midlands of North-West might not be a better location.

12 January 1999 : English Sports Council approves £120m of Lottery money to buy the site and stadium at Wembley and design a replacement.

29 July 1999 : Plans for a Sir Norman Foster-designed new 90,000-seat stadium unveiled by Wembley National Stadium Limited and the Football Association. The historic Twin Towers, Wembley's signature, are not included. Cost is put at £475m and reopening scheduled for 2003.

2 December 1999 : Culture Secretary Chris Smith tells MPs the new stadium will not be able to stage athletics events such as the Olympic Games. FA later agrees to pay back £20m of the Lottery money as a penalty for not making Wembley suitable for athletics.

August 2000 : Cost of rebuilding Wembley has risen from £475m to £600m, it emerges.

7 October 2000: Wembley closes after England lose 1-0 to Germany in the last-ever game there.

Late November 2000 : Every City institution approached by WNSL and its bankers Chase Manhattan refuses to lend money to build the stadium.

19 November 2000 : FA reveals that FA Cup semi-finals will be played at the new Wembley to help it pay its way. Fans criticise the move.

8 December 2000 : The Football Association finally takes control of the Wembley project from WNSL and Ken Bates and announces that the £660m scheme will be drastically scaled down to cut costs.

19 December 2000 : Ken Bates ousted as Wembley chairman amid concern about WNSL's failure to raise any of the £410m loan it needs.

8 February 2001: Ken Bates resigns from the Wembley board with a strongly-worded broadside against fellow WNSL directors, Kate Hoey 'and her lackeys', the project's bankers and Sir Rodney Walker, his replacement as chairman. 'Even Jesus Christ only had one Pontius Pilate; I had a whole team of them', says Bates

29 April 2001: Key FA and WNSL figures warn that he scheme will be scrapped unless the Government provides around £100m. Confusion surrounds the project's funding, viability and entire future.

webTitle: A semi for teacher - problems for us all

fields.headline: A semi for teacher - problems for us all
fields.standfirst: Graham Norwood on how local authorities are trying to force builders to cater for moderate earners
fields.trailText: Graham Norwood on how local authorities are trying to force builders to cater for moderate earners.
fields.body:
The debate over social housing for public sector workers is set to make a comeback.

Next month the Greater London Assembly will unveil planning guidelines obliging builders to increase the proportion of properties given over to social housing on otherwise-private residential developments. This would not benefit the poorest groups, who still rely on council housing, but would help moderate earners in defined jobs who cannot afford London house prices.

But rows are brewing over the proposal and the debate is creating unlikely alliances. Some social housing experts have joined developers in doubting the scheme's effectiveness.

The argument goes like this: the GLA says that since 1980 London house prices have risen by 3.9 per cent a year to around £180,000, but most earnings have risen by only 2.7 per cent a year. It found that 70 per cent of so-called key workers (mainly health, teaching and public transport staff) earn £25,000 or less - below the £25,800 identified by the authority as the minimum needed to buy in London.

So the Assembly wants 50 per cent of new developments to be given over to social housing for the next 10 years. The 50 per cent figure is seen by experts as a bargaining ploy - it may fall to 30 per cent. However, some experts claim the GLA proposal does not address the real problem - that too few new houses are being built.

They say developers will build the same number of properties on a site whether 70 per cent or 100 per cent are aimed at the private market. But they fear that if 30 per cent is set aside for social housing without a rise in the total number of properties built, the remaining properties may not satisfy demand from private buyers - pushing up prices even further. Experts say that with so few new council houses being built, low-paid groups who are ineligible for social housing (such as the unemployed) will stand little chance of moving from inappropriate or sub-standard local authority properties.

'Governments need to make the housing market more responsive, more quickly, and to provide more homes to meet demand,' argues Michael Ball of the University of the South Bank. 'The key worker scheme may benefit teachers, but unless more homesare built, it just reduces the housing stock for everyone else.'

Predictably, the developers agree. The House Builders' Federation says local authorities are already forcing builders to cut profits on new developments to fund so-called 'planning gains' - parks, community facilities and environmental improvements that builders are expected to pay for in return for planning permission.

The developers say they also lose out because of the Government's push towards building on brownfield sites (which brings demolition and clean-up costs). Now they claim the social housing drive may be the straw that breaks the camel's back.

'Financing for a development is structured on the basis of the price we'll get for the properties,' says Martin Simms of developer St James Homes. 'A lot of social housing on a scheme will push overall prices down to a level that will threaten its viability.'

Simms says developers will identify authorities that favour social housing - and avoid them. He says the west London borough of Hounslow, for example, risks losing key private investment because it is considering a 40 per cent quota of social housing for all new developments.

Whatever local authorities do, social housing will be a bigger element of every new private development in coming years. This creates a more basic issue - how to integrate social homes with private ones on an estate.

Some developers take a traditional approach. St James has just opened a glitzy estate in west London called Kew Riverside, but the social housing is separate from the private flats. 'They back onto a retail area,' says Simms, which means they are next to superstores, car parks, noise and poor views.

Other developers, such as Countryside Properties, encourage a 'pepper-pot' approach, sprinkling individual social housing flats or houses among private ones.

Its best-known development is the Greenwich Millennium Village, where the homes look identical and are a mix of privately rented, privately owned, housing association and shared ownership.

'It's down to local authorities to decide on the volume of social housing and how it is spread through an estate,' says Countryside's Guy Lambert. 'Pepper-potting lifts the overall appearance of an area and improves the social mix. Anyway, if you separate social housing, you just create the ghettos of the future.'

Contacts

GLA Key Issues for Key Workers - downloadable from www.london.gov.uk.
