fields.headline: Hot properties
fields.standfirst: Just like the housing market, the wine world is all about location, location, location
fields.trailText: Just like the housing market, the wine world is all about location, location, location.
fields.body:
About this time every year, I think about selling up and moving closer to the centre of London. I live in a suburb so far from the West End that friends have taken to attaching air-mail stickers to the letters they send me. 'Jesus, mate, I could have flown to Paris for the price of a taxi to your place,' an Aussie winemaker told me recently. Needled, I contact some estate agents, wander around a few properties and realise that to find something similar in a nicer postal district, I'd have to triple my mortgage.

Prices, my neighbours and the wine bar that's just opened by the tube station are the reasons why I still live in Colliers Wood. Don't worry, I'm not on secondment to Property Week . I mention my little semi to make a broader point: namely that, just like the real-estate business, wine is all about three things: location, location and location.

Actually, that's not completely true. In the world of slurping and spitting, reputation, tradition, snobbery and the opinions of certain American journalists have an impact, too. But the analogy still holds. A Bordeaux chteau owner, selling his pile to avoid French tax, asked me: 'Where should I buy my next vineyard?' I suggested the Alentejo or the Languedoc, both places with cheap land, a reliable climate and the potential to make great wines. He looked at me as if I'd suggested a move to Romania. 'No one would pay a high price for the wine because no one could point to either place on a map.'

The wine world is like a game of Monopoly in this respect: if Bordeaux is Mayfair, then Romania is the Old Kent Road. You pay a lot of money for famous names and areas, not all of it related to what you find in the bottle. It is possible to find cheaper wines in top regions, but if you want value for money, look elsewhere.

You've got two choices here, depending on whether you're buying the wine for investment or for your own pleasure. If it's the former, you can try to second-guess the mind of Robert Parker, the world's most powerful wine critic. It's possible that he will fall in love with the wines of southern Portugal, but I wouldn't bet money on it. On the other hand, he has fallen in love with Australian Shiraz, so you never know.

The second option is to buy wines from under-rated areas because they're cheap and taste good, not because they might pay dividends in 20 years' time. You've got plenty of choice if you avoid the obvious blue-chip regions: Bordeaux, Burgundy, the Napa Valley, Piedmont, Tuscany, Ribera del Duero and Champagne.

My tips, in no particular order, are: Chile, Argentina, southern Italy and the islands, Greece, Portugal, Navarra, Jerez and Tarragona in Spain, the Loire Valley, the southern Rhne and the Languedoc-Roussillon in France, South Africa and parts of Australia. Buy wisely from these places and you'll drink good wine at decent prices. You won't be the envy of label worshippers, but do you care? I don't, but then what do I know? After all, I'm the man who chooses to live in the suburbs.

Best cellars: Five up-and-coming wines

2000 Buongiorno Argiolas, Sardinia (£4.49, Thresher, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up). I'm starting to change my mind about Italian whites. This Sardinian blend of Nuragas and Vermentino is the sort of stuff that could give Frascati a good name. (Well, better, anyway.) Full and flavoursome with a herbal, faintly nutty twist.

2000 Kiwi Cuvée Sauvignon Blanc, Vin de Pays du Jardin de la France (£4.99, Tesco). Cheeky old Tesco! This label is certain to wind them up in the Loire Valley, but I'm not too bothered myself. It is a super fresh, spritzy, abundantly nettley Sauvignon Blanc with a New Zealand-like undertone to it. As crisp as a poppadom.

1998 Domaine Le Cazal, Minervois (£4.99, Marks & Spencer). Frequently a source of some really good value reds, the Minervois has done it again with this perfumed, sun-kissed blend of Carignan, Grenache, Cinsault and Syrah. Spicy and concentrated with understated oak and tons of fruit.

1999 Santa Ines Merlot (£4.99, buy two save £1, Thresher, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up). This may or may not be Merlot (most Chilean 'Merlot' is Carmenère), but who's counting? It's a dark, almost opaque red with rich, chocolatey flavours, sweet tannins and a grassy, Cabernet Franc-like undertone. Super stuff.

2000 Domaine Gerovassiliou White, Epanomi (£6.49, Oddbins). Oddbins has an impressive line-up of Greek wines on its shelves. None more so than this amazing white, which tastes like a cross between a Meursault and a Condrieu. Soft and mellow with flavours of vanilla, apricots and cream.

 Tim Atkin has been shortlisted for the 2001 Lanson Awards for his work in Life magazine. Send your views to him at tim.atkin@observer.co.uk

Full and flavoursome with a herbal, faintly nutty twist. 2000 Kiwi Cuvée Sauvignon Blanc, Vin de Pays du Jardin de la France (£4.99, Tesco). Cheeky old Tesco! This label is certain to wind them up in the Loire Valley, but I'm not too bothered myself. It is a super fresh, spritzy, abundantly nettley Sauvignon Blanc with a New Zealand-like undertone to it. As crisp as a poppadom. 1998 Domaine Le Cazal, Minervois (£4.99, Marks & Spencer). Frequently a source of some really good value reds, the Minervois has done it again with this perfumed, sun-kissed blend of Carignan, Grenache, Cinsault and Syrah. Spicy and concentrated with understated oak and tons of fruit. 1999 Santa Ines Merlot (£4.99, buy two save £1, Thresher, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up). This may or may not be Merlot (most Chilean 'Merlot' is Carmenère), but who's counting? It's a dark, almost opaque red with rich, chocolatey flavours, sweet tannins and a grassy, Cabernet Franc-like undertone. Super stuff. 2000 Domaine Gerovassiliou White, Epanomi (£6.49, Oddbins). Oddbins has an impressive line-up of Greek wines on its shelves. None more so than this amazing white, which tastes like a cross between a Meursault and a Condrieu. Soft and mellow with flavours of vanilla, apricots and cream.  Tim Atkin has been shortlisted for the 2001 Lanson Awards for his work in Life magazine. fields.headline: Choi rider
fields.standfirst: Pak choi, choi sum, gaai choi... isn't it high time you turned over a new leaf?
fields.trailText: Pak choi, choi sum, gaai choi... isn't it high time you turned over a new leaf?
fields.body:
For one second, I thought I saw the shadow of a smile. A crack at the corner of her lips. At last an acknowledgment of my continued custom - 20 years now. But no. That is not the way they do business in London's Chinatown, with its baskets of strange greens and dangling ducks. I guess a surly grunt is preferable to an insincere 'Have a nice day.'

The greens arrive by truck, hugger-mugger in loose-weave reed baskets that could double as a laundry bin. Heads down, the shop staff machete the untidy green stems into shape, bring the leaves together into a uniform huddle then secure them with a rubber band. Neat, crisp, pert. The gardener Joy Larkcom describes them as 'the warp and woof of Chinese cookery'.

A little oval plate of steamed Chinese greens in oyster sauce interests me more than any other vegetable. Even asparagus. It could be the tender-stemmed and elegant choi sum, the purple-veined spinach or the fat, leafy bulbs of pak choi. Then again, the chef might have splashed his sizzling garlic, oyster sauce and shredded ginger over long, finger-thick stems of Chinese broccoli. A Chinese meal is never quite the same without that little battered dish, its well-worn edges and its steaming mound of 'greens in brown stuff'.

Pak choi, sometimes called baak choi, seems to me to be perhaps the perfect vegetable, having soft, melting leaves and plump stems bursting with juice. So there you are, stuffing the steaming leaves into your mouth, getting the hot sting of garlic and ginger and the deep savour of the oyster sauce, then - crunch - you bite into the chubby stems and the blistering juice squirts out. A sensational mouthful that makes our national dish of buttered broccoli look about as exciting as compost.

There are usually two sorts of pak choi on sale. A white-stemmed one with dark leaves and a pale green-stemmed one with softer leaves. Both are good. I am attempting to grow the latter in the garden this year.

Even better than pak choi is the same idea made with Chinese broccoli. The stems are like asparagus, tender but with some resistance. Now, we have been led to assume these platters of glistening greens are straight from the steamer. Yet anyone who has tried this will know that by the time the stems are al dente the leaves have turned the colour of a squashed frog. What you need to do is plunge the stems and their leaves into deep, furiously boiling water. I don't salt mine much, as most Asian bottled sauces are so jam-packed with the stuff that you are bound to overdo it. The quicker they cook the better.

Gaai choi is the loosely packed brassica with wavy leaves. As if someone has done an impression of Melvyn Bragg's hair with a cabbage. It keeps well and has a smart, mustardy bite. In fact, most shoppers know it as mustard cabbage. It needs a good wash. Aphids and grit like to snuggle down inside the folds of the stems.

This is where things get complicated. Even as a regular user of Asian shops, I get my Chinese broccoli mixed up with my Chinese flowering cabbage. Both have long green stems and leaves. Both have tight flowers bursting yellow. The flavour is not dissimilar. Eagle eyes will pick up that the cabbage has more pointed, shinier leaves and whiter stems. The broccoli, the vegetable I long more than any other to find in British greengrocers and markets, has more tenderness and softer leaves. Both are candidates for blanching or stir-frying.

Greens of any sort are comfortable with the knee-jerk seasonings of garlic, ginger and chilli, but I like them with lemon, too. If you are stir-frying, add some very finely shredded lemon grass to the garlic and ginger before you add the leaves. A good squirt from a lemon would do, too.

I honestly do not know why we don't grow these greens instead of our boring broccoli and pungent sprouts. The few specialists and keen amateurs who do, claim our weather is perfect for them. Many taste of mustard, too, a spice that seems part of the British soul. I must say I don't use them with fish - I don't think they work together - but their green heat is welcome with chicken, pork and beef, and they are fine on their own tossed with the garlic and ginger with which they sit so happily.

Chicken with choi sum and lemon grass

Enough for 1 as a main dish

250g boned free-range chicken meat
1 large, fat stalk of lemon grass (or 3 smaller supermarket ones)
2 fat, juicy garlic cloves
1 large knob of ginger, about the size of a golf ball
groundnut oil

for the greens

300g choi sum or Chinese broccoli 1 plump clove of garlic
groundnut oil
a small handful chopped coriander leaves

Cut the chicken into thin strips, about the thickness of a little finger. Put them into a bowl. Peel the outer leaves from the lemon grass and slice the more tender inner leaves into very fine rounds. Peel the ginger and finely crush it. Peel the ginger, too, then rub it on a very fine grater, so that you get a thick purée. Scrape it into the bowl with the chicken, the garlic and the sliced lemon grass. Drizzle over enough oil to moisten and toss the whole lot gently, then set aside for an hour or more.

Rinse the greens under running water, then tear into manageable lengths. Peel and finely chop the garlic. Get a wok hot, pour in a small pool of oil, let it smoke, then add the marinated chicken. There will be much splutter and pop. Let the chicken cook, without moving it, until the underside is golden brown. Now turn it over and cook the other side.

Lift the chicken out with a draining spoon or tongs. Toss the garlic into the wok, then before it burns, dump the greens, shaken free of any water, in with it. They will crackle and steam alarmingly. (If they don't, your wok wasn't hot enough). Turn them over in the hot oil for a minute or two until they wilt and the stems are tender.

Return the chicken and any escaped juices to the wok. Grind over some salt, chuck in the coriander and toss gently together. Serve while hot and sizzling.

Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce and ginger

In theory, this is a side dish. That is how it would be eaten in a Chinese restaurant. I am happy to eat it as a supper dish, piled on top of a bowl of rice. Enough for 2 as a side dish.

600g pak choi, choi sum or Chinese broccoli

for the sauce

1 knob of ginger about the size of a golf ball
2 large, juicy cloves of garlic
2 tbsp groundnut or vegetable oil
2 tbsp oyster sauce
1 tsp sesame oil

Rinse the greens, taking care to get every bit of grit out from the folds of the leaves. A brief soak in cold water is probably the best way. Peel the ginger and cut it into wafer-thin slices, then cut into matchstick-sized shreds. Peel the garlic and chop finely.

Fill a large pan with water, bring to a furious boil and salt lightly. Dunk the green on to the water and leave to boil till tender. I think they should have a bit of bite, too.

When the greens are within a minute or two of doneness, get a wok or frying pan really hot, then add the oil. As the oil starts to shimmer and lightly smoke, throw in the ginger and garlic. Quickly move the pan around so that the oil and aromatics swoosh around and up the sides. The garlic will colour in seconds - don't let it burn. Stir in the oyster sauce and the sesame oil and let it bubble briefly. Turn off the heat. Drain the greens, then add them to the sauce. Any drips of water left will simply help to correct the consistency of the sauce. Eat while the greens are still piping hot.

Stir-fried choi sum

Choi sum leaves are like spinach in that they cook down to nothing. What may seem like a misprint soon appears to shrivel down to the right amount. Enough for 1-2 as a side dish.

500g spinach, Chinese purple spinach or choi sum
2 tbsp groundnut oil
2 fat cloves of garlic
1 knob of ginger, the size of a walnut in its shell
1 medium-sized, hot, fresh red chilli
2 tbsp Chinese rice wine
1 tsp caster sugar
tsp salt

Remove the thickest of the stems from the choi sum - but leave the tender ones - or discard any coarse leaves from the spinach. Rinse thoroughly to remove any grit.

Peel the garlic and finely chop. Peel the ginger and shred finely, so that each piece is not thicker than a matchstick. Cut the chilli in half lengthways, remove the seeds if you wish (leave them in if you fancy something rather hotter), then slice very thinly.

Get your wok hot over a high flame, then add the oil. It will shimmer and maybe smoke slightly. Quickly scrape in the garlic and the ginger. Move them quickly round the pan, either by shaking the pan or with chopsticks. They will brown in seconds. Throw in the chilli. Now add the greens and stir-fry for one minute. In that time they should wilt and soften to a deep emerald green. Move them around quickly so that they do not burn. Slosh in the rice wine (or a drop of dry sherry, if that is what you have around), then sprinkle over the sugar and the salt. Don't be tempted to add less: they are an essential part of the recipe. Leave to bubble for a minute or two, then serve immediately.

fields.headline: Corinthian, Glasgow
fields.standfirst: Glasgow's Corinthian is gaudy, ghastly and over-elaborate. And that's just the clientele
fields.trailText: Glasgow's Corinthian is gaudy, ghastly and over-elaborate. And that's just the clientele.
fields.body:
Telephone: 0141 552 1101
Address: Corinthian, 191 Ingram Street, Glasgow.
Dinner for two, including wine and service, £75.

In the old days, the grand, imposing building on Glasgow's Ingram Street was where dodgy geezers went to be tried and sentenced for serious crimes such as larceny and murder. Today, reinvented as a veritable wining-and-dining complex called Corinthian, the old Sheriff's Court is now a place where the crimes are actually committed. Granted, bad cooking probably does not warrant a long stretch inside. But the offence of grievous bodily harm upon a lovely little sea bream really ought to carry with it some form of judicial penalty.

It was not what I had hoped for from Glasgow. The city has developed a fearsome reputation for its restaurants, which can only be secured now that an outpost of the Gordon Ramsay empire has pitched tent at One Devonshire Gardens. In theory, I was not spoiled for interesting places to try. In practice, it was a Sunday night and most of them were closed. In any case, for those interested in the bizarre excesses to which Britain's burgeoning restaurant business is prone, there was something irresistible about Corinthian. It is, for a start, the first restaurant I have seen advertised at an airport. There is a huge illuminated billboard - announcing its many bars and private rooms and members-only facilities - that is right in your face as you come off the shuttle from London.

But then there is nothing shy and retiring about Corinthian. The pillars are huge. The arches are wide. The ceilings are high and grand and carry every flounce and flourish you could wish for, plus enough gold to keep Tutankhamen happy. Indeed, the only thing wearing more gold than the ceiling was the clientele. Corinthian is flash.

The menu tries to be equally so, and that's where it falls down. This really is a remarkable setting. It's vivid and theatrical and, if you're looking for a special night out, vivid and theatrical is sometimes exactly what you want. Stefan King, the chap behind the conversion, should be congratulated for having the balls to do it. Now, though, he should turn his attention to the kitchen.

The problem is one of complete over-adornment. Just reading the list makes you dizzy. Take a starter of confit Cajun salmon. Confit salmon could be nice. Cajun salmon equally so. But both? Likewise a main-course dish advertised with both Thai spicing and Indian lime pickle displays a scatter-gun approach to the global larder.

I began with the most successful dish of the whole meal - what was described as a 'cassoulet' terrine of black pudding and ham hock. It was rich and unctuous and the white beans slipped in between the two other ingredients offered a calming influence. It was completely let down, however, by a pool of a grimly over-reduced meaty sauce, which stuck to the roof of my mouth. We would become very familiar with it before the night was out. My companion Steven, the Observer 's new Scotland editor, chose red mullet fillets on a tian of leeks with a red pepper sauce. It was fearsomely cold, and therefore completely tasteless, as if it had only just waved goodbye to the fridge.

After a long wait, during which we had a lot of time to admire the ceiling, our main courses were delivered and, before we could say anything, our waitress departed. We stared at the table. Something was definitely missing. It reminded me of the joke about the old Jewish guy who calls over the waiter and demands he try the soup. 'What's wrong with it,' says the waiter. 'Just try the soup,' says the man. 'But what's wrong with it?' The old man barks at him: 'Try the soup.' 'OK,' says the waiter. 'Where's the spoon?' The old man claps his hands with grim pleasure. 'Exactly,' he says.

There was no cutlery on our table. I looked for waiting staff, but the room is so big they were probably obscured by the curvature of the earth. Eventually we got up and nicked knives and forks off a table half a kilometre away. It was a bit of a pity we did, because it meant we could eat. Steven had ordered the roast duck breast. The meat was fine, served pink as he had requested, but it came on a lake of that appalling sauce which, in turn, was studded with unnecessary lumps of beetroot. This was a dish that simply did not work.

It was a veritable triumph next to mine: that roasted sea bream on curried noodles with a sauce vierge. I will admit I ordered it because it sounded terrible, but if it's on a menu it ought to be edible. The bream was over-seasoned and the tough and chewy noodles had been flavoured with something that tasted like it had come out of one of those packets you get in a pot noodle. That's not hyperbole. That really is what it reminded me of. Beneath the approximation of a vierge lay another river of that meat reduction, as if no dish was allowed out of the kitchen until the sauce guy had been allowed to screw it up. (Incidentally, if these were three different sauces, the effort was wasted, because they tasted the same to me.)

The mixed puddings that I tried were more successful, as in not offensive, being mostly ice creams and sorbets. Steven was less impressed with his macadamia-nut ice cream. 'It's like skiing at Aviemore,' he said. 'It promises snow but delivers ice.'

All of this wouldn't really matter so much if Corinthian was cheap. But, of course, it isn't. The fact is it costs an awful lot of money to over-gild the lily. They have to get it back somehow.

Contact Jay Rayner on jay.rayner@observer.co.uk.

fields.headline: Sex on a stalk
fields.standfirst: With their eye-catching colours and feminine curves, tulips transform the plainest beds into bejewelled borders
fields.trailText: With their eye-catching colours and feminine curves, tulips transform the plainest beds into bejewelled borders.
fields.body:
There is something in the form and detail of tulips that manages to be beautiful while being outrageously sexy. You cannot hide this in a cloak of horticulture or blind botany. From the first, men have lusted after tulips, ruined themselves for possession of them exactly as they have lusted after women. All the great courtesans were tulips. Cleopatra and Marilyn Monroe were tulips. The full curve of hip and buttock with tuck of waist is drawn in satin petals. The admiration is sexual more than aesthetic, and there is more than a touch of sexual ambiguity. The folded leaves around the swollen bud are vulval, yet at the same time they are overtly and precisely phallic, knowing no sexual boundaries. Tulips are our temple paintings, a celebration of beauty and sex decorously growing in the safety of the garden.

And every year I am surprised by them. I don't really trust the inevitability of them in the way that I do snowdrops, crocuses or daffodils striking the hours of the year as reliably as autumn rainfall. Then they do. But the exceptional thing about tulips is that although they are robust and regular, they never lose their regal intensity. I went to a wedding at a Sikh temple the other day and the bride was dressed in a fabulous ruby gown laced and decked with gold, her hands filigreed with henna - she was a walking 'Abu Hassan' or 'Keizerskroon'. Tulips raise the stakes, pitching the garden into the exotic from the more homely virtues of primroses, violets and daffodils.

Tulips come from the scorching hillsides of Turkey and Iran where the drainage is brutally sharp, the winters surprisingly harsh and dry. It is astonishing that they grow so well in our sodden climate - and doubly so in my own quagmire of a garden. We have a batch of 'Queen of the Night' in our herb beds, where the winter wet and odd bouts of frost have done for half a dozen rosemary bushes and reduced the sage to sorry rags, yet the tulips are back with a cocky vengeance, now in their fifth year.

'Queen of the Night' has a satiny purple head with plum-shaded depths balanced on a smoky green stem. In our garden she is juxtaposed against forget-me-nots and the new leaves of lovage, fennel coming through in her last week (she lasts for about two good weeks) and the emerging buds of the hornbeam hedge opening daily behind her. There are eight beds edged with box, and the tulips peak out above that frame. What works - I feel like a New Labour apparatchik talking about flowers 'working' - is that there is only one variety of tulip in this area. Mix'n'match and you diminish tulips utterly. You are as likely to mix tulips up together successfully as you are to get a good drink by sloshing half a dozen different great wines together.

What also works (I'm in the groove now) is the fresh lime green of the new growth. Most tulips look better against the backdrop of spring green. Many people have commented on the successful relationship between tulips and euphorbias, mainly because euphorbias such as E palustris, E polychroma and E amygdaloides purpurea all have intense acid-green 'flowers' as well as their spring foliage. In our spring garden, with its euphorbia backing band, we have 'Spring Green', a viridflora tulip with ivory petals and what the trade calls 'feathered green' - a soft green blaze along each petal. There are also some T sylvestris - bright yellow with pointy petals, all clean lines - and 'West Point', another lily-flowered tulip with primrose-yellow pointed petals.

Lining the lime walk are lily-flowered 'White Triumphator', their simplicity enhanced by the massed effect. Like all white flowers, they look best in shade. In our walled garden, all pastels and whites, we have 'Carnaval de Nice', a double latte and white, with a raspberry ripple splashed on it. I am not sure if I like it - but I'm happy to go on coming to a decision for a few years yet. And among the emerging cardoon leaves is 'negrita', a plum-coloured flower with rather thin leaves.

But it is the Jewel garden where most of the tulips are and, to be honest, we should have had a lot more. But our chronic inability to order things at the right time and then the ridiculousness of the wet just when they should have been planted did for the best-laid plans. Of all the flowers that grow, tulips are the most jewel like, both in intensity of colour and tone and in opulence.

Working for 10 years dressing women with jewels taught me how earrings or a brooch can lift and transform every stitch of clothing. Tulips have that effect on a border. There is 'Queen of Sheba', a burnished, Burmantoft red edged with orange. The other side of the main path is 'Abu Hassan', described in the catalogue as 'dark mahogany', which it isn't, but it does evoke that verbal struggle for richness. Like all triumph tulips, it is thick stemmed and ideal for cutting, although it is hard to take a single one from the garden. It makes sense to have a cutting area just for that purpose and to leave the border tulips well alone.

Then there are the parrots. The oddest thing about tulips is that they are most treasured in their aberrations. Diseased, misshapen, the tulips that really inspired market madness were the 'broken' ones - offspring of monochromatic tulips that have been infected with a virus spread by aphids, causing streaking and stippling of the petals. Growers have even used radiation on the bulbs to induce mutation, engineering freaks for the show. If tulips are a glorious celebration of sex, then the parrots rejoice in decadence. To me, a parrot tulip looks as though it has just been hit by a bullet, the petals flayed and ripped on the exit, but otherwise scarcely touched.

We have 'Blue Parrot', which is the colour of red paint water with a blue brush dipped in; 'Black Parrot', which is not black but instead the richest shade of burgundy. Opened out it is like a frosted portwine stain on a window. We also have 'Rococco', vermilion corrupted by a puckered scar of greeny blue, and 'Orange Favourite', which has green blotches and a yellow base and is, I am horrified to learn, possibly 'on its way out'. What can this mean? Why?

'Orange Artist' is a member of the viridiflora group and is among my favourite tulips of all, an orange flower streaked lividly with purplish, greenish grey on a thick chocolate stem. 'Princess Irene' is less showy, more orange streaked by a distinctly purple splash at the base of each petal. The freakiest of the lot is T acuminata, a species tulip with small petals like yellow and vermilion twists of paper, a flower on fire and although beautiful, curiously stripped of sex. You need the curves.

My roots: A week in Monty's garden

Like most people, over the Easter weekend I had my first sustained period in the garden this year. No rain, not much sun but four days of dry soil and the chance to busy and bury myself in it. That is as good as holidays get in my book. The swallows came back and the hedgerow leaves grew by the hour. The first tulips (sylvestris) flowered. The mown grass looked like lawn and not an attempt to cheat winter. It was light till past 8.30pm. I dream of all this through winter and

it never lets me down, gets better each year.

One of the things I like most about stretches in the garden is that I can enjoy mundane things such as mowing the grass, weeding, sweeping paths or giving the greenhouse a really good soak. Perhaps the measure of how much you love an activity is how boring the chores seem. In my own garden, there are no boring chores. But I did tackle a few bigger jobs.

One was to move all the red and white currants and most of the gooseberries from their existing position tucked away in a corner of the garden. For the past couple of years they have suffered dreadfully from sawfly, defoliating bushes in a matter of days. I do use pyrethrum, but reluctantly, and it is damage limitation rather than prevention or cure. So I dug a new piece of ground where the westerlies will rip into a sawfly before it can rip into the currant bushes. Our blackcurrants are looking very healthy this year. Last year the birds got the lot, so I have put all the currants together and will net them in due course.

We have been working in the Jewel garden, moving grasses that have got too big, rearranging, weeding, cutting back, putting in more box hedging - all without disturbing the tulips and alliums that are so important to it. It is getting late for this kind of work and would have been better done in the autumn, but it was too wet then and there has been no time until now.

Lest I appear too smug, I will admit to making the mistake of sowing mangetout peas in soil blocks (I grow all beans, peas and leaf crops in soil blocks now - it gives them a really good, slug-free start) and putting them under the mister in the greenhouse, trying to cheat a few days' start on the germination. But they all promptly rotted. However, I do have a good batch of 'Alderman' peas outside and I have replaced the mangetouts with another batch, this time in the dry.

Your roots: When to plant out your tulip bulbs

The best time to plant tulips is November, but make a list now from the ones you see and like. Put the order in late summer. We got most of ours from Peter Nyssen (0161 747 4000). I have left our tulips in the ground for the past few years. But if you lift the bulbs after the leaves have died back, you can plant the garden throughout the year without damaging dormant bulbs. Dry them on a rack or net and keep the large, healthy ones for replanting next year. Smaller bulbs can be grown in a special bed and planted in a few years.

fields.headline: Improved care for mothers promised
fields.trailText: Mothers-to-be will get better care during labour and more choice about how they give birth in a multi-million pound package of help for maternity services to be unveiled by health secretary Alan Milburn.
fields.body:
Mothers-to-be will get better care during labour and more choice about how they give birth in a multi-million pound package of help for maternity services to be unveiled by health secretary Alan Milburn.

Grim tales of women going into labour in overstretched, understaffed and dirty maternity wards have prompted ministers to act. They will promise more midwives to ensure one-to-one care during birth, "home from home" style wards in hospitals and more opportunities for a home birth for those who want it.

Milburn believes thousands of infants' lives courld be saved over the next decade by providing the best available care from conception onwards.

This week will signal a shift into pre-election mode, as Labour tries to put the welfare of children centre stage. The moves come as the National Family and Parenting Institute calls for the creation of a Ministry for the Family to help deal with the remaining "gaps, inconsistencies and inadequate help and provision" for parents.

Milburn's speech on Wednesday will be backed up by trade secretary Stephen Byers, who will launch a streamlining of maternity pay and leave, making it easier for small firms to administer. New screening services for expectatnt mothers will be launched tomorrow by junior health minister Yvette Cooper, herself pregnant. "What we are trying to ensure is that giving birth is as pleasant and as fulfilling an experience as it can be," said one source close to Milburn.

"It's important that women are offered more privacy, more support and that there isn't this medicalisation of pregnancy and childbirth. It's not an illness to have a baby."

Earlier this year, MPs warned that staff shortages meant women could not always have a midwife with them throughout labour, even though this reduced the risk of difficult births and of medical intervention. Yesterday the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists suggested a shortage of junior doctors threatened mothers' and babies' safety.

One key aim is to meet the government's target of reducing infant mortality. Two-thirds of deaths in the first year are linked to low birthweight and physical immaturity: better care in pregnancy, including advice about diet and smoking, could reduce these numbers.

Milburn will tell the Royal College of Midwives' annual conference in Torbay that maternity wards across Britain must match the standards of the best, He is expected to make it clear that women should not have to fight reluctant doctors to be allowed a home birth if it would be safe for them.

Help will be focused on low-income mothers, who are at higher risk of postnatal depression, while babies born to the poorest fathers weigh on averagle 130g less than those born to the richest.

fields.headline: Saturday might and workday mourning
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Last year the Times sought to catch up with the Telegraph. Now the Guardian - three magazines, three walloping tabloids, two broadsheets and more sections than you can count before breakfast - seems to be trying to gazump them both.
fields.body:
And so, with a mighty thump of newsprint on doormat, the battle for Saturday is renewed. Last year the Times sought to catch up with the Telegraph. Now the Guardian - three magazines, three walloping tabloids, two broadsheets and more sections than you can count before breakfast - seems to be trying to gazump them both. You can hear the familiar dinner party refrain already: 'Frankly, I mean ... who's got time to read all this'?

There's a simple answer to that. Some dozen or so years back, Saturday sales were the runts of most circulation litters. Then the truth of a changing society dawned. Sunday shopping, all-night shopping, four-day weeks, flexible working... The Saturdays that editors had grown up with had changed utterly. They had become about leisure as well as family chores. They were, in marketing-speak, the 'new Sunday' - with reading time to match.

Thus, on the sixth day, our dailies grew almost exponentially. The worst sales morning of the week became the best. Price resistance crumbled, too: you could add pennies as well as sections on Saturday and not notice a drop. Nor, significantly, did the second dinner party tune - the one about not needing a Sunday paper because there was so much left over to read from Saturday - appear to work in practice. Sunday sales held up stoutly. People who loved their papers didn't choose: they bought - nay, devoured - both.

A tale of triumph amid the gloom? Up to a point. If you put more of the right stuff in, you'll get more out. That works on Sundays with initiatives such as The Observer's new food and sports monthlies. It works on Saturdays with the Times's play listings and football handbooks. It will surely work again as the Guardian pours resources into its dramatically revamped and now glossy main mag. A fretful week for the Independent: those who offer least sell least. But our dailies and Sundays are not, of course, even stevens in this contest. A Sunday paper has only Sunday to worry about. A daily has to think of the long, increasingly dour stretch between Monday and Friday: and thereby hangs a less triumphant tale.

Look at last month's ABC figures. Only the FT, Star and Scotsman among the dailies are up year on year in the UK and Ireland, where most of these magazines and supplements are distributed. Some - like the Guardian - are holding pretty steady. Some - like the Times and Telegraph - are in slightly choppier seas. And those figures, remember, are averages for six-day publishing. If you sell, say, a quarter of a million extra on Saturday, that means your Monday-to-Friday sales are well below par. Your headline total, in short, depends on sustaining Saturday.

ABC doesn't break out Saturdays from the rest, so estimates are guesstimates: but the National Readership Survey does separate Saturdays, and you can gauge the difference. Add perhaps 400,000 readers for the more driving broadsheets and nearly a million of them for the Mail.

Is the glass, then, half empty or half full? Does it make more sense to pile resources into sustaining Saturdays or to worry about the lousiest weekdays (such as Fridays, cursed by the four-day week and the early rush to the country)? It's here, perhaps, that the Guardian move looks most interesting. Two magazines from Friday - The Editor , a briskly bouncy pull-together of the week, and Space, a design and property mag - have been rolled back into Saturday. The price of offering more on Saturday is offering a bit less on Friday.

This is a fundamental decision which competitors across the board (such as the Mirror) would agree with. Research, it's said, shows that the market for still more extra on Saturdays exists. It also shows that people don't feel they've got time for add-ons through stressed, fall-apart weekdays. In other words, you put your eggs in the most promising basket.

But for the dailies, those weekdays remain unadorned, a blight on growth or progress. If you can't add to cover their weakness, what can you do? The problem can be overstated: it creeps rather than rushes forward, and its impact varies from paper to paper. Nevertheless, the decline in home deliveries means a more fragmented sale through the week. Circulation falls aren't very often the result of a straight switch between titles, more a move from three-day purchase to two. New entrants such as the free Metros have left their mark. Most dismally of the lot, perhaps, the decline in women readers - the hidden factor behind so much woe - is stark through the week.

What to do? The logic of more on Saturday is also the logic of less in the working week. That may not mean simple downsizing, but developing a new pace and formula for dailies which existing readers may not relish. One answer - from the Telegraph - is subscription sales at a lesser rate, which encourage continuous purchase. But such wheezes come expensive. Fewer than 60% of Telegraph UK sales in March were made at full price; 300,000 depended on subscription bargains.

Plugging away on Saturday, then, is the only show in town. It has huge advantages. It brings dividends. It weakens the poorer players. It is a proven opportunity to reach the women (and their advertisers) that the rest of the week sometimes leaves behind. Thump goes the doormat. Do not, though, for a moment suppose that that's the end of story.

Does it make more sense to pile resources into sustaining Saturdays or to worry about the lousiest weekdays (such as Fridays, cursed by the four-day week and the early rush to the country)? It's here, perhaps, that the Guardian move looks most interesting. Two magazines from Friday - The Editor , a briskly bouncy pull-together of the week, and Space, a design and property mag - have been rolled back into Saturday. The price of offering more on Saturday is offering a bit less on Friday. This is a fundamental decision which competitors across the board (such as the Mirror) would agree with. Research, it's said, shows that the market for still more extra on Saturdays exists. It also shows that people don't feel they've got time for add-ons through stressed, fall-apart weekdays. In other words, you put your eggs in the most promising basket. But for the dailies, those weekdays remain unadorned, a blight on growth or progress. If you can't add to cover their weakness, what can you do? The problem can be overstated: it creeps rather than rushes forward, and its impact varies from paper to paper. Nevertheless, the decline in home deliveries means a more fragmented sale through the week. Circulation falls aren't very often the result of a straight switch between titles, more a move from three-day purchase to two. New entrants such as the free Metros have left their mark. Most dismally of the lot, perhaps, the decline in women readers - the hidden factor behind so much woe - is stark through the week. What to do? The logic of more on Saturday is also the logic of less in the working week. That may not mean simple downsizing, but developing a new pace and formula for dailies which existing readers may not relish. One answer - from the Telegraph - is subscription sales at a lesser rate, which encourage continuous purchase. But such wheezes come expensive. Fewer than 60% of Telegraph UK sales in March were made at full price; 300,000 depended on subscription bargains. Plugging away on Saturday, then, is the only show in town. It has huge advantages. It brings dividends. It weakens the poorer players. It is a proven opportunity to reach the women (and their advertisers) that the rest of the week sometimes leaves behind. Thump goes the doormat. Do not, though, for a moment suppose that that's the end of story.

fields.headline: 'Big Brother' goes into the classroom
fields.trailText: Channel 4 is to put cameras into classrooms for a major  Big Brother  style internet broadcast.
fields.body:
It will portray life in the classroom as it really is. Channel 4 is to put cameras into classrooms for a major Big Brother style internet broadcast.

Michael Jackson, C4's chief executive, said Real Teachers, as part of 4 Learning, would help fulfil the channel's public service remit because it would enable new teachers to learn from colleagues. 'Big Brother in the classroom is a good way of putting it,' he said yesterday.

But plans for the project, to be broadcast later this year, have been criticised by the National Confederation of Parent Teachers Associations. It was concerned for the privacy of the children involved and warned the site could attract paedophiles.

Paul Ashton, C4 commissioning editor for schools and special projects, who is a former teacher, said measures had been taken to protect pupils. 'It is a very beautiful and simple idea and we have consulted educational groups including the PTA and the Teacher Training Agency.

'The live webcam section will be password protected. Only bona fide teachers and people like Ofsted inspectors will have the password.'

Margaret Morrissey, of the NCPTA, was unconvinced. She said: 'If people can gain access to American government computers then they can certainly work out how to get into a Channel 4 website. We have to be extremely concerned for children's privacy. Paedophiles are mentally ill people who spend their lives trying to gain access to children.

'What happens if they recognise a child on the site and are able to put a name to a face as well as the school? I accept that there is only a small chance of this happening - but it only needs to happen once.'

Ashton said that Channel 4 already makes some money from sponsors for its Homework High website, where teachers answer questions and pupils can access a library of 48,000 responses.

The first schools to take part will be secondaries, but the hope is to recruit at least one primary school.

Hazlewood Integrated School in north Belfast is one of two schools now taking part in the pilot project, which is due to launch in September.

Headteacher Noreen Campbell said she was pleased to be taking part in Real Teachers because it would help newly-trained teachers. 'We consider ourselves an open organisation and we welcome observation. It was discussed at governor level and we agreed there was much to be gained from the project provided safeguards, in terms of issues of access to the internet, were guaranteed.'

Dr Seamus Quinn is the science teacher whose classroom is being filmed. He said: 'At first the children thought it was like Big Brother and they played up to it but now they ignore it. People are surprised at how well-behaved they are, but of course we aren't perfect.'

Ashton aims to recruit a further 22 schools which will use the live webcams. The site will also contain videos of teachers who do not wish to be filmed live, and a library of lesson plans.

fields.headline: It's Cold War up North
fields.standfirst: If Hague loves Yorkshire why is he backing a Star Wars plan that would make it a nuclear target?
fields.trailText: If Hague loves Yorkshire why is he backing a Star Wars plan that would make it a nuclear target? And why any anarchist deaths on May day won't be accidental.
fields.body:
The British political class adores America. Like a sad old man who fears his young wife will seek her pleasures elsewhere, our élite will give the United States whatever she wants if she will only massage the fragile national ego. ('Say our relationship is special, really, really special. Say it! Now say it as if you mean it! ') Lindis Percy - a radical pacifist midwife and grandmother - is less enchanted. As a peace campaigner, she protests outside US bases. As a citizen, she asks by what legal authority America occupies British territory?

It's a good question. The 1945 Labour Government handed land to America without public and Parliamentary debate and without a treaty specifying reciprocal obligations. A Whitehall briefing note from the Treasury Solicitor, which Percy found in public records, confirmed what everyone suspected: RAF officers at the bases and, by extension, their elected masters in Westminster have no power to stop the Americans launching operations which are against Britain's national interest.

Percy has been arrested and jailed many times for her curiosity. Last week she was on trial at Harrogate Magistrates' Court. Her crime was to have protested outside 'RAF' Menwith Hill - which is, in fact, the 13th Field Station of the US National Security Agency. She had draped a Stars and Stripes on the road outside. On it she had written 'George W. Bush... oh dear'. A military vehicle went over the flag, and the driver, the Ministry of Defence Police maintained, became the victim of 'a racially motivated crime' (proving once again that political correctness is an authoritarian conservative's dream).

Her racism took a terrible toll on the American. 'He was quite visibly distressed to drive over his national emblem, which he holds particularly dear,' the prosecutor, Gregor Purcell, told the court. I would have thought that if you're a soldier of a foreign power working in a colonial outpost, you should be a little less precious. Judge Peter Nuttall may have thought the same. In any event, he cleared Percy on Friday.

The questions she raises won't go away as easily. Menwith Hill, near the Yorkshire Dales, and a second US base, 'RAF' Fylingdales on the North Yorkshire Moors, are essential elements of George W Bush's plans to build the 'son of Star Wars' defence against ballistic missiles.

No one near power in Britain supports Star Wars - apart from William Hague and Iain Duncan Smith, who are little more than displaced American nationalists (and whose closeness to power is debatable to say the least). Whitehall has always maintained that defence policy must uphold multilateralism, not unilateralism; that nuclear weapons are a deterrent; and that anyone who disagrees is some kind of traitor undermining patriots' efforts to defend the country they love.

In 1994 Tony Blair proved he was fit to join respectable society when he told his party conference that, whatever delegates said, the next Labour administration would support deterrence and multilateral disarmament. The odd Leftist cried 'betrayal' - Blair had once been a member of CND. But with the Cold War over, the leader could argue that multilateralism would bring a safer world. Russia could be persuaded to decommission her dangerously unstable warheads and prevent the export of nuclear technology. The Chinese military could be calmed. The terrifying possibility of an arms race between India and Pakistan could be averted.

The Americans are destroying all his hopes and shredding Establishment certainties which had flourished for half a century. Deterrence theory holds that if you have nuclear weapons no enemy will launch a nuclear attack for fear of a terrible reprisal. Bush needs the electronic eavesdropping technology at Menwith Hill and Fylingdales to track ballistic missiles and shoot them down before they reach the US. America can attack without fear of retaliation. Multilateralism is based on honouring international treaties. Bush will unilaterally renounce the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, the cornerstone of nuclear arms control, as he develops Star Wars.

As for love of country, the Yorkshire of the moors, dales and Bettys Café Tea Rooms, which Hague claims to love, will become a target for any enemy of the United States. If the Americans were to shoot down a missile over Britain, it wouldn't disappear like a blip on a computer game, but shower the country with radioactive debris. You need to have an intense dislike of the British in general and Yorkshiremen in particular to contemplate going along with Bush.

The Foreign Office and Ministry of Defence are worried sick that Russia and China will be pushed into militarism and xenophobia. The generals say that Bush's attempts to sell the idea to his allies by pretending Star Wars can protect Western Europe are ludicrous: it's too expensive and can't be made to work.

But Blair refuses to be a patriot. He will not tell the Americans that Britain will not allow its hospitality to be abused. Desperate Ministers have told me in apparent seriousness that they expect the planning departments of Harrogate Council and the North Yorkshire Moors National Park Authority to enter the world of international diplomacy in the PM's place and prevent the Americans expanding Menwith Hill and Fylingdales.

Last month Harrogate Council considered a planning application to install battery-charging houses at RAF Menwith Hill. They will power the Space-Based Infra Red System the Americans will use to identify warheads. The objections of 200 people weren't considered, and elected councillors didn't debate the application. That bogus 'RAF' in RAF Menwith Hill has its uses. The base is on Crown Land and it is a Royal prerogative of the Crown to exempt itself from democratic scrutiny. Monarchical Britain's archaic constitution and the interests of the American Republicans suit each other well. 'We have no control,' said a council spokeswoman. 'There's nothing we can do to stop them.'

Harold Best, the Labour MP for Leeds North West, took the last available option. He wrote to Geoff Hoon, and asked the Defence Secretary to open up the secret process by holding a public inquiry into the expansion of Menwith Hill. Hoon and Best are old friends. Hoon forgot their friendship and decided it would be politic in this instance to ignore the request.

Tony Blair likes to project himself as a strong leader rather than a pathetic old man. But to hang on to America's affections, he is prepared to reverse the U-turn he made in 1994 and leave the defence of deterrence, multilateralism and patriotism to Lindis Percy. Cynics say that politicians always break their promises. But Blair is in a league of his own. He's betrayed his betrayal.

Time to arrest this development

The May day 'riots' of last year weren't riots at all. They were an undoubted success for the police. No one was hurt. Most of the 7,000 or so demonstrators were peaceful, and officers never lost control of the few who weren't.

The protest would have been remembered for the gentle wit of anti-capitalist marchers who dug up the lawn in Parliament Square and planted pot plants, were it not for a tiny detail. The triumph of crowd management was marred when some berk sprayed slogans on the Cenotaph. Reality was overtaken by images of disgusting revolutionaries getting away with dishonouring the memory of the dead.

If a war memorial had been painted in the provinces, few would have noticed. But the graffiti was in the backyard of editors and broadcasters. They ignored the Met's successes and condemned officers for their flabby permissiveness.

It is scarcely original to say that image matters more than substance. But then Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, is scarcely an original man. In the past few days, Stevens and the press have egged each other on like bullies preparing themselves to thrash the living daylights out of their target.

'Anarchist fanatics plan to bring mayhem to Oxford Street on May Day, police warned' (the Mirror ). 'Sir John Stevens urged law-abiding demonstrators to stay well clear of disturbances by "violent extremists"' (the Mail ). 'A thousand hardcore protesters plan to spread violence across London during anti-capitalism demonstrations on May Day, Scotland Yard warned' (the Express ). 'Anarchists plotting May Day mayhem have been training at American action camps, police said yesterday. Up to 50 British extremists are thought to have been on courses to learn urban guerrilla tactics for causing disruption' (the Mirror again).

Listen to the language - 'militants', 'urban guerrillas', 'extremists' and (very modern) 'hardcore' - and look at the 'wanted' pictures on the news pages. Good policing is calm and proportionate. Good officers know that 'zero tolerance' can be dangerous intolerance and concentrate on the basics of preventing crime and preserving order.

I've no doubt that some protesters would welcome a fight, but what we're hearing from Stevens and his new friends in the press is menacing and hysterical. Officers on duty will be wound-up like springs, as will their adversaries. If there are anarchist deaths, they won't be accidental.

fields.headline: People's peers disgrace democracy
fields.standfirst: Last week's appointments to the House of Lords confirm the contempt New Labour has shown for truly democratic principles
fields.trailText: Last week's appointments to the House of Lords confirm the contempt New Labour has shown for truly democratic principles.
fields.body:
Nothing more betrays the hollowness of New Labour's claim to be 'new' than its attitude towards reforming the state and its equivocation about democracy and the sanctity of the public realm. It just doesn't get it. Beyond a group of disillusioned intellectuals, it thinks, nobody cares about voting, accountability or the shape of the constitution.

The national belly-laugh at the House of Lords' Appointments Commission's announcement of 15 new peers should begin to disabuse it. The patronising view that ordinary people have no interest in the hows and whys of their constitution has been punctured. These aren't people's peers; they are from exactly the same pool of great and good who have been occupying the red benches as life peers for the past 40 years.

It wasn't meant to be like this. The commission is independent. It canvassed the country for applications. It has five criteria for selection for a peerage - independence, commitment to high standards in public life, a record of achievement, capacity to contribute to debates and the spare time to attend them - that seem reasonable. The peers to be produced by this rational process would be obviously superior either to the old hereditaries or party hacks.

But the ill-judged aside of Lord Stevenson, chairman of the commission, that 'the human being should feel comfortable in the House of Lords', gave the game away. What is at issue, as Tom Paine, writing 200 years ago, saw more clearly than any other critic of the British constitution, is a structure and culture in which our governors still function as a class above the governed.

As Paine put it, the invading Normans constructed a constitution that allowed the new French-speaking barons to deliberate and then do what they wanted to the subject English. That was the way the system essentially operated in 1800. Universal suffrage and the veneer of modern democracy have been bolted on to the same structures, so that much of what Paine inveighed against is still alive.

For excellence and career achievement, along with feeling at home on the red benches, are utterly inadequate criteria for becoming a national legislator. I'm sure that Sir John Browne, chief executive of BP, or Professor Susan Greenfield, director of the Royal Institution, will make wise and considered interventions in those debates where their expertise will be welcome. But the Lords could have availed itself of their wisdom without making them full-time legislators. It could easily and simply have asked them to become full-time members of its select committees or to give evidence on legislation.

But the solution that has been adopted means that because the newly appointed peers have a track record of achievement in one area, they have the right of voting and speaking in all areas - from asylum-seekers to fox-hunting - despite the fact they are accountable to nobody for how they vote.

This is an impossible principle to defend. Arguments that elections might be dangerous because turnout could be low, that the intake might be unpredictable, that the Lords will gain a legitimacy to rival the Commons and that party point-scoring will replace the considered tone of the Lords are spurious. They are dangers that have to be guarded against, but they cannot obstruct the basic position. In a democracy, legislators must be accountable to the people.

Indeed, the proposition is even larger than that, a point well understood by Paine and his contemporaries in enlightenment Europe, who were delightedly shrugging off centuries of rule by monarch and church. Any community needs a functioning and efficient public realm where argument can be freely made, political support marshalled and those who make decisions can be held to account by those for whom they are made. The eighteenth- and nineteenth-century constitution builders in Europe and the US did no more than try to construct a political architecture that could permit the expression of an accountable public realm, in which democracy and citizenship were key components.

Britain has never tried self-consciously to build a constitution that entrenched and succoured the public interest. The political class has always taken the view that the constitution, designed by the Normans and amended by successive generations, is pretty much unimprovable. But the consequences of this failure are all around. We may not care much that we have the fewest elected officials per thousand of population of most democracies, but more worrying is our lack of commitment to the principle of voting and, beyond that, to an idea of a public sphere. Our spatchcock constitutional arrangements suffuse our public culture, and that culture itself is compromised by our lack of faith in a conception of 'publicness'.

So it is that 3,166 people filled in the form to become a peer, thinking that nothing could be more normal than becoming a legislator via a university-type admissions system. So it is that we do not have the constitutional template properly to entrench the independence of a public corporation like the BBC. In our constitutional system, the public realm is the Crown in Parliament which controls all it surveys; there can be no true independence for anything within its embrace.

So it is that the Government has constructed Private Finance Initiatives and Public Private Partnerships without ever, until being challenged by Ken Livingstone, thinking carefully what the constitution of such arrangements might be that would entrench and safeguard the public interest.

And even the concession that a PPP might have public-interest 'partnership' directors has been squeezed grudgingly from a disinterested Government. And so it is that even the principle of universal taxation has just been breached, with the Government conceding that business can choose what tax it pays instead of local authorities having the right to charge a supplementary business rate. We are back to pre-Civil War England.

The hope was that when New Labour took office and launched its constitutional reform programme that it understood this was the means to the greater end, renewing and so reclaiming Britain's battered public realm.

We were wrong. New Labour had no such ambition. But as the laughter over people's peers reverberates, maybe it will learn. If it wants fewer such cock-ups, it should understand the spirit of the times.

But the solution that has been adopted means that because the newly appointed peers have a track record of achievement in one area, they have the right of voting and speaking in all areas - from asylum-seekers to fox-hunting - despite the fact they are accountable to nobody for how they vote. This is an impossible principle to defend. Arguments that elections might be dangerous because turnout could be low, that the intake might be unpredictable, that the Lords will gain a legitimacy to rival the Commons and that party point-scoring will replace the considered tone of the Lords are spurious. They are dangers that have to be guarded against, but they cannot obstruct the basic position. In a democracy, legislators must be accountable to the people. Indeed, the proposition is even larger than that, a point well understood by Paine and his contemporaries in enlightenment Europe, who were delightedly shrugging off centuries of rule by monarch and church. Any community needs a functioning and efficient public realm where argument can be freely made, political support marshalled and those who make decisions can be held to account by those for whom they are made. The eighteenth- and nineteenth-century constitution builders in Europe and the US did no more than try to construct a political architecture that could permit the expression of an accountable public realm, in which democracy and citizenship were key components. Britain has never tried self-consciously to build a constitution that entrenched and succoured the public interest. The political class has always taken the view that the constitution, designed by the Normans and amended by successive generations, is pretty much unimprovable. But the consequences of this failure are all around. We may not care much that we have the fewest elected officials per thousand of population of most democracies, but more worrying is our lack of commitment to the principle of voting and, beyond that, to an idea of a public sphere. Our spatchcock constitutional arrangements suffuse our public culture, and that culture itself is compromised by our lack of faith in a conception of 'publicness'. So it is that 3,166 people filled in the form to become a peer, thinking that nothing could be more normal than becoming a legislator via a university-type admissions system. So it is that we do not have the constitutional template properly to entrench the independence of a public corporation like the BBC. In our constitutional system, the public realm is the Crown in Parliament which controls all it surveys; there can be no true independence for anything within its embrace. So it is that the Government has constructed Private Finance Initiatives and Public Private Partnerships without ever, until being challenged by Ken Livingstone, thinking carefully what the constitution of such arrangements might be that would entrench and safeguard the public interest. And even the concession that a PPP might have public-interest 'partnership' directors has been squeezed grudgingly from a disinterested Government. And so it is that even the principle of universal taxation has just been breached, with the Government conceding that business can choose what tax it pays instead of local authorities having the right to charge a supplementary business rate. We are back to pre-Civil War England. The hope was that when New Labour took office and launched its constitutional reform programme that it understood this was the means to the greater end, renewing and so reclaiming Britain's battered public realm. We were wrong. New Labour had no such ambition. But as the laughter over people's peers reverberates, maybe it will learn. If it wants fewer such cock-ups, it should understand the spirit of the times.

fields.headline: Has this been a term of endearment?
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's government has made history. What it has yet to demonstrate is the capacity to change the country's destiny
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's government has made history. What it has yet to demonstrate is the capacity to change the country's destiny.
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the year
fields.body:
A week is a long time in politics; 48 months is an eternity. Four years ago this Wednesday, Tony Blair stood before the black door on his sun-dappled first day in office. 'Enough of talking,' said the man of action. 'It is time now to do.' Strip off the hype which has gushed from Number 10 ever since; blow away the froth of the daily headlines. How has his government actually done? Let us try, as clinically as is possible, to assess the performance of New Labour.

The starter test of any government, I would suggest, is that it is reasonably accomplished at governing. This sounds an undemanding hurdle, but it is a first fence many previous governments have failed to surmount. The Blair government has made serious, self-inflicted mistakes - the Millennium Dome blasts them still. The unexpected has come close to blowing them over. Foot and mouth has not been - I am being charitable - a textbook example of how to handle an emergency. The Government teetered on the lip of the abyss during last autumn's fuel protests. It is natural that we should curse their blunders more than we offer credit for the mistakes they have avoided. But the Blair government has eschewed perpetrating any spectacular errors.

The novices to red boxes who took office four years ago have broadly run a competent government. Its life has been punctuated by crises, which have been invariably generated not by dissident backbenchers or off-message Ministers, but erupted from the inner core of the regime. There have been gripping soap operas, none more so than the double resignations of Peter Mandelson. But the damage done has been to the actors, not to the country at large. There has not been the economic calamity or civil crisis which destroys governments and wrecks countries.

The Blair government has not inflicted upon us a Suez, a Three Day week or a Winter of Discontent. There has not been the vicious social conflict of the inner-city riots and the miners' strike in the Eighties. There has not been anything approaching the ruinousness of Thatcher's poll tax or Major's Black Wednesday. Just by being reason ably adept at ruling, the Blair administration is lifted above the average run of postwar governments.

The next test of any government is whether it has been true to its promises. Generally, the soi-distant People's Prime Minister has fulfilled the rather low expectations the people had of him. Blair was elected on a paradoxical prospectus. The subtext of his campaign was: everything is appalling; we will change it very slowly. The Conservatives may have left office in May 1997, but their term of power did not properly end until just two years ago, when Gordon Brown finally released the Government from the Tory spending corset. Transformed schools and hospitals await realisation. If not delivered in the second term, the punishment of the electorate may be terrible.

Blair's most reckless pledge was to restore faith in public life. Back on May Day 1997, even the most cynical observer did not anticipate they would have quite so much sleaze in them. In other respects, this government has delivered more than it promised. The last manifesto pledged nothing about child benefit - it has actually risen by 25 per cent. They did not claim to be able to create full employment, yet they have achieved that historic goal of Labour.

Any set of rulers with an eye on claiming a large place in posterity must aspire to be more than competent deliverers. The superior rank of government is occupied by those which make changes lasting beyond their lifetime. It is not conceivable that the Conservatives could unravel devolution to Scotland and Wales, an aspiration of progressive governments dating back to Gladstone.

One of the ironies of Blair is that, for all his relentless emphasis on the modern, his bigger achievements have been based on ambitions set by long-dead predecessors. A settlement in Ireland has eluded every premier since the nineteenth century. The minimum wage was a Labour goal when Keir Hardie founded the party. The Tories have been compelled to accept it, just as they have been forced to support independence for the Bank of England. This government could come to a full stop today - and would leave enduring legacies.

There are other elements of the Blair record which the Right accepts because they are as amazed as many on the Left are disgusted that they have been enacted by a Labour government.

Which takes us to my next test of a government: has it permanently altered the framework of political choice? The verdict here is mixed. With a little help from the grisly pantomime that is William Hague's Conservative Party, New Labour commands the centre ground and swathes of territory on both flanks. Harold Wilson's unrequited dream of making Labour 'the natural party of government' is closer to realisation by Tony Blair than under any previous Labour Prime Minister.

But he has achieved it more by following the consensus than by challenging the status quo. His government has pandered to illiberality more often than it has confronted prejudice. It has become a little less bashful about making the case for the active state and a fairer society, but remains coy of full candour.

Since the Third Way was giggled to death, it has become ever clearer that this is a government which moves by inches rather than leaps. There is nothing intrinsically wrong with that: small steps, provided there are enough of them, can take you on a long journey.

Baby bonds are an eyecatching device to give the poor an asset stake in society. But this is the safest sort of radicalism. The first beneficiaries of the scheme will not come into possession of their modest endowments until Mr Blair is eligible for his pension. He, Gordon Brown, David Blunkett and Alistair Darling, along with the Institute for Public Policy Research and the Fabian Society, all claim paternity over baby bonds. When one good notion has to be spread around four Cabinet Ministers and two think tanks, it tells us that New Labour is not bursting with bold and innovatory ideas.

This brings me to the last and most demanding test. The outstanding governments are those which alter the country's destiny. The project to secure the exclusion of the Conservatives from power for a generation has withered as Blair's enthusiasm for changing the Westminster voting system has shrivelled. In terms of the private goals he set for his premiership, the most evident failure has been Europe. Towards Europe as a whole, and towards the single currency especially, public opinion is more aggressively hostile than ever.

The greatest wrangling between the Prime Minister and the Chancellor about the next manifesto is not over what it says about tax, but about the warmth of the phraseology towards the single currency. The fiercest struggle about that is within Mr Blair himself. Will he hedge his self-perceived destiny with deadening qualifications or will he articulate the belief that his epochal role is to make Britain a fully engaged partner in Europe?

The Blair government has demonstrated that it can make history. Only in its second term will we discover whether it has the capacity to change the future.

webTitle: Tax break row engulfs Tory donor

fields.headline: Tax break row engulfs Tory donor
fields.standfirst: Anger as front-bench MPs seek to ease levy on spread betting companies
fields.trailText: Anger as front-bench MPs seek to ease levy on spread betting companies.
fields.body:
Leading Conservatives in William Hague's Treasury team are seeking to change new tax laws in a way which would directly benefit a businessman who has donated millions of pounds to the party.

In a move which brought immediate calls for an inquiry into how rich donors influence politics, three members of the Tory front bench have laid down amendments to the Budget which would cut the amount of tax paid by spread betting firms.

Stuart Wheeler, chairman of the country's biggest such firm, IG Index, donated £5 million to the Tory party last January. It was the biggest single donation to any party.

Wheeler said at the time that he was seeking 'no influence' over party policy, although he had met Hague and party chairman Michael Ancram for discussions on various issues. Ancram described the donation as a 'most generous and valuable contribution'.

The amendments were proposed last Thursday by Tory MPs Richard Ottaway, Howard Flight and James Clappison, and will now be debated by the Commons committee scrutinising the Finance Bill. They propose that taxes on financial spread betting - which lets people bet on the movement of City prices - should be cut by 1 per cent and that those on sporting spread betting should fall by 2 per cent.

The amendments also call for changes in the way the taxes are calculated, which would reduce tax liabilities for spread betting firms. If they are successful, IG Index would save more than £1m a year in taxes, said a spokesman for the company.

'This is extraordinary,' said James Plaskitt, a Labour MP and a member of the influential Treasury Select Committee which scrutinises the work of Gordon Brown's department. 'The biggest spread bookmaker of all is Stuart Wheeler, the man who gave the Conservatives more than £5m, and here we find three Tory MPs putting down amendments which would reduce the tax his firm pays and increase their profits. I will be calling on the select committee to look into it.'

Ottaway, who is leading the push for the Budget changes, met the Spread Betting Association last week before proposing the amendments. There are only five association members, and IG Index is one of the leading ones.

The company spokesman agreed that the proposed changes exactly mirror what the association wants. There is no suggestion that Wheeler himself was involved in lobbying to change the tax rules.

When the amendments were introduced, other members of the Commons committee raised concerns that there was a conflict of interest. Former Labour Ministers Peter Kilfoyle and Tony Banks questioned the Tories' motives.

Ottaway denied the donation had had any influence on Tory policy, saying he had proposed the amendments because of the powerful arguments put to him. 'I have never met Mr Wheeler and I have never spoken to him,' he said. 'Central Office never rang me about this issue.'

The IG Index spokesman said: 'There is no connection between the two issues. The donation was a personal one, not a company one.'

The news comes at a difficult time for Hague and Shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo. This week Sam Younger, head of the Electoral Commission, the independent body which scrutinises party funding, will publish the first lists of party donors, putting the issue of cash and politics under fresh scrutiny.

In an interview with The Observer, carried out before details of the amendments emerged, Younger said he would launch an inquiry after the election into millionaire donors and the influence they have on politics. He said the commission would consider proposals for a cap on donations.

Labour has also been criticised for accepting multi-million pound donations. In January the party was bounced into revealing that three individuals - publisher Lord Hamlyn, author Christopher Ondaatje and Government Minister Lord Sainsbury - had each donated £2m.

'I am sure the issue of a cap on donations is going to remain a live one,' Younger said. 'It is clear in that flurry of debate in January about the large donations to both Labour and the Conservatives that there will remain legitimate public concern that, whatever the transparency, if someone gives a large amount of money to a party it gives them and their interests a privileged consideration.

'It is hard to get away from that however much a party argues that it is not the case. You are not going to get rid of the suspicion, and that's why we have to look at it again.'

IG Index has been lobbying to get the new tax rules changed. It claims taxes will hit spread betting firms harder than high street betting shops because they are in a riskier market.
