webTitle: Scotland comment: Kill quangos? Don't be silly

fields.headline: Kill quangos? Don't be silly
fields.trailText: The dictum of S.J. Perelman - 'I believe in giving a man the handlebars and letting him ride the bicycle' - implies that if he falls off it's his own fault. It is not a principle being applied by Ministers of the Scottish Executive.
fields.body:
The dictum of S.J. Perelman - 'I believe in giving a man the handlebars and letting him ride the bicycle' - implies that if he falls off it's his own fault. It is not a principle being applied by Ministers of the Scottish Executive.

The fiasco over the appointment of Rod Lynch as Scotland's new tourist supremo has found them in a mode that is becoming all too familiar - fixing blame firmly on the relevant quango. It is alleged that the tourist board did not tell Ministers that Mr Lynch had a job which he couldn't give up and which looked a little more than part-time. This would strain the credulity of the most gullible observer, especially since it seems a Minister was on the selection panel.

Henry McLeish has promised to make a bonfire of the quangos but their usefulness to Ministers is such that they are bound to survive in considerable quantities. They are, of course, a means of patronage, of throwing a bone to old friends who have fallen on hard times.

I once interviewed a Tory chairman of a hospital board which had encountered a misfortune so severe that Ministers had thrown him to the wolves. Still angry over what he regarded as a forced and unfair resignation, he threatened to take his revenge by making embarrassing disclosures but then he growled: 'If they give me a wee quango I'll be quite content.'

But the chief value of the quango is that it allows Ministers to evade responsibility. We saw the same syndrome in the exams fiasco - odd how this word keeps cropping up - last year. And when, earlier this month, Jack McConnell announced a new executive team for the Scottish Qualifications Authority, the unworthy thought instantly crossed my mind that the Minister was making contingency plans to ensure that the scapegoats were in place should anything go wrong this year.

Perhaps the development was inevitable because the culture of blame is part and parcel of our confrontational politics, from which the new Edinburgh Parliament, despite hopes that it would be more consensual, has not yet departed. Opposition parties continue to call for ministerial resignations over trifles as well as larger failures. It is not surprising that Ministers should have developed a variety of evasive strategies. If Oppositions had not devalued the currency of resignation, then Ministers might be able take the blame without having inevitably to commit political hara-kiri.

Despite the perception of some of our hyperventilating newspapers that the tourism affair shows the Executive to be in a state of almost comical disarray, with warring Ministers running around like headless chickens, there are more hopeful signals that our new system is beginning to settle in.

Ross Finnie has handled the foot-and-mouth crisis in Scotland with a quiet and consistent authority which contrasts with the swings and shifts of his English counterpart, Nick Brown. It is even rumoured that the model of a rural affairs ministry will be adopted in England after the election, though Mr Finnie's bailiwick includes potentially conflicting interests such as agriculture and the environment.

The Italians are studying the Scottish devolutionary settlement to see if it can help them resolve their regional tensions. The campaign for English regional devolution is beginning to make a real impact, exploiting the universal perception in England that Scotland gets an unfair slice of the cake. We are at the beginning of a longer constitutional journey.

And an opinion poll in yesterday's Scotsman reports that Scots feel more patriotic than ever before. Four-fifths feel more Scottish than British. It is to the credit of the SNP that such sentiments do not necessarily conflict with the idea of a multicultural society.

At least some of this new confidence must flow from having our parliament. It has ended the culture of grievance which blamed London for all our troubles. When there are storms, at least most of them take place in home waters.

webTitle: Does Ken's first year amount to pigeon feed?

fields.headline: Does Ken's first year amount to pigeon feed?
fields.standfirst:
One year on, London's Mayor is as popular as ever, but the champagne is far from flowing

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: One year on, London's Mayor is as popular as ever, but the champagne is far from flowing.
fields.body:
Helen Mirren thinks he's 'wonderful'; the restaurateur Sir Terence Conran considers him mature; even pigeon-feed vendor Bernard Rayner who was furious with Ken Livingstone, has now settled out of court.

The initial verdict on the Mayor of London's first year in charge seems to be a rosy one: he barely needs the services of Joy Johnson, the new spin doctor who was appointed last week.

Yet the champagne will not be flowing this Friday. With a major London Underground strike and May Day chaos predicted this week, celebrations would seem inappropriate.

Livingstone's frustration with the limitations of his job may also help take the shine off this anniversary.

Trouble is looming over his plans next month to issue Londoners with a glossy report on his first year's performance, including a mayoral interview conducted by Mirren.

The first draft, leaked to The Observer , has already been rewritten after objections to a cheeky portrayal of the Greater London Assembly, which scrutinises Livingstone, as uncertain about how to do its job.

The Mayor is also being challenged for taking the credit in 'helping the Metropolitan Police recruit 2,500 more officers', even though only the Home Secretary can authorise changes in police numbers. The GLA sets the Metropolitan Police's budget.

And pledges about 'fighting the Government to get the world-class Underground the capital deserves' gloss over the fact that the Treasury is in charge of Tube privatisation.

But the report's boasts cannot conceal that its author has nowhere near the resources or the freedom given to New York's Mayor Rudy Giuliani, whose success he is expected to match.

'To give him credit, this is still very early days,' said Conservative vice-chairman Steve Norris, Livingstone's closest challenger in the mayoral race last year.

'But what this year has exposed... to his own chagrin, is the paucity of power available to the Mayor. This is the third most important politician in Britain, supposedly, and we don't even give them the power to decide that there will be more policemen on the streets.'

Next month, GLA chairman Trevor Phillips is expected to trigger a review of whether the Assembly's existing powers are adequate. Should London get control over its own hospitals? How can Whitehall Ministers be properly held to account by the Assembly? But such questions may not be resolved until long after Livingstone has left office.

The Mayor's enemies admit he has nimbly avoided many potential traps: he has worked well with the City and avoided serious criticism for raising council taxes. His worst PR disaster was the banning of pigeons from Trafalgar Square - to the outrage of Rayner, the licensed vendor of pigeon feed.

But the honeymoon is over. Friends say Livingstone looks tired: criticism that he has made little visible difference cannot be deflected by the nine-page list of achievements rushed out by his office this weekend.

But it is Norris's charge that there have been 'absolutely no changes for the better on transport as a result of Livingstone's first year' that really stings the Livingstone camp. Critics say but for the personal loathing between Livingstone and Chancellor Gordon Brown a deal could have been done by now on Tube privatisation.

'Livingstone and his team are still operating in some sense as an opposition,' said one senior GLA insider. 'Prior to the election it was Millbank, now it's the Government, they're still running a campaign rather than running London.'

There are tougher challenges ahead, including this week's Tube strike. So far, Livingstone has refused to condemn the hardline RMT union, one of his staunchest backers, but faces increasing pressure from angry passengers to do so.

'It will be a week in which we see what kind of guts this Mayor has,' says one veteran Livingstone watcher.

fields.headline: Care pledge to mothers
fields.standfirst:
 Labour's plan for maternity services
 More midwives
 Home birth choice extended
fields.trailText: Mothers-to-be will get better care during labour and more choice about how they give birth in a multi-million-pound package for maternity services to be unveiled by Health Secretary Alan Milburn.
fields.body:
Mothers-to-be will get better care during labour and more choice about how they give birth in a multi-million-pound package for maternity services to be unveiled by Health Secretary Alan Milburn.

Grim tales of women going into labour in overstretched, understaffed and dirty maternity wards have prompted Ministers to act. They will promise more midwives to ensure one-to-one care during birth, 'home from home' style wards in hospitals, and more choice of a home birth for those who want it.

Milburn believes thousands of infants' lives could be saved over the next decade by providing the best available care from conception onwards.

This week will signal a shift into pre-election mode, as Labour tries to put the welfare of children centre stage. The moves come as the National Family and Parenting Institute calls for the creation of a Ministry for the Family to help fill the remaining 'gaps, inconsistencies and inadequate help and provision' for parents.

Milburn's speech on Wednesday will be backed up by Trade Secretary Stephen Byers launching a streamlining of maternity pay and leave, to make it easier for small firms to administer.

New screening services for expectant mothers will be launched tomorrow by junior Health Minister Yvette Cooper, herself pregnant. 'What we are trying to ensure is that giving birth is as pleasant and as fulfilling an experience as it can be,' said one source close to Milburn.

'It's important that women are offered more privacy, more support and that there isn't this medicalisation of pregnancy and childbirth.

'It's not an illness to have a baby. We need to make sure that NHS hospitals reflect that, and that women have more choice of a home birth.'

Earlier this year MPs warned that staff shortages meant women could not always have a midwife with them throughout labour, even though this reduces the risk of difficult births and of medical intervention. Yesterday the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists suggested a shortage of junior doctors threatened mothers' and babies' safety.

But the real concern is meeting the Government's target to reduce infant mortality. Two-thirds of deaths in the first year are linked to low birthweight and physical immaturity: better care in pregnancy, including advice about diet and smoking, could reduce the number born underweight and premature.

Milburn will tell the Royal College of Midwives' annual conference in Torbay that maternity wards across Britain must match the standards of the best. He is expected to make clear that women should not have to battle reluctant doctors for a home birth if it would be safe for them; home birth rates nationwide vary from three per cent to 20 per cent.

Midwives will also get a greater say in how services are organised, while a National Standards Framework for children will narrow variations in services.

Help will focus particularly on low income mothers, who are at higher risk of postnatal depression, while babies born to the poorest fathers weigh on average 130g (4.5 oz) less than those born to the richest.

fields.headline: Fury over rural lobby's shares
fields.standfirst:
Self-styled champions of the countryside invest in companies that harm their cause

Countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Self-styled champions of the countryside invest in companies that harm their cause.
fields.body:
The Countryside Alliance has come under attack from rural campaigners, environmentalists and MPs after an investigation by the The Observer revealed it has invested in companies criticised for damaging the countryside and farming communities.

The alliance's largest stock market investment is in Barclays, the bank that sparked a storm of protest last year by shutting 171 rural offices with the loss of thousands of jobs. The alliance then condemned the move, which it said 'will cost rural jobs and will further penalise rural people'. A spokesman said: 'We would never consider banking with an organisation that didn't show commitment to a regional rural network.'

According to the confidential documents prepared by the alliance's financial advisers Wise Speke, the campaign group holds more than £40,000 worth of shares in Barclays. In total, the alliance has investments worth more than £530,000 in oil corporations, chemical manufacturers, tobacco giants and arms companies.

Liberal Democrat frontbench spokesman Vincent Cable, who led a parliamentary protest over the rural bank closures, said: 'It seems a case of double standards that an organisation campaigning on these issues should hold such investments. Barclays in particular has shown it is not as sensitive to the needs of rural areas as it should be.'

The alliance's £30,000 investment in oil giant Shell will also embarrass the organisation, which supported last year's fuel protests and has been critical of the profiteering of the oil companies. In January, the alliance's chief executive, Richard Burge, called on the Government to be tough on the oil firms.

He said: 'Rural people are particularly vulnerable. We have seen the withdrawal of banking services from the countryside, and now we are seeing an unfair and indefensible fuel pricing policy which affects rural people twice as much as urban people because their journeys are on average twice as long. It is the Government's role to protect them.'

Although best known for supporting hunting and other blood sports, the Countryside Alliance has tried over the past two years to present itself as a champion on all manner of rural issues, from rising fuel prices to building on green belt land.

In its manifesto, the alliance said: 'We promote conservation and the viability of the countryside as part of the national heritage.' The alliance's campaign for a rural rights handbook stated: 'We plan to build on our sponsorship of work on biodiversity... we take notice of concern in rural areas about pollution and pesticides.'

Yet despite this, the alliance is investing in a number of companies with poor track records in these areas. It has large investments in ICI, one of the worst polluters in the country; last year the firm was discovered to have been dumping toxic chemicals in quarries in rural Cheshire.

The alliance also holds almost £18,000 of shares in Rio Tinto, the controversial mining company that has been criticised worldwide for its poor environmental record. In 1998 more than 50 MPs signed an Early Day Motion describing it as 'probably the most uncaring and ruthless company in the world'.

Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, who has been in dialogue with the alliance on environmental and farming issues, was shocked at the disclosures. He said: 'This is a stupid set of investments for the alliance to have. It is supposed to be fighting for renewed life and vigour in the countryside, yet is investing in these merchants of death.

'What are these companies ever going to do for rural regeneration? While farmers are going to the wall, it should be investing in companies that support the countryside.'

Other alliance investments include shares in two tobacco companies, BAT and Imperial Tobacco, and more than £25,000 in arms company GKN.

A spokesman for the International Fund for Animal Welfare said: 'What these investments really show is that, while the alliance pretends to believe in things like the environment and rural poverty, it is only interested in promoting cruel blood sports.'

The alliance's spokesman said: 'Our investments are run by a group of independent trustees who make their decisions solely on what will give the best financial performance.' But a senior Alliance source said last night the disclosures would almost certainly lead to a review of the share portfolio.

webTitle: 'We come here for work, not to live on handouts'

fields.headline: 'We come here for work, not to live on handouts'
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A major study of illegal immigrants has found that almost all of them come to Britain with the intention of finding work, contrary to the popular image of new arrivals in search of generous benefits.
fields.body:
A major study of illegal immigrants has found that almost all of them come to Britain with the intention of finding work, contrary to the popular image of new arrivals in search of generous benefits.

'Not a single illegal immigrant we examined thought that benefits was a reason for coming to Britain,' said Professor Bill Jordan of Exeter University, who carried out the government-funded project.

'A key reason people gave for coming here was that they expected to be able to work,' said Jordan, whose work was based on interviews with more than 150 illegal immigrants. 'It's a reflection of our economic conditions.'

Asylum seekers, who are registered on arrival, are largely prevented from working. But illegal immigrants find work, the survey discovered, because they are highly motivated, presentable and - above all - prepared to accept low pay. Many were also better educated than their British counterparts. Half the immigrant workers doing manual jobs were graduates or had diplomas.

Nick Hardwick, director of the Refugee Council, said: 'This research is very significant. It absolutely destroys the myth that people are coming here for a cushy life on benefits.'

'Hamid', from Turkey, works as a kitchen porter in a restaurant in London's West End. Instead of coming to Britain hidden in the back of a lorry, the popular view of an illegal migrant, he arrived as a tourist four years ago and then outstayed his visa. He earns £3.50 an hour, well below the minimum wage and works six 10-hour shifts every week.

'My employer says that he cannot get British people to do the work,' said the 24-year-old. 'I only ever expected to work hard if I came here. No one ever mentioned benefits or housing and I have not applied for them. Britain is a freer country than Turkey and I can work. That is why I came.' He shares a two-bedroom flat with five other men. They pay the rent of £300 a week in cash.

'One reason that these people do not get identified is that our society is open and deregulated,' said Jordan. 'There are very few internal controls and there is a very good chance that you will avoid detection in any sphere.

'The benefits regime, for so long a point of political controversy, simply appears to be irrelevant,' said Jordan. 'If people can get work in the shadow economy, they don't encounter the benefits system at all.'

The only use of benefits detected by researchers was either when British co-workers sold an immigrant a national insurance number, or when immigrants married a Briton.

Experts believe that there may be up to a quarter of a million illegal immigrants in Britain.

Most recent research into the attitudes of immigrants to Britain has focused on the views of asylum seekers because they are registered and easily identifiable. Jordan and his colleagues, funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, found their respondents through community networks and also by joining workplace 'raids' carried out by the Immigration Service.

webTitle: Leader: Let the people be heard on May Day

fields.headline: A day for protest, not violence
fields.standfirst:
Let the people be heard on May Day

Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: On Tuesday, 7,000 London policemen in full riot gear will keep a watchful eye, ready to intervene aggressively if any one of the thousands of May Day marchers foments violence.
fields.body:
On Tuesday, 7,000 London policemen in full riot gear will keep a watchful eye, ready to intervene aggressively if any one of the thousands of May Day marchers foments violence. Anti-capitalist campaigners have taken their fight to the World Trade talks in Seattle, last week's Summit of the Americas in Quebec and for two successive years to the World Economic Forum in Davos. Tuesday's anti-capitalist rally promises to be the largest yet in Britain.

Some of the shadowy groups behind Tuesday's march live in an anarchist demi-monde, whose culture and ideology excuse violence to serve the cause to which they obsessively adhere. They undermine and delegitimise a rally that is otherwise giving expression to deeply held and genuine feelings of outrage at the growing power of corporations, not least in their subversion of the public realm. Any violence will both justify a disproportionate police response as well as grievously weaken the protesters' argument. We condemn such violence both for itself and for its wider stupidity.

It is important the campaigners on Tuesday are seen for what they really are, the most vocal in a growing popular revolt, extending from consumers to the investment community, that is rightly contesting the way in which large corporations define contemporary economic and social life. Capitalism was once recognised for what it is - self-interested, unstable and with an inbuilt propensity to monopoly and exploitation that required close regulation and management. It is also creative, wealth-generating and the most powerful force for technological innovation the world has known. Politicians worldwide seem in thrall to the second part of this proposition while forgetting the first.

A proper concern to promote growth, investment and employment has been transmuted into governmental acceptance that every aspect of policy must contribute to building a civilisation in which only business values, concerns and priorities have importance. This is a worldwide phenomenon, incubated in neo-conservative think-tanks in Washington and exported worldwide through US companies and banks along with American-controlled international institutions. Its most complete expression may be the evisceration of the Labour Party as a political force that champions the public realm and the underdog, but all of Europe's social democratic parties have been weakened in similar ways.

Anti-capitalist campaigners have taken their fight to the World Trade talks in Seattle, last week's Summit of the Americas in Quebec and for two successive years to the World Economic Forum in Davos. Tuesday's anti-capitalist rally promises to be the largest yet in Britain. Some of the shadowy groups behind Tuesday's march live in an anarchist demi-monde, whose culture and ideology excuse violence to serve the cause to which they obsessively adhere. webTitle: Leader: Government must be more open about nuclear incidents

fields.headline: A deadly silence
fields.standfirst:
Government must be more open

Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
fields.trailText: Will we ever learn? Eighteen years after the Department of Health promised greater openness about the incidence of cancers around nuclear power stations, we report today the appearance of another frightening cluster near the Oldbury reactor next to the Severn Estuary.
fields.body:
Will we ever learn? Eighteen years after the Department of Health promised greater openness about the incidence of cancers around nuclear power stations, we report today the appearance of another frightening cluster near the Oldbury reactor next to the Severn Estuary. Two decades after Sellafield became a by-word for danger to public health, children in the town of Chepstow appear to be 11 times more likely than elsewhere in Britain to contract leukaemia.

This incidence of illness is not only an indictment of successive governments' complacency about the dangers of nuclear power. It is, equally important, testament to the pathetic resolve of politicians of all parties to ensure that public information should reside in the public domain. Cancer clusters are still almost impossible to trace from government statistics as currently published; the figures are too general and cover too large an area. Yet postcode analysis of the incidence of illness, for both cancer and other diseases, could transform our understanding of some illnesses. As always, the stock inclination of Britain's institutions - the Department of Health is little different from any other - remains to disclose as little as they can get away with.

Swathes of important information remain hidden because impertinent public scrutiny is much harder work for public officials than secrecy. We cannot blame this government alone for failing to brush away the patronising fetish for obfuscation of a Civil Service which has never known - or acted - any better. But the Oldbury scandal reminds us graphically that we still live in a secret society.

webTitle: Comment: root causes of poverty and inequality must be addressed

fields.headline: Cradle to the ballot box
fields.standfirst: Baby bonds are welcome, but they'll do little to remove the root causes of poverty and inequality
fields.trailText: Baby bonds are welcome, but they'll do little to remove the root causes of poverty and inequality.
fields.body:
Babies and elections have always been, in the jargon of the moment, contiguous. This time round, there is a difference. Now babymania can jump species. Phoenix the calf, an emblem of Disney cuteness among mountains of scorched flesh, gets the livestock cull curtailed. Less flamboyantly, the 750,000 human infants born every year in Britain also score a victory. Each will soon have a dowry of £250 apiece, rising to £500 for the poorest. With three further top-ups of £100 and a government promise to match any family contributions, the least well-off 18-year-olds should end up with a modest nest egg, courtesy of the four fairy godfathers of government.

David Blunkett is the political driver for the Child Trust Fund, successfully piloted in the US over the past decade and imported by the left-wing think tank, the IPPR. Alistair Darling is also keen on asset-building. An ominous silence hung over the Treasury when baby bonds were first mooted before Gordon Brown eventually proclaimed himself in favour of a plan designed to ensure that every newborn will enter the world with the word 'Prudence' practically stamped on his or her brow. As for Tony Blair, this idea had everything.

To the Right, it offered the camphorous odour of Thatcher's mothballed credo of a property-owning democracy. Baby-bonders would, in the Tory view, be the spiritual heirs to the Sids who snapped up shares and council houses.

To the Left, it bore the equally comforting whiff of progressive universalism. While the scheme's foundation, on the shaky faultline where Beveridge and neo-liberalism collide, rendered it acceptable to almost all, the plan has a special resonance for Blair. In his 1999 conference speech, he described two babies, side by side in the labour ward and destined, if he had his wish, to live in a meritocratic society where all began life on an equal footing. Baby bonds match the policy to the dream. Better still, a scheme costing a modest £1 billion a year offers a branding unbuyable even by a government that splurges £62 million on three months' worth of advertising. This, the subtext reads, is an administration that loves poor children.

And still, our child poverty rate is the third highest in the industrialised world: 100,000 more children were plunged into hardship during the first two years of the Blair government. Although changes to tax and benefits have reversed that trend, more than three million children will remain below the breadline at the election. Of those, 600,000 of them could have been removed from income poverty if the £2.4bn forgone by last year's cut in the basic tax rate had been used to increase benefits.

Regressive taxes on cigarettes and petrol continue to clobber the poor, as does the Social Fund. The Social Security Select Committee recently reported that the fund, a model of Dickensian parsimony, exacerbates child poverty because parents cannot afford to repay crisis loans for items such as fridges and cookers. So far, the Government has resisted subsequent calls for a review.

As ever, the children of poor households continue to do worse at school and to get the worst-paid jobs, or none. By their late teens, that damage may be irreversible. Certainly the notion that 18-year-olds will emerge from a chrysalis of poverty into fully formed trustafarians, ready to spend with care (rather than to squander their money on drugs and drink as their rich-list equivalents tend to) seems unproven.

Nor are parents struggling to buy food and shoes likely to be sustained by the knowledge that their children are custodians of untouchable funds worth several thousand pounds. Perhaps such caveats count for little against a suspicion that approval from those debarred by extreme poverty from saving, including the seven out of 10 lone parents who currently have no back-up funds at all, is not the applause Labour most desires.

Despite last week's volte-face allowing more generous parental leave, women of all backgrounds remain sceptical of a government perceived to have done too little on childcare provision and flexible working hours. So how helpful to have news programmes full of vox pops involving wards full of new 'mums' (not a father in sight, even on politically correct Channel 4 News ) offering warm plaudits to Blair's largesse.

Though it would be cynical to accuse the Government of blatantly touting for votes among those impressed by its drive towards child equality, there is no doubt that some remain more equal than others. One minute, the Government is offering Hans Christian Andersen fairytale outcomes, in which all must have equal prospects. In the next, it sketches cautionary tales worthy of a Hoffman or a Belloc, on what must happen to those corrupted by the forces of exclusion.

Slap a curfew or a school exclusion order on them. March 'yobs' to cashpoints or incarcerate them in one of our scandalous young offenders' institutions to rot or, if especially unlucky, to die. Tony Blair's latest wheeze, to reward non-offending teenagers in high crime areas with vouchers for CDs or trainers, looks either like a belated balance of carrot to stick or the feeblest of pre-election gimmicks.

It may also be a sign that Blair, an expert on wayward adolescents and infant innocents alike, has a Dr Spockish urge to treat the nation's children as his own. The trouble is that parenting is a haphazard, emotional affair, whereas politics is structured and calculating. Conflate the two and the upshot is the liberal press gurgling over Blair's plans while the Daily Telegraph, simultaneously, infers the extinction of the welfare state and the advent of a US-style residuum.

The suspicion is that Blair is bowing to the perception that the views of Left and Right must, like the rich child and the poor, be equally indulged. In addition, political entrail-reading usefully magnifies the scope of what's really on offer. Baby bonds, and an allied savings scheme for poor adults, are a valuable gesture, but a tiny one. Suggesting that they are the foundation of a DIY society is as unrealistic as hoping to buy Chatsworth with Green Shield stamps.

Last week, Blair's personal think tank filled in the gaps on an anti-poverty strategy. The Performance and Innovation Unit urged him to increase income and inheritance tax and end the middle-class stranglehold on getting the best education. A meritocratic society depended, it said, on high social mobility and the absence of any association between class and opportunity. Such truisms bear repetition in a week when Blair plans to stick to his 1997 pledge not to put up income tax while his 'People's Peers', a Gilbert and Sullivan array of toffery, make the notion of democratic appointments look risible.

As for baby bonds, the enthusiasm of its reception should make Labour bolder and less disingenuous. Though the sketch is vague and the budget small, we would love it to work. But voters also know that children's lives cannot be transformed unless direct taxes rise. Blair should flesh out his trust plan, reform the Social Fund, step up the crusade to end child poverty by 2020 and concede that notions of forging equality on the cheap belong in the realm of storks and gooseberry bushes.

fields.headline: 'Get rid of all that namby-pamby stuff about rights...'
fields.standfirst: Alistair Beaton, author of the satirical hit  Feelgood, chances on a secret memo from the Prime Minister seeking a livelier manifesto
fields.trailText: Alistair Beaton, author of the satirical hit  Feelgood, chances on a secret memo from the Prime Minister seeking a livelier manifesto.
fields.body:
The health service:
Existing draft mentions Welfare State. Twice! How was this allowed to happen? Build on the baby bonds initiative. Health bonds? Mid-life bonds? Granny bonds?

More emphasis on personal responsibility. Savings. Looking ahead. We say to 21-year-olds: start planning for that hip operation now! Stress role of private enterprise in provision of crucial services. Sponsored wards? Ambulances to respond toaccidents only upon production of a valid credit card? Sale of organs from deceased to highest bidder? (Ask Gould to run focus group on that before inclusion in manifesto.)

Law and order:
Not tough enough. Get rid of namby-pamby stuff about rights and responsibilities; we've gone past that. Key phrases include 'firm' 'tough' 'crackdown' 'end to yob culture'.

Announce special courts (NB: no jury) to fast-track young offenders. Removal of right to appeal? General tone needs to be more action-oriented. Dream up eye-catching measures that won't cost much, eg young thugs to be made to serve afternoon tea in old people's homes.

Agriculture:
Remove picture of Nick Brown. Use instead upbeat pic of Phoenix (cuddlier and prettier). Don't talk of 're-establishing the best traditions of British farming after the current epidemic is over'. Foot and mouth our chance to get rid of farming altogether (as Thatcher got rid of miners). Opening up Britain to multinational food companies to be presented as opportunity. Use positive phrases for this, eg 'responding to realities of the global marketplace' etc.

Foreign policy:
Who the f... authorised re-use of 'a foreign policy with an ethical dimension'?! Last time round it got us into deep shit. Try instead 'a responsible foreign policy'. Rewrite last para into something like: 'Human rights are important. So are Britain's exports. We need to strike the right balance between the two.' NB: Check this still allows us to (a) cosy up to China and (b) sell Hawk jets to dodgy regimes.

The economy:
Low inflation our main achievement. The economy in safe hands. Careful and gradual progress. No return to boom and bust. OK if this section sounds dull. Keep it short. Try to find uglier picture of Gordon Brown.

Asylum and immigration:
We must be seen to be firm but fair. First draft of manifesto emphasises latter at expense of former. Adjust. We need to state clearly our belief in decent, humane, multi-ethnic society, open to accepting from abroad those fleeing persecution. British people decent people but not a soft touch. Economic migrants posing as refugees to be pursued ruthlessly. (But make sure phrasing is vague so we can import cheap labour for cafés, restaurants, cleaning companies etc.)

Education:
Needs more about right to choose an individually tailored learning package (formerly known as an education). Create strategy to change curriculum every year, so that teachers too tired to protest about pay and conditions. Gifted and talented children to be sponsored by business - free crisps and CDs for best SATS performances?

Transport:
Admit that we haven't got this quite right. (Implication that Prescott to blame not entirely undesirable.) Emphasise long-term advantage of private-public partnerships. Abandon phrases such as integrated transport policy, now subject of mockery. Don't mention Virgin Trains. Don't mention Railtrack. Don't mention Hatfield. Maybe don't mention transport at all. Ring Peter and ask what he thinks.

 Feelgood by Alistair Beaton is now running at the Garrick Theatre, London. Mrs Blair resumes her Diary next week.

fields.headline: Asylum translators lost for words
fields.standfirst:
Home Office uses inexperienced students to interpret tales of terror as refugees plead to stay
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Home Office uses inexperienced students to interpret tales of terror as refugees plead to stay.
fields.body:
It was when the asylum-seekers began describing the abuse they had suffered that Alex Reynolds ceased to understand a word they said. Having been persuaded against his judgment to act as a translator for the Home Office on behalf of refugees, the 22-year-old student was exhausted and traumatised.

He looked across the table at the 17-year-old who was trying to explain for the third time how Nepalese police had tortured him, and turned to the Home Office interviewer sitting calmly flicking through his notebook. 'I told the interviewer I couldn't understand what this man was saying,' said Reynolds.

'I'd been honest that what I spoke was fairly fluent village Nepalese, but this man's life seemed to be in real danger and I couldn't convey that. I'd accepted the job because I'd been told I wouldn't need to know anything complex or political - but this man was telling me his life depended on him being able to stay in Britain for reasons I couldn't understand.'

The man from the Home Office was unmoved. 'He was calm and unruffled by the obvious chaos in front of him,' Reynolds said. 'He advised me to paraphrase what the man said and simplify if need be. He said that if the interviewee disagreed with the transcription of the interview after the judgment had been passed, he could always appeal.'

Reynolds's experience is far from uncommon: an Observer investigation has discovered that the Home Office routinely employs untrained and inexperienced translators for asylum interviews in contradiction to explicit government legislation.

'Potential interpreters are interviewed by staff at the Central Interpreters Unit or at one of their local offices before being accepted on to the panel,' said a Home Office spokeswoman. 'The only exception to this rule is when someone is already working for another government department, the local police force or is a well-qualified professional interpreter.'

Reynolds, an anthropology student at Newcastle University, had not spoken Nepalese for almost two years and was not interviewed or even given a contract before being sent to Liverpool and confronted by asylum-seekers with tales of violence and terror. He simply replied to an email from Sakura Communications, a local interpretation unit employed by the Home Office to supply translators to Immigration and Asylum offices.

'I told Sakura exactly what level my Nepalese was at,' said Reynolds. 'They weren't bothered and gave me a brief description of the job on offer. When I asked if they wanted to meet me, they said that wasn't necessary.'

Three days later Reynolds found himself in the staffroom of Liverpool's Immigration and Asylum office. 'All the others were in their thirties and professional translators. They were shocked to see me but one took me aside and gave me a crash course in words he told me I'd need, like oppression, pain and danger. He told me the name of the outlawed Maoist party the asylum-seekers would support and made sure I at least had a dictionary.'

Over 70 per cent of asylum-seekers to Britain are refused entry, a decision appealed against by most of them but upheld in over 80 per cent of cases. The Government cites these statistics as proof of its stringent interviewing procedures, but the experiences of Reynolds and others persuaded to act as unqualified translators has left the Home Office facing questions over how seriously it tries to understand the plight of those appealing for help. 'It seems unlikely to me that either of the men I translated for will get asylum,' said Reynolds. 'The system obviously wanted to get rid of them as soon as possible. They didn't seem bothered whether these people got a fair trial or not.'

Veronica Oakeshott, a politics student at Newcastle University who also spent a year in Nepal, answered an advert by Sakura in the student newspaper. 'I explained that I wasn't fluent but the person they'd had lined up for the job had been sacked the day before and she was obviously desperate,' said Oakeshott. 'I was given no trial or interview - they just told me to go to the office in Leeds, but nobody indicated what the job was going to be. I was shocked: I didn't think I would be involved in crux of whole thing.'

She was told to translate legally-binding Home Office statements into Nepalese for the refugees to sign. 'I told the Home Office interviewers again and again that I could not do it but they just wrote that in their scripts and told me to carry on.'

At the end of the day, Oakeshott rang Sakura and explained her difficulties, telling them she did not want to return the next day as she had previously agreed. 'The same woman laid this massive guilt trip on me and said it would be impossible to find another translator in time. She said the refugees were relying on me; that they had already booked their train tickets, despite not having any money to speak of.

'I felt the Home Office was going through the motions. They obviously had a huge backlog but didn't seem to care that I couldn't do the job. I was in a horrible position; I decided not to go back but I felt completely traumatised by the experience.'

When The Observer rang Sakura, claiming to be a student interested in translation work, Geoff Heron, the office manager, confirmed the students' claims. 'We try to employ only native speakers but we also have a number of undergraduates and postgraduates on our books because sometimes it's an emergency process.

'No qualifications are necessary although we always make sure translators know exactly what they'll be doing. The refugees can start making revelations about what they've been through and we have employed students who have found the experience very traumatic,' he admitted. 'There have been cases when the interviews have had to be stopped because they've found it too upsetting.'

Having been persuaded against his judgment to act as a translator for the Home Office on behalf of refugees, the 22-year-old student was exhausted and traumatised. 'I told the interviewer I couldn't understand what this man was saying,' said Reynolds. 'I'd been honest that what I spoke was fairly fluent village Nepalese, but this man's life seemed to be in real danger and I couldn't convey that. I'd accepted the job because I'd been told I wouldn't need to know anything complex or political - but this man was telling me his life depended on him being able to stay in Britain for reasons I couldn't understand.' The man from the Home Office was unmoved. 'He was calm and unruffled by the obvious chaos in front of him,' Reynolds said. 'He advised me to paraphrase what the man said and simplify if need be. He said that if the interviewee disagreed with the transcription of the interview after the judgment had been passed, he could always appeal.' Reynolds's experience is far from uncommon: an Observer investigation has discovered that the Home Office routinely employs untrained and inexperienced translators for asylum interviews in contradiction to explicit government legislation. 'Potential interpreters are interviewed by staff at the Central Interpreters Unit or at one of their local offices before being accepted on to the panel,' said a Home Office spokeswoman. 'The only exception to this rule is when someone is already working for another government department, the local police force or is a well-qualified professional interpreter.' Reynolds, an anthropology student at Newcastle University, had not spoken Nepalese for almost two years and was not interviewed or even given a contract before being sent to Liverpool and confronted by asylum-seekers with tales of violence and terror. He simply replied to an email from Sakura Communications, a local interpretation unit employed by the Home Office to supply translators to Immigration and Asylum offices. 'I told Sakura exactly what level my Nepalese was at,' said Reynolds. 'They weren't bothered and gave me a brief description of the job on offer. When I asked if they wanted to meet me, they said that wasn't necessary.' Three days later Reynolds found himself in the staffroom of Liverpool's Immigration and Asylum office. 'All the others were in their thirties and professional translators. They were shocked to see me but one took me aside and gave me a crash course in words he told me I'd need, like oppression, pain and danger. He told me the name of the outlawed Maoist party the asylum-seekers would support and made sure I at least had a dictionary.' Over 70 per cent of asylum-seekers to Britain are refused entry, a decision appealed against by most of them but upheld in over 80 per cent of cases. The Government cites these statistics as proof of its stringent interviewing procedures, but the experiences of Reynolds and others persuaded to act as unqualified translators has left the Home Office facing questions over how seriously it tries to understand the plight of those appealing for help. 'It seems unlikely to me that either of the men I translated for will get asylum,' said Reynolds. 'The system obviously wanted to get rid of them as soon as possible. They didn't seem bothered whether these people got a fair trial or not.' Veronica Oakeshott, a politics student at Newcastle University who also spent a year in Nepal, answered an advert by Sakura in the student newspaper. 'I explained that I wasn't fluent but the person they'd had lined up for the job had been sacked the day before and she was obviously desperate,' said Oakeshott. 'I was given no trial or interview - they just told me to go to the office in Leeds, but nobody indicated what the job was going to be. I was shocked: I didn't think I would be involved in crux of whole thing.' She was told to translate legally-binding Home Office statements into Nepalese for the refugees to sign. 'I told the Home Office interviewers again and again that I could not do it but they just wrote that in their scripts and told me to carry on.' At the end of the day, Oakeshott rang Sakura and explained her difficulties, telling them she did not want to return the next day as she had previously agreed. 'The same woman laid this massive guilt trip on me and said it would be impossible to find another translator in time. She said the refugees were relying on me; that they had already booked their train tickets, despite not having any money to speak of. 'I felt the Home Office was going through the motions. They obviously had a huge backlog but didn't seem to care that I couldn't do the job. I was in a horrible position; I decided not to go back but I felt completely traumatised by the experience.' When The Observer rang Sakura, claiming to be a student interested in translation work, Geoff Heron, the office manager, confirmed the students' claims. 'We try to employ only native speakers but we also have a number of undergraduates and postgraduates on our books because sometimes it's an emergency process. 'No qualifications are necessary although we always make sure translators know exactly what they'll be doing. The refugees can start making revelations about what they've been through and we have employed students who have found the experience very traumatic,' he admitted. 'There have been cases when the interviews have had to be stopped because they've found it too upsetting.'

fields.headline: Court of appeal
fields.standfirst: Everyone says the Prime Minister's wife is a brilliant barrister - top in her bar exams, taking silk at only 40. But how good is she really? John Gibb has his day in court with Cherie Booth QC
fields.trailText: Everyone says the Prime Minister's wife is a brilliant barrister - top in her bar exams, taking silk at only 40. But how good is she really? John Gibb has his day in court with Cherie Booth QC.
fields.body:
We have been told about Cherie the fierce, protective mother, and we know all about Cherie the power behind the Prime Minister who looks out of place in a formal suit. But what do we know about her career at the Bar? This woman is a serious barrister, a Silk making at least £250,000 a year in human rights legislation and employment law. Although we rarely hear about it, she spends every available moment following her career.

So where is she? It's not easy to find out. The dead-eyed man at the information desk in the Royal Courts of Justice in London won't tell you, and don't even think of asking her chambers or the press office at Number 10, but I've managed to discover that Cherie Booth QC is due in the Court of Appeal this cold February morning and her client is a Nigerian chief from Lagos called Humphrey Idisi.

By 10.30am, she is on her feet in Court 69. Below the judicial bench, the well of the court and the public seats have all the corporate charisma of a conference room of a Forte Travel Lodge hotel. It is a light, airy chamber, pale oak furnishings, bland carpet, functional. There are no jury seats; this is where the judiciary makes all the decisions.

The three Lord Justices sit above the proceedings, their hollow faces illuminated by green-glass reading lamps and their less impressive lower parts hidden behind thick panelling. It's hard to tell if they are perched high above the court so they can look down on the participants or whether their self-imposed isolation is for their own protection.

This is a story of false imprisonment, mock executions, piracy and an attempt to strangle the Russian ambassador to Nigeria. To add to the drama, we are in the presence of a star. This is not only because of Booth's reputation as an advocate, but also because of the barrier erected between the Prime Minister's wife and a fascinated public.

For some reason, probably because it was one of their first briefs, details of the appeal were issued by her new chambers, Matrix, on 7 May last year. It was announced that Ms Booth will be representing Chief Humphrey Idisi, a Nigerian businessman with considerable influence in his country, and his companies, Lonestar Drilling and Lonestar Overseas Limited. Idisi is appealing against a judgment handed down in the High Court by Justice Langley last November.

The appeal concerns the alleged 'imprisonment' of the Ukrainian crew of a cargo vessel called the Dubai Valour, from which oil rigs and drilling equipment had been lost during a storm off the Cape of Good Hope. It is alleged the crew were held prisoner and harshly treated over a period of 18 months while Chief Idisi attempted to claim £12m in compensation from her owners. When the Russian ambassador went to intercede on the crew's behalf, it is further alleged that Chief Idisi personally attempted to strangle him.

The ship owners, Gulf Azov, then successfully sued Idisi for the return of the £3m it paid for the release of the ship and for damages relating to the imprisonment of its crew and the impounding of its vessel. The court was satisfied that the evidence against Idisi was so overwhelming that there was no prospect of him establishing a defence, and the ship owners won the case without a trial.

Chief Idisi is now claiming in the Court of Appeal that the allegations against him amounted to accusations of torture and crimes against humanity. His case is that these accusations should have been tested before a jury and it is an infringement of his human rights. When I called Idisi in his office in Lagos and asked him how it had happened that he was being represented by Cherie Booth QC, he said: 'This is an important case for me and my company. I wanted the best, and you cannot get better than the Prime Minister's wife.'

When I arrive, Booth is standing in the front of the well of the court with her juniors and instructing solicitors around her. Graham Dunning, counsel for Gulf Azov, sits at the back, eyebrows raised, taking notes and looking professionally astonished. The appeal is listed for two days, and Booth is in the middle of a submission about the conditions in which the Ukrainian crew had been kept. There had been stories of starvation and mock executions by Idisi's men. Booth seems ill at ease. From time to time, she stops to search for a letter or a statement. Occasionally she drops bundles of papers on the floor while her junior, Bita Bhalla, a smart-looking black barrister with grizzled grey hair, pink shirt and stiff white collar, scrabbles about on the carpet.

The repartee between Ms Booth and the Bench is more in the nature of a conversation than a dispute. She tends to speak in a chatty rather than a dramatic way, occasionally dropping the odd Lancastrian vowel. Her point is that her client's arrest of the crew was perfectly legal and that they were in fact looked after in an exemplary manner by the chief and the Nigerian police.

I am surprised at the way she frequently talks over the judge and vice versa. This is not a technique which one would ever see in a criminal trial at the Old Bailey. On the long bench above the court, the wigged and bespectacled Lord Justices Brooke, Longmore and Buckley are not smiling. Chief Idisi has already been sentenced to three months in prison in his absence for contempt of court. In other words, he has ignored the High Court judgment against him.

In the end, their Honours retire for a month to consider their verdict while Cherie and her retinue depart into the Gormenghastian depths of the High Court and across the large yard towards Chancery Lane. She seems utterly at ease, gesticulating and laughing with her clients as she goes. Judgment is finally handed down on 9 March and is in all respects against Chief Humphrey Idisi.

There is no argument about the brilliance of Cherie Booth QC. Brought up in Liverpool, her ascent to Bar stardom was the culmination of a long struggle. Her father Tony, a bit-part actor known for his heavy drinking, his womanising and his willingness to perform in films such as Confessions of a Taxi Driver, left his wife Gale when Cherie was seven years old. Times were hard, Gale gave up her acting career and was forced to work in a chippie to make ends meet while Cherie blossomed at Seafield Convent Grammar School in Crosby, coming out with straight As. She continued her academic career at the London School of Economics, where she graduated with a first-class degree in law. Oliver Welch, a fellow student, describes her as 'focused'. 'She was clever, and slightly aloof. People were wary of her.' In 1976, she came top in the Bar finals and immediately went to Derry Irvine (now her husband's Lord Chancellor) as a pupil at his chambers in 2 Crown Office Row.

Irvine was a successful barrister specialising in employment and Trade Union law. He insisted that most of his pupils should be academically gifted and highly qualified, but after snapping up Booth, he made an exception to his rule and took on the young Anthony Blair, who came to him after scraping through the Bar finals with a modest third. It was not long before Booth and Blair started walking out together and the romance turned into history.

But it was Blair to whom Irvine eventually offered the tenancy while Cherie Booth went off to George Carman at New Court. This was a strange decision by Irvine. Cherie Booth was known to be brilliant. She had the gift of being able to quickly dissect complex legal problems and a natural talent for analysis and strategic decisions. Irvine claimed she left before he could make her an offer.

According to a circuit judge who knew him well, Blair was an average hack who had the priceless gift of charm; he was personable, amusing and considerably more clubbable than the reticent, slightly prickly Booth. Cherie Booth's time at New Court was not a success. She was unable to specialise in the areas such as human rights and employment law which interested her. In 1992 she left Carman and went to join Michael Beloff at 4-5 Grays Inn Square, one of the biggest and best sets in London. Beloff was immediately impressed with her. 'She made as great an impression on me in the first five minutes as anyone ever has,' he recalls. 'She played the whole thing beautifully and made her pitch without being conceited in any way.'

Booth's career took flight, and she began to flourish at the Bar. She took Silk in 1995 when she was only 40 and started to pick up high-profile employment cases, such as that of Martin Neary, the Westminster Abbey organist who was dismissed.

In March 1998, she was hired by the brewers Shepherd Neame to represent it in an action against the government. It was an application for leave to appeal against a judgment which had been made in favour of the Chancellor's decision to increase excise duty on beer. The brewers and, in fact, the entire brewing industry were outraged at the disparity of treatment between the UK and the member states. The case had originally been handled by Michael Beloff, but he was forced to withdraw, and when brewery director Stuart Neame was offered Cherie Booth as an alternative, he jumped at the chance. When I ask him why, he immediately replies, 'Publicity, old boy, publicity.'

Cherie Booth had little to do. Before she even stood up in court, Lord Justice Richard Scott said, 'We've read your written submissions and we agree with you' and granted the brewery the right to appeal. Much to Neame's delight, the story finished up on the front pages of most of the papers. Booth never uttered a word in open court as the court had been persuaded by written argument.

In 1999, Booth and a small coterie of successful barristers from 4-5 Grays Inn Square started to plot the formation of a new and revolutionary law firm. The idea was to create a medium-sized set of chambers with no more than 37 members which would offer a complete law service. There would be no 'Head of Chambers' - it would be managed by a democratically elected committee of members and would aim to reflect the legal requirements of the new millennium. Booth had much to do with establishing the core values: public-service ethic, innovation, cross-fertilisation of service and ideas, teamwork, etc. It was the antithesis of the traditional chambers. Clerking would be done away with and replaced with an administrative staff to manage members' practices, handle marketing, etc. They employed Shandwyck, the PR consultancy, to handle the media frenzy which would no doubt accompany the launch. All that was missing was a title, and after a day of deliberation, someone came up with the name Matrix.

I spend an afternoon at Matrix HQ in Griffin Building, an old police station on the corner of Grays Inn and Clerkenwell roads. The reception is dominated by a translucent desk which changes colour from soft, reassuring pink to blue to yellow every 30 seconds. Members - no one is referred to as a partner - walk around in jeans and shirtsleeves, offices are glass panelled, there is an open-plan administration room inhabited by smiling PAs. A small room with a telly and a few armchairs is used by exhausted members as a common room. There are no ashtrays.

The legal profession will take many years to shed its old image. Much was made about Michael Beloff's recent decision to join them before he inexplicably changed his mind and decided to return to his old set at 4-5 Grays Inn Square. Could it be that he feels more comfortable in a traditional environment rather than the new age, ground-breaking Matrix?

I next bump into Booth a month later in Court 74 in the Court of Appeal on 27 March. The little chamber, tucked away at the top of the East Wing of the RCJ, is packed. The plaintiff is a 53-year-old teacher by the name of Shirley Pearce who had been persecuted by her pupils at Mayfield Secondary School in Portsmouth. Pearce is a lesbian, and the verbal and physical abuse to which she was subjected in the early 90s was the result of the children learning of her sexuality and persecuting her for it. No steps to protect her or discipline those responsible appear to have been taken by the school. When her working life became so intolerable that she was forced to go to the headmaster for help, his response was to tell her to 'grit her teeth or run away'. When the chairman of the governors wrote to say that she 'must have realised that [she] risked abuse', Pearce went to an industrial tribunal claiming sexual discrimination.

The claim was rejected on the grounds that she was discriminated against because of her sexuality, not because of her gender. The appeal, which Pearce is funding personally, is opposed by Hampshire Education Authority and the governors of Mayfield School, who briefed Cherie Booth to represent them. The legal issues revolve round the law relating to human rights and sex discrimination. Booth claims that the Tribunal judgment was correct because neither the sex discrimination legislation nor the Human Rights Act has been drafted to accommodate this particular anomaly. Laura Cox QC is acting for the plaintiff, and the appeal has created a great deal of interest in the gay community. The public benches are thronged with grey-haired female ramblers and thin, bald men in black suits, while fresh-faced women wearing bikers' leathers stalk the corridors outside. The two male judges, Lord Justice Henry and Lord Justice Judge, adopt bleak, slightly appalled expressions throughout the proceedings and remain mostly silent. The third member of the bench, Lady Justice Hale, delivers terrifying questions while adopting a sinister smile in the manner of a head prefect who has caught a fifth former with a packet of Benson & Hedges. 'Ms Booth, are you really asking us to believe?' etc.

Booth makes her points eloquently and seems on much surer ground among the intricacies of human rights, sexual discrimination and employment legislation. 'It is the government to blame, not my client,' she says. 'The Sex Discrimination Act is not capable of legislating on matters of sexual orientation. What have the public authorities done to infringe the plaintiff's human rights? We say, nothing at all.'

Both teams have to prepare final submissions during the lunch hour. Booth and her junior retire to the crowded public snack bar for a tuna sandwich as they scribble away; papers in piles on the table and all over the floor by their feet.

I have begun to realise that Booth is oblivious to her appearance in court. She gives the impression that she has clothed, fed and dispatched her kids and her husband, washed up, slapped on lipstick, grabbed her wig and gown and just made it in time for a five-hour bout of legal argument before rushing back to fix the tea.

Today, she is wearing a horsehair frieze-top barrister's wig from which one of a pair of the 'babies' (curls) stitched to the tail has gone missing, a white collarett and bib, a Queen's Counsel's black gown, a black worsted jacket with gauntlet cuffs and a formal waistcoat - all from Thresher & Glenny of 67 Chancery Lane. Jewellery is minimal: a red-gold wedding band, a chunky silver ring, a bracelet and a pair of small, heart-shaped diamond earrings.

She arrives in court carrying a bottle of Volvic mineral water and a packet of Kleenex tissues and keeps her private documents in a Silk's red brief bag. Her nails are unvarnished. Her hair is black with auburn tints. While she appears neat and tidy first thing, she is a habitual fidget and indulges herself with constant movement - swivelling to talk to her junior, shifting her position on the hard benches, screwing up her features as if squinting into the distance, taking her watch off and playing with it, stifling yawns, pulling her ear and dragging her hand down her face. Her habit of scratching her scalp results in her wig shifting back on her head, leaving stray locks showing in the front and dislodging the occasional strand so it hangs down across her cheek. By 3.40pm, the wig has become completely askew, endowing her with a rakish appearance at odds with the po-faced solemnity of the court.

At the end of the day, after judgment has been reserved and their Lordships have departed, Cherie turns to talk to her junior and passes him a pile of papers and files from her bench. She yawns, looks at her watch and begins to disrobe in court. Her gown, jacket and waistcoat are discarded down to a revealing black v-neck sweater, over which she slips a less formal jacket and coat, ready to make a break for it out of the private entrance in Carey Street where her car awaits. As she leaves, she turns to me and says, 'Are you following me around?' 'Yes,' I tell her.

The Shirley Pearce appeal lasts three days and is inconclusive, the three Lord Justices reserving judgment and making the point that many other appeals are in the pipeline. It's hard to understand why the appeal had come to court at all.

Whatever one says, the fact that Cherie Booth is the Prime Minister's wife is bound to have an effect on her clients and may affect some of the judiciary, who either react against her in order to show their independence or slobber unctuously over her because she is a celebrity. While this attitude is unfortunate but probably unavoidable, there is no sign that it has affected her cases, or that her career as a barrister is suffering. Her appearance at a judicial revue on 9 April representing an inmate at the Personality Disorder Unit in Ashworth Special Hospital is an illustration of the earnings potential of the Human Rights Act. The appellant, her client Adrian Ng, a Chinese national, has been an inmate in the Personality Disorder Unit at Ashworth for 15 years. Ng, who has apparently become a model patient, was convicted of the ritual slaughter of Mai Tai Tang and her two children at The Old Bailey in November 1984. He claimed in court that he had been 'possessed by gods' and was detained indefinitely in a secure hospital.

Ashworth, Rampton and Broadmoor are where our most dangerous men and women are kept, and security in these establishments is compatible with Category B prisons, although the inmates are mentally ill and therefore technically not criminally responsible. Ng is objecting to the monitoring of his private telephone calls by hospital staff, claiming that it infringes his human rights. The judgment will be made principally on written submissions and the review consequently requires only one day of the court's time.

A judicial review can be used to examine whether a decision made by a public authority - in this case, the Department of Health - is irrational, unreasonable or a breach of the principle of proportionality. The hearing is presided over by His Honour Justice Newman, and Booth is up against the Department of Health and Ms Aswini Weerera representing Ashworth Hospital. She has been retained by Nigel Leslie, a solicitor who specialises in human rights and mental health.

Booth makes the point that the hospital's policy of monitoring 10 per cent of private telephone conversations is incompatible with Article 8 of the Human Rights Act which entitles the individual to privacy and family life. The Department of Health argues that security considerations are such that it is vital to remove any right to privacy on the telephone. In the past, there have been numerous public inquiries into Ashworth as a result of the discovery of active paedophile rings, pornography and drugs in the hospital. The Department of Health barrister says there is a compelling need for telephone monitoring because of the special circumstances which exist in these places, the manipulative nature of many of the inmates, and the need to avoid drugs becoming more readily available.

'The Secretary of State has taken a step too far,' says Booth. 'The telephone is my client's only link with the outside world. He feels - with justification - that if a conversation with, for instance, his sister, is overheard and forms part of an analysis of his mental state by a member of staff, it could be taken out of context and he will have no redress. He should have the right of private conversation with members of his family.'

When the court adjourns, the proceedings disintegrate into informality. 'I really must visit one of these places,' says Booth. Another lawyer jokes, 'Well, smoking pot and hanging out at Ashworth Hospital sounds interesting', and Ms Weerera adds, 'Actually, I think temazepam seems to be the drug of choice at Ashworth.'

Booth remarks coyly: 'I see there's a tranche of mental-health cases coming up, but it's nothing to do with me. Why are there so many photographers hanging around outside?' she asks me.

'It's the judgment on the Kilshaws' adoption appeal,' I tell her, and when I mention that the judge has halted the trial of the Leeds footballers in Hull because of an article published in the Sunday Mirror and that it's enough to make you give up journalism, she suggests, 'Well, why not try something more honourable?'

Nigel Leslie, the instructing solicitor, says Booth's greatest skill lies in her ability to get to the legal heart of the case. 'She's easy to work with, gets on with it. No aloofness. You feel that she loves her job. We started from a very difficult position in this case and finished in a position of strength. I'm happy.'

Booth takes an active part in the running of her chambers and spends time sitting as a recorder in the Crown Court. While she sees this as a public duty, it could also be the first step towards becoming a member of the judiciary. No one knows. Many women find her silence to be disappointing. A spirited and opinionated woman such as Booth could achieve much if she spoke out on behalf of working women in this country. 'She's a good role model, in particular for women at the Bar,' says Helena Kennedy QC. She has to work at being a professional in a tough job, she has to appear at her husband's side at often inconvenient times, and she has to be a housewife and mother. It is hard to know where she could find the time to be an ambassador for women as well.

Personally, she is a strange mixture of highly opinionated politician and domestic goddess. She has lost weight, joined a gym and become reconciled at occasionally leaving the anonymity of the Bar to become a public figure with an expensive wardrobe and a travelling hairdresser. Her stylist Andre Suard at Michaeljohn, in the West End, is one of a handful of top crimpers able to get away with £90 for a cut and has Kirsty Young, Melanie Griffiths and Barbara Dixon among his clients. Booth has used him for more than five years, but you won't see her in Michaeljohn's smart salon because since 1997 Andre has travelled to her.

When public figures such as Cherie Booth go out of their way to remain anonymous, they sometimes create a mystique about themselves which encourages speculation and untruths. No doubt she understands this perfectly well and has considered the odds, and no doubt she thinks it's worth the risk.
