He insisted that most of his pupils should be academically gifted and highly qualified, but after snapping up Booth, he made an exception to his rule and took on the young Anthony Blair, who came to him after scraping through the Bar finals with a modest third. It was not long before Booth and Blair started walking out together and the romance turned into history. But it was Blair to whom Irvine eventually offered the tenancy while Cherie Booth went off to George Carman at New Court. This was a strange decision by Irvine. Cherie Booth was known to be brilliant. She had the gift of being able to quickly dissect complex legal problems and a natural talent for analysis and strategic decisions. Irvine claimed she left before he could make her an offer. According to a circuit judge who knew him well, Blair was an average hack who had the priceless gift of charm; he was personable, amusing and considerably more clubbable than the reticent, slightly prickly Booth. Cherie Booth's time at New Court was not a success. She was unable to specialise in the areas such as human rights and employment law which interested her. In 1992 she left Carman and went to join Michael Beloff at 4-5 Grays Inn Square, one of the biggest and best sets in London. Beloff was immediately impressed with her. 'She made as great an impression on me in the first five minutes as anyone ever has,' he recalls. 'She played the whole thing beautifully and made her pitch without being conceited in any way.' Booth's career took flight, and she began to flourish at the Bar. She took Silk in 1995 when she was only 40 and started to pick up high-profile employment cases, such as that of Martin Neary, the Westminster Abbey organist who was dismissed. In March 1998, she was hired by the brewers Shepherd Neame to represent it in an action against the government. It was an application for leave to appeal against a judgment which had been made in favour of the Chancellor's decision to increase excise duty on beer. The brewers and, in fact, the entire brewing industry were outraged at the disparity of treatment between the UK and the member states. The case had originally been handled by Michael Beloff, but he was forced to withdraw, and when brewery director Stuart Neame was offered Cherie Booth as an alternative, he jumped at the chance. When I ask him why, he immediately replies, 'Publicity, old boy, publicity.' Cherie Booth had little to do. Before she even stood up in court, Lord Justice Richard Scott said, 'We've read your written submissions and we agree with you' and granted the brewery the right to appeal. Much to Neame's delight, the story finished up on the front pages of most of the papers. Booth never uttered a word in open court as the court had been persuaded by written argument. In 1999, Booth and a small coterie of successful barristers from 4-5 Grays Inn Square started to plot the formation of a new and revolutionary law firm. The idea was to create a medium-sized set of chambers with no more than 37 members which would offer a complete law service. There would be no 'Head of Chambers' - it would be managed by a democratically elected committee of members and would aim to reflect the legal requirements of the new millennium. Booth had much to do with establishing the core values: public-service ethic, innovation, cross-fertilisation of service and ideas, teamwork, etc. It was the antithesis of the traditional chambers. Clerking would be done away with and replaced with an administrative staff to manage members' practices, handle marketing, etc. They employed Shandwyck, the PR consultancy, to handle the media frenzy which would no doubt accompany the launch. All that was missing was a title, and after a day of deliberation, someone came up with the name Matrix. I spend an afternoon at Matrix HQ in Griffin Building, an old police station on the corner of Grays Inn and Clerkenwell roads. The reception is dominated by a translucent desk which changes colour from soft, reassuring pink to blue to yellow every 30 seconds. Members - no one is referred to as a partner - walk around in jeans and shirtsleeves, offices are glass panelled, there is an open-plan administration room inhabited by smiling PAs. A small room with a telly and a few armchairs is used by exhausted members as a common room. There are no ashtrays. The legal profession will take many years to shed its old image. Much was made about Michael Beloff's recent decision to join them before he inexplicably changed his mind and decided to return to his old set at 4-5 Grays Inn Square. Could it be that he feels more comfortable in a traditional environment rather than the new age, ground-breaking Matrix? I next bump into Booth a month later in Court 74 in the Court of Appeal on 27 March. The little chamber, tucked away at the top of the East Wing of the RCJ, is packed. The plaintiff is a 53-year-old teacher by the name of Shirley Pearce who had been persecuted by her pupils at Mayfield Secondary School in Portsmouth. Pearce is a lesbian, and the verbal and physical abuse to which she was subjected in the early 90s was the result of the children learning of her sexuality and persecuting her for it. No steps to protect her or discipline those responsible appear to have been taken by the school. When her working life became so intolerable that she was forced to go to the headmaster for help, his response was to tell her to 'grit her teeth or run away'. When the chairman of the governors wrote to say that she 'must have realised that [she] risked abuse', Pearce went to an industrial tribunal claiming sexual discrimination. The claim was rejected on the grounds that she was discriminated against because of her sexuality, not because of her gender. The appeal, which Pearce is funding personally, is opposed by Hampshire Education Authority and the governors of Mayfield School, who briefed Cherie Booth to represent them. The legal issues revolve round the law relating to human rights and sex discrimination. Booth claims that the Tribunal judgment was correct because neither the sex discrimination legislation nor the Human Rights Act has been drafted to accommodate this particular anomaly. Laura Cox QC is acting for the plaintiff, and the appeal has created a great deal of interest in the gay community. The public benches are thronged with grey-haired female ramblers and thin, bald men in black suits, while fresh-faced women wearing bikers' leathers stalk the corridors outside. The two male judges, Lord Justice Henry and Lord Justice Judge, adopt bleak, slightly appalled expressions throughout the proceedings and remain mostly silent. The third member of the bench, Lady Justice Hale, delivers terrifying questions while adopting a sinister smile in the manner of a head prefect who has caught a fifth former with a packet of Benson & Hedges. 'Ms Booth, are you really asking us to believe?' etc. Booth makes her points eloquently and seems on much surer ground among the intricacies of human rights, sexual discrimination and employment legislation. 'It is the government to blame, not my client,' she says. 'The Sex Discrimination Act is not capable of legislating on matters of sexual orientation. What have the public authorities done to infringe the plaintiff's human rights? We say, nothing at all.' Both teams have to prepare final submissions during the lunch hour. Booth and her junior retire to the crowded public snack bar for a tuna sandwich as they scribble away; papers in piles on the table and all over the floor by their feet. I have begun to realise that Booth is oblivious to her appearance in court. She gives the impression that she has clothed, fed and dispatched her kids and her husband, washed up, slapped on lipstick, grabbed her wig and gown and just made it in time for a five-hour bout of legal argument before rushing back to fix the tea. Today, she is wearing a horsehair frieze-top barrister's wig from which one of a pair of the 'babies' (curls) stitched to the tail has gone missing, a white collarett and bib, a Queen's Counsel's black gown, a black worsted jacket with gauntlet cuffs and a formal waistcoat - all from Thresher & Glenny of 67 Chancery Lane. Jewellery is minimal: a red-gold wedding band, a chunky silver ring, a bracelet and a pair of small, heart-shaped diamond earrings. She arrives in court carrying a bottle of Volvic mineral water and a packet of Kleenex tissues and keeps her private documents in a Silk's red brief bag. Her nails are unvarnished. Her hair is black with auburn tints. While she appears neat and tidy first thing, she is a habitual fidget and indulges herself with constant movement - swivelling to talk to her junior, shifting her position on the hard benches, screwing up her features as if squinting into the distance, taking her watch off and playing with it, stifling yawns, pulling her ear and dragging her hand down her face. Her habit of scratching her scalp results in her wig shifting back on her head, leaving stray locks showing in the front and dislodging the occasional strand so it hangs down across her cheek. By 3.40pm, the wig has become completely askew, endowing her with a rakish appearance at odds with the po-faced solemnity of the court. At the end of the day, after judgment has been reserved and their Lordships have departed, Cherie turns to talk to her junior and passes him a pile of papers and files from her bench. She yawns, looks at her watch and begins to disrobe in court. Her gown, jacket and waistcoat are discarded down to a revealing black v-neck sweater, over which she slips a less formal jacket and coat, ready to make a break for it out of the private entrance in Carey Street where her car awaits. As she leaves, she turns to me and says, 'Are you following me around?' 'Yes,' I tell her. The Shirley Pearce appeal lasts three days and is inconclusive, the three Lord Justices reserving judgment and making the point that many other appeals are in the pipeline. It's hard to understand why the appeal had come to court at all. Whatever one says, the fact that Cherie Booth is the Prime Minister's wife is bound to have an effect on her clients and may affect some of the judiciary, who either react against her in order to show their independence or slobber unctuously over her because she is a celebrity. While this attitude is unfortunate but probably unavoidable, there is no sign that it has affected her cases, or that her career as a barrister is suffering. Her appearance at a judicial revue on 9 April representing an inmate at the Personality Disorder Unit in Ashworth Special Hospital is an illustration of the earnings potential of the Human Rights Act. The appellant, her client Adrian Ng, a Chinese national, has been an inmate in the Personality Disorder Unit at Ashworth for 15 years. Ng, who has apparently become a model patient, was convicted of the ritual slaughter of Mai Tai Tang and her two children at The Old Bailey in November 1984. He claimed in court that he had been 'possessed by gods' and was detained indefinitely in a secure hospital. Ashworth, Rampton and Broadmoor are where our most dangerous men and women are kept, and security in these establishments is compatible with Category B prisons, although the inmates are mentally ill and therefore technically not criminally responsible. Ng is objecting to the monitoring of his private telephone calls by hospital staff, claiming that it infringes his human rights. The judgment will be made principally on written submissions and the review consequently requires only one day of the court's time. A judicial review can be used to examine whether a decision made by a public authority - in this case, the Department of Health - is irrational, unreasonable or a breach of the principle of proportionality. The hearing is presided over by His Honour Justice Newman, and Booth is up against the Department of Health and Ms Aswini Weerera representing Ashworth Hospital. She has been retained by Nigel Leslie, a solicitor who specialises in human rights and mental health. Booth makes the point that the hospital's policy of monitoring 10 per cent of private telephone conversations is incompatible with Article 8 of the Human Rights Act which entitles the individual to privacy and family life. The Department of Health argues that security considerations are such that it is vital to remove any right to privacy on the telephone. In the past, there have been numerous public inquiries into Ashworth as a result of the discovery of active paedophile rings, pornography and drugs in the hospital. The Department of Health barrister says there is a compelling need for telephone monitoring because of the special circumstances which exist in these places, the manipulative nature of many of the inmates, and the need to avoid drugs becoming more readily available. 'The Secretary of State has taken a step too far,' says Booth. 'The telephone is my client's only link with the outside world. He feels - with justification - that if a conversation with, for instance, his sister, is overheard and forms part of an analysis of his mental state by a member of staff, it could be taken out of context and he will have no redress. He should have the right of private conversation with members of his family.' When the court adjourns, the proceedings disintegrate into informality. 'I really must visit one of these places,' says Booth. Another lawyer jokes, 'Well, smoking pot and hanging out at Ashworth Hospital sounds interesting', and Ms Weerera adds, 'Actually, I think temazepam seems to be the drug of choice at Ashworth.' Booth remarks coyly: 'I see there's a tranche of mental-health cases coming up, but it's nothing to do with me. Why are there so many photographers hanging around outside?' she asks me. 'It's the judgment on the Kilshaws' adoption appeal,' I tell her, and when I mention that the judge has halted the trial of the Leeds footballers in Hull because of an article published in the Sunday Mirror and that it's enough to make you give up journalism, she suggests, 'Well, why not try something more honourable?' Nigel Leslie, the instructing solicitor, says Booth's greatest skill lies in her ability to get to the legal heart of the case. 'She's easy to work with, gets on with it. No aloofness. You feel that she loves her job. We started from a very difficult position in this case and finished in a position of strength. I'm happy.' Booth takes an active part in the running of her chambers and spends time sitting as a recorder in the Crown Court. While she sees this as a public duty, it could also be the first step towards becoming a member of the judiciary. No one knows. Many women find her silence to be disappointing. A spirited and opinionated woman such as Booth could achieve much if she spoke out on behalf of working women in this country. 'She's a good role model, in particular for women at the Bar,' says Helena Kennedy QC. She has to work at being a professional in a tough job, she has to appear at her husband's side at often inconvenient times, and she has to be a housewife and mother. It is hard to know where she could find the time to be an ambassador for women as well. Personally, she is a strange mixture of highly opinionated politician and domestic goddess. She has lost weight, joined a gym and become reconciled at occasionally leaving the anonymity of the Bar to become a public figure with an expensive wardrobe and a travelling hairdresser. Her stylist Andre Suard at Michaeljohn, in the West End, is one of a handful of top crimpers able to get away with £90 for a cut and has Kirsty Young, Melanie Griffiths and Barbara Dixon among his clients. Booth has used him for more than five years, but you won't see her in Michaeljohn's smart salon because since 1997 Andre has travelled to her. When public figures such as Cherie Booth go out of their way to remain anonymous, they sometimes create a mystique about themselves which encourages speculation and untruths. No doubt she understands this perfectly well and has considered the odds, and no doubt she thinks it's worth the risk.

webTitle: The 100 day verdicts - what the papers say

fields.headline: The 100 day verdicts - what the papers say
fields.trailText: How Bush's first 100 days have been received in the US
fields.body:
George Bush is certainly no friend of the environmentalists, as his withdrawal from the Kyoto Treaty showed. But even the President may have balked at the acres of newsprint provoked merely by his completing 14 weeks in office.

At the traditional 100-day benchmark used to assess every President against Franklin D Roosevelt's whirlwind start, Bush's 62 per cent approval rating helps his supporters to argue that he has exceeded expectations - although both the manner of his victory and the frequent campaign 'Bushisms' meant that expectations could hardly have been lower at the outset.

The debate in the US is now dividing along traditional ideological grounds - conservatives are delighted and liberals angry that Bush has governed much more conservatively than his centrist campaign suggested, despite the controversy over the legitimacy of his election.

Here are snippets of how the major American commentators have sought to sum up the 100-day landmark, along with links to the full pieces.

David Broder, The Washington Post
It is a welcome change not to have a president who seizes every situation as a stage for dramatizing his care for those in distress. But Bush in these opening months of his presidency has gone to the other extreme. It is doubtful that most voters in the country can recall hearing the President speak out on more than two occasions - Inauguration Day and his address on the budget to the joint session of Congress.

This leaves Bush without clear definition as he nears the 100-day mark of his presidency. Nothing has gone seriously wrong; few achievements are in the books; and we don't yet feel that we know him .... When the matters the country is discussing are not subjects the president is willing to address, a vital element of democratic leadership is missing. One hopes he will enlarge his concept of his job and let his voice be heard.
David Broder - The Reticient President, Washington Post

William Safire - The New York Times
Bush is mistakenly accepting the essential premises of the 100-day measurement, which are: How busy has he been? How much legislation has he stampeded Congress into passing? How profoundly has his continuing campaigning and dominance of television seized the imagination of his compatriots? How ringingly has his oratory reassured the one-third of the nation that, as F.D.R. might now say, is ill tempered, ill advised and ill at ease?

That's a fair way to assess a liberal president, but no way to assess a conservative president. The hundred-day yardstick measures activity, not stability; new entitlements, not new restraints; historic milestones, not necessary review; dramatically getting the country moving again, not quietly getting the country back on the right track.
Les Cents Jours, New York Times

Al From, The Christian Science Monitor
: When the talking stops and the walking starts, George Bush is no compassionate conservative. He's no different kind of Republican. He hasn't moved his party to the center. He's pushed it even further to the right. The president may not realize it yet, but he does that at his political peril. Voters who thought they were buying a compassionate conservative may soon become disenchanted with a president who governs as a conventional conservative. Here, too, the new president might learn from President Clinton. When voters perceived Clinton as moving left in his first two years, after running as a New Democrat, they exacted an enormous price on his party in the 1994 midterm election. So conservatives and congressional Republicans may delight today when the president veers to the right. But their mood may sour dramatically next year if the voters hold him to his promise of being a different kind of Republican. Bush's No Moderate: He's to the right of Reagan - Christian Science Monitor.

Ronald Brownstein, LA Times

From beyond the grave, the Clinton administration haunts its successor. Initially, comparisons with former President Clinton almost entirely benefited President Bush. Lately, they've emerged as one of Bush's biggest headaches. The divide, as on just about everything concerning Clinton, is the line between his personal and policy legacies.

Bush's efforts to undo specific Clinton regulations and spending decisions have generated fierce controversies. It's almost as if, on the way out, Clinton sowed land mines all across the path of his successor's first 100 days. Bush has set off the loudest explosions concerning environmental and other regulatory issues.Probably more than anything else Bush has done, these reversals have fueled the perception that he is governing more conservatively than he ran. They also contributed to the rising share of Americans in recent polls who said Bush was more concerned about big corporations than he is about ordinary citizens. In both of these respects, the Clinton administration actions established a yardstick against which Bush, involuntarily, was measured.

Bush Steps Lightly With His Agenda After Triggering Clinton Land Mines - LA Times

Andrew Sullivan - The New Republic
The press has done its best to caricature Bush as a clueless, arsenic-wielding buffoon. But he stands apart from the rest of this city primarily because of his ordinariness. He was never a high school class president or a hall monitor. He is, in many ways, the accidental president. And because of this, in striking contrast to his predecessor, he has retained a strikingly large zone of privacy. He didn't, for example, milk the homecoming of the Hainan detainees, as more professional pols like Reagan or Clinton would have.

He does his job as many other normal people do theirs--professionally and within limits. ... His wife is even more impressive on this front. She knows who she is. And she is not, ultimately, a public figure. This new delineation of what is legitimately public takes time to sink in, since it is expressed more by what is absent than by what is unmistakably present. But it is real, and it is a relief. And it is, I think, central to Bush's early success" Can you remain a human being in Washington?, The New Republic

webTitle: Channel 4 to raise cash in Square Mile

fields.headline: Channel 4 to raise cash in Square Mile
fields.trailText: Channel 4 will attempt to raise money in the City for fresh investment. This is a radical move for a broadcaster which has furiously attacked privatisation proposals, most recently from the Conservative party, as 'unthinking vandalism'.
fields.body:
Channel 4 will attempt to raise money in the City for fresh investment. This is a radical move for a broadcaster which has furiously attacked privatisation proposals, most recently from the Conservative party, as 'unthinking vandalism'.

Chief executive Michael Jackson has told The Observer that Channel 4, which will unveil an increase in revenue and profits when it publishes its annual report on Tuesday, needs more money to pursue its ambitious plans for expansion into new media markets.

'The investments we have made mean we are at the limit of what we can afford to do comfortably,' he explained. 'We want to raise money for other exploitations of the Channel 4 brand.'

The nuts and bolts will be left to the yet-to-be appointed managing director of 4 Ventures, the new business division which includes subsidiaries FilmFour, producer of hit films such as Shallow Grave, E4 and Channel 4 International. Jackson confirmed that floating some of the profitable subsidiaries was an option.

fields.headline: Jackson's hunt for cash
fields.standfirst: Critics accuse Channel 4 of dumbing down and the Tories aim to privatise it. Its bullish boss tells  Sarah Ryle he'll go to the City to fund his ambitions
fields.trailText: Critics accuse Channel 4 of dumbing down and the Tories aim to privatise it. Its bullish boss tells Sarah Ryle he'll go to the City to fund his ambitions.
fields.body:
From his office over the entrance to Channel 4's headquarters, Michael Jackson has a view of everybody who enters his empire. If there are any of his recent detractors inside, he'll know about it.

Last week he was again accused of dumbing down. Independent producers have ganged together because, they say, the broadcaster is losing its highbrow plot. More prosaically, it is also busily slashing the budgets of its 400 or so independent suppliers.

The 'snotty' coverage, as Jackson styles it, in sections of the media like the Guardian does rankle. Perhaps because he counts Georgina Henry, the paper's deputy editor, as a friend. Perhaps because it represents his natural home. He looks more like a university lecturer than an executive earning almost half a million pounds a year, or a man who would rather be in his garden shed tinkering with his chemistry set than playing the media mover and shaker.

As such he embodies the split personality of the channel he has presided over since 1997. Channel 4 is a public sector creature with a commercial alter ego. It has to satisfy the critics who want top-quality programmes but it has to fund those programmes in the real world.

Right now, he can relax a little. On Tuesday he will unveil a beefy rise in revenue and profitability that may go some way to offsetting last week's downbeat audience figures (C4's share fell to 9.3% in the first quarter). Advertising revenue in the last three months is up, he adds, despite the difficult environment (ITV has watched ad spend decline).

But even income in excess of £700m is insufficient for Jackson's ever-expanding ambitions. He reveals that the network will now go to the City for more cash. Channel 4 is demonstrably upping its commerciality whether or not it is dumbing down.

The timing of the announcement is fortuitous if not planned. Chris Smith hassaid if Labour wins the election C4 will remain in the public sector. But Jackson's plans to raise money, through share offerings in a package of subsidiaries if necessary, will undoubtedly renew calls for privatisation of the whole.

Jackson knows this, but says he will consider anything that will protect the business, in the way that he was prepared to pay anything to protect Friends and ER for C4 - the station coughed up £120m. 'You have to have a battering ram to launch a new station,' says Jackson. E4, the new pay TV spin-off, which is premiering the new series at the moment, has up to 2006 to break even and is expected to absorb £58m of investment. These days, rights to shows are sold with digital rights. Not to have a digital outlet is not a commercially sensible option. E4 has helped push C4's share of the digital audience up by 14%. FilmFour is an acknowledged brand leader and a subscription success story, having won 450,000 viewers since its launch in 1998 (the whole of ONdigital has managed fewer than 1m).

But if E4 is Channel 4 'without the shite' - in Ali G's words - perhaps the critics accusing C4 of abandoning its 'quality' image are right. Not to mention its public service remit. Jackson has an interesting take on the definition of public service. For example,of late, he says, he has been mostly thinking about computer games. He has been playing Tank Wars online and is rather taken with the prospect of a C4 games site.

Fun, and easy to charge for. You can see where he's going. So what's the public service justification, then? 'Well, we'd be investing in creativity, we'd be investing in companies up and down the country.'

So, presumably, the justification for investing in horse racing and a new interactive betting subsidiary, Go Racing, (with BSkyB and Arena, yet to be signed) is the investment in the nation's race courses.

Luckily, Jackson has other, arguably stronger arguments at hand. He points to the increased investment in Channel 4 News, which now transmits seven days of the week. There is 4 Learning, with its website Homework High, and a handful of comedy shows that do not make money. There are plans afoot for more business coverage.

He says the public receives its dividend from C4 in the form of innovation and, interestingly, in the form of a virtual community.

The broadcaster, he says, is keen to provide a central area of common ground for an increasingly 'disaggregated' nation - the stuff of coffee break conversations.

Ali G's contribution to the national wealth, goes the thinking, was to hold up a mirror to society. 'That's what Britain was like in the year it was made,' Jackson argues.

He boasts that most of the entertainment on the recent night of Comic Relief night hailed from Channel 4: Ali G, Graham Norton and Big Brother .

The strength, or weakness, of Jackson's arguments make it obvious that reconciling the traditional idea of public service with modern broadcasting is not easy.

But he wouldn't worry about that. Change is his buzzword. Change is what takes up most of his time, either provoking it or nurturing it.

fields.headline: The sack races back
fields.standfirst: A fresh wave of lay-offs is coming from bosses who feel no guilt, say  Neasa MacErlean, Jill Insley  and  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: A fresh wave of lay-offs is coming from bosses who feel no guilt, say Neasa MacErlean, Jill Insley and Tracey Boles.
fields.byline: Neasa MacErlean, Jill Insley  and  Tracey Boles
fields.body:
Redundancy and recession hit the headlines with a vengeance last week. Hot on the heels of Gordon Brown's warning that Britain could not be insulated from the world economic slowdown came news that 3,100 staff are to lose their jobs at mobile phone company Motorola in Bathgate, West Lothian, and 950 at US engineer Timken in Northampton. The closures follow job losses at Cable & Wireless, Compaq, Marconi, Cammell Laird, Ericsson and Morgan Stanley in the last three months alone.

But all of them are just a taste of what is to come, according to leading employment lawyers and the outplacement consultancies that find work for redundant staff. These advisers - who are brought in early on redundancy plans to design consultation methods and other parts of the lay-off process - are already working on further announcements for other organisations.

'There is a big increase in numbers in the pipeline,' says Michael Burd of law practice Lewis Silkin. 'There has been a big increase just in the last few weeks. An awful lot of jobs will be affected.'

Inquiries to outplacement consultancy Drake Beam Morin have risen by at least 30 per cent in the last six months. Peter Coles, its business development director,says: 'We're at a stage where organisations are coming up against worse trading than expected. Decisions that they've been playing with for a while are coming to a head.'

The banking, technology and telecommunications sectors have already started 'downsizing'. Among those expected to be hit in the coming weeks are the media and 'American-owned businesses where decisions are made in the US to have cutbacks around the world,' Burd says.

The causes are not, by and large, being attributed to the start of any UK recession but rather to problems in certain sectors - fierce competition in technology, for instance - and to the slowdown of the US and other economies.

There were 667,000 redundancies last year - well below the 1.25 million in 1992, the worst year in the last decade, but edging above 1996 and 1997, when the totals were kept to below 650,000. It looks quite possible that there will be a substantial increase in the figure for this year. It's bad enough to lose a job, but another worrying trend is that some employers are paying less in redundancy packages than they did in the Nineties.

'The amounts have really been pared back,' says Jo Bond of Right management consultants. A major reason for this is that employers have become accustomed to making people redundant and no longer throw money at the problem to assuage their guilt.

Coles of Drake Beam Morin says employers are now less willing to agree to early payment for staff in final salary pension schemes: 'This is phenomenally expensive for them. Where they were dealing with a small number of people that was fine, but as the numbers increase...'

However, they are more likely to negotiate over other benefits, such as laptops, life insurance and private medical insurance, where the cost to the employer is low but the value to the employee is high.

Some sectors retain a tradition of large pay-offs. Burd of Lewis Silkin says: 'A lot of the old ex-unionised industries have very good enhanced packages which were negotiated by the unions. And the amount of redundancy pay depends also on factors such as the nature of the industry, the strength of bargaining power [of workers] and issues such as whether the employers want to make the lay-offs in stages. If they want people to carry on working for a while they may be more generous.'

A big difference between now and 1992 is that many people who are laid off could quickly find new work, especially in South-east England. Only 5.2 per cent of the nationwide working population is unemployed, but in parts of the Home Counties the figure drops to below 1 per cent.

And there is no longer a stigma to being made redundant. Job losses through mergers and cost cutting are now ever-present. Coles says employers' attitude towards making staff redundant went through a sea change in 1991 to 1993.

He says virtually everyone now knows someone who has lost a job: 'Ten years ago, anybody being made redundant was a shock. Nowadays it's normal.'

Know your rights

If there is one time when it is worth knowing your employment rights, it is when you are being laid off. Many employees lose out because they do not know what they are entitled to. For instance, if your employer lays off 20 or more people, you could end up with another 90 days in damages if managers failed to consult with you, your union or other representatives.

So what else could you be entitled to? If your basic redundancy payment is part of your contractual agreement it is likely to be significantly more generous than statutory redundancy, which goes to all workers who have been with an employer for at least two years and is capped at £7,200.

Your contract will probably specify your notice period, but if it does not you can fall back on the statutory limits of one week's notice for each year worked (up to a maximum of 12 weeks for 12 years). Instead of working out the notice, you and your employer can agree a payment instead.

You should also decide how much you want to negotiate. If a limited number of people are being laid off, you often stand a good chance of keeping your job if you fight for it. You need to scrutinise the selection criteria your employer is required to produce and then make your case. Many banks, for example, have allowed people to stay if they can find someone to swap with them.

If you decide to go you can frequently negotiate a few additional benefits. The company car is often given to employees who ask. Similarly, it is often easy for an employer to keep someone on the company health insurance scheme for another few months.

webTitle: Now you're free to find a new life

fields.headline: Now you're free to find a new life
fields.standfirst: ... but think before spending that big cheque. It will have to last
fields.trailText: ... but think before spending that big cheque. It will have to last.
fields.byline: Neasa MacErlean, Jill Insley  and  Tracey Boles
fields.body:
When you receive your redundancy payment, you may feel that you deserve a holiday or some other treat to recover from all the stress. But Charles Levett-Scrivener of independent financial adviser Towry Law warns that it is important not to rush into spending or investing your cash.

'The first thing you must decide is what you are going to do with your life,' he says. 'Will you get another job in the same area, start a second career, become self-employed or take early retirement?'

If you decide to take early retirement, you will probably need to invest the money to produce a stable and regular income; if you plan to start your own business, you will probably need any spare cash for start-up capital.

Your employer may provide financial advice as part of the redundancy package. If not, IFA Promotion (0800 085 3250) can provide a free list of independent advisers in your area.

Initially you should pay your redundancy cheque into a high-interest account. Bristol & West's Online Easy Access account pays 6.6 per cent on deposits of £1,000 or more, while Birmingham Midshire's telephone-operated SimplySave account pays 6.25 per cent on sums of £5,000 or more. Check out the MoneyFacts website for current rates.

If you have children or other dependants your first priority should be to take out life insurance to replace the death-in-service cover you were entitled to while working.

Pay off expensive short term debts such as credit cards, personal loans and hire purchase and, if money is tight, work out if there are any other cuts you can make to household spending. If you think you may run into problems with your mortgage, contact your lender and explain the situation. Ask if you can make reduced payments for a time, or even take a payment holiday.

Once you have found a new job or retired, you will need to invest whatever is left of your redundancy payment. You may want to pay off part or all of your mortgage, but remember that unless you have a flexible mortgage, you will have to remortgage again to get access to your money.

If you were a member of your old employer's company pension scheme, you should also seek professional advice on what to do with your accumulated contributions.

Nick Bamford of pensions specialist Informed Choice says: 'There are four options open to you: you can leave the money in your old employer's scheme as a pre served pension benefit; you can switch it to your new employer's scheme; transfer it to a personal pension; or transfer it to a Section 32 buyout policy.

The decision depends on your attitude to risk, how long you expect to stay with your new employer and the relative benefits offered by the different schemes.

Bamford says you will need to supply your adviser with the 'leaving service benefit statement' that you will be given on leaving your employer.

This will enable him or her to calculate the rate of growth you need in any private arrangement to match what you are receiving in your old employer's scheme.

When indolence comes naturally

Former business development manager Peter Green wasn't expecting to stop work early, but when his employer, Panasonic, made a wave of redundancies five years ago, he decided the offer of early retirement was too good to pass up.

After working for Panasonic for 18 years his redundancy payment was 'very generous'. However, like many prospective pensioners he was worried his standard of living would fall when he gave up his job. Although he was able to draw on his Standard Life pension straight away because he was 55, he knew it would only cover his basic needs. 'I went to a financial adviser who I found through IFA Promotion and said "Make me some money",' says Peter, now 60. 'I already had some investments with Bradford & Bingley but they were not doing that well. I wanted something more pro-active.'

With the help of independent adviser Frank Cochran, Peter has built up a sizable pot of money, which enables him to live a pleasant lifestyle. As well as playing tennis, he travels a lot to Spain and the Far East. Cochran assessed Peter's attitude to risk and found that while he was essentially conservative about his investments, he was prepared to be adventurous with 30 per cent of his portfolio and speculative with another 20 per cent. With this profile in mind, they built up a portfolio designed to give him a regular sustainable income as well as growth.

He draws income from two with-profits bonds, with Sun Life (£40,000) and Scottish Widows (£20,000), which are currently returning 8.5 per cent each. A Skandia multi-Pep, offering access to more than 200 funds, has been chosen to deliver growth. It has grown from £31,607 to £52,773 since 1996. Peter also has two cash mini-Isas and an AIG guaranteed quarterly stock market bond, which limits exposure to the stock market.

Peter's investments have enabled him to move into a big house in rural Shropshire, fulfiling a dream. 'I had paid off my mortgage when I left Panasonic, but I took out another when I moved house 18 months ago - I aim to pay it off in another four years.'

So would he do it all again? 'Yes, but people are different. Some say they wouldn't know what to do with themselves, but I am naturally good at being indolent. I listen to traffic reports on the radio and think "Thank God that's not me".'

Contact IFA Promotion on 0800 085 3250.

webTitle: Forget the stigma, reap the benefits

fields.headline: Forget the stigma, reap the benefits
fields.standfirst: It is nearly always worth signing on after you've been made redundant
fields.trailText: It is nearly always worth signing on after you've been made redundant.
fields.byline: Neasa MacErlean, Jill Insley  and  Tracey Boles
fields.body:
Many people who are made redundant do not sign on. 'They associate signing on with long periods of unemployment,' says solicitor Michael Burd of Lewis Silkin. 'Many people just won't do it: they see it as an admission of defeat.'

But there are major advantages. 'Everyone should go along to the JobCentre,' says Jeff Masters of the Low Pay Unit. For a start, your entitlement to the basic state pension will be protected.

An Age Concern guide, Your Rights 2001-02 , says: 'You will receive credits towards your pension if you are drawing a benefit such as jobseeker's allowance or incapacity benefit. If you are under 60 and seeking work, it may be worth signing on (even if you are not entitled to benefit) because you will receive credits.

Many people will qualify for non means-tested jobseeker's allowance. If you have been working for some time you should have enough National Insurance contributions to entitle you to £53.05 a week for up to 26 weeks. To qualify, you must sign a 'Jobseeker's Agreement' and fulfil its conditions about the way you are looking for work.

But if you don't have enough NI credits, and have less than £8,000 in savings and other capital, you could qualify for means-tested Job skeer's Allowance. If you are living with an opposite-sex partner, their income and savings will be taken into account as well. (The law favours same-sex couples here by not treating them as a couple.)

If you have a mortgage, you can be entitled to help with repayments after nine months of redundancy. For mortgages taken out before October 1995, you get help after four months.

fields.headline: Targets of the global protest
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: When you want to change the world, don't think small. From multinationals to the cafe on your corner, the May Day protesters want to take them all on, write Paul Harris and Nick Paton Walsh.
fields.byline: Paul Harris and Nick Paton Walsh
fields.body:
When you want to change the world, don't think small. From multinationals to the cafe on your corner, the May Day protesters want to take them all on.

The diverse nature of the targets reflects different groups behind the protests but they all agree on one thing - capitalism and globalisation fail the poor. These are the people who would be first against the wall:

MCDONALD'S

Charge: Accused of exploiting workers, paying low wages and being responsible for deforestation. Also accused of harming the health of children by aggressively marketing its products towards them, and of advancing US 'cultural imperialism'.

Defence: McDonald's claims not to buy beef from rainforest or deforested land and usually buys locally. It says it pays staff above the minimum wage and publicises nutritional information about its burgers.

MONSANTO

Charge: Accused of creating GM crops, that allegedly infect the gene pool. Studies have shown genetic material from some GM pollen has crossed the species barrier and altered the genetic code of bees.

Defence: Monsanto says there is no proof that its products damage genetic structures, and instead claim the company helps agriculture across the world. They have shelved plans for the Terminator gene, which sterilises seeds.

NIKE

Charge: Accused of supporting child labour and sweatshop conditions.

webTitle: Mayday demo: For one Day only...

fields.headline: For one day only...
fields.standfirst:
Some anarchists will fire water pistols on Tuesday's demo. Police say others will have swords. The hype could deter many peaceful protesters - and bring about the worst predictions of violence

Special report: Mayday 2001
fields.trailText: Some anarchists will fire water pistols on Tuesday's demo. Police say others will have swords. The hype could deter many peaceful protesters - and bring about the worst predictions of violence.
fields.byline: Paul Harris,Nick Paton Walsh and Tony Thompson
fields.body:
Over tender chicken breast served with saffron rice the talk was of revolutionaries plotting chaos on the streets of London.

May Day was still two months away, but the message from the police was clear: there would be no repeat of last year's anarchist riots. As he dined with a succession of newspaper executives, Sir John Stevens, Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, revealed the protesters would be shown no mercy. A zero tolerance approach would crush them. London's monuments would be untouched by vandals. 'We will not allow them to go ahead. They won't be doing it to the Cenotaph again,' he said.

Long before the first brick is thrown and the first police truncheon falls, the battle for May Day has raged fiercely - but over the net and in the media, not on the streets.

Stevens' lunch tour was the first salvo and launched a police media campaign to portray the protesters as a dangerous threat. Photographs of suspected ringleaders have been circulated freely to the press. Never mind that the people involved have never been identified, let alone charged with any specific offences. Newspapers, eager to run the colourful copy, lapped up the steady stream of scare stories.

The anarchists were thousands strong, they wrote; some would carry samurai swords; they had links to the Real IRA; they were being trained in US camps and many were battle-hardened by protests from Seattle to Prague. Police raided an empty south London building they termed a camp for anarchists. They destroyed the squat - and took along a Sunday Telegraph journalist - as they pointed ominously to a graffito on the wall that read, 'Smash police skulls'.

London's Mayor Ken Livingstone also joined the fray on the side of the police. He warned protesters to stay away and left no doubt any police action would have his approval. Anita Roddick, founder of Body Shop, was vilified for donating money to training programmes in non-violent protest, but some of the May Day anarchists actually oppose her business.

For observers of the tiny British anarchist scene, the hype has been astonishing. 'Not since the anarchist scare of the 1890s has British anarchism had a media profile like this. It is quite amazing,' said political scientist Ben Franks, who wrote a PhD on the subject at Nottingham University.

Now thw media skirmishes are over. Physical battle lines will be drawn on Tuesday. Backing up the police public relations offensive is an enormous operation designed to cope with hundreds, if not thousands, of arrests. More than 6,000 officers will be on duty with more on stand-by. Dog units, mounted officers and police helicopters will all be deployed. Police have identified 300 potential targets and plan to defend them all. They will employ undercover 'spotters' who have been memorising the faces of dozens of activists to be arrested on sight.

An armoured JCB will remove cars and other barricades while trained climbing specialists will tackle those who scale buildings and chain themselves to public structures. The Cenotaph and the statue of Churchill, daubed and given a mohican haircut of turf during the last protest, will be boarded up.

'Anyone who commits any kind of criminal activity will be held to account,' Assistant Commissioner Mike Todd told The Observer: 'They may arrive under the impression that, because there will be so many of them, the police will not be able to deal with them all. That will not be the case.'

For many protesters the media onslaught was a shock. It painted a radically different picture to their own small-scale PR campaign that had filtered through to the newspapers via the internet and stickers pasted on walls.

Their focus was on Monopoly, a game picked as an ironic symbol of anti-capitalism and an excuse to tour London causing chaos. Websites were set up inviting people to join in, and a mock Monopoly board was created as a guidebook. The idea was simple. It was also funny, as was the fact that the group organising it called itself the Wombles (White Overall Movement for Building Liberation through Effective Struggle). Protests will include musical street parties, water pistols and giant inflatable dice. At first glance, the event would seem to be more like Rio than riot.

The police scare tactics were a huge setback. With all the talk of police guns and protesters' swords, there were fears thousands of people would be scared off. Any chance of a tolerant greeting from ordinary citizens also seemed to have disappeared.

At a meeting a week ago, closed to the media but attended by an undercover Observer reporter, one of the May Day leaders urged people not to talk to the press. 'We have had our fingers burnt. We have learnt our lessons,' said Andy, whose surname is known only to associates.

Not everyone agreed. Other protesters began to emerge, eager to portray themselves in a less sinister light. Emails started arriving in newspaper offices, hitherto obscure groups began to write press releases. Many were from the radical Left, such as Revolution, while anarchist bodies such as Class War remained aloof.

The police media campaign, protesters said, was paving the way for violence. By creating the public perception of bloodthirsty anarchists preparing to rampage, they were pre-justifying a planned assault. The police had scores to settle from last year and were looking for any excuse to crack heads.

'Some people are preparing for violence on May Day,' said a Revolution statement. 'They are bringing 1,000 outside agitators on top of 5,000 hardened regulars. They will be masked up to conceal their identity, they will be armed to the teeth. They have a planning HQ at New Scotland Yard.'

In any battle there are casualties. But in this PR war the victims have been people like Alfred Scott. On May Day, Scott, 25, will take a day off work, don white overalls and a mask and head to Oxford Street. In police terms that is enough for him to be a major target. He fears a bad beating or worse.

But the quietly spoken doctor does not look like a threat to the state. Sitting in a north London cafe, he wore a shirt and tie. He has a neat haircut and an accent that would make any middle-class parent proud. But he is afraid. 'Violence is going to happen. The police have assured that. But I am a pacifist by nature. I just want to go along and protest and make my views known,' he said.

Those views are the usual mix of left-wing sympathies for the poor and the Third World, an anger at Thatcherism and a feeling that capitalism has not provided an answer to all the world's needs.

Ben, a 16-year-old from Watford doing his GCSEs, will also be going. 'I don't pretend to have a lot of political knowledge, but a lot of things are being ignored in the world, that are not known about and should be. Third World poverty appals me,' he said.

It is not radical stuff, but the flames of violence have been so fanned over the past week that Scott will be bringing his first aid kit on the march. 'People are going to get hurt, I know it. I feel that I have to use my knowledge of medicine to help people when the police attack them,' he said.

But the innocent protesters do hide an extremist hard core bent on violence. The Monopoly board concept masked a serious intent. Last year the protesters were contained by police in Trafalgar Square. It hampered their attempts to cause real disruption and allowed hundreds to be corralled together and filmed by police cameramen. A widespread Monopoly tour of the capital would ensure that such an event did not happen again.

'Last year was really considered a failure by some. But this year we will have 20 to 30 events going off all over the place at the same time. It will not be a failure again,' said Charlie, who has been attending protests for two years.

Many of the hard core will be the same people behind the violence last year. Thought to number little more than 50, there is a strong contingent linked to the Kurdish community, which is supportive of Turkish Communist groups, and also the Italian anarchist group Ya Basta. Others come from British groups such as Class War or the anti-roads campaign, Reclaim The Streets, which organised last year's protests. Sprinkled among them will be a few militant environmentalists, such as Green Anarchists and Earth First, and hardline revolutionary Communists.

These are the activists who make up the real leadership of the Wombles and they intend to dress in the white-padded overalls first used on Italian protests. Few of their full identities are known. One of the leading Wombles is Lunghi, whose first name is a mystery. Police know only that he is Italian-born and believe he is dangerous. After May Day, the Wombles will disband. Next year they will be back in a new guise.

For these people, much of the Monopoly board is just a diversion. The real trouble could start anywhere at anytime and violence is on the agenda. Many of the groups attending the protests swim in the crowded but tiny pond of left-wing extremist politics.

The only way to guarantee coverage of their groups is to make sure the media get the pictures they want. Peaceful protests rarely generate good television. Smashed windows and smashed heads do.

'If it went off peacefully there would be nothing in the newspapers. That would be no fun,' said Stephen Micaoel, an anarchist poet and squatter.

Many of the Wombles agree. One of their leaders, Mike, knows it is inevitable. He does not consider damage to property to be violent. It is political expression. 'Violence involves giving pain to another live being. A window does not feel pain,' he said.

Shops across the capital, from McDonald's to a west London fur shop, from Mayfair hotels to Coutts Bank, are braced for the worst. None has plans to close for the day, but if the worst comes to the worst their shutters will come rattling down. All have drafted in extra security.

Amid the smoke and mirrors of the pre-protest media sparring match only one thing has become clear - no one now expects a peaceful demonstration. In that respect, police and hard core protesters could both get what they want. The police will arrest hundreds and the demonstrators will be splashed across every front page. The Battle for May Day would have been won by extremism on both sides. Only people like Alfred Scott would have lost.

Mayday the cast

Starring...

SIR JOHN STEVENS plays the big sherriff: As the top cop in town, it is Sir John's task to defend the city against the barbarian horde descending on its innocent citizens. Does not like swords.

ANITA RODDICK plays the damsel in distress: She's got double trouble, after getting mixed up with training camps for protesters. But some of the marchers hate Body Shop anyway.

KEN LIVINGSTONE plays the turncoat: Marvel as he becomes an unexpectedly staunch ally of the police and foe to the protesters. He saw the writing on the wall and went with the boys in blue.

RONALD MCDONALD plays the dastardly villain: Ronald claims he is miscast, but protesters are convinced his company ruins people's health and want to wipe the smile off his face.

...and not forgetting the chief attraction: THE WOMBLES!

webTitle: Met tactics raising May Day riot threat

fields.headline: Met tactics raising May Day riot threat
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mayday 2001
Focus: For one day only...
fields.trailText: Police were last night accused of over-reacting to the threat of May Day violence in London and creating an atmosphere which makes a serious riot more likely.
fields.byline: Paul Harris, Nick Paton Walsh and Tony Thompson
fields.body:
Police were last night accused of over-reacting to the threat of May Day violence in London and creating an atmosphere which makes a serious riot more likely.

As thousands of protesters begin to arrive in the capital, fears have grown that the 'zero tolerance' approach will inflame tensions and spark violent scenes much worse than those of last year, when the Cenotaph was defaced and a statue of Winston Churchill decorated with turf.

Several MPs have criticised police tactics. Labour backbencher Alan Simpson said he believed elements within the police and the Home Office were 'looking for a ruck' with the protesters, made up of anarchists, environmentalists and other fringe groups. "Of course if you look for it you will find it,' Simpson said.

Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes said that there was a danger the police could overreact following last year's disturbances, while the Government was too keen to appear tough on law and order. 'Both the police and Government have something to prove,' he said.

More than 5,000 officers will be on duty in the capital on Tuesday - one policeman for every protester expected to attend. On stand-by are police dog teams, motorbike units and even an armoured JCB to remove barricades.

Experts in crowd behaviour warned that the police operation and media campaign against a small group of pro-violence activists could turn a peaceful protest into a riot. 'In demonising a hardcore minority they give them a huge power over the remainder of the crowd,' said Dr John Drury, a Sussex University psychologist.

Last night police in Kent were watching Channel ports, responding to fears that the protests will be hijacked by extremists from the Continent. Eastern European far-right groups and Basque separatists are known for their interest in the anti-globalisation movement. 'It's a popular body of ideas that some groups want to hijack to increase their profile,' said a police source.

Police are frank about their desire to keep peaceful demonstrators away. 'We have had a great deal of success in discouraging legitimate protesters from attending the event,' said Assistant Commissioner Mike Todd, who heads the operation.

But human rights group Liberty said: 'We are worried that the right to peaceful protest is being harmed.'

fields.headline: Cheers, Miss Bush. You're nicked
fields.standfirst: The Bush Files
fields.trailText: Jenna Bush, 19, one of George W. Bush's twin daughters, has been arrested and charged with under-age drinking.
fields.body:
Jenna Bush, 19, one of George W. Bush's twin daughters, has been arrested and charged with under-age drinking in Austin, Texas, in the latest embarrassing incident involving the US President's daughter.

Already Ms Bush has faced allegations in the supermarket tabloid The National Enquirer from fellow students at her university in Austin that she is partial to marijuana. She has also been photographed tumbling to the ground in a female friend's arms at her fraternity party, apparently the worse for wear.

In the most serious incident, Ms Bush instructed her secret service bodyguards to accompany her to a Fort Worth jail to bail out a friend accused of being drunk in public.

Commentators have already drawn comparisons with the wild youth of the President, who was partial to drink and has skirted round allegations of cocaine use.

At 1.30am yesterday President Bush was asleep in the White House, preparing for an early flight to Texas on Air Force One for a speech inaugurating a new museum. Jenna, meanwhile, was in a popular Austin bar called Cheers. Two officers entered, having walked, unknowingly, past Jenna's secret service guards. The memorably brief police citation on Jenna read: 'Glass of beer - drank from it.' She will appear in court on Wednesday.

Assistant Police Chief Michael McDonald said Jenna was 'very co-operative' as were the Secret Service agents who had stayed 'just outside' and 'were not aware she was consuming alcohol'.

The offence does not entail a custodial sentence unless the offender is 'intoxicated', said another police spokesman. But it can carry a fine of $200 or a period of community service, which will be determined by the courts on Wednesday.

The Fort Worth episode was more serious, with Jenna's 18-year-old friend jailed for four hours after his arrest at a party when he called for Jenna Bush and her bodyguards, according to Fort Worth sheriff Dee Anderson.

webTitle: Cabal of lawyers drives Bush further to right

fields.headline: Cabal of lawyers drives Bush further to right
fields.standfirst: The Bush Files
fields.trailText: The moderate safeguards in US law are being swept aside, reports  Ed Vulliamy in Washington.
fields.body:
George W. Bush's administration - 100 days old today - is being hailed as his country's most ideologically right-wing of the past 100 years, across a spectrum of policies ranging from the environment to labour, civil rights to social issues.

But the rip tide that cuts beneath all Bush's plans to transform the landscape, with more durable results than any other policy, is the hijacking - behind closed doors - of the US judiciary.

The administration - to which power was in effect granted by the Supreme Court in a controversial ruling last December - is preparing not only to set the highest court in the land on course for a conservative generation, but has quietly revolutionised the way in which all federal judges are appointed to benches across the country, guaranteeing politically right-wing selections.

At the core of this manoeuvre, which will weave a new fabric in US society, is a tightly organised right-wing lawyers' group which has come in from the fringes to the core of the administration.

It is called the Federalist Society, of which Bush's Solicitor General Theodore Olson, Interior Secretary Gale Norton, Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham and Senate Judiciary Committee chairman Orrin Hatch are leading members - as are many members of the new White House counsel team.

Stalwart conservative judges on the Supreme Court Anthony Scalia and Clarence Thomas are patrons and guests of the group, and Attorney General John Ashcroft is a close affiliate.

The emergence of the Federalists is traced in a study by the New York-based Institute for Democracy Studies, which concludes that 'extreme conservative organisations sponsoring a combination of right-wing litigation and advocacy are opening the way for a radical transformation of the American legal system'.

Ralph Neas, President of the Washington think-tank People for the American Way, says that 'the White House counsel's office and the Department of Justice are being turned over to the Federalist Society, a bastion of far-right legal thought'.

The Federalist Society's philosophy underpins, and is ready to steer, all the administration's cornerstone policies on deregulation of environmental and labour law, education, civil rights and abortion. The author of the IDS study, Julie Gerchik, says that 'the agenda is to dismantle everything built since the New Deal'. There was even a Federalist panel in Chicago on 28 March entitled 'Rolling Back the New Deal'.

'Where is the divide between politics and the law here?' says Gerchik. 'This is politics enforced by legal mechanisms.'

The society has already had an impact on major decisions: when Bush pulled America out of the Kyoto treaty on climate change, he did so after reading what he called 'important new information'. That information was a report commissioned by David McIntosh, a Federalist Society founder, arguing that toxic emissions were exaggerated and warning of costs to business.

But above all, the society has ousted the legal establishment which - in the form of the profession's traditional representative body, the American Bar Association - has helped oversee the selection of judges and guarantee the profession's integrity for five decades.

Since Eisenhower, the ABA has had a semi-official role in advising on judicial appointments. But in a sudden, little-noticed move last month, President Bush cut the ABA entirely out of the appointment process. The Federalists were delighted, having for years targeted the association (in a special publication, ABA Watch) for such issues as its support for gun control and opposition to the death penalty.

The ABA's removal creates a vacuum in the recommendation of judges, and into it has moved a 15-person committee formed between the White House and Justice Department urgently to seek candidates for some 100 vacancies to federal benches (one-eighth of all judges).

This recommending committee is firmly in the hands of the Federalist Society, controlled by Deputy Attorney General Larry Thompson, a society member, and others. Sources add that some 70 judges have so far been interviewed, a quarter of them recommended by the Federalist Society.

The society was founded 20 years ago with a mission to beat back what it saw as a liberal orthodoxy permeating public policy and the courts since the Civil Rights movement.

Society members propelled the attempted impeachment of President Clinton over the Lewinsky scandal. Prosecutor Kenneth Starr was an active member, as were many of his team.

Its major benefactor is the Scaife Foundation, controlled by billionaire conservative magnate Richard Mellon Scaife, who deploys his fortunes to advance right-wing causes. Among those causes was the 'Arkansas Project', initiated by Scaife at a cost of $24 million to mount the suit by Paula Jones - and eventually Lewinsky - against the President.

The first meeting between Scaife and the 'Arkansas Project' was chaired by Theodore Olson, who steered it and is now Solicitor General of the US, the country's most influential lawyer, head of the Federalist Society's Washington chapter, based in the White House.

Olson cut his teeth under Starr in the Reagan administration, and was counsel to Reagan during the Iran-Contra affair. He was himself investigated (but not indicted) by a special prosecutor for lying to Congress, and went on to become chairman of the American Spectator magazine, which 'broke' the Paula Jones story. His wife Barbara is a pivot of the Washington right-wing social circuit, herself chairwoman of a conservative women's organisation funded by Scaife.

From this background, Olson emerged into the public glare as George Bush's knight and mouthpiece, triumphantly arguing the President's case against the Florida recounts in the Supreme Court and ultimately winning him the election.

The Federalists' other channel to power has been through clerkships at the Supreme Court under sympathetic judges Scalia, Thomas, Kennedy - and Chief Justice William Rehnquist.

Many saw Bush's victory as a watershed moment when the judges put politics above the law. But it is to the future of the court over the next four years - and thence a generation - that the Federalists are looking.

The backgrounds of the Supreme Court's main conservatives are contentious: Justice Rehnquist was author of the memo during the historic Brown vs. Board of Education case in 1952 supporting racial segregation, saying: 'It is about time the court faced the fact that white people in the South don't like the coloured people'.

But Rehnquist and the court's other conservatives have always toiled in counterpoint with liberal appointees and moderate Republicans. However, only this week, a 5-4 verdict on an apparently innocuous case about driving licences in Alabama cut a major inroad into the 1964 Civil Rights Act, ruling that individuals cannot now sue federal agencies over discrimination cases.

In the hands of Bush's legal team now are two possible appointments during his term of office which could swing the court decisively to the right.

The Federalists are not the only group taking care to ensure a conservative federal judiciary. Three right-wing organisations funded by the Scaife Foundation have organised a series of junkets so that judges can attend political seminars on the advantages of deregulation in environment, labour and civil rights law.

They are the Law and Economics Centre, the Liberty Fund and FREE - the Foundation for Research on Economics and the Environment, which funded all-expenses-paid trips, some lasting as long as two weeks, to luxury venues, featuring golf and horse-riding for the justices.

As well as money from the ubiquitous Scaife family, both the FREE and the LEC trips for judges are bountifully funded by oil giants Shell and Exxon, and Philip Morris cigarettes.

Many of the judges who enjoyed them failed - by their own admission - to disclose these junkets on their annual financial reports, as required by their own federal ethics laws, according to the Washington-based watchdog group Community Rights Counsel.

The CRC found that judges' attendance at the junket seminars 'increased significantly between 1992 and 1998' with a record 88 judges taking trips in 1998. With 800 active judges at any time, this means that about 10 per cent of the federal judiciary takes a trip each year.

An exhaustive study by the CRC of seminars and subsequent verdicts by judges who attended them finds 'doctrinal shifts' and 'considerable evidence that the education judges receive' has led to 'a strand of judicial activism that is distinctly pro-market, clearly hostile to federal environmental regulations and decidedly in keeping with the curriculum of FREE seminars'.

webTitle: 'Duty Free Man' is air rage culprit

fields.headline: 'Duty Free Man' is air rage culprit
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: He is known simply as 'Duty Free Man'. The first British study of air rage attacks has found the type of person most likely to blow their top at 30,000 feet is male, in his thirties, en route to Europe or the US with family or friends, drunk and desperate for a cigarette.
fields.body:
He is known simply as 'Duty Free Man'. The first British study of air rage attacks has found the type of person most likely to blow their top at 30,000 feet is male, in his thirties, en route to Europe or the US with family or friends, drunk and desperate for a cigarette.

He might assault the crew, sexually harass women or simply attack his fellow passengers. But when the plane lands, he is increasingly likely to face a stint in jail. The study, by the UK Airport Police Commanders, examined all incidents of violence and misbehaviour at airports across the UK in the past eight months in an effort to profile typical offenders. It reveals:

 Three quarters of incidents involved men, and a third involved men aged 30 to 39.

 Most were British and three-quarters were white.

 The majority were travelling in company.

'There are noticeable trends,' said superintendent Tim Burgess, chairman of the UK Airport Police Commanders Association. 'There are factors like holiday stress, a lack of trolleys for their bags, and security searching them that can contribute. But eventually it's down to the predisposition of someone to be violent.

'For many people their holiday starts before they board the aircraft, in the pub the night before, for instance. Alcohol is often the underlying contributing factor.'

The identification of 'Duty Free Man' comes as authorities battle with record numbers of violent incidents on flights. Figures given to The Observer by the Civil Aviation Authority show a 10 per cent rise in reports of 'disruptive behaviour' over the past year. Passenger-on-passenger violence has also risen by 50 per cent in the last year, from eight incidents a month in 1999 to 12 in 2000.

Airlines have become increasingly strict about passenger conduct at airports and during flights, prompting concerns that a 'zero-tolerance' policy encourages dangerous behaviour. Simon Evans, of the Air Transport Users Council, said: 'While we support all measures to stem this behaviour, it is very important that airlines are not tempted into over-reaction. Staff must be properly trained to lower the temperature and not exacerbate it.'

webTitle: Scotland must play to its strengths, says ex-chief

fields.headline: Scotland must play to its strengths, says ex-chief
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: A former chief executive of the Scottish Tourist Board has warned that, while the 2001 season is set to be a 'disaster', there should be no rush to find a new leader for the industry.
fields.body:
A former chief executive of the Scottish Tourist Board has warned that, while the 2001 season is set to be a 'disaster', there should be no rush to find a new leader for the industry.

Derek Reid, chief executive of the board from 1994-96, said: 'This year is going to be a disaster. We can pretty much write it off, but we must now look to 2002.'

Following the turmoil surrounding the short-lived appointment of Rod Lynch, he said it would be difficult to find someone of the calibre required quickly. 'The driving force of the industry is not structures but the consumer,' Reid added. 'We are underperforming. We are not meeting the needs of modern consumers.

'The targets that have been set in recent years have been missed. It was heading this way before foot and mouth and its terribly puerile to blame the weather and the strong pound.

'Ireland has been showing very high rates of growth. If the Irish tourist industry can grow then why can't ours?' Reid added that the Scottish industry must begin to exploit its strengths such as golf, culture and heritage. 'We might have some of the top courses in the world but it can be very difficult to get a game on the likes of Muirfield, Gleneagles and Turnberry,' he said. 'The Irish built 27 new courses and pitched them as places where visitors could play.'

He also called for a switch of focus away from the major population centres. 'Rural Scotland is on its knees. The Executive needs to work with public bodies to direct investment beyond the central belt.'

Meanwhile, Shadow Tourism Minister Kenny McAskill called for the operations of visitscotland, as the board is now known, and Scottish Enterprise to be linked.

'Tourism and the economy go hand in hand. So much so that it's always seemed rather bizarre to me that the management of these sectors is not linked,' he said.

'At a minimum, cooperation is required between investment strategy and the tourist industry.'

McAskill added that going down that road would make matters such as infrastructure easier to deal with. 'There has to be a wholesale review of how the industry operates. It is time to start again with a blank sheet of paper and a bigger marketing budget,' he said.

The Shadow Tourism Minister added that any changes to how the industry was managed would have to be more than superficial, and called on the Executive to make the most of its representatives abroad.

'An approach is required that ties in with the Executive's representation in Brussels and the attaché that will be based in Washington. Selling Scotland is an international responsibility.'

webTitle: Bloody Sunday probe hit by secrets row

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday probe hit by secrets row
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: Doubts have been thrown on the credibility of the Bloody Sunday inquiry if key military intelligence documents are not disclosed.
fields.body:
Doubts have been thrown on the credibility of the Bloody Sunday inquiry if key military intelligence documents are not disclosed.

Home Secretary Jack Straw and Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon are seeking public interest immunity (PII) certificates to prevent material being disclosed to Lord Saville's tribunal, which resumes tomorrow after a break of several weeks.

The intelligence material includes further details on unsubstantiated claims by an alleged IRA informer - code-named 'Infliction' - that Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness, now Northern Ireland's Minister of Education, fired the first shot on 30 January 1972.

McGuinness strenuously denies the claim. His lawyers are in negotiation to establish whether he will be protected from prosecution. The grant of a PII certification would make it impossible to test whether the informer's claim could be substantiated.

Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams this month called on the Prime Minister to ensure full disclosure. He said: 'I believe we are watching a serious attempt being made to subvert the Saville inquiry, by those within the British military and political establishment who are intent on preventing the inquiry from getting to the whole truth.'

He said adequate disclosure was being denied of army photographs and film footage from helicopters. Soldiers' rifles fired on Bloody Sunday have been destroyed - some after the Saville inquiry was announced. If the tribunal refuses to accept PII certification, it may be overruled by judicial review. This happened on the issue of anonymity for military witnesses.

Earlier this year, a civilian witness was cross-examined by a lawyer representing soldiers about a criminal conviction in England in 1965. The witness asked if there would be an equivalent chance to cross-examine soldiers. Since they are not to be named, this seems unlikely.

The Ministry of Defence will not contend that any of the 13 dead on Bloody Sunday or a fourteenth who died later were actually carrying weapons on the day - only that they must have been close to people who were. But military lawyers will apparently insist that more than 30 IRA bombers and gunmen were smuggled away, dead or wounded - a story long ago dismissed as myth in Derry.

There has also been concern at the tribunal's cost, now running at some £41 million with a possible final bill of over £100m, now that the inquiry is not expected to conclude until 2003.

webTitle: Top police officers held in drug raid arrests

fields.headline: Top police officers held in drug raid arrests
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Two officers working for Britain's most elite police force, the National Crime Squad, have been arrested in a series of raids aimed at smashing a drug ring operating within the organisation.
fields.body:
Two officers working for Britain's most elite police force, the National Crime Squad, have been arrested in a series of raids aimed at smashing a drug ring operating within the organisation.

The arrests, the latest in a series of corruptions scandals to dog the organisation, were among 10 made by Derbyshire police in the early hours of Saturday morning.

The 10, identified only as five men and five women, all in their thirties and forties, were detained on suspicion of possessing and supplying cocaine and cannabis. Drugs were recovered from three premises that were raided.
