The spokesman said: 'The other three are from Derbyshire, although two of those have previously served with the National Crime Squad. All the officers are of constable or sergeant rank.'

webTitle: How the capital of  cool lost its allure

fields.headline: How the capital of  cool lost its allure
fields.standfirst:
Four years ago London was hailed by Newsweek as the coolest city on the planet. Now even Fishguard gets more plaudits. Amelia Hill discovers why the gloss has worn off and asks just what has gone wrong

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Four years ago London was hailed by Newsweek as the coolest city on the planet. Now even Fishguard gets more plaudits. Amelia Hill discovers why the gloss has worn off and asks just what has gone wrong.
fields.body:
It was the moment Londoners stopped apologising for the drabness, the traffic, their manners and the price of a cappuccino. Suddenly, everything was cool, sophisticated, innovative and of such quality that the rest of the world could only watch in envy.

It was 4 November 1996 and the capital was, officially and categorically, labelled the coolest city on the planet. 'When I wrote that cover article for Newsweek , London was bubbling over with creativity and verve,' said Stryker McGuire, UK editor of the American magazine.

'The city's clubs, fashion industry, art world, architecture and general lifestyle were streets ahead of anything the rest of the world had to offer,' he added. 'My only concern was that enough people wouldn't be able to get here in time to enjoy the fun because one thing was certain: it wouldn't last.'

And it hasn't. Four years after coolly accepting the accolade, London has come back to earth with a bump. This week could see the city descend into chaos, paralysed by May Day rioters and disgruntled Tube workers.

This is just the climax to a litany of grinding problems, apparently unsolved despite the election exactly a year ago of a maverick Mayor. In the past few weeks alone, accounts of gangland shootings have hit the headlines; tourists have deserted the capital in droves, frightened off by stories of national malaise; Mayor Ken Livingstone has failed to resolve the Tube crisis and the city's stock has plummeted in the eyes of the world.

So steeply, in fact, that the latest edition of the Lonely Planet travel guide unceremoniously stripped the city of its crown of cool, condemning it instead for its worship of commerce over culture and awarding it the wooden spoon.

'It's not a great time for London's tourist industry,' admitted Lonely Planet 's Jennifer Cox. 'But this book is extremely positive about the majority of places in Britain. We rave about Fishguard.'

How did London lose out to Fishguard? A cursory glance at the paeans inspired by the London Eye, the Tate Modern, Somerset House, British Museum and the restored Wallace Collection seems to prove that the capital's cultural life is still bubbling.

Leading architects including Richard Rogers and Norman Foster are continuing their transformation of the city and, when it finally reopens, the Millennium bridge will enable tourists and natives alike to view the chaos all around them, once magnificent, now depressing.

'Londoners and foreigners alike are on a generalised downer about the city,' said McGuire. 'It's a feeling that may not be justified by facts and figures, but the psychology of depression that's going around now is just as important.'

The irony is that London has done much to puncture its own myth: the gloss of smugness, with which it assumed that its natural verve and vitality would hide any multitude of sins, has been rubbed away, revealing a natural pessimism.

'Where once there was hope and expectation in London, there's now disillusion and apathy,' said McGuire. 'In the last year or so there has been a sudden convergence of the scepticism and cynicism bred by disappointment. Now people who may have said the glass was half-full four years ago are calling it half-empty.'

Part of the problem was the attempt by Prime Minister Tony Blair in the wake of Newsweek 's piece to trade on London's success. With the age-old wisdom of the terminally uncool, the Government failed to appreciate that the moment it nominated representatives of cool to sip champagne in Downing Street, it ensured the termination of their reputation with deadly accuracy.

Not that this would normally matter, pointed out Rachael Philipps, editor of Time Out 's 'Sell Out' section. One of the central reasons for London's coolness is its ability to spawn and gobble up trends.

But a stillness to London's once whitewater-rapid waters has emerged from the ripples that emanated from Newsweek 's article. A self-fulfilling prophecy of despair is sucking the city down. The malaise can be seen from the top deck of any bus: the No 38, for example, links Hackney, where more shootings take place than anywhere else in Britain, to Piccadilly Circus, battening down its hatches against the May Day rioters.

'I don't know whether it's because the absence of political opposition has taken the positive tension out of the system,' said McGuire. 'But until something changes, this cultural and intellectual stagnation is going to continue and the mood is going to worsen.'

In his book, London: A Biography, Peter Ackroyd tells how London is anthropomorphised in different forms depending on the mood of the time: in times of optimism, the city is portrayed as a young man, lithe and vital; in times of trouble, it becomes a deformed giant, swollen headed and shrunken limbed, choked by ashes and killing more than it breeds.

'This is a city built on money, power, trade and commerce,' said Ackroyd. 'It is uniquely brutalising and ugly, built on the imperatives of money, not the need of its citizens.'

Although crime has fallen overall, police worry that the criminals have simply moved out of the engorged centre and into the less high-profile outlying areas: there were 17 per cent more homicides in south London last year than in 1999, and 8 per cent more in the east.

In the centre of the city, including Theatreland and the rest of the West End, there is evidence that few inroads have been made into serious crime. 'I've been coming to London for business and holidays every year for the past decade and I've never felt so insecure,' said Wafa Omar, pausing in front of a yellow police sign in Leicester Square asking for help with a murder. 'They say crime is down but, to me, it feels more theatening.'

As the map of London grows ever bigger, as the Outer Metropolitan Area melds into the Greater London and Inner London areas, tourists and natives alike begin to feel they are losing grasp of London's true identity.

Rob Humphreys, editor of the London Rough Guide for the past 15 years, believes the city has simply become too big: 'There's very little sense of self in London any more,' he said.

'There's no coherent sense of identity in the city as a whole, there are just a load of disparate communities which swallow people up, all too often forcing them into deprived pockets which they can't get out of.'

Standing on the Royal Victoria Dock footpath down by the Dome, the heart of of London's renewal, Alan Craig bears testimony to this claim. All around him glint signs of the much-praised redevelopment of London's eastern river corridor: cranes dip over the half-built ExCel exhibition centre, finishing touches are now being put to the University of England's campus, shining cars accelerate away from the Britannia Village and planes roar in towards London City Airport.

In the midst of this activity, however, Craig runs a community project, the Mayflower centre, on the Kier Hardie estate in Ordnance ward, Canning Town, Britain's most deprived district.

'We've been waiting for this sort of regeneration for decades,' said Craig. 'We were delighted when all this started happening a few years ago. We thought it was proof that London was really on the up.'

But instead the local council announced in February that 1,900 households were going to be served with compulsory purchase orders and moved out of the area so that private, wealthy tenants could be moved in.

'This treatment exposes the lie at the heart of the claim that London is a modern city of cool,' said Craig.

'The Government has a vision about what they want London to be like and they're determined to achieve that despite the little people getting in the way.

'We were ignored by the previous government, which was bad enough, but this area has two sorts of poverty now - the poverty of material things and the poverty of complete disempowerment.'

webTitle: The debt we must bear for Africa

fields.headline: The debt we must bear for Africa
fields.standfirst:
If the G7 can afford to cancel the debt of African nations, why can't the IMF and World Bank?

Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Bob Geldof asks if the G7 can afford to cancel the debt of African nations, why can't the IMF and World Bank?
fields.body:
This evening in Trafalgar Square Nelson Mandela will once again not only represent his country but also that great moral courage rightly applauded by the admiring crowds in London and around the world.

I visited him recently in his home in Johannesburg. I had come to show him a report that proves what Drop the Debt, the continuation of the hugely successful Jubilee 2000 campaign, has been saying for a long time. The World Bank and the IMF can afford to cancel 100 per cent of the debts owed by the poorest countries, just as the Group of Seven (G7) richest nations already have done.

The sombre reality of a continent he has done so much to change and lead by example preoccupied and troubled him. He talked of his profound sorrow at the Aids pandemic gripping the continent and under which 20 per cent of the people of his own country suffer. He spoke, without bitterness but with frustration, about the clear linkage between Africa's debt problem and the continent's inability to deal effectively with the massive destruction caused by this terrible disease.

He told me how Zambia loses two thirds of its trainee teachers to HIV each year. How the result has brought to a shattering halt the tiny education system in that country. How Zambia pays more in debt repayments to us than on its entire healthcare budget. How ridiculous it is that Zambia, having entered the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) initiative, which is supposed to end the debt crisis, will end up paying more in debt than they did prior to entering the initiative, as a result of the complex, arbitrary and ineffective series of financial hurdles the World Bank and IMF have imposed on these countries.

And how on average there has been only a pathetic 27 per cent reduction in the debt payments that are crushing and smothering those countries which have so far qualified for debt relief.

His head turned down, and that familiar voice began to shake as he spoke of the onerous debt burden breaking the backs of the increasingly tired and defeated peoples of this beautiful, intoxicating continent.

This is a man whose imprisonment mirrored that of his country, whose freedom was his country's freedom. Who was unbowed, unbroken and, in his most staggering defeat of his tormentors, was not embittered. Now he sat silent, for a moment beyond words at the monstrous enormity of what he had outlined in this tragic tour d'horizon .

The independent study I was showing Nelson Mandela, on the World Bank and International Monetary Fund was by Chantrey Vellacot, a leading global accountancy firm. I also told him that I had heard of a report circulating within the World Bank that the HIPC initiative is severely flawed and not capable of delivering what it set out to do - a lasting exit from the debt crisis for the poorest countries. After numerous rewrites this report was finally made public last week, and it proves that far deeper debt cancellation is required.

When I left Mandela he was armed with the findings of the independent report and arguing that now, before infrastructure utterly collapses and instability sets in, we must persuade and force the global institutions to relent and free the people of Africa from their unjust and unjustifiable yoke.

Two days later, South African President Thabo Mbeki talked to me of the upcoming conference on Aids in Africa. This was the time for increased pressure, he said, echoing his predecessor. He showed me the Millennium Action Plan, drawn up by him and other African leaders, which they would be discussing at the next Organisation for African Unity meeting, and which they will be taking in its final form to the G7 summit in Genoa in July. In broad, bold and blunt language, these leaders demand deeper debt cancellation.

These are not extremists. South Africa is a relatively rich country, able to handle its own debt burden - at least prior to the Aids crisis. Mbeki and Mandela are speaking for their continent and less fortunate neighbouring countries, which desperately need more debt relief.

This whole debt crisis has become a sickening joke. Everyone - the politicos, the bankers, the bureaucrats - know these people can never pay back this money. Nor do we need their cash. That argument has been won already - else why the 100 per cent relief from the G7? If the argument pertains to the richest nations, why not their agents, the IMF and World Bank, which we own as taxpayers in the richest nations?

Urgent and decisive action is required now as the impact of Aids is turning a desperate situation into an even more critical one. Gordon Brown says he is alarmed about the ongoing debt crisis, and he is right to be. Especially in light of the Aids crisis the debt initiative he has done so much to lead from inside the political mainstream is faltering. Even by its own standards it is failing. By the standards set by Drop the Debt, it is woefully inadequate.

Gordon Brown and the finance Ministers of other rich nations who gathered this weekend in Washington must follow through on their own commitment. They must direct the World Bank and the IMF to do as the richest nations have done and give 100 per cent debt relief. One day this will happen. And when it does, the only pertinent question will be, why not before? Did you really require those extra 5,000 people to die each day in Africa of Aids before you see the logic that appears so obvious to everyone else? Was it truly necessary to cripple the health, education and agricultural sectors, removing hope for the weakest and the poorest? What new whip do you wish to have with which to beat them?

webTitle: Ten key things about... space travel

fields.headline: Ten key things about... space travel
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Sixty-year-old American multimillionaire Dennis Tito has become the first-ever space tourist. But as he holidays on the international space station he will miss celebrations back on planet Earth next Thursday, marking the fifth annual International Space Day.
fields.body:
Sixty-year-old American multimillionaire Dennis Tito has become the first-ever space tourist. But as he holidays on the international space station he will miss celebrations back on planet Earth next Thursday, marking the fifth annual International Space Day.

1. The Russians were space travel's pioneers. In 1957 they sent a dog, Laika, into orbit. Four years later the first man, Yuri Gagarin, blasted off on 12 April. And in 1963, the first space woman was Valentina Tereschkova, because Soviet leader Kruschev fancied her

2. The first American astronaut was Alan Shepard, on 5 May 1961. Ten years later he commanded the Apollo 14 lunar mission, during which he became the first man to play golf on the Moon

3. On 20 July 1969, Neil Armstrong, commander of Apollo 11, was the first man on the Moon. As he left the capsule, he said: 'One small step for man, a giant leap for mankind.' He later admitted to fluffing his lines. It should have been: 'One small step for a man...'

4. Outer space starts about 100 miles above the Earth

5. Mir, Russia's seventh space station, orbited Earth for more than 15 years, re-entering the Earth's atmosphere on 23 March 2001

6. Nasa's space budget for 2002 is $14.5 billion

7. Stanley Kubrick's 1968 film, 2001: A Space Odyssey, was developed from The Sentinel, a short story by Arthur C. Clarke

8. In 1997, the ashes of Gene Roddenberry, creator of Star Trek, and of Sixties drug guru Timothy Leary were blasted into space

9. There is no expression in Klingon for 'good morning'

10. 'OK, let's get this mother out of here.' The last words spoken on the Moon, by Eugene Cernan, Apollo 17, on 14 December 1972

webTitle: Phil Hogan: A really useful parent

fields.headline: A really useful parent
fields.trailText: 'If God had wanted the world's curtain-twitchers to take the law into their own hands, he wouldn't have encouraged town councils to set up wheel-clamping departments.'
fields.body:
I'm driving our little trainspotter off to see Thomas the Tank Engine, who this weekend is apparently puffing around with his busy friends Percy and Daisy at a small station in the middle of nowhere especially convenient, unless you happen to live near Colchester and how many of us can make that claim with an air of swagger? Still, we are so excited by the prospect of meeting our uncannily lifelike hero face to face that I find myself almost voluntarily railroaded into warbling along with the special Thomas tape beginning 'Down in the station early in the morning' every mile of the route, a journey needless to say punctuated with frequent reminders by Pol Pot junior in the back that any accidental detour into the sidings of Radio 4 news and current affairs will be looked upon as a trespass against reason and punishable by every conceivable vocal objection of the ear-perforating kind.

But our arrival is soon being marked in the time-honoured way of snailing our way through a traditional picturesque village bottleneck before attempting to traverse what the Highway Code would be pleased to call a 'staggered' junction along with converging lanes of rival parping motorists trying to insinuate themselves up the narrow incline past the 'Shambolic Parking Facilities Ahead' sign. Hoooo-Hoooo! goes a train. We can see its black smoke blasting up over the houses.

'It's Thomas!' shrieks the little one. We can't see him, of course. 'Where is he? Where IS he?'

Naturally by the time we get to the top of the hill there is a cheery russet-cheeked steward to direct us back to the bottom again, explaining that the recent rain has turned all the overflow carparks into the Ganges so it might be an idea to leave our vehicle somewhere on a nearby continent and get a bus from there? I don't think so. We jerk our way back down the hill trying not to run over the toes of the crowds struggling up with their toddlers and buggies and elderly relatives with their heads in the age of steam, and back into the picturesque village.

'Where's THOMAS?' the little one wants to know as a matter of urgency.

'Won't be long!' I coo, glancing about and displaying as much bogus composure as having eight miles of traffic up your arse allows.

My first instinct is to park on the grass verge, a move that requires me only to affect enough blindness not to have seen the handpainted 'No Parking Please!' sign and put to one side my natural sympathies with local cottage-dwellers constantly being besieged with visitors from the outside world - though obviously they are perfectly free to move to Toxteth or Peckham if they get fed up with daffodils and nice views - and, let's face it, if God had wanted the world's curtain-twitchers to take the law into their own hands, he wouldn't have encouraged town councils to attract criminals back to honest employment by setting up wheel-clamping departments.

Still, I'm not one to cause trouble and have my tyres let down by vigilantes in tweed hats, so I relent, and leave the car in a field. I'm sure no one will want to use the goalposts. The little fellow has now fallen asleep due to nervous exhaustion, which means I now have to carry him across the staggered junction and up the bloody hill, with downcoming cars now running over my toes. We join the queue. It starts sleeting, which is the cue for the boy to wake up in a rage. 'Listen for Thomas! Listen for Thomas!' I say in the calming, parent-skills voice I use with the children in public. We listen. Nothing. Luckily I spot a minuscule sign in Biro saying that ticket holders don't have to queue at all. We're in!

We see Toby the Tram and George the Psychotically Bad-tempered Steamroller and learn how signals go up and down in the freezing cold, before repairing to the warmth of the Larding Shed, where we spend an intriguing 10 minutes watching people shunting hot dogs and burgers into their mouths. At last Thomas arrives and we are soon jampacked in one of his run-down carriages. Hoooo-Hoooo! he toots. Only the hardest of hearts could wish to be at home watching the football.

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Marriages made in hell

fields.headline: Marriages made in hell
fields.trailText: 'In an average lifetime, if you find love once, you're lucky. If you find it twice, it's a miracle. Any more than that and you're kidding yourself.'
fields.body:
I know two betrothed couples. One couple is so right for each other that splitting them up would be a crime against nature - like trying to separate the moon from the stars. Hardened cynic though I am, I tend to get very soppy about this kind of thing and, after hearing the news, spent the best part of a boozy evening earnestly debating their 'innate rightness', to the point where the man I was with concluded that I'd eaten a bad olive. Which wasn't a first. In the past, when I've been similarly enthused on behalf of 'love matches', eyebrows have been raised at my sudden 'unfeminist turnaround'. A case of: will madam be catching the bouquet, or will she be leaving that to the fish on the bicycle?

To my mind, they are missing the point. While there is nothing worse than observing a rotten, stale or pointless relationship (especially from the inside), this is not to say that these are the only kinds of relationships which exist. It's just that I believe that true love is very rare, and should be celebrated as such. In an average lifetime, if you find love once, you're lucky. If you find it twice, it's a miracle. Any more than that and you're kidding yourself. To this end, I am forever idolising 'happy couples'. It's somehow warming to observe other people's happiness, like basking in a second sun. In a skewed way, it makes you realise what feminism is, or should be - women being their definition of 'happy', not yours. Women being 'happy', period.

The second betrothed couple is different. They are Crap Couple, and everyone knows at least one of them. She's frazzled from all the effort it's taken to nab him; he just stands there pulling rueful 'doomed' faces like something out of The Likely Lads. However unkind it sounds, couples like these should be banned. They are bromide in the air supply - depressing, exhausting and desexualising all those who come into contact with them. What's more, this particular Crap Couple has been 'engaged' for more than four years, which seems rather a long time for any bride to be kept in a state of 'ecstatic anticipation'. Sometimes, when drunk, she admits that she wonders if he'll ever marry her at all.

I thought of Crap Couple when I read about Jane Andrews, the former aide to the Duchess of York. She is accused of flying into a rage when it became clear that her long-term boyfriend, Tommy Cressman, wasn't going to marry her, and stabbed him fatally. True or not, just reading about it made me wince. Primarily because a man was dead, but also because it struck me that you'd never read about a man accused of stabbing a woman because she wouldn't marry him. Any amount of insane reasons, yes, but not that one. Even today, in 2001, women are still perceived as obsessed hellhags who'd boil any number of bunnies in pursuit of the diamond ring. Indeed, a new study claims that, out of all Europe, British women are the most obsessive about marriage. Men, meanwhile, are still presenting themselves, as the quarry. A 'prize' to be courted, cajoled and won.

It's amusing, really, this idea of marriage to a man as a 'reward', kind of like an emotional version of the gold clock company men get for years of loyal service. What I would very much like to know is who decided that 'bachelor' wasn't at least as sad a word as 'spinster'. I would also like to know how it is that the gender so famously led by their genitals has got away with playing so hard to get with their emotions for so long. For far too many men, it seems that marriage is less their way of honouring their love as it is the ultimate thing they can do to shut up the woman they love. Which is grossly insulting, though maybe not as insulting as the men who refuse to marry at all.

The subtle insult implied in the lack of enthusiasm on the part of the man is what seems to sting women most. This is the great unsayable. As a rule women don't get upset because they're not married to their men, they get upset because their men don't want to marry them. Which is all to do with horrible men who enjoy winding women up, and stupid women who allow themselves to be wound up in the first place. It's almost definitely where Crap Couples come from, and why so many marriages end in divorce initiated by the woman. In many cases, the woman got what she wanted the day she whisked him up the aisle. The rest is just hell and Ikea.

However, in the strange world of the Crap Couple, being divorced is better, less humiliating, than never having been married at all. And I wonder not for the first time why it's people like me who are always labelled the cynics.

webTitle: Past, present and future of legal betting

fields.headline: Gambling a-gogo
fields.standfirst: Betting shops are 40 years old this week and bear no resemblance to the dives of 1961. There are more changes to come
fields.trailText: Betting shops are 40 years old this week and bear no resemblance to the dives of 1961. There are more changes to come.
fields.body:
I put on weight in the sixth form. Before then, if I wanted to have a bet, I had to sneak out of school at lunchtime, ride on a bus for half an hour to a transport cafe, hand over the bet, jump on a bus back, and arrive at school breathless a few minutes before the first lesson of the afternoon. I could, of course, have squandered my stake money on a sandwich; filling, but not fulfilling.

On 1 May 1961, life became easier; legal betting shops opened for the first time since the middle of the nineteenth century. The nearest to my school, a short walk away, was a seedy room in the backstreets of Croydon, managed by a formidable middle-aged blonde. When she paid out the winners, her scowl would have petrified a Blackpool landlady.

The premises were dingy by government decree; the 1961 Betting & Gaming Act required that licensed betting offices did not encourage loitering. The participants were expected to enter, place a bet, and leave with the alacrity and discretion of a Cabinet Minister visiting a bordello.

For more than 100 years, the public had been denied the legal opportunity to wager in cash away from a racecourse. Betting shops flourished in the first half of the nineteenth century, more than 400 operating in London alone, but the Attorney General noted: 'The mischief arising from the existence of these betting shops was perfectly notorious.' The 1853 Betting Houses Act closed them down, and for more than a century government and punters were united in a hypocritical alliance.

Betting continued. A labyrinthine network of bookmakers' runners serviced the nation's gambling instinct, and illegal shops continued to operate until they were legalised 40 years ago.

Fred Done owns 256 betting shops, and is the largest independent bookmaker in Britain. The recently published 'Rich List' estimated the wealth of Fred and his brother, Peter, at a conservative £78 million, but he began with nothing. In 1959, the 15-year-old Fred worked with his father in the family's bookmaking business.

'He traded in Knott Mill, one of the rougher areas of Manchester, under a tarpaulin in a back yard. He would open the shop from 11 to three and from five to seven for the evening dogs. Bets were written on any scrap of paper, with a nom de plume on the back.

'We had runners in all of the factories in Trafford Park, one of the biggest industrial complexes in Europe. We would send a taxi round every day, and the bets would be handed over in clock bags.' These were leather bags which, when closed, set the time on a clock, confirming that bets had not been placed after racing had started.

'There were no books, there was no income tax, no betting duty. What you had at the end of your day was profit. The only payment you had to make was bribe money to the police, two or three quid a week to keep them off your back. If they were going to raid you, they'd let you know.' Bookmakers' runners, who earned 10 per cent commission on all the bets they collected, were imprisoned automatically for a third offence; when a raid was imminent, substitutes were employed.

'Of course, punters were not as well-informed then. I once said I felt sorry for them and my father said, "If I ever hear you say that again... Always remember, skin 'em and stamp on 'em".' Limits on multiple bets protected bookmakers from excessive losses. The businesses were highly lucrative and had to be protected from predators. 'I'm choosing my words here. You would get threats and you had to look after yourself. You had to be tough to stay in the industry. We had runners in all the pubs as well, and there was a lot of competition. The pubs were probably worse than the factories to control.'

In 1961 Done went to work for the Peters chain of betting shops in Salford, marking up prices, and after a few years he had been promoted to manager of their credit office. 'There was no [security] camera, no till. In those days it was so good that you could allow for the fiddling and still make money. But when betting tax came in and we started trimming the odds, it became a business.'

The first five years of High Street betting were the most rewarding, and by the mid-1960s local magistrates had granted an estimated 16,000 licences. Applicants had to prove a knowledge of the business; one of the most compelling arguments was to admit to a couple of prosecutions for illegal bookmaking.

John Banks, who owned a chain of betting shops in Scotland, and who later became one of the biggest racecourse bookmakers, described the shops as 'money factories', a description that attracted the Government's interest. In 1966 they introduced betting tax.

The following year, Done started out on his own. 'Two weeks after we opened our first shop, foot and mouth struck. I had no cash and thought we wouldn't make it through. Most bookmakers closed, but we kept going with the dogs, and the punters came. They wanted to bet.'

One of the first men to realise the potential of betting shops was Cyril Stein of Ladbrokes. He acquired shops, no matter how run down, no matter the location. He moved the licensed premises, refurbished them, and turnover soared. 'Cyril was a man before his time,' says Done. 'I've never liked Ladbrokes. They've always been too aggressive, but I looked up to them. I think they've lost it now.'

Betting tax was increased and the Government, under pressure from football pools companies, imposed a 33 per cent tax on the fixed-odds coupons issued by bookmakers. The number of High Street shops began to decline, and now there are just over 8,000.

Until the mid 1980s, punters could listen only to an audio commentary on races, provided by the Exchange Telegraph Company. Each region had a commentator with an appropriate accent. 'When the regular man had a day off, a cockney took over. We hated him.'

Not until 1986 was regulation relaxed. Television screens were permitted which, a year later, would bring live racing via satellite to the majority of shops. Bookmakers were allowed to have two amusement-with-prizes machines and to provide soft drinks and refreshments. They were permitted to open in the evenings and on Sundays, but duty at 10 per cent (nine from 1996) was driving punters to illegal bookmakers. Still operating in pubs, clubs and factories, they account for a reputed 10 per cent of betting turnover.

'The tax killed off big punters in the shops who wanted to bet the odds-on chances, the man who would have £4,000 to win £1,000. Since offshore betting began, some of my biggest customers have been coming into the shop to see the prices and watch the races, but walk outside to call Victor [Chandler, who pioneered offshore betting] to bet on their mobile phones.'

Frankie Dettori rode all seven winners at Ascot in September 1996, and the betting industry shuddered. 'I wrote out cheques for £1.5 million. Even my gardener won £10,000 off me.' Bookmakers suffered another blow when the Government introduced the National Lottery six years ago, although a strange logic denied betting shops the right to sell tickets.

'The Lottery was a blow. Not necessarily the jackpot, but the scratch cards. They took away significant business.' The advent of off-shore bookmaking, with lower deductions, was the final punch. The Government conceded.

Betting duty will be abolished, perhaps as soon as the autumn, to be replaced by a 15 per cent tax on bookmakers' profits. 'If they hadn't done anything,' says Done, 'the number of betting shops would have been halved within five years. Now, I believe there will be an increase in the number of shops. It's an exciting time. I can't wait to get to work in the mornings.'

Done closed his credit business a decade ago - too much hard work betting against a shrewd clientele that didn't always pay up - but he will be tempted to start again. 'It's a different business now, with punters using Switch and Delta cards - you don't get knocked. I'll also be looking at starting a fixed-odds coupon for football.'

He should do well. Over the years Done's policy of giving more concessions than his rivals has built up a loyal clientele. A Manchester United devotee for more than half a century, Done pays out early those who have backed the Old Trafford team to win the Premier League when they are clear at the top. In 1998 Arsenal finished the season strongly to overtake United for the Championship, a late run that famously cost Done half a million.

The government will study the report of the Gambling Review Body, due in July, before contemplating further changes to betting-shop legislation. The Tote want to install their terminals in pubs and clubs, but the betting industry has one of the most efficient lobbies in Parliament.

John Brown is chairman of William Hill. Apart from a break of eight months when Grand Met took over the company, he has worked for Hills since 1959. The late William Hill was one of the best-known rails bookmakers of the past century, whose credit-betting company boasted 400,000 clients. Initially sceptical, Hill began to buy betting shops in 1966 and now the company he founded owns 1,500.

Brown's father ran a newsagent's shop in the East End of London, and took bets on commission for a local bookmaker. The chairman of Hills, who has bet since he could write a slip, believes that the abolition of betting duty will wipe out illegal bookmakers instantly, boosting turnover.

'One of the biggest changes in my time has been the decline in greyhound betting. In the old days, the dogs represented a third of turnover on Saturdays. You would go to work on a Monday and have hundreds of bets to settle from Saturday night's results. Now it's only a couple of dozen. The Greyhound Express closed, and then the tracks decided that results could not be made available race by race at night to outside agencies. That killed it.'

Brown, too, is now optimistic about the future. 'I think the betting shop will become a mini Las Vegas. Horse racing will flourish, and dog racing. Betting on football will continue to grow and I think we will see a new generation of slot machines in which the result is not determined within the machine.

'If we are paying the Government 15 per cent of profits, we will be able to put in machines that return 95 per cent of stakes to punters.' Numbers games, similar to the Lottery, have proved popular in the last few years. 'We would like the ability to bet on the Lottery, even if we can't sell the tickets.

'The number of shops should increase, but I don't think they will become significantly bigger. You will want one on every street corner. It is still the case that 80 per cent of our customers spend less than 10 minutes in the shop. The British public enjoys betting on horse racing and I think the whole business, horses, dogs, everything, will prosper. In one sense, the high deductions of recent years have protected us. They froze out the skilled punter. The big hitters, the really shrewd punters, will come back, and we are going to have to be proper bookmakers again.'

Such men were scarce in my youth. I might have put on weight in the sixth form but, strangely, when betting became convenient, every ounce I gained seemed to be matched by the corresponding loss of a pound from my pocket.

He moved the licensed premises, refurbished them, and turnover soared. 'Cyril was a man before his time,' says Done. 'I've never liked Ladbrokes. They've always been too aggressive, but I looked up to them. I think they've lost it now.' Betting tax was increased and the Government, under pressure from football pools companies, imposed a 33 per cent tax on the fixed-odds coupons issued by bookmakers. The number of High Street shops began to decline, and now there are just over 8,000. Until the mid 1980s, punters could listen only to an audio commentary on races, provided by the Exchange Telegraph Company. Each region had a commentator with an appropriate accent. 'When the regular man had a day off, a cockney took over. We hated him.' Not until 1986 was regulation relaxed. Television screens were permitted which, a year later, would bring live racing via satellite to the majority of shops. Bookmakers were allowed to have two amusement-with-prizes machines and to provide soft drinks and refreshments. They were permitted to open in the evenings and on Sundays, but duty at 10 per cent (nine from 1996) was driving punters to illegal bookmakers. Still operating in pubs, clubs and factories, they account for a reputed 10 per cent of betting turnover. 'The tax killed off big punters in the shops who wanted to bet the odds-on chances, the man who would have £4,000 to win £1,000. Since offshore betting began, some of my biggest customers have been coming into the shop to see the prices and watch the races, but walk outside to call Victor [Chandler, who pioneered offshore betting] to bet on their mobile phones.' Frankie Dettori rode all seven winners at Ascot in September 1996, and the betting industry shuddered. 'I wrote out cheques for £1.5 million. Even my gardener won £10,000 off me.' Bookmakers suffered another blow when the Government introduced the National Lottery six years ago, although a strange logic denied betting shops the right to sell tickets. 'The Lottery was a blow. Not necessarily the jackpot, but the scratch cards. They took away significant business.' The advent of off-shore bookmaking, with lower deductions, was the final punch. The Government conceded. Betting duty will be abolished, perhaps as soon as the autumn, to be replaced by a 15 per cent tax on bookmakers' profits. 'If they hadn't done anything,' says Done, 'the number of betting shops would have been halved within five years. Now, I believe there will be an increase in the number of shops. It's an exciting time. I can't wait to get to work in the mornings.' Done closed his credit business a decade ago - too much hard work betting against a shrewd clientele that didn't always pay up - but he will be tempted to start again. 'It's a different business now, with punters using Switch and Delta cards - you don't get knocked. I'll also be looking at starting a fixed-odds coupon for football.' He should do well. Over the years Done's policy of giving more concessions than his rivals has built up a loyal clientele. A Manchester United devotee for more than half a century, Done pays out early those who have backed the Old Trafford team to win the Premier League when they are clear at the top. In 1998 Arsenal finished the season strongly to overtake United for the Championship, a late run that famously cost Done half a million. The government will study the report of the Gambling Review Body, due in July, before contemplating further changes to betting-shop legislation. The Tote want to install their terminals in pubs and clubs, but the betting industry has one of the most efficient lobbies in Parliament. John Brown is chairman of William Hill. Apart from a break of eight months when Grand Met took over the company, he has worked for Hills since 1959. The late William Hill was one of the best-known rails bookmakers of the past century, whose credit-betting company boasted 400,000 clients. Initially sceptical, Hill began to buy betting shops in 1966 and now the company he founded owns 1,500. Brown's father ran a newsagent's shop in the East End of London, and took bets on commission for a local bookmaker. The chairman of Hills, who has bet since he could write a slip, believes that the abolition of betting duty will wipe out illegal bookmakers instantly, boosting turnover. 'One of the biggest changes in my time has been the decline in greyhound betting. In the old days, the dogs represented a third of turnover on Saturdays. You would go to work on a Monday and have hundreds of bets to settle from Saturday night's results. Now it's only a couple of dozen. The Greyhound Express closed, and then the tracks decided that results could not be made available race by race at night to outside agencies. That killed it.' Brown, too, is now optimistic about the future. 'I think the betting shop will become a mini Las Vegas. Horse racing will flourish, and dog racing. Betting on football will continue to grow and I think we will see a new generation of slot machines in which the result is not determined within the machine. 'If we are paying the Government 15 per cent of profits, we will be able to put in machines that return 95 per cent of stakes to punters.' Numbers games, similar to the Lottery, have proved popular in the last few years. 'We would like the ability to bet on the Lottery, even if we can't sell the tickets. 'The number of shops should increase, but I don't think they will become significantly bigger. You will want one on every street corner. It is still the case that 80 per cent of our customers spend less than 10 minutes in the shop. The British public enjoys betting on horse racing and I think the whole business, horses, dogs, everything, will prosper. In one sense, the high deductions of recent years have protected us. They froze out the skilled punter. The big hitters, the really shrewd punters, will come back, and we are going to have to be proper bookmakers again.' Such men were scarce in my youth. I might have put on weight in the sixth form but, strangely, when betting became convenient, every ounce I gained seemed to be matched by the corresponding loss of a pound from my pocket.

webTitle: How the Mob broke movie pickets

fields.headline: How the Mob broke movie pickets
fields.standfirst: As the Hollywood studios brace for a strike, a book reveals their bloody history of union-bashing, reports  Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.trailText: As the Hollywood studios brace for a strike, a book reveals their bloody history of union-bashing, reports  Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles.
fields.body:
The studio chief did not like the idea of one of his stars dating a black singer, so he asked a mobster to bump him off. The mobster refused and also declined requests to blind the singer. If that sounds like something out of the movies it is - but in real life and not a script. The studio chief was Columbia's Harry Cohn and the stars were Kim Novak and Sammy Davis Jnr.

As Hollywood approaches deadline time on the strike front, a book has been published about the extraordinary history of the film world and the often incestuous relationship between studios, unions and mobsters. It spotlights bloody union battles of the past, when pickets set cars on fire and 'reds' were seen under every studio bed.

The strikes in the film industry of the 1940s had a resonance that echoes today. 'At stake was nothing less than control over an industry that was essential in forging people's consciousness,' writes Gerald Horne in Class Struggle in Hollywood 1930-1950.

The same holds true now. Neither the anticipated writers' or actors' strikes have even started yet - the current writers' agreement ends on Tuesday - but already the press coverage about the possibility of an entertainment industry shutdown is huge. What is different this time around is that the control of film content is in dispute in a very different way. But there may be lessons for both sides from the previously unpublished material about the bitter Hollywood strikes of the Forties.

Horne, a history professor at North Carolina University, chooses as his starting point the film industry dispute in 1945 when the Conference of Studio Unions (CSU) went on strike in Los Angeles. It was a highly charged period with strikers confronting police and strike-breakers - one of whom, an actor called Ronald Reagan, recalled later that 'homes and cars were bombed... workers trying to drive into a studio would be surrounded by pickets who'd pull open their car door or roll down a window and yank the worker's arm until they broke it'. Reagan, once a union firebrand himself, crossed the lines and saw the strike as a 'Soviet effort to gain control over Hollywood and the content of its films'.

At the time, the Communist Party was strong in California with a membership of around 10,000, second only to New York. Many screenwriters, then more influential than today, were members or supporters. The writers were seen as such a powerful force that the FBI would monitor film content for signs of pro-Soviet or radical bias. They duly kept lists of everyone involved in such films as For Whom the Bell Tolls, Edge of Darkness (about Norwegian patriots resisting the Nazis and starring Errol Flynn) and Keeper of the Flame (a melodrama with Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn). Today the writers are still at loggerheads with the studios, but the battleground has shifted to payment for cable and internet rights and 'intellectual property'.

In the Forties, studio chiefs were already concerned about the power of the unions and portrayed demands for better fees as Communist-inspired and part of a plot to control film-making. They hired heavies from mobster associates to break strikes. The gangster Bugsy Siegel, for example, controlled a powerful union of extras.

Horne concludes: 'The central - though tacit - metaphor for the postwar United States was the simultaneous rise of organised crime and decline of the organised Left - and the fulcrum of this seesaw was the film industry.'

The studios reacted to the CSU's strike with a lockout in 1946. In the anti-Communist mood that swept the country, they were able to take back control and the unions were crushed. Horne sees the strike as a pivotal moment in Hollywood history that shifted for ever the film industry's balance of power and affected everything from the kind of stories that were told to production values.

Just as important was the Mob. In the Thirties, gangsters had been brought in by the studios to maintain 'labour peace', but they also established themselves within the unions, looking for rich pickings wherever they might be. As Orson Welles put it: 'A group of industrialists finance a group of gangsters to break trade unionism, to check the threat of socialism, the menace of Communism or the possibility of democracy... when the gangsters succeed at what they were paid to do, they turn on the men who paid them.'

Mobster Mickey Cohen claimed that Harry Cohn, the boss of Columbia, had asked for singer and actor Sammy Davis Jnr to be bumped off because it was feared his relationship with the young Kim Novak would harm her marketability. Cohen supposedly relented and merely threatened Davis with the loss of his one good eye if he persisted.

The strikes caused splits between writers and actors. Philip Dunne, the Oscar-winning screenwriter of How Green Was My Valley, claimed that Reagan 'postured all over the place' with his claims of picket line violence. Those who crossed the picket included Clark Gable, Esther Williams, Red Skelton, Greer Garson and Mickey Rooney. By contrast, in 1943 Jimmy Cagney, who was close to the Left, took over as leader of the Screen Actor's Guild. Other actors who were prominent in a movement to free a labour organiser, Tom Mooney, included Groucho Marx, Boris Karloff and Clifford Odets.

During the strikes, imaginative tactics were employed. Strikers would try to damage box office returns by picketing cinemas and divulging film plots to queuing filmgoers. Pickets outside cinemas showing Lady on a Train told potential customers: 'Ralph Bellamy's the killer. And David Bruce gets the girl.'

No one was in any doubt as to what the prize of control would be. A.P. Gianinni of the Bank of America, one of the industry's prime funders, observed prophetically: 'Those who control the cinema can control the thought of the world.'

No wonder the strikes were bitterly fought. Photographs from the time show pickets trying to stop strike-breakers entering Warner Brothers in 1946. Disney workers dressed in Mickey Mouse masks picketed cinemas during their 1941 strike. Pickets massed outside Paramount Studios in 1945 and supporting students from UCLA joined them. A sheriff's car was torched outside MGM in 1946.

'One movie Hollywood has never produced and probably never will is the story of its own unionisation,' as one of the protagonists quoted by Horne put it. It would be quite a movie.

 Class Struggle in Hollywood 1930-1950 : Moguls, Mobsters, Stars, Reds and Trade Unionists by Gerald Horne (University of Texas Press)

fields.headline: The strike plot in 2001
fields.trailText: A short guide to the dispute which threatens to halt Hollywood.
fields.body:
The dispute: Contracts of writers and actors are due for renewal on Tuesday 1 May and 30 June respectively. Both seek better deals than are being offered by studios on 'residuals', payments for use of their work overseas, on cable, video, DVD and the internet. Studios claim that they do not have the funds to meet the claims, unions claim that the market is constantly increasing. Writers also seek protection for their 'intellectual property' and restriction of use of the phrase 'A Film By...' now increasingly used by directors.

The unions: The writers are represented by the Writers' Guild of America. There are 11,000 members with a median salary of $84,000 for those working. Around 40 per cent are unemployed. The actors are represented by the Screen Actors' Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, which represents 135,000 actors in total. Among guild members, 70 per cent earn less than $7,500 a year.

Background: Many believe that studios and networks are promoting a strike because they would be able to lay off many workers as the recession bites.

Cost: Prolonged strikes would cost the Los Angeles economy nearly $6.9 billion, according to a study commissioned by Mayor Richard Riordan and published last week. About 130,000 jobs could be lost.

Effect: The growth on television of 'reality' programmes, and an increase in the number of films made outside the US.

Last writers' strike: 1988, lasted 22 weeks.

fields.headline: Franka Potente
fields.standfirst: And her new-found poise opposite Johnny Depp in Blow
fields.trailText: Franka Potente's new-found poise opposite Johnny Depp in Blow.
fields.body:
Looking at the ads for the cocaine-trade epic Blow, it would be easy to imagine that Penelope Cruz is in every single scene. In fact, for the first third of the film another young foreign actress plays opposite Johnny Depp. But even if you saw Franka Potente in the film that made her a star, Run Lola Run, you would have a tough time spotting her here. In Run Lola Run she runs the streets in heavy boots, all stomping punky-ravey sulkiness. In Blow she seems poised, and definitely more grown up.

'I was hesitant about doing too big a role in an American movie because it meant losing my German accent. This role was just the right size,' Potente claims. At 26, she is older than she seemed in Run Lola Run. And she's experienced, having packed in a lot of work on TV and film since becoming a professional actress in 1996. Although Blow is her first American film, she is not having the kind of culture shock foreign stars often find in Hollywood, having been an exchange student in the US at 17. 'I did the whole thing. I had an American boyfriend, went to football games, tennis tournaments and to my prom. I was so serious about my American boyfriend that I brought him back to Germany with me to visit my parents. They were horrified.'

She makes up half of Germany's hippest film couple with Tom Tykwer, writer-director of Run Lola Run and Potente's recent German film, The Princess and the Warrior. 'Tom is one of the few authors who's able to write good female parts. Most of the time, I think, "Pah! This can only be written by a man who knows nothing about women." But Tom is really good.'

With Tykwer writing for her, she is unlikely to disappear to Hollywood full-time, but she has just finished starring opposite Matt Damon in The Bourne Identity, a big budget thriller in the intriguing hands of Swingers and Go director Doug Liman. Seems like Potente is leaving that stroppy running girl image behind fast.

Five things you need to know about Franka Potente
1. She sang two of the songs on the Run Lola Run soundtrack.
2. She goes out with 35-year-old writer-director Tom Tykwer.
3. She fences.
4. She studied at the Lee Strasberg Theater Institute in New York.
5. Although she has pale reddish hair in Blow, it is naturally brown.

fields.headline: Taking LA to the cleaners
fields.standfirst: Ken Loach's polemical message is just as powerful even though he's working in Hollywood
fields.trailText: Philip French: From the start... there's a sense of the camera as a barely tolerated presence
fields.body:
Ken Loach is a romantic socialist, in love with the movement's distant past, disgusted by its present, unhappy about its future. He recently resigned from the Labour Party, but while he probably had a sneaking regard for Michael Foot, it's doubtful whether he's been wholeheartedly in favour of any Labour leader since Keir Hardie. The title of his latest movie, Bread and Roses, a film about a more-or-less successful industrial action involving the unionisation of office cleaners in Los Angeles, comes from the slogan of the striking workers in Lawrence, Massachusetts in 1912: 'We want bread - and roses, too.' Ah, those were the days! That slogan is echoed in other Loach films - his TV quartet about the 1926 National Strike, Days of Hope, and his superb film set in the Spanish Civil War, Land and Freedom.

Loach's career is one of the most singular in British cinema, 36 unremitting years as a left-wing moviemaker. He's thought of, and clearly thinks of himself, as an uncompromising artist working in a hostile environment and this is undoubtedly true. Nevertheless, he's managed to make 14 feature films as well as 22 movies and documentaries for television. Few of the theatrical works have found a large popular audience in the English-speaking world, and some of the TV films were rejected as too tendentious by the channels that commissioned them. But Loach, so far as one knows, has never had a film re-edited by a producer or distributor, though Kes, his one uncontested masterpiece, was subtitled in the States.

Over the decades, he has also found congenial and like-minded collaborators to help him plough his lonely furrow. Writers Barry Hines, Jim Allen and Paul Laverty (author of Bread and Roses); cinematographers Chris Menges and Barry Ackroyd; designer Martin Johnson; editor Jonathan Morris; composer George Fenton; producers Tony Garnett, Sally Hibben, Rebecca O'Brien - all have worked with him on four films or more.

Although set in the States, Bread and Roses is financed by five European countries and is in no sense a Hollywood movie. From as far back as Cathy Come Home, Loach has always tried to give his films an unmediated sense of life through the use of hand-held cameras, improvised dialogue and a deliberately rough, documentary look. From the start, when the film's heroine, Maya (Pilar Padilla), arrives in Los Angeles as an illegal immigrant from Mexico, there's a sense of the camera as a barely tolerated presence.

The film begins with Hispanic crooks preventing a reunion between Maya and her elder sister, Rosa (Elpidia Carrillo), because Rosa hasn't raised the balance of the transportation fee. At the end, it comes full circle when Rosa runs after the US Immigration authority bus that is taking a central character to be dumped back over the border. In between those distressing scenes, Maya proves herself an energetic, energising force, first escaping from the clutches of the vile desperado who demands sex in place of the unpaid immigration bill.

She then gets a job working with Rosa as a cleaner in a skyscraper that houses numerous top law firms and Hollywood agents, and immediately forms an alliance with a crafty young union organiser, Sam (Adrien Brody), who politicises her the way a similarly bearded left-wing Jewish intellectual does working-class factory girl Sally Field in Norma Rae.

Their initial meeting is playful in a Chaplinesque mode as she helps him avoid the security guards who pursue him. Thereafter, their relationship is more serious as he stages a series of consciousness-raising meetings with her colleagues (mostly Latin American, though there's one very unco-operative Russian immigrant) and they conduct a guerrilla campaign to attract media attention and to undermine the morale of the skyscraper's proprietors.

No one seeing this film could dispute the charge that the janitors are dreadfully exploited and are correct in demanding better conditions and pay and the right to organise. Not for the first time, however, Loach treats all middle-class people with contempt and holds up to ridicule those he regards as class-traitors who serve the capitalist establishment - foremen, the police, bureaucrats. There are not many characters in his films like the kindly schoolmaster in Kes and the understanding parish priest in Raining Stones.

He is also hostile to the older trade-union officials who disapprove of Sam's theatricality and provocations. Loach, one infers, would rather lose than compromise. Fabian tactics are anathema to him and the small victories that stem from New Labour and the social ameliorisation that might have flowed from Gore defeating Bush are to him not worth having. The nearest Bread and Roses gets to recognising certain complex bedrock truths about social situations and human nature is when Maya discovers that her sister has turned informer to pay for her husband's medical bills and has worked as a prostitute for a decade to support the family back in Mexico City. But in defending Rosa, Maya cannot just say: 'She's uninsured.' She has to add: 'Like 40 per cent of the people of the country.'

Two recurrent Loach motifs turn up in this film. The first is his romantic attachment to Hispanic women and his belief, as shown in Land and Freedom and Carla's Song, that rebel girls should not confer their sexual favours on men until they've proved their political worth. The second is that Loach clearly agrees with the nineteenth-century French anarchist Proudhon that 'property is theft'. In Raining Stones, the unemployed workers steal the turf from a Conservative Club bowling green; in My Name is Joe, a team of unemployed youths steal soccer shirts and shorts from a van; here, Maya robs a filling station to put a comrade into law school; in each case, these escapades are played for laughs.

The most up-to-date line comes when Sam tells the jubilant workers: 'You've got to stop begging and organise. Stand up for your rights.' What he actually says, and a factor in getting this movie a 15 certificate, is: 'Stand up for your fucking rights.'

fields.headline: Taking LA to the cleaners
fields.standfirst: Ken Loach's polemical message is just as powerful even though he's working in Hollywood
fields.trailText: Ken Loach's polemical message is just as powerful even though he's working in Hollywood.
fields.body:
Bread and Roses (110 mins, 15)
Directed by Ken Loach; starring Pilar Padilla, Elpidia Carrillo, Adrien Brody

Ken Loach is a romantic socialist, in love with the movement's distant past, disgusted by its present, unhappy about its future. He recently resigned from the Labour Party, but while he probably had a sneaking regard for Michael Foot, it's doubtful whether he's been wholeheartedly in favour of any Labour leader since Keir Hardie. The title of his latest movie, Bread and Roses, a film about a more-or-less successful industrial action involving the unionisation of office cleaners in Los Angeles, comes from the slogan of the striking workers in Lawrence, Massachusetts in 1912: 'We want bread - and roses, too.' webTitle: Observer review: 150 Years of Popular Musical Theatre by Andrew Lamb

fields.headline: Make 'em laugh...
fields.standfirst: If you want to know what is the highest form of art, look no further than 150 Years of Popular Musical Theatre by Andrew Lamb
fields.trailText: If you want to know what is the highest form of art, look no further than 150 Years of Popular Musical Theatre by Andrew Lamb
fields.body:
150 Years of Popular Musical Theatre
Andrew Lamb
Yale University Press £30, pp390
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Music originated among the singing spheres and ever since has been drifting down to ground, gravitationally tugged towards the raucous, unharmonious human world. Church music still aspires to address the sky, but opera secularised the art and acquainted it with our profaner passions. The hybrid form that Andrew Lamb calls 'popular musical theatre', in which speech is intermittently sublimated and raised aloft by song, marks music's arrival on Earth.

Cheered up by music, we can sing and dance through the rain, and believe, as the irrepressible orphan bellows in Annie, that: 'The sun will come out tomorrow.' The popularity of musicals, and their profitability, demonstrates our craving for a reassurance and an exhilaration that used to be dispensed by hymns and the ritualised chanting of the Mass. The mission persists: as a defrocked singing nun memorably put it: 'My heart will be blessed by the sound of music.' Or, if you're a non-denominational pantheist, you can choose to be whirled around in that cacophonous circle of life that is placed on view in the opening number of The Lion King.

Musicals aren't necessarily spiritual and high-minded, however. They can be outrageously, infectiously, exhilaratingly bad for you, since music has no conscience. The hottest ticket in New York these days is for Mel Brooks's The Producers, a musical version of his film about a deranged Jewish impresario who mounts a Broadway show called Springtime for Hitler, with epicene chorus boys as goose-stepping gauleiters. He hopes (for his own farcical reasons) to lose money, but finds to his consternation that his gruesomely tasteless extravaganza is a hit. Our feet can't be stopped from tapping, even if they're accompanying the thunderous advance of a panzer division.

Opera began as the preserve of emperors and generals, for whom Handel composed virtuoso tirades in Giulio Cesare or Tamerlano; Viennese operetta continued to confine itself to morganatic intrigues in tinpot Ruritanian monarchies. The musical, however, as Andrew Lamb argues in this racy history, was from the first a demotic form.

Lamb might have proved his point more conclusively if he'd begun that history 250 years ago, not 150. The first musical is surely John Gay's The Beggar's Opera, which, ironically, cheapened grand opera by assigning lyrical sentiments to mendicants and criminals who don't believe in what they're singing. When Brecht and Weill set out to modernise and radicalise the musical in the early twentieth century, all they needed to do was to update Gay in The Threepenny Opera, which assaults the hypocrisy of capitalism and the puritan morality that sustained it.

The musical's relations with opera have always been vexed. Reynaldo Hahn, Proust's lover, wrote a gooey operetta about Mozart's erotic dalliances in Paris; Andrew Lloyd Webber defers to Gounod's Faust in The Phantom of the Opera, quoting Marguérite's mercenary aria about the jewel box.

More often, as Lamb demonstrates, the citations are sarcastic. Barbieri's zarzuela El Barberillo de Lavapiés replaces Rossini's Seville barber, who crimps the upper classes, with a chirpy colleague from the Madrid slums, and Lloyd Webber's preferred heroines are broken-down divas whose lives are not quite as operatic as they'd wish: Evita, or Norma Desmond from Sunset Boulevard. Lamb concludes, appropriately, with Jonathan Larson's Rent, in which Puccini's carefree bohemians mutate into HIV-positive wannabes living in the sulphurous East Village.

The musical is sceptical about the art's astral origins, and has made a habit of debauching divinities. The Orpheus of Offenbach is a philanderer who can't wait to be rid of the termagant Eurydice. In Gilbert and Sullivan's Thespis, the debilitated gods, as in Wagner's Götterdämmerung, resign from power. Weill's One Touch of Venus turns the goddess of love into a shopgirl, and in Damn Yankees Adler and Ross re-enact the Faust myth in the sweaty locker-room of a baseball team.

Offenbach sent his Orpheus to the underworld; the composers of American musicals have been even bolder in probing the existence of the underclass. The gift of song, for these musicians, belongs not to a classical god, but to oppressed blacks who vent their grief and rage in music. Hence the bass's stoical meditation on 'Ol' Man River' in Showboat - given an extra edge of vindictive menace when Paul Robeson, a communist sympathiser, sang it - or the choruses, alternately uproarious or elegiac, of the ghetto-dwellers in Porgy and Bess.

We think of the musical as a form synonymous with glamour but it has an even greater fascination with squalor: Guys and Dolls contains an illicit crap game, and Pal Joey is set in a sleazy clip joint. Even My Fair Lady begins in the murk of the Covent Garden market, with Eliza among the downtrodden blooms. Inevitably, she is lifted out of the gutter: her experience reverses the desanctifying of the goddess that occurs in La Belle Hélène or One Touch of Venus.

Although music may have bumped down to earth, it can never forget its loftier home. While Shaw's Henry Higgins in Pygmalion can only teach elocution to his cockney pupil, Lerner and Loewe's Eliza teaches the throttled, repressive Higgins to sing, which is more of an achievement. We expect such moral and emotional miracles from the musical: if you want a spiritual experience, buy a ticket for a Broadway show.

fields.headline: A darker shade of Gray
fields.standfirst: She was the Angry Young Woman of Eighties TV. Now Muriel Gray is a top horror writer, with Stephen King as a fan. But she still has her own demons to face
fields.trailText: She was the Angry Young Woman of Eighties TV. Now Muriel Gray is a top horror writer, with Stephen King as a fan. But she still has her own demons to face.
fields.body:
Muriel Gray made her name being opinionated, rude, passionately enthusiastic and outraged; a post-punk presenter on programmes such as The Tube and The Media Show, with an inquisitive face and a mouthful of insults. Her bleached hair bristled; her bright-painted mouth grimaced; her brow furrowed. Everything about her seemed mobile and hungry and cross. Even her Scottish accent seemed bracingly unemollient. But today, as she sits opposite me in her office in Glasgow eating a doorstopper of a poached-egg sandwich and drinking coffee, her thin face is tired and bare under her whitened crop of hair.

She's in her forties now: businesswoman, occasional presenter, dogged writer of startling horror novels, wife, mother of three children, a skinny woman run off her plimsolled feet, trying to be in two places at once, anxious somewhere at the back of her brain, exhausted but putting a smile on it.

I am here today to meet her as horror writer - her third novel, The Ancient, is published tomorrow, a scary and grotesque tale of a cargo ship which is like a floating house of horrors, carrying as it does a crew of sailors with their own secret demons and a monster that surges out of the fetid darkness of the ship's holds.

Gray's father was a merchant seaman, but she got the idea one day when she was driving past a rubbish van and saw that the men had made a figure out of garbage that was sitting on the front seat. 'It was disgusting,' she says with relish. I tell her her book was disgusting too - full of ripped flesh and nameless terrors made from our most inadmissible fears. 'Well, I hope it's disgusting, I tried to make it disgusting. But was it scary enough?'

Yes, I assure her; quite enough - and it is also well-written and grim, much grimmer than her previous novels, which allowed glimpses of human contentment. 'It's true, it is the bleakest one. I hadn't really thought of that. I know it's usually a male thing - but I've loved horror since I was nine or 10. I've always read voraciously and still do - but when I go on holiday, I have to pack the Stephen King and the Pan Book of Horror Stories under the Jane Austen. I prefer the horror that isn't just gothic - the stuff that's grounded in everyday life. People in bedsits with their Baby Bellings. There's nothing more frightening than your safe haven being threatened by something dark.'

Stephen King is her hero - and he has unexpectedly given her a quotation for the cover of The Ancient. He requested the manuscript out of the blue, and emailed her the 'nicest comment. It is the highlight of my professional life,' she exclaims.

She thinks she sees life in terms of horror. 'The other day my husband Hamish was talking about these webcams that people are installing in their second homes, so at any time you can just click on it and see how your nice second home in Tuscany might be getting on - and I just thought about clicking on it and seeing this seventeenth-century family in the sitting room. Or I listen to the baby alarm and expect to hear something else, something spooky, in the background.' Of course, she says: 'I don't believe any of the supernatural things. I wish it was like that - there'd be nothing more romantic. It presupposes a plan, reasons for things. Good and evil, black and white, hidden secrets and delights. It's escapism really. Comforting.'

Gray thinks of herself as a writer now, more than a presenter, or someone who runs Ideal World - which she started 10 years ago and which is now the biggest TV production company in Scotland. 'It's not me who's made it work, though. It was just a daft, pissy little thing when I was running it. Then I got this fantastic partner, Zad Rogers. And when I got pregnant, Zad and I begged and pleaded for Hamish [her husband] to join us. I took a back seat. It's all down to them. It only grew so large and successful when I stopped coming into the office and wandering around shouting and eating egg rolls.' She sinks her teeth into her sandwich and the yolk runs down her chin.

For a long time, she says, she thought she had stopped being so angry. 'I didn't have the heart for it any more.' When she was younger, she admits to having been confrontational 'just to see what happened. You know, the equivalent to pushing against someone in a nightclub. I was always a fight-starter, particularly in print. It was fun, kind of - I do like fights. 'I've never been like Julie Burchill, doing it for the sake of hearing her own voice. I always got furious about things I cared passionately about. There are things that make me flamingly angry, and I don't stay calm. I shoot my mouth off. She chuckles, thinking perhaps of her most recent outbursts about fox-hunting or Catholicism.

There's another kind of anger as well - one which she is less in control of and more wary of. It's like a red mist that comes over her. She will be in a supermarket or just walking along a street and she'll see someone behaving badly or abusively, and she'll pick a fight. It's like life-rage. I have had this terrible internal pain for such a long time, so I suppose I feel the desire to have it matched by a physical pain. "Please smash me in the face" - well, there'd be a queue down the street to do that. I'd have to issue tickets.'

She laughs again, a hoot of merriment - she has this tremendous ability to be funny and caustically cheerful and scornfully upbeat, and yet completely sorrowful, all at the same complicated time.

The sorrow comes because of an accident that happened four years ago, and which turned her happy, well-run, successful world on its head and changed her life forever. Her second child, a two-year-old daughter called Rowan whose photograph she shows me, with her sweet pale face and soft brown hair and her mother's bluest eyes, went out one morning with the nanny. They were visiting the next-door-neighbour while Muriel worked on her book. Rowan fell into the neighbour's pond and was found face down in the water, unconscious. She nearly died, and has been severely brain damaged ever since. Gray doesn't know if Rowan even recognises her parents or siblings (two years ago they had a third child, Angus, to be a companion for eight-year-old Hector). She doesn't know what goes on in her 'darling, darling head'.

Gray has been quoted as saying that she didn't blame the nanny because it was her fault for having one. It's true that she was always puritanically anxious about having a nanny - she can't understand women who simply hand over their children to a carer and don't see them for 12 hours a day. But she says that 'fault' and 'guilt' are the wrong words; they sound 'ludicrous'. It's more, she says, turning her bony face toward me, 'that I'm a mother. How could I not have saved her? Why couldn't I have prevented that grief, that terror? It's a parent's most basic job, and I failed it. I didn't keep her safe. My darling wee girl.' There's no comfort for that sense of loss - you don't get over it. Time doesn't heal.

Since that time, Gray has coped by somehow taking all the burdens on herself (this is not how she would put it). She won't ever have a nanny again, though she has had a helper. She takes responsibility for her three children, ferrying them to school and collecting them (Rowan goes to a special school 20 miles away), shopping, cooking, caring, being a full-time mother and fitting her work round the corners of her day. Writing often starts at 10 at night, when the children are asleep. She rarely leaves them for a few hours, let alone a night or a week. And she copes by not thinking too far ahead. And by being cheerful, hour by hour.

'Denial is essential. Otherwise you'd go mad. Look at people in other countries, where all their children are dying of Aids. They still cope and look after their families and keep on working and living, and it's not because they're different, less sensitive, not at all. It's because they've developed this heightened ability to contain their pain. You have to contain pain, otherwise you come apart at the seams.'

She is heartened and 'interested', nowadays, by the fact that she still feels professionally driven. 'I gave up doing programmes when I got pregnant with Hector - I didn't want to have a baby and then just dump him. What a waste of having children. And I've been a housewife full-time for four years. I've turned down almost everything because I can't leave home. I've never had the ambition to get ahead - what does that mean: "get ahead"? Fame for fame's sake, I don't understand that at all; it disgusts me. But I feel the urge to create things, to make things. Looking after children is not rocket-science, and it can be terribly frustrating.'

For a while, she felt finished. 'But now I feel I'm not finished yet, I have lots more to say.' She doesn't worry about getting older - 'except one day I won't be able to lift Rowan any more. I was never beautiful when I was young anyway; it's not like Claudia Schiffer getting older. I think I've got the Andy Warhol syndrome anyway; I was always old.'

She doesn't believe in the hierarchy of suffering - 'the I'm-sadder-than-you-are culture' - and she knows that she is 'very lucky really. I have fantastic things in my life. All my children are gorgeous. Hamish is gorgeous; poor love, we hardly even go out for dinner together now. The tarpaulin over our life flaps as if we were in a gale force 10 , but we manage to peg it down and it's OK, we're OK - whereas some people have tarpaulins that fit perfectly tightly and neatly and still they are miserable.'

But, she says: 'I am terribly tired. I have the ability to burn brightly when required. It's like lighting a flare. Then I fizzle out.'

She doesn't, she says quite cheerfully, have much time for the concept of 'happiness. Maybe happiness is more a state of contentment, with peaks and troughs. One of the phrases that for me sums up what I mean by happiness - this sounds hopelessly old-fashioned - is 'the successful fulfilment of duty". Not self-gratification, and that "listen to me, I'm so special" thing. No, happiness because you've fulfilled your duty to your husband, your children, your friends, your family.'

What makes this austere statement poignant, of course, is that Gray feels she has not fulfilled her duty towards her daughter; so she is forever an exile from happiness. Nothing she does now can ever be enough.

She doesn't like religions (in fact, the day I meet her, she has just penned a vitriolic attack on Catholicism for the Guardian, and blithely talks to me of rosaries being shoved up arses). She is disturbed by 'the dark clouds of religious fervour that are closing in again', and doesn't believe in God. She grew up an agnostic and for four years has been more of an atheist, there being no room for God in a world in which her daughter lost so much. But she has no fear of death, not any more.

'I used to, of course. I used to dread dying. In that way I've changed hugely. I only worry about getting stuff sorted out beforehand; it's life that worries me. Sometimes I look forward to dying. Not "hooray" - but at least there's an end to it. It's nice to think that life is finite. People won't always suffer.'

So the agony hasn't abated? She smiles and pokes around in the unappetising beige remains of her poached-egg sandwich. 'No. How can it?'
