fields.headline: 'I don't think there's genius in my writing'
fields.standfirst: If all fiction is autobiography and all autobiography is fiction then where does that leave Paul Theroux? He talks about expatriate life, VS Naipaul and taking the curse off the evil eye
fields.trailText: If all fiction is autobiography and all autobiography is fiction then where does that leave Paul Theroux? He talks about expatriate life, VS Naipaul and taking the curse off the evil eye
fields.body:
Observer: What is Hotel Honolulu about?

Theroux: I see it as a book about a place which is very difficult to write about. There are two places that are hard to write about. A place like Britain, England in particular, which has been written about by everybody, and then the place that's never been written about. I've tried to find a form that would accommodate the place that I've been living in for 11 years.

Obs: Is it the first attempt to make a literature of Hawaii?

Theroux: I don't know of any other book. There are books about Hawaii, such as James A. Michener's Tales of the South Pacific. Robert Louis Stevenson didn't like it. He thought it was silly, full of missionaries and uncomfortable. He didn't like the weather and then he took off to Samoa.

Obs: And the book's also about you, of course.

Theroux: Let's say a version of me. I wanted to write about a writer who had stopped writing, a person with writer's block. It's something that interests me a lot because - knock on wood - I've never had it. It's about a man who is suffering through this period of 10 years of not writing anything, whereas in the last 10 years I've actually written 10 books.

Obs: You seem to be wanting to say in your work generally, but in this book more than ever before, that all fiction is in some way autobiography and that all autobiography is fiction.

Theroux: Well, I think that's true. Everything is fiction. You only have your own life to work with in the way that a biographer only has the letters and journals to work with.

Obs: What's fiction for?

Theroux: For telling the truth. And I think it's a version of the truth which is made up of...

Obs: Lies?

Theroux: Speculations more than lies, but it really is the most truthful thing at its best. That's why people still read it and why we still need it.

Obs: The narrator says: 'I used to be a writer.' There's a lot of self-criticism, almost self-loathing in the book. Is this your Ordeal of Gilbert Pinfold?

Theroux: There is a Gilbert Pinfoldish story here. It's not self-loathing; I think it's like exorcising a fear, a fear of not being able to write. It's also taking the curse off the evil eye. One of my fears is not writing. I don't know how to do anything else.

Obs: Did you always want to be a writer?

Theroux: No. What I really wanted to be was a 'useful person'. I wanted to be a doctor; I even did pre-medical.

Obs: How did you switch?

Theroux: I was actually on my way to medical school. That's what I was reading at university - science, embryology and chemistry.

Obs: When you were growing up, who else did you read?

Theroux: Travellers and people who had two strings on their bows. The writer-doctor, the explorer-doctor, the explorer-writer, the painter-writer.

Obs: Like who?

Theroux: Well Chekhov, Somerset Maugham, Greene and Edward Lear. I loved Lear and still do. In the end, partly because of Vietnam, I thought I want to just leave the country and hide and not be in the army, so I went to Africa.

Obs: You were in Africa, then London and now you're in Hawaii. Are you a natural expatriate?

Theroux: I'm not as much an expatriate as you might think. When I began to make some money, I really wanted to have a home.

Obs: Which you had here, surely?

Theroux: Yes, but I felt like an alien. I felt like someone off a rocket ship, like ET, anyway. So when I made some money in the mid-Seventies I bought a house in Cape Cod, near where I grew up. I always considered that home. Yes, I was an expatriate but I could pop on a plane and go home. It's not like being Rimbaud in Ethiopia who had given up writing. Rimbaud abandoned everything. I was never in that position.

Obs: But the 'I' in this book, the Paul Theroux figure in this book, actually makes a point of saying he's abandoned everything.

Theroux: All his bridges are burnt.

Obs: You like to self-dramatise, don't you? Why is that?

Theroux: That's how I feel sometimes.

Obs: How did you feel when you first went to Hawaii ?

Theroux: I was really out on a limb. If you look at a map you see that Hawaii is in the middle of nowhere. It's 17 hours of straight flying from London. It's very far away and sometimes you feel as if you're on another planet. But I like that. Also, that's ideal for writing.

Obs: You write: 'One of my first pleasures in Hawaii was that my past did not matter.'

Theroux: Yes. You're just a white guy, a 'howlie'. Howlie technically means 'of another breath'.You're just a ghost, a wraith. In most societies, a stranger is just a ghost. I like that.

Obs: But you're also a very literary person. You're steeped in literature, you're very well read and I remember you in London being deeply involved in the literary world. Don't you miss that?

Theroux: No, I really don't. When I was living in London, I had a very happy home and I was living in the bosom of my family. I liked that much more than being a member of literary society. I knew, and still know, most of the writers in London and literary London is a very friendly place in the sense that people know each other very well. I wrote a piece about Bruce Chatwin's funeral.

At Bruce's funeral, everyone came together; everyone knew Bruce and everyone knew each other. His funeral was the high watermark of that decade's creative activity. It was also the day that Salman Rushdie got the fatwa. After that, I felt: 'Well, this is it, time to go.'

Obs: Your marriage broke up or was breaking up?

Theroux: Well, yes. It didn't so much break up as... this is a very difficult thing to talk about, but I was kind of leaving. I think the problem wasn't my wife at all - it was me. I felt very restless in 1989 and I felt superfluous. I had these years of feeling the superfluous man, like Oblomov. I had one of those periods of questioning what I was doing and wondering about life.

Obs: So you went to Hawaii?

Theroux: When my wife and I split up, I went to the Pacific. I spent months and months travelling around islands. I recorded that in The Happy Isles of Oceania. It wasn't the total answer but it helped. If you have something on your mind, it really helps to be alone and be among total strangers in a completely alien environment. In the global village, it's not that easy because people have cellphones.

Obs: Do you have a cellphone?

Theroux: No, I don't. I draw the line there. I think that would be death for me. I don't think I've ever seen a person having a serious conversation on a cellphone. It's like a kiddie thing, a complete time waster.

Obs: Do you have email?

Theroux: Not when I'm travelling, but in normal life I do.

Obs: There's a lot of sex in Hotel Honolulu.

Theroux: I've been told there's a lot of sex in everything I write.

Obs: There's a great deal in this novel - of all kinds. I wondered whether you're reflecting something about Hawaii or whether it reflects something about you.

Theroux: There's maybe more sex than usual because hotels are just bedrooms. It's also true in a place like Honolulu with so many visitors. I think it's true to the place, true to the hotel and true to Honolulu.

Obs: Is the hotel a real hotel?

Theroux: No, pure invention. By some stroke of fortune, no one's ever called a hotel Hotel Honolulu.

Obs: There's a bit at the end here: 'The only place that can truly be hell is the one that was once paradise.' Is this what you're saying about Hawaii?

Theroux: Yes, because it's an Eden that's been invaded by traffic and mobile phones.

Obs: So, you've gone all the way across the world and you're in hell?

Theroux: Not hell, but a place that's been disfigured by people and the people who have gone there.

Obs: What will the Hawaiians say about your book?

Theroux: They probably won't like it. People who don't read books a lot are threatened by books. If it was reviewed in Hawaii, it would be universally panned. The idea of being written about is threatening. There are certain recognisable people in it, but most of them are dead.

Obs: And, of course, you've got Leon Edel [the biographer of Henry James] in the story. It must have been a great relief for you to find him there.

Theroux: Amazing. I used him in the book. It wasn't quite like that. The way I wrote about it was as though we were two aliens from a different planet. Meeting him was wonderful.

Obs: So the Edel story is a fictionalised version of the truth. That wasn't true of Sir Vidia's Shadow, though, was it?

Theroux: Sir Vidia's Shadow is everything that I could remember about my friendship [with V.S . Naipaul] and knowing him. This was a master-servant relationship. People who know Naipaul tend to be very nervous around him, saying the wrong thing, serving the wrong wine, or just saying the wrong thing about his books. When he finally left André Deutsch, Diane Athill said: 'I was delighted when he left; it was such a sense of relief, I almost wept with joy. I never had to be nice to him again.' So it's a sense of relief. It's like selling your yacht.

Obs: But that book is not just about relief.

Theroux: You can't write about a friend, you can only write about a former friend. I thought I can write the book that I'd been narrating in my head all this time To me, it's one of the best books I've written. I think it's a very satisfying book because in my life - this is the reason I can't write biography - is I take too many liberties, but there are no liberties in the book.

Obs: You painted yourself in a pretty unflattering light.

Theroux: Well, unsparing. I tried very hard because I couldn't do it to him and not to myself. Probably the book's about me and not him. There was a kind of spurious furore about it but it will settle down. The great thing about a book is that it goes it's own way. Hype helps maybe for a month or so but in the end if a book is good, the book will look after itself and that's definitely true. That's a Naipaul lesson, actually. And that's why it's the fairest profession, because if you write something well, it will be printed. If it's good, it will be absolutely deathless.

Obs: Stevenson's words are as fresh now as when they were written. They still speak to us across time and distance.

Theroux: He's completely original.

Obs: Are you following in his footsteps?

Theroux: I don't see the footsteps. He died young; he wasn't there a long time and he's a true genius. You can see there's genius in his writing. I don't think there's genius in my writing. Talent maybe, not genius.

 Paul Theroux's books include The Great Railway Bazaar, The Family Arsenal and The Mosquito Coast. His new novel is set in Hawaii, where he now lives

Theroux: Speculations more than lies, but it really is the most truthful thing at its best. That's why people still read it and why we still need it. Obs: The narrator says: 'I used to be a writer.' There's a lot of self-criticism, almost self-loathing in the book. Is this your Ordeal of Gilbert Pinfold? Theroux: There is a Gilbert Pinfoldish story here. It's not self-loathing; I think it's like exorcising a fear, a fear of not being able to write. It's also taking the curse off the evil eye. One of my fears is not writing. I don't know how to do anything else. Obs: Did you always want to be a writer? Theroux: No. What I really wanted to be was a 'useful person'. I wanted to be a doctor; I even did pre-medical. Obs: How did you switch? Theroux: I was actually on my way to medical school. That's what I was reading at university - science, embryology and chemistry. Obs: When you were growing up, who else did you read? Theroux: Travellers and people who had two strings on their bows. The writer-doctor, the explorer-doctor, the explorer-writer, the painter-writer. Obs: Like who? Theroux: Well Chekhov, Somerset Maugham, Greene and Edward Lear. I loved Lear and still do. In the end, partly because of Vietnam, I thought I want to just leave the country and hide and not be in the army, so I went to Africa. Obs: You were in Africa, then London and now you're in Hawaii. Are you a natural expatriate? Theroux: I'm not as much an expatriate as you might think. When I began to make some money, I really wanted to have a home. Obs: Which you had here, surely? Theroux: Yes, but I felt like an alien. I felt like someone off a rocket ship, like ET, anyway. So when I made some money in the mid-Seventies I bought a house in Cape Cod, near where I grew up. I always considered that home. Yes, I was an expatriate but I could pop on a plane and go home. It's not like being Rimbaud in Ethiopia who had given up writing. Rimbaud abandoned everything. I was never in that position. Obs: But the 'I' in this book, the Paul Theroux figure in this book, actually makes a point of saying he's abandoned everything. Theroux: All his bridges are burnt. Obs: You like to self-dramatise, don't you? Why is that? Theroux: That's how I feel sometimes. Obs: How did you feel when you first went to Hawaii ? Theroux: I was really out on a limb. If you look at a map you see that Hawaii is in the middle of nowhere. It's 17 hours of straight flying from London. It's very far away and sometimes you feel as if you're on another planet. But I like that. Also, that's ideal for writing. Obs: You write: 'One of my first pleasures in Hawaii was that my past did not matter.' Theroux: Yes. You're just a white guy, a 'howlie'. Howlie technically means 'of another breath'.You're just a ghost, a wraith. In most societies, a stranger is just a ghost. I like that. Obs: But you're also a very literary person. You're steeped in literature, you're very well read and I remember you in London being deeply involved in the literary world. Don't you miss that? Theroux: No, I really don't. When I was living in London, I had a very happy home and I was living in the bosom of my family. I liked that much more than being a member of literary society. I knew, and still know, most of the writers in London and literary London is a very friendly place in the sense that people know each other very well. I wrote a piece about Bruce Chatwin's funeral. At Bruce's funeral, everyone came together; everyone knew Bruce and everyone knew each other. His funeral was the high watermark of that decade's creative activity. It was also the day that Salman Rushdie got the fatwa. After that, I felt: 'Well, this is it, time to go.' Obs: Your marriage broke up or was breaking up? Theroux: Well, yes. It didn't so much break up as... this is a very difficult thing to talk about, but I was kind of leaving. I think the problem wasn't my wife at all - it was me. I felt very restless in 1989 and I felt superfluous. I had these years of feeling the superfluous man, like Oblomov. I had one of those periods of questioning what I was doing and wondering about life. Obs: So you went to Hawaii? Theroux: When my wife and I split up, I went to the Pacific. I spent months and months travelling around islands. I recorded that in The Happy Isles of Oceania. It wasn't the total answer but it helped. If you have something on your mind, it really helps to be alone and be among total strangers in a completely alien environment. In the global village, it's not that easy because people have cellphones. Obs: Do you have a cellphone? Theroux: No, I don't. I draw the line there. I think that would be death for me. I don't think I've ever seen a person having a serious conversation on a cellphone. It's like a kiddie thing, a complete time waster. Obs: Do you have email? Theroux: Not when I'm travelling, but in normal life I do. Obs: There's a lot of sex in Hotel Honolulu. Theroux: I've been told there's a lot of sex in everything I write. Obs: There's a great deal in this novel - of all kinds. I wondered whether you're reflecting something about Hawaii or whether it reflects something about you. Theroux: There's maybe more sex than usual because hotels are just bedrooms. It's also true in a place like Honolulu with so many visitors. I think it's true to the place, true to the hotel and true to Honolulu. Obs: Is the hotel a real hotel? Theroux: No, pure invention. By some stroke of fortune, no one's ever called a hotel Hotel Honolulu. Obs: There's a bit at the end here: 'The only place that can truly be hell is the one that was once paradise.' Is this what you're saying about Hawaii? Theroux: Yes, because it's an Eden that's been invaded by traffic and mobile phones. Obs: So, you've gone all the way across the world and you're in hell? Theroux: Not hell, but a place that's been disfigured by people and the people who have gone there. Obs: What will the Hawaiians say about your book? Theroux: They probably won't like it. People who don't read books a lot are threatened by books. If it was reviewed in Hawaii, it would be universally panned. The idea of being written about is threatening. There are certain recognisable people in it, but most of them are dead. Obs: And, of course, you've got Leon Edel [the biographer of Henry James] in the story. It must have been a great relief for you to find him there. Theroux: Amazing. I used him in the book. It wasn't quite like that. The way I wrote about it was as though we were two aliens from a different planet. Meeting him was wonderful. Obs: So the Edel story is a fictionalised version of the truth. That wasn't true of Sir Vidia's Shadow, though, was it? Theroux: Sir Vidia's Shadow is everything that I could remember about my friendship [with V.S . Naipaul] and knowing him. This was a master-servant relationship. People who know Naipaul tend to be very nervous around him, saying the wrong thing, serving the wrong wine, or just saying the wrong thing about his books. When he finally left André Deutsch, Diane Athill said: 'I was delighted when he left; it was such a sense of relief, I almost wept with joy. I never had to be nice to him again.' So it's a sense of relief. It's like selling your yacht. Obs: But that book is not just about relief. Theroux: You can't write about a friend, you can only write about a former friend. I thought I can write the book that I'd been narrating in my head all this time To me, it's one of the best books I've written. I think it's a very satisfying book because in my life - this is the reason I can't write biography - is I take too many liberties, but there are no liberties in the book. Obs: You painted yourself in a pretty unflattering light. Theroux: Well, unsparing. I tried very hard because I couldn't do it to him and not to myself. Probably the book's about me and not him. There was a kind of spurious furore about it but it will settle down. The great thing about a book is that it goes it's own way. Hype helps maybe for a month or so but in the end if a book is good, the book will look after itself and that's definitely true. That's a Naipaul lesson, actually. And that's why it's the fairest profession, because if you write something well, it will be printed. If it's good, it will be absolutely deathless. Obs: Stevenson's words are as fresh now as when they were written. They still speak to us across time and distance. Theroux: He's completely original. Obs: Are you following in his footsteps? Theroux: I don't see the footsteps. He died young; he wasn't there a long time and he's a true genius. You can see there's genius in his writing. I don't think there's genius in my writing. Talent maybe, not genius.  Paul Theroux's books include The Great Railway Bazaar, The Family Arsenal and The Mosquito Coast. His new novel is set in Hawaii, where he now lives

fields.headline: Proud to be a Snoot
fields.trailText: Are you now or have you ever been a Snoot? Does your blood boil when you see 'flout' confused with 'flaunt' or 'procrastinate' muddled with 'prevaricate'? Is a split infinitive a sign of the imminent end of civilisation as we know it? Does a rogue apostrophe make you seethe? When you read 'Ceasar salad' on a menu, do you storm out of the restaurant?
fields.body:
Are you now or have you ever been a Snoot? Does your blood boil when you see 'flout' confused with 'flaunt' or 'procrastinate' muddled with 'prevaricate'? Is a split infinitive a sign of the imminent end of civilisation as we know it? Does a rogue apostrophe make you seethe? When you read 'Ceasar salad' on a menu, do you storm out of the restaurant?

If your answer to any one of the above is an unequivocal yes, then you are an inveterate, double-dyed-in-the-wool, platinum-plated, 24-carat and unregenerate Snoot.

The term is the American novelist David Foster Wallace's, and it's to be found in his amusing and provocative essay on English language usage in the April issue of Harper's magazine.

You will not find Snoot in any dictionary. Yet. We owe the acronym to the Wallace family, who derive it, says Wallace, from 'Syntax Nudniks of Our Time'. In other words, a Snoot is 'an extreme usage fanatic'. In case you're in any doubt, Mr Wallace adds: 'A Snoot can be defined as somebody who knows what dysphemism means and doesn't mind letting you know it.'

You know the type. The person who sneers at the confusion of 'owing to' and 'due to'. Who raises a supercilious eyebrow at the checkout queue marked '10 items or less'. Who excoriates the misuse of 'hopefully'.

A straw poll of The Observer newsroom revealed a predictably high Snoot count, especially in our acclaimed sub-editing section, with hanging participles, the misunderstanding of 'disinterested' and the use of 'obligated' being chief among the horrors endured by the average healthy, moderately socialised Snoot. To such individuals, listening to most people's English feels like watching somebody use a Stradivarius to hammer nails.

Generally speaking, your Snoot is unabashed by his or her snootiness. In fact, secure behind their OED and their Fowler's, they are proud of it. For the Snoot, correct language usage (ie Standard Written English or SWE) is as important as a well-pressed suit or unladdered tights. Banality, clichés and sloppy thinking are one thing; galumphing linguistic solecisms are something else altogether.

The odd thing about Snoots is that, even as they would die in the last available ditch to unsplit an infinitive, they will also, as highly intelligent beings, recognise that language is not, and never has been, prescriptive. Historically, indeed, language is normative, ie answering to, and evolving in response to, the democratic preferences of the many, not the few.

The grandfather of the Snoot is Jonathan Swift. 'From the Civil War to this present Time,' he wrote in a magnificent counterblast in 1712, 'I am apt to doubt whether the Corruptions in our Language have not at least equalled the Refinements of it.' Many of the terms to which he objected - 'mob', 'sham', 'banter' and 'bully' - are now part of the common currency.

Wallace is right to point out that although we live in a world in which salads occasionally belong to Ceasar and in which we can expect space travellers 'to boldly go', if we flout the contemporary rules of language, we risk opprobrium. An important part of his essay is devoted to arguing that language is meaningless without rules and that those 'descriptivist' liberals who say that 'ain't' is as valid as 'is not', or that 'ax' is an acceptable substitute for 'ask' are condemning those who use 'ain't' and 'ax' to a ghetto of deprivation based on their inability to muster a command of SWE.

It's not exactly a new point, but Wallace gives it a new spin by pointing out that the 'descriptivist' revolutionaries who rejected traditional authority and traditional inequality with their insistence on Politically Correct English (PCE), what he calls 'euphemistic doublespeak', have 'now actually produced a far more inflexible prescriptivism... [that's] not just silly but confused and dangerous.'

PCE, mercifully, has not had the same impact in Britain as it's had in America, though we have all witnessed some of its madder provisions. And that's another thing that many British Snoots can't stand - the Americanisation of the pure well of the English language. That complaint has a long history, too. Nineteenth-century Snoots were quick to complain about 'hospitalise', 'prestigious' and 'belittle'. Their descendants fuss over 'reportedly' as a substitute for 'according to reports', and 'dialogue' or 'impact' used as verbs.

They take their cue from that king of Snoots, Samuel Johnson, who first complained about 'the American dialect, a tract of corruption to which every language widely diffused must always be exposed'. Confused? Relax. It is the ability to entertain two contradictory positions at the same time that's the hallmark of the natural Snoot.

robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Observer review: The Day We Had Hitler Home by Rodney Hall

fields.headline: G'day, Adolf, fancy a tinny?
fields.standfirst: Rodney Hall deposits the German dictator into a small town in Australia in The Day We Had Hitler Home, but what is he doing there?
fields.trailText: Rodney Hall deposits the German dictator into a small town in Australia in The Day We Had Hitler Home, but what is he doing there?
fields.body:
The Day We Had Hitler Home
Rodney Hall
Granta £15.99, pp351
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Rodney Hall is an Australian writer with indisputably fine credentials who has twice won the antipodean equivalent of the Booker. But his latest novel, The Day We Had Hitler Home, jerks the reader to attention by depositing Hitler into the plot, only to recede into opaque twists and obscuring quirkiness.

Hitler arrives, implausibly, in a small Australian town shortly after the First World War and is invited home, even more implausibly, by an Australian family - Audrey McNeil, her irascible sister, Sibyl, and Sibyl's lascivious, roaming-eyed husband, Immanuel.

Audrey inhabits a perfumed terrain of post-adolescent self-absorption, preoccupied with her recently acquired camera and her speculations about whether Immanuel is about to seduce her. The arrival of Hitler supplies her with new matter and she is soon discovered musing with perturbed fascination on his 'clammy skin' with its 'stippling of pores, some grossly open and peppered with blackheads, others tiny pits sprouting aggressive hairs'.

Hitler, meanwhile, behaves as if he is Charlie Chaplin just dropped in from The Great Dictator: he stuffs himself with cream cakes, falls over, grunts and sneers and is highly sensitive about his moustache. Audrey's fascination for the 'radiant cold energy' of this 'fabulous creature, a European' continues unabated until, that is, Hitler asks her if she has 'ever thought about... how stimulating shit can be?' and grabs her breasts.

Hitler's significance seems primarily as a catalyst for change in Audrey's life, as a sort of hyper-racist, megalomaniac guru of self-realisation. After Hitler has been handed over to the Germans, Audrey decides to pursue her 'passion for modernity' and Europeans in particular, and moves to Munich, clutching a small notebook of jottings in German which she believes Hitler left behind.

She enters a carnivalesque Europe of Isherwoodian cinema-drones and amorality and makes the outsider's mistake of falling in with the stiffs - bankers, pragmatists and the ancient pterodactyls sipping tea and jangling their bracelets. She attends rants being given by the new sensation, Adolf Hitler, and eventually finds her way to the headquarters of the National Socialist party. In a scene of gruesome anticlimax, she presents Hitler with what she thinks is his notebook and then appears to have nothing else to say, except to pose her own underwhelming 'overwhelming question': 'I have come... to ask if women frighten you.'

The Hitler plot appears to be over and the reader is excitedly awaiting an explanation of quite what has been going on, when Audrey undergoes a change of ideology, courtesy of Bello, an African actor, sweaty and sensuous, a man of dark moods, dark passions, a lover and a victim. As a result of Bello, Audrey comes to 'harbour doubts about Nazism' and, after Bello is lynched, is forced to flee Germany. She returns with her 'collection of images' to Australia, where her sister and brother-in-law have just died, true to the Futurist manifesto, in a plane crash.

At one point, Audrey finds that, 'suddenly I am at the still centre'. This comes as little surprise to the reader. The driving force of the narrative is the developing character of Audrey; all other personalities, historical figures and artistic movements are subjected to the relentless permutations of self-analysis. Family secrets intertwine with the darkest hours of history; personal traumas are relayed in insistent breathiness, drowning out the shrillness of Nazism. The final twist of the knife, in which Audrey realises that her hold on Hitler was mere fantasy, seems to tip back the scales, return the small people to anonymity; Audrey duly goes home - and the great go to history.

It also gives the lie to all Audrey's scene-stealing, but if Audrey was a fantasist after all, then The Day We Had Hitler Home seems little more than a spluttering literary What if?, opening with sensation and ending in irresolution.

webTitle: Observer review: My Dream of You, Juno & Juliet, The Diary of an America Au Pair and Love in Idleness

fields.headline: Meaning machines
fields.standfirst: All life and love is here. And so are Mrs von Teplitz's hip bones. Anna Shapiro on the latest fiction: My Dream of You, Juno & Juliet, The Diary of an America Au Pair and Love in Idleness
fields.trailText: All life and love is here. And so are Mrs von Teplitz's hip bones. Anna Shapiro on the latest fiction: My Dream of You, Juno & Juliet, The Diary of an America Au Pair and Love in Idleness
fields.body:
My Dream of You
Nuala O'Faolain
Michael Joseph £12.99, pp464
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Juno & Juliet
Julian Gough
Flamingo £9.99, pp295
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Diary of an America Au Pair
Marjorie Leet Ford
Chatto & Windus £10.99, pp346

Love in Idleness
Charlotte Mendelson
Picador £12.99, pp275

Buy it at a discount at BOL

If novels can be said to be machines for accumulating meaning, the journalist and memoirist Nuala O'Faolain's extraordinary first novel is all meaning. This is true right from the start, and meaning grows, so that the ending is more devastating than anything I've read since The Mill on the Floss.

As a result, to outline the story of My Dream of You is to undersell it, not that the action of the novel - a 49-year-old Irish woman's return to her native country after 30 years - is mere scaffolding, since it's all so beautifully integrated.

'I believed in passion the way other people believed in God,' Kathleen, narrator and heroine, declares. Yet when we meet her, she has not experienced passion in any conventional sense for decades. She's worked as a travel writer, seeking always the impersonal freedom of rooms and places without history or associations, and one-night stands with business travellers.

Even her London home is a 'perfect nothingness', a basement flat where she never invites anyone and her closest associate is the neighbour's cat, to which she brings treats without ever petting it. Yet here is why she brings it treats: once, when Kathleen fell so hard she couldn't move, it came and sat by her until she was able to get up.

The person she is closest to is a fellow travel writer, a gay American named Jimmy, and they have a bond of the kind many women dream of. Then, just when Kathleen has had a one night stand too many, been offered sex for a dollar by an eight-year-old girl living on a traffic island, and been called an old bitch, Jimmy dies from a heart attack. Kathleen gives up her job and her flat and pulls an idea out of nowhere: she'll write a historical novel based on a nineteenth-century legal brief the love of her life once handed her, about a wealthy Englishwoman who was sued for divorce because she had an affair on her Irish estate with her groom, when people were dying all around them during the potato famine.

The trip to Ireland is for research. Kathleen is not someone to whom people matter too little but for whom they matter almost more than she can stand. Her research into the Englishwoman's affair is her research into the nature of love - love for family, country, home, beauty, sex, nature, animals, one's self. In the course of this travel writer's one serious journey, she makes and loses a great new friend, has a passionate sexual relationship for the first time in decades and dares revisiting, most of all, memories she has tried never to think of.

Early on, we are given to understand that her father was awful, but you don't know how terrible he was until very late. By that point, there have been deaths upon deaths, though the tone overall is mainly of Kathleen's passionate persistence of attachment. At the end, Kathleen shows us the death of a character in the novel she has been writing. So heavily has meaning accumulated that we experience the death also as her pal Jimmy's; as Ireland's; as all the thousands in the famine; as the death of Kathleen's mother; of romance; and as the loss of everything that cannot be retrieved in our own lives from the cruelly indifferent passage of time.

Juno & Juliet is in another Ireland, a funnier and easier one. Juno and Juliet are identical twins; Juliet, the narrator, sees Juno as fabulously beautiful, so, naturally, Juliet is too. But Juliet regards herself as disliking almost everybody, whereas Juno's serene, forgiving nature makes her a magnet for the millions. Juliet is a little in love with her sister herself and therefore a little jealous of anyone Juliet especially likes. This isn't a problem for them until, during their first year at university, in Galway, they meet Michael, a man even Juliet can see is nice.

This proves something of a red herring, however. Julian Gough is so good a writer, he should probably dispense with plot. What he has is an outstanding talent for comic scenes and for an evocation of balmy good nature. In Juno & Juliet, he has created the Silent Twins who talk. And read. Juliet's love and appreciation of literature, and what her beloved professor says about it, are worth the price of the book alone.

webTitle: Observer review: Hotel Honolulu by Paul Theroux

fields.headline: Even Basil Fawlty wouldn't check in
fields.standfirst: Seedy, venal, mesmerising - and that's just the hotel owner. Paul Theroux builds a multi-layered portrait of modern America on a pun in Hotel Honolulu
fields.trailText: Seedy, venal, mesmerising - and that's just the hotel owner. Paul Theroux builds a multi-layered portrait of modern America on a pun in Hotel Honolulu
fields.body:
Hotel Honolulu
Paul Theroux
Hamish Hamilton £16.99, pp441
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Hotel Honolulu is a book built on a pun. Arriving in Hawaii, a blocked and impecunious writer takes a job as hotel manager. It is, his illiterate boss tells him immediately, a 'multistory' hotel. And so it turns out to be, but in an unexpected sense of the word: each of the residents and staff has a tale to tell, and over the course of eight years the writer remembers how to write them down. He ends up amanuensis as well as manager to the establishment. There are 80 rooms in the Hotel Honolulu, and 80 interlocking stories in Hotel Honolulu: the multi-storey building becomes the multistory book.

The book-as-building conceit has some important precedents. Proust likened A La Recherche to a cathedral, Gerard Manley Hopkins compared the Petrarchan sonnet form to the Parthenon and in the preface to Portrait of a Lady, Henry James famously gave the blueprint for his 'house of fiction'. And now Theroux has his hotel. It seems a suitably non-denominational choice of edifice for a book about America's cultural plurality.

'Nothing to me is so erotic as a hotel room, and therefore so penetrated with life and death,' the novel begins, and from that little piece of semantic origami Theroux unfolds his twin themes. There is death - homicide, suicide, plain old senescence. And there is sex. Lots of sex, in all sorts of permutations - couplings, triplings, even an 'insecticide' (a Hawaiian's word for incest). The narrator reflects: 'In a small hotel you see people at their best and at their worst... this is where America stays.'

And as the people come, so the narrator teases their stories from them: Puamana, the prostitute who was going to be a nun and ended up bedding John F. Kennedy; Roland Miranda, the long-term resident who fashions an elaborate coffin in his room and then dies in it; Amo the flower arranger and his gay lover, Chip, and many, many others. Theroux has himself described the book as a cross between Seinfeld and The Canterbury Tales, and certainly in its scatology, its bawdy, its tragedy and its staggering inventiveness, the book has much in common with Chaucer's.

Where Chaucer has his innkeeper, Theroux has his hotelier. Buddy Hamstra, the multi-millionaire owner of Hotel Honolulu, is the novel's astonishing central character, and, in many ways, its dramaturge. Buddy is a man whose idea of intellectual achievement is finding a new simile for female genitalia, whose motto for life is 'Never jack off a dog' (he'll tell you the story if you ask), who thinks that 'Christmas is always a ratfuck' and whose favourite practical joke involved putting his wife's ashes in a pepper grinder and inviting his friends round for dinner.

Venal, dipsomaniacal, utterly selfish, entirely believable and grossly unforgettable, Buddy is a compaction of all that is loathsome and mesmerising about America. There is no mistaking Theroux's horror at Buddy, but there is no mistaking his fascination either.

One of the chief themes of this pleasurably complex novel is how we use narrative to give form to experience. Reaching Hawaii - 'this green illiterate world' - the writer/narrator luxuriates in living an 'unsorted life', of no longer compulsively having to pattern his experience into words. Over time, however, he becomes pained by this relentless contingency and starts to influence the lives of his guests: an analogue for the writer's ability to control his dramatis personae. Soon, the multi-storey hotel starts to take on the qualities of the multistory hotel: 'Being the manager here was like existing within an unpredictable jumble of episodes and characters to which I alone knew the narrative line.'

The mise-en-abîme effect this creates of book-inside-building-inside-book is further complicated by the fact that the nameless writer bears a considerable resemblance to Theroux; both live in Hawaii, both write with a mellifluous beauty about their hobby of beekeeping and so forth. When the writer alludes to 'the detailed autobiographical fantasies of my books', it is in part a challenge from Theroux: I'm here, I'm involved, but you'll never tease me out, because everything - even autobiography - is fantasy, fictionalised.

Describing his house of fiction, Henry James (an important presence in the book) wrote that it has: 'In short not one window, but a million... but they are, singly or together, as nothing without the posted presence of the watcher - without, in other words, the consciousness of the artist.' Theroux's hotel of fiction could easily have lapsed into a neat conceit for a book of unconnected stories, but his managerial skill - his artistic consciousness - is magnificent. So do yourself a favour: check in.

webTitle: The shrinking space for dissent in Pakistan

fields.headline: The shrinking space for dissent in Pakistan
fields.standfirst: The dangers of taking an unpopular stand
fields.trailText: Beena Sarwar: the internet has increased international solidarity but it can't help dissenting views reach the masses.
fields.body:
The years of oppression and state censorship under Zia ul Haq have left their mark on Pakistani journalism in many ways. Journalists have come up with ingenious methods of getting across news and views, on the other hand. But continuous attacks on freedom of expression coupled with the strengthening of militant right non-state actors has led to journalists having to exercise a lot of caution in how they write.

While journalists still continually put themselves on the line, the space for dissenting opinions is continually shrinking. When you take a stand that offends the authorities or militant groups, you can feel very daunted about doing it again even if you won that round in the first place. You can never be sure that the people who supported you will be around the next time.

In a largely unlettered society, newspapers have a limited impact. Among these, the greatest readership belongs to the Urdu language press, which is correspondingly more careful not to go against establishment views. There is relatively more space for dissenting views in the non-mainstream independent press, for example in English and Sindhi. But it is risky to go against the establishment view on matters like the army, religion, foreign policy, or to oppose the government's policy on nuclear weapons. However, brave journalists do raise these issues and often get away with it.

With regard to religion, there is little in the way of open discourse because of the government's own caution in the face of militant religious groups. The 'blasphemy law', Section 295-C of the Pakistan Penal Code provides capital punishment for any convictions. It has been enough over the last few years just to accuse people and initiate a mob reaction; a reasoned, open debate on the mass media could go a long way towards strengthening the constituency of those who believe in justice and tolerance.

I don't feel that the situation for press freedom has improved much in recent years. The continual censorship from various quarters has led to the internalisation of many of the establishment views. The journalist's sense of isolation has decreased as a result of the internet. Internet campaigning helped get Najem Sethi of the Friday Times released, and has encouraged a lot of solidarity among journalists. But the electronic media still needs to be opened up more so that it's not what we call 'His Masters Voice'.

If we don't allow open discourse, the public will feel that there is nothing they can do about their situation. They will assume that there is only one view and if they don't share it they will feel totally isolated.

Beena Sarwar has been a journalist in Pakistan since 1987 and is currently Editor of The News on Sunday. She has worked with The Star, Karachi and was Features Editor at the Frontier Post, Lahore before joining the News, where she launched the weekly The News on Friday (now Sunday). She is currently on sabbatical leave on a television documentary course.

webTitle: Sport: Wembley fiasco to rival Dome

fields.headline: Wembley fiasco to rival Dome
fields.trailText: Officials warn Blair that stadium needs £100m or flagship plan faces collapse.
fields.body:
The government is facing a Dome-style fiasco after the consortium behind the troubled plan to rebuild Wembley football stadium demanded more than £100 million of public money to keep the project afloat.

In a development which has echoes of the ill-fated Greenwich project, when Ministers repeatedly had to come to the rescue at a cost of hundreds of millions of pounds, senior Wembley insiders say the stadium deal is close to collapse.

The Football Association has warned Tony Blair that the £660m plan to rebuild Wembley will have to be abandoned within months unless it receives a substantial amount of taxpayers' money. Such a move would deal a crushing blow to the credibility of British sport.

But Ministers, scarred by the Dome experience, are fearful of getting involved in case Wembley becomes another financial and public relations disaster. It would also be a severe humiliation for Culture Secretary Chris Smith, who has always opposed giving Wembley further financial aid.

'It wouldn't look great if we were seen to be bankrolling the country's richest sport,' said a Whitehall source.

Ministers are planning to oppose any cash rescue, and Gordon Brown, the Chancellor, is thought likely to be a stumbling block. One Minister told The Observer last night: 'Where's the money going to come from? Twickenham [headquarters of English rugby] was built without a penny of public money. What justification is there for more public money going into Wembley? They've had £120m of Lottery money already and there'll be an outcry if we give them more.'

A Whitehall source confirmed that talks were going on between No 10 and the FA, which the Government hoped would produce 'a mutually beneficial conclusion'. That may indicate that the Prime Minister wants to avoid Wembley becoming a colossal embarrassment by remaining closed for ever.

The scheme is beset by serious financial problems, concern about its viability and growing doubts that the new stadium is actually needed.

'If the Government says no to us, we will walk away from it and the project wouldn't go ahead. The sums simply don't add up without a cash injection from somewhere. We need about £100m,' said a source for Wembley National Stadium Limited, the FA subsidiary overseeing the project.

'At the moment we are faced with an unbridgeable gap in our funding plans. A partner would lessen the financial burden considerably. But without that, the project's dead.'

The Observer has learnt that Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive, approached No 10 earlier this month after it became clear the FA would not secure the £410m loan to fund the redevelopment because of doubts in the City. A previous attempt to raise the money last autumn failed.

Although WNSL has recently managed to secure pledges of more than £300m, it is faced with a funding gap of between £40m and £100m. Crozier is facing mounting opposition within the FA from those who see the new Wembley as a potential black hole which could even bankrupt the organisation.

Some members of the FA's ruling board now believe English football does not need a new national stadium and that England games and FA Cup finals should continue to be played elsewhere, as they have been since Wembley shut in last October. It is costing the FA £2m a month to keep Wembley closed, but it cannot reopen because it does not meet modern safety standards.

It is almost two years since the FA unveiled Sir Norman Foster's design for a 90,000-seat, ultra-modern, luxurious replacement for the ageing, decrepit Wembley, which opened in 1923. The site was bought with £130m of Lottery money to become a multi-purpose national stadium. But since then it has been hit by a series of setbacks, including doubts that the stadium would be able to pay its way.

fields.headline: Census chaos over form delivery
fields.trailText: The organisation of the 2001 census was in chaos yesterday as officials deployed 'emergency measures' to cope with tens of thousands of households which have still not received forms.
fields.body:
The organisation of the 2001 census was in chaos yesterday as officials deployed 'emergency measures' to cope with tens of thousands of households which have still not received forms.

Many are terrified they face a £1,000 fine for non-compliance with tonight's census. But yesterday the Office of National Statistics moved to reassure them.

Paul Vickers, planning chief of the ONS, admitted the threat of a hefty fine had heightened anxiety. He assured The Observer, however, that only those who gave false information or 'wilfully' refused to complete a form would be prosecuted.

'It is a legal requirement to complete the census form,' Vickers said. 'But we do not want to go down the road of prosecuting people.

'People are nervous they will fill things out wrong. But we are here to help - no one is going to be fined for anything except a wilful act.'

The cost of the huge Count Me In project is now expected to rise well over its £255 million budget.

The ONS has already drafted in hundreds more staff and tripled the number of helplines. This year's form is the most detailed in 200 years of census history, and last night the number of calls for help was approaching 1.5 million.

Many people find the form confusing, or say they have still not received one. In some inner-city areas, the latter amount to 20 per cent of the population.

This is an unprecedented level of response to a government campaign. In 1991, less than 130,000 called census helplines.

Census director Graham Jones said: 'We were victims of our own success. I do not believe that a lot of people are not going to be filling [the form] in.'

Historically, only Hitler in 1941, the poll tax in 1991 and the suffragettes in 1891 have had any real impact on average levels of compliance with a census.

This time the 41 questions - eight more than in 1991 - have attracted concern that they include categories for ethnic origin, and a voluntary question about religion.

Len Cook, Registrar General for England and Wales, yesterday conceded that people could write Welsh in the 'Any Other White' box. But anyone using a sticker produced by Plaid Cymru could, technically, still be prosecuted.

In 1991, 342 people were taken to court. One of then was Charlie Watts, the drummer with the Rolling Stones. He was fined £350 after declaring: 'Those who fill in the forms are sheep.'

The census has involved 30 million specially-designed forms and envelopes, and a state-of-the-art scanner to grade them using a unique coding system. Each of Britain's 24 million households should have been called on by one of 70,000 enumerators. They were told to deliver the forms in person rather than simply post them through the letterbox.

But there were reports yesterday of a last-minute panic, with enumerators still wandering around with stacks of undelivered forms - trying to catch up with people who had not been in during working hours. The ONS is also investigating allegations that some forms have simply been dumped.

The census has also led to at least one urban myth. But yesterday the ONS assured us that - no matter how many people put 'Jedi' in the religion box - it will not result in registration of a new faith based on Star Wars .

The census helpline number is 0845 301 2001.

webTitle: Bloodsport gamblers fuel inner city cockfights

fields.headline: Bloodsport gamblers fuel inner city cockfights
fields.standfirst: At dozens of secret venues every week, birds and dogs will be ripped to pieces as thousands of pounds change hands
fields.trailText: At dozens of secret venues every week, birds and dogs will be ripped to pieces as thousands of pounds change hands.
fields.body:
The brutal blood sports of cockfighting and dogfighting are on the rise in Britain again, according to animal welfare officials, with dozens of events taking place around the country each weekend.

Police wildlife officers and senior officials in the RSPCA have told The Observer that they are receiving record numbers of tip-offs. More than 250 suspected cockfights and 100 dogfights were reported to the RSPCA in the last year alone.

Many contests are conducted on a grand scale lasting two or three days and involving dozens of competitors. What was once believed to be a minority sport is fast becoming a major underground industry.

The number of prosecutions for cockfighting has increased sharply during the past five years but officials admit the true scale of the problem may be even greater as a large number of fights are not reported at all.

The recent rise is being attributed to bouts which take place in inner city locations, particularly in Birmingham, Bradford and Leicester.

Tens of thousands of pounds are staked on the contests which often take place in ordinary homes that offer few clues about what goes on inside.

Earlier this month, RSPCA inspectors recounted a raid on the terraced home of Javid Iqbal in Birmingham. Inside they found blood spattered at waist height around all four walls of an upstairs room. Inspectors found dozens of videos of staged fights, metal spurs and other items associated with the bloodsport.

Investigators believe the case represents merely the tip of the iceberg and that many other private homes are being used for regular bouts. Later this year another Asian man will appear in court charged with using his home for organised quail fighting.

Dogfighting, which peaked during the late Eighties, is also on the rise with increasing numbers of banned breeds such as American pit bull terriers being smuggled back into the country. In February, four men received prison sentences after a sophisticated dog-fighting ring was uncovered in Nottinghamshire.

'In the wake of the Dangerous Dogs Act, many of the people involved at the highest levels of dog fighting took their animals abroad,' says Chief Superintendent Barry Fryer, head of the RSPCA's Specialist Operations Unit. 'We are now seeing an increasing number of these animals being returned to Britain, even though they are now illegal here. We're not really sure why, but the climate seems to be right for dog fighting once more. Our information indicates that it is on the increase.'

Barry Fryer, head of the RSCPA's Specialist Operations Unit, says: 'So far as both activities are concerned, there are certainly fights taking place around the country every weekend. There are a number of individuals who are very active in this barbaric pastime who are well known to us. Sizeable sums of money are often involved. In one raid we found an eight-year-old boy among the spectators.'

As well as cockerels, an increasing number of fights are also being staged between quails and partridges. Rather than wearing spurs, these birds have their beaks sharpened with metal files so that pecks to the head inflict far more damage.

The owners of the most successful birds can become wealthy through selling chicks from the same bloodline. Some pedigree birds have allegedly changed hands for the sort of sums normally reserved for racehorses. Fights are often videoed so owners can show off the prowess of their stock.

Although incidents are on the increase, both sports are built around close-knit communities and notoriously difficult to infiltrate. Changes in the law mean that even being a spectator at a cockfight or possessing equipment that could be used in one are criminal offences.

Another trend is that cockfighters from different communities are coming together to compete in 'national' championships. They will often travel hundreds of miles to participate in weekend events which involve dozens of fights. The exact locations remain unknown until the last moment and are revealed on a strict 'need to know' basis.

webTitle: Villages want Gaelic test for homebuyers

fields.headline: Villages want Gaelic test for homebuyers
fields.trailText: Some of Ireland's most idyllic beauty spots may soon be off limits if local inhabitants get their way and stop outsiders from moving into Irish-speaking regions.
fields.body:
Some of Ireland's most idyllic beauty spots may soon be off limits if local inhabitants get their way and stop outsiders from moving into Irish-speaking regions.

An influx of foreigners and wealthy Dubliners to the scenic western seaboard area has prompted the residents of the Gaeltacht to petition their local councils to introduce language tests before allocating local authority housing or granting new planning permissions.

Rejecting claims of xenophobia, they say their culture will not withstand further dilution. They are supported by conservationists, who believe the beauty of the landscape won't survive a further 'bungalow blitz'.

Irish is now spoken only in small pockets of seven counties; at the turn of the century there were an estimated 500,000 native speakers.

Although the number of adults who use the language on a daily basis has fallen to just over 20,000, it is regarded as one of the more successful indigenous tongues in Europe.

Despite this, and the millions of pounds spent by the government on its preservation each year, a recent study conducted at the Max Planck Institute in the Netherlands forecast that Gaelic, with less than 100,000 speakers worldwide, will be extinct by the end of the century.

Many Irish speakers do not agree. In Carraroe, 30 miles outside Galway in the heart of the Gaeltacht, Mici O'Flatharta, a prominent local businessman, says the language will survive if protected.

'We have to make sure people moving in here, particularly children, are Irish speakers,' he says. 'We've got no objections to French, Germans, whatever, buying houses. But they have to be prepared to converse with the locals in our language.'

O'Flatharta and other locals propose that applicants should state their first language when applying for houses in Gaeltacht areas.

Under the Galway county development plan there is provision to refuse planning permission for housing schemes if a case can be made that the Irish language is threatened. However, so far local planning authorities have made no indication that they intend to test on language in the future.

The neighbouring council in County Clare may have set a precedent when it moved recently to ban 'non-natives' from building homes along much of its coastline.

That move was prompted by spiralling house prices when foreigners started moving into the area; the price of some properties has quadrupled in the last two years. The government gives grants of up to £IR12,000 to Irish speakers who buy homes in Gaeltacht regions, but the help is minimal when small one-acre sites can sell for £IR50,000.

Mandy Reid of Galway's Rural Development Company says far larger grants are needed to preserve the family support structures in the Gaeltacht. 'It's not that we want to keep people out, but we have to protect what we've got,' she says.

Demographic changes have caused other tensions. In some of the country's more remote villages, non-nationals can account for up to a third of the population.

Aine Ni Chonaill, a school teacher from west Cork, established her Immigration Platform party to stem the flow of foreigners into rural Ireland. Although she polled just 293 votes in the last election, she maintains that her 'Ireland for the Irish' ethos will gather momentum as the country becomes 'saturated' with non-nationals.

Some foreigners can vouch for the strength of local feeling against their presence. Tony Lowes, a New York-born writer, moved to south-west Ireland in 1963. His passionate support for the environmentalist movement has led to him receiving a bullet in the post.

'The question in the Gaeltacht should not be who builds houses, but what type of home they build,' he says.

'Irish planners are destroying a beautiful landscape by permitting hacienda-style ranch houses to be thrown up in the most inappropriate places.

'Planning is about the use of land, not who uses it. I think this is a more important issue than language.'

fields.headline: Baffled admen turn to Jung
fields.trailText: Big companies are turning to the works of Freud and Jung in a desperate effort to unlock the minds of affluent consumers, after studies showed they were becoming immune to the hard sell of advertising.
fields.body:
Big companies are turning to the works of Freud and Jung in a desperate effort to unlock the minds of affluent consumers, after studies showed they were becoming immune to the hard sell of advertising.

Britons with successful careers and large incomes are so sophisticated that advertisers are unable to use traditional methods to analyse their tastes and aspirations. Known as 'VIPers', the top 17 per cent of the population includes lawyers, media workers and politicians.

Frustrated by failing to get VIPers to spend, advertising experts are using a psycho-logical test to advise brands on which TV programmes they should advertise.

SemioMetrie, based on the techniques of Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung, involves asking consumers how positive or negative they feel about 210 abstract words such as magic, island, glory, forgiveness, red and respect. The answers reveal more about affluent consumers than traditional methods.

Being abstract, the words are more likely to catch interviewees off guard. 'Red may provoke a deeply positive response because somebody is a socialist or a very negative one because they hate Manchester United, but it is their very first reaction we want,' said Richard Marks, director of the first UK Semio Metrie study.

Researchers found those identifying with words in the 'pleasure' area of the map were most likely to watch Channel 4, while those associating themselves with 'duty' words liked BBC1. Men went for words such as war, rifle and nudity, while women ticked wedding, maternal and patience.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Elite police squad officers arrested in drug raids
fields.body:
Elite police squad officers arrested in drug raids

Two officers working for Britain's most elite police force, the National Crime Squad, and three officers from other forces were arrested in a series of raids aimed at smashing a drug ring operating within the organisation.

The arrests, the latest in a series of corruptions scandals to dog the organisation, were among 10 made by Derbyshire police in the early hours of Saturday morning. The 10, identified only as five men and five women, all in their thirties and forties, were detained on suspicion of possessing and supplying cocaine and cannabis. Drugs were recovered from three premises that were raided.

An NCS spokesman said four of those arrested were with the Derbyshire force and one with Nottinghamshire Police.

Everest expedition discovers clothes of 'Mallory and Irvine'

An American expedition to discover whether George Mallory and Andrew Irvine conquered Mount Everest before their deaths 77 years ago has found a sock and mitten thought to belong to the men just 2,000ft below the summit. The new evidence was found at about 27,000ft, possibly the highest camp established by the British mountaineers. The sock and mitten were excavated in a shallow gully near the crest of Everest's North Ridge.

Omagh vandals: three quizzed

Three people - two men and a juvenile - were being questioned by police about the wrecking of the Garden of Remembrance to the victims of the Omagh bomb. Vandals uprooted trees, overturned seats, smashed flowerpots and pulled out shrubs.

Spy Trap's Daneman dies

Actor Paul Daneman - best known for his role in the BBC1 drama series Spy Trap - died yesterday at the age of 75.

His wife, novelist Meredith Daneman, said he had lost a long battle against heart disease. He had his first heart attack when he was 53 while acting on the West End stage. He used his experience of recovering from this attack as the basis for a successful comedy series, Affairs of the Heart.

New tip-off in Lamplugh hunt

A police team looking for the body of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh continued to search remote woodland in the Quantock Hills in Somerset after new information from the public prompted them to extend the scope of the operation.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said last night that the search by the 20-strong team had taken longer than originally thought because the search area has been extended following new information.

But he said he could not comment on reports that a local man had come forward to saying that a member of his family had seen a man digging in the Quantocks at about the same time as Lamplugh went missing in 1986.

New numbers

Four million mobile phone numbers beginning 03, 04, 05, 08 and 09 were decommissioned yesterday. By mid-morning almost three-quarters of the people concerned were using their new numbers correctly.

For more information, contact The Big Number on freephone 0808 224 2000 or www.numberchange.org

TV industry sees religion as a joke, says former BBC expert

The BBC's former head of religious broadcasting, Ernest Rea, has said that 'people who control the television industry in this country are... children of the Sixties and Seventies, secular people who accept as a given that the notion of God is a nonsense and who regard religion as little more than an amusing but outdated phenomenon.'

Lottery numbers

The winning numbers are 2 25 33 40 44 47, bonus 17. Thunderball numbers are 2 7 11 12 23, Thunderball 9. Lottery Extra numbers are 5 12 33 38 42 48.

fields.headline: Keane's escape lesson for FA
fields.trailText: It can be done, but not if the referee has seen it.
fields.body:
It can be done, but not if the referee has seen it.

To explain: an FA rule states that if a referee has seen an incident, then whatever action he takes, or doesn't, is deemed appropriate, whether he is right or wrong. If he misses it, then the FA can act on their own. Thus did Carlisle's Richard Prokas escape further punishment after his tackle on Patrick Vieira. Thus is Roy Keane's red card and automatic four-match ban for his stud-stabbing of Alf-Inge Haaland - it being his second dismissal of the season - a convenient end to the matter.

It is clearly an anomaly, and a rule that needs revising. How is it that Vieira last season could get six matches for spitting and Keane a lesser punishment for assault, the Manchester police having so far declined to get involved? The reason is simply because the referee could not act on one, having already sent off Vieira just before the spitting, but did as much as he could on the other, at least on the day. So far David Elleray is in dereliction of duty; his report did not recommend any further action against Keane and so the FA say they are not considering any. Football should follow rugby league's lead. Their video panel is on stand-by to meet on a Monday to consider weekend controversy, whether dealt with by ref or not, and metes out punishment, after which players can appeal.

The FA acted in the case of Chelsea's Slavisa Jokanovic treading on the head of Sunderland's Don Hutchison last month, charging him with violent conduct only on Friday. In addition, the FA's video panel, who meet 'as and when', might discover some courage, the sort Fifa showed last week in banning Colin Hendry for six international matches for his frightening elbow on a San Marino player. Somehow the FA, laughably, concluded last week that Chelsea's Celestine Babayaro stamping on Arsenal's Freddie Ljungberg was accidental.

fields.headline: Beckham hits back at Keane
fields.trailText: David Beckham has responded to Roy Keane's criticisms of Manchester United by claiming the Champions are 'a great team'.
fields.body:
David Beckham has responded to Roy Keane's criticisms of Manchester United by claiming the Champions are 'a great team'.

Keane, the United captain, upset several of his Old Trafford team-mates with his latest controversial outburst. Beckham was as hurt as anybody by United's Champions League quarter-final exit at the hands of Bayern Munich 10 days ago, but he reckons their haul of seven Premiership titles in nine seasons shows they are anything but 'an average team' as Keane described them.

Beckham, talking to Manchester radio station GMR, also hinted that Keane should have kept his mouth shut. The England captain said: 'It is disappointing when you don't do well in the European Cup, but this is a great team.

'So many people have said there should be changes and there should be this and there should be that, but we've won seven championships in nine years as well as FA Cups and a European Cup. I don't think that is really the sign of an average team.

'There are some who have not done as well as they can do this season, but you should always stick together as a team. We have never been a side who have come out in the papers and said things about each other, or other players.

'It's the manager who makes the decisions. If he thinks the team needs strengthening, then it's up to him what happens. He [Sir Alex Ferguson] has said all along that he's going to strengthen the team. He's done it before and he'll do it again. That's what Manchester United is all about.'

Beckham scored in United's 2-0 win at Middlesbrough. Phil Neville scored the other goal. After the game, Ferguson refused to fuel the row: 'I've not heard the Beckham interview so I have no comment,' he said .

In the race for the second and third places in the Champions League, Arsenal, Leeds and Liverpool all won. Ipswich play at Charlton tomorrow night.

fields.headline: No Keane, but no complacency
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough may well escape relegation this season, but their performance in this game proved they are a league away in talent compared with the title-winners. Try as they would, the Teessiders were hopelessly outclassed by a United side that featured many unfamiliar faces, and they were outplayed in almost every position. Goals in the opening and closing few minutes of the game gave United the cushion to enjoy a relaxed afternoon in the sunshine.
fields.byline: John Wilford at The Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
Middlesbrough may well escape relegation this season, but their performance in this game proved they are a league away in talent compared with the title-winners. Try as they would, the Teessiders were hopelessly outclassed by a United side that featured many unfamiliar faces, and they were outplayed in almost every position. Goals in the opening and closing few minutes of the game gave United the cushion to enjoy a relaxed afternoon in the sunshine.

Terry Venables, who has achieved so much since his arrival last December, when Boro were bottom of the table with just 11 points, persisted with an attacking formation relying on Windass, Boksic and Ricard to chase the goals that would ensure another season in the Premiership.

United had an unfamiliar line-up, with Keane still injured and presumably not to be seen again this season pending his suspension for That Challenge last week on Alf Inge Haarland. Barthez failed a fitness test so, Van Der Gouw was in goal and 20-year-old Michael Stewart made his debut in midfield. Philip Neville replaced brother Gary in defence with Giggs, Cole, Yorke and Chadwick starting on the bench. Scholes was not in the squad - his wife being in labour.

It was Philip Neville, playing left-back, who gave United a fourth-minute lead. Picking up the ball halfway inside his opponents' half, Neville was allowed to move forward unchallenged before unleashing a right-foot shot from 25 yards which caught Schwarzer flat-footed on his line. The ball flashed past his despairing, but late, dive just inside the left-hand post.

Boro's reply relied mainly on Boksic making solo runs at the United back line without the support to outwit Stam and Johnsen. And United's confidence wasn't shaken when Dean Windass fastened on to a loose ball at the edge of the area and drove a low right-foot shot a yard to the outside of Van Der Gouw's right-hand post. In the main, though, it was still Boksic versus the rest, and despite his vigour he lacked the pace to sprint past defenders as quick as Wes Brown.

United continued to look comfortable with their lead, but Boro, urged forward by Okan and Ince, began to play with more spirit. A good chance fell to Windass and just before half-time Windass volleyed the ball goalward only for Van Der Gouw to push it over the bar in style.

Stewart, who became more influential as the game went on, marked his debut with a yellow card when he collared Windass as the former Bradford player was sprinting towards the penalty area. United, although playing at a leisurely pace, still strung passes together as if they were on the training ground, finally clinched the result with a Beckham goal six minutes from time.

It was embarrassingly simple. Giggs pulled the ball back from the byline and Beckham side-footed it past Schwarzer's right hand.

fields.headline: Maestro McAllister
fields.trailText: The trapdoor is shaking on its hinges for Coventry City. After 34 years of top-flight football, the hurt is ominously close. Surely it is too much to expect the great escapologists to do it again. Five points adrift, two games to go.
fields.body:
The trapdoor is shaking on its hinges for Coventry City. After 34 years of top-flight football, the hurt is ominously close. Surely it is too much to expect the great escapologists to do it again. Five points adrift, two games to go.

Succumbing late to Liverpool, the blow was all the crueller in that it was delivered by Gary McAllister. Having departed Highfield Road last summer, he graced the red shirt with the kind of qualities Coventry so dearly miss. The 36-year-old Scot with the distinguished touch and redoubtable example created the first goal and claimed the second.

If anyone was in any doubt about the graveness of Coven try's predicament, the DJ blasted that Eighties classic 'The Final Countdown' as the Sky Blues cantered out to confront their Premiership fate. Presumably he hadn't noticed it was also appropriate motivation for Liverpool, given the fact the singers were a band called Europe.

With the Worthington Cup in the bag and FA and Uefa Cup finals looming, the small matter of a Champions League finish is unquestionably at the forefront of every Anfield mind. Liverpool could not afford to show their hosts any compassion, and duly rattled Coventry as early as the fourth minute. From a Gary McAllister corner, Sami Hyypia's header was hooked off the line by John Eustace before Patrick Berger lashed the rebound high over the bar.

Character being such a crucial ingredient in the thick of the relegation mire, City brushed off their early scare and instantly took the game to Liverpool: Youssef Chippo's clever threaded pass released the marauding Paul Williams and the home supporters rose in anticipation. The big defender, finding himself in unfamiliar territory, took aim but his clipped shot was turned aside by Sander Westerveld. On the offensive, they threatened again immediately. Paul Telfer's corner, glanced on by John Hartson, dropped invitingly for Eustace but the 21-year-old midfielder couldn't quite steer the ball on target.

With their Welsh spearhead of Hartson and Craig Bellamy in troublesome mood, complemented by the support of their tricky Moroccans - Hadji, returning from a three match suspension, and Chippo - Coventry were playing some tidy football. All they needed was the boldness to turn possession into penetration but clear-cut chances were scarce.

In fact the next one fell to the visitors. Robbie Fowler ghosted in to meet Markus Babbel's long-range drive with an acrobatic volley which arched over the bar. Realising the initiative was there to be seized Liverpool began to press towards the Coventry goal. Chris Kirkland has an impressive presence for so young a goalkeeper - he needed to, considering his defence was, understandably, a little nervy at times.

Liverpool ended the first half as they began it, causing Coventry to skip a heartbeat from a Gary McAllister corner. Floated in beautifully, Hyypia rose to glance the ball onto Fowler, whose angled header drifted wide.

Missing the influence of Steven Gerrard, Liverpool lacked cohesion, and squandered chances. Fowler, in particular, was not enjoying the most productive of games. Such is the difference between top and bottom though. Looking for a matchwinner with so much at stake, Liverpool introduced Michael Owen, while for Coventry, his international striking counterpart from Peru, Ysrael Zuniga, entered the fray. Lively he was too, latching on to a Hartson flick on with his first touch, only to be thwarted by Westerveld.

Owen was direct, energetic, and a constant threat. He was unfortunate to see his goalbound curler deflected by Williams with a huge shout for handball. Ignored by the officials, Liverpool had to make do with a corner and duly unleashed their frustration as McAllister's umpteenth delivery was dispatched majestically by Hyypia's header. A minute later McAllister pierced the hearts of his former club with another immaculate free kick, his fourth in four games. With friends like that, Coventry don't need enemies.

fields.headline: Lions go up fighting
fields.trailText: In Millwall's long and troubled history the crowd incident which led to a 20 minute hold-up here will hardly merit a footnote but a few idiots still tarnished what should have been a day to celebrate earning promotion.
fields.byline: Duncan Mackay at the Racecourse Ground
fields.body:
In Millwall's long and troubled history the crowd incident which led to a 20 minute hold-up here will hardly merit a footnote but a few idiots still tarnished what should have been a day to celebrate earning promotion.

The match was only into its second minute when a handful of the 3,000 travelling supporters decided to try and storm the Wrexham sections of the ground. The police quickly got the situation under control before a long stand-off developed until the interlopers returned to their seats following an appeal from Mark McGhee, the Millwall manager.

To the credit of most of the Millwall fans, they made their disgust known but they could still end up with their club having to make another visit to the Football Association. Oh, how the First Division must be looking forward to the prospect of the extra police bills a visit from the Lions will bring.

When the match restarted there was a heightened tension, which was added to when Wrexham took the lead almost immediately - and in front of the Millwall supporters. There were nine minutes on the clock when Carlos Edwards fired in a low cross which Craig Faulconbridge turned into the net.

It took Millwall until the 53rd minute to equalise, when Tim Cahill met David Livermore's corner with a powerful header which sparked a joyous pitch invasion, and a three-minute delay.

That led to a warning that one more problem would lead to the match being abandoned, prompting a chorus of 'No one likes us, we don't care'. But then it does take a special sort of fan to want to ruin their own party.
