fields.headline: Preston in play-offs
fields.trailText: Preston clinched their place in the First Division play-offs through a 3-1 win at Crewe, and the failure of Burnley and Wimbledon to get maximum points.
fields.body:
Preston clinched their place in the First Division play-offs through a 3-1 win at Crewe, and the failure of Burnley and Wimbledon to get maximum points.

Preston's success, achieved with one goal from David Healey and two from Jonathon Macken, contrasted sharply with the fortunes of West Bromwich Albion. A win at home to relegation-threatened Huddersfield would have guaranteed them a play-off spot too, but they were held to a 1-1 draw. However, it could have been even worse because Huddersfield's Andy Booth, scorer of the goal that brought his old club Sheffield Wednesday a 2-1 win at West Brom last month, put the visitors ahead after just seven minutes when he latched onto goalkeeper Nico Vaesen's long goal-kick down the middle, raced between the centre-backs and coolly lobbed the ball over the keeper, Russell Hoult.

West Brom equalised 10 minutes later through Jason Roberts - his first goal in 11 games.

Birmingham secured their berth in the play-offs by beating Grimsby 1-0, but Burnley and Nottingham Forest, the teams immediately behind them, suffered defeats at the hands of Sheffield United and Gillingham respectively.

Burnley's loss will have been particularly disappointing for their former Greek international keeper Nik Michopoulos. He saved a penalty by Paul Devlin, only for Peter Ndlovu to tap in the rebound. Burnley, who then had Kevin Ball sent off, conceded another goal in the last minute, from Carl Asaba.

Watford, while announcing that they expect to be in a position to name Graham Taylor's successor as manager 'within the next few days', played a straight bat on reports that it will be Gianluca Vialli.

A club statement read: 'Watford Football Club has nothing to add to the speculation concerning the position of team manager.'

In what was expected to be Taylor's final match at Vicarage Road before his retirement, the Watford fans acknowledged his tremendous career with the club with T-shirts bearing his photograph and proclaiming: 'There's only one Graham Taylor.'

Unfortunately, his team, needing a win over relegated Tranmere to maintain their faint promotion hopes, could hardly be said to have helped make the occasion special in being held to a 1-1 draw. Most notable scorers were Alan Lee and Bobby Zamora. Lee's last-minute goal gave Rotherham a 2-1 win over Brentford, and thus automatic promotion from the Second Division, while Zamora's hat-trick in Brighton's 4-1 win against Macclesfield brought them the Third Division title.

Plyers, it is said, only feel tired when they are losing. One wonders what Port Vale will make of that following their 3-2 defeat at home to Notts County.

Having beaten Brentford in last Sunday's LDV Vans Trophy Final, and Northampton last Thursday, they will need all the energy they can muster this week. They face Bristol Rovers (a) tomorrow; Oxford (a) on Tuesday; Walsall (h) on Thursday; and Luton (a) on Saturday.

fields.headline: Buchan boosts United
fields.trailText: The principle of no pain, no gain has to be brought to every outing by teams fighting relegation, but it was Motherwell, safe from the agonising anxieties of avoiding the drop, who had to suffer on Tayside.
fields.body:
The principle of no pain, no gain has to be brought to every outing by teams fighting relegation, but it was Motherwell, safe from the agonising anxieties of avoiding the drop, who had to suffer on Tayside.

Defeat would be souring enough, but the sending-off of central defender James Okoli 12 minutes into the second half would deepen the disappointment, as the referee seemed to favour his opponent, Charlie Miller, in the scuffle which brought the red card.

Okoli had fouled the United midfielder, whose retaliation caused the initial offender to come back with fisticuffs of his own. If the referee was going to send off anyone - he could have satisfied himself with cautions as the violence would not have offended a nun - it should have been both.

United had established a clear authority and had seemed more likely than their visitors to add to the strike with which they had taken the lead at a crucial time.

The exhilarating execution of Buchan's goal was as predictable as a snowfall at the equator in a match which, until then, had seemed bland, both sides beset by difficulties.

It was an indication of Motherwell's personnel problems in recent times that their starting line-up should contain only two players, Kevin Twaddle and Steven Hammell, who were in the team for their last visit to Tannadice, at the end of January.

The intervening three months have seen an extraordinary turnover as manager Billy Davies has been forced to reduce costs, jettisoning a raft of players as the club wrestle an £8 million debt.

United's disadvantages, of course, derived mainly from their own central nervous system. The 2-1 defeat by St Mirren last Monday not only reduced the gap between the sides to one point, but clearly diluted the self-belief of Alex Smith's team.

There was an unmissable edginess about the home side which led naturally to a lack of composure and inventiveness. Guile is invariably the first victim of tension. In the circumstances, nobody would be surprised and the long periods of unthreatening football, both sides apparently apprehensive about committing too many players in forward areas.

If United were ahead territorially before Buchan's goal, it was through industriousness and commitment, qualities which have to be complemented by creativity if superiority is to be achieved. The home side's near things before their productive spell shortly before the break were not near enough to be worth chronicling.

Apart from a lob volley from Twaddle after a marvellous through pass from Said Chaiba had left him clear on the right side of the penalty area - his effort sending the ball a foot wide of the far post - Motherwell were without menace.

Buchan's intervention was as brilliant as it was sudden. After Chaiba and David Hannah had contested possession in midfield - the latter claiming a free kick as his team-mate sped off with the ball - Buchan made a powerful run past two defenders on the left of midfield and, as Derek Lilley moved across the box to receive what seemed an inevitable pass, Buchan suddenly hit the ball with his right foot and it swerved wickedly away to the left of Jon Connolly from 25 yards.

If that seemed like a bad moment for the goalkeeper, making his Motherwell debut, it would be followed soon after by two of deep satisfaction, Connolly first foiling Lilley when the latter was sent clear on a pass from Craig Easton and then making a marvellous save from David Partidge's close-range volley from a corner kick by Miller.

Connolly had to go to work again when Lilley was sent clear on the right side of the box and he did what was necessary, falling to smother the striker's low shot, but the lack of pace in the effort made the chore much easier. That typified United's endeavours after Okoli's dismissal. There was a fearfulness about them which was almost palpable.

St Mirren, Dundee United's partners in distress, kept the gap between the two teams at the bottom to just one point with a 2-1 win at Dunfermline.

The Saints, having given themselves a relegation lifeline with their win at United last week, lived on their nerves in the opening 20 minutes, with Dunfermline creating the best chances.

Three of them fell to Steve Crawford, who came closest to scoring with a shot which hit the post. St Mirren, no doubt lifted by such let-offs, broke the deadlock after 31 minutes with a Jamie McGowan header and Mark Yardley increased their lead three minutes before half-time. Dunfermline did not get their goal, through Lee Bullen, until the last minute.

In the circumstances, nobody would be surprised and the long periods of unthreatening football, both sides apparently apprehensive about committing too many players in forward areas. If United were ahead territorially before Buchan's goal, it was through industriousness and commitment, qualities which have to be complemented by creativity if superiority is to be achieved. The home side's near things before their productive spell shortly before the break were not near enough to be worth chronicling. Apart from a lob volley from Twaddle after a marvellous through pass from Said Chaiba had left him clear on the right side of the penalty area - his effort sending the ball a foot wide of the far post - Motherwell were without menace. Buchan's intervention was as brilliant as it was sudden. After Chaiba and David Hannah had contested possession in midfield - the latter claiming a free kick as his team-mate sped off with the ball - Buchan made a powerful run past two defenders on the left of midfield and, as Derek Lilley moved across the box to receive what seemed an inevitable pass, Buchan suddenly hit the ball with his right foot and it swerved wickedly away to the left of Jon Connolly from 25 yards. If that seemed like a bad moment for the goalkeeper, making his Motherwell debut, it would be followed soon after by two of deep satisfaction, Connolly first foiling Lilley when the latter was sent clear on a pass from Craig Easton and then making a marvellous save from David Partidge's close-range volley from a corner kick by Miller. Connolly had to go to work again when Lilley was sent clear on the right side of the box and he did what was necessary, falling to smother the striker's low shot, but the lack of pace in the effort made the chore much easier. That typified United's endeavours after Okoli's dismissal. There was a fearfulness about them which was almost palpable. St Mirren, Dundee United's partners in distress, kept the gap between the two teams at the bottom to just one point with a 2-1 win at Dunfermline. The Saints, having given themselves a relegation lifeline with their win at United last week, lived on their nerves in the opening 20 minutes, with Dunfermline creating the best chances. Three of them fell to Steve Crawford, who came closest to scoring with a shot which hit the post. St Mirren, no doubt lifted by such let-offs, broke the deadlock after 31 minutes with a Jamie McGowan header and Mark Yardley increased their lead three minutes before half-time. Dunfermline did not get their goal, through Lee Bullen, until the last minute.

fields.headline: Misery for sad Palace
fields.trailText: Crystal Palace are staring at Second Division football next season. They have won only once in 14 matches and the manner of this defeat will give them no encouragement whatsoever for their final two matches at Portsmouth and Stockport.
fields.body:
Crystal Palace are staring at Second Division football next season. They have won only once in 14 matches and the manner of this defeat will give them no encouragement whatsoever for their final two matches at Portsmouth and Stockport.

Long before the end, fans were calling for the head of manager Alan Smith and the return of Steve Coppell, who resigned last summer rather than, as he put it, 'bang heads' with new owner Simon Jordan. Some supporters even hurled used up season tickets on to the pitch perimeter to express their dissatisfaction.

Even against a team with little to play for and who were reduced to 10 men before half-time when Keith Andrews was sent off for a reckless challenge on Andrej Rubins, Palace were found wanting.

When Temuri Ketsbaia peeled off his shirt and threw it at the dug out in disgust after being substituted a couple of minutes later, Wolves briefly looked in disarray. But they not only held on to Andy Sinton's spectacular 35-yard half-volley which dipped under the cross bar, but added to it when Adam Proudlock, sent through the middle by Michael Branch, bobbled his shot over the line. Proudlock had to look twice to check that the ball really had gone in.

Palace mounted plenty of pressure in the second half without ever really looking like retrieving the situation. Their last chance went when Finland international Aki Riihilahti was denied by a goalline clearance. Palace deserved no more and barring a turnaround in fortunes will play outside the top two divisions for the first time in nearly a quarter of a century.

fields.headline: City caught short by Cort
fields.trailText: Doctors have told Tim Flowers he possess the arthritic hip of a 60-year-old, but the Leicester keeper proved yesterday that the rest of his 34-year-old body is in perfect working order. Flowers' reflexes and agility enabled him to make four splendid saves, but he was beaten in the cruellest fashion three minutes into stoppage time.
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James's Park
fields.body:
Doctors have told Tim Flowers he possess the arthritic hip of a 60-year-old, but the Leicester keeper proved yesterday that the rest of his 34-year-old body is in perfect working order. Flowers' reflexes and agility enabled him to make four splendid saves, but he was beaten in the cruellest fashion three minutes into stoppage time.

The keeper was left stranded when Carl Cort's shot was deflected in to condemn City to their ninth successive defeat. The ovation for Flowers from the Newcastle crowd at the end reflected the quality of his saves.

The best was an instinctive reaction which deflected Nikos Dabizas' powerful close-range header on to the bar in the 57th minute of a match dominated by Newcastle.

Not far behind in quality was Flowers' sharp response in the 12th minute to a Kevin Gallacher volley which was touched on to a post, while Cort and Gary Speed also suffered at the keeper's hands.

Cort's anguish was even worse in the 83rd minute when he headed Lomana LuaLua's cross wide from only six yards. Even Flowers should have been left with no hope on that occasion, although Cort's fortuitous winner made amends.

While Flowers was denied a clean sheet, Newcastle keeper Shay Given finally achieved one through of the ineptitude of Peter Taylor's team.

Newcastle have conceded goals in all of their previous 29 matches and City - scorers of only 10 goals away from home this season - always offered the best chance of ending that depressing sequence before the end of the season.

So it proved. Taylor can point to the absence of Robbie Savage, Muzzy Izzet, Matt Elliott and Gerry Taggart - who would be difficult to replace in any team. But he will have expected a better response from their replacements, most of them bought by him from lower league clubs. Leicester seriously troubled Given only once when he saved at the end of a break by Ade Akinbiyi.

webTitle: Old Firm lacks the old venom

fields.headline: Old Firm lacks the old venom
fields.trailText: Like a boxer in a re-match with the only man who has ever beaten him, Celtic would, in normal circumstances, be entitled to at least mild apprehension over this afternoon's return to Ibrox Park, the scene of their solitary defeat from 43 outings in the domestic campaign.
fields.body:
Like a boxer in a re-match with the only man who has ever beaten him, Celtic would, in normal circumstances, be entitled to at least mild apprehension over this afternoon's return to Ibrox Park, the scene of their solitary defeat from 43 outings in the domestic campaign.

The current climate, however, is far from conventional. Not only has that 5-1 thrashing from Rangers last November been followed by two victories over their great rivals at Hampden and Celtic Park, but the CIS Insurance League Cup and the championship have been stowed away and a rendezvous with Hibs in the Tennents Scottish Cup final beckons invitingly on 26 May.

At a time of the year when the final Old Firm showdown often assumes the significance of a league decider, Rangers find themselves in the alien position of having nothing to gain, yet having to absorb whatever pressure attends such an event. With their supporters already disenchanted by a calamitous season, Dick Advocaat's players enter the fray in the realisation that even the satisfaction of victory will be an ephemeral thing, lasting only the length of the day on which it is achieved.

It is an awkward assignment at which Celtic have had much more practice through the past dozen years or so. The Parkhead side have on several occasions during that time won meaningless Old Firm skirmishes - the title already lost - and have, in the process, attracted a jaundiced look from some of their fans.

In some quarters, such victories have been met with ridicule. 'Beating Rangers when it meant nothing - it's too little, too late,' they seemed to say. When I outlined to Advocaat the possibility of his team being given similar treatment now that the roles have been reversed, he responded in a way that the majority of Rangers' followers would find appealing, even encouraging.

'It's never too late to win an Old Firm match,' said the Dutchman. 'These games are played at a different level and it brings great satisfaction to win them.'

With Claudio Reyna suspended and players such as Giovanni van Bronckhorst and Neil McCann still missing because of injury, Advocaat's team will still be at less than full strength, but, at Celtic Park, Martin O'Neill will be without Chris Sutton, Bobby Petta and Stilian Petrov, three players who would be natural first picks if available.

In any case, Advocaat now carefully avoids giving the impression that he believes Celtic's triumphs this season have been attributable mainly to Rangers' misfortunes. He emphasises that his own squad's lengthy casualty list through the past few months has nothing to do with what O'Neill's team have done.

'It would be unfair to Celtic, because they have been very consistent throughout the season,' he said. It was when Rangers lost 6-2 at Parkhead at the end of August that the first tremors of O'Neill's impact were felt and even Rangers' impressive retaliation at Ibrox three months later made little difference. After that wide-margin victory, they were still 12 points adrift.

Advocaat believes there was something artificial about both of the high-scoring games, that a measure of the difference between the sides could more accurately be made in the CIS Cup semi-final, which Celtic won 3-1, and in the league fixture at Parkhead, the home side winning 1-0.

'I think Celtic deserved to win the semi-final, although there were some strange refereeing decisions and in the last match, I thought we did well enough in the second half to get a draw. So there was not much between us, much more like normal,' he said.

No matter the noises Advocaat makes about being stimulated once again by the singular atmosphere of an Old Firm collision, however, it is impossible to escape the impression that he is willing the season to draw to a close as quickly as possible to allow him to take a short break, re-group and implement changes that will strengthen his side for next time.

O'Neill's interest is captured much more effectively by the Scottish Cup final than even a meeting with Rangers, but the fact that he will not field a deliberately experimental line-up - one that gives trials to younger, peripheral players - until today's commitment is fulfilled.

'It won't be the most meaningful fixture in Old Firm history, but it's a game in which we'd want to beat them,' he said. Then, with undisguised sarcasm, alluding to the possibility of colliding with opponents desperate for atonement, he added: 'Rangers will be fired up for it. There's no reason to think the game will be anything other than a great footballing spectacle.'

It is more likely that the event will be marked by a certain caginess as each tries to ensure that the embarrassments they both suffered in the first two games are not repeated. Celtic may have more self-belief than opponents whose morale has taken a battering over a lengthy period, but it is difficult not to predict that O'Neill's players, with a cup final in the offing, will be looking after themselves, if subconsciously.

Unfettered by such a tantalising prospect, Rangers will surely view the occasion as an opportunity to restore some pride and credibility and it would be no surprise if they were to inflict Celtic's second defeat of this extraordinary season.

fields.headline: Ginola's pig's ear
fields.trailText: The prodigal son's return was celebrated not with a fatted calf but with a pig's ear of a game, this sterile goalless draw doing little to enhance either side's already pencil-thin chances of qualifying for Europe.
fields.byline: Gerry Cox at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
The prodigal son's return was celebrated not with a fatted calf but with a pig's ear of a game, this sterile goalless draw doing little to enhance either side's already pencil-thin chances of qualifying for Europe.

In the absence of almost any meaningful goalmouth action, the biggest cheer of the day was reserved for the appearance as substitute of David Ginola, returning to White Hart Lane for the first time since he left Spurs for Villa last summer.

All sides of the ground rose in applause of the Frenchman who was such a favourite with Spurs' supporters, but the fact that he appeared for just the final 10 minutes meant he had little chance of rescuing what was an archetypal end-of-season game.

Although Villa had - indeed still have - a mathematical chance of a Uefa Cup place, they did not start like a team with anything to play for, while Spurs cannot wait for the season to end.

Struck down by a rash of injuries and stuck in mid-table, all Hoddle can hope for is that his youngsters and bit-part players can push them selves a little closer to centre stage as he starts rebuilding.

Yesterday it was young defender Anthony Gardner's turn to shine in the absence of Sol Campbell and Chris Perry, and the former Port Vale player excelled on his full home debut. Not that he had much to contend with, as Villa managed just one serious chance, when Paul Merson broke clear of the defence in the 74th minute only to have his shot well saved by Neil Sullivan, with Luke Young clearing Darius Vassell's follow-up off the line.

Spurs also created little, their best chance coming midway through the first half when Les Ferdinand slid in on a cross from Simon Davies but diverted the ball over the bar from close range.

With eight players out, Spurs ran out of steam, and Hoddle admitted: 'I wouldn't mind the season closing down now. We've got a lot of long-term injuries, but at least this is invaluable experience for the youngsters.'

Villa's manager John Gregory was tempted to send on Ginola earlier: 'He has turned games for us in the last 20 minutes before, but sometimes players returning to their old clubs do not do themselves justice.' Shame he was not given the chance.

webTitle: Why must my son move to New Zealand?

fields.headline: Why must my son move to New Zealand?
fields.trailText: I am a divorced woman in my late fifties. I have two sons, one of whom is married to a lovely woman from New Zealand. They have two young children - my only grandchildren.
fields.body:
I am a divorced woman in my late fifties. I have two sons, one of whom is married to a lovely woman from New Zealand. They have two young children - my only grandchildren.

They have recently devastated me with the news that they have decided to sell up home and emigrate to New Zealand. I am heartbroken and can barely bring myself to speak to my daughter-in-law, who, rightly or wrongly, I blame for taking my son away from me. They live near to me now and are such an intrinsic part of my life that I don't know how I will cope when they have gone.

Am I right to depend so heavily on them for my happiness and blame my daughter-in-law for breaking up the family?
NS

Some problems are not amenable to solving, only to commiserating. Family bonds can be so strong under certain circumstances that outside people are irrelevant. Yet you know deep down that it's madness to put all your emotional eggs in one basket.

Your anguish is very like a bereavement or a divorce. Pinning the blame on someone is a common response, and yet it seems illogical because it appears to prolong the agony. Maybe it displaces the pain, making it easier to deal with, perhaps in a situation where guilt is involved.

You must realise your comment about breaking up the family is unfair, especially from your daughter-in-law's perspective. She is actually reuniting her family, by taking her children to her home in her native to land to meet the other set of grandparents. You cannot blame her in the least for wanting to do that, and wanting it very vehemently. Her parents' claim on the grandchildren is quite as strong as yours. You must reconcile yourself to being alone in your grief, as this move of theirs may bring simultaneous joy to many other folk.

It is worth dwelling on this point so that you don't compound your misery by creating a breach between you and them. Instead make the most of the time you have left with them and enjoy it to the full. Sometimes it takes a catastrophe to propel oneself out of a rut, so think positive. Will you be able to plan a visit to your family maybe, even on a yearly basis? You may never have thought of travelling so adventurously before, but it should be within your grasp. It could be something to look forward to and plan for.

There are other things, too, like discussing how to keep in touch. Letters of course, but in these days of modern technology there are more exciting ways such as email. You can have instant conversations at little extra cost, and it's possible to send pictures this way. Maybe your son could help set up a computer for you to practise with email before he goes.

I realise that nothing will wholly compensate for not seeing your grandchildren growing up day by day. It does sound as if you have come to rely on them too much for your emotional outlet. It can sometimes be too heavy a burden of responsibility for a young family to cope with, and they probably feel agonies of guilt for leaving you alone.

On the theme of salvaging joy from sorrow, try to take stock of your life and recreate those vital social contacts that seem to have gone missing. There is never any shortage of activities to join, depending on what your interests are. Don't forget your other son too. Maybe he has felt cold-shouldered and left out because he hasn't provided you with an extended family. He needs your support as much as anyone.

You can make this bolt from the blue an opportunity for a new start if you will, so bestir yourself, be adventurous and don't be suffocated by sorrow.

Readers' replies

NS's dilemma rings a bell with me because my only daughter and her boyfriend, both Australian passport holders, are planning to return there in a year or so. Australia permits visitors to stay for up to three months a year, and has a scheme for 'Aged Parents' to be admitted permanently. NS could find out whether similar arrangements are offered by New Zealand.

If she does not want to transplant she could take out a shared-equity scheme (as described in last week's dilemma) to free up capital and allow her to travel regularly. Above all, she should avoid breaking up the family by alienating her daughter-in-law and losing visiting rights to their new home. Probably the daughter-in-law wants her own parents to share in their grandchildren too, and she and NS's son may well feel they can give their children a better life in New Zealand. Meanwhile, why not take up some new interests and make some new friends? In the end we all have to be self-reliant.
MEC of Finchley

Next week's dilemma

A friend of mine has recently split up from her husband of 22 years. He has left her for a younger woman who has subsequently had a baby. My friend's daughter, who is 20, has always been an independent girl but since her parents split, she has become very clingy to her mother and even moved back to the family home.

My friend is in a quandary. She actually needs her own space to sort herself out but feels unable to add to her daughter's insecurity by asking her to leave. Is she right to put her child's feelings above her own, or should she put herself first?
CB of Surrey

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk

 Views on problems must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

NS could find out whether similar arrangements are offered by New Zealand. If she does not want to transplant she could take out a shared-equity scheme (as described in last week's dilemma) to free up capital and allow her to travel regularly. Above all, she should avoid breaking up the family by alienating her daughter-in-law and losing visiting rights to their new home. Probably the daughter-in-law wants her own parents to share in their grandchildren too, and she and NS's son may well feel they can give their children a better life in New Zealand. Meanwhile, why not take up some new interests and make some new friends? In the end we all have to be self-reliant. MEC of Finchley Next week's dilemma A friend of mine has recently split up from her husband of 22 years. He has left her for a younger woman who has subsequently had a baby. My friend's daughter, who is 20, has always been an independent girl but since her parents split, she has become very clingy to her mother and even moved back to the family home. My friend is in a quandary. She actually needs her own space to sort herself out but feels unable to add to her daughter's insecurity by asking her to leave. Is she right to put her child's feelings above her own, or should she put herself first? CB of Surrey Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk  Views on problems must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: Fathering a child in your fifties

fields.headline: Who are you calling grandad?
fields.standfirst: It's all very well having a baby in your twilight years but will you still have the energy to change a nappy at 4am - or cope with a gaggle of under-nines in the local Happy Eater?
fields.trailText: It's all very well having a baby in your twilight years but will you still have the energy to change a nappy at 4am - or cope with a gaggle of under-nines in the local Happy Eater?
fields.body:
Phil Collins, eh? What a geezer. A father for the fourth time at 50! Hey, that's older than Tony Blair - though younger than Eric Clapton (56) and Bill Wyman (65), who have also been furiously at it with their young missuses.

Still, it proves that the old todge is still working, which is always a bit tricky PR-wise, in the absence of inviting tabloid photographers into your bedroom. After all, there's not much point bagging - oh, all right, shagging - a nice 29-year-old if you've got nothing to show for it except high blood pressure and a rather pleasing sense of personal achievement. It's just not enough. You want a medal too. Look what I've been up to!

Obviously, unlike Tony, Phil hasn't got a general election on his plate this year. But you can imagine his record company thinking it won't do sales of the back catalogue any harm, especially now he's reaping the benefits of going bald early by not looking any older than he did in 1975. And you know what they say about bald men who can play two drum-kits at once. Oh... and are millionaires.

But this isn't really about older men showing they can still do it. No problem there. Oh no. Indeed, anecdotal evidence gathered in my own household suggest that your well-looked-after man in, say, his early to late forties is as priapically entertaining and crucial to events as ever, whatever the weather, as a result of improved nutrition, daily press-ups and not having sex very often. Other, more wide-ranging, studies show that fantastically beautiful young women between 18 and 35 in search of a partner are much more attracted by the greater sensitivity and experience of an overweight, ageing Don Juan with his own helicopter than a young fumbler with nothing but moths in the bank. And who can blame them?

The question is, why on earth would the mature chap of means want to start a family when he could be out nightclubbing with fellow bachelor dandies Peter Stringfellow and Andrew Neill? I can understand David 'Pop' Jason taking the plunge at 61. I mean, not having had a baby before, he couldn't be expected to know which way was up, though I'm sure he's found out by now. I was sorry to hear that he and his new wife have decided not to hire staff. Very brave, Dave.

Clapton, too, has his reasons for starting afresh (his 25-year-old girlfriend is expecting this summer), 10 years after the horrible death of his four-year-old boy, who fell out of a 53rd-floor skyscraper window in New York. But come on, what are the rest of you guys up to?

Up until now, it's been a safe bet that John Humphrys has never appeared in the same sentence as Clint Eastwood and Jack Nicholson. Yes, the correct answer is they have all fathered children in their fifties and sixties. Has someone told them that late parenthood is the elixir of youth? Where do they get their enthusiasm from? Well, from their wives presumably, who of course are not in their fifties and sixties and would like to make use of all those alpha-plus genes before the handle drops off the dispenser. From an evolutionary point of view, there's no point bagging - oh all right, shagging - a celebrity if you've got nothing to show for it in the way of acquiring wealth, power and status for your unborn children.

But you have to wonder what possible use they'll be round the house. I'm sure old Humph will do his bit, but where will he be when it really counts - ie when the tot wakes up at four in the morning? Safely on his way to the office, of course. And you can't imagine Clint (now a sprightly 70) chasing his three-year-old round Tesco, or Jack Nicholson surrounded by under-nines in a Happy Eater on the A1 trying to get a couple of slices of toast out of the waitress ('Listen, all you have to do is hold the goddamn bacon, beans, chips, brown sauce, onion rings, sausages, black pudding, curry and mushy peas, bring me the toast and coffee, give me a check for the all-day monster brunch, and you haven't broken any rules , OK?')

And, later, where will Dad be when junior needs him to help change the spark plugs on the car? Or to do a spot of babysitting when junior has kids of his own? Look at young Dylan Zeta-Douglas-Jones or whatever the little fellow is called. Does Michael Douglas not realise that by the time little Dylan is old enough to follow in his father's footsteps and marry a woman half his age, Mike will be 112 and spunky grandpa Kirk will be on his third face transplant?

Of course there's nothing really new about veteran male superstars fathering children. It's just that in the good old days you didn't put an announcement in the paper. Mick Jagger had no sooner had a son with Jerry Hall at the age of 54 than he was busy having another one with some foxy twenty-something Brazilian model. But do you see him bragging about it?

The trouble is, even the best-ordered spotlit marriages can start to unravel given the right circumstances. All you need is a decent restaurant, an open cupboard and the proximity of a live woman and anything can happen. Ask Boris Becker, who moves up another rung on the ladder of fatherhood just as Phil Collins reaches the top and looks over the gutters into a glorious sunset.

Naturally one hesitates to throw one's wet blanket on the flame of hope and happiness, as Phil snuggles up to wife number three or hoists aloft the ceremonial first nappy for the waiting cameras.

The rich are different from us. They take a while to settle down. And you can't hurry love, as I believe Phil himself once put it. Though, of course, he was only 29 himself at the time.

Foolproof fathering for the over-fifties

DON'T be tempted to grow a 'youthful' pony-tail (the rule is: if it hangs, someone will swing on it)

DON'T even think about going green and using washable eco-nappies (unless someone else is doing the changing, washing and ironing)

DON'T ask the children from your first marriage to babysit. They'll only compare birthday presents

DON'T give your child a shoulder ride. It's bad for your back and makes your hair stick up

DO be careful bending down to retrieve stray bathroom toys from behind the toilet

DO try to take it in the chin when the other mums and dads at school mistake you for grandpa

DO accept help from strangers when you're struggling to get the buggy though the doors of the bookies

DO ditch the designer suits in favour of prevomit-patterned jumpers from M&S

webTitle: Having a teacher called Al Gore

fields.headline: They say you never forget a brilliant teacher. I know I won't - he's called Al Gore
fields.trailText: Shortly before my first day in Al Gore's class at the Columbia School of Journalism, one of his assistants sent all the students an email with suggestions on how to address him. The options were: Mr Vice President, Professor Gore and just plain Mr Gore.
fields.body:
Shortly before my first day in Al Gore's class at the Columbia School of Journalism, one of his assistants sent all the students an email with suggestions on how to address him. The options were: Mr Vice President, Professor Gore and just plain Mr Gore. At the start of class, Gore dismissed those options, saying: 'You can call me Al', but he preferred 'Your Adequacy', an honorific, he explained, created specifically for former Vice Presidents.

That set the tone for my experience with Gore and his class: at once ceremonial and deliberately casual; at times serious, but often pretty funny.

When Gore first announced, only days after Bush's inauguration, that he would teach a course at Columbia University called 'Covering National Affairs in the Information Age', there was a flurry of speculation about his intentions. Maybe he was trying to keep from sliding into oblivion, as defeated presidential candidates tend to do. Instead of retreating to his native Carthage, he would make his mark at the most prestigious journalism school in the country and stay at the centre of the New York media establishment. Perhaps it even meant he was getting an early start for the 2004 election. The class, after all, allows Gore a weekly captive audience of future journalists.

After showing up on the first day in a tweedy-looking jacket and a burgundy V-neck sweater, Gore toned down the anachronistic Ivy League look to a kind of hip SoHo-casual out fit with both trousers and sweater in downtown black. He had his jacket off as he worked his way through the raised hands, eliciting a lively discussion. Gore's personality problem is not so evident in an academic setting. He is not the wooden obscurantist everyone imagines. He's pretty fast on his feet and most of his jokes are amusing. There are moments when the slightly oily mien of his public persona comes through, but in general, he turns out to be relaxed, witty and charming when not on camera or limited to sound bites.

In his first session, on 'how to deal with disagreement among scientists', Gore was animated, even dynamic. Putting in more effort than many full- time professors, he drove the class along not by lecturing but by building on students' comments and pushing them to clarify their answers. Gore was a journalist for almost six years, as an army reporter in Vietnam and as a staff writer at the Nashville Tennessean , so he knows the turf, and his questions were well placed.

What if the balance of opinion is so overwhelmingly in favour of one side, like 98% to 2%? What if you know that the dissenters are employed by some industry lobby? What if, by reporting both sides, your article inadvertently suggests to the reader that there is no such thing as global warming? (And allows George W. Bush to say, as he did recently, that he's not sure global warming is real.) The journalism students, indoctrinated to believe that there is such a thing as perfect objectivity, balked. But, they cried, you have to include both sides. Gore responded that 'balance' and 'both sides' don't always bring you closer to the truth.

In full sail, Gore decided to chart a course further into the abstract. 'Who can offer a definition of deconstructionism?' he asked. Soon we were discussing the clockwork universe, meta-narratives and the human genome, all in relation to balanced reporting and objectivity. Some students didn't buy it. A student named Mei Fong raised her hand and dismissed the whole thing as 'too high-minded'. (She reiterated her point by saying, twice: 'I'm not pulling this out of my ass.') 'Reporters,' she said, 'want the meat, the bone and the juice.' The rest, Mei suggested, is not important.

Gore's answer was impressive. 'All that is to say that some meanings come not only from the facts, or from balance, but from the relationship between all the story's components.' This was the Gore I had always heard about, the one who is busy with thought, who likes to weave different conceptual threads into one cohesive idea.

The following week, we had the first of several visiting speakers. Gore had invited Rupert Murdoch to class to discuss corporate consolidation of the media. It was a topic close to Gore's heart (his undergraduate thesis examined the effect of television on politics) and he had prepared some questions for Murdoch to start with. Unfortunately, they were mostly softballs, or they came across that way. That's not to say that Gore didn't try. He asked about bias in the press, news owners participating in editorial decisions, and even about Murdoch's personal record on these issues, and yet almost all the queries landed at Murdoch's feet.

People brought up the usual News Corporation scandals: the South China Morning Post ; Murdoch's withdrawal of BBC distribution from his Star TV network in China - HarperCollins's book deal with Deng Xiaoping's daughter - but he maintained his sort-of-imperial air and explained it all away.

Towards the end of the session, The Simpsons came up. 'I believe The Simpsons is the best show that has ever been on television,' Murdoch said quite proudly. Who can argue with that? Smiles all around. Any critical mass that might have gathered against him in the past hour and a half dissipated. All evil media moguls should have such an ace in the hole.

When we found out that the third class would address the role of financial journalism and the guest was Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, the joke went around that session four would be about covering religion and the guest would be the Pope, or if he's unavailable, God.

The following week, David Letterman was brought in with two of his writers to talk about political humour. Initially, they were glib. 'People read the funnies before they read the front page of the newspaper,' Letterman said. But Gore didn't let them off the hook. He pressed the subject and, by the end, his guests came around a bit. They even listened as Gore drew flow-charts and talked for a while about meta-narratives, by which he meant the shared assumptions people have about public figures. 'Like Gore is stiff, Bush jumbles words and Clinton loves cheeseburgers,' he explained.

As class ended, someone near me sniped: 'What a show-off.' This is a consistent reaction from some of the students. Gore swaggers, they say. He's always posturing. And he flaunts his intelligence. There is, of course, an element of exhibition here. So what? Gore is not, to strike a theme, pulling this stuff out of his ass; he is in full command of his ideas. Maybe he does get a little esoteric, but it's refreshing to encounter a politician who not only knows what he's talking about but might have something important to say on the subject.

Part of Gore's political failure, we hear, is that he always sounds as though he is leading a graduate seminar. Well, now he's doing just that, and he's pretty good at it. It could be Gore has found his true métier.

webTitle: Theatre: the rise of marathon plays

fields.headline: Long plays journey into night
fields.standfirst: As the RSC comes to the end of its marathon history cycle, the Royal Court shows that there is still plenty of mileage left in stories of the Sixties
fields.trailText: As the RSC comes to the end of its marathon history cycle, the Royal Court shows that there is still plenty of mileage left in stories of the Sixties.
fields.body:
Richard IIIYoung Vic, London SE1
Presence Royal Court Jerwood Theatre Upstairs, London SW1
The Female Odd Couple Apollo, London W1

Marathons are doing big theatrical business. Peter Hall's nine-hour production of Tantalus, soon to arrive at the Barbican, has been drawing crowds on its worldwide tour. And the RSC's history cycle has proved to be both audience pleaser and artistic triumph.

Really long occasions turn the audience into a faction of their own. You breathe an air of festival - and an air of siege. Buttock to buttock with a stranger for the best part of a day, you're almost bound to bond with or really hate your next-door neighbour, as you watch a saga of unravelling lives. Either way, you get hyped up, conscious of your own drama, and more geared into the hates and adorations that are raging away on the stage.

All of which helped to fuel the excitement as the last of the RSC's eight histories drew to its close at the Young Vic. A large part of the audience for Michael Boyd's production of Richard III had earlier in the day witnessed, in Henry VI, Part 3, also directed by Boyd, the trigger for the play's action. As a result, one of Shakespeare's most familiar plays was seen not as an isolated feat of demonic capering but as an inevitable consequence of years of dynastic struggle.

Boyd's production benefits from this energy. It's edgy and full of detail; it's required watching, with the rest of the cycle, for anyone who's faintly interested in Shakespeare, theatre or history. But it's not nasty enough. A world described as 'reeling' and 'snarling' mostly totters and sneers. All the necessary effects are put in place, but without - perhaps this will come - the necessary crack of desperation. It's the culmination but not the crown of this cycle.

Doomy gongs, sometimes with a didgeridoo echo, accompany particularly bad moments. Queen Margaret (a too trim Fiona Bell) heaves a sackful of bones on her back, which she tips on to the stage. In Tom Piper's design, a set of burnished doors dominates a bare stage that spreads out like the fingers of a hand through the audience; the action doesn't flow quickly enough down these digits. Though this isn't a sluggish production, it's not a seamless one; you're always aware of a procession of separate scenes. Sometimes this pays off. It's a gorgeous, arresting moment when, after hours of dark costumes, Richard arrives with his court all in gold - and pushes his queen aside as he receives his flunkeys.

Aidan McArdle is a nimble, impish Richard; he's swift, funny, volatile, a petulant misogynist who kisses with contempt. But he's never really frightening; he never seems to have a strategy. It's Richard Cordery as Buckingham, the spurned spin doctor, who supplies the chilling element. Bulky but dainty, he looms over McArdle, breathing an emollient nastiness - all perfunctory smiles and prelate-like sanctimoniousness.

The lust for theatrical length is the more striking, since the tendency over the past few years has been for plays to get shorter. One and a half hours with no interval is the norm. This permits a smooth evening out - Art and supper and bed before midnight. It also enables a particular kind of play: condensed, delivered all in one breath, taking you into the heart of a moment. You can detect the influence of Beckett in this. The drama consists not in debate but in gradually revolving an idea, tilting it against different lights.

David Harrower's Presence is a lovely example. In 1995, Harrower had a hit at the Edinburgh Festival with Knives in Hens, a play whose language was as compact as its title. Earlier this year, he provided a vivid new version of Six Characters in Search of an Author. His new, well-named play is a different kind of success. Apparently modest - without large-scale action, big debate or highly wrought language - it's none the less intense.

Harrower has alighted on an intriguing subject - the Beatles' 1960 visit to Hamburg. In exploring it, he avoids all the obvious traps. The Sixties style has yet to come - there's not a floppy fringe, tote-bag or collarless jacket in sight. The Mersey beat hasn't been thought of; there's no hint of Cavern music here, only the sounds of the previous generation heard in a Benny Goodman record, which is despised by the Fab Four, who drop ash on it as it spins.

You don't see all four band members, and those who do appear are unexpected. These were the days of pre-Ringo Pete Best, advised to plonk himself in front of the others on stage, since he's the one most likely to draw a crowd. There's one bold, provocative, anarchic figure, but he's (provocatively and anarchically) called Paul. A John character is heard only offstage, breezing through 'Rule Britannia' on his mouth-organ.

What's offered is a version of history that wires the Sixties into post-war Europe, that makes you see the era as a continuation of something darker than its songs. Rae Smith's black, neon-lit design twists between bar and bedroom; Ralf Little, of The Royle Family , is a delightful, lolloping George; Sarah Woodward, playing a woman who proves that any style can be thought subversive, is dynamite.

Meanwhile, theatrical fossils are still being dug up. The Female Odd Couple is the kind of fusty, relentlessly bantering West End comedy that makes you really pleased that intervals do, occasionally, still exist.

It was a bad idea of Neil Simon to transform his hit Broadway show so that the parts of the ill-matched flatmates (one pernickety, the other a slob), made famous in the movie by Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau, are played by women. All the teasing peculiarity - does 'odd' really mean 'queer'? - of the original evaporates. You have to fight really hard to find something comic about two women quarrelling about cleaning.

As an update, with women being, as it were, the new men, this fails abysmally. Paula Wilcox, the woman wedded to her pinny, manages to be sprightly and amusing; Jenny Seagrove, tousled and appealing, is as abrasive as a feather duster.

Peter Hall's nine-hour production of Tantalus, soon to arrive at the Barbican, has been drawing crowds on its worldwide tour. Either way, you get hyped up, conscious of your own drama, and more geared into the hates and adorations that are raging away on the stage. All of which helped to fuel the excitement as the last of the RSC's eight histories drew to its close at the Young Vic. webTitle: Simon Rattle's production of Beethoven's Fidelio

fields.headline: What's so funny about Beethoven?
fields.standfirst: Back home for Glyndebourne, Simon Rattle wants his Fidelio to shock
fields.trailText: Perhaps Simon Rattle was hungry when we met at Glyndebourne (where he is rehearsing a new production of Beethoven's Fidelio , due to open the season on May 17). Or perhaps music is his food, because - even after instantly transforming a plate of moussaka and roast potatoes into nervous energy - he went on comparing operas with meals.
fields.body:
Perhaps Simon Rattle was hungry when we met at Glyndebourne (where he is rehearsing a new production of Beethoven's Fidelio , due to open the season on May 17). Or perhaps music is his food, because - even after instantly transforming a plate of moussaka and roast potatoes into nervous energy - he went on comparing operas with meals.

Recalling Rameau's mythological romp Les Boréades , which he conducted at Salzburg and the Proms in 1999, he said: 'It's the world's greatest tapas bar. The whole of the food chain is there, but snack-sized.' And when I commented on his thinness, he beamed 'I'm still on the Tristan diet.' He has just conducted Wagner's Tristan und Isolde for the first time in Amsterdam, and despite the narcosis of the music he managed to be invigorated by it.

'You're in a sea of amniotic fluid. Some of the time it made me want to lie down in a foetal position on the rostrum and sob. But in the end it lifts you off the ground. It's not a cholesterol high, like Syzmanowski's King Roger - there's so much exotic sweetness in that, you can feel it shortening your life.'

Wagner worried that the febrile chromaticism of Tristan might drive men mad. Rattle sees it more medicinally, and believes that the score saved the life of Claudio Abbado (whom he will succeed next year as chief conductor and artistic director of the Berlin Philharmonic). Abbado lost most of his viscerae after an operation for cancer, but resurrected himself by conducting Tristan - despite its erotic morbidity, its longing for extinction - in Japan. He recently told Rattle that he thought he would overcome his illness if he could find a way both to eat (since his digestive system is now outside his body) and to conduct.

There is a strange metabolism at work in conducting itself, which takes ideas - those silent symbols in the score - and converts them into sound. Like eating in reverse, it gives a disembodied, diagrammatic thought flesh and blood, and makes it a sensation. How Rattle must have licked his lips when he began to study the score of Fidelio two years ago, because what he found there had probably not been heard since the nineteenth century: tempo markings fleeter than usual (the prisoners' chorus, he points out, usually so mournful, should be allegretto), and a vocal style which evokes Italian bel canto, not the stentorian rhetoric of Wagner.

Rattle, with his vivid auditory imagination, says that he heard the music 'walk' with a different tread. He compares Fidelio - usually so deliberate and dogged, a triumphal march of archetypes - with the twisting, emotionally circuitous journey in Schubert's song cycle Die Winterreise. ' Tristan for me is Schubert on steroids, but this somehow permits Schubert to exist. It's all so subtle and delicate. When Rocco sings his aria about money, you can hear that he's not telling the truth. He tries to keep it in B flat major, but it's actually in G minor. The whole thing has to move in the way we know Beethoven played the piano - skittish, bizarre, not one steady pulse.' With his rare gift for verbalising, Rattle wants the same from his singers: they must, he says, 'pronounce' the music, deciphering the feelings caged in the notes. The orchestra, too, is engaged in articulate speech.

On the day we met, Rattle was still conducting an invisible, inaudible band, gesticulating in an empty pit. The Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment is due to arrive tomorrow: this will be the first Fidelio ever played on period instruments, and Rattle says he can't wait to hear how the horns will utter Beethoven's sounds - 'all those sharp, buzzing colours'. He continues to conduct Beethoven's symphonies with orchestras of the later, lusher kind, and this season performed the Fifth with the Vienna Philharmonic in London. But, as he insists, 'These pieces don't need helmets' and he was delighted when the VPO, 'the boys', as he fondly calls them - allowed him to goad them on a madly propulsive, impishly athletic race through a score they already knew so well: 'They're supposed to be conservative, but they were willing to explore this other way of doing it. I suppose they think "Let's humour Simon" - a bit like the way the grown-ups humour ET.' More likely, of course, they capitulated to the enthusiasm and elation of a genuine visionary, who has re-conceived the most familiar and revered of composers, dispensing with a ponderous tradition.

By the end of the nineteenth century, Beethoven had become a model of knotty Promethean intellect: sculpted by Max Klinger, he glowers on a rocky pinnacle in the pavilion of the Vienna Secession, with Christ crucified on the rear of his throne. In the twentieth century, 'Fidelio' and the Ninth Symphony were used as anthems of resurgent humanism - music to accompany the liberation of the concentration camps or the breaching of the Berlin Wall. Beethoven, as a certified classic, had become sacrosanct, as monumental as Klinger's glowering effigy of him.

Rattle - casually demonstrating a novelist's capacity to conjure up Beethoven's physical presence and intuit his psychological quirks - seeks to make the music sound as it did to its first hearers, who were terrified by its messianic frenzy. 'Goethe should have been able to keep up with Beethoven, because the second part of "Faust" is as apocalyptic as any of his music, but he fled after nine days with him. He just couldn't stand the wildness. Mendelssohn, when he heard the Fifth Symphony, said that it threatened to make the planets fall off their axes. Weber walked out of the Seventh, and called it music fit only for the asylum. Beethoven was always asking to have this or that mountain moved just a foot or so to the left. This was a man who stuck his hat on his head and stomped off, pushing through the middle of a royal procession. He even managed to spill wine and coffee inside his own piano, which is some achievement. Did you ever meet the conductor Klaus Tennstedt? That's how I imagine Beethoven. Steps were made for falling up. No piece of furniture was safe when he was in the room - especially if it happened to be expensive. He didn't inhabit the real world, and his music had unreal expectations of performers.'

The unreality extends, in some performances of Fidelio, to human nature: did Beethoven idealise Leonore and Florestan, those prisoners of conscience, and demonise their oppressor Pizarro?

For Rattle, and for the director Deborah Warner, these are all fallible, morally compromised beings. Rattle has imagined a novel which elaborates on their relationships, and inveigles them into a seamy complicity behind the scenes. 'There's no right and wrong in a post-revolutionary time. Even Mandela, who's a living saint, was involved in an armed struggle. Pizarro says that Florestan, whom everyone thinks of as a victim, was a murderer too. I suspect that Leonore, supposedly the ideal woman, has had some secret relationship with Pizarro. And what happens at the end, while everyone's rejoicing? I think they take Pizarro off and lynch him. There are atrocities and betrayals - political and sexual - in the background which no one will ever speak about.'

The proper response to Fidelio is not liberal complacency. Rattle is hoping for the same shock - both musical and dramatic - delivered by his Don Giovanni with Deborah Warner at Glyndebourne in 1991. That concluded with a blasphemous orgy during which the libertine defiled a statuette of the Virgin Mary.

'By the end of the first performance, there was a message on the noticeboard at the stage door asking Deborah to please phone the editor of the Catholic Herald. That proved we'd succeeded.' Before leaving, I asked Rattle if he had a wish list of operas. Glyndebourne's cancellation of Rameau's Hippolyte et Aricie rankles, but Wagner's Ring and Berg's Lulu seem to be on his mind: maybe, he said, 'The Germans', which is how he refers to the Berlin Philharmonic - will do them.

He is still oddly wary of Verdi: 'Until I can sit through Ballo in Maschera , I don't think I should be allowed to do Falstaff . I only heard Otello for the first time a few years ago. I'd never even heard a note of it on record. So I got to know it sitting with Bernard Haitink in a box at Covent Garden, watching Carlos Kleiber conduct.' Rattle's face ignited at the memory of Kleiber's wizardry, as his downbeat caused a storm at sea to explode out of the orchestra pit. 'Bernard turned to me in the middle of the first act and whispered "Simon, I think my studies have just begun".'

Rattle has conserved the same open-minded capacity for admiration, and the same giddy, almost adolescent delight in what he does. He was so precocious - he learned music at five, mounted his first concerts (domestically) at six, and conducted an occult score by Boulez when he was 15 - and is still so young that we have an entire career to look forward to. By the way, I have solved the mystery of his hair. Those corkscrew curls, grey but still resilient, have always fascinated me. Surely he doesn't have time for sessions with heated tongs? I think, after our lunch, that I know the follicular secret. Coils store energy, and release it when shaken (or, perhaps, rattled). What makes Rattle's hair curl is its sheer excitement at growing out of his brain.

webTitle: BBC backs new cartoon: God, the Devil and Bob,

fields.headline: The Devil has the best toon
fields.standfirst: It was pulled in the States, but the BBC is backing God, the Devil and Bob, reports  Akin Ojumu
fields.trailText: It was pulled in the States, but the BBC is backing God, the Devil and Bob, reports Akin Ojumu.
fields.body:
The Grateful Dead singer Jerry Garcia was the subject of numerous tributes after his death, but perhaps the most flattering came last year when he inspired the character of God in the short-lived animated series God, the Devil and Bob.

Given tongue by a languid James Garner, God, who seemingly hails from the West Coast, sports a potbelly, Hawaiian shirt and thick white beard. In the opposing corner stands the Devil, voiced by Alan Cumming as a decadent cabaret host.

Deadheads loved the show, the critics too. It was sly and gently irreverent - much closer to The Simpsons and King of the Hill than, say, to South Park.

The series - now bought by the BBC - begins with a bar-room bet between God and the Devil. Can a slovenly Detroit carworker - Bob Alman - do enough good deeds to save the world? Each week, Alman faces a new moral dilemma armed with conflicting advice from his rival mentors. 'My soul has become a battleground for a war between God and Satan,' Alman explains to his wife in an early episode. 'But I know you're just gonna make that sound weird.'

One plotline has Satan torment Alman by materialising as the cute boyfriend of his teenage daughter. But this animated tug of war between good and evil failed to reach to biblical proportions in the States; NBC pulled it following a wave of protest.

Religious groups complained, advertisers shied away and 22 of NBC's local affiliates refused to air it. That's more stations than refused the groundbreaking first series of NYPD Blue.

God, the Devil and Bob died in the US after four episodes. Outraged fans vented their frustration on its website.

Frankly, it is hard to see what all the fuss was about. Turning a latter-day Book of Job into primetime entertainment may have been adventurous, but was hardly blasphemous. And in this animated morality tale - in contrast to the Jesus-Satan encounters in South Park - a rather easy-going deity keeps the upper hand.

The show swipes at corporate miscreants - Exxon, Microsoft - rather than at the Scriptures. Making God an ageing, genial hippie was always liable to provoke the Bible Belt, but is entirely in harmony with the cartoon's light, playful touch.'It's not my intention to raise the red flag about religion,' says creator/producer Matthew Carlson. 'I want to be irreverent. I'm not trying to make a major comment about religion. I don't expect theologians to take all this seriously.'

With hindsight, it's easy to accuse Carlson of naivety. Aside from the often lucrative antics of TV evangelists, religion has little place in mainstream - especially fictional - US television.

When it does feature, it's handled with kid gloves - as in Highway to Heaven and, more recently, Touched By An Angel. But God, the Devil and Bob tested the primetime boundaries at a time when politicians were keeping eagle eyes on the entertainment industry on the eve of the Presidential election.

'It was a little risky for network TV,' says New York Times critic Caryn James. 'But compared to the type of shows you see on Comedy Central [South Park] or HBO [Sex and the City, The Sopranos], the content was relatively benign.'

James claims the show's demise was hastened by modest ratings. Scheduled mid-season - against ABC's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire - God, the Devil and Bob certainly wasn't an instant success. But NBC was suspiciously quick to cut its losses.

The fate of God, the Devil and Bob was similar to that of Clerks , a controversial animated series that - after repeated postponements - lasted just two episodes. Director Kevin Smith (Mallrats, Chasing Amy, Dogma) publicly railed against ABC for their treatment of the cartoon.

Smith's view was that Clerks 'really pushes the edge of the envelope, but ... doesn't push the edge of the envelope the way of kids sitting around saying "ass" or "dick".' It was still deemed too hot to broadcast in the US. One episode featured a gag about the Challenger space-shuttle explosion in 1986.

The BBC apparently has no such qualms about God, the Devil and Bob. After buying the show last year, it held preview screenings for both staff and religious groups, and received favourable feedback.

Ernie Rae, head of religious programmes, himself compared it to a 'modern morality tale'. And according to Sophie Turner Laing, the BBC's controller of programme acquisitions: 'The religious leaders who saw the film were quite optimistic that the show could deliver a religious message to an audience who might otherwise avoid one.'

Because only one 13-week series was made, it cannot outstay its welcome. So it will never suffer the diminishing returns that afflict longer-running shows.

Since Heart of the Matter , the BBC has been toying with various alternative ways of filling 'the God slot'. Witness Simon Mayo's funky approach to religious and moral issues in BBC1's Sunday night chatfest The Big End .

God, the Devil and Bob wasn't bought to fill precisely this slot, but it does demonstrate that the corporation has been doing some lateral thinking about its religiously themed programming. As Sophie Turner Laing points out, British attitudes to religion differ from those seemingly prevalent in America. 'I get the feeling that we are rather more tolerant,' she says. 'No one I have spoken to finds the show offensive.'

So maybe the Deadhead godhead will get a kinder reception this side of the Atlantic. Interestingly, even in the States the casting of God as Jerry Garcia was seen as a plus point. 'People thought that was pretty funny,' says the NYT 's Caryn James. There may even be an additional bonus for viewers drawn to the kindly, bearded figure with the wise words. His teachings are widely available. Just look under 'G' in any good record shop.

 God, the Devil and Bob starts on 8 May, BBC2

Five of the best US TV animations

The Simpsons America's favourite dysfunctional family. Jammed with cultural references, Matt Groening's creation has maintained its high standards since 1989.

King of the Hill The brainchild of Beavis and Butt-head creator Mike Judge. The suburban humdrum of Hank Hill and family is given droll treatment in an intelligent show.

Daria A cult success on both sides of the Atlantic. Precocious teen Daria dislikes her dim classmates, teachers and family. All fall prey to her acid wit.

South Park Forget the deliberately amateurish animation, the show's outré humour can't be ignored. At its best, South Park is deliciously subversive.

Futurama A hapless pizza delivery man, Philip Fry, is transported to the year 3000. Matt Groening's follow-up to The Simpsons is similar in tone and visual style to the long-running hit.

fields.bodyText: The Grateful Dead singer Jerry Garcia was the subject of numerous tributes after his death, but perhaps the most flattering came last year when he inspired the character of God in the short-lived animated series God, the Devil and Bob. Given tongue by a languid James Garner, God, who seemingly hails from the West Coast, sports a potbelly, Hawaiian shirt and thick white beard. In the opposing corner stands the Devil, voiced by Alan Cumming as a decadent cabaret host. Deadheads loved the show, the critics too. It was sly and gently irreverent - much closer to The Simpsons and King of the Hill than, say, to South Park. The series - now bought by the BBC - begins with a bar-room bet between God and the Devil. Can a slovenly Detroit carworker - Bob Alman - do enough good deeds to save the world? Each week, Alman faces a new moral dilemma armed with conflicting advice from his rival mentors. 'My soul has become a battleground for a war between God and Satan,' Alman explains to his wife in an early episode. 'But I know you're just gonna make that sound weird.' One plotline has Satan torment Alman by materialising as the cute boyfriend of his teenage daughter. But this animated tug of war between good and evil failed to reach to biblical proportions in the States; NBC pulled it following a wave of protest. Religious groups complained, advertisers shied away and 22 of NBC's local affiliates refused to air it. That's more stations than refused the groundbreaking first series of NYPD Blue. God, the Devil and Bob died in the US after four episodes. Outraged fans vented their frustration on its website. Frankly, it is hard to see what all the fuss was about. Turning a latter-day Book of Job into primetime entertainment may have been adventurous, but was hardly blasphemous. And in this animated morality tale - in contrast to the Jesus-Satan encounters in South Park - a rather easy-going deity keeps the upper hand. The show swipes at corporate miscreants - Exxon, Microsoft - rather than at the Scriptures. Making God an ageing, genial hippie was always liable to provoke the Bible Belt, but is entirely in harmony with the cartoon's light, playful touch.'It's not my intention to raise the red flag about religion,' says creator/producer Matthew Carlson. 'I want to be irreverent. I'm not trying to make a major comment about religion. I don't expect theologians to take all this seriously.' With hindsight, it's easy to accuse Carlson of naivety. Aside from the often lucrative antics of TV evangelists, religion has little place in mainstream - especially fictional - US television. When it does feature, it's handled with kid gloves - as in Highway to Heaven and, more recently, Touched By An Angel. But God, the Devil and Bob tested the primetime boundaries at a time when politicians were keeping eagle eyes on the entertainment industry on the eve of the Presidential election. 'It was a little risky for network TV,' says New York Times critic Caryn James. 'But compared to the type of shows you see on Comedy Central [South Park] or HBO [Sex and the City, The Sopranos], the content was relatively benign.' James claims the show's demise was hastened by modest ratings. Scheduled mid-season - against ABC's Who Wants to Be a Millionaire - God, the Devil and Bob certainly wasn't an instant success. But NBC was suspiciously quick to cut its losses. The fate of God, the Devil and Bob was similar to that of Clerks , a controversial animated series that - after repeated postponements - lasted just two episodes. Director Kevin Smith (Mallrats, Chasing Amy, Dogma) publicly railed against ABC for their treatment of the cartoon. Smith's view was that Clerks 'really pushes the edge of the envelope, but ... doesn't push the edge of the envelope the way of kids sitting around saying "ass" or "dick".' It was still deemed too hot to broadcast in the US. One episode featured a gag about the Challenger space-shuttle explosion in 1986. The BBC apparently has no such qualms about God, the Devil and Bob. After buying the show last year, it held preview screenings for both staff and religious groups, and received favourable feedback. Ernie Rae, head of religious programmes, himself compared it to a 'modern morality tale'. And according to Sophie Turner Laing, the BBC's controller of programme acquisitions: 'The religious leaders who saw the film were quite optimistic that the show could deliver a religious message to an audience who might otherwise avoid one.' Because only one 13-week series was made, it cannot outstay its welcome. So it will never suffer the diminishing returns that afflict longer-running shows. Since Heart of the Matter , the BBC has been toying with various alternative ways of filling 'the God slot'. Witness Simon Mayo's funky approach to religious and moral issues in BBC1's Sunday night chatfest The Big End . God, the Devil and Bob wasn't bought to fill precisely this slot, but it does demonstrate that the corporation has been doing some lateral thinking about its religiously themed programming. As Sophie Turner Laing points out, British attitudes to religion differ from those seemingly prevalent in America. 'I get the feeling that we are rather more tolerant,' she says. 'No one I have spoken to finds the show offensive.' So maybe the Deadhead godhead will get a kinder reception this side of the Atlantic. Interestingly, even in the States the casting of God as Jerry Garcia was seen as a plus point. 'People thought that was pretty funny,' says the NYT 's Caryn James. There may even be an additional bonus for viewers drawn to the kindly, bearded figure with the wise words. His teachings are widely available. Just look under 'G' in any good record shop.  God, the Devil and Bob starts on 8 May, BBC2 Five of the best US TV animations The Simpsons America's favourite dysfunctional family. fields.headline: The caped crusader
fields.standfirst: So you thought that France was a musical desert? Then you haven't taken account of Air
fields.trailText: So you thought that France was a musical desert? Then you haven't taken account of Air.
fields.body:
Air Shepherd's Bush Empire, London W12

Between them, Popstars and Oasis have made British pop appear redundant to most people over the age of seven (despite the fact that there's good stuff going on away from the Top 40) simply by demonstrating how drearily well we understand its mechanisms and respect its traditions.

This is why much of the more inspiring stuff, particularly in the arcane field of rock, seems to be coming from among the ranks of those who were previously excluded from it (Hole, Sleater-Kinney, Fiona Apple, Polly Harvey, Asian Dub Foundation) or who come from non-English speaking territories like Norway, Sweden, Iceland and France. Unable to rely in the same way on instinct, they're more inclined to engage the mind. The good thing about being a French band is that you can do what the hell you like with the Anglo-American pop tradition, because it's not coursing through your veins; it's simply something you might love, in the same way you might a good claret.

I suspect that I'm not alone in this view, because Shepherd's Bush Empire was packed on Wednesday night, with touts outside doing a brisk trade in tickets at £100 a throw. On Tuesday night, Sigur Ros, from Iceland, had ben the show to be seen at, but tonight belonged to Air. Just when you thought you'd seen the last of him in this review, Noel Gallagher was perched like the Queen Mother on a balcony. In front of him was Michael Stipe, who appeared transfixed throughout, then dashed away faster than a British Airways steward being chased by Peter Buck. As with the rest of us, what they saw will have surprised them.

Air's first album, Moon Safari, arrived out of the blue in 1998, presaging a rush of French acts. Initially, it was thought of as dance music by association, though almost none of it was programmed: Jean-Benoit Dunckel and his partner, Nicolas Godin, are, in essence, old-school musicians, combining a mischievous, postmodern exterior with deft, accomplished playing. You may not own it, but if you've been to a dinner party in the last three years, or entered any of the world's swankier lifts, you've heard it. Moon Safari sounded fresh when it was released and still does now. It's what most of us had turned out to see. So, naturally, Air played none of it.

Instead, accompanied by three colleagues - all, like them, dressed in black - they played their new album, 10,000 Hz Legend , track by track, in order. This could have looked like a naked exercise in force-feeding a new product to the public if you didn't know that the record isn't released until 28 May, meaning that hardly anyone present had heard a note of it.

In combination with the low-key presentation (three banks of keyboards spread across an unadorned stage and a couple of blokes playing guitars, plus drums), this quickly came to look not so much like bravery, but evidence of a touching trust in both their audience and the power of their music to work its own magic. I'd heard the album, but everyone else seemed to find the show just as absorbing as I did.

There was a bit of Franglais chatter between songs ('We 'ope to make you higher and higher'; 'Zis is a song called "Sex Born Poison". It's about ze poison you can sometimes 'ave in your sex'). Otherwise, the story of the show was the story of a beguiling album that turns out to be at least the equal of Moon Safari . In a parallel universe, either 'How Does it Make You Feel?' or the seven-minute 'Radian' might be the best song on Pink Floyd's Wish You Were Here . 'Radio #1', with its throbbing, elliptical chorus and seductive nod towards 'Yes Sir, I Can Boogie'-style Euro-disco, was lusher and more dynamic than on plastic, as was the gentle drift of 'People in the City'.

It was a surprise that the pure mood pieces, which do much to build tension between other passages on the album, worked so well in a live environment. Anyone who came to dance will have left disappointed, but even without the rapturously-greeted encore of 'La Femme D'Argent' from the first album, anyone who came to listen will have gone away surprised and delighted.

Jean-Benoit Dunckel, who, in deference to the prog-rock tradition, wears the kind of cape once favoured by Rick Wakeman, just went home looking like Dracula.
