This is the man who threw handfuls of dollar bills at his fans and stood above them, relishing the ensuing mayhem, who pretended to have himself guillotined at every one of his shows, who was condemned by the MP Leo Abse for 'peddling the culture of the concentration camp', and whose records were banned in the early 70s after a campaign by Mary Whitehouse. When Johnny Rotten auditioned for the Sex Pistols, he mimed to Cooper's song 'Eighteen'. Once, during a 1969 Alice Cooper show in Toronto, a member of the audience threw a live hen on stage; Cooper, thinking it would be able to fly, threw it back. The audience tore it to pieces. And what did it all mean? Alice Cooper was the Eminem, or the Beastie Boys, of his day. He was trying to show us what we, as a society, had come to. 'Society has created this Frankenstein, this Alice Cooper,' he said in 1973. One critic, Allan Jones, made the point that Alice was not Alice Cooper, but 'the audience was'. Even though it all got too much for him in the late 70s, when he used to drink more than a bottle of whiskey a day, Vincent Furnier has often referred to himself as 'the ultimate put-on'. He is a conservative Christian. As long ago as 30 years ago, he declared, 'I'm the most American rock act. I have American ideals. I love money.' You wonder what drives him still. He doesn't need the money. He has just flown thousands of miles, been subjected to delays and stopovers, and is visibly weary. Perking up on air, he says, 'I didn't know that rock'n'roll was such a long-lasting disease. There's a guitar germ or something. When I was a little kid, and I heard the electric guitar for the first time, it got in my system. Chuck Berry or whatever. To this day, all of my albums are guitar-driven rock'n'roll. The only thing that won't go away is garage rock. The Rolling Stones are the best garage band of all time. Two guitars, bass, drums, and a lead singer. That's garage rock. Aerosmith. AC/DC. Alice. Led Zeppelin. These are all great garage bands.' He's a fluent speaker. 'If I wasn't doing this,' he says, 'I would have loved to have been a lightweight boxer.' He took up golf, he says, to take his mind off drinking. He talks readily about his drinking years. 'Let me tell you who my big brothers were. Jim Morrison, Jimi Hendrix, Keith Moon, Harry Nilsson. These people were my best friends. I was the little kid - the one on the way up. Every one of these guys were like maniacs. Look who I was looking up to. The thing I did learn is that you don't have to die. I learned a long time ago that Alice Cooper had to have his own life. Tomorrow night, onstage, it'll be fun to be Alice for two hours. But I don't have to be Alice now. Jim Morrison thought he had to be Jim Morrison all the time.' Fans are gathering. Alice poses for snaps. º ª He says, 'I've got to do a dress rehearsal - in a real dress!' The Australians love him. The first time he came here, he says, was in 1976. In Perth, in his hotel room, he woke to the sounds of what he thought were fans shouting 'Alice! Alice!' Preparing to bathe in the adulation, he opened the window. What they were really shouting, he says, was 'Abba! Abba!' In the car, he tells me about his family. His wife Sheryl is a former ballet dancer who took a job on the side performing in his stage show. She played the part of the nurse and also the leather-clad dominatrix who attacks, and is attacked by, Alice on stage. These parts are now played by Calico Furnier, Alice and Sheryl's 19-year-old daughter. He has a 16-year-old son, Dashiell, and an eight-year-old daughter, Sonora. 'My son loves hockey, heavy metal and so on,' he says. 'So I go into his room, and he's watching a Britney Spears video. Him and his buddies are all sitting there. Normally they're all listening to this hell-raising music. I said, "You guys like this?" He said, "Dad, look at her." I went: "Right!"' Alice clenches his fist. 'As a father,' he says, 'I thought, "I have a son!"' Britney Spears is on Alice's mind for another reason - he has devised a Britney routine for his new show. In the routine, Calico dresses up as Britney, in a shortie kilt, and gets into a fight with Alice. We talk about Britney's celebrated virginity and the fact that, a decade ago, Brooke Shields worked the same ploy. 'What guy in the world doesn't like that image?' he says. '"This is my butt. Nobody's touched it." Every guy in America is saying: "Let me be the first!"' Back at the hotel, Alice's manager Shep Gordon, who was introduced to him in 1969 by Jimi Hendrix, is discussing Alice's golf options with a local professional called Clem. There is a course nearby. On the other hand, the weather is bad; we are experiencing the tail end of a cyclone off the Gold Coast. Gordon, who used to wear flowers in his hair, is now bald, but has a tanned pate. He lives in Hawaii. He says, 'I think Alice has been a remarkable reflection of an adolescent's feelings about the world Like all great artists, he's a reflection of the times.' As times have changed, so Alice's act has changed - it has become more doomy. The show he is preparing has the same name as his most recent album: Brutal Planet. 'The world is a different place,' says Gordon. 'Thirty years ago it was about throwing water balloons in the summer recess. Now it's about bringing a gun to the school and killing everybody. A song like "School's Out" becomes very trite, almost. Whereas 30 years ago, it was revolutionary.' Gordon says, 'It is a brutal planet. It's one of the reasons I live in Hawaii.' Here in Newcastle, the surf is pounding on the beach. Wind is buffeting the windows. Upstairs in his hotel suite, Alice is wearing slippers, having removed his snakeskin boots, and is sitting with his feet up, watching golf on TV. When I arrive, he flicks the remote and starts watching a recording of the Grammy awards. 'There's so little rock involved,' he says. 'It's all about what's easy to listen to. Now, rap has made a place. Rap is basically the voice of the street. But when you look at the rock charts and see Destiny's Child, and Ricky Martin I like Ricky Martin, but I take exception when they say, "It's all rock'n'roll." It's not rock'n'roll. Rock'n'roll is Aerosmith. Rock'n'roll is AC/DC. Rock'n'roll is The Offspring.' Alice grew up in Detroit, but the family moved to Phoenix when he was 10, hoping the dry climate would have a beneficial effect on the young Vincent's asthma. It did. His father, Mickey, was a car dealer and then an electronic engineer who preached in his spare time, as his own father had done. Alice says he is part French, part Sioux. 'So maybe that's where my drinking problem came from. You can probably trace me back to Creole. There's a little bit of hillbilly in there, too. But when I look at myself, the high cheekbones and the black hair, there's some Indian in me, I can tell.' As a kid, although never particularly musical, he liked to dress up as Elvis Presley. At Cortez High School, his first band was called The Earwigs. 'It wasn't a band,' his older sister Nickie would tell reporters, 'it was a joke.' He was a marathon runner, and he formed The Earwigs with Dennis Dunaway, another runner, for a school revue. Along with 'the early days of being in the band', Alice tells me that his schooldays were the best time of his life. 'I basically ran my school. I had all my teachers totally under my spell. I was funny. Popular. I was a jock. I had the only band in school. I got along with every sect at high school. I was sort of the go-to guy. If somebody wanted to meet a girl, they'd say, "We'll call Vince. Vince'll introduce you."' Before he decided on the name Alice Cooper, the band was called Nazz, and then The Spiders. 'I had such a great time with my original band,' he tells me. 'The only thing we had going for us was that we believed in this silly rock'n'roll that we were doing - and the theatrics.' For a time they all lived together in a mansion in Greenwich, Connecticut. 'We weren't what people imagined,' he says. 'People assumed we were into drugs, but we were drinkers. People might have thought we were liberal, but we were conservative. We called ourselves Alice Cooper, but we were probably the biggest chauvinist pigs out there.' After having massive hits with the albums School's Out and Billion Dollar Babies, the band split up in 1975. 'They wanted to ditch the theatrics,' Alice tells me. 'One guy wanted to be George Harrison; one wanted to be Pink Floyd. I was going, "Guys, we won the war. We won. Everybody wants to be us now. You want to go backwards?" I was thinking just the opposite. Instead of having less theatrics, I was thinking five times more.' Since then, working with a fluctuating line-up, Alice has become increasingly theatrical. The first big show was called Welcome to My Nightmare. 'This was guitar killer-monster rock with real theatrics. With spiders coming up out of the floor! There was a bed that came out, and monsters came out from under the bed and did ballet! If you're going to say "Welcome to My Nightmare", do it. If you're going to say "Brutal Planet", you'd better give them Brutal Planet.' We drive to the venue for the dress rehearsal. The stage set is already in place - a guillotine, a crashed car, piles of tyres and rusty pieces of machinery. Brutal Planet is set in a futuristic, Mad Max-like dystopia. In the dressing room, which contains a lifelike rotting corpse, a television crew from Channel 10 is setting up cameras for an interview. Alice sits on the sofa, in a sea of skulls. On camera, he says, 'The show is very apocalyptic and dark. One song, "Wicked Young Man", is about Columbine.' The interviewer says, 'Certain sections of the community blame music for these tragedies.' 'You know, it's so ridiculous,' replies Alice. 'What rock album was Hitler listening to? He was listening to Wagner when he was killing everybody.' The rehearsal begins. As the guitars start to crunch, Alice moves about the stage, a hopped-up, skinny presence, a dervish with wild hair. He practises walking around the stage, posing with a crutch. He practises holding out his mike towards the auditorium to encourage the audience to sing. He sings, 'I've gotta get outta here/Mum and Dad have got me drinking whiskey/I'm 18 and I like it.' He looks like a timeless old pirate. Age has not withered the Alice Cooper persona, but improved it. The more hollow-eyed and wrinkled he looks, the better. He struts around between the guitarists, playing air guitar. 'The breath of the death is the only sound,' he whispers into the microphone. More practising. The stunts must be organised. Calico, dressed as a nurse, runs on to the stage. Alice practises abducting Calico and shutting her in the boot of the wrecked car. Later, she bursts out of the boot. There are more scuffles. Alice rehearses sticking a curved sword into a plastic baby, and then waving the baby above his head. He is then arrested and guillotined on stage. As he disappears behind the guillotine, his head is substituted for a rubber lookalike. Later, Calico appears as Britney and mimes the words, 'Hit me one more time', at which point Alice does. On the way back to the hotel, Alice says, 'My old body feels like I walked from California.' There is silence for a while. Then he says, 'Look at the size of that!' We are approaching a large building, festooned at every entrance with golden arches. It is Friday the 13th of April, Good Friday, the day of the show itself. In the hotel, Alice tells me about Christianity, which he began to take seriously 10 years ago. 'It's everything,' he says. 'It's what I live for. If you gave me a choice between rock'n'roll and my faith, I'd take my faith. Rock'n'roll is fun - it's what I do for a living. But it's not what I live on. I believe in classic Christianity. I've given my whole life to the Lord. But I don't think that means you can't be a rock'n'roller. Ten years ago I went to my pastor and said, "I can't be Alice Cooper any more." He said, "D'you think God makes mistakes?"' He is religious, he says, having indulged in every pleasure it is possible to indulge in, and having, at the end of it, still felt empty. 'If you had known me 20 years ago, you would have said, "This is the most crazed, addicted person on the planet."' Drinking, he says, is 'a real freedom in the head. And I lived behind that mask for an awful long time.' Alice drank with Keith Moon, who was 'such a loon. You had to love him. Of course, you had to sit with him and drink all night. Same with Harry Nilsson. Same with John Lennon. John liked to drink.' Others involved were Mickey Dolenz, of the Monkees, Bernie Taupin, John Belushi. 'You'd get on the same level and everyone was having a great time. 'I've had every car, every mansion,' says Alice. 'I went through everything you could do.' Of his experience with drugs, he says, 'You lived through the 60s and 70s. You tried this and that.' He says he hasn't cheated on his wife since they got together a quarter of a century ago. Of being debauched, he says, 'I got to the end and realised there was nothing out there. I was still hungry for something. I was the prodigal son. I left the house, achieved fame and fortune, and found out that that was not what I wanted. Now I read the Bible every day. I pray every day. That's really what I'm about.' Is he, in a way, a sort of preacher, carrying on the tradition of his father and grandfather? 'Sometimes,' he says, 'I think what I do on stage is a very dramatic warning to the audience that Satan is not a myth. I believe he's very active.' Calico is sitting at the hotel bar. She wants to be an actress. When she told her father this, he told her to practise saying the phrase, '"Do ya want that wit' cheese?" Cos that's what you're going to be doing.' Of the show, she says, 'Your jaw is going to drop to the floor.' She feels fully rehearsed, and is not worried about getting hurt in the scene where she has a fight with her father. Alice appears to punch her in the face. 'Sometimes you just get clocked,' she says. 'But it is stage fighting. It's hit and push. You push your hand back if you make any contact.' She ponders for a while, and says, 'It's Spinal Tap, the show. We're just waiting for Stonehenge to drop.' Half an hour before the show is due to begin, I walk into Alice's dressing room. He is watching a kung-fu movie. Chinese men are tumbling around, shouting. He's calm. Alice says, 'You didn't believe me, did you?' He opens a trunk, which is full of kung-fu videos. The door opens. It is Brian Nelson, known among the entourage as Renfield. Nelson, originally a fan, had spent years attending every Alice Cooper show within driving distance of his home in Buffalo; before he was hired as Alice's assistant, he had become an Alice authority, with a huge collection of memorabilia. He knows more about Alice than anybody on earth, possibly Alice himself. He says to me, 'What are you doing? Alice needs to be alone now.' Nelson ushers me to the door. Alice nods. Outside, in the corridor, Nelson says, 'You shouldn't have done that! This is when Alice watches his kung-fu movies!' The show begins with a sinister voice: 'Well, well, well - what have we here? I am the controller of the city of the dead run by the sadistic megalomaniac Alice Cooper. Go now while you have a chance before it's too late. If he catches me now, he'll kill me if I'm lucky!' And then everything happens - the Mad Max costumes, the dry ice, the raw guitar chords. Eric Dober, the rhythm guitarist, had told me he was nervous; this was his first performance in the band. Alice had told Dober to make his playing as raw as feasibly possible, to 'make that guitar just a horrible thing'. And now Dober is bucking over his guitar, squeezing a suitably hellish noise from it. The show runs smoothly. The Newcastle fans seem to be either young or fairly old - a good proportion are well into middle age. One kid has the word 'Twisted' inked across his face. 'I'm Twisted Boy,' he tells me. Adults, I think, like Alice because he reminds them of the time when they used to say that the world was going to hell in a handcart, but did not really believe it. Kids see him as another point on the hellish cartography that is their cultural world. Alice stabs the baby; Alice shuts his daughter in the boot of the car. The guillotine scene works well. Alice croaks out his Aids-era song, 'Poison' ('You're poison, running through my veins'). When he sings 'School's Out', lots of people stand up and start bopping around. Towards the end, he disappears and comes back wearing a T-shirt which says 'Britney Wants Me' on the front, and 'Dead' on the back. Calico appears, dressed as Britney. They fight. After the show, Alice has agreed to 'meet and greet' some competition winners and members of a local golf organisation. 'Say please and thank you,' says one man to his son. One man, a collector of Alice memorabilia, asks Brian Nelson to sign something. In the car afterwards, Alice sings 'There's no business like show business' in a jaunty manner. We drive through the windy streets of Newcastle towards the golden arches. 'We should do a commercial for these guys,' says Alice. Then he says, 'At least I'm always thinking. I've always got an angle. I'm an ideas man.' But when we get to McDonald's, there is a huge tailback. The queue has been caused by Alice Cooper fans, who left the venue before us. 'I'll have a quarter pounder with cheese,' says Alice. And we join the end of the queue.  Alice Cooper tours the UK from 15 to 21 May. For ticket information, call 0115 912 9129.

fields.headline: Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: James Ellroy
fields.trailText: James Ellroy.
fields.body:
Ah-wooooo!!!!
I beg your pardon? James Ellroy, right? Self-proclaimed demon dog of American letters? Obsessive chronicler of 40s-50s LA's seamy underbelly - murderers, gangsters, venal Hollywood appetites - in the likes of The Black Dahlia , White Jazz , and LA Confidential ? With. Their. Staccato. Machine-gun. One-word. If that. Sentences? Probably inspired by the unsolved murder of his mother when he was a child? Former speed-freak, compulsive masturbator, and panty-thief jailbird? Given to howling like a wolf at book signings and weddings (principally his own)? That's him.

Not your usual shy, retiring wordsmith, then?
Not exactly. They'll be battening down the hatches at Ellroy's appearances - Ottaker's Bookshop, Norwich, tomorrow night, Nottingham Waterstone's Tuesday night, Bath Waterstone's Wednesday night, and Border's Charing Cross Road and the ICA, both London, Thursday lunchtime and evening, respectively - as he reads from and discusses The Cold Six Thousand , the second part of a proposed trilogy of his 'alternative history of the post-war American century'.

Can we get our copy inscribed?
You'll get something along the lines of 'WHITE JAZZ SLASHES THROATS!' or 'AMERICAN TABLOID BLOOD BLITZ!' if past scrawls are anything to go by, particularly as he says The Cold Six Thousand is 'My best book. Easily. All the way.'

All right! Turn those Hades-howls up to 11!
Actually, it might be better to keep them in reserve. At a recent signing, a young man brought along his dog, proudly informing Ellroy that his name was Gas Chamber. 'I was horrified,' he recalls. 'People confuse the persona with the real me. They don't realise I'm a happily married man living in Kansas City. I just want good neighbours and peace of mind.'

So he has gone soft?
You might say that; we'll be right behind you (cowering behind the nearest Harry Potter display).

fields.headline: Water, water everywhere...
fields.standfirst: We are always being told to keep our fluids up, but as Patricia Dobson discovers, too much water can kill
fields.trailText: We are always being told to keep our fluids up, but as Patricia Dobson discovers, too much water can kill.
fields.body:
When I sat down in the surgery waiting room, I was aware that people were giving me strange looks. Perhaps it wasn't surprising: wouldn't you stare at someone still in her pyjamas, eyes bulging, head lolling around like a cow with BSE, dry retching and babbling incoherently? They probably had me down as one of the local winos or drug addicts.

Of course, I'm not a wino or drug addict. Incredible as it may seem, I was in this state because I had drunk too much water. Incredible because, these days, we're constantly being told we don't drink enough water. Anything less than eight large glasses of water a day, and your body is under-hydrated, resulting in tiredness, depression, headaches, sallow skin, blocked innards and general unhappiness.

According to some devotees, water can reduce the risk of bladder and other cancers. And there are websites that will tell you how much water there is in everything (bananas 74 per cent, half a cup of cooked rice 89 per cent, if you really want to know). There are also those who set great store by not only how much we drink but also when we drink it (first thing in the morning, good; during mealtimes, bad). Quite often it seems as if we've gone back a few hundred years and are being sold a modern version of hydropathy. That was the treatment thought up by a German peasant called Vincenz Priessnitz in 1799, who recommended using water to rid the body of what he termed 'bad juices', which he believed were responsible for all illnesses.

According to Medical Blunders by Robert Youngson and Ian Schott (a must for any self-respecting hypochondriac), the treatment at his spa in Graefenberg was simple but highly popular: wrap yourself from head to foot, drink a glass of water every 30 minutes and wait for the sweat to flush out all those 'bad juices'. He also recommended water enemas, not a million miles from the thinking behind the benefits of what's now called colonic irrigation (whose fans apparently included Princess Diana).

For women prone to cystitis, water is, along with cranberry juice - whose prophylactic properties are now widely recognised - your saviour. Everyone from girlfriends to women's magazines tells you that the way to flush out that nasty bug is with lots of water. Which is all very well, but if you wake in the middle of the night with what you suspect are the early signs of a urinary infection, just make sure you keep an eye on exactly how much you're drinking.

Which is just what I didn't do a few weeks ago. Waking up at 5am for a pee and feeling that telltale burning sensation, I did what any woman who heeds the advice would do: I sat on the toilet with a jug of water by my side. After a few trips to the kitchen for a refill, I ended up with a very bad case of the runs - and strangely, I'd stopped peeing as much. Determined to flush out the infection, though, I kept downing the water. After 90 minutes of this - by which time I'd probably got through something like four litres - the burning sensation went only to be replaced by something more sinister: a strange throbbing headache, awful nausea and a worrying sense of confusion. Thankfully my faculties - and inbuilt alarm system - hadn't deserted me completely and, after a phone call to a local casualty department, I was advised to head straight to my GP (with what they thought was a suspected bladder infection).

My GP tested my urine but found no sign of any bacteria and so asked me to tell him exactly what I had done in the preceding few hours. Although he had been thinking about prescribing antibiotics (the usual treatment for bladder infection), his suspicions were already aroused. My claims that it was cystitis didn't tally with the evidence - my urine sample showed no rogue bacteria, but it did provide a vital clue. 'It is completely clear, not yellow at all, almost totally water,' he said, and then sent me to the chemist with a prescription for a strong diuretic. Two of these were enough to provoke four of the longest pees I've ever had. Immediately, the headache cleared, the nausea lifted and my eyes and mind were able to focus properly. My GP checked up on me twice during the next 10 hours, possibly to make sure I hadn't lost consciousness.

Because that's what could have happened if I hadn't sought medical advice. Excessive water intake can result in water intoxication, which occurs when too much water is retained in the brain. It's a condition which, according to Professor Steven Sacks, head of renal medicine at Guy's, King's and Thomas' School of Medicine, is not very common because 'the rate at which you take in the water is important. It's really quite hard to do.'

If you do manage it, though, the sodium level in the body is diluted and, because it's sodium that controls the level of water flowing into the tissues through osmosis, any reduction in the sodium level upsets the flow of water and salts inside and outside the cells, resulting in cell swelling all over the body. When that happens in the brain, it creates nausea, headaches, confusion and, in extreme cases, convulsions and coma; in other words, cerebral oedema.

'People do die from water intoxication,' adds Dr Adrian Wagg, a consultant geriatrician at London's Middlesex Hospital who has a keen interest in continence issues. 'Ecstasy is a classic case - kids go clubbing in hot environments, drink too much too quickly and cause low sodium due to dilution.' Indeed, according to reports at the time, the plasma sodium level of Leah Betts, the girl who died after taking an ecstasy tablet some years ago, fell to 126 millimoles per litre, when the normal level is between 134 and 145. There is, however, some debate over whether water intoxication is the only cause of ecstasy-related deaths. A more common reason is that ecstasy raises body temperature, over-stimulates the heart and increases blood pressure with often fatal consequences.

In normal circumstances, our bodies recognise that we've taken in extra fluid and that the circulating blood is more dilute. It then sends a signaI, through the anti-diuretic hormone which is released from the pituitary gland and reduces the amount of water lost in urine, to eliminate the excess water through the kidneys. This usually works very efficiently but, as Professor Sacks points out, the kidneys can only produce a certain amount of urine over a 24-hour period, and that's about 14 to 15 litres - or just over half a litre an hour - at the very most. If you overdo it, drinking as much as I did over such a short period of time, the kidneys just can't cope and the water disperses through the blood and other organs, resulting in water intoxication.

So how much water should we be drinking? About two litres a day, according to Dr Wagg. And how much is too much? Difficult to say, because everyone is physically different, but it would be wise to limit your intake to less than one litre over two to three hours, and certainly not to keep drinking glass after glass after glass, as I did.

In future, I'll be more careful. In the meantime, hold the water - a straight whiskey will do just fine.

Thankfully my faculties - and inbuilt alarm system - hadn't deserted me completely and, after a phone call to a local casualty department, I was advised to head straight to my GP (with what they thought was a suspected bladder infection). My GP tested my urine but found no sign of any bacteria and so asked me to tell him exactly what I had done in the preceding few hours. Although he had been thinking about prescribing antibiotics (the usual treatment for bladder infection), his suspicions were already aroused. My claims that it was cystitis didn't tally with the evidence - my urine sample showed no rogue bacteria, but it did provide a vital clue. 'It is completely clear, not yellow at all, almost totally water,' he said, and then sent me to the chemist with a prescription for a strong diuretic. Two of these were enough to provoke four of the longest pees I've ever had. Immediately, the headache cleared, the nausea lifted and my eyes and mind were able to focus properly. My GP checked up on me twice during the next 10 hours, possibly to make sure I hadn't lost consciousness. Because that's what could have happened if I hadn't sought medical advice. Excessive water intake can result in water intoxication, which occurs when too much water is retained in the brain. It's a condition which, according to Professor Steven Sacks, head of renal medicine at Guy's, King's and Thomas' School of Medicine, is not very common because 'the rate at which you take in the water is important. It's really quite hard to do.' If you do manage it, though, the sodium level in the body is diluted and, because it's sodium that controls the level of water flowing into the tissues through osmosis, any reduction in the sodium level upsets the flow of water and salts inside and outside the cells, resulting in cell swelling all over the body. When that happens in the brain, it creates nausea, headaches, confusion and, in extreme cases, convulsions and coma; in other words, cerebral oedema. 'People do die from water intoxication,' adds Dr Adrian Wagg, a consultant geriatrician at London's Middlesex Hospital who has a keen interest in continence issues. 'Ecstasy is a classic case - kids go clubbing in hot environments, drink too much too quickly and cause low sodium due to dilution.' Indeed, according to reports at the time, the plasma sodium level of Leah Betts, the girl who died after taking an ecstasy tablet some years ago, fell to 126 millimoles per litre, when the normal level is between 134 and 145. There is, however, some debate over whether water intoxication is the only cause of ecstasy-related deaths. A more common reason is that ecstasy raises body temperature, over-stimulates the heart and increases blood pressure with often fatal consequences. In normal circumstances, our bodies recognise that we've taken in extra fluid and that the circulating blood is more dilute. It then sends a signaI, through the anti-diuretic hormone which is released from the pituitary gland and reduces the amount of water lost in urine, to eliminate the excess water through the kidneys. This usually works very efficiently but, as Professor Sacks points out, the kidneys can only produce a certain amount of urine over a 24-hour period, and that's about 14 to 15 litres - or just over half a litre an hour - at the very most. If you overdo it, drinking as much as I did over such a short period of time, the kidneys just can't cope and the water disperses through the blood and other organs, resulting in water intoxication. So how much water should we be drinking? About two litres a day, according to Dr Wagg. And how much is too much? Difficult to say, because everyone is physically different, but it would be wise to limit your intake to less than one litre over two to three hours, and certainly not to keep drinking glass after glass after glass, as I did. In future, I'll be more careful. In the meantime, hold the water - a straight whiskey will do just fine.

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: reward yourself with regeneration, dealing with a dry mouth, and how to calm puffy eyes
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: reward yourself with regeneration, dealing with a dry mouth, and how to calm puffy eyes.
fields.body:
Exhausted? Feel like every movement of your body is powered by will alone? Out of breath and dragging your legs up the hill? Notice your reaction to life tends towards the negative? So tired you can't even be bothered to go to bed? You need a holiday, mate!

But seriously (seeing as holidays don't fall off trees), we can take the core mechanism of a good holiday and use it as a template for a discrete 24-hour instant self-regeneration programme. The first stage of a holiday comprises the wind-down and unravelling process - being willing to pull your foot off the gas pedal to reduce idling speed altogether.

This tends to cause the release of a hundred different random thought streams and consequent disorientation as your familiar internal reference points become blurred and momentarily irrelevant. Instead of fixing your location on the metaphysical map by such reference points as your interpersonal relationships, what you do for a living, how you do it, how (you think) others perceive you, social status (as you see it), financial status, hopes, dreams and expectations, you can only fix it by reference to being in a state of unwinding. The Taoists of the ancient Orient, field leaders in burden relinquishment, called this process of self-voiding 'investing in loss', the rationale being that it's hard for life to fill you with its goodies when you're already full (of yourself) and damn tired from it to boot.

The unnerving thing about letting go like this is an inevitable sense of having lost the overview. Suddenly, all the demons that have been obscured by activity come rushing up to the surface. That's the second stage: facing your demons. So you grapple with your fears of failure, illness and death; you wrestle with your resentments and inadequacies. You wonder whether it may have been better just to keep going.

But you're so exhausted, you haven't even the stamina to keep this up for long, and eventually you succumb to the pull of TV, a good book or just plain gravity, and fall fast asleep. You don't even care that the sun is shining, albeit very intermittently. You just want to sleep. And you do. You sleep and sleep (for a good hour or more - remember, we only have one day). And you dream, and your dreams unleash a torrent of twisted images, like the dross in a waste-disposal unit.

But after a while, as you come to - and this is the third stage of regeneration - you do start to wonder if it might be nice to experience the sun on your face, and the thought of interacting with others live, by phone or email mildly excites rather than terrifies you. Be careful, now, because you mustn't rush this stage. Slowly, you stumble from your bed (or couch) and, with mind fresh, instil a positive thought, such as 'I access limitless energy now!', because we all know you can't self-regenerate successfully with a negative attitude - that would only reinforce the exhaustion.

Next you attend to your liver, because though all organs and indeed systems are intimately involved in the exhaustion-emptying-regeneration process, it's your liver that does the living, and which provides the key to re-energising yourself. So saying, take hold of your lower front ribs on both sides (one side per hand) and gently prise apart, breathing deeply throughout. Keep prising till you feel you have reached full lateral extension. Hold for a minute or until you grow bored of it and release slowly. This will not only reduce stress in your liver region and increase circulation of blood and energy, but will also help your diaphragm relax and hence increase breath capacity - crucial in energy production.

Finally comes re-entry. Swallow a few drops of Bach Flower Remedy of Olive, and gird your loins with such sentiments as 'I am fully regenerated now (though a proper holiday would've been nice), and ready for anything! I'm so regenerated I can hardly bear it!' Too gung ho? Oh, forget it. Let's pull a sicky and stay in bed.

Your questions

For years now I have woken up every morning with a very dry mouth. Any ideas?
Peter, via email

According to the simplistic tenets of Oriental physiology, this arises from kidney energy deficit, when kidneys lose ability to keep the body heat down in the lower part of the body, creating a 'false' heat in the head region. As well as avoiding alcohol, tobacco, coffee, tea, Chinese takeaways and other well-known dehydrators, and putting a humidifier in your room, massage your kidneys with fists in circles 36 times in each direction morning and night, drink pineapple juice before sleep and consider a treatment or two of acupuncture to rebalance.

Hello Barefoot, For the past year I've had puffy eyes - not just on waking up, but all day - and dark circles under my eyes. I'm 31 and never had any problems before. I always get enough sleep. As a designer for the internet, I spend a lot of time in front of the computer. My GP did a blood test to see if my kidneys were playing up, but gave me the all clear. His only advice was to use a steroid cream (Betnovate) around my eyes, which I didn't do because I didn't like the sound of it. I've tried teabags, cucumber, cotton wool pads soaked in milk, expensive eye creams and gels - all to no avail.
Kate, via email

Two things here. One is the local treatments you've been trying are all helpful, but try a tissue-salt version of natrum mur to reduce fluid retention and eyebright herb in an eyebath. Also, use your knuckle to very gently massage around the eye sockets, from the outer corners to the inner, under the eyes towards the nose and over the eyes towards the ears, 18 times every two hours, to disperse old blood and fluid and induce fresh circulation. Additionally, try headstands or other inverted postures if possible, as these help circulation greatly. The second aspect is that in Oriental thought, this is caused by kidney and liver energy deficit, which often won't show up on Western tests but can be treated successfully by acupuncture and Chinese herbs.

fields.headline: Midnight blues
fields.standfirst: Don't let caffeine spoil your beauty sleep. Plus, the danger of being too clean, and what 'brown' really means
fields.trailText: Don't let caffeine spoil your beauty sleep. Plus, the danger of being too clean, and what 'brown' really means.
fields.body:
Finding myself virtually midway between my 30th and 40th birthdays, I have recently abandoned running and have instead embarked on a renewed quest for eternal youth by taking up yoga. I've found that sitting quietly, humming and 'saluting the sun' in the morning allows me to breathe deeply and thereby oxygenate every centimetre of my body. I've also noticed that concentrating on breathing deeply for a few minutes before going to bed helps me to drift into a slumber that insomniacs would trade their right arms for.

Sleeping soundly rewards us with health benefits far beyond the accepted increased capacity to work and play hard: crucially, it enables us to look younger and our organs to perform more efficiently. This is because slumber prompts the pituitary gland to release growth hormone (GH), a super-restorative that increases the amount of nutrients absorbed by the body's cells, encourages the growth and repair of muscles and bone, and strengthens the immune system. The rate of tissue growth and repair is greatest at night because, under the influence of GH, this is when our cells are the most active and are multiplying themselves the most vigorously. This is why sleep deprivation is reflected in our skin: if we don't get enough replenishing sleep, the pituitary gland produces less GH, the rate of skin-cell replacement slows down, and the skin loses its clarity and bloom. All in all, the more you can do during the day - especially during the late afternoon and early evening - to prepare your body for a good night's slumber, the better.

Caffeine-rich drinks are among the most common causes of insomnia, and some people, particularly hyperactive children, can be so sensitive to caffeine that even having a coffee or cola in the morning can disrupt their sleep. Drinking non-caffeine-containing drinks, such as fresh fruit juice, during the day, or a herbal infusion such as camomile tea or a hot, milky drink (apart from chocolate, which contains caffeine) at night should encourage you or your child to wind down sufficiently to sleep deeply and kick-start the production of a hefty dose of growth hormone, nature's own elixir of youth.

Nutrition news: Playing dirty

The number of children who have inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is far higher than was previously thought, according to a nationwide study carried out by the Institute of Child Health, the British Society of Gastroenterology Research Unit and the British Paediatric Surveillance Unit. Professor Bhupinder Sandhu, of the Institute of Child Health, believes that this increase can be explained by the relatively clean environment in which British children now live: it is thought that not being exposed to the same range of bacteria as their parents somehow alters their immune system. (Alternatively, a microbe in food could be responsible.) The popularity of so-called 'anti-bacterial' cleaning and disinfecting products, along with discouraging children from playing outside and becoming dirty, may therefore be contributory factors in the higher number of cases.

Your questions

How come high-fibre foods, such as wholemeal brown breads and pasta, brown rice and bran are meant to be better for you than the white, processed variety? And do they help you lose weight, rather than the processed kind, as I have been led to believe?
Romani, London

There is confusion regarding the words 'brown', 'wholemeal' and 'wholegrain'. Because there is no legal definition of the word 'brown', many 'brown' products are, in fact, white products that have been dyed. By contrast, wholegrain and wholemeal products are legally required to include the whole of a plant's husk.

Wholemeal products such as wholegrain rice, bread and pasta are healthier than white, processed foods because they contain more fibre, the plant material that stimulates the gut to produce substances that ward off heart disease and cancer. Fibre encourages the liver to produce high-density lipoprotein ('good' cholesterol) and reduces the absorption of the fats and sugars that can lead to obesity, diabetes and heart disease. Wholemeals also swell in the presence of plenty of water, thereby stimulating the gut to transport food through it efficiently. And, as if that wasn't enough, the plant husks that wholemeal products contain endow them with beneficial nutrients, such as B vitamins, zinc and magnesium.

High-fibre foods do help you to lose weight, because water drunk with them prompts the fibre to swell in the stomach, thereby stimulating stretch receptors in the stomach lining to send positive signals to the fullness centre in the brain. As a result, and unlike its white relation, wholemeal bread will make you feel more satisfied and thus less tempted to eat as much.

fields.headline: Chinese chequer
fields.standfirst: Not sure where to go for authentic Asian greens? Sue Webster spills the beans
fields.trailText: Not sure where to go for authentic Asian greens? Sue Webster spills the beans.
fields.body:
I used to feel mildly irritated when Chinese grocers responded to my questions about the bewildering variety of crunchy-looking greens on display in their shops with explanations that were not so much botanically inadequate as Monty Python-esque. Typically, the answer to the question, 'What is this, please?' was the maddening 'Chinese vegetable'. But now I know better. Cantonese for vegetable is 'choi', so 'pak choi' means simply white vegetable, 'gaai choi' is mustard greens and 'choi sum' is flowering cabbage. Most of us can recognise pak choi (or bok choy, let's not be fussy.) It looks a bit like Swiss chard, though it is also available as an all-green variety. It is by far the most popular of all the so-called Chinese greens - to the extent that it is the most commonly available Asian brassica in supermarkets. The trouble is that it tends to be sold in ludicrously small packs (£1.29/200g from Sainsbury's; £1.29/200g from Waitrose) and any minute now the supermarket execs will come up with the bright idea of enclosing a sachet of soy sauce and some throwaway chopsticks for an extra 50p.

To go shopping at an oriental grocers, you usually need to go armed with a little more information. (Joy Larkcom's Oriental Vegetables is a useful guide.) Chinese kale, which is sometimes called Chinese broccoli (gai laan), has thick stems, white flowers and a white bloom on the leaves. Cooks who buy them as an experiment come a cropper if they don't realise that the stems have to be peeled. Chinese spinach has nothing to do with spinach as we know it, and its leaves come in colours ranging from variegated to red; but it has a pleasing, mild flavour. Both leaves and stalks only have to be chopped and stir-fired. Chinese chives, or gau choi, have flat, rather than tubular leaves and a strong, garlicky flavour. You can buy them blanched, complete with the buds (gau wong) to add to noodles or soup. At Yum-Yum's Oriental Supermarket, 22-23 Sydney Street, Brighton (01273 606 777), smiling staff will help identify all vegetables in season, but say choi sum and pak choi (about £10/kg) are the ones they can get all year round.

Best value of all are the exotic greens sold by the likes of Peter Clark of Kingcup Farm, Denham, at the weekly London Farmers' Markets (020 7704 9659). Clark originally grew coriander and mizuna for the Indian communities of west London; now he finds they are taking over from rocket as a salad. He also notes an urban preference for white-stemmed (rather than green) pak choi. 'It has a nicer flavour, but it's also a psychological thing: people think it will be better than cabbage.' He charges a mere £3/kg. His latest hits include 'chop suey greens'; pea shoots, which appeal all the more if they have flowers or the odd mange-tout-like pod attached; and the mild mitsuba or Japanese parsley. 'People who shop in the markets seem to live on takeaways, a bit of pasta or restaurant food during the week,' he observes. 'So when they cook something at the weekend, they want to try out something different.'

Meanwhile, contrary to expectations, 90 per cent of all farm shops remain open, despite the foot and mouth crisis, and many grow Asian greens under glass. At Secretts' Farm Shop, Hurst Farm, Chapel Lane, Milford (01483 520 500), the biggest seller is tat soi. The Chinese name means 'very ancient cabbage', but this refers to the variety; in fact tat soi is really rosette pak choi, a sort of baby version with dark green, very succulent leaves (£1.20/100g). 'You put it in with your other salad leaves to give variety,' says Greg Secrett, enthusiastically. 'It provides the juicy bit.'

fields.headline: Better red...
fields.standfirst: The season of true Treviso is almost over, but Sybil Kapoor is not bitter
fields.trailText: The season of true Treviso is almost over, but Sybil Kapoor is not bitter.
fields.body:
Fred Foster, the man behind Turnip's fruit and vegetable stall at Borough Market in London, enjoys teasing his customers. 'Ah, but what do you mean by trevisse?' he asks, as he points to two boxes. One is piled high with what look like fat heads of rosy-coloured Belgium endive, the other is filled with glossy cream and magenta chicory, their thin leaves sprouting brush like from woody stems. Trick question. I raise my eyebrows and point to the latter box.

Trevisse - as it was called when I worked as a chef in New York - belongs to the radicchio family. Its true name is radicchio di Treviso and it is grown around Treviso in the Veneto region of Italy. Foster chuckles gleefully in agreement before adding: 'Of course a lot of the chefs I supply call radicchio di Verona [the other one] Treviso.' He picks up a pink head and explains, 'It's cheaper and they get more for their money, but I have to say it doesn't taste as good as the real one.'

One head of Treviso costs about £1.50. The plants are dug up throughout the winter, bound together and stored in the dark for four or five days until their leaves have turned a deep red. Their roots are then submerged in spring water for a further few days to remove some of the bitterness. Its season, which is late this year, will end in a few weeks - so hurry. 'It's the only vegetable I know that hired a PR company to promote it to chefs,' continues Foster, 'but it's becoming very fashionable'.

Such concepts are irrelevant to Nino Sassu, chef and joint owner of Assaggi. 'It doesn't make sense to have ingredients in or out of fashion,' he states. 'I think that they should be assessed on their own merits and what they can bring to a recipe.' As winner of the Best Italian Restaurant of the Year at the recent London Restaurant Awards, he ought to know. Every spring, Sassu incorporates radicchio di Treviso into his repertoire, tossing it into a wild rocket salad with speck and scarmorza (a smoked mozzarella), cooking it with sweet red onions, wine and saba to serve with venison; and mixing it into risottos, which he garnishes with a few shredded and deep-fried leaves.

I, too, cannot resist its succulent bittersweet leaves. They taste so good tossed in a little olive oil and served with a pinto bean salad, or mixed into pasta with some crispy bacon. Simply, Treviso is worth the money, never mind the fashion.

 Turnip's, Borough Market, London SE1 (020 7357 8356). Open Monday-Thursday 10am-2.30pm; Friday 10am-6pm; Saturday 9am-4pm. Assaggi, The Chepstow, 39 Chepstow Place, London W2 (020 7792 9033).

fields.headline: The perfect boy band
fields.standfirst: Louis Walsh, manager of Westlife
fields.trailText: Louis Walsh, manager of Westlife.
fields.body:
The perfect package will hook as many fans as possible, so you need five different looks: blond, dark, cheeky, camp and macho. Girls like guys from Eminem to Ronan Keating, so you have to include something for everyone. If someone didn't like Take That, they might have had a soft spot for Robbie because he's a character. Five is the magic number: it gives people just enough to look at. BBMak and 911 have three, and it doesn't look right. When I was forming Boyzone I was tempted to have four, though, because it would have been much easier to fit them in a taxi.

I like to have one guy in the band who has a bit of an edge because he'll attract the girls who fancy baddies, but a group full of bad boys, like Five or East 17, will never do big business. It's best if they look like every young girl's boy next door, with the difference that he's able to smile and dance and sing. The girls must believe in the backs of their minds that one day they'll go out with him. It doesn't help the fanbase if one of the boys is in a relationship or having a baby - but I can't control their lives as much as I'd like to.

What you can control is the formation of the band. You can't leave it up to luck that five talented people will find each other and make it. You need a whole team around the band to groom them, bring them songs, choreography, styling and get them on all the big TV and radio shows. They've got to be able to sing and project some personality.

And then the rest is up to the girls. They go crazy, buy all their records, posters and DVDs and go to every show they can. And then they grow up. But the boys do, too; when you see facial hair, earrings and tattoos and they start to talk about being individuals, it's time to go to the conveyor belt and get a new set.

 Louis Walsh set up boy band Boyzone and now manages Westlife, among other acts.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: As the only two Rolling Stones who had jobs, families and turned up on time, Charlie Watts and Bill Wyman formed a special relationship. But Charlie will never forgive Bill for that teddy boy hair cut
fields.trailText: As the only two Rolling Stones who had jobs, families and turned up on time, Charlie Watts and Bill Wyman formed a special relationship. But Charlie will never forgive Bill for that teddy boy hair cut.
fields.body:
Charlie Watts: The Rolling Stones was a solid entity. Bill could play with the Stones now and it would be like the Stones 30 years ago. I miss having Bill around. Not so much on stage, but the social bit.

The first time I met Bill was in 1963 in this pub that used to be opposite the World's End, Chelsea, near where Mick, Keith and Brian used to live in Edith Grove. He had a huge bass amp which was a big deal at the time. He'd been in the band about a week. And he used to have a teddy boy cut, much to my anger, because he's a little bit older than us - but we don't mention that.

In 30 years of the Stones, I never fell out with Bill. He's a very kind person, easy-going. We were very close in the band structure. We were the rhythm section, so his problems were nearly always my problems. When he left the band - God, bloody hell! - I could have killed him. We had two weeks where I was playing three hours a day to audition new bass players. I was dead at the end, my bloody hands were killing me. Ninety per cent of choosing a person is that you live with them. Bill was always easy to live with. We've seen each other through various ups and downs.

The last time he was with us was when he married that dreadful Mandy girl. I think it was one of the lowest periods of his life. It was a kind of nervous breakdown; just trying to keep together was hell. He used to sometimes confide in me. Now it's wonderful that he's found Suzanne (his third wife, whom he married in 1993) and has three lovely children. Many times I'd see him when I was having a difficult time. I'd go and knock in the early hours, and just sit there, and I think I got on his nerves, like most drunks.

These days he calls sometimes. He's not allowed to come to my gigs at Ronnie's, it's too intellectual for him and I don't go to his, it's too much dumbing down. No, I'm joking. I think he'd like to see my band, but he's not sitting near the front. And I'll try and see him with the Rhythm Kings because he has some wonderful musicians. Bill was always the most sensible of all of us. Mind you, I was never that mad.

Bill Wyman: I don't miss anything about the Stones since leaving in 1993. Well, I miss the money, that's about all. I don't get a pang when I see them, never have. And the relationships - well, I don't see Keith that much but the others I see all the time. We're just good mates. But Charlie comes by when he's in town. He just appears.

When I first joined the Stones in December 1962, he was still playing with Alexis Korner, then a month later he was asked to replace the drummer. He was great, Charlie, I liked him straightaway. I was closer to him than any of the others, but then we were the rhythm section. We're totally different personalities, but we were the only ones who were always on time, so we were always chatting away to each other. And we were the first two to be married, the first two to have children, so we were the family men if you like, and we were slightly older. We were the two that were working - none of the others had jobs at the beginning - so we were the only ones that had money. When we started touring, the others thought of us as more conventional, we didn't want to go partying really, we'd go home to our families.

He was always supportive in any problem and I suppose I was to him. He'd always repay me by buying me a little painting or something, he's very generous like that. He knows I collect Scottish things and Scottish toy soldiers, so he'd buy me something like a sporran from the Battle of Waterloo.

I really like Charlie's humour. He's got the one-liners spot on. He's hysterical, but most people don't get it. Sometimes he'll phone me from Argentina when the Stones are touring and say, 'I was on stage again tonight and I turned round to say something to you, and you weren't there again,' and I'll be cracking up on the phone - it's 3 o'clock in the morning - and I'll say, 'Where are you?' and he'll say, 'I don't know, some place called Boners Arees or something.' That's his charm. He doesn't even know he's in Argentina.

 Bill Wyman & The Rhythm Kings's new album is Double Bill . Charlie Watts & the Tentet will be at Ronnie Scott's 4-16 June.

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... a cup of coffee
fields.trailText: ... a cup of coffee.
fields.body:
What commodity, found in 93 per cent of British households, is the second most valuable in the world? It is coffee and, in the same way that the Middle East is the world's oil well, so South America (and Brazil in particular) produces most of the world's coffee beans. However, a quick scan of the supermarket shelves reveals rather more variety than you get on the average forecourt.

At the bottom end of the market, you have jars of instant coffee. In 1938, Nestlé scientists discovered how to preserve the aroma and taste of coffee with hydrocarbons. During the war, US soldiers found it in their ration packs and developed a taste for it. By the 60s, Nestlé was producing instant coffee by extracting liquid coffee from beans and freezedrying it - they called it Nescafé.

Today, Nestlé estimates that 3,000 cups of Nescafé are drunk every second. It is a fairly economical drink: the cost of the water and electricity for the kettle is negligible. If a 100g jar costs £2.25, and if you get 50 generous cups out of it, then you'll be drinking about 4p worth of coffee in each.

Further along the shelf you will find coffee from Kenya, Ethiopia, Java, Colombia, Puerto Rico and Costa Rica. And you'll notice a distinction between arabica beans and robusta beans. Arabica beans are grown at altitudes between 600m and 2,000m, mostly in South America, while the more coarsely flavoured robusta is grown below 600m in parts of Africa and Asia.

As with oil, coffee prices fluctuate. Some stability, and a reasonable level of income for the smaller coffee grower, has been introduced by the Fairtrade organisation. It buys washed arabica beans for 85p per lb and pays an additional 10p for organically produced beans - world coffee prices can be significantly lower.

To get the best out of arabica beans, you will need a grinder and at least a cafetière. An adequate home espresso machine will cost you £150, but it is the only way to bring out the beans' oils.

Hordes of coffee shops have sprung up to service our burgeoning caffeine dependency, pushing all sorts of exotica - at, say Starbucks, you can purchase a large caramel macchiato for £2.95. So one cup costs almost four times what the farmer receives for 1lb of beans.

Arabica beans Fairtrade price: 85p/lb
Grinder £19.95
Home espresso machine £150
Cafetière from £20
Ground coffee £1.25/100g
Instant coffee £2.25/100g
Caramel macchiato £2.95

fields.headline: Keep out: Jedd's room
fields.standfirst: Your child's bedroom needn't be a bomb site. Tamsin Blanchard dares to go where every parent fears to tread
fields.trailText: Your child's bedroom needn't be a bomb site. Tamsin Blanchard dares to go where every parent fears to tread.
fields.body:
There's something really seductive about miniature things. The charm of a doll's house is that it is a miniaturised version of an adult world. It's like those tiny models of design classic chairs you can buy. Sure you'd like the full-scale Eames Eiffel chair in your living room, but having the miniature version sitting on your shelves is almost as good. But for most parents, there is nothing charming whatsoever about their children's bedrooms, where the beds are smaller, the chairs and tables are a fifth the size of the ones in the rest of the house, and the mess is bigger and more chaotic than in any other room. Small is not necessarily beautiful. Welcome to the pigsty.

While children seem to have more toys than previous generations, there are more and more solutions for making their bedrooms bright and beautiful. Ikea (020 8208 5600) has expanded its children's section to include everything the modern nursery could possibly need: toys, rugs with hopscotch 'chalked' on to it (Hoppa, £25), comical bulbous plastic stools (Mammut, £5 each) in bright, primary colours, and storage crates (Mard, £2.90 each). There are even miniature bucket-and-mop sets (Duktig, £5), designed to teach your children to clean as they learn. Who are they trying to kid?

For some parents, however, brightly coloured plastic is not the ideal home environment. Interiors stylist Rebecca Duke has not compromised her own style for her children's bedrooms, which are surprisingly tidy and minimal. Coco, five, is the proud owner of a French wrought-iron bed, painted to match the walls. 'She said she wanted pink,' says Duke. The paint is all Designers Guild. And the bed is a bargain find from a junk shop, which Duke sanded down and painted to look like new. There are also green chairs - child's size - also a find from a junk shop. 'I'm not into children's wallpapers and fabric. I'm a junk-shop queen,' says Duke.

'Everything is old and salvaged - funny bits and pieces that I've found on my travels.' On the floor is a purple, stripy rug from Habitat. Coco shares the room with her baby sister Minnie, who sleeps in a cot. Next door, their three-year-old brother Jedd has a room to himself, painted little-boy blue, chosen from The Paint Library. Most of his toys are tidied away in Ikea storage boxes, leaving the room looking clean and simple. His bed is made from MDF and painted the same colour as the walls. Tim Chapman designs children's beds like Jedd's and sells them, unpainted and ready for assembly, through his mail-order company, Bump. Jedd's sleigh day bed is available in four different mattress sizes, for £225, plus £125 for the mattress. It also comes as a bunk bed, for £435 for the frame. For a brochure, call 020 7249 7000.

Another alternative to primary-coloured plastics is plywood. Two years ago, the north London furniture showroom twentytwentyone (020 7288 1996) came up with the Childsply project - a brief for designers to make a piece of functional children's furniture out of plywood. It is now touring with the British Council and is currently in Berlin. Robin Day's chair has since gone into production and is a perfectly simple construction designed, as ever, to be practical, long-lasting and comfortable; it costs £99. Simon Alderson of twentytwentyone was one of the brains behind Childsply. 'We have a lot of enquiries about children's furniture,' he says. He sees the market divided into two categories. 'From the parental point of view, pieces should be durable and cost-effective because the child is going to outgrow them and destroy them anyway.'

Other children's furniture on sale at twentytwentyone include the classic Bertoia wire chair (from £150), which has been scaled down for children with an aesthetic eye and rich parents. The stackable Kartell Centro Kappa chair in plastic (£48) and the Swedish company Trip Trapp's colourful plywood Hippo rocking chair (£99) are both also available to order.

Some of the pieces originally shown as part of Childsply are now in production with the independent company Oreka Kids. This is the first collection of furniture to be made exclusively for children, and has been overseen by designers Michael Marriot and Simon Maidment. Their brief to a team of seven designers has been to design furniture that was neither miniature adult designs, nor oversized toys, but multifunctional objects that would stimulate activity and creativity. Jane Atfield has come up with Amaretti, a trolley which can be used as a cart, baby bed or simply as storage (£235); the Azumis have designed Oreo, a work table and bench which can be flat-packed and carried by children (£355); Flapjack is by Sebastian Bergne - a shoe and coat locker where kids can learn to tie laces and record their height (£260).

Matthew Hilton's Jammy Dodger can be a fantasy house, train, boat, castle, desk or seat (£230). High prices go hand in hand with small UK production, but at least the designs are a step in the right direction.

The Biscuit collection is available by mail order, and from selected outlets. For more information, call 020 8884 3435 or go to www.orekakids.com to place an order.

Not surprisingly, the Biscuit range has made it into the Design Museum before the shop floor. It's on show as part of the Minor Works exhibition, which ends today, alongside some prototypes by students at Buckingham University, and last year's Childsform project, another project for twentytwentyone where designers were given a block of foam to create a game, toy or piece of furniture for one- to six-year-olds. And yes, there are chairs to sit on, so your kids can tell you if they're any good.

For father-of-two Andrew Dunbar, expensive 'designer' children's furniture is not an option. He has found that the most useful piece of furniture his children own is something he knocked up himself. It's a sturdy, low footstool made out of pine, with a grab hole in the middle. For Ellie, almost four, and Daisy, almost two, it has become indispensable. The girls use it to make adult-sized homes more child-friendly - to stand on to reach the sink to brush their teeth, or to get things from the fridge. They have four in the house. The stools have been such a hit, Dunbar has gone into production with them. They are £25, and can be ordered by calling 01702 716 363.

Jedd's sleigh day bed is available in four different mattress sizes, for £225, plus £125 for the mattress. It also comes as a bunk bed, for £435 for the frame. For a brochure, call 020 7249 7000. Another alternative to primary-coloured plastics is plywood. Two years ago, the north London furniture showroom twentytwentyone (020 7288 1996) came up with the Childsply project - a brief for designers to make a piece of functional children's furniture out of plywood. It is now touring with the British Council and is currently in Berlin. Robin Day's chair has since gone into production and is a perfectly simple construction designed, as ever, to be practical, long-lasting and comfortable; it costs £99. Simon Alderson of twentytwentyone was one of the brains behind Childsply. 'We have a lot of enquiries about children's furniture,' he says. He sees the market divided into two categories. 'From the parental point of view, pieces should be durable and cost-effective because the child is going to outgrow them and destroy them anyway.' Other children's furniture on sale at twentytwentyone include the classic Bertoia wire chair (from £150), which has been scaled down for children with an aesthetic eye and rich parents. The stackable Kartell Centro Kappa chair in plastic (£48) and the Swedish company Trip Trapp's colourful plywood Hippo rocking chair (£99) are both also available to order. Some of the pieces originally shown as part of Childsply are now in production with the independent company Oreka Kids. This is the first collection of furniture to be made exclusively for children, and has been overseen by designers Michael Marriot and Simon Maidment. Their brief to a team of seven designers has been to design furniture that was neither miniature adult designs, nor oversized toys, but multifunctional objects that would stimulate activity and creativity. Jane Atfield has come up with Amaretti, a trolley which can be used as a cart, baby bed or simply as storage (£235); the Azumis have designed Oreo, a work table and bench which can be flat-packed and carried by children (£355); Flapjack is by Sebastian Bergne - a shoe and coat locker where kids can learn to tie laces and record their height (£260). Matthew Hilton's Jammy Dodger can be a fantasy house, train, boat, castle, desk or seat (£230). High prices go hand in hand with small UK production, but at least the designs are a step in the right direction. The Biscuit collection is available by mail order, and from selected outlets. For more information, call 020 8884 3435 or go to www.orekakids.com to place an order. Not surprisingly, the Biscuit range has made it into the Design Museum before the shop floor. It's on show as part of the Minor Works exhibition, which ends today, alongside some prototypes by students at Buckingham University, and last year's Childsform project, another project for twentytwentyone where designers were given a block of foam to create a game, toy or piece of furniture for one- to six-year-olds. And yes, there are chairs to sit on, so your kids can tell you if they're any good. For father-of-two Andrew Dunbar, expensive 'designer' children's furniture is not an option. He has found that the most useful piece of furniture his children own is something he knocked up himself. It's a sturdy, low footstool made out of pine, with a grab hole in the middle. For Ellie, almost four, and Daisy, almost two, it has become indispensable. The girls use it to make adult-sized homes more child-friendly - to stand on to reach the sink to brush their teeth, or to get things from the fridge. They have four in the house. The stools have been such a hit, Dunbar has gone into production with them. They are £25, and can be ordered by calling 01702 716 363.

fields.headline: Go buy
fields.standfirst: The Phaidon 55
fields.trailText: The Phaidon 55.
fields.body:
'Whatever we have done,' said Henri Cartier-Bresson, 'Kertész did first.' High praise indeed for the former clerk at the Budapest Stock Exchange who went on to become one of the world's leading photographers and who is celebrated in a small but stylish paperback by Phaidon, as part of its new series of mini-monographs that slip nicely into the gap between hefty full-colour tome and that unimaginative gift, the 'little book'.

The Phaidon 55 is made for the modern-day flneur - lighter than an IXUS and small enough to stash in the back pocket of your Levi's, it's the perfect companion for a leisurely bus trip or a stroll through the city. Each title contains 55 prints and a lively introduction to the photographer.

André Kertész, for example, was a pioneer of the compact camera. Leica in hand, he went in pursuit of the bizarre, the poetic and the surreal in everyday situations, the results neither forced nor heavy-handed but spontaneous and unpretentious. He was also self-taught, but among his friends were eminent photographers and painters including Cartier-Bresson, Brassaï and Mondrian, whose pipe and glasses he shot in 1926.

Other pioneers of photography represented in the series include Bauhaus professor and avant-garde artist László Moholy-Nagy, Eadweard Muybridge, whose locomotion studies of the 1870s changed our understanding of animal and human movement, and fellow Victorian Julia Margaret Cameron, famed for her expressive portraits and tableaux vivants. Contemporary photographers Nan Goldin and Citibank Photography Prize winner Boris Mikhailov bring the series up to date.

 The first 20 Phaidon 55 titles are published on 5 May, priced £4.95 each.

fields.headline: More letters to the editor
fields.trailText: School's out
fields.body:
School's out

The school admission problems described by Tracy McVeigh (News, last week) are all too common, for several different reasons:

 In some areas schools can set conditions regarding area, distance and selection on the basis of ability or religious affiliation.

 Popular schools get oversubscribed.

 The LEA can remove catchment-area place guarantees for some schools.

 Legal judgment has resulted in late applications being given lower priority.

 Limiting infant class sizes to 30 pupils can restrict availability of classrooms and/or teaching staff.

 There are often also priority criteria relating to siblings and distance from home to school.

It is not surprising that parents can be confused by admission restrictions which sometimes make a mockery of their preference (never a legally enforceable choice). The government must simplify the system.
George Allen
Chelmsford
Essex

Palestinian plight

Michael Bishop eloquently put the case against Israel in its treatment of the Palestinians (Letters, last week), but much of the blame lies with the Americans who have indulged their client's flouting of UN resolutions.

Resolutions 242 and 338 call for land captured in the Six Day War to be restored to previous borders. Instead, Israel colonised much of the occupied land and fobbed off the Palestinians with spongiform areas dotted with 'settlements'.

Palestinians can suffer the subjugation and hope opinion comes to their aid, or revolt and be branded terrorists. They have tried both ways. The latter is more effective.
Harvey Quilliam
Maghull

Tunnel vision

John Prescott should try more than one brief subway ride to get the real picture of the New York system (Business, last week). When Bob Kiley took over the subway, one out of two trains was failing and fires on the line were almost daily. The truth is that improvements in New York have been better, quicker and cheaper than Labour's privatisation plans for the Underground.
Lynne Featherstone
Liberal Democrat transport spokesperson
Greater London Authority

Wild Britain

I manage a wood for the League Against Cruel Sports and I do not recognise the picture of British wildlife implied by your headline 'UK teems with life as species beat extinction' (News, last week).

Subsidy of sheep has led to overgrazing and loss of flora and fauna. Elsewhere, Maff policies have led to loss of wetland, hedge removal and an intensive arable culture based on fertilisers, pesticides and weedkillers.

Most species of bird have suffered: the corn bunting down 74 per cent; bullfinch 62 per cent; skylark 75 per cent; and even the house sparrow down 64 per cent.
John Butter
Barnstaple
Devon

Age concerns

Lynn Barber describes Tracey Emin's father as '80 but totally compos mentis ' (Life, last week). Some people do get dementia in older age, but 80 per cent do not. I hope this will encourage her to seek out subjects who combine their years with a fully functioning brain.
Margaret Edwards
Richmond
Surrey

Twists and turns

As two Serb generals go on trial for the Srebrenica massacre (though General Ratko Mladic remains at large), Henry Porter rightly raises the issue of France's role (Comment, last week). Drawing attention to the secret talks between the French UN commander, General Bernard Janvier, and Mladic, he points out that there is suspicion that the general acted on instructions from France's then Prime Minister, Alain Juppé.

Previously, Juppé accompanied Britain's Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd in talks with the Milosevic government. The French press claimed they offered Serb forces a free hand to take towns in Bosnia. It is not only the French who need to 'come clean'.
Charles Pottins
Wembley
Middx

fields.headline: France turns the tables
fields.standfirst: Le pop culture
fields.trailText: France turns the tables.
fields.body:
As an Arsenal fan with a couple of Elizabeth David cookbooks in my kitchen, I'm no stranger to the idea of French culture overwhelming the native British product. But I'm not sure I can cope with the worldwide success of French pop - musiques actuelles , as it's known across the sleeve. It's everywhere. Daft Punk, Air, Dimitri of Paris, St Germain, Vanessa Paradis, Laurent Garnier: they're up the charts, down the clubs, across the airwaves, on ads, in movies. Time Out called the new Daft Punk album 'the first truly irrefutably great dance album of the 21st century'. Madonna worked with French producer Mirwais. There's been a Made in France week at the Jazz Café, topped off by trumpeter Eric Truffaz, whose band has been seriously and favourably compared to funk-era Miles Davis. Charlie Gillett, radio DJ and doyen of world music, sees St Germain's Tourist album as 'the next Moby'. There's a Serge Gainsbourg tribute act playing les botes de New York and a new English-language biography of the ugly little con , out on 25 May - Sylvie Simmons's Serge Gainsbourg: A Fistful of Gitanes (£12.99, Helter Skelter).

It doesn't seem right, though. French popular music has always been rubbish. That's God's natural law. The French can cook, don't wash, have crises de foie and make pop records of such determined awfulness that their only sales outside France have always had to be subsidised by a little-noticed section of the Treaty of Rome - the Community Regional Artistic Policy. When Truffaut sneered that British cinema was a contradiction in terms, we thought the same of French pop. It was an oxymoron. At best.

So how has this happened? How is France now a world beater not just at football and shoulder-shrugging, but pop music, too? 'Shocking, isn't it?' laughed my Anglo-French friend Paul, who grew up in south London and now lives just east of Paris. 'It's the cut-and-paste culture that's made it possible.'

Sampling, that is. Music that requires neither musical training nor ability, just talent - and which doesn't depend on the listener understanding the lyrics. 'The great problem before was their silly voices. French is a language that just doesn't rock. Cut-and-paste music has broken down national characteristics. It's put the French on an equal footing with the world.' But that doesn't explain why it's happened in France rather than Spain or Italy. 'True. I was in Italy just the other week, driving along, thinking: what a country, great weather, food, architecture. It's perfect. Then I turned on the radio.'

Why France, then? Thierry Jacquet of Virgin France has pointed to the collapse of the home market in the early 90s, 'making professionals understand that the domestic market wasn't sufficient any more'. For the first time, the notoriously insular and self-absorbed French music industry was forced to look to a wider world. To survive, it had to develop international sales. At which point the French government got involved - an inconceivably étrange notion to the Anglo-American music business whose relationship to the state is, to steal a phrase from HL Mencken, that of a dog to a lamppost. Various French ministries and organisations combined to set up music-export offices in major cities around the world and, through them, subsidise tours by artistes . The money goes to venues, promoters and PRs rather than the artistes themselves. Although not a huge amount, in 2000, St Germain played 22 dates around Europe, backed by a subsidy of 30,000FF (£3,000). While, Laurent Garnier's 13 shows were underwritten by 38,000FF of government money.

In London, the French Music Bureau ( en français , Bureau des Musiques Actuelles) is based at the French Institute - come out of the Natural History Museum, cross the road. It's run by Marie-Agnès Beau - 'Call me MAB.' She bought me a glass of red wine and a tranche of gigot d'agneau. 'I was never interested in food till I lived here and missed the food at home,' she said.

She told me about the workshops given by French rap groups that she's organised in British schools. She talked about what she has to spend - £100,000, mostly for the subsidies. 'A little money to everyone so the show happens. Money for the first time, then they don't need it next time.' She explained how the French government has always been determined to promote its culture around the world. 'We are always more concentrated on culture. We are shocked with the importance of money in England. But you know how to make money from culture, from music. We don't.'

Disarmingly, charmingly, she gave some credit for this new pop triomphe to us Brits. 'You were the first to be interested in French DJs and their music. From there it went round the world. And two years later, back to France. Laurent Garnier started his career in the UK. Here, music belongs to youth culture. That's only just starting in France. And, believe it or not, all the French artists refer to the Clash and Asian Dub Foundation. Both had something they wanted to say which is very strong. We French have to say something. We are all big mouths. Especially me.'

So that's the French of today: big-mouthed, internationally successful, cool, even. They've always been le dernier cri of chic, but cool? I asked Paul about this.

'Gallic pride takes it in its stride. They never noticed they had no place in world pop.'
