fields.headline: Letters to the Editor
fields.standfirst: The big issue: Time to talk about racism
fields.trailText: Time to talk about racism.
fields.body:
 Your leader, 'Prejudice has no place in politics' (Comment, last week), needs elaboration.

Our Prime Minister has failed to improve the position of ethnic minorities. The government should create a department for social inclusion to work with the Home Office and other Ministries. As well as social deprivation and exclusion, its remit should cover 'ethnic community affairs', acknowledging that, while anti-discrimination laws are essential, legislation does nothing to remove prejudice. It requires a more joined-up approach to tackle the underlying causes.

The Home Office has generated mistrust among ethnic communities. It is not the department to promote better race relations.
Tara Kumar Mukherjee
Confederation of Indian Organisations (UK)
London

 War did not break out between white and Asian youths in Bradford on Easter Sunday. The people who started the trouble in Lidget Green were not the same group who finished it. Our disturbances have never been in the Premier League of British riots. It is simply that much is distorted because some 20 per cent of us come from a Pakistani Muslim background.

We do have serious problems with some Asian young men and their relationship to drug dealing. Just as we need to see Lidget Green as an incident sparked off by a bout of heavy drinking, so we need to find ways of talking about this problem openly and honestly, in ways that get past superficial accusations of racism or the fear of such accusations. Bradford church leaders know that this can only be done by people coming from transparently anti-racist organisations who are willing to unite with those Muslim leaders who are beginning to overcome traditional reluctance to speak about such problems within their own communities.

While politicians generate more heat than light on matters of ethnicity and culture, we have some honest talking to do in Bradford.
Rev Geoff Reid
The Methodist Church Touchstone Centre
Bradford

 In the emergence of racism as a key theme in the pre-election phoney war, one thing should not surprise us: the direct relationship between political rhetoric and an increase in attacks on asylum seekers.
Andy Gregg
Refugee Education & Training Advisory Service
London

 I am not a Tory but I feel Michael Portillo was right not to sign the Election Campaign Compact. The way the CRE has handled the matter, especially publicising the names of those who refuse to sign, poses a far greater potential danger to the freedoms of Britain.

By adopting the position it has, the CRE is demonstrating the mentality it purports to oppose.
Patrick Powell
Emsworth
Hants

webTitle: Florence to put a price tag on history - 64p

fields.headline: Florence to put a price tag on history - 64p
fields.trailText: Tourists who flock to Florence may soon be charged an admission fee to enter the city.
fields.body:
Tourists who flock to Florence may soon be charged an admission fee to enter the city.

Renaissance palaces and squares make it an open-sky museum meriting a tax on visitors, says the mayor, Leonardo Domenici. Money to maintain such treasures is running out.

Some have condemned the proposal as an attack on the Florentine tradition of sharing its history with the world. 'Certain values have no price,' said Vittorio Sgarbi, an art critic. But others hail the plan as a trailblazer for other cash-strapped Italian cities such as Venice and Rome.

In an open letter to Corriere della Sera , Domenici proposed that a modest supplement should be added to the hotel or restaurant bills of Florence's 11 million annual visitors. 'Cities and places of art must be open spaces, to be lived with no limitations,' he wrote. 'But it is fair that those who come to visit them contribute, even partially, to their upkeep.

'Cities... are submitted to increasing daily pressure. Wear and tear of monuments and works of art is no longer caused just by ravages of time.'

The mayor's spokesman, Enzo Risso, said the fee could be as little as a one-off 2,000 lire (64p) per tourist, regardless of how long they stay. This would help pay for security guards, restorations, lighting and maintenance.

Florence's art superintendent, Antonio Paolucci, and Corriere della Sera backed the proposal. The city's cathedral - with its adjacent Baptistry and the Santa Maria Novella basilica - already levy entrance fees.

Several cities discreetly discriminate against tourists over prices. Venice charges them four times more than locals for ferry rides, double for public lavatories.

Rome wanted to charge an entry fee during its jubilee last year, but the proposal became bogged down in parliament. The mayor of Venice, Paolo Costa, complained that such fees would turn the cities into museums.

The only cities that levy fees, critics point out, are dead ones - such as Pompeii and Herculaneum.

The mayor's spokesman, Enzo Risso, said the fee could be as little as a one-off 2,000 lire (64p) per tourist, regardless of how long they stay. This would help pay for security guards, restorations, lighting and maintenance. Florence's art superintendent, Antonio Paolucci, and Corriere della Sera backed the proposal. The city's cathedral - with its adjacent Baptistry and the Santa Maria Novella basilica - already levy entrance fees. Several cities discreetly discriminate against tourists over prices. Venice charges them four times more than locals for ferry rides, double for public lavatories. Rome wanted to charge an entry fee during its jubilee last year, but the proposal became bogged down in parliament. The mayor of Venice, Paolo Costa, complained that such fees would turn the cities into museums. The only cities that levy fees, critics point out, are dead ones - such as Pompeii and Herculaneum.

webTitle: Agony ends for China's caged bears

fields.headline: Agony ends for China's caged bears
fields.standfirst: Pooh is free. So are 59 others. But 7,000 remain trapped behind bars in barbaric bile trade
fields.trailText: Pooh is free. So are 59 others. But 7,000 remain trapped behind bars in barbaric bile trade.
fields.body:
Pooh has no idea she is making history. A powerful shot of drugs has left the Asiatic black bear flat on her back as she is carried from a tiny cage in one of China's notorious bear farms.

Gail Cochrane, a vet from Irvine near Glasgow, examines the recumbent Pooh and declares her 'a lucky bear'. The term 'lucky' is relative. Pooh, who weighs nearly 17 stone, has just been released from a cage measuring 2ft by 4ft by 2ft 6in. Other, bigger bears have spent more than 20 years in smaller cages, some with crush bars forcing them to spend their lives spreadeagled on the floor. Pooh is among the few bears who will not need surgery to repair their injured bodies.

She is the last of 60 bears released by the charity Animals Asia. Within five years 500 bears will have been set free. The first 60 are part of a pilot scheme in Sichuan province, the biggest habitat of this endangered bear species, also known as moon bears because of the crescents on their chest fur.

Tai Tan is not such a 'lucky bear'. Cochrane had to remove a metal catheter, used by Tai Tan's masters to tap the bile in her gall bladder, allowing it to be milked daily. Cochrane breezes through the operation in a newly refurbished rescue centre at Long Qiao, an hour's drive from Chengdu, capital of Sichuan. Tai Tan has many of the ailments found in these captive bears. Her teeth are all broken from gnawing the bars of her cage and the soles of her paws are covered with cracks. She has not walked for years.

While Cochrane extracts a bloody mess of metal, fat and tissue from the stomach, Beverly Elmer, a veterinary nurse from Suffolk, removes years of plaque from the teeth.

Why have these creatures had to suffer so? Because they are farmed for their bile, an ingredient of Chinese medicine used to cure fevers, liver complaints and sore eyes. And the bile-pumpers have done their job well: there is now an over supply and the surplus is being used in shampoos, anti-wrinkle creams and even wine.

In 1998 Jill Robinson from Nottingham, founder of Animals Asia, took her first tour of bear farms with Cochrane. One of the 'farms' was in a five-storey block of flats. Climbing two flights of stairs, they entered a flat with 32 bears crammed into four rooms.

Some farms were better, but all kept these large wild animals crushed in tiny cages. When bear farming started in the mid-Eighties Chinese farms used primitive surgery to insert the catheter, leading to infections. The severity of the internal problems often killed the bear. Four of the 64 rescued in this pilot scheme never made it to freedom; peritonitis and septicemia took them first.

The Chinese government eventually replaced the use of catheters with a 'free dripping' method which involves drilling a hole in the abdomen and pushing up a thin plastic tube to milk the bladder. Cochrane shakes her head at the idea that this is supposed to be 'more humane'. It is the source of constant inflammation and infection, she says, and exposes the abdomen to the risk of leaking, which can lead to death.

The irony of this maltreatment is that it began with the Chinese government's attempts to conserve the bears. In 1984-85 licences were issued to farm 2,000 bears. The original target was to issue 40,000 licences by the Year 2000. Robinson says grimly: 'If nothing else, our campaign of exposure has worked and at least that hasn't happened.' There are still 7,000 bears in farms according to official figures, and other estimates are higher. The deal worked out between the Chinese government and Animals Asia in July 1999 commits China to phasing out bear farming altogether. Meanwhile, 500 bears will be saved and bear farms are being closed down. The charity pays the farmers compensation - 'quite enough to set up an alternative business,' says Robinson.

Animals Asia's critics say it has been duped by the authorities into allowing the bile trade to continue by providing a humanitarian cover, but Robinson believes China is genuine in wanting to eradicate the farms and that bear farming will end in her lifetime.

Freedom, a young female whose front paws were lost, presumably when she was trapped, is in the enclosure where recovering bears are given their first taste of grass, fresh air and water in a pool. She is rolling around, clasping tuffs of turf in the stumps of her legs. 'It makes you fit to burst,' says Robinson.

Meanwhile, Pooh is now recovering after being released and is waiting for a sponsor. It costs £4,500 to sponsor a bear for life and the donor gets to name the bear.

fields.headline: Torment as life ebbs away
fields.standfirst: As a hunger strike in Turkey's jails claims its twentieth victim, families wait with grief and pride, writes  Chris Morris  in Istanbul
fields.trailText: As a hunger strike in Turkey's jails claims its twentieth victim, families wait with grief and pride, writes  Chris Morris  in Istanbul.
fields.body:
The doctor came into Umus Sahingoz's room in a heavily guarded hospital ward. 'It's a lovely spring day, and your mother's here,' he said. 'We can treat you. Don't you want to live?'

Weak and drifting in and out of consciousness, the 31-year-old woman whispered a reply. 'It is a beautiful day and I'm proud to continue my struggle. Until the politicians listen, we won't stop.'

'She's just a bag of bones,' said Fatma, Sahingoz's mother. 'Every time she closes her eyes I think she's dead.'

Fatma related the story as she sat on a park bench watching children in the playground. Her daughter is about to die - another victim of a hunger strike in the Turkish prison system.

Yesterday it claimed its twentieth life when Fatma Hulya Tumgan, in jail for being a member of the banned Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front, died in hospital after refusing solid food for 187 days.

Hundreds of prisoners from extreme left-wing groups are taking part in the protest, and doctors warn that dozens of them are in a critical condition. A battle of wills between a determined state and fanatical prisoners ready to die for their cause is turning into a tragedy.

Umus has been refusing food for nearly 200 days. Like other prisoners she has been taking sugared water, salt and vitamins. When she loses consciousness, hospital staff pump blood serum into her body. But as soon as she wakes up, she demands the treatment be stopped.

'From time to time we believe there has been force-feeding,' said Dr Osman Ozturk from the Turkish Medical Association. 'But the state has been unable to make it systematic, because it is against medical ethics.'

More than a hundred of the most seriously ill prisoners have been transferred to hospital wards where soldiers guard the doors. Each inmate has a relative who stays with them 24 hours a day. Many families appear to support the struggle.

'This is the choice my daughter has made,' Fatma Sahingoz said calmly. 'I'm a mother and I'm dying with her. But I have to respect her choice. The state should take some steps to allow our children to survive.'

Belatedly, the government has introduced legislation which would ease the regime of isolation in prisons, which is at the heart of the dispute. Human rights groups have already criticised the proposals, which have yet to be approved by parliament, as inadequate.

The hunger strike began in October as a protest against plans to transfer prisoners from dormitory wards into new 'F-type' prisons where inmates are held in small cells, either in solitary confinement or with up to two other people.

Security forces stormed 20 jails in December and transferred about 1,000 inmates to the new prisons. Thirty prisoners and two soldiers were killed in four days of clashes, but the enforced transfers did not end the 'death fast'.

The prisoners have a long list of demands, which the government refuses to discuss. Officials say a return to the dormitory system is out of the question. Under the old regime, inmates ran their own wards and indoctrinated new recruits.

'The state cannot be held hostage by terrorists,' Justice Minister Hikmet Sami Turk has said. He has promised modern prisons which conform to international standards. 'I have a clear conscience,' he said last week, 'and I appeal to the prisoners to give up their meaningless protest.'

The hunger strikers have gained little public sympathy as their protest has intensified. But they seem to feel that they have nothing to lose and among the left-wing groups behind the hunger strike dedication to the cause is undiminished.

Of the 20 people who have died so far, four have been prisoners' relatives and supporters who have joined the protest in private houses in Istanbul and Izmir. Three volunteers died in a shanty house overlooking the Bosphorous. 'I am smiling at death,' wrote Gulsuman Donmez in a letter to her 11-year-old son shortly before she died. 'Only someone who is on hunger strike can know these feelings. I love you and I hope you understand.'

Such extraordinary sentiments arise from a long history of bad blood between the Turkish state and the hardline political Left. In the new prisons inmates say they are isolated and beaten by wardens. Umus Sahingoz has told her mother she has been raped. There is no way to confirm the prisoners' claims, but pressure groups such as Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch have demanded a full inquiry.

The Turkish government should 'take all necessary measures to eradicate torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment', Amnesty said last week. '(It)... must ensure that each individual deprived of their liberty is treated with respect for the inherent dignity of the human person.'

The mounting death toll is doing little for Turkey's battered human rights image, but criticism from European governments has been muted. 'It has been badly handled, but there's no obvious solution,' one diplomat said.

The immediate need is for a short-term deal to end the protest, but neither side seems prepared to compromise. 'Now they're dying one by one,' Fatma said. 'Very soon it will be five by five.'

webTitle: Taliban set to reignite civil war

fields.headline: Taliban set to reignite civil war
fields.trailText: The uneasy quiet in the Afghan civil war is about to end.
fields.body:
The uneasy quiet in the Afghan civil war is about to end. Troops of the Northern Alliance are preparing to resist a Taliban offensive that they believe is imminent.

Last week the alliance's leader, ousted president Burhanuddin Rabbani, sat in his stronghold here, spoke of the coming conflict and urged Pakistan to end its support for the Taliban regime.

He said: 'Preparations are being made for the forthcoming war. The hunger and deaths will continue. We need aid. Those countries that are influencing the fighting in Afghanistan for their own gains only make the problems worse.'

In recent weeks military activity has been building up in the mountains of Badakshan, the province held by the alliance. Its military leader, Ahmed Shah Massud, who recently attracted widespread publicity during a visit to Europe, has met fellow rebel commander General Abdul Rashid Dostum to try to redraw a front line against the expected Taliban offensive.

The Taliban, backed by Pakistan, is pushing north to drive out resistance. The alliance, which controls about 30 per cent of the countryside, is aided from nearby Tajikistan - from where Iranian jets bring in fuel and arms.

When the frail-looking figure of Rabbani arrives at the governor's house, a shabby double-storey building on the outskirts of the city, the guards snap to attention. He emerges from a Jeep and slowly climbs the stairs to the conference room.

These are his wilderness years. He was declared president in 1993 after Mujahideen factions took control of Kabul in April 1992. But the coalition quickly collapsed and, when the Taliban ousted Rabbani's government in September 1996, he escaped to the ethnically distinctive north and to Faizabad, where he was born in 1940.

By Taliban standards, he is a religious moderate. He was elected head of the alliance, or Jamiat-i-Islam, in 1972 and began to organise anti-communist rallies, which eventually led to the war against the Soviet Union.

'He hated the communists,' says Abdul Wahab, a school-friend who remembers Rabbani as an impassioned orator. 'And there is some case for saying that his revolt led to the destruction of the Soviet Union.'

An attempt was made by the Soviet-backed regime to arrest him in 1974, but, aided by students, he escaped - and returned only after the Mujahideen had won the Soviet-Afghan war.

Sitting in the governor's house, Rabbani rebukes Pakistan for its support for the Taliban. 'People call this a civil war,' he says. 'But they have to realise that the fighting in Afghanistan has external factors. Pakistan has made its case clear - it will support the Taliban against us.'

In the UN league table of the world's poorest nations, Afghanistan comes 170 out of 178. But Rabbani does not heap draconian Islamic puritanism on top of poverty.

Soldiers patrol the streets only to monitor any Taliban offensive. In stark contrast to the rest of the country, girls study beside boys in mixed-sex schools.

At the Saeda Makhfi School in Faizabad, 60 teachers, mostly women, teach mathematics, English literature and Arabic to 1,080 students. Men and women are known to date before marriage - although, out of respect for religious customs, the couples hide their romantic liaisons from their parents.

'Girls are naturally better educated here than the boys; they don't have the same distractions,' says Muhammed Qadir, 48, the school's principal. 'You find that most of the educated workforce is composed of women.'

fields.headline: Mugabe police to use gunships
fields.standfirst: Fears that helicopters may be used on opponents
fields.trailText: Fears that helicopters may be used on opponents.
fields.byline: Jason Burke and Andrew Meldrum in Harare
fields.body:
The government of Zimbabwe has secretly converted four helicopter gunships for use in police operations. With tensions running high, the readying of gunships would appear to signal more violence in the near future.

Last week President Robert Mugabe's government issued an unprecedented threat against foreign embassies and aid organisations, and launched a renewed campaign of intimidation of pro-democracy campaigners.

The Mi-35 'Hind' helicopters, which are already equipped with armaments, have been fitted to operate against small groups of scattered targets.

Embassies and aid organisations were increasing security and making plans to pull out personnel yesterday.

Diplomats and aid workers had been warned that they would 'live and meet with the fortunes of the party they would have chosen to support'. More than 32 supporters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) have been killed in state-sponsored political violence in the past year.

The threat came as Mugabe loyalists, particularly the war veterans led by Chenjerai 'Hitler' Hunzvi, began a campaign of violence and extortion directed at factories and businesses in urban areas.

'Our next target will be to deal once and for all with foreign embassies and non-governmental organisations who fund the Movement for Democratic Change,' Hunzvi said.

Mugabe, who is 77, has repeatedly attacked Britain as Zimbabwe's chief overseas enemy and a supporter of the MDC. Virtually all Western donors, with the exception of France, have halted financial aid to the government, citing its oppression, corruption and economic mismanagement. Instead, the aid has gone to civic organisations which support democracy.

John Makumbe, a political scientist, said the threat was part of a wider strategy. 'It is an attack on the foreign funding of any organisation that stands up for democratic rights and human rights in this country,' he said.

Last week Mugabe's war veterans stole 140 tonnes of EU food aid. Police took no action to stop two days of looting of a food warehouse. Harare said that 'humanitarian personnel who allowed themselves to indulge in partisan political work' would not receive government protection 'when they find themselves in trouble'.

 Additional reporting by Brian Johnson-Thomas.

fields.headline: Secret grief of jazz charmer
fields.trailText: A new book reveals the immense power that one woman held over legend Duke Ellington.
fields.body:
He was known for his gregarious charm and liaisons with countless women. But a new book reveals the immense power that one woman held over him. Jazz legend Duke Ellington was so overcome with grief when his mother died that he lay in her bed for two weeks, unable to do anything but weep.

This claim is made in a new biography - dropped by one publisher last year on the eve of its publication after the jazzman's family objected to the revelation that Ruth Ellington, the woman the world knew as his sister, was in fact his daughter.

Austin Lawrence, author of Duke Ellington And His World, to be published in Britain in June, reveals that Ellington's love for his mother Daisy shaped the way he treated his family. Her death from cancer in 1935 plunged him into a deep depression.

Lawrence said that Ellington was unable to cope: 'The day of his mother's death was the saddest of Ellington's life; his first and only true love had died. He was literally paralysed with grief. He felt a part of his life was over.'

Ellington never wore brown again after his mother died, according to his son Mercer, because he'd been wearing it the day she died.

After her death, Ellington was unable to write anything for seven weeks but eventually composed 'Reminiscing in Tempo', a 12-minute testimony to his mother that filled two 78-rpm discs on all four sides and was lambasted by the critics, forcing Ellington to question his career.

'Every page of that particular manuscript was dotted with smears and unshapely marks caused by tears,' said Cootie Williams, trumpeter in the band. 'Except for this piece, in all of Ellington's thousands of works, there was always solo space left for his musicians to improvise and expand on the piece. In this one there was no space; he allowed no deviation.'

fields.headline: LA's second biggest industry
fields.standfirst: Drug rehab is a habit some celebrities just can't kick
fields.trailText: Drug rehab is a habit some celebrities just can't kick, reports Joe Neumaier.
fields.body:
Hollywood is known for its excess. Excessive wages, excessive budgets, excessive awards shows. Now the drug problem that has long bedevilled the entertainment industry is causing concern not just on account of its excess, but for being unstoppable. The result, as Hollywood bible Entertainment Weekly reports, is that 'recovery has practically become LA's second-biggest industry'.

The arrest last week of Robert Downey Jr in a bleak Los Angeles alleyway for suspected drug use, mere days away from his scheduled appearance before a Palm Springs judge for a parole-violating drugs transgression last November, has set off warning bells in the creative community. Actors' careers in jeopardy is only one factor; the other is Hollywood's growing realisation that rehabilitation is now a routine part of life for many of its recidivist users. Kelsey Grammer of Frasier, Friends star Matthew Perry, Courtney Love, Melanie Griffith and Christian Slater have all benefited from rehab.

Centres such as Malibu Promises and the Daniel Freeman Drug Rehab Clinic in Los Angeles and Hazelden in Minnesota are the immediate refuge for fallen stars. The 30-day treatment plans at Malibu Promises begin with detox and then a daily regimen that includes group and individual therapy as well as physical workouts. According to the centre's brochure, treats offered include meals prepared by a gourmet chef.

'I think rehab is just absorbed into the culture,' says Bruce Porter, author of Blow, the non-fiction book about how Hollywood met cocaine, which has been turned into a film starring Johnny Depp and Penelope Cruz. 'The cycle seems to be: you do a little rehab, you go back to work, the rehab didn't take, so you go back to drugs, you do a little more rehab. That's going to be our next story - that rehab doesn't really work.'

In Downey's case, even a 12-month stint in prison didn't work. The actor, whose on-going guest spot on Ally McBeal was reportedly cut short by creator-producer David E. Kelley after the latest incident, was released last August and appeared on magazine covers under headlines like 'Mr. Clean'. For Downey, however, rehab was not the magic cure that many believe it to be.

Neither was it for Aaron Sorkin, the 39-year-old creator of the White House drama The West Wing. After kicking a cocaine addiction five years ago - for which he received an 'award' from the Phoenix House substance abuse recovery centre - Sorkin was arrested on 15 April at Burbank Airport for possession of magic mushrooms and marijuana.

Whether it's cocaine, as with Downey and Sorkin, or painkillers such as Vicodin (Perry's addiction, which earlier this year forced him from the set of his movie Servicing Sarah and away from taping Friends), it appears that the real difficulty is not getting stars to acknowledge they have a problem - after all, drug counsellors are now a common sight on TV and movie sets. The more serious issue is whether stars can ever get out of the spiral of addiction when surrounded by a culture as frenzied as Hollywood's.

'In the creative world, where at the end of a day or at the end of a gig there's this tremendous letdown when the work is done, there's this compulsion to retrieve something of that,' says Porter. 'Cocaine is a drug that's much more geared toward the creative process. You can go for days and have the illusion that you're sharp and everything you say is brilliant and you can maybe produce more, so cocaine is the perfect drug for the entertainment business.'

The town's culture of contrition requires a brief bit of lip-chewing, and the now-obligatory stay in a cushy rehab centre after which the assumption sets in that everything is fine. What this cycle doesn't make room for is the work: lawyers often draft contractual agreements, sometimes including monetary carrots, to keep stars clean. One such case is Charlie Sheen's contract for Spin City, which states that the former addict loses out on bonuses if he relapses into his old ways.

'Downey's problems required him to be recast in this summer's romantic comedy America's Sweethearts, but often on movies there's simply a break in the action for a bit,' says Dade Hayes, who covers the film industry for Variety .

While all aspects of the industry have felt the negative effect of stars' drug problems, the television industry has an inordinate amount of actors and actresses who fall prey to addiction.

'In television, the workload is so much more demanding, so gruelling for months at a time, that drugs may be a way to cope, whereas on a film you lose a little bit of time, but it can be spaced out a bit,' says Hayes. The problem is not always properly addressed, he adds, because producers 'might not want to mess with a good thing, at least not to the extent that it would compromise their earnings.'

Yet if the star's behaviour goes unchecked there are inevitable consequences. 'A star who has a substance abuse problem is a terrorist to all of the people he or she works with,' according to a former producer of Home Improvement, which continued for eight seasons despite star Tim Allen's alcohol problems in the Nineties. 'They are held hostage because the star ultimately determines the course of every day.'

Downey's latest run-in with the law caused David E. Kelley to issue a statement saying: 'We are wrapping up the stories on the final few episodes of Ally McBeal for the season without him.' Actors reportedly had to shoot alternative scenes and some dialogue was changed to accommodate his absence.

'Fifteen years ago, cocaine was romanticised. It's not that way now,' says Porter. 'And yet they still don't know how to treat it. All the rehab centres are basically aimed at heroin users. Which is a problem, but it's only part of the problem.'

'I have found a remarkable degree of tolerance on the part of movie producers,' says Hayes. 'It's like a complete slap in the face to the attitude that Hollywood has taken in public.

'It's interesting - in sports there's a sense of exasperation when an athlete falls repeatedly to drugs. In the entertainment industry, people are more than willing to give abusers second, third, fourth chances.'

But is that ultimately damaging their product? When so much money goes into marketing a film and a star's personal problems upstage the multi-million-dollar product, one would think substance and alcohol abuse would be given a firmer reprimand. According to Porter, it never will, since it's a key part of the culture.

'L.A. is an "up" town,' he says. 'When you go into the restaurants, it looks like everybody's on cocaine. There's a huge energy quotient there, as if everybody's riding a rapid. So cocaine is a natural in this environment, where you have to appear to be constantly juiced all the time to get your ideas across, to achieve the image of buzz, to be "on". You can't keep up like that normally.'

 Joe Neumaier is a New York-based writer covering the entertainment industry

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Gates remains No 1 tycoon
fields.body:
Gates remains No 1 tycoon

Microsoft boss Bill Gates remains the richest man in the world, with his wealth estimated at £37.5 billion. The 'rich list' in last week's Sunday Times wrongly said he had been supplanted by the Wal-Mart chairman S. Robson Walton.

According to People magazine, the wealth the paper attributed to Walton of £45.3bn was an over-estimate - the real figure is closer to £17bn. The 1.7bn Wal-Mart shares owned by founder Sam Walton's widow and their four chilren are evenly divided among them.

People quotes Forbes magazine's most recent calculations, which show Gates's wealth down from the £43.8bn logged for him last year.

Settlers wounded in Gaza

Six Jewish settlers were wounded, some seriously, in a Palestinian mortar attack on Netzer Hazani, a Jewish settlement in the Gaza Strip.

Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres was today due to meet Arab leaders to discuss a proposal to end almost seven months of violence.

15 die in Algerian arrest riots

Fifteen Algerians died and 336 others were injured in riots between Berber demonstrators and riot police in the eastern region of Kabylie.

Six days of clashes began after three teenagers were arrested and beaten by gendarmes after allegedly insulting the security forces.

Tamil Tigers kill hundreds

Tamil Tiger guerrillas claimed victory in Sri Lanka's bloodiest battle in a year and said nearly 500 combatants had been killed before government troops were forced to retreat in the country's north.

The military said earlier its troops pulled back in the face of a counter-attack by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, and put the death toll at 377.

Underground protest

A partial strike on the Paris metro continued yesterday as unions campaigned for higher pay and more jobs.

Royal blow

Bulgaria's highest court confirmed a decision to deny registration to a party formed by King Simeon II. It had hoped to win 35 per cent of the votes in general elections on 17 June.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Happier return | High-risk cover | Call of Corelli
fields.body:
Happier return

Unsure about filling in the income section of your tax return? The Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds has produced a free guide to help you.

Many investors are not aware that the type of investment they hold determines the nature of the information they need to put down. The guide outlines the information you have to provide on income from UK-authorised unit trusts and Oeics (open-ended investment companies). For a copy, phone 020 8207 1361.

High-risk cover

Holidaymakers with pre-existing medical conditions normally find it difficult to get insurance for their travels. Many more do not realise that they are not covered until they have already bought a policy.

Now Bishopscourt Group Insurance Services is covering travellers who have had recent heart attacks, or suffer from cancer or HIV. However, premiums are likely to be substantially higher than with normal policies and will vary depending on the condition. Phone 01227 267 584.

Call of Corelli

The popularity of Captain Corelli's Mandolin has caused a 77 per cent increase in holiday bookings to Cephalonia, the Greek island where the book and film are set. 'Holidaymakers are guaranteed to love it, but they should be wary of a broken heart if they face an accident without adequate travel insurance,' warns Primary Direct.

Check that your policy covers vehicle and motorcycle hire, which are the most popular - and risky - ways to get around Greek islands. Travel insurance does not usually include third party liability cover for the hire of vehicles, so check with the hirer before you take one out, says Primary.

Coping with debt

When you are up to your ears in debt, working out how to repay your creditors and who to pay first can seem impossible.

The Bankruptcy Association has produced a guide on how to settle up with creditors. The booklet, price £9.95, is available from Freepost, 4 Johnson Close, Lancaster LA1 1BR.

Not so foolish

Motley Fool, the humorous financial information website, has published a book on how to prepare for retirement. It is available, price £5.99, by phoning 020 7881 8146.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Chartwell Guaranteed Return Bond
fields.trailText: Chartwell Guaranteed Return Bond.
fields.body:
Contact 01225 446556

Aim To pay income fixed at 6.52 per cent gross for five years plus guaranteed return of capital.

Bells & whistles Chartwell has rebated some of the commission on sales of the bond to enhance income paid to investors. This means the rate is 'higher than any comparable building society or guaranteed income bond available at the moment'. As a comparison, the top five-year building society account pays 6.10 per cent on £5,000 and above and 6.15 per cent on £50,000 and above.

How it works This is an offshore bond, based in Jersey and managed by London Pacific Assurance, a subsidiary of the London Pacific Group, which has £4.9 billion under management. Investors can have income paid annually at 6.52 per cent, quarterly at 6.38 per cent, monthly at 6.35 per cent or rolled up as growth of 36.49 per cent over the whole five years. A basic-rate taxpayer will receive 5.09 per cent net (annual), 4.98 per cent net (quarterly), 4.95 per cent net (monthly) and 28.46 per cent net (growth). Bond rates change constantly, but Chartwell believes it can offer these rates for at least another week. Jersey offers no statutory compensation scheme, but as part of London Pacific's permit in Jersey, it is required to ensure that assets equal to not less than 90 per cent of policyholder liabilities are placed in the hands of an approved independent custodian. These assets cannot be used to satisfy other creditors of London Pacific. This means, it says, that the assets lodged with custodian Kleinwort Benson can only be used to satisfy policyholder liabilities.

Minimum £5,000.

Charges Built into the guaranteed return.

Tax Income is paid gross, and non-taxpayers have no tax to pay when bringing the income onshore. Taxpayers will be liable to pay tax at their appropriate rate.

Risk Low

Should you invest? Chris Wicks of Glossop adviser Bridgewater Financial Planning says the rates offered are far better than those on all other bonds available at the moment. However, he had not heard of London Pacific before and would want to find out more about it before recommending it to clients, particularly as the investment is based offshore.

Colin Jackson of Ilford adviser Baronworth says the bond is ideal for non-taxpayers. But although assets are lodged with an independent custodian, Jackson says he would rather bondholders had straightforward statutory protection.

Points out of 10 Wicks - 5, Jackson - 5.

webTitle: Money writes: E111 was not what 'dottore' ordered

fields.headline: E111 was not what 'dottore' ordered
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I believe there is widespread avoidance of the European agreement to accept form E111 for emergency medical treatment.

When I was in Italy, a local hospital said E111 forms were invalid unless they showed the current year. My E111 is dated 1983, so, back home, I tried to renew it at my post office. I was told I could do this only if I had lost the original because a fee is paid to the Post Office for each one issued.
DM, London

The UK is the only European country that issues E111 certificates that do not expire, so it is easy to see why doctors elsewhere believe they are out of date. The Post Office now says it will process every application form, even if you already have a valid certificate.

The Department of Health decides on any restrictions. It is aware of the problem and is happy for you to request a new form each year. There is no charge.

Anyone who has to pay for medical treatment because a European country refused a valid E111 certificate can claim a refund when they return home. Send a copy of your certificate to: DSS Benefits Agency, Pension and Overseas Benefits Directorate (Med), Tyneview Park, Whitley Road, Newcastle NE98 1BA. The agency will try to recoup the cost from the other country and, if successful, will reimburse you.

Foreign affairs: Taxman's interest

My mother lives in the US and has savings here. The interest is paid into a UK bank and transferred to her American bank. The UK bank recently wrote saying that because of legislative changes, from April, banks must report to the Inland Revenue details of interest received by non-resident customers whose countries of residence are 'fully reportable'. I can find no details of this.
SK, Newtownabbey

This is part of the existing double taxation agreements that is not fully off the ground. UK banks are now required to tell the Inland Revenue about all interest they pay to what are vaguely called 'other authorities' - in your mother's case to non-residents' US bank accounts. The Inland Revenue is prepared to share this information with the American tax service to cut down on crime, but only if the Americans reciprocate.

Negotiations are continuing, but the Americans have not yet agreed to co-operate. Until they do, your mother's information sits on Revenue files and goes no further.

Pension top-ups: Added years

I pay £100 a month into an AVC, the Guardian Choices Top-Up plan. I am about to double my contribution, but a colleague suggested that buying past added years from Teachers Pension was a better bet.
AB, Broadway

If you intend teaching until retirement and expect to earn above-inflation pay increases, buying added years is the better option.

If you earn less than £30,000 a year, it is probably cheaper to buy a stakeholder pension than to up your AVCs, but you cannot have an occupational and a stakeholder pension if you earn more (unless you have freelance earnings). Your AVC is now in the hands of Aegon. You should see a financial adviser, because the right answer depends on your individual circumstances.

Writeback: British Gas service contracts

Several readers report that they do not get a British Gas annual service every 12 months. When RM of Budleigh Salterton complained the service was overdue, British Gas said the contract allowed for inspections at any time during the year: 'Since 1995 the gap between services has increased. At this rate, it will be only a matter of time before I've paid for an annual service I've not received.'

CH of Poundbury complained in January that a visit due last November was late and was told he had been scheduled for April. On his insistence, the boiler was serviced in February. He was told the next service would be in October 2002, but he could phone for an 'extra' service in the contract year to November 2001.

British Gas admits dates have been out of synch. It says engineers try to carry out the service as close to the anniversary as possible, but between October and April, repairs take priority over servicing. They catch up on service visits in the summer.

fields.bodyText: I believe there is widespread avoidance of the European agreement to accept form E111 for emergency medical treatment. When I was in Italy, a local hospital said E111 forms were invalid unless they showed the current year. My E111 is dated 1983, so, back home, I tried to renew it at my post office. I was told I could do this only if I had lost the original because a fee is paid to the Post Office for each one issued. DM, London The UK is the only European country that issues E111 certificates that do not expire, so it is easy to see why doctors elsewhere believe they are out of date. The Post Office now says it will process every application form, even if you already have a valid certificate. The Department of Health decides on any restrictions. It is aware of the problem and is happy for you to request a new form each year. There is no charge. Anyone who has to pay for medical treatment because a European country refused a valid E111 certificate can claim a refund when they return home. Send a copy of your certificate to: DSS Benefits Agency, Pension and Overseas Benefits Directorate (Med), Tyneview Park, Whitley Road, Newcastle NE98 1BA. The agency will try to recoup the cost from the other country and, if successful, will reimburse you. Foreign affairs: Taxman's interest My mother lives in the US and has savings here. The interest is paid into a UK bank and transferred to her American bank. The UK bank recently wrote saying that because of legislative changes, from April, banks must report to the Inland Revenue details of interest received by non-resident customers whose countries of residence are 'fully reportable'. I can find no details of this. SK, Newtownabbey This is part of the existing double taxation agreements that is not fully off the ground. UK banks are now required to tell the Inland Revenue about all interest they pay to what are vaguely called 'other authorities' - in your mother's case to non-residents' US bank accounts. The Inland Revenue is prepared to share this information with the American tax service to cut down on crime, but only if the Americans reciprocate. Negotiations are continuing, but the Americans have not yet agreed to co-operate. Until they do, your mother's information sits on Revenue files and goes no further. I am about to double my contribution, but a colleague suggested that buying past added years from Teachers Pension was a better bet. webTitle: Wealthcheck: Nursing my finances back to health

fields.headline: Nursing my finances back to health
fields.standfirst: Jenny's pension, endowment and savings are all in need of some help, she tells Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Jenny's pension, endowment and savings are all in need of some help, she tells Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Jenny Warner
Age: 40
Lives in: South London
Occupation: Nurse
Earns: £13,000
Mortgage: £67,000
Debts: None
Investments: Isas, investment trust savings plan, instant access account
Pension: Occupational pension plus AVCs
Aims: To maximise the money she has available, boost her pension and provide some financial security for her children

Both Jenny Warner and her partner Dominic had rural childhoods. Hers was in 'deepest Northamptonshire'. His was in Ireland. They would like their two daughters, Bronte, aged three, and Maille, aged 20 months, to have a similar upbringing. So they have decided to sell their house in London and move to the south coast.

'We thought we had better make our escape now before Bronte started school,' explains Jenny.

They are looking for a property around Southampton or Southsea where they will be able to get more for their money than in London. Dominic has found a job in the area and his new employer is paying the relocation costs.

They would like to remortgage at the same time but are locked in with their current lender by a hefty redemption penalty. Nevertheless their lender, Alliance & Leicester, has agreed to them switching to a flexible mortgage without penalty, and Jenny hopes they will eventually be able to start paying off chunks of their loan early.

Their current repayment method is an Allied Dunbar endowment but they have been told it will probably not pay off the loan in full. She wonders how best to proceed with the endowment.

The one downside of their move is that Jenny will have to give up her well-paid part-time nursing job organising organ transplants. Although she does not envisage having too many problems finding a new job, she doubts she will earn as much and it may take several months to organise. During the intervening period, they expect to have to dip into their £8,000 savings, in a Northern Rock instant access account.

Another consequence will be a further gap in her pension contributions. Her pension is one of her prime concerns - and regrets. She admits: 'I rather naively opted out of the NHS pension scheme in my earlier twenties. I didn't see any harm at the time as I was intending to go abroad to work.' She rejoined about seven years ago and converted the private pension she had begun into a free-standing AVC scheme. However, the arrival of children meant her pension contributions went down again when she started working part-time.

Still, she and Dominic have invested about £18,000 in Isas linked to funds such as Norwich Union European, Henderson Global Technology and Fidelity's UK Aggressive.

They are contributing a further £100 a month to a Gartmore Isa and Jenny has started an investment trust savings plan for £20 a month with Edinburgh Fund Managers. These investments are mainly intended for the future financial security of the children. She realises she has chosen high-risk funds but feels that over the next 15 years they will come good.

Although she is concerned about her children's financial security, she admits she is unsure how much life cover she and Dominic have apart from the cover Dominic gets with his pension scheme.

Adviser 1:Sharon Linnard

The penalty-free switch to Alliance & Leicester's flexible mortgage is useful for the short term, but it would be worth checking alternative offers when penalties cease to apply.

Early surrender of endowments offers poor value, and there is no second-hand market for unit-linked contracts, such as that with Allied Dunbar.

It may be worth simply discontinuing premiums and accepting a lower policy value with the mortgage split, part endowment/part repayment. Penalties on surrender or premium cessation need to be explored.

Turning to Jenny's pension concerns, the new stakeholder pension rules mean that she could continue contributing up to £300 a month gross to a pension while she is between jobs. When she starts work again, a stakeholder pension can be maintained alongside any occupational scheme, providing she does not earn over £30,000 a year.

As Jenny says, their Isa savings are in relatively high-risk funds. The recovery of technology funds could take a considerable time but, in the event of a partial recovery, perhaps at least a proportion of the holding could be switched to a different sector.

For peace of mind, the couple should consider taking out a term assurance policy: it may be possible to purchase death cover of £100,000 each over a 15-year term for no more than £23 a month.

Sharon Linnard works for chartered accountants KPMG.

Adviser 2: Dan Kemp

It is important that Jenny look at whether she is making the best use of her additional pension contributions. One option open to members of the NHS pension scheme is to buy added years of service. A new option is the advent of stakeholder pensions. The charges on these schemes are likely to be lower than on Jenny's FSAVC policy.

Regarding the endowment, Jenny should not be panicked into making a decision too quickly. Most old endowments make the majority of their charges in the first few years. You only really get full value if you continue investing until maturity. As Jenny has other savings, it is likely that these will be more than sufficient to cover any shortfall.

This touches on a key issue: I would want to encourage Jenny to be more selfish with her savings. At present these are mostly focused toward providing financial security for her children. However, the money she has invested in Isas could make a huge difference to her retirement and that should be her priority, with the surplus going to her children.

Jenny has clearly taken an adventurous approach to her investment, which has not done her any favours over the past year; however it should prove successful over the long term. My only concern is the lack of balance. It is important to include both higher- and lower-risk funds in any portfolio.

Dan Kemp works for financial advisers Holden Meehan.

 Advice is for guidance only. Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

fields.headline: How not listening to your man can make you a mint
fields.standfirst: It was a row with my wife that got us writing, Body Language author Allan Pease tells Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: It was a row with my wife that got us writing, Body Language author Allan Pease tells Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Allan Pease first became rich and famous at the age of 24, when he wrote Body Language, a book aimed at marketing and sales people who wanted to understand their customers' responses better. It went on to sell 4 million copies in 33 languages.

Now, 25 years later, he and his wife Barbara are having a similar success - with Why Men Don't Listen & Women Can't Read Maps (Orion, £7.99).

In two years, it has sold three million copies in 26 languages - and it is about to be published for readers in Romania and Afghanistan.

Tackling a similar subject to John Gray's Mars and Venus books, Why Men Don't Listen is rooted more in behavioural science, says Allan.

But the book might never have been written at all if the couple had not lost money as a result of unsatisfactory advice from professional advisers five years ago.

The Peases, who were then living in semi-retirement, were left with very little apart from each other. 'We had to watch every single penny,' says Allan, who is now 49.

But they were quite capable of living frugally. Both come from poor families on housing estates in small towns. They are both vegetarian, non-smokers, non-drinkers and not great spenders.

They then started thinking of ways to bring in money again - and this lead to more books - on communications, the difference between the sexes and the art of persuasion.

Why Men Don't Listen... gives all sorts of insights into male and female differences - why men do not like getting advice, for instance, why only 1 per cent of international air pilots are female, why women are more tuned into sympathy and empathy than men, and 300 pages of ideas.

The inspiration for the book came when Barbara hit Allan over the head with a map while they were having the classic marital driving and navigation row in Italy. They then started to document the spark points for male-female conflict.

In their own marriage, they are very conscious of the gender differences. On money, for instance, Barbara - a 38-year-old who had planned to become an accountant but became a model instead - watches their finances day to day and brings Allan in when they both need to take a view of the bigger picture. 'Most men are not particularly good at the fine detail. If she ever leaves me, I'll be buggered,' he says with a big laugh.

But men are also happier at taking risks, he says: 'The whole evolution of men is based on taking risks - going over the horizon to face the unknown.'

However, they are not planning to take too many risks with their money now. 'Last year we bought into shares,' says Barbara. 'But this year we are going to sit tight on the shares we have.'

They own three large houses in England and Australia, and are going to cut back on the huge amounts of work they have put in during the past few years.

'We are going to start yoga and meditation,' he says. Barbara adds: 'We'll walk the dog and ride the horses and go for lots of beach walking at our new house in Australia.

webTitle: BT rips up key plan for UK network

fields.headline: BT rips up key plan for UK network
fields.trailText: A central part of BT's massive restructuring programme - seen by chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield as vital to restoring the company's flagging fortunes - has been dropped, throwing the whole scheme into turmoil.
fields.body:
A central part of BT's massive restructuring programme - seen by chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield as vital to restoring the company's flagging fortunes - has been dropped, throwing the whole scheme into turmoil.

Insiders say the company has ripped up its original blueprint to create a separate company, NetCo, which was to have run BT's UK network. The move was seen as playing a crucial role in the future shape of BT and was viewed as the most radical part of the restructuring.

The serious problems surrounding NetCo will raise further doubts over the company's direction as BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland prepares to take the chair at BT on Tuesday.

Bland has already hinted that he is prepared to re-examine BT's move to divide itself into five separate divisions - a plan described by Bonfield as 'no less dramatic' than the company's privatisation in 1984'.

When Bland was asked whether the telecoms downturn meant BT's restructuring plans might require a fresh examination, he said: 'It's something you keep under continuous review.'

And, with an apparent nod in the direction of the City, which is pressing for a more radical scheme in return for stumping up for an impending £5 billion rights issue, Bland said: 'I come with a fresh and uncluttered perspective, so there isn't anything that's unthinkable.'

The reconsideration of NetCo is another setback for cash-strapped BT. At one stage last year, it was mooted that BT would look to float up to 25 per cent of the company. BT also contemplated loading NetCo with debt to try to reduce its own £30bn debt mountain.

Insiders say the old NetCo plan has been abandoned because BT has been unable to decide on the structure of the company. 'It's back to the drawing board for NetCo. They can't see how they can go forward with the old plan,' one source familiar with the situation said.

There has been confusion as to whether NetCo - which would have leased network capacity to telecoms firms - should have included BT's DSL division, whose technology turns conventional telephone lines into high-speed data carriers.

Some in BT favoured lumping in part of its branded retail arm. At one stage there were plans to include parts of Ignite, its broadband arm. However, BT now intends to inject large parts of Ignite into Concert, its overseas division focused on corporate clients, and sell the revamped firm to joint partner AT&T.

Finance director Philip Hampton is now likely to be charged with coming up with a new range of options for the future of BT's core network.

fields.headline: The American crocodile that swallowed freedom
fields.trailText: Appeasement, Winston Churchill said, is the policy of being nice to a crocodile in the hope that he will eat you last. Allow me to introduce a leading contemporary crocodile. It is called the Recording Industry Association of America, the trade body that represents the music recording companies.
fields.body:
Appeasement, Winston Churchill said, is the policy of being nice to a crocodile in the hope that he will eat you last. Allow me to introduce a leading contemporary crocodile. It is called the Recording Industry Association of America, the trade body that represents the music recording companies.

The RIAA is obsessed with the supposed threat of the internet to its members' prosperity. It is prepared to go to unbelievable lengths to stamp out that threat. Readers of this column will be aware that the RIAA is suing a US magazine for publishing the code of a small computer program called DeCSS that unscrambles DVD files so that Linux users can play their own disks. What is perhaps less well known is that a company that prints the DeCSS code on a T-shirt is also being sued.

The reason the crocodile is able to get away with this is because it has been endlessly appeased by legislatures worldwide. The US Congress has twice rolled over when faced with the lobbying muscle of the RIAA. Its first act of appeasement was the granting of a ludicrous extension of the period during which works enjoy copyright protection. But the coup de grace came when the RIAA persuaded the supine US legislature to pass the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) - aka the Copyright Lawyers Lifetime Employment Act - which, among other things, makes it a crime even to speculate in public about technical measures to circumvent copy protection schemes.

Having screwed Congress, the RIAA turned its attention to the European Union and successfully lobbied its Parliament into promoting the European Copyright Directive. This will embed the key provisions of the DMCA in the law of every EU country within 18 months. This is no longer just an American problem.

It gets worse. The RIAA's ideas for embedding anti-copying technology in the next generation of hard drives has been warmly received by the consortium of companies that make these devices. CPRM (Content Protection for Recordable Media) is a system for enforcing copy protection on personal computers. The basic idea is to enforce digital rights management - copy-prevention, limited use, whatever - in electronic media. If this nonsense isn't stopped, the days when you could do what you please with your own hard disk are numbered.

Then there's the RIAA's own technology venture - the Secure Digital Music Initiative (SDMI) - which has developed ways of embedding hidden 'watermarks' in music files. So confident was the industry that it issued a public challenge to researchers to see if they could remove the watermarks without degrading the audio quality of marked recordings.

The challenge was taken up. Edward Felten and his fellow computer scientists at Princeton found that they could easily remove them. But when it was announced that they would publish their research findings at a computer conference last Thursday, the RIAA went apeshit and threatened legal action to stop publication. Threats were made against the authors, the conference organisers, and their employers. In the end, Professor Felten backed down. 'Litigation is costly, time-consuming, and uncertain,' he said, 'regardless of the merits of the other side's case. Ultimately we reached a collective decision not to expose ourselves, our employers, and the conference organisers to litigation at this time.'

It's a Grade A scandal. A powerful, paranoid industry is claiming the right not only to censor what people publish in magazines or on T-shirts but to determine what scientists investigate and even what they will be allowed to publish. Sooner or later, free societies are going to have to rein in the pretensions and power of the RIAA. This crocodile must be stopped. Now.

The RIAA's ideas for embedding anti-copying technology in the next generation of hard drives has been warmly received by the consortium of companies that make these devices. CPRM (Content Protection for Recordable Media) is a system for enforcing copy protection on personal computers. The basic idea is to enforce digital rights management - copy-prevention, limited use, whatever - in electronic media. If this nonsense isn't stopped, the days when you could do what you please with your own hard disk are numbered. Then there's the RIAA's own technology venture - the Secure Digital Music Initiative (SDMI) - which has developed ways of embedding hidden 'watermarks' in music files. So confident was the industry that it issued a public challenge to researchers to see if they could remove the watermarks without degrading the audio quality of marked recordings. The challenge was taken up. Edward Felten and his fellow computer scientists at Princeton found that they could easily remove them. But when it was announced that they would publish their research findings at a computer conference last Thursday, the RIAA went apeshit and threatened legal action to stop publication. Threats were made against the authors, the conference organisers, and their employers. In the end, Professor Felten backed down. 'Litigation is costly, time-consuming, and uncertain,' he said, 'regardless of the merits of the other side's case. Ultimately we reached a collective decision not to expose ourselves, our employers, and the conference organisers to litigation at this time.' It's a Grade A scandal. A powerful, paranoid industry is claiming the right not only to censor what people publish in magazines or on T-shirts but to determine what scientists investigate and even what they will be allowed to publish. Sooner or later, free societies are going to have to rein in the pretensions and power of the RIAA. This crocodile must be stopped. Now. john.naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Co-op scandal to explode again
fields.standfirst:
• Leading City names face subpoenas
 Regan aims to expose top bankers and lawyers
fields.trailText:
• Leading City names face subpoenas
 Regan aims to expose top bankers and lawyers
fields.body:
The scandal over the £1.3 billion bid for the Co-operative Wholesale Society by entrepreneur Andrew Regan in 1997, which collapsed in criminal charges, is set to blow up again in the City.

Regan's lawyers plan to subpoena prominent City figures and institutions to try to prove that their client is innocent of stealing £2.4m because he took the advice of the best financial brains.

The process began last week, when letters arrived at the offices of investment banks, accountants, corporate lawyers and regulators, requesting detailed information about a 1995 deal between Hobson Holdings, a firm headed by Regan, and the Co-op. That deal forms the basis of the theft charges.

Further letters are expected to go out from Regan's lawyers, Burton Copeland, this week. Among those being asked for information is Michael Foot, now in charge of banking regulation at the Financial Services Authority. At the time of the Co-op bid, he worked for the Bank of England. Also on the list are senior executives of Hambros Bank, which advised Regan. The bank was severely criticised for its conduct.

The best known invest ment banker being asked to help is Brian Keelan, then a corporate finance adviser at UBS. His shrewdly aggressive tactics were generally credited with having halted Regan's bid.

Others include Tim Shacklock, then a senior corporate financier at Kleinwort Benson; the law firms Herbert Smith and Travis Smith Braithwaite; and accountant KPMG. All acted for parties in the 1995 or 1997 deals.

The letters, some of which have been seen by The Observer, also request details of the employment records of Robert Bonnier, then a trader at UBS, and now head of online directory Scoot.

Regan's lawyer Ian Burton said yesterday: 'It will be necessary for us to explore the dynamics of what was happening in 1997, as we believe this has a decisive bearing on the events of 1995. Initially, we are seeking assistance on a voluntary basis, but if this is not forthcoming, we will issue witness summonses.'

webTitle: Britain braced for flood of company profit warnings

fields.headline: Britain braced for flood of company profit warnings
fields.trailText: A huge squeeze on the profits of corporate Britain is piling on pressure for further interest rate cuts.
fields.body:
A huge squeeze on the profits of corporate Britain is piling on pressure for further interest rate cuts.

Profit warnings from UK quoted companies were up by 77% in the first quarter of this year, according to an Ernst & Young analysis to be released tomorrow.

Another report, from the credit checking company Experian, will show that the UK is in its longest period of declining profits since the last recession.

This follows figures showing that UK growth stumbled to a two-year low during the first quarter of this year.

A rate cut by the Bank of England next week is becoming increasingly likely, say City analysts.

Experian's study of the profitability of British towns and cities will show the number of 'loss-making' towns - where firms' total losses exceed profits - increased by 62% over last year. Worthing again emerges as the most profitable. Workington, in Cumbria, is the highest lossmaker.

'There's an across-the-board decline in company profits,' said Experian's Peter Brooker. 'All sizes of companies are suffering.'

Overall, the nation's average profit margin fell from 6.23% in 1999 to 5.96% in 2000. The average proportion of loss-making companies rose from 30 to 32% last year.

Brooker said the strong pound had hit profits and margins. He added: 'Rising employers' costs have also helped to depress profits and this has hit small and medium-sized companies disproportionately.'

Experian's quarterly eco nomic health check of the UK's 2,000 largest companies will show the return on capital falling by 15% year on year - also the sixth successive quarterly fall. Average return on capital, a key measure of corporate profitability, will be 11.18% in the last quarter of last year, compared with 14.18% at the beginning of 1999.

Ernst & Young's analysis will show the highest number of profit warnings for more than three years. It expects the situation to deteriorate further in the next quarter.

fields.headline: Cushnie sues over £12m 'theft'
fields.trailText: Carl Cushnie, the founder of collapsed trade finance house Versailles, is suing his former finance director over the alleged theft of £12m from Cushnie's private investment company.
fields.body:
Carl Cushnie, the founder of collapsed trade finance house Versailles, is suing his former finance director over the alleged theft of £12m from Cushnie's private investment company.

The action comes as the Serious Fraud Office is preparing criminal charges over Versailles' spectacular £630m crash last year.

Frederick Clough, Versailles' ex-finance director, is already being sued for £50m by the group's administrators for alleged fraud over the siphoning of funds offshore. Cushnie, once Britain's highest-flying black businessman, is assisting the SFO and says he had no knowledge of the fraud.

According to recently filed accounts, Cushnie's private company, Marrlist, suffered a £12.8m loss last year following the alleged 'misappropriation of assets' by Clough. A High Court writ has now been issued to recover the money.

Clough left Marrlist in February 2000. He was paid a massive £1.9m by Cushnie for the year. This weekend Clough's solicitor declined to comment on the case.

fields.headline: Cammell woos Moulton
fields.trailText: Directors of shipbuilder Cammell Laird are planning to meet Jon Moulton, head of venture capital firm Alchemy Partners, to discuss buying the company out of receivership.
fields.body:
Directors of shipbuilder Cammell Laird are planning to meet Jon Moulton, head of venture capital firm Alchemy Partners, to discuss buying the company out of receivership.

Cammell directors, including Brett Martin, Jon Schofield, and chairman Juan Kelly, have also been in discussions with ship repairer A&P for some weeks about merging the two businesses, and are constructing a deal with possible backing from Alchemy.They have also had approaches from other venture funds.

Moulton believes Cammell Laird can return to the profitability it enjoyed less than a year ago, before it was hit by the failure of two major contracts, and that some of its former management team are capable of steering it back to health. He is considering whether to back the buyout.

His involvement will cause unease among unions, who are opposed to Alchemy involvement following its failed attempt to buy Rover last year. However, Moulton does not see Cammell as an asset-stripping opportunity. He would not close the Birkenhead yard, although the outlook for the 1,000-odd jobs there would be uncertain.

Alchemy, and receivers PricewaterhouseCoopers, have also been approached by shipping entrepreneur Jonathan Palmer, a former chief executive with Norwegian firm Ugland, who is interested in Cammell. Palmer is believed to have invested heavily in Cammell bonds, which were trading at a hefty discount to issue price when the company went into receivership.

Palmer and A&P are among a wide range of parties who have contacted receivers, but were the only two to have visited Birkenhead by the end of last week.

Cammell directors believe a merger with A&P would create chances for efficiencies.

Cammell has two main UK yards, at Birkenhead on the Mersey and at Hebburn on the Tyne, while A&P has one at Falmouth, Cornwall, and another on the Tyne. The likeliest outcome would be for one of the Tyneside yards to close.

Unions are also opposed to the A&P proposals, which are likely to see the Cammell Hebburn yard close. The GMB union would strongly oppose any closures.

Moulton is, however, concerned that Cammell Laird's order book is threadbare.

webTitle: In my view: New Labour's poor show

fields.headline: New Labour's poor show
fields.trailText: When it was suggested some years ago that a new Labour government would need two terms to achieve anything substantial, few people had any idea that Labour would devote so much of its first term to establishing a reputation for prudence.
fields.body:
When it was suggested some years ago that a new Labour government would need two terms to achieve anything substantial, few people had any idea that Labour would devote so much of its first term to establishing a reputation for prudence.

The consequence is that an awful lot of weight is going to be put on what is widely expected to be the second Labour term - a term to which they are likely to be re-elected, in many cases, by voters with a very heavy heart who have seen what can happen across the water when disillusionment with the Democrats allowed the Republicans to steal victory.

In reviewing Lord Saatchi's recent thoughts about cutting the tax burden a lot further, Professor Niall Ferguson suggested that perhaps there had been a real shift in the electorate's bias towards improvements in public services and away from tax cuts.

Yet the official statistics bear out the anecdotal evidence that public spending growth has been slower in Labour's first term than under the Conservatives.

Ironically, the big growth promised from now on is provoking mounting charges from the Opposition that, at just the moment when the 'prudence' point is regarded as proven, such growth may not prove to be affordable after all.

In the long run it is certainly true that public spending cannot grow faster than the economy as a whole without putting a savage squeeze on consumer spending. But the important contribution of Keynesian analysis was to point out that in the short run it does not make sense to cut back public spending when the rest of the economy is in trouble. Such cuts only magnify the problem.

The interesting point about the British economy at present is that, at least until recently, domestic demand has been buoyant, so it was quite possible to have legitimate concerns about the timing of the Chancellor's great public sector expansion plans.

But the daily news of redundancies in the UK being declared by US multinationals shows that the US slowdown is beginning to bite. And the Confederation of British Industry's latest quarterly industrial trends survey also bears out the fears of the 'doves' on the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee about the impact of the world scene on the UK. The high exchange rate, too, is beginning to hit us hard.

Thus it may well turn out that the planned acceleration in the growth of public spending is needed not only for the obvious reason that most people think we live in a Galbraithian world of 'public squalor', but also to offset weakness in the economy elsewhere.

It all raises the basic question of what the Labour Party is for? Way back in 1961, in a book that made a great splash at the time, The Stagnant Society, Michael Shanks argued: 'There is a strong case for a radical party making a deliberate effort to increase public spending as opposed to private spending in the economy - if only because a Conservative administration has a natural bias the other way. The relative importance of public and private spending constitutes a natural dividing line between left- and right-wing parties in a modern affluent society.'

Of course, this is a country which, for all its reputation for pragmatism, tends to lurch from one extreme to the other. The Labour Party spent a lot of time recovering from an excessive bias towards public spending in the Sixties and Seventies. When you think of the oil crises and the inflationary problems that were added to the excessive public spending of the mid-Seventies, it is remarkable that the Callaghan government of 1976-79 survived as long as it did. History is likely to look a lot more kindly on the prime ministers of the Seventies than many commentators did at the time.

The sad death of George Bull, director of the Anglo-Japanese Economic Institute, reminded me of an interview Bull conducted with Margaret Thatcher in the Eighties, in which he extracted the admission that one of her aims was to transform the British political battleground into one resembling that of Republicans and Democrats - in other words, to abolish the Labour Party altogether.

'New Labour' was an attempt, I think, to produce an electable left-of-centre party, not to offer something subject to approval by the Daily Mail. A new book, Public Policy For the 21st Century ' (edited by Neil Fraser and John Hills, The Policy Press) contains an interesting account of how Labour developed its economic policies during the Eighties, a reminder that New Labour did not begin with Tony Blair.

In it, Neil Kinnock is quoted by Mark Wickham-Jones as saying to an adviser in July 1986: 'No one has yet unveiled a system for spending money that you don't know you are going to have or can reasonably expect.'

Kinnock was well ahead of the field in the prudence game, but I should not be surprised if he thought it had been overdone, particularly with regard to public sector investment, or the lack of it, until recently.

Quite apart from public squalor, the issue that concerns most people with a vestige of left-wing ideology is that of poverty and the distribution of income. Hills, of the London School of Economics, one of the leading experts in this field, emphasises the long gap between the announcement and the implementation of Labour measures to improve the lot of the poor. Thus some of the measures to alleviate poverty will not have their full effect until what is expected to be Labour's second term.

Hills concludes that 'it is too early to judge whether New Labour's strategy for tackling poverty and inequality is a success' and hints that it could fail 'if taxation is thought of by politicians and the public simply as a "burden", and if the positive results of what it finances are left unconnected'.

Even as I write, there is speculation that Blair will renew his pledges not to raise the basic or top rates of income tax...
