webTitle: Insurers in bid to defuse anger over endowments

fields.headline: Insurers in bid to defuse anger over endowments
fields.trailText: The Association of British Insurers is to try to calm the furore over endowment mortgages by drawing up a new code of practice.
fields.body:
The Association of British Insurers is to try to calm the furore over endowment mortgages by drawing up a new code of practice.

According to some estimates, up to 6m of the 10m mortgage endowments held by UK homeowners are not on target to pay off the mortgages they cover. Most endowment holders will have to make up the difference, which may run to tens of thousands of pounds.

The ABI's code, which takes effect from July and will be followed by all ABI members, is designed to make sure policyholders are kept up to speed on how their endowment is performing so that they can take action.

The Financial Ombudsman Service now fields up to 400,000 calls a year from people who believe they were mis-sold an endowment. It handled 9,300 complaints in the year to March 2001, more than three times the previous year's total. It expects the complaints to peak next year at 13,000 cases.

The problem arose because endowments' performance is forecast assuming future interest rates - which may change. 'We want to let people know the endowments may not perform in plenty of time,' says an ABI official.

The code was inspired by the reprojection letters sent to consumers in the past year since the Financial Services Authority and the ABI first realised there was a problem. The letters are colour-coded red, amber and green according to the severity of the shortfall risk.

webTitle: Scottish Power plots $3bn bid for US energy giant

fields.headline: Scottish Power plots $3bn bid for US energy giant
fields.trailText: Utility giant Scottish Power is considering a move to bolster its American West Coast operations by swooping on Oregon's Portland General in a deal that could total $3bn (£2.17bn).
fields.body:
Utility giant Scottish Power is considering a move to bolster its American West Coast operations by swooping on Oregon's Portland General in a deal that could total $3bn (£2.17bn).

Portland's owner, Enron, last week broke off talks with US utility Sierra Pacific over a deal said to be worth $3.1bn. This opened the door to Scottish Power.

A City source said Portland, which sells power to 725,000 customers in and around the state capital of Oregon, would be a perfect fit for the Pacificorp business in the north-west US, which Scottish bought in 1999 for £4.7bn. Scottish has consistently said it wants to build up its business in the US.

PacifiCorp has some 1.5m residential, commercial and industrial customers spread over six states: Oregon, California, Washington, Wyoming, Utah and Idaho.

'Portland sits in the middle of PacifiCorp territory in Oregon,' he said. 'There would be added customers and big synergies in infrastructure, operations, and head office functions. It would make sense.'

Scottish Power's management will be quizzed about the move when it sets out its strategy in the UK and US at a results meeting this week.

There have been concerns over PacifiCorp after the shutdown of the Hunter power plant in Utah forced the company to buy in electricity at prices vastly inflated by the California power shortage. The problem cost Scottish Power £160 million in the first nine months of last year.

It would also come up against regulatory issues if it embarked on a bid. Earnings from PacifiCorp are expected to come in at around £349m before exceptionals. Peter Atherton, utilities analyst at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, said: 'I would expect Scottish Power to be looking very closely at PGE, given their stated strategy of adding to their PacifiCorp assets.'

 Analysts will also be keen on a progress report on the sale of Southern Water, valued at £1.7bn with £1bn of debt, on Thursday. They are expecting pre-tax profits to fall from £737m last year to £616m this.

webTitle: Bland set for toughest battle at BT

fields.headline: 'Bruiser' set for toughest battle at BT
fields.standfirst: Jamie Doward  talks to Sir Christopher Bland who will need his legendary toughness to turn around the ailing giant
fields.trailText: Jamie Doward talks to Sir Christopher Bland who will need his legendary toughness to turn around the ailing giant.
fields.body:
Sir Christopher Bland is talking about Happiness with a capital H. The comedy drama starring comedian Paul Whitehouse happens to be the BBC chairman's favourite programme at the moment. 'It's pretty good to watch Happiness or listen to Pick of the Week and be able to think "I'm really working".'

But such a luxury will not be afforded to Bland when he starts his new job as chairman of BT on Tuesday. Indeed, Bland may have little time for channel surfing, such is the gargantuan task awaiting him.

Everyone who has come into contact with Bland talks about his tough negotiating skills and the force of his personality. His favourite word, apparently, is robust.

His reputation for being something of a bruiser - he is an ex-Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guard and a former Olympic fencer - will stand him in good stead at BT - which, like Aunty, sometimes seems to hanker back to the halcyon days when it was a monopoly.

The telecom giant is on the ropes: a privatisation success story that has turned sour. A £30bn debt mountain has raised huge questions over BT's future and the City has been baying for management blood as the price of stumping up £5bn for a rights issue - the largest in UK corporate history.

So far the City has secured the scalp of BT managing director Bill Cockburn and the somewhat sedate defenestration of Bland's predecessor, Sir Iain Vallance, who now assumes the lofty but meaningless title of president emeritus.

Whether the Square Mile loses its blood lust depends on whether Bland can improve the beleaguered company's lot.

Many would like to see the shooting fanatic kick off his new day job with a full-scale review of the BT management board. Despite his reputation as a fixer rather than a politician Bland's riposte is a study in measured response. 'There won't be a review with a capital R, but I can't think of any organisation in which you don't look at management structure on a continuous basis. But the implication that everything is perfect would also be misleading.'

Commentators and analysts alike have lined up to call for more executive directors to be added to the company's board in a bid to help the behemoth think up some fresh ideas. Bland seems open to this.

'They've got what I would describe as a more American structure, with only two executives now. That is Peter [Bonfield, the chief executive] and Philip [Hampton, the newish finance director]. My own instinct is to see how it works and if it needs to be changed I and the board will talk about it.'

And then there are some who point out that BT's restructuring plan, announced last year and described by Bonfield as 'no less dramatic in its way than the original privatisation back in 1984', is no longer viable. The aim was to split the company into five discrete divisions, some of which would be floated off, others demerged.

But as the City has fallen out of love with the telecoms sector and values have crashed many doubt whether such a plan is feasible. When asked whether market developments had evolved, Bland breaks into a laugh and says: 'That's a very pious way of putting it. It's what Macmillan called "events dear boy, events".'

Bland hints that such a plan will need to be reviewed once he is settled at the company's Newgate Street HQ. 'That's something you keep under continuous review, but I don't start at BT until Tuesday morning. I've seen quite a lot of various board papers and a great deal of restructuring analysis has been done. I don't think any alternative hasn't been looked at in some detail. I think the way forward is coalescing and part of my job is to finalise that coalescing process.'

This seems an understated way of admitting that part of his new job will be to beat BT into shape. The over-riding criticism of the company is that it is overly bureaucratic, stupefied by a civil service mentality that means decisions take months to evolve.

Certainly Bland's reputation for cutting out the deadwood at logistics group NFC is legendary. There have obviously been similar challenges at the BBC, where the jury is still out on his performance.

Bland argues that, like Aunty, BT has in the past suffered at the hands of watchdogs. 'Dealing with regulators ad infinitum ad nauseum is something that imposes a great deal of bureaucratic process upon you, so I have some sympathy with any organisation where external forces are involved. But, like NFC, BT came out of a denationalised organisation and the quirks and behaviour patterns built up over many years. If it's bureaucratic, we should streamline and simplify.'

Some wonder whether Bland, born in 1938, has the ability to really transform the company, a task that many believe will take years, if not light years, to complete. The day his appointment was announced BT's shares slid 5%. David Manning, at fund manager Foreign & Colonial, said: 'Bland's age is a disappointment. It would have been better if they had gone for someone in their early fifties who could be there for the long term. But having anyone fresh as chairman means there will be more options possible - you should never underestimate the options that can open up.'

Indeed, Bland does seem prepared to rip up the rule book and start again. 'Part of my value as chairman is that I come with a fresh and uncluttered perspective, so there isn't anything that is unthinkable.'

But what about the critics who argue he doesn't have a telecoms' background? Bland points out this hasn't helped some of the experts. 'I would ask the critics why all the big telecom groups around the world are in what one might politely call difficulties.'

Possible clues to BT's future could lie in LWT's past. 'At London Weekend, when I became chairman, we had a travel business, a technology business, a publishing business and we got out of those pretty quickly. At NFC Gerry Murphy and I sold Pickfords, which would have been unthinkable in the old NFC because it was a great brand and was seen as the heartland of NFC.'

But BT is in a different league, a company that has lost more than two-thirds of its value in 18 months, a company that has attempted two full-blown mergers - with Cable & Wireless and US carrier MCI - only to end up having to go it alone, and a company that has seen nimbler rivals such as Vodafone eat its lunch many times over.

Given this, Bland must have had worries about leaving the BBC. OK, the £500,000 salary BT is offering, not to mention options and bonus packages, beats his £85,000 a year stipend from the BBC, but he hardly needed the money.

'The difficult thing was leaving the BBC two years before the extension to my contract was up. The other issue was that I was very clear if I was going to BT I would have to go very speedily. You either had to do it now or not at all. But if you did it now that would impose pressures on the BBC.'

And, of course, this is not something Aunty wants to worry about just before an election. The loss of Tory-supporting Bland - seen as a political counter-weight to Labour-leaning Director-General Greg Dyke - at such a crucial time rocked Westminster.

'It would suit me personally, if I had no honour, to walk out of the BBC on Monday night, but that would be totally unfair to my colleagues.' The solution is a stop-gap measure that sees Bland juggling both jobs until after the general election. 'I'm absolutely clear that this is less than ideal for both organisations, but it is bearable for a short period.'

Once the solution was given the green light from both Number 10 and William Hague, Bland decided to combine the two roles for the next few weeks. 'It is possible for short periods to work six or seven days a week. It's quite exhilarating sometimes, but you don't want to do it for ever.' Vallance might have said the same thing about BT.

fields.headline: Edinburgh granite plays Yorkshire grit
fields.trailText: While Peter Burt, James Crosby and other key executives were devoting all their energy to securing an agreement on merger terms last week, Sir John Shaw, the Bank of Scotland chairman, had to spend his time in meetings with Henry McLeish, Scotland's First Minister, the Scottish Secretary Helen Liddell and other politicians.
fields.body:
While Peter Burt, James Crosby and other key executives were devoting all their energy to securing an agreement on merger terms last week, Sir John Shaw, the Bank of Scotland chairman, had to spend his time in meetings with Henry McLeish, Scotland's First Minister, the Scottish Secretary Helen Liddell and other politicians.

This was an eloquent testament to the power of the Scottish lobby, which turns rabid at the merest whiff of lost jobs or, more important, an erosion in the corporate power base.

Crosby may not have been dragged into meetings with Yorkshire political leaders, but the issue is no less sensitive for him. His company has been in Halifax for 200 years, 100 years less than BoS has been in Edinburgh but long enough for history to count, and it is one of the city's major employers. Neither will give up their base gladly. Indeed, it could prove the main sticking point to clinching a deal.

There are plenty of suggestions for compromise. Halifax and BoS are complementary, and that could be reflected by dividing the head offices between the two places: Halifax would get retail banking, while Edinburgh would take corporate business.

There are precedents. Commercial Union and General Accident effectively paid off the Scottish lobby by making GA's Perth head office the base of its general insurance business - then easily the largest part of the group - when they merged. Abbey National has kept the head office for its life company in Glasgow, where Scottish Mutual was based before it was acquired.

In the end, however, one of the offices has to take precedence and be home to the brass plate, the boardroom and the like. Which is chosen will be crucial. 'If BoS gives that up to Halifax, we will have the Royal Bank going around boasting they took an English bank to Scotland, while BoS gave everything up,' said one shareholder. It is a prospect that will be playing heavily on Burt's mind.

Some investors suggest they should split responsibilities between the two places, but create a new head office in London, where all the bosses spend a lot of time. That idea, however, has, been dismissed.

A deal may be announced as early as next week. Scotland and Yorkshire are holding their breath.

fields.headline: Blue-blood Caz at the crossroads
fields.standfirst: The butlers and stiff upper lips stay, says  Frank Kane, but everything else will change for the UK's most illustrious stockbroker
fields.trailText: The butlers and stiff upper lips stay, says Frank Kane, but everything else will change for the UK's most illustrious stockbroker.
fields.body:
It may not seem a very radical step for a firm to put 'Group plc' after its name, but when stockbroker Cazenove does that tomorrow, it will signal the end of an era in City history and usher in a new world for the illustrious firm known as Caz.

Life behind the highly polished glass and wooden doors at 2 Tokenhouse Yard may, on the surface, carry on as usual. The butlers will still guide their clients up the oak staircase, past portraits of great Caz stockbrokers of the past. Caz executives will still have the firmest of handshakes and the stiffest of upper lips. But everything will have changed.

The decision to incorporate is the biggest gamble Caz has taken in its 177-year history. Hitherto, it has been a partnership, with all the benefits that brings: huge financial rewards, lack of public scrutiny and unity of purpose. An expert on City matters, former top financier turned author Philip Augur, summed it up: 'Cazenove was well-connected, powerful, discreet bordering on the secretive, and with an effortless style. It was gentlemanly capitalism in corporate form.'

The Caz set-up enabled the firm to sail through crises that would have ruined others. Unlike almost every other City blue-blood, Caz stayed out of the mad free-for-all of Big Bang, preferring to stay independent with the financial backing of its wealthiest City clients. Its best business-winner of the Eighties, David Mayhew, was at the heart of the Guinness affair, which destroyed many a City reputation, yet the firm stood by him. Tomorrow, he becomes chairman of the new company.

The partnership structure enabled Caz to flourish financially. In a world dominated by the 'bulge bracket' - Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley, and Goldman Sachs - Caz remains the pre-eminent UK corporate stockbroker, regu larly near the top of performance league tables. It has gained increasing business in corporate advisory work. It is involved in serious fee-taking in three of the biggest corporate shows in town: the Bank of Scotland/Halifax merger, and the restructurings of Marks & Spencer and BT.

So, the first question must be: why change a winning formula? The answer is that the game has changed. The big global investment banks that fight Caz for business on a daily basis dwarf the London firm. If the market puts a value of around $2bn on Caz when it floats 18 months from now, that still pales beside Goldman Sachs, at around $44bn, or Merrill Lynch, at $52bn.

A market listing will give it access to capital, but will also enable it to remunerate its star players with something much more tangible than the promise of a partnership in the distant future: equity. Caz will have to pay to retain the young stars who are not content to wait for their goodies, especially when - in the good times - the Americans are throwing shares around.

So incorporation represents an opportunity to drag the firm into the twenty-first century, and grow the business along orthodox investment banking lines. Organisationally, Caz now looks much like a typical US outfit: a mainstay corporate advisory business, accompanied by traditional strengths in corporate stockbroking and a relatively new research-based equities business. It also has the normal bolt-on businesses of asset management and private equity.

There are ambitious plans to continue the overseas expansion that has been a feature of recent years. But there are great risks attached to incorporation, which is why Caz executives, under joint managing directors Nigel Rowe and Robert Pickering, have planned the move so painstakingly and for so long.

The first is the pay structure after plc status. Equity will ensure a flow of bright young things into the firm, but what will keep them when the lure of partnership is removed?

Under the new accounting structure, Caz made profits of £86m on revenue of £297m in the first nine months of the current financial year. Respectable for a medium-sized merchant bank, but puny compared with the bulge bracket. Return on capital was around the sector average at an estimated 25%.

One danger is that the constant demand for equity and performance-linked bonuses will wittle away the capital base and reserves.

The other great danger is that, like any other public company, Caz will be vulnerable to takeover. That cannot happen for 18 months at least, because the shares are not tradeable in present form and will remain in the hands of a safe former partners, employees and City friends.

But Caz would be an attractive morsel for a bulge bracket firm later on. Some experts believe the new directors will avoid the trouble and expense of a public offering by selling out in the next 18 months, but this is flatly rejected by Rowe and Pickering. 'We thought of a sale last summer, of course, but decided it wasn't right for us,' they insist.

But the record of British financial institutions that have sworn by their independence is not good. Caz has bravely taken the biggest of gambles. The next 18 months will judge whether it has hit the right blend of blue-blood and bulge bracket.

webTitle: Socialite battles Saudis for Shell building

fields.headline: Socialite battles Saudis for Shell building
fields.trailText: Robert Tchenguiz, the Iraqi-born socialite, is bidding against the Saudi Royal family to buy a London landmark.
fields.body:
Robert Tchenguiz, the Iraqi-born socialite, is bidding against the Saudi Royal family to buy a London landmark.

Tchenguiz's company, Rotch Property Group, will on Wednesday table a £310m bid for Shell-Mex House, the Thirties Art Deco building overlooking the Thames next to the Savoy hotel on the Strand.

Tchenguiz, who confirmed the bid to The Observer this weekend, says his financing is already in place. This would make him favourite to buy Shell-Mex.

In the past four years, Rotch has become Britain's biggest private company, with property assets of more than £3bn. Tchenguiz's firm has in the past six months bought the City headquarters of WestLB and the Royal Bank of Scotland for £440m.

But Tchenguiz faces intense competition. Property insiders say Arabs are desperate to siphon cash out of the Middle East as the Arab-Israeli crisis escalates.

Last week, the Saudi Royal family placed 100 buildings in and around Berkeley Square in London's Mayfair under offer for £330m.

Shell-Mex, which is the headquarters of publishing group Pearson, was bought by New York tycoon Steven Witkoff 18 months ago. He stands to make £100m from the sale.

Tchenguiz, who once dated supermodel Caprice and was known to be close to the Princess of Wales, typically buys properties let long-term to blue-chip clients. He injects little of his own equity and is highly leveraged. His business model relies on property values rising in a low-interest-rate environment.

Shell-Mex, which is the headquarters of publishing group Pearson, was bought by New York tycoon Steven Witkoff 18 months ago. He stands to make £100m from the sale. Tchenguiz, who once dated supermodel Caprice and was known to be close to the Princess of Wales, typically buys properties let long-term to blue-chip clients. He injects little of his own equity and is highly leveraged. His business model relies on property values rising in a low-interest-rate environment.

webTitle: Byers braced for a hard sell

fields.headline: Byers braced for a hard sell
fields.standfirst: The DTI boss has shown he can manage crisis but he will be sorely tested in the coming weeks.  Oliver Morgan  reports
fields.trailText: The DTI boss has shown he can manage crisis but he will be sorely tested in the coming weeks. Oliver Morgan reports.
fields.body:
When Stephen Byers was parachuted into the Department of Trade and Industry on 23 December 1998 in the wake of the first Mandelson scandal, few thought he would be there by the end of Labour's first term.

Had he known what UK manufacturing would throw at him - a net loss of 254,000 jobs, the dumping of Rover and the fiasco over the Alchemy bid, the decimation of the steel industry, the continuing agony of shipbuilding and the rout in the technology sector - perhaps he would have thought twice about saying, 'OK, Tony'.

But say OK he did. And not only does he still have both hands clasped around Whitehall's notorious poisoned chalice, but if the Westminster rumour mill is to be believed, he will be promoted to the Department of Education. Talk has moved to the identity of his successor: The betting is on Transport Minister Lord MacDonald at two to one, e-commerce Minister Patricia Hewitt at threes and Geoff Hoon, the Defence Secretary, as the outside choice.

Byers has been the longest serving Trade and Industry Secretary since Michael Heseltine, who held the post for four years in the early Nineties. He has won admirers among MPs and unions for his handling of the various crises, despite concern on his appointment that, as a Blairite moderniser, he would not be union-friendly.

Even MPs from the Left have found it difficult to criticise Byers. Paul Flynn, veteran member for Newport West, whose constituents will be hard hit by Corus's decision to cut 1,300 jobs at the nearby Llanwern plant, says: 'There is a great deal of anger, but most of it is directed at the company. People feel that Byers has done his best.'

The view is shared by Michael Leahy of the ISTC steel union, who says: 'Byers has been helpful in backing our plan to mitigate the impact of these measures.' And Michael Jacobs, well connected general secretary of the Fabian Society, says: 'He had a problem with Rover last year but he has done what people expected him to do and has survived a difficult brief.'

Byers has managed not simply through graft - although there was a lot of that. He worked hard last spring to wrest Rover from Alchemy - whose plans would have led to halving production and the workforce - and encouraged the rival Phoenix consortium to step in and succeed.

He has backed an ISTC plan to provide training for Corus workers in return for a stay of execution in the hope that market conditions would improve, saving jobs.

Recently he is reported to have impressed on PricewaterhouseCoopers, receivers at beleaguered shipbuilder Cammell Laird, the need to sell the business as a going concern, allegedly going so far as to urge that Alchemy be barred from buying it.

In addition, Byers and his team of advisers have gained a reputation as arch spinners. When he extricated himself from the Rover affair, he pointedly blamed BMW for keeping him in the dark. He made clear his displeasure at Corus's 'high-handed' approach to the 6,000 job losses resulting from its restructuring. The tactic has worked but it has soured relations with some of Britain's best-known companies.

Corus chairman Sir Brian Moffat called Byers' negotiations with the unions 'blatant electioneering' and wrote to him expressing 'dismay and disappointment' in cutting Corus out of the negotiations.

Nor has the Government made friends at Cammell Laird. There was disbelief when orders for four naval ferries went to Germany last January. And officials were accused of being unhelpful over Cammell's attempts to win a $500m order for cruise ships for the new Luxus line. Yard officials said the DTI was unrealistic in demanding a $150m performance bond as a condition for underwriting part of the project.

Cammell chairman Juan Kelly said last week: 'My only comment in respect of Luxus was the lack of competence on the part of the DTI.' Frank Field, the Birkenhead MP, says Luxus was partly to blame. But he added that senior Bank of England officials told him the DTI performance bond was unworkable.

Perhaps more than any other Minister, Byers would have liked Blair to have stuck to his plans for a 3 May election. For between then and 7 June a battery of difficult industrial news is expected, generated by some of those companies that he has targeted for blame.

On 15 May the consultation period for the ISTC rescue plan ends, and this is expected to trigger massive redundancies in Wales and North-east England. Leahy of the steel union says action to disrupt production is likely. Corus may urge the Government to mediate - a tricky proposition.

Within the next month, PWC hopes to announce a preferred bidder for Cammell Laird. This may be good news, but PWC has already announced 320 job losses and if current interested parties step in, cuts and rationalisations would be likely.

Also in May, MG Rover will announce results for the final eight months of 2000, expected to be a loss of £300m. The future of Rover, and the Government's role in it, will resurface as an issue.

On top of all this comes a weekly barrage of job losses from the hi-tech companies that the Government has carefully courted. Motorola, Ericsson, Marconi and Compaq are four recent examples.

Jacobs of the Fabian Society says: 'These are the elephant traps. Any Minister who is at the mercy of events sees their reputation rise or fall on the way the last crisis plays out, particularly with an election coming.'

But while Byers has been at the mercy of some events, he has been on top of others. When Ford and Vauxhall last year announced the end of car-making at Dagenham and Luton, Byers accepted the explanation that overcapacity led to closures.

Industry observers point out that Byers's reaction in a crisis seems dictated by how well informed he is. As BMW and Corus kept him out of the loop it was important to regain the initiative through aggression. While this may amount to a media strategy, it does not solve the problem.

One policy expert close to Labour says: 'The real problem is that they have eschewed industrial strategy, and they are left with "events". Instead of picking winners, they have ended up often picking up losers.'

But even here there are inconsistencies. Some winners have been picked - the DTI appears to have been markedly less reticent about granting £500m aid to BAE Systems as part of the Airbus A380 development and for Rolls-Royce to provide engines than it was to help out Cammell Laird. Ditto aid for Rolls-Royce to provide Airbus engines.

Jacobs says Byers has been radical in other areas of policy such as the environment and work-life balance, but he believes a more interventionist industrial policy would mean a more successful DTI and less crisis management in a second term.

webTitle: Hard times in West Lothian, boom time in Flensburg

fields.headline: Hard times in West Lothian, boom time in Flensburg
fields.trailText: Ask a British shipyard worker or mobile phone producer where he is going for his summer holidays and Flensburg is unlikely to top the list. This is not just because Germany's most northerly large town lacks the charms of Lanzarote or Malaga.
fields.body:
Ask a British shipyard worker or mobile phone producer where he is going for his summer holidays and Flensburg is unlikely to top the list. This is not just because Germany's most northerly large town lacks the charms of Lanzarote or Malaga.

Flensburg has become something of a nemesis to British manufacturing. US electronics company Motorola chose to shut its profitable Bathgate factory in Scotland instead of its lossmaking German one. In January Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon announced that four roll-on roll-off ferries for the navy were to be built at the town's Shiffbau-Gesellschaft shipyard.

Flensburg (pop 88,000), has a trading history dating from the thirteenth century. Since it voted in a 1920 plebiscite to be part of Germany, it has been an important maritime site, boasting a naval station and academy since before the Second World War. Today its industries include shipbuilding, metalworking, and paper-milling, along with the more refined practices of rum and smoked eel production.

But what does Flensburg have that UK shipyards or phone plants don't? Its workforce is well paid. It enjoys exactly those social entitlements, labour laws and union influence that UK companies and business lobby groups argue would undermine British competitiveness.

But UK union officials believe the more co-operative regime helps rather than hinders inward investment. They believe the town's success owes much to its interventionist state government. Flensburg seems to be a symbol of success. But don't mention that in West Lothian.

fields.headline: Maggie Hyde's company futures
fields.trailText: There is a horrid fascination in watching a grand enterprise such as Marks and Spencer head towards its doom, like seeing an old clip of the R101.
fields.body:
There is a horrid fascination in watching a grand enterprise such as Marks and Spencer head towards its doom, like seeing an old clip of the R101. It has been in a downward spiral in the past year, capped by the fiasco of the attempted closure of its French stores and the spat over chief executive Luc Vandevelde's £800,000 bonus.

M&S is a classic Libra, right from its origins in the partnership between Michael Marks and Tom Spencer (28 September 1894). The sign of the Scales is not just about relationships. It depends on balancing divergent interests, reflected in the complementary clothing and food parts of the business. Libra has a touch of class and quality, but the M&S horoscope also shows practical Virgo, noted for its careful attention to detail.

So can M&S can recover its balance? The underlying situation is better this year than last. The 12-year growth cycle of Jupiter starts anew in August so, if there is to be any sustained turnaround, look for its first stirrings then. November brings dramatic change, when radical Uranus makes a clean sweep, and it is difficult to imagine Vandevelde hanging on after then.

The likely outcome is a merger or takeover. The odds on a new partner for Libran M&S have been shortening since February, with a remaining window of opportunity at the end of May for a deal on its own terms. Finding a good match now may be its best last chance, before it gets left on the shelf.

webTitle: Trade Minister replies to attack on Gats

fields.headline: How to break down barriers
fields.standfirst: Trade Minister  Richard Caborn  replies to Gregory Palast's attack on Gats
fields.trailText: Trade Minister Richard Caborn replies to Gregory Palast's attack on Gats.
fields.body:
I can assure you that under Gats, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Services, there are no plans to create 'an international agency with veto power over parliamentary and regulatory decisions', as reported by Gregory Palast in The Observer on 15 April.

Gats, to which Britain has been a signatory as a member of the European Union and the World Trade Organisation since it came into force in 1995, is not the end of democracy, as he suggested.

Instead it brings services within multinational trade rules, and contributes to world trade and the development of poorer countries by progressive liberalisation of trade in services.

It does this through negotiations aimed at improving market access, and contains a mandate aimed at reducing trade barriers such as measures relating to qualifications, technical standards and licensing by developing disciplines to ensure that domestic regulation does not constitute an unnecessary restriction to trade.

No national laws and regulations will be struck down, but they should not be applied in a way that is more burdensome than necessary to ensure the quality of the service. Importantly, Gats explicitly respects national policy objectives and countries' rights to maintain their existing regulations. Remember, two-thirds of the WTO members are developing nations and they hold a veto, so their interests will always be taken into account.

Discussions are at an early stage but if the WTO finds a suitable definition, without compromising the right to exercise national regulation, we believe it could be helpful to have such disciplines to discourage governments from over-regulation .This is consistent with the Government's own policy of encouraging better regulation and reducing red tape.

To correct your article's 'slip-up' on the banana dispute, the EU's decision on bananas was taken in 1997, and the complainants' case against the EU was made as much under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade as under Gats.

It never hinged on bananas being a 'service'; they are clearly goods. But the case upheld complaints that non-EU service providers in the industry were discriminated against by the EU on bananas in a way banned by Gats.

Gats is important as the volume of services in world trade is growing. The UK is the world's second-largest exporter of services, totalling £65bn in 1999.

It is important that world markets remain open and free from over-burdensome regulation. It is inconceivable that in negotiations that require unanimity, any country will give up its parliamentary or regulatory rights.

fields.headline: Watch out for: Allied Domecq
fields.trailText: Drinks group Allied Domecq is set to show a rise of around a 10% in half-year profits on Tuesday, with attention focusing on the saga of the Montana Wine bid and the firm's growth prospects.
fields.body:
Drinks group Allied Domecq is set to show a rise of around a 10% in half-year profits on Tuesday, with attention focusing on the saga of the Montana Wine bid and the firm's growth prospects.

Allied, whose brands include Ballantine's Scotch and Beefeater gin, had said in January that trading from September to the end of the year was in line with expectations.

Analysts expect pre-tax profits for the half-year to the end of February to be around £225m, compared with £204m the year before. The interim dividend is seen at around 4.2p, compared with 4.0p previously.

Analysts will be looking for Allied's view on the effects of a US slowdown on its business, as well as its sales figures for key west European and south-east Asian markets.

The UK group has been making small acquisitions around the world, after it lost out to Diageo and Pernod Ricard last December in the race for the Seagram drinks empire. Diageo is now more than twice the size of Allied, which is only just ahead of Pernod. Analysts say winning more fast-growing premium brands is central to Allied's growth prospects.

Over the past 12 months, Allied shares have outperformed the UK drinks index by 13%, the UK market by 45%, and the Dow Jones European food and beverage index by 27%.

webTitle: Kevin Danaher - Power to the people

fields.headline: Power to the people
fields.standfirst:
The May Day demonstration, like those at Seattle and Quebec, is not about smashing capitalism, but about demanding a say in the future of the planet, says the architect of a growing New Protest movement

The globalisation debate - Observer special
fields.trailText: The May Day demonstration, like those at Seattle and Quebec, is not about smashing capitalism, but about demanding a say in the future of the planet, says Kevin Danaher, the American writer and architect of a growing New Protest movement.
fields.body:
When it comes to rebellion on the streets, I must confess a prejudice. In a pitched battle between children armed with banners and spray paint against highly trained police and military personnel with a large array of deadly weapons, I tend to side with the kids.

As a child, I was taught about an instance of property destruction known as the Boston Tea Party and it made a positive impression on me.

At recent street protests in Quebec and in the late-1999 Seattle protests against the World Trade Organisation, this 50-year-old was out on the streets with the young people. I was very impressed by their analysis, their courage, their creativity and their heartfelt desire to protect other species from the human onslaught.

Why would these young people be rebellious? Maybe it's due to things such as seeing the major biological systems of the planet collapsing while an oil company cowboy in the White House pulls the US government out of the mild Kyoto Accords because it might disrupt the profits of his benefactors. Contrary to media suggestion, the youth-led movement for global economic transformation is not 'anti-globalisation'.

There are really two varieties of globalisation: élite globalisation (which we oppose) and grassroots globalisation (which we promote). The top-down globalisation is characterised by a constant drive to maximise profits for globe-spanning corporations. It forces countries to 'open up' their national economies to large corporations, reduce social services, privatise state functions, deregulate the economy, be 'efficient' and competitive, and submit everything and everyone to the rule of 'market forces'. Because markets move resources only in the direction of those with money, social inequality has reached grotesque levels.

The United Nations Development Programme reports that the richest 20 per cent of the world's people account for 86 per cent of global consumption and the poorest 80 per cent of the world's population struggle to survive on just 14 per cent of total consumption spending. This is why tens of thousands of children die needlessly every day, because resources distributed by market forces automatically bypass the poor.

But there is another kind of globalisation that centres on life values: protecting human rights and the environment. Grassroots globalisation comprises many large and growing movements: the fair trade movement, micro-enterprise lending networks, the movement for social and ecological labelling, sister cities and sister schools, citizen diplomacy, trade union solidarity across borders, worker-owned co-ops, international family farm networks, and many others.

While these constituents of grassroots globalisation lack the money and government influence possessed by the corporations, they showed at the WTO protests in Seattle that they are able to mobilise enough people to halt the corporate agenda in its tracks, at least, temporarily.

There is a big question confronting us as we enter the twenty-first century, which is: will money values dominate life values or will the life cycle dominate the money cycle? The great spiritual leaders of all cultures have been clear that the best path in life does not consist of amassing material goods. Jesus used violence only once, against a specific occupation - not Roman soldiers or tax collectors - but bankers. Paul of Tarsus said: 'The love of money is the root of all evil.' Confucius said: 'The superior person knows what is right; the inferior person knows what will sell.' Even George Soros, the billionaire financier, admits: 'Markets basically are amoral.'

Here in the United States, large sections of the public are increasingly critical of corporate rule and its consequences. A recent business magazine survey revealed that 74 per cent of the public believe big corporations have too much power, and 73 per cent believe top executives get paid too much; 95 per cent of those polled agreed with the following statement: 'US corporations should have more than one purpose. They also owe something to their workers and the communities in which they operate, and they should sometimes sacrifice some profit for the sake of making things better for their workers and communities.'

Let's be clear about the 'free market'. It is an ideological construct that does not exist in reality. All the countries that successfully industrialised did so through state intervention, with government playing an active role in directing investment, managing trade and subsidising chosen sectors of the economy.

The temple of democracy has been taken over in recent decades by the transnational money-changers. Large corporations dominate national governments and they dominate the secret global government (the World Trade Organisation, World Bank, International Monetary Fund etc) that is being constructed behind the backs of citizens. This explains why the rulers need to hide their rule-making procedures: if less than 1 per cent of the population (millionaire corporate lawyers) monopolise the rule-making process, they can't let the public know the details.

Would the policies of these global bodies be kept so secret if they were really in the public interest. Wouldn't the corporate lawyers want to debate openly with us opponents of corporate globalisation and prove their claims that we don't know what we're talking about? Yet getting these global financial bodies to debate in public is like pulling teeth.

We are now experiencing 'a constitutional moment'. Corporate interests are writing a global constitution that elevates corporate profit-making above the rights of citizens to protect their jobs and the environment. Whether the rule-making takes place in the WTO, the IMF or in planning the coming free-trade area of the Americas, the only people with a seat at the table represent transnational corporate interests.

If workers, small businesses, non-profit groups and environmentalists are not represented when the rules get written, then their interests will be subordinated to those of corporate profit-making. Look around and you will see mounting symptoms. The world economy produces more food per capita than ever before, yet we have more hungry people than ever before.

The environmental crisis is evident in eroding topsoil, poisoned ground water, melting glaciers, receding icecaps at the poles, a depleted ozone layer, the build-up of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and unsustainable patterns of resource consumption. In turn, these crises are producing a moral crisis in which the affluent avert their eyes and pretend there is no crisis.

In the cities of rich countries around the world, in Seattle, Quebec, London, protesters rage against an economy that turns every living thing into dead money. These protests are the beginning of a movement that puts love of life above love of money. If it is true that 'nature always bats last', then the world view that seeks to ride with nature will outlast the world view that seeks to dominate it and turn it into money.

fields.bodyText: When it comes to rebellion on the streets, I must confess a prejudice. In a pitched battle between children armed with banners and spray paint against highly trained police and military personnel with a large array of deadly weapons, I tend to side with the kids. As a child, I was taught about an instance of property destruction known as the Boston Tea Party and it made a positive impression on me. At recent street protests in Quebec and in the late-1999 Seattle protests against the World Trade Organisation, this 50-year-old was out on the streets with the young people. I was very impressed by their analysis, their courage, their creativity and their heartfelt desire to protect other species from the human onslaught. Why would these young people be rebellious? Maybe it's due to things such as seeing the major biological systems of the planet collapsing while an oil company cowboy in the White House pulls the US government out of the mild Kyoto Accords because it might disrupt the profits of his benefactors. Contrary to media suggestion, the youth-led movement for global economic transformation is not 'anti-globalisation'. There are really two varieties of globalisation: élite globalisation (which we oppose) and grassroots globalisation (which we promote). The top-down globalisation is characterised by a constant drive to maximise profits for globe-spanning corporations. It forces countries to 'open up' their national economies to large corporations, reduce social services, privatise state functions, deregulate the economy, be 'efficient' and competitive, and submit everything and everyone to the rule of 'market forces'. Because markets move resources only in the direction of those with money, social inequality has reached grotesque levels. The United Nations Development Programme reports that the richest 20 per cent of the world's people account for 86 per cent of global consumption and the poorest 80 per cent of the world's population struggle to survive on just 14 per cent of total consumption spending. This is why tens of thousands of children die needlessly every day, because resources distributed by market forces automatically bypass the poor. But there is another kind of globalisation that centres on life values: protecting human rights and the environment. Grassroots globalisation comprises many large and growing movements: the fair trade movement, micro-enterprise lending networks, the movement for social and ecological labelling, sister cities and sister schools, citizen diplomacy, trade union solidarity across borders, worker-owned co-ops, international family farm networks, and many others. While these constituents of grassroots globalisation lack the money and government influence possessed by the corporations, they showed at the WTO protests in Seattle that they are able to mobilise enough people to halt the corporate agenda in its tracks, at least, temporarily. There is a big question confronting us as we enter the twenty-first century, which is: will money values dominate life values or will the life cycle dominate the money cycle? The great spiritual leaders of all cultures have been clear that the best path in life does not consist of amassing material goods. Jesus used violence only once, against a specific occupation - not Roman soldiers or tax collectors - but bankers. Paul of Tarsus said: 'The love of money is the root of all evil.' Confucius said: 'The superior person knows what is right; the inferior person knows what will sell.' Even George Soros, the billionaire financier, admits: 'Markets basically are amoral.' Here in the United States, large sections of the public are increasingly critical of corporate rule and its consequences. A recent business magazine survey revealed that 74 per cent of the public believe big corporations have too much power, and 73 per cent believe top executives get paid too much; 95 per cent of those polled agreed with the following statement: 'US corporations should have more than one purpose. They also owe something to their workers and the communities in which they operate, and they should sometimes sacrifice some profit for the sake of making things better for their workers and communities.' Let's be clear about the 'free market'. It is an ideological construct that does not exist in reality. All the countries that successfully industrialised did so through state intervention, with government playing an active role in directing investment, managing trade and subsidising chosen sectors of the economy. The temple of democracy has been taken over in recent decades by the transnational money-changers. Large corporations dominate national governments and they dominate the secret global government (the World Trade Organisation, World Bank, International Monetary Fund etc) that is being constructed behind the backs of citizens. This explains why the rulers need to hide their rule-making procedures: if less than 1 per cent of the population (millionaire corporate lawyers) monopolise the rule-making process, they can't let the public know the details. Would the policies of these global bodies be kept so secret if they were really in the public interest. Wouldn't the corporate lawyers want to debate openly with us opponents of corporate globalisation and prove their claims that we don't know what we're talking about? Yet getting these global financial bodies to debate in public is like pulling teeth. We are now experiencing 'a constitutional moment'. Corporate interests are writing a global constitution that elevates corporate profit-making above the rights of citizens to protect their jobs and the environment. Whether the rule-making takes place in the WTO, the IMF or in planning the coming free-trade area of the Americas, the only people with a seat at the table represent transnational corporate interests. If workers, small businesses, non-profit groups and environmentalists are not represented when the rules get written, then their interests will be subordinated to those of corporate profit-making.
